DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 1, or the 20th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: Portugal becomes independent again after the Portuguese under the leadership of John IV drive out the Spaniards.
1887: Portugal secures the secession of Macau from China's Ching court.
1918: The Danish parliament passes an act giving independence to Iceland.
1921: With the United States and Britain as mediators, representatives of China and Japan hold negotiations on the issue of the Shantung dispute on the sidelines of a meeting in Washington.
1922: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Manchu dynasty, and Wan Yung, daughter of Yung Yuan, a former minister in the Ching court, hold their wedding ceremony in Beijing's Forbidden City.
1927: The Republic of China's Chiang Kai-shek and Soong Mayling hold a wedding ceremony witnessed by Tsai Yuan-pei in Shanghai.
1932: The government of the Republic of China, which was moved to Loyang on Jan. 30 due to the Japanese invasion, moves back to Nanjing.
1935: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the Kuomintang, the ruling party of China.
1936: Chinese Communist Party leaders, including Mao Tse-tung, Chu Teh, and Chou En-lai, send a letter to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek asking him to allow the CCP to join the war against Japan to save the country.
1951: Communist Chinese troops enter Lhasa, Tibet.
1956: Chiang Kai-shek finishes his book titled "Soviet Russia in China."
1959: Twelve members of the United Nations, including the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, Japan, and France, sign a treaty in Washington stipulating that the South Pole region will be used for peaceful purposes such as scientific exploration and that no military bases will be allowed.
1961: The first nuclear reactor in the Republic of China, installed by scientists from the National Tsinghua University campus in Hsinchu, is put into operation.
1962: India rejects mainland Chinese proposals for a cease-fire and negotiations over disputed territory.
1969: The ROC government sets up the Armed Forces University, with Yu Po-chuen serving as commandant and Chiang Wei-kuo as vice commandant.
1971: A total of 43 miners of the Keelung Coalmine Company are killed in an accident at the Chisingkeng mine in northern Taiwan.
1972: The ROC and Ivory Coast sign a trade agreement.
1973: A total of 14 seamen go missing when the Tatung, a freighter plying the route between the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung and Makung, in the Penghu archipelago, sinks.
1973: The Kuomintang selects 45 candidates for the Taipei City Council election. Sixty-three candidates fight for 49 seats.
1976: A metalworking trade mission representing leading U.S. companies arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1979: Jurisdiction of the Central Bank of China is moved from the Presidential Office to the Executive Yuan.
1987: Eight people are killed in a fire blamed on arson at a job-training center on the ROC-controlled Green Island.
1987: The Ministry of Education announces that National Chungcheng University will be established in Minhsiung Village, Chiayi County and will begin admitting students in the 1989 academic year.
1988: Benazir Bhutto is nominated to be prime minister of Pakistan, becoming the first woman elected to govern a Muslim nation.
1988: The Executive Yuan announces guidelines governing unofficial participation in international academic conferences and cultural and athletic activities held in mainland China, as well as regulations governing visits to Taiwan by overseas mainland Chinese scholars and students.
1989: Mikhail Gorbachev becomes the first Soviet leader to visit the Vatican and meet the Pope, ending 70 years of mutual hostility between the USSR and the Vatican.
1999: The first batch of the two-in-one lottery tickets issued by the Central Bank of China go on sale, causing a buying spree around the island.
2001: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) loses its position as the largest party in the legislature at the legislative election, winning only 68 seats as compared with the 87 seats won by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Motse's lesson of the day: "There are many rulers in the world but few are magnanimous. For everybody to imitate the ruler is to imitate the unmagnanimous. Imitating the unmagnanimous cannot be taken as following the right standard."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WELCOMES CHEN'S ASSURANCE OF STICKING TO PLEDGES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 30 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government welcomes any comments by President Chen Shui-bian reaffirming his pledge not to change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, a State Department spokesman said Tuesday.

"We continue to hold to them (the pledges) and we certainly welcome any comments that say he (Chen) does hold to them and he's not going to undertake any actions that would contradict them," State Department Richard Boucher said at a regular press briefing.

Boucher made the comments one day after Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General James Huang said in Taipei that President Chen has reaffirmed his commitment to maintaining the status quo across the Taiwan Strait on many occasions, and that commitment will remain in place through the rest of his term.
On Monday, Boucher had said that the United States is opposed to any referendum that would change Taiwan's status or move towards independence.
"Our primary interest is in maintaining stability across the Taiwan Strait, and the United States is opposed to any unilateral steps that would change the status quo," Boucher also said Monday.
Boucher reiterated the U.S. position after President Chen said over the weekend that he would hold a referendum on a new constitution for Taiwan in 2006.

Huang responded on Tuesday to Boucher's comments by saying that holding a referendum does not mean that President Chen's pledges made in his first inauguration speech in 2000 would be changed. In that speech, Chen pledged that he would not declare independence, not change the name of Taiwan's government, not add the state-to-state theory to the ROC Constitution, and not promote a referendum on the issue of independence versus unification.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CONFIDENT OF WINNING 25 LEGISLATIVE SEATS

TEXT.P: Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Huang Chu-wen expressed optimism Wednesday that his party will win 25 legislative seats in the Dec. 11 elections and help the "pan-green camp" gain majority control in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.
Huang said President Chen Shui-bian will be a lame duck president unless the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and TSU wins a majority of seats in the legislature.
Only by ending a disorderly legislature dominated by the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party will Taiwan continue its economic development, Huang said.

Huang said that with majority control in the legislature, the "pan-green camp" will be able to abolish what he called the unconstitutional "truth investigation commission" created by the "pan-blue alliance" to probe the March 19 shooting of President Chen.

Instead, Huang said, the "pan-green camp" will set up a new commission to investigate the truth behind the 228 Incident, the period of White Terror and the Kaohsiung Incident during KMT rule and probe the "ill-gotten" assets of the KMT.
Meanwhile, Huang said more than 150,000 people are expected to participate in a TSU-organized parade set for this Sunday in Taipei.

The parade is aimed at promoting a referendum for a new constitution, a new name for the country and U.N. membership under the name of "Taiwan" in order to make Taiwan a "normal country, " Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS

New York Times: Ridge, first secretary of U.S. security, is quitting his post
Tom Ridge, the first secretary of homeland security led the post-9/11 effort to protect the United States from a terrorist attack at home, said on Tuesday that he would leave his job no later than Feb. 1. Ridge, was the seventh member of President Bush's cabinet to announce his resignation since Election Day in a thorough reshaping of the administration. At a news conference later, he did not rule out the possibility of eventually taking another job in the administration or running for office.
Wall Street Journal: Homeland Security's Ridge joins the exodus from Bush's cabinet
As changes in President Bush's cabinet continued, Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge said he will step down as soon as a successor is found to head his department. Ridge told a news conference that he will remain in office at least until Feb. 1. While saying that he is leaving the country much safer today than before the department was created two years ago=, Ridge cautioned, however, that much work remains, particularly in improving cooperation with America's international partners in the fight against terrorism and in getting the private sector to invest more in securing vital infrastructure.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE NAB 2 SUSPECTS USING FOREIGN LABORERS' INFO TO OBTAIN CELL PHONES

TEXT.P: Police have arrested two suspects in central Taiwan who are suspected of using foreign laborers' personal information to obtain large numbers of cellular phones, the Criminal Investigation Bureau reported Monday.

Police were tipped off about one month ago that members of the crime ring often approached foreign laborers in their hangout eateries or shops, claiming that they would help the laborers remit money home or apply for cellular phones. Copies of needed documents, commonly known as "foreign laborers' cards," were then collected from the foreign laborers to apply for cellular phone numbers.
Local mobile phone operators have issued "foreign laborers' cards" with various preferential rates and simplified application measurers to attract foreign workers and thus expand their market shares.
The cellular phone numbers obtained would then be sold or end up in the hands of fraud rings or gangsters, who use them to avoid detection by police when committing criminal deeds.

In two separate raids in Changhua County and Taichung County Sunday, police were able to round up two suspects -- Lai Pei-yao, 24, and Kao Min-ho, 42, seizing more than 2,000 "foreign laborers' cards" and over 200 international phone cards in total.

Judging from the fact that between August and November this year, the crime ring had applied for 70,000 cellular phone numbers with "foreign laborers' cards", police estimated that tens of thousands of the cell phone numbers could have already been sold on the market and that many may have been sold to fraud rings or gangsters.
The police said they will now provide related information to communications operators and ask them to step up screening during the application process for cellular phones.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN JOINS ASIAN 'GREEN LANE' FOR SPEEDY IMPORT CERTIFICATION
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Charles Kang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is joining four other Asian economies in establishing a system, to be dubbed "Green Lane," which helps speed up imports of electrical and electronic products by providing quick issuance of certification documents, a Singaporean daily reported Wednesday.

Members of the Asia Network Forum (ANF) -- which groups major testing and certification bodies from Japan, Singapore, Taiwan, South Korea and mainland China -- decided Tuesday during an ANF general meeting that the "Green Lane" project will be materialized in the near future to further facilitate imports among the ANF member countries.

The Lianhe Zaobao daily reported that once the "Green Lane" project is established and takes effect, imports of electrical and electronics products, such as DVD players, will take only 10 days to move from the factory into the country of destination, instead of the current 45 days.

The ANF member countries have agreed to exchange among themselves issuance and recognition of product certification. The certificates that are issued by ANF member countries will save time in the border-crossing process, said Henry Heng, CEO of Singapore's PSB Group, which is one of the five organizations of the ANF.

Taking Singapore as an example, Heng said, Singapore exported some S$6 billion worth of electrical and electronics products to the other four ANF member countries over the past two years via a fast channel, which features mainly product and export certificates that were issued by the ANF and recognized by other ANF member countries.

The ANF was established five years ago in Singapore to provide speedy product safety testing and inspection services using advanced technology for a range of products, including chemical and materials, electrical and electronics, as well as mechanical and building.

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market moved down Wednesday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December dropping 39 points to end at 5,770, with 32,051 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January lost 20 points to finish at 5,790, with 215 contracts traded, while March futures slid 22 points to close at 5,770, with 11 contracts traded. June futures went down 11 points to close at 5,769, with 10 contracts traded, and September futures dropped 25 points to finish at 5,700, with six contracts changing hands.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,809 for December, 5,810 for January, 5,792 for March, 5,780 for June and 5,725 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, ended mixed.

No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 46.14 points to close at 5,798.62.
The bourse opened at 5,778.06 and fluctuated between 5,815.87 and 5,745.05 during trading. A total of 2.56 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$52.89 billion (US$1.64 billion).
Textile issues was the only one of the eight major stock categories in the market that gained ground, with a rise of 1.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT THINKS BEIJING TRYING TO INFLUENCE ELECTIONS: AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has kept abreast of reports that mainland China is trying to influence the Dec. 11 legislative elections, his top aide said Wednesday.

Su Tseng-chang, secretary-general to the president, made the remarks when he attended a press conference to drum up support for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidates at Taipei 101, the tallest skyscraper in the world.

Su was referring to Chen's remarks the previous day while on the campaign trail for DPP candidates in Keelung, in which he said Taiwan businessmen in Shanghai recently hosted a big banquet to drum up support for the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) that was attended by Kuo Su-chun and Huang Liang-hua -- who are KMT at-large legislative candidates -- with Chinese policemen standing guard outside the restaurant. "The Communist Party of China supports the KMT, the Taiwanese must support the DPP," the president claimed.
Noting that while DPP officials cannot go to mainland China but the KMT has gone out of its way to solicit votes there, Su questioned how much Beijing is trying to influence Taiwan's elections.
Kuo said Wednesday that she only accompanied her husband, Hung Hsi-yao, to the mainland to attend a gathering of Taiwan businessmen there.

She noted that Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland are also Taiwanese and have the same right to choose their favored legislative candidate. As an at-large candidate, she said she sees nothing wrong with inviting Taiwan businessmen to return to support KMT candidates.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou also urged President Chen not to "randomly label" anyone as being in league with the communists.

He said the president should not forget that he is the embodiment of national unity, and not the source of a split, and urged him to pay more attention of the woes of the public, such as the diminished income of farmers and the 120,000 school children who cannot afford to pay for lunch at school.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-MEMBERS OF MAYOR MA'S ADMINISTRATION RUNNING FOR LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: A group of five former officials of Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's administration teamed up Wednesday to promote their bids to win seats in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Lin Cheng-hsiu, former director of the city government's Department of Civil Affairs; Kung Wen-chi, former chairman of the Indigenous Peoples Commission; Wu Yu-sheng, former director of the Department of Information; Lai Shyh-bao, former vice chairman of the Economic Development Commission; and Su Ying-kuei, a sitting legislator and former deputy convener of Taipei's human rights advisory panel, said their professional backgrounds will make them a strong backup for the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party and enhance the checks and balances in the government.

However, they denied their entry to the legislature was aimed at paving the way for a bid by Mayor Ma to run for the 2008 presidency, saying they are joining forces in the election campaign because they share a similar philosophy.
Political analysts said that Ma and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng are two of the most likely KMT candidates for the 2008 presidency.

However, unless the "pan-blue alliance" continues its majority control in the legislature after the Dec. 11 elections, Wang will lose his speakership of the legislature, which will diminish his leverage in the KMT, according to the analysts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA-FLAGGED GRAVEL SHIP SINKS OFF TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: A Panama-flagged gravel ship sank off Taichung, central Taiwan, in inclement weather Tuesday, leaving four of its crew members missing with seven others rescued, Coast Guard Administration (CGA) authorities said Wednesday.

The seven rescued mainland Chinese crew members were taken to Taichung City by coast guard officers, while the four missing crewmen, also from mainland China, are feared drowned, although the coast guard is continuing its search, CGA officials said.
According to CGA authorities, the 1,745-ton gravel ship signaled an SOS before noon Tuesday when it sprang a leak as it was about 40 nautical miles off Taichung.
The ship was on its way to the southern port city of Kaohsiung from Hong Kong, transporting sand and gravel.

Two CGA patrol frigates arrived in the location of the stricken vessel at around 1: 30 p.m. and the gravel ship's captain later contacted the ship's Taiwan agent, which in turn sent a tugboat to the scene. While the tug was preparing to tow the cargo ship that evening, however, the cargo ship suffered a sudden water intake and sank immediately at around 10 p.m., CGA officials said.
All the crewmen jumped overboard when the ship began to sink.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANCER-AFFLICTED DOCTOR RUNS MARATHON TO `KILL FEAR'

TEXT.P: A surgeon suffering from leukemia who calls himself Jet has signed up to run in the 2004 ING Taipei International Marathon slated to kick off Dec. 19, because "running can drive away his fears."
Jet will be the first cancer-stricken doctor to take part in any international marathon held in Taiwan.
Jet said during an interview with the Central News Agency that he has been treasured every day of his life for the last six years since his doctors confirmed their diagnosis.
Fear of death is constantly with him, Jet admitted, even though he is a professional medical man who is supposed to know the disease better than the average layman.
His fear continues to prevail, despite his seeking religious comfort and despite his leading a much healthier life, including eating more greens and getting more sleep, Jet said.
After trying many different ways to kill this fear, Jet said, he has found that nothing beats running to make him feel relaxed.
Over the past several years, Jet said, he has become addicted to running and can easily dash from Renai Road up to Yangmingshan "before he knows it."
Running from Shihlin all the way to coastal Chinshan by traversing the mountainous Yangmingshan is a piece of cake, a relaxed Jet said.
A "Taiwan Forrest Gump" or not, Jet said he finds peace whenever he runs.
He has been receiving treatment for his leukemia since the first year of diagnosis and has shown no symptoms for the last five years.
Running is probably another kind of treatment, he claimed.
He has also just published his first book, titled "Challenges and Gains in Cancer" to share his experiences and mental outlook as a cancer patient.

The 2004 ING Taipei International Marathon offers a NT$1 million cash prize for the top overall finishers if the runners run the standard 42.195 km marathon and break the Taiwan records -- 2: 14 for males and 2:35 for females, according to sponsors.
Other race events include a half-marathon (21 km), a nine-km race and a three-km race, the sponsors said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING PARTY HAS HIGHEST EXPECTATIONS OF ITSELF: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun has instructed that an ongoing crackdown on vote-buying will target all political parties, especially the Democratic Progressive Party, because as the ruling party, it has to be subjected to a higher standard of inspection, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Wednesday.

Chen Chi-mai quoted the premier as noting that the upcoming legislative elections are significant as they are the first national elections since the March 20 presidential election, and he urged all legislative candidates and voters to abide by the law in campaigning activities.
The premier has asked the Central Election Commission (CEC) and local election commissions to carry out their duties faithfully so that the election results can be passed on quickly and correctly.
He also asked the Ministry of Justice to step up a crackdown on violence and graft during the 10-day official campaign period that kicked off Wednesday before the Dec. 11 election day.

Yu urged political parties, candidates and third parties to follow the regulations and not to run radio or TV ads. He warned that the CEC and the Government Information Office (GIO) will deal with violators according to the law.

In addition, the premier wants the GIO and the Mainland Affairs Council to compile information concerning mainland China's and the international community's reactions to the elections and to analyze the information.
Meanwhile, anti-graft teams comprised of prosecutors, police and investigators began to station themselves in police stations around the nation.
Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan, while unveiling an anti-graft team plaque at a Taipei city police station, reaffirmed the government's determination to crack down on graft to ensure a clean election.

Chen said that the team will act swiftly on any violations in the elections. He noted that as the elections enter their final stage, graft cases will become even more rampant judging from past experience, and he warned candidates and their supporters not to challenge the law.

He also urged the public to pitch in to help contain corruption, saying that the ministry has appropriated cash rewards for information leading to the arrest of corrupt officials, saying that the minimum reward will amount to NT$500,000 (US$15,520).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INTENDS NO CHANGE IN CROSS-STRAIT STATUS QUO: CABINET AIDE

TEXT.P: Taiwan has no intention of changing the status quo across the Taiwan Strait in terms of its relations with mainland China, Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Wednesday.
Chen made the remarks in the wake of a weekly Executive Yuan meeting in response to fresh concerns from the United States in this regard.

Chen stressed that President Chen Shui-bian's recent promise to put forth a suitable constitution for Taiwan by 2006 will not touch on sensitive issues and he reiterated that the president does not have the slightest intention of making any change to the country's official title or traditional territory that is designated in the existing Constitution.

According to Chen, the president will remain firm to his "four noes plus one" pledge revealed in his May 2000 inauguration speech and to his vow made in this year's Oct. 10 National Day address to stay away from issues linked to the independence vs unification dispute while pushing for an adequate constitution for the nation.

Richard Boucher, spokesman for the U.S. State Department, told a news conference a day earlier in Washington, D.C. that "we continue to hold to them (the pledges) and we certainly welcome any comments that say he (Chen) will hold to them and that he is not going to undertake any actions that would contradict them."

Boucher also said that the United States opposes holding any referendum that would alter Taiwan's status quo or take it on the path toward independence. "Our primary interest is in maintaining stability across the Taiwan Strait, and the United States is opposed to any unilateral steps that would change the status quo, " he repeated.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI LAWMAKERS VISIT TAIWAN PRISON TO PUSH FOR PRISONER EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: A Thai National Assembly delegation visited a Taiwan prison Wednesday to study the feasibility of bilateral exchanges of prisoners.

The seven-member delegation, which arrived in Taipei earlier in the day, is headed by Sukhum Laowansiri, a member of the Thai National Assembly and an adviser to the Thai prime minister. Among the delegation members is Pichan Piboonwattanawong, vice chairman of the Thai National Assembly's Human Rights Commission.

The Thai lawmakers held face-to-face talks with the 29 Thai convicts who are serving their terms in a prison on the outskirts of Taipei to inquire about their willingness to return home to serve out the remainder of their time in Thai prisons.
It marked the first time Thai lawmakers have visited Thai inmates in Taiwan.

During the 40-minute meeting, the lawmakers talked with the inmates in their native tongue and the inmates were reported as being moved by the visit of parliamentarians from their homeland, saying they have few opportunities to speak their mother tongue in prison.

More than 70 percent of the Thai prisoners said they are willing to return home to serve their terms, while some others said they will make a decision after they gain a better understanding of the prison term commutation formula.

For years, local human rights activists and families of Taiwan nationals serving time in Thai prisons have been pushing for the two countries to exchange prisoners, but their appeals have been hindered by the absence of formal diplomatic ties between Taiwan and Thailand.

Thanks to strenuous efforts by a Taiwan-Thai cultural exchange promotional group, the Thai parliament finally decided to send a fact-finding delegation to Taiwan to study the feasibility of exchanging prisoners.
The lawmakers will also travel to Taichung in central Taiwan to visit Thai prisoners incarcerated there before returning to Thailand.

Laowansiri said his mission will push the Thai parliament to discuss relevant issues and draft law revisions to pave the way for an early realization of the long-talked-about exchanges of prisoners with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL NOT BE MARGINALIZED BY CHINA-ASEAN FTA: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not be marginalized by the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) between mainland China and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) , an official of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) claimed Wednesday.

Yeh Ming-feng, vice chairman of the nation's top economic planning agency, made the remarks in the wake of the signing of the accord Monday between the mainland and the 10-member ASEAN during an ASEAN summit meeting in Laos, with the aim of creating the world's largest free trade area by 2010, a sprawling market of 1.8 billion people.
Yeh noted that the mainland is trying to marginalize Taiwan, but said that "with Taiwan's robust economic strength, it will not be marginalized."

It is estimated that the mainland's trade with ASEAN totaled US$78.2 billion in 2003, up 42.8 percent from 2002. In the first nine months of this year, bilateral trade reached US$75.453 billion. Judging from this trend, bilateral trade between the mainland and ASEAN could reach US$100 billion in 2004, said Yeh.

Asked about possible adverse effects on Taiwan's economic development with the closer economic ties between the mainland and ASEAN, Yeh said Taiwan ranks between 15th and 17th in world trade, showing its strong economic might.
"Taiwan will not be absent from the international stage, " he stressed.

Contradicting Yeh's claims, however, Kung Ming-hsin, an official of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, a think tank, said that under the "ASEAN plus one," Southeast Asia's exports of raw materials and machinery equipment to the mainland will increase, which will be detrimental to Taiwan.

He suggested that Taiwan step up relations with Southeast Asian countries, but at the same time target the United States and Japan for the signing of FTAs in the mid- and long-term, adding that although progress in this respect is slow, Taiwan still needs to make the effort.

An even bigger threat, he noted, will be "ASEAN plus three, " meaning cooperation between ASEAN, the mainland, Japan and South Korea, which he said will have even greater impact on Taiwan, so that the island must go on high alert in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PAPAYA ALLOWED TO ENTER JAPAN AFTER 8-YEAR TALKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan can finally export papayas to Japan after eight-year negotiations with Japanese authorities, according to a statement released Wednesday by the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine (BAPHIQ) under the Council of Agriculture (COA).

The statement said that the BAPHIQ received an official announcement that day from Japan's Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (MAFF) allowing Taiwan papayas to be shipped into Japanese markets as long as they have been through an officially approved quarantine and anti-pest procedure and have passed official tests conducted by both Taiwanese and Japanese quarantine experts.

BAPHIQ officials indicated that their researchers developed years ago a steaming method that has proved capable of wiping out all fruit flies that live on papayas, especially the new Tainung No. 2 strain of papaya developed by COA experts.
The bureau filed an application with the MAFF for certification of the method and export permission in 1997, the officials noted.
After years of on-site inspections and report reviewing, the MAFF passed the Tainung No. 2 papayas fit for import at a public hearing in October and filed the official announcement Wednesday.

The officials added that in addition to papayas, the BAPHIQ has also filed testing reports on the quarantine and anti-pest procedures for start fruit, cantaloupe and night-blooming gereus, while making efforts to develop effective quarantine technology for other local fruit such as guava and bell fruit in the hope of opening overseas markets for these products.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY CONTINUES TO DEVELOP POSITIVELY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Wednesday that the economy and competitiveness of Taiwan are both developing in a positive direction, in the wake of reports that the Standard and Poor's Ratings Services (S&P) has revised its outlook on Taiwan to negative from stable.
Yu pointed out that Taiwan's economic growth is rising and its unemployment rate is falling, while its rankings in terms of global competitiveness have also improved significantly.

Taiwan advanced one place to become the world's fourth-most-competitive economy this year, according to the latest Global Competitiveness Report released by the World Economic Forum, and has jumped from 17th place last year to 12th this year in another assessment conducted by the International Institute for Management Development, he noted.
S&P revised its outlook as a result of rising cross-Taiwan Strait tension and the island's weak fiscal flexibility owing to high fiscal deficit and a growing government debt burden.

However, Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said the government has carried out a series of fiscal and financial reforms over the past three years and has successfully improved the financial environment in Taiwan.

Also, President Chen Shui-bian has shown goodwill on many occasions to try to improve relations between Taiwan and mainland China and has proposed that both sides start negotiations on the launch of cross-strait passenger and charter flight services, Chen Chi-mai said.

According to Thomas M.F. Yeh, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, debts payable by the central government accounted for 32.2 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP) as of the end of September, which is lower than the 35.6 percent of the United States, the 107.7 percent of Japan and the 100.7 percent of Singapore.
The ratio was 36.6 percent of GDP after taking into account the debts of local governments, which is still lower than the 62.8 percent of the United States and the 157.3 percent of Japan, Yeh said.
Government deficits amount to NT$247.8 billion (US$7.7 billion) this year, compared with NT$300 billion last year, Yeh added.
On the financial reforms in Taiwan, Yeh pointed out that the ratio of non-performing loans of domestic banks fell to 3.32 percent in October this year from a high of 8.4 percent in 2002.

In an effort to reduce the number of financial institutions in Taiwan, the government has worked out a timetable that aims to raise the combined market share of the three largest financial institutions to above 10 percent and to lessen the number of government-owned financial institutions to six by the end of 2005, Yeh went on.
It is the government's goal to cut the number of financial holding companies from 14 to seven by the end of 2006, he said.
In addition, he added, domestic investment as a percentage of GDP is expected to rise to 20 percent this year, when economic growth is likely to reach 5.9 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: SICK BLACK-FACED SPOONBILL BEING TREATED

TEXT.P: A black-faced spoonbill wintering in a wetland area in southern Taiwan was found unable to stand, captured and sent for immediate treatment, Tainan county officials said Wednesday.

Tainan County Animal Disease Prevention Center officials said it was the second of the rare birds to be brought in for treatment and initially diagnosed that the bird might have been infected by microbes and that its condition is not life-threatening.
The center was conducting various tests on the bird in order to make a positive diagnosis.
The officials said the first black-faced spoonbill was captured Tuesday morning and that the bird was recovering well following treatment.

Each year, the endangered birds arrive at the wetlands located at the estuary of the Tsengwen River in Tainan County to spend the winter before heading back north to their breeding grounds between March and April the following year. A total of 727 of the rare migratory birds had arrived as of last week.

During the winter of 2002-2003, 71 black-faced spoonbills died of botulism poisoning after eating contaminated food in the wetlands, and county officials have since conducted regular checks and tests on the wetlands to protect the birds.
According to a global survey conducted in January of this year, only 1,206 black-faced spoonbills remain in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL POWER FORUM AND EXHIBITION OPENS

TEXT.P: The 2004 Taipei International Power Forum and Exhibition opened Wednesday at the Taipei World Trade Center, with Taiwan's newest technologies and equipment related to energy conservation and application on display.

Speaking at the opening of the show, National Science Council Chairman Wu Mao-kun said that the theme of energy effectiveness, diversification and conservation are key world trends and the most important issues in the wake of the Kyoto Protocol, signed in October by most developed countries to reduce emission of greenhouse gases.

A total of 46 Taiwan companies and more than 60 experts from Austria, Britain, Canada, Germany, Japan, mainland China and South Korea are taking part in the three-day activities, organized jointly by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , the Taiwan Solar Industrial Association, the Taiwan Battery Association and the Taiwan Electric Scooter Industry Development Association.

Specialists will hold 61 forums on the development of the most advanced technologies on batteries, solar energy and electric vehicles, while companies will launch six rounds of new product presentations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MEDICAL PROFESSIONALS TOP 180,000 IN 2003

TEXT.P: There were 183,000 medical professionals in Taiwan by the end of 2003, an average of 81 per 10,000 people, the Directorate Generate of the Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Wednesday.
The figure represented an increase of 39,000 from 1998, DGBAS officials said.
Regarding the national health insurance system, the DGBAS said that 78.4 percent of children use the service, compared with 19.5 percent of adults aged 40-64, and 40.3 percent for those over 65.
Beds in medical institutions totaled 136,000 in 2003, up 12,000 from 1998, or an average of 60.3 beds per 10,000 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, UTAH SIGN COOPERATION AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh signed a cooperation agreement with Utah State Governor Olene Walker Wednesday.

Under the agreement, exchanges between the two sides will cover such areas as business, tourism, education and culture. Arrangements will also be made for exchanges of visits between manufacturers and trade delegations from both sides as well as the participation of various trade exhibitions.
In addition, both sides will assign a representative for close cooperation and they will monitor and assess the progress and results of various cooperation projects.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs said that Utah exports to Taiwan totaled US$62.78 million last year, mainly computer and electronic products, foods, minerals and asphaltic products. Over a score of Taiwan manufacturers are investing in Utah, mainly in computer, biochemistry, printing and real estate businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO CHIEF TO UNVEIL NEW VISION FOR TAIWAN FILMS

TEXT.P: Lin Chia-lung, director-general of the Government Information Office (GIO), will unveil a plan to boost the local film industry on the eve of the Golden Horse Film Festival Thursday, according to a GIO official.

The plan was worked out by a committee formed to promote the flagging film industry. Representatives of the film industry and dignities involved with the Golden House Film Festival, will be invited to attend Wednesday's news conference, said the official.
Under the plan, the film industry will be redefined to include DVDs and the industry will be given more assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE-AMERICAN THANKS OMBUDSMAN FOR HELPING HIM STAY IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An American citizen with a Taiwanese mother thanked Control Yuan member Liao Chien-nan Wednesday for helping him obtain residency in Taiwan after he had overstayed his alien resident certificate by eight years.
George Laverne Jennings presented flowers to Liao as a token of gratitude when Liao was making an inspection tour of the Taichung County Government in central Taiwan.

The 28-year-old man was born in Colorado in 1976 to an American father and a Taiwanese mother. His mother took him back to Taiwan after his father died in 1984. He has since lived in Tantzu township, Taichung County with his mother.

His alien resident certificate expired eight years ago, but he never realized the legal problems concerning his status until he went to see a doctor early this year and came to learn that he was not covered by the national health insurance program.
According to Taiwan's immigration law, he was supposed to be deported and banned from entering Taiwan again for a period of eight years.

After his case was brought to public attention with the assistance of Taichung County Councilor Lin Chu-wang, the Control Yuan set up a special panel to coordinate authorities to overcome the legal restrictions.
Jennings was issued a resident visa on Nov. 16 as a student at a language center at Feng Chia University.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CALLS FOR TAIWAN-U.S. MUTUAL TRUST

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday he looks forward to the day that Taiwan and the United States can trust each other without suspicions.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with Olene Walker, governor of Utah, who is currently visiting Taipei.

The president took advantage of the meeting to express his gratitude for a positive response from the U.S. State Department to his reaffirmation a day earlier regarding his commitment to upholding his "four noes" pledge while formulating a new constitution and policy toward relations across the Taiwan Strait.
"I'm grateful for the United States' positive response to my reaffirmation and I earnestly hope that our two countries can become closer without any mistrust," Chen told his guest.
He stressed that Taiwan's proposed new constitution would be formulated in line with Taiwan's constitutional system and would not contradict his previous commitments on cross-strait issues.
Under Taiwan's constitution-amending procedures, Chen said, the new constitution draft requires the consent of three-fourths of legislators before it is put to a nationwide referendum.

Even if the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) manages to win a simple majority in the new Legislature Yuan to be elected Dec. 11, Chen said it is unlikely the "pan-green" camp will control three-fourths of the 225 legislative seats.

"Against this backdrop, the opposition camp, with more than one-fourth of the legislative seats, will be able to play a check-and-balance role in writing our new constitution and thus help ensure steady proceedings in our constitutional re-engineering work," Chen explained.

The president further said his new constitution proposal would not violate his previous commitments on cross-strait relations, including the "four noes" pledge articulated in his May 2000 inaugural address, which he reaffirmed in his second inaugural address.
"The commitments on constitutional reform and cross-strait relations that I have promised remain unchanged, and there will be absolutely no change through the rest of my term in office, " Chen said.
He reiterated that pursuing permanent peaceful development on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and completing normalization of cross-strait relations are the top mission of his second term.

"I sincerely hope the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can resume dialogue on the foundation of their 1992 Hong Kong talks," Chen said, adding he believes that the next two years are crucial for the development of cross-strait ties.
At a campaign rally last weekend, Chen vowed to hold a referendum in 2006 on a new constitution for implementation from May 20, 2008.

Asked whether Chen's push for a new constitution violated his earlier commitments on preserving the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, U.S. State Department Richard Boucher said Monday that the Taiwan leader's earlier "pledges were very, very important, and they need to be respected."
"As far as whether any other ideas or proposals contradict that or not, I think he'll have to explain," Boucher said.
On Tuesday, Chen took advantage of his meeting with a visiting U.S. congressional delegation headed by Rep. John Culberson (R-Texas) to reaffirm that had not wavered in his previous commitments.

Asked about the U.S. views on Chen's reaffirmation during a daily press briefing in Washington, D.C. later that day, Boucher said: "We saw the statement...and we certainly welcome any comments that say he does hold to them [Chen's pledges] and he's not going to undertake any actions that would contradict them."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR HAS HIGH EXPECTATIONS FOR KAOHSIUNG FREE TRADE PORT ZONE

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Harbor will become more competitive after the first of next year when it becomes a free trade port zone, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh said Wednesday.
Hsieh made the remarks during a meeting with Singapore's representative stationed in Taipei, Ker Sin Tze.

Given that the Kaohsiung free trade port zone is slated to begin operations on Jan. 1, 2005, Hsieh expressed the hope that the nearby Chienchen economic processing zone would be included in the free trade zone to further enhance the harbor's competitive edge.

In response to Ker's question of opening direct trade, transport and postal links between Taiwan and mainland China, Hsieh claimed that with the entry of the free trade zone, Kaohsiung Harbor will be able to serve as a transshipment center between the two sides before the full three links are set up.

Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan and Keelung Harbor in northern Taiwan are the country's first two ports authorized by the central government to operate as free trade port zones. Keelung Harbor -- Taiwan's second-largest port -- began free trade operations in September.
Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau officials have predicted that Kaohsiung port -- Taiwan's largest -- will be more lucrative after its free trade zone becomes operational.

Shipping companies using the Kaohsiung Free Trade Port Zone, where goods, personnel and capital are allowed to move freely, will see their operating costs and tax rates go down and enjoy a quicker customs clearance process, they said.

They estimated that more than NT$60 million (US$1.8 million) in administrative costs can be saved each year and that an additional 5 million tons of cargo can be handled by the Kaohsiung Harbor, increasing business worth over NT$150 million and creating more than 400 jobs.

They also forecast that the Keelung and Kaohsiung harbors together will be able to court an additional combined investment of about NT$4.56 billion (US$137 million) and create at least 900 job opportunities after kicking off their free trade operations.

Taichung Harbor in central Taiwan and various economic processing zones and industrial zones across the country are still waiting for the final government approval to set up free trade port zones, a major drive launched by Taiwan to make it a business operations hub in the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-U.S. TIFA TALKS END WITH CONSENSUS ON KEY TRADE ISSUES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 30 (CNA) (By Winnie Chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A sub-Cabinet-level meeting under the the Taiwan-U.S. Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) concluded Tuesday with both sides reaching consensus on four major trade issues.

ROC Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long, head of the Taiwan delegation, said the two-day meeting was a success as both sides had reached consensus on intellectual property rights (IPR) protection, the opening of the telecommunications market, agricultural trade and revisions to Taiwan's pharmaceutical law.

Chen said the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) Office has agreed to consider Taiwan's request to remove its name from America's Special 301 "priority watch list" for intensified IPR violations monitoring.
As to Taiwan's expectation of signing a bilateral free trade agreement (FTA) , Chen said the USTR has come to a better understanding of Taiwan's desires.
"It requires our long-term efforts. The possibility of signing a Taiwan-U.S. free trade pact is not nil, " Chen said, adding that TIFA is a stepping-stone to a Taiwan-U.S. free trade agreement.

The TIFA trade consultation is the highest-level official Taiwan-U.S. economic meeting. The just-concluded meeting is the first of its kind in six years. The United States suspended TIFA consultations in 1998 due to its discontent with Taiwan's allegedly sloppy IPR enforcement. With tremendous progress in Taiwan's crackdown on commercial piracy, the U.S. government finally agreed to resume TIFA talks this year.
The U.S. delegation to the just-ended meeting at the USTR office in Washington, D.C. was headed by Deputy U.S. Trade Representative Josette Sheeran Shiner.

During the meeting that began Monday, Chen said Taiwan agreed to adopt a national quota system instead of the existing global quota system from next year for rice imports. Under the new quota system, Taiwan's rice market will open wider to foreign-grown rice.
In response to the U.S. request for further liberalization of Taiwan's telecommunications market, Chen said Taiwan already opened its fixed-line network market in September.

As to the U.S. request for patent rights to pharmaceutical data and other market liberalization measures, Chen said relevant government agencies will come up with draft revisions to existing laws for legislative approval in line with the U.S. suggestions.
Meanwhile, Chen said the two sides agreed to hold a teleconference in December to decide whether Taiwan's processed poultry meat can be allowed to enter the U.S. market.

In return, Chen said, Taiwan will decide whether to re-open its market to U.S. beef after an expert team that has recently completed a field study in the United States comes up with an inspection report before the end of December.

The Taiwan delegation to the TIFA meeting was composed of officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Council of Agriculture, the Directorate General of Telecommunications, the Bureau of National Health Insurance Bureau, the Board of Foreign Trade and the nation's representative office in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO SARS QUESTIONNAIRES FOR INBOUND AIR TRAVELERS: HEALTH DEPARTMENT

TEXT.P: Inbound passengers at Taiwan's international airports will no longer have to fill out a questionnaire on severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), a spokesman for the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) said Wednesday.

Shih Wen-i, deputy director-general of the health department's Center for Disease Control (CDC) , said that the measure will be stopped immediately, but the requirement of having temperatures taken will be maintained. But he added that arriving passengers with fever, vomiting or diarrhea -- common symptoms of some epidemic diseases including SARS -- will still be required to fill out the questionnaire.
The CDC decided to lift the measure on the grounds that a very small number of SARS cases were screened out of passengers' questionnaires since the practice began in March last year, Shih said.

However, he pointed out that potential SARS- and communicable disease- infected passengers will be fined from NT$3,000 to NT$15,000 (US$450) , if they are found to have not handed over their questionnaires. He called for continued cooperation from the public to prevent a reoccurrence of SARS in the winter peak seasons of flu and other maladies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, SOUTH KOREA RESUME REGULAR COMMERCIAL FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Regular commercial flights between Taiwan and South Korea were resumed Wednesday after a 12-year hiatus due mainly to political reasons.

The two Taiwan carriers assigned to fly the Taipei-Seoul route -- China Airlines and EVA Airways -- didn't hold special celebration activities. The passenger occupancy rates of their first regular Taipei-Seoul flights in 12 years reached an average of 80 percent.

According to a route allocation agreement reached last month among six Taiwan carriers interested in operating Taiwan-South Korean flight services, the Taipei-Seoul route was assigned to China Airlines and EVA Airways, and the Kaohsiung-Seoul line was designated to UNI Airways and Mandarin Airlines.

The Taipei-Jeju line was designated to Far East Air Transport and TransAsia Airways, the Kaohsiung-Jeju line was appointed to UNI Airways and Far East Air Transport. The Taipei-Busan line was designated to TransAsia Airways and UNI Airways.

On the South Korean side, Korean Air and Asiana Airlines will initially provide seven weekly flights connecting Seoul with Taipei. Some South Korean media executives traveled to Taipei aboard the two Korean ailines' first flights to Taipei Wednesday. A representative of the Incheon International Airport also arrived in Taipei aboard the Korean Air flight to promote bilateral exchanges.

Taiwan and South Korea struck an aviation agreement Sept. 1 authorizing the formal resumption of air links between both sides after the links had been broken off in 1992 when Seoul switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTOR INDICTS CANDIDATE IN DEFIANCE OF SUPERIOR'S CONCERNS

TEXT.P: A maverick prosecutor who made headlines in January by questioning President Chen Shui-bian in his investigation into an alleged vote-buying case was thrust into the limelight again Wednesday by returning a vote-buying indictment without the approval of his superior at the Hualien District Prosecutors' Office.

At a hastily called news conference, Chang Hsao-ping, a spokesman for the Hualien District Prosecutors' Office said the indictment from prosecutor Lee Tzu-chun against You Ying-lung, the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) failed candidate in the 2003 by-election for magistrate in Hualien County, is invalid because it had not been approved by the Public Prosecutor General Kuo Wen-tung and, therefore, did not have the office's seal.
Chang said Kuo had asked Lee to reinforce his legal grounds for prosecuting You but was refused by Lee who made public his indictment anyway.
Chang said Kuo has ordered Lee to transfer the case to another prosecutor.

However, Lee said that the indictment has been completed and should have gone into force as it was sent by mail to the Hualien District Court on Monday. He didn't know what else Kuo wanted him to hand over to other prosecutors.
Kuo's approval is only an administrative process which would not affect the legal effect of his indictment against You, Lee went on.

Lee said he didn't agreed with Kuo's view that the treatment of similar cases in Japan should be taken into account before handling the case, because foreign legal precedents are not binding on domestic cases.
Meanwhile, a spokesman for the Hualien District Court confirmed that his court has received Lee's indictment but has not yet assigned it to any judges.
As to the validity of the indictment, a spokesman, Lai Chun-liang, said the judges assigned to hear the case will be decided by themselves whether the indictment is valid or not.
You was investigated for promising during his campaign to give subsidies to chiefs of aborigines in Hualien County, which is populated mainly by aborigines.
As a candidate of the ruling DPP, You claimed that his promise was backed by his party and DPP Chairman Chen Shui-bian, who is also the head of state.
It was for that reason that the prosecutor subpoenaed the president for questioning on Jan. 14 and caused an uproar.

For the president, it was all grist to the mill. Instead of avoiding the probe by invoking his constitutional immunity from any judicial pursuit, he appeared at the prosecutor's office on time and answered Lee's questions in a cooperative spirits.
You was angry Wednesday after learning that he was charged by Lee for vote-buying, claiming that the indictment has violated his constitutional freedom of speech.
He dismissed the indictment as politically motivated and he claimed this was evident from the prosecutor's decision to subpoena the president three months before the 2004 presidential election.
You said he is mulling filing a complaint with the Control Yuan against the prosecutor on the grounds of abuse of power.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INAUGURATES TV SATELLITE-RECEIVER SYSTEM FOR ABORIGINES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian inaugurated an islandwide satellite-receiving system aimed at reinforcing television signals transmitted to aboriginal communities in remote mountainous areas.

In a ceremony to mark the inauguration of the system, President Chen, Council of Indigenous Peoples (CIP) Chairman Chen Chien-nien, and Director-General of Government Information Office Lin Chia-lung jointly put a dish on an antenna.

The president also spoke with a group of aborigines in Wutai, Pingtung County in southern Taiwan via satellite hookup. The tribesmen greeted the president by saying in chorus, "We love you. We like you."
For his part, Chen said, "I know Wutai. I have been there. It is the best place to live in the world."

The system, established at a cost of NT$71 million (US$2.2 million) , consists of 100,584 satellite dishes installed in various places around the island. It improves the reception of TV signals in Taiwan's mountainous areas, which are inhabited predominately by aborigines.
With this system in place, CIP Chairman Chen Chien-nien said a TV channel that caters to aborigines will be launched by Taiwan Television Enterprise next July.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH TRADE MISSION TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A British trade mission organized by the London-based Deansgate consultancy will arrive in Taiwan on Dec. 6, according to a press release issued by the British Trade and Cultural Office in Taipei on Wednesday.

The products and services represented on this mission include: diesel-powered generators, marine and industrial oil pollution control equipment, management development and performance coaching, non-slip products such as mats, reel material, self-adhesive stirps and panels, and bottle openers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY

TEXT.P: Today is Thursday, Dec. 2, or the 21st day of the 10th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1804: Monarchy returns to France when Napoleon Bonaparte crowns himself Emperor Napoleon I at Notre Dame, 11 years after King Louis XVI was guillotined.
1815: The Rajah of Nepal signs peace treaty with Britain.
1823: U.S. President James Monroe, introducing his "Monroe Doctrine," warns Europe to keep its hands off both American continents.
1901: King Camp Gillette markets a safety razor with a double-edged disposable blade in the United States.
1908: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, is crowned emperor of China at the age of three.
1911: Chinese revolutionaries capture Nanjing.
1923: The Young China Party sets up in Paris, France.
1942: A nuclear chain reaction is demonstrated for the first time by American scientists working on a secret project in Chicago.
1954: Republic of China Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh signs the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty with U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles in Washington.
1965: The World Health Organization formally recognizes Taiwan as free of malaria.
1968: The Taiwan Power Company signs an agreement with the World Bank for a loan of US$50 million for construction of the Dachien Dam.
1971: Soviet Union spaceship "Mars III" lands on Mars.
1974: The Fifth Asian Congress of Pharmaceutical Sciences opens a four-day meeting in Taipei.
1974: The Young China Party celebrates its 51st anniversary.
1976: The Fourth Asian Composers' League Conference holds its closing ceremony, with more than 100 delegates and observers from 20 countries attending.
1976: The ROC's "Hai Kung" research vessel leaves Keelung for an expedition to Antarctica.
1988: A cyclone packing winds in excess of 177 kph hits Bangladesh, killing thousands and leaving more than 5 million homeless.
1986: The Chunghwa (ROC) Blues and the Chunghwa Whites win 1st and 2nd places, respectively in the Third International Baseball Tournament.
1989: V.P. Singh, leader of the Janata Dal Party, replaces Rajiv Gandhi as prime minister of India.
1989: Elections are held for the Legislative Yuan, Taiwan Provincial Assembly, Taipei and Kaohsiung municipal councils, county magistrates, and provincial-level city mayors.
1990: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition wins re-election in the first elections since 1932 involving all of Germany.
1994: A ferry carrying more than 600 people collides with a freighter and sinks in Manila Bay, the Philippines. Sixty bodies are recovered, and 85 people remain missing.
1995: The ROC elects 164 lawmakers to the Third Legislative Yuan.
1995: A Singapore court sentences former Barings Bank trader Nick Leeson to six-and-a-half years in prison for his part in the crash of Britain's oldest merchant bank.
1996: ROC Foreign Minister John Chang departs for South Africa.
1997: After a bitter power struggle with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, President Farooq Leghari of Pakistan resigns.
1999: The Republic of China signs a formal aviation agreement with Palau as part of its efforts to facilitate exchanges between the two countries.

Motse's lesson of the day: "Heaven is all-inclusive and impartial in its activities, abundant and unceasing in its blessings, and lasting and untiring in its guidance. And so, when the sage-kings had accepted heaven as their standard, they measured every action and enterprise by heaven. What heaven desired they would carry out, what heaven abominated they refrained from."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The China Times:
Junior high school principal's suicide is allegedly connected with pressure from a councilor's lobbying.

DOC.HEADLINE: RARE DECEMBER TYPHOON MAY TRIGGER TORRENTIAL RAINS IN TAIWAN: CWB

TEXT.P: A rare December typhoon is forecast to bring torrential rains to Taiwan in the next few days when the typhoon encounters strong northeast trade winds, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Thursday.

Nanmadol, the 27th typhoon reported in the Pacific area this year, was located some 930 kilometers south-southeast of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Hengchun at 11 a.m. Thursday, moving in a west-northwest direction toward Taiwan at a speed of about 30 km/h, CWB forecasters said.
The typhoon has a large radius of more than 250 kilometers, with maximum sustained winds of up to 198 km/h.

The weather bureau may issue a sea warning for Typhoon Nanmadol late Thursday night or Friday morning, depending on how the typhoon's strength and pace change after it makes landfall in the Philippines, the meteorologists said.
The CWB forecast that Typhoon Nanmadol will stir up high waves with strong winds in the seas near Taiwan, adding that it still remains to be seen whether the typhoon will directly hit Taiwan.
The typhoon is expected to bring large amounts of rainfall to Taiwan, probably beginning Friday afternoon, when it encounters a northeast trade wind system, the forecasters said.

Vessels operating in the Bashi Channel and southern Taiwan Strait should be on high alert against strong winds and high waves over the next few days, while people in Taiwan's north and northeastern areas should be on guard against torrential rains, the forecasters said.

Typhoons are extremely rare in the Western Pacific in December because of the colder weather, according to the CWB meteorologists. The last time that the CWB issued a sea warning for a December typhoon was in 1964.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS

Manila Bulletin: Super-typhoon approaching Luzon
The National Disaster Coordinating Council (NDCC) yesterday warned residents in Luzon area to prepare contingency measures as super-typhoon "Yoyong," with center winds that could reach 200 kilometers per hour, reaches either Quezon or Aurora today or tomorrow.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Storm death toll hits 500
REAL, Quezon -- Real, a coastal town of 30,000 people, was fast becoming a ghost town as the survivors scrambled to flee an approaching typhoon that was expected to hit land on Thursday night. Tropical storm "Winnie" has resulted in a casualty count composed of at least 500 dead and missing.
The Philippine Star: 'Winnie' toll: 600 dead, missing
The death toll from flashfloods and landslides caused by heavy rains dumped by tropical depression "Winnie" soared to 412 yesterday as wind and rain from an approaching typhoon hampered rescue efforts. At least 177 other people were reported missing.
The Manila Times: Signal No. 4 for Super 'Yoyong'
A powerful typhoon on Wednesday bore down on Luzon where rescuers were battling to reach survivors from flash floods and landslides that have killed nearly 350 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS COMMIT TO SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT FOR ENVIRONMENT'S SAKE

TEXT.P: An environmental group said Thursday that 66 legislators from across the political spectrum, or 30 percent of all Legislative Yuan members, have signed a declaration committing themselves to pursuing sustainable development to protect the environment.

The Taiwan Environmental Protection Union (TEPU) and a dozen other civic groups held a press conference to unveil the names of the legislators. The list included more legislators from the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), than from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP).

TEPU President Chen Chiao-hua said that 37 legislators from the DPP, 10 lawmakers from the TSU, nine legislators from the KMT, nine independent legislators and one lawmaker from the PFP signed the declaration.

Chen noted that a certain political party questioned the TEPU's motive behind seeking the endorsement of legislators and refused to sign it. She stressed the TEPU's goal is to promote environmental protection.

The civic groups also presented a skit to ridicule the current state of political affairs in which corrupt legislators have failed to come to the rescue of the people living in a Taiwan inundated with garbage and nuclear waste and prone to mudslides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU PROMOTES 'TAIWAN REPUBLIC' ENVELOPES

TEXT.P: The pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Thursday it will promote the use of "Taiwan Republic" envelopes as part of its campaign to rectify the name of Taiwan and formulate a new constitution for Taiwan.
TSU legislative whip Chen Chien-ming said that although the "new name and new constitution" campaign is a solemn cause, it can be addressed in a cheerful, light-hearted manner.

Chen said that just as people need new clothes to fit their body when they grow up, Taiwan has reached a stage in its development where it requires a new constitution and a new national designation to fit its present reality.

"This is a delightful thing. We should tackle it in a cheerful mood. We'll promote the 'new name and new constitution' campaign in an amusing manner by encouraging the use of newly designed 'Taiwan Republic' envelopes," Chen said.

He displayed a pile of the new "Taiwan Republic" envelopes donated by a TSU supporter at a news conference. Their format is identical to the standard envelope issued by state-owned Chunghwa Post Co. except for the addition of the words "Taiwan Republic" on the top of the address blank.

Chen said the TSU will distribute the new "Taiwan Republic" envelopes to its supporters during a street parade in Taipei Sunday to drum up support for its candidates running in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
In his view, Chen said, the present "Republic of China" postage stamps issued by Chunghwa Post should also be changed to distinguish them from those issued by the People's Republic of China.

"At present, our postage stamps bear the name 'Republic of China,' which has often confused foreign citizens who tend to mistake our stamps as those issued by the People's Republic of China. We should print the word 'Taiwan, ' not the 'Republic of China, ' on our postage stamps to avoid any confusion," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA PREPARES FOR MARSHALL ISLANDS PRESIDENT'S VISIT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Thursday declined to comment on a wire service report that Marshall Islands President Kessai Note will visit Taiwan next week to pave the way for a return visit by President Chen Shui-bian, only saying that the ministry is in the midst of preparing for Note's visit.
MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said that the ministry will publicize Note's itinerary in Taiwan once the ministry has finalized all relevant plans.

Declining to confirm whether President Chen will reciprocate by traveling to the Pacific ally next year as the wire service report said, Lu only noted that it is a "diplomatic norm" for heads of state of allied countries to exchange state visits.
If Note does visit Taiwan next week, it will be his third trip to Taiwan as Marshall Islands president, following visits in May 2000 and May 2004.
According to the wire service report, Note will travel to Taiwan next week on a trip expected to pave the way for a return visit by Chen next year.

Chen's visit, probably sometime in March or April of 2005, would be his first to the Marshall Islands, according to the report. Chen is also expected to visit five other ROC diplomatic allies in the Pacific region -- namely Palau, the Solomon Islands, Kiribati, Tuvalu and Vanuatu -- during the trip, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFERENCE ON POST-ELECTIONS U.S.-TAIWAN-CHINA TIES SET FOR DEC. 13

TEXT.P: The U.S.-based Formosa Foundation is set to host an international conference on post-elections U.S.-Taiwan-China relations in Taipei on Dec. 13, a senior ROC presidential adviser said Thursday.

Wu Pei-li, former chairman of the foundation and a senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, said the re-election of U.S. President George W. Bush, the formation of a new mainland Chinese leadership headed by Hu Jintao, the re-election of President Chen and the upcoming legislative elections in Taiwan will all have a major effect on the subsequent development of the triangular relations among the three governments.

The conference, which has been organized against this backdrop, will cover several main topics, including the 2004 elections in Taiwan, cross-strait relations, Taiwan's economic future, as well as the implications of the elections on the political and strategic relationship between the United States and Taiwan, and revising the "one China policy, " Wu said.

The American participants will include Heritage Foundation research fellow John Tkacik, University of Pennsylvania professor Jacques de Lisle, University of Miami professor June Dreyer, University of Southern California professor Daniel Lynch and Davidson College professor Shelley Rigger.
The Formosa Foundation is a non-profit organization established in 2001 by a group of Taiwanese-Americans in Los Angeles.

Wu said the foundation will continue to push the U.S. government to drop its "one China policy" and adopt a "one China, one Taiwan" policy which he said would better fit the current status quo in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING PARTY AND OPPOSITION PLAN BIG RALLIES THIS WEEKEND

TEXT.P: The ruling party and the opposition announced Thursday they would be holding large rallies on "super Saturday," the last weekend before the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Lee Ying-yuan, a vice secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said that there will be a rally in Taipei Saturday, dubbed "Taiwan vs. China, " and one in the southern city of Kaohsiung the same evening.

Lee said that the rallies, expected to draw over 100,000 people in each city, will go on as planned in spite of Typhoon Nanmadol, a rare December typhoon which is expected to drench participants. The party will supply raincoats and umbrellas, Lee added.
President Chen Shui-bian will take part in the rally "rain or shine," and will join former President Lee Teng-hui in Kaohsiung, Lee said.

He called the day of the rallies "super Saturday" because of its importance to the campaigns of the party's candidates. Supporters of the DPP and its political ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will first meet at the former Sungshan Tobacco Factory, with four DPP campaign managers -- DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung, Premier Yu Shyi-kun and Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, with Vice President Annette Lu announcing the beginning of the event.
President Chen will join the supporters later before they arrive at Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.
The DPP and the TSU, commonly referred to as the "pan-green camp," hope to win a clear majority in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.

Along the march route there will be eight stops, with DPP legislative candidates highlighting the need for a "green" majority in the legislature so that key legislation can be passed, such as that to retrieve alleged ill-gotten gains in real estate from the former ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and joining the United Nations under the name of Taiwan.
Meanwhile, the KMT also announced it would hold a large rally on Sunday in what an official described as a "promote the ROC vs. eliminate the ROC" activity.

Liao Fung-teh, director of the KMT's Organization and Development Committee, as well as Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's Culture and Communications Committee, urged those who love their county to come to the Taipei City Government building Sunday afternoon.

Liao said that since the pro-independence TSU will also hold a rally on the same day to promote the writing of a new constitution, the public will be able to see the difference between the two parties and can chose the correct path to take.
Liao said that if the people are in favor of a completely new constitution, they should join the TSU; if they support a revision of the ROC Constitution, they should join the KMT.

Chang also said that the rally aims to highlight the KMT's views on seven issues -- opposition to tampering with history, opposition to Taiwan independence and the writing of a new constitution, depletion of national coffers, resistance to paying an exorbitant price for weaponry, address rising consumer prices and deteriorating social order and protection of farmers' livelihoods.
Chang urged all supporters to bring along anything that can be identified with the ROC to the rally to show their support for the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AUTHOR'S CHILDREN'S BOOK MAKES N. Y. TIMES 'TOP 10'

TEXT.P: An English-language children's book, authored and illustrated by Taiwan artist Chih-yuan Chen, has made it to the New York Times Book Review's "top 10" bestseller list, the Hsin-Yi Foundation reported Thursday.

"Guji Guji, " a modern-day ugly duckling story with a reptilian twist: the title character is a crocodile raised among a family of ducks -- is the second illustrated book that Chen has published in the United States.
His first, "On My Way to Buy Eggs, " another children's book, was named one of U.S. Publishers Weekly's best children's books of 2003.

"Guji Guji" is the third book of Chen's that has received the Hsin-Yi Picture Book Award offered by the Hsin-Yi Foundation, which was founded by Yuen Foong Yu Paper Manufacturing Co.'s founder and is one of the most prestigious organizations in Taiwan devoted to publications and activities for children.
Chen was awarded a gold medal in the illustrated book division in the 2004 Taipei International Book Fair earlier this year.
Buzz about "Guji Guji" began in late August, when the Washington Post praised its "keen humor" and the New York Times Book Review called it "hilarious."
USA Today followed suit, describing it as "quietly funny...about true family values and accepting differences."

"Sales skyrocketed after Daniel Pinkwater dubbed 'Guji Guji' a masterpiece on National Public Radio's Weekend Edition last month. The book is now going into its sixth printing, with more than 55,000 copies in print in just three months," said the New York Times Book Review.
Now the No. 4 bestseller on Amazon's children's book listing, it has also been listed by the U.S. School Library Journal as a "must buy."
An original in his own family, Guji Guji proves to himself and others that family, no matter where or what that family may be, is worth protecting and cherishing.
The story has much to say about appreciating families and differences, and it will resonate with children long after the final page is turned, said the publisher's review.

DOC.HEADLINE: POPULAR WILL IS KEY TO SUCCESS OF CONSTITUTIONAL REFERENDUM: ADVISER

TEXT.P: Any modification to the Republic of China Constitution as proposed by President Chen Shui-bian must have the support of the people before a referendum can be held on the issue, a senior presidential adviser said Thursday.

According to Wu Li-pei, who is also a former chairman of the U.S.-based Formosa Foundation, the constitutional re-engineering project must be backed up by strong popular support and cannot be achieved by Chen's personal will alone.
Expressing the hope that the constitutional reform will clarify the status of Taiwan, Wu said the United States has no right to interfere in a decision made by Taiwan through a democratic process.

Washington on Monday reiterated that it was "opposed to any referendum that would change Taiwan's status or move towards independence" in the wake of the president's proposal raised over the weekend to hold a referendum in 2006 for a new constitution.

This prompted a reassurance from the ROC government that the constitutional re-engineering project would have nothing to do with the issues of independence versus unification, or a change of territorial boundaries or the country's official name.
According to Wu, the United States, for the sake of its own national interests, does not want war to break out across the Taiwan Strait and expects Taiwan to refrain from any provocative moves.

Wu said he believes there will be a chance for Taiwan and China to reopen dialogue after the Dec. 11 legislative elections because cross-strait peace will be crucial to China's economic development and to the stability of the new Beijing leadership headed by Hu Jintao.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER OFFICIATES GROUND-BREAKING FOR SCIENCE PARK IN YUNLIN

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to link up to the global optoelectronics industrial chain as an important maker and supplier within a few years with more government and private investment to establish new companies in newly developed industrial parks, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday.

The optoelectronic manufacturing industry is the second "trillion star" industry that the government hopes to build, following the semiconductor manufacturing industry, said Yu during a ground-breaking ceremony for the development of the Yunlin section of the Central Taiwan Science Park.
Taiwan's semiconductor manufacturing industry has achieved the government's goal this year to have its overall production value exceeded NT$1 trillion (US$31 billion), Yu said.

Once the development of the optoelectronic manufacturing industry is in full swing, prospectively in three to four years, Taiwan may turn itself into a key player in the world's optoelectronics industry, with production even surpassing that of Japan, Yu claimed.

The Yunlin section of the Central Taiwan Science Park, located in Huwei township of the south-central county of Yunlin, will be 96 hectares, of which 44 hectares will be research and factory locations.
Two optoelectronics companies have already registered to move into the Yunlin section, Yu said.
