The Ukrainian parliament passed a vote of no confidence in the government of Prime Minister Vladimir Yanukovych on Wednesday in the latest sign that outgoing President Leonid Kuchma appears to have abandoned Yanukovych, his preferred successor, in a power struggle with opposition candidate Viktor Yushchenko. The vote triggers the automatic resignation of Yanukovych's government, which Kuchma has to accept. Kuchma, however, can allow the Cabinet to stay on for up to 60 days until a new government is formed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 69.33 points to close at 5,867.95.
The bourse opened at 5,861.52 and fluctuated between 5,867.95 and 5,826.51 during trading. A total of 3.13 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$60.35 billion (US$1.88 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.5 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1.4 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.3 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.2 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.8 percent, cement stocks at 0.7 percent, textile stocks at 0.5 percent and paper and pulp issues at 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 425 to 192, with 194 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HOPES TO PASS DRAFT AMENDMENTS TO REFERENDUM LAW SOON

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Thursday expressed the hope that the Executive Yuan will send draft amendments to the Referendum Law to the Legislative Yuan soon so that they can be passed in current legislature, which will conclude at the end of January.

Tsai Huang-liang, DPP whip in the legislature, made the remarks one day after the Executive Yuan withdrew draft revisions to the Referendum Law from its weekly agenda at the last minute ostensibly because some civic groups still think that the threshold for initiating and mounting a petition is too high, and that Premier Yu Shyi-kun had asked for further coordination.

However, there is speculation that the retraction has to do with pressure from the United States after a spokesman from the U.S. State Department expressed serious concern about President Chen Shui-bian's call to put a new constitution to a public referendum in 2006.

Tsai said that the DPP can understand the situation, but he expressed the hope that after the Dec. 11 legislative elections, the Executive Yuan will send the revised draft amendments to the legislature as soon as practicable.

He said that even some DPP legislators, the Nuke-4 Referendum Initiative Association and other civic groups have differences about the amendments, believing that the Executive Yuan should consider all aspects of the issues before sending them to the Legislative Yuan.
"The retraction is not due to pressure from the United States, " he said.
The Taiwan Solidarity Union, an ally of the DPP, asked the Executive Yuan to explain clearly why it had not included the draft amendments into discussions.

The opposition People First Party said that the Executive Yuan's withdrawal is probably just a ploy, with the intent to reap the maximum political gains by continuing to keep sensitive questions concerning Taipei-Beijing-Washington relations on the front burner.

The draft amendments that the Cabinet had intended to discuss actually dramatically lowered the threshold for initiating a petition for a national referendum to 0.05 percent of those eligible to vote in the last presidential election, or about 8,000 people. The law currently stipulates that to initiate a referendum requires 0.5 percent of eligible voters from the last presidential election, or about 80,000 people.

The law also stipulates that a collection of signatures of 5 percent of the eligible voters in the latest presidential election, or approximately 800,000 signature must be obtained before the proposal can be screened by the Referendum Supervisory Committee. The draft amendments suggest lowering the threshold to 2 percent, or about 300,000 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR, JANE GOODALL PLANT TREES IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou joined British conservationist Jane Goodall at a tree-planting activity at the Taipei American School on Thursday.
Ma and Goodall planted four tree on the school's campus and near the sidewalk outside the school.
Ma told Goodall that the city government adopted a set of tree protection regulations last year to preserve rare trees and trees of a certain height, age and circumference in the city.
Ma said he hopes the Roots and Shoots program promoted by the Jane Goodall Institute will continue to expand in Taiwan to educate students to protect the environment.
There are currently 415 Roots and Shoots groups in kindergartens, elementary schools, high schools, colleges and communities in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December gained 85 points to close at 5,855, with 28,912 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January moved up 72 points to finish at 5,862, with 194 contracts traded, while March futures gained 79 points to finish at 5,852, with eight contracts traded.
June futures gained 99 points to finish at 5,844 with five contracts traded, while September futures moved up 56 points to close at 5,761, with nine contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,770 for December, 5,790 for January, 5,773 for March, 5,745 for June and 5,705 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
December TE futures moved up 4.25 points to close at 218.25, with 4,129 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained 3.65 point to finish at 218.15, with 25 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

December TF futures gained 15.2 points to finish at 1,006.2, with 4,840 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved up 16.6 points to end at 1,006.8, with 181 contracts traded. March TF future gained 25 points to finish at 1,007, with seven contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAILS AICA DECISION TO HOLD CONGRESS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian hailed the International Association of Art Critics (AICA) as one of Taiwan's best friends Thursday because the UNESCO affiliate has braved Beijing's opposition to hold its 2004 world congress in Taiwan.

Addressing the opening of the AICA 2004 World Congress at the Taipei County Government building, Chen said artistic activities symbolize a country's freedom and creativity while artistic criticism can serve as a bridge between artists and the general public.
As a member of the international community, Chen said, Taiwan is more than willing to make positive contributions to the world and fulfill its duties and obligations.

However, Chen said Taiwan has been shut out of the United Nations since 1971 when the U.N. General Assembly gave the China seat to Beijing. For years, he went on, Taiwan has faced enormous difficulties taking part in U.N.-sponsored activities because of Beijing's diplomatic suppression.
Against this backdrop, Chen said, the AICA's choice of Taiwan as the venue for its 2004 annual congress is of great significance.

Chen further said his administration has consistently placed much emphasis on cultural development and artistic activities and education, with an aim to make Taiwan a country with vitality and creativity. He urged all AICA conference-goers to present valuable advice to help boost Taiwan's cultural development.

The AICA was founded in Paris in 1948 and was recognized as a non-governmental organization by UNESCO in 1951. The AICA now has branches in 72 member countries, representing more than 4,000 art critics around the world.

Taiwan became a formal member of the organization under the designation of "AICA Taiwan" in 2001 and the AICA authorized Taiwan to hold its 2004 world congress last year. AICA Taiwan is one of the few local organization that have been able to join an organization affiliated with the United Nations Education, Science and Cultural Organization (UNESCO).

More than 200 art critics from 63 AICA member states are taking part in the AICA World Congress which will run through Dec. 9. The congress activities will include an Administrative Council meeting, a general assembly, symposiums and tours to local sites of interests.

Chen Chao-hsing, honorary president of the AICA Taiwan, said the ongoing world congress has provided a conduit for Taiwan to develop ties with major arts groups and will have a significant impact on the nation's future artistic and cultural development.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR INVESTMENT IN PUBLIC CONSTRUCTION TO SET NEW RECORD

TEXT.P: The private sector has actively taken part in public construction projects, and its investment could reach NT$120 billion (US$3.72 billion) by the end of the year, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday.
The premier made the remarks while attending a party to mark the contract signing between Dragon Steel Corp. and Taichung Harbor on the building of a steel factory.

Premier Yu said that given the difficult financial situation, the government's investment in public construction projects has continued to drop. In addition, the government is bound by the national debt law, and with debts amounting to three trillion, the ceiling cannot be raised further.

He noted that the Executive Yuan has since the latter half of 2002 advocated that the private sector take part in public construction projects. Investment from the private sector amounted to NT$62.4 billion in 2003, up 860 percent from 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO LAUNCH HISTORIC LANDSCAPE PRESERVATION PROGRAM

TEXT.P: The government is planning to funnel NT$2.5 billion (US$77.88 million) over four years into a program aimed at preserving the historic and cultural landscapes in Taiwan, according to the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) on Thursday.

Under the program, which will run from 2005 to 2008, the government will fund a series of projects to maintain and restore historic buildings, traditional communities, historic streets, ancient city walls and historic sites in designated areas, including Tainan City, Changhua County's Lukang township, and the Wanhua district of Taipei City, as well as Penghu County, CEPD officials said.
The program is expected to create 1,121 jobs per year, the officials said.

Although Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations, the government will make a bid through the Council for Cultural Affairs to have some of the historic properties in Taiwan be included on the list of World Heritage sites of the U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), they said.
The basaltic landscape in Penghu is considered the most promising site to be nominated for the bid, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE OUT OF EVERY FOUR WORKERS IN TAIWAN SMOKE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: One out of every four working people in Taiwan smoke and nearly half of all workplaces do not enforce a no-smoking regulation, the latest survey on smoking hazards in the workplace showed Thursday.

The survey was conducted on 9,017 full-time workers over the age of 15 by a workplace smoking hazard prevention center at the commission of the Bureau of Health Promotion (BHP) under the Department of Health.
The survey showed that 24.2 percent of workers smoke -- 42.4 percent of men and 3.2 percent of women.

Miners and gravel workers smoke the most, followed by men working in construction. The trades in which most women smoke are real estate and the borrowing and lending sectors, followed by the culture, sports or leisure sectors.

On trades that enforce a ban on smoking most thoroughly, the sectors of medical care and social welfare had the highest ratio of 90 percent, followed by education services at 70 percent, and the agriculture, forestry and fishery sector, and construction sector ranked at 10 percent and 37 percent, respectively, in the lowest bracket, showing that they have the most serious smoking hazard in the workplace.

BHP education official You Po-chun noted that according to smoking hazard prevention regulations, the owners or violators in a smoke-free workplace can be fined between NT$1,000 and NT$3,000 (US$31.25 to US$93.75).
But You noted that most people don't want to confront violators, with less than 50 percent of people surveyed saying that they would try to dissuade or report violators.

DOC.HEADLINE: 76 PERCENT OF TAIWAN COMPANIES HIRE DISABLED WORKERS: POLL

TEXT.P: Around 76 percent of Taiwan companies have hired disabled workers, with over half of them saying that professional skills make the difference, according to the results of a recent survey.

The poll, made by a headhunting Web site, show that about 76 percent of domestic businesses have employed an average of 2.1 mentally or physically handicapped workers -- mainly partially paralyzed persons.

Some 48 percent of them admitted to having hired disabled workers due to government law, while 57 percent claimed that professionalism is their top consideration while deciding whether or not to hire such a person.

According to the poll results, around 35 percent of handicapped respondents are trying to find a job, while the remaining 65 percent are employed with an average monthly salary of NT$20,166 (US$605) -- a level which falls short of the average of NT$30,517 as claimed by the employers questioned.

Some 57 percent of the handicapped pointed to a lack of company willingness to hire disabled workers as their major problem in finding a job, ahead of about 50 percent who citied a lack of an offer of adequate work.
Nearly 92 percent of the disabled people polled think that the government should further step up its employment campaign for them, the survey showed.

Statistics compiled by the Ministry of the Interior show that there are around 896,740 handicapped people in Taiwan, accounting for 4 percent of the country's total population. More than 65 percent of them have a senior high school education, followed by 18 percent with a junior high school certificate. Only 2.3 percent have higher education training.
The www.1111.tw Web site carried out the survey Nov. 15-30 via interviews, telephone and the Internet, recovering 761 valid questionnaires.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Five million workers face Treasury blitz on pensions.
Five million teachers, police, firefighters and town hall staff will have to contribute up to two thirds more to fund their final-salary pension schemes under plans drawn up by Gordon Brown.
Financial Times: Whitehall fury at Brown demands for budget cuts.
Gordon Brown has become embroiled in a Whitehall row after ordering government departments to cut spending as part of a deal to avoid a pre-election surge in council tax.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGAL GROUP CALLS FOR MORE CONCERN FOR FOREIGN LABORERS' RIGHTS

TEXT.P: The Legal Assistance Foundation (LAF) urged the public Thursday to show more concern for the rights and interests of foreign laborers and mainland Chinese spouses of Taiwan citizens.
LAF Secretary-General Cheng Wen-lung made the appeal at a news conference attended by two Vietnamese workers who recounted the ordeals they have endured in Taiwan.

Cheng said foreign laborers from other developing countries have contributed to Taiwan's economic development over the years, but many of them have not received reasonable treatment after they contracted diseases or fell victim to workplace accidents, he added.
Because of language barriers and disadvantageous social status, Chen said, foreign laborers have difficulties filing complaints about maltreatment at the hands of the Taiwanese.
"Out of consideration of human rights and humanitarianism, we should show more concern and extend necessary assistance to foreign workers and caregivers," Cheng said.

The LAF has received 6,865 applications for legal assistance since its inauguration in July this year, Chen said, adding that 2,850 of those applications, including 107 filed by foreign applicants, have been approved.

During the news conference, two Vietnamese women, identified as Meihua and Linmei, said they were misled by manpower brokers into believing that they could earn big bucks if they came to work in Taiwan. However, they said they had not received reasonable treatment since their arrival.

Meihua said she was assigned to care for a quarantined patient during her first trip to Taiwan. She was repatriated after she was infected by the contagious disease. On her second trip to Taiwan, Meihua claimed she was hired to care for a partially paralyzed man. She said she had to endure sexual assault and domestic violence. The employer frequently threatened to repatriate her if she failed to comply with his demands.

In Linmei's case, she first worked at a factory, but absconded after she was hospitalized due to overwork. She then worked at an underground factory where she cut herself because of unfamiliarity with the mechanical operations. She was forced to leave the hospital after two days of treatment because her employer was afraid of being found to have hired an absconder.
Cheng said the LAF is striving to help Meihua and Linmei receive reasonable compensation.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTED OIL AVERAGED US$34.1 PER BARREL IN FIRST NINE MONTHS: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Fueled by a global economic recovery and rising tension in the Middle East, imported oil cost an average of US$34.1 per barrel in the first nine months of this year, government authorities reported Thursday.

According to statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) , the average price for the January-September period represents a rise of 20.9 percent over the previous year's level. The country's oil imports totaled US$9.24 billion in value in the same period, an increase of 40 percent year-to-year.

Taiwan consumed a total of 110 million kiloliters of oil and other fuel in the first nine months, up by 11.9 percent compared to the year-earlier amount, the statistics show. Some 99.18 million kiloliters of energy sources were imported, or 98.1 percent of the total. Only 1.9 percent was produced at home.

The country has for long relied almost fully on foreign imports to meet domestic demand. Taiwan's oil supplies come overwhelmingly from the Middle East, while mainland China, Australia and Indonesia are its leading suppliers of fuel coal.
In the first nine months, the mainland and Indonesia provided Taiwan with 48.4 percent and 36.2 percent of its fuel coal needs, respectively, while Australia accounted for 12.5 percent.

Although the mainland is the world's largest coal producer and consumer, DGBAS officials said that the mainland's own robust demand for fuel has led to a supply shortage and pushed up its prices markedly on the international market.

Taiwan imported coal as both fuel and material at an average price of US$49.6 per metric ton in the January-September period, a jump of 47.2 percent over the average level of a year ago, according to DGBAS tallies. The country's fuel imports grew by 11.3 percent for the same nine-month period, with a value worth US$2.28 billion, up by 63.8 percent from the year-earlier level.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S MILITARY EXPANSION TARGETS TAIWAN: U.S. THINK TANK
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The military expansion of mainland China in recent years has a short-term goal of imposing its terms on Taiwan, a former official of the U.S. Department of Defense said Wednesday.
Daniel Blumenthal made the remarks in a seminar on the future of the mainland Chinese military sponsored by the American Enterprise Institute (AIE), a U.S. think tank.
Blumenthal said Beijing has in recent years continued to expand its military might, as well as update its weaponry and command and communications system.
The military buildup aims at overwhelming Taiwan militarily and to prevent the United States from interfering in an event of a conflict in the Taiwan Strait, he said.

Murray Scor Tanner, an expert from the Rand Corp., said the mainland tried to pressure Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland during Taiwan's presidential election early this year, warning them that if they supported Taiwan independence, they would have to forget businesses on the mainland, but President Chen Shui-bian won the election anyway. This, he said, makes one wonder what options are available if economic interference is ineffective.

But Harvey Feldman, a senior researcher from the Heritage Foundation, said the mainland might have the capacity to unify Taiwan by force soon, but using force against the island will not be in the long-term interests of Beijing.

Feldman stressed that the crucial thing is that the U.S. administration must let Beijing know clearly that it will not sit by in the event of a military attack against Taiwan, adding that if the United States were to allow that to happen, Japan, South Korea, the Philippines and other Southeast Asian nations would view the United States in a less favorable light.

But Feldman also agreed that the United States must ask Taiwan to exercise self-restraint, and that both sides of the Taiwan Strait must act cautiously and avoid provocation so that cross-strait differences can be resolved peacefully.

DOC.HEADLINE: RISE OF NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR STILL WITHIN TOLERABLE RANGE: BOFT

TEXT.P: The continuing appreciation of the new Taiwan dollar has had limited impact on the competitiveness of local industries, with the range of its surge narrower compared with those of its competitors such as Japan and South Korea, Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Director-General Huang Chih-peng said Thursday.
Huang said the rising local currency has different effects on different industrial sectors, and exporters usually do not wish to see a drastic and lasting fluctuation of the currency.
Most traders and industries surveyed by the BOFT think the rise is still within a "tolerable" range so far, Huang said.
Having gained nearly NT$1.5 against the U.S. dollar over the past month, the new Taiwan dollar further breached the NT$32 benchmark Thursday to finish at NT$31.990 against the greenback.

According to Kung Ming-hsin, an expert from the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, the new Taiwan dollar has to rise following the footsteps of Japan and South Korea in order to maintain the competitiveness of Taiwan's exports.
However, a financial bubble may occur in Taiwan if the currency continues to surge as a result of an influx of international hot money, Kung warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CONFIDENT OF TAIWAN'S WHO BID

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday he is convinced that Taiwan can join the World Health Organization (WHO) as an observer.

"With the perseverance and support of our allies and friends, we'll attain our goal of becoming a WHO observer," Chen said while meeting with Palau Vice President Sandra S. Pierantozzi, who concurrently serves as the South Pacific island nation's health minister.

Stressing that Taiwan has reached world standards in medical service, health care, epidemic control and public sanitation, Chen said it's unfair and unreasonable to exclude Taiwan from the WHO and its governing body -- the World Health Assembly (WHA).
Chen expressed his gratitude for Palau and other countries that voiced support for Taiwan's WHO bid at this year's WHA conference held in Geneva in May.
"Although we didn't succeed, we'll not be daunted by the setback. So long as we do not give up our bid, we'll make it one day," he said confidently.

Despite its failure to join the WHO, Chen said, Taiwan will continue to offer medical aid to its diplomatic allies and offer humanitarian aid to needy countries to fulfill its obligations as a member of the international community.
Pierantozzi is currently in Taiwan to attend an Austronesian health ministers meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SHARE MEDICAL CARE EXPERIENCE WITH AUSTRONESIAN STATES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that Taiwan wants to promote ties with Austronesian states, noting that Taiwan's aborigines are Austronesian people.

Receiving health ministers from Palau, Tuvalu and the Marshall Islands who are in Taiwan for the health ministerial conference of Austronesian States, Chen said Taiwan's aborigines share the same origin as that of the other Austronesian people and are predisposed to the same hereditary illnesses, such as diabetes, obesity and gout.
Besides environmental factors, Chen said, the prevalence of these diseases might have something to do with genetics, which is worth studying jointly by Taiwan and other Austronesian states.
Chen said his government would like to sign a joint communique on health with these states to promote Taiwan's ties with them.
The president said the communique would advance the exchanges of medical information and cooperation between Taiwan and Austronesian states.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S UBIQUITOUS SUPPRESSION STEADILY ALIENATES TAIWAN: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland China's ubiquitous diplomatic suppression of Taiwan has driven the two sides of the Taiwan Strait even further apart, Taiwan's top mainland policy planner said Thursday.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu made the remarks while meeting with three visiting U.S. Congressmen -- John Culberson, John Carter and Phil Gingrey -- along with their aides.

Wu said that although commercial and cultural exchanges across the strait have been brisk in recent years, the mainland has continued to threaten Taiwan militarily and squeeze Taiwan's participation in international organizations and activities on various political and non-political occasions.

Just last month, Wu said, the mainland authorities forced an across-the-board market recall on the mainland of boxed Yungho-brand soybean milk simply because the package identified Taiwan as its country of origin.
Worse still, Wu said, mainland customs have recently ordered the seizure and destruction of all products carrying labels denoting Taiwan as their country of origin.
During an international hair styling and makeup contest in Milan last month, Wu said, the mainland delegates demanded that the Taiwan delegation change its designation to "Taiwan, PRC."
"All these repressive moves have hurt the Taiwan people's feelings and only drive the two sides further apart," Wu said.

Touching on the mainland's relentless military threat, Wu said Taiwan plans to purchase advanced defensive weapons to protect its security and prevent the cross-strait military balance from overly tilting in the mainland's favor.

In view of the increasing social unrest on the mainland, Wu went on, Taiwan has to heighten its alert and is making every possible effort to protect itself from falling prey to the mainland regime's stirring up of nationalism and patriotism, moves that are aimed at taking the mainland people's minds off their discontent with the communist government in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER'S BODYGUARDS FELLED BY FOOD POISONING

TEXT.P: A total of 37 police officers called in to safeguard Premier Yu Shy-kun when he visited Taichung Harbor in central Taiwan, as well as three of the premier's bodyguards, contracted food poisoning Thursday after eating tainted box lunches.
The premier was unaffected, according to Chen Chi-mai, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan.

Most of the victims complained of hot flushes, tightness in the chest, difficulty breathing and palpitations, all of which are symptoms of food poisoning, according to surgeons at a hospital in Wuchi, to which 37 of the victims were admitted.
Three others, including Liao Yung-lai, director of the Executive Yuan's Office in Central Taiwan, and two bodyguards of the premier were sent to another hospital in Taiping, Taichung County.
Most of the victims left hospital after preliminary treatment.
They fell sick at 2 p.m., one hour after consuming lunch boxes provided by a local caterer.
Some of the victims noted that the fish they were given did not smell good. The premier ate the same lunch box but left the suspicious fish untouched, his spokesman said.
The premier was at Taichung harbor to preside over a ceremony to mark the signing of a warehouse-leasing contract between an iron mill and the harbor authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO UNVEILS NEW MEASURES TO REVITALIZE MORIBUND MOVIE INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: The tax exemption for foreign films will be canceled as part of the government's efforts to revitalize Taiwan's moribund movie industry, Government Information Office (GIO) Director-General Lin Chia-lung said Thursday.

Lin said the GIO has consulted with the Ministry of Finance and relevant film operators on the proposal to cancel tax exemption or deduction privileges for imported movies in order to enhance the competitiveness of locally produced films.

Lin unveiled a new package of measures aimed at reviving the flagging local movie industry two days ahead of the presentation of the annual Golden Horse Awards in honor of outstanding Chinese- and Taiwanese-language films, actors, actresses and other movie professionals.
Lin said the government will set up a "movie venture capital fund" to pool resources in the public and private sectors to produce fine-quality films with market potential and artistic value.
According to the GIO's plan, Lin said the Executive Yuan Development Fund will contribute 45 percent to the "movie venture capital fund" and the remaining 55 percent will come from private investors.
The GIO will also coordinate with financial institutions to provide NT$3 billion in low-interest loans for movie production and marketing, Lin said.
Meanwhile, Lin said, the GIO will assist the private sector in setting up a talent nurturing center to train a new generation of professionals in film production and marketing.
In addition, Lin said, the GIO plans to coordinate private groups in setting up a movie marketing center to promote locally produced films at home and abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.S. to increase its force in Iraq by nearly 12,000.
The American military presence in Iraq will grow by nearly 12,000 troops by next month, to 150,000, the highest level since the invasion last year, to provide security for the Iraqi elections in January and to quell insurgent attacks around the country. The Pentagon is doing this mainly by ordering about 10,400 soldiers and marines in Iraq to extend their tours. Commanders had signaled for weeks that there was a likelihood that additional troops would be needed to provide security for elections scheduled for Jan. 30, and the Pentagon took a first step in October by ordering 6,500 troops to extend their tours. But the force levels announced Wednesday are larger than many officers had expected and reflect the insurgents' deadly resiliency and the poor performance by many newly trained Iraqi security forces in the face of rebel assaults.
Wall Street Journal: Fed view shifting on inflation; rate rises likely.
A growing number of Federal Reserve officials believe inflation risks are on the rise -- a shift in sentiment that will likely keep the central bank raising interest rates at its next few meetings. Officials cite several reasons for their new found concern: slowing productivity growth, the lower dollar, high energy and commodity prices, recent inflation data, and anecdotal evidence of businesses raising prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSFORMATION NEEDED FOR TEXTILE INDUSTRY'S SURVIVAL: EXPERT

TEXT.P: In the face of an abolition of the quota system due next year in the global textile market, Taiwan's textile industry must seek to diversify and push for transformation if it wants to enjoy continued growth, domestic experts said Thursday.

Huang Yao-tang, chairman of the Taiwan Textile Research Institute, said that the domestic industry should shift its focus to industrial applications for sustainable development in view of fiercer challenges from structural changes in the international market.

Once the quota system has been lifted, Taiwan's garment makers -- currently the mainstay of the industry, accounting for 80 percent of the domestic industry -- will not be able to compete against rivals in mainland China due to their cheaper production costs, Huang said.
In an effort to break this bottleneck, Taiwan textile companies should devote their resources to creative applications for diversified uses.

Compared to a share of 30 percent or the even higher 50 percent production application rate enjoyed by European and U.S. textile makers in other industries, such as the biotech and the architecture arenas, Taiwan manufacturers should bravely embrace the arrival of an "intelligence era" with sharpened competitiveness, he argued.

The major obstacle facing the domestic industry today, he pointed out, is that research and markets are not pegged to each other. Taiwan companies do not have the know-how to turn research achievements into innovative products in the market and to promote them in other countries, he said.
To serve that end, the Taiwan Textile Research Institute provides domestic companies with total solution packages, with finance and subsidies from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), he said.
The institute will hold a series of seminars and exhibitions to display their advanced research results and new products particularly and solely for industry insiders, starting from next Monday.
In terms of application fields, the pavilions will focus on themes surrounding health care, security monitoring, medical treatment and digital imprinting and testing.

Taiwan's textile industry and related businesses yield about NT$60 billion (US$1.88 billion) in output value per year at present, and an MOEA upgrading program seeks to double the level to NT$120 billion by 2008. The domestic industry was once the country's No. 1 earner of foreign exchange reserves.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMEN URGE E.U. TO KEEP CHINA ARMS EMBARGO
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Twenty-five members of the U.S. House of Representatives wrote Thursday to the prime minister of the Netherlands, current chair of the European Union, urging him to do whatever he can to make sure the 25-state bloc does not lift its arms embargo on mainland China.

Due to the fact that the remainder of the U.S. congressional sessions after the November elections is rather short, the prospects for passing HCR 512, which was introduced in mid-October, are slim. The co-introducers of HCR 512 -- Reps. Steve Chabot (R-OH) and Sherrod Brown (D-OH) -- decided to initiate a letter to the European Union in lieu of the resolution. The letter quickly obtained the endorsement of more than 20 of their congressional colleagues.
HCR 512 refers to a resolution pushing the European Union to maintain its ban on arms sales to the mainland.

The letter to the Dutch prime minister reads: "We believe that Europe should take the positions of other democracies into account. The views of the United States, Japan and democratic nations that surround China -- such as Taiwan and South Korea -- should weigh heavily in the balance between pro and con. They clearly do not favor lifting the embargo."
It concludes: "We urge you to use your good offices to work with your European Union colleagues to make sure that the arms embargo on China remains."

The 25 co-signers are: Reps. Steve Chabot, Sherrod Brown, Tom Lantos, Tim Ryan, Mark Souder, Pete Sessions, Tom Tancredo, Vito Fossella, Earl Blumenauer, Steve King, John Shimkus, John Hostettler, Gene Green, Lane Evans, Howard Berman, Brad Sherman, John Culberson, Ron Lewis, Shelley Berkley, Gil Gutknecht, Dave Camp, Peter King, Hilda Solis, Thaddeus McCotter and Nita Lowey.

Meanwhile, the Formosa Association for Public Affairs (FAPA), a Washington-based group dedicated to promoting Taiwan's cause, said in a press statement Wednesday that it is pleased to learn that both the U.S. administration and Congress oppose the lifting of the E.U. arms embargo.

Noting that if the embargo is lifted, the military balance in the Taiwan Strait will shift unacceptably in the mainland's favor, FAPA President Wu Ming-chi said the FAPA will do whatever it can to make sure it is not lifted next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER URGES KMT TO DONATE PARTY LOGO TO NATION

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) should donate its "white sun against a blue sky" party emblem to the nation to avoid confusion, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker said Thursday.

Shen Fu-hsiung, a physician-turned-legislator, made the appeal after President Chen Shui-bian urged the KMT last week to voluntarily change its party logo, which he said resembles too closely the Republic of China's national emblem. If the KMT fails to change its emblem in three months, Chen said, he will push for a revision to the existing National Emblem Law to "outlaw" the KMT's party logo.

Shen said the KMT should take the initiative to donate its party emblem to the nation. Should the KMT do so, Shen said, the Legislative Yuan should pass a resolution formally accepting the KMT logo as the ROC's national emblem thereafter.
Because of historical factors and the KMT's party-state concept, the ROC's national emblem is only slightly different to the KMT logo.
Provided that the KMT donates its party emblem, Shen said, the DPP should also be magnanimous enough to accept the logo as the nation's new emblem.
Shen urged both camps to end their ideological strife and devote more of their energy to developing Taiwan into a better and stronger country.

DOC.HEADLINE: EAST ASIAN ECONOMIC CONFERENCE HELD IN TOKYO

TEXT.P: The 32nd East Asian Economic Conference, an annual forum of business leaders from Japan and Taiwan, was held here Thursday, drawing about 140 participants.

The Taiwanese delegation was led by Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinatrust Commercial Bank, while Akio Kosai, vice chairman of the Keidanren, or Japanese Business Federation, headed the Japanese delegation.
The participants exchanged views on the economic prospects for mainland China, Japan and Taiwan, and ways to promote economic and business cooperation between Taiwan and Japan.
The Japanese delegation was optimistic about Japan's economic recovery in the coming year, but admitted that it depends very much on the economic growth in mainland China and the United States.
For its part, the Taiwan delegation said its country's gross domestic product is expected to expand by 5.93 percent this year.

The Taiwan delegates asked Japan to speed up the processing of applications for patents, while the Japanese delegates asked the Taiwan authorities to get tough on piracy, set up a standard process for processing patent applications, and improve the quality of the patent-reviewing process.
Both sides agreed that they should continue to work together closely.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM URGES E.U. NOT TO LIFT ARMS EMBARGO ON CHINA

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen asked the European Union Thursday not to lift its arms embargo on mainland China.

Meeting the representatives assigned to Taipei by E.U. member states, Chen noted that the embargo was imposed after the 1989 Tiananmen Square Massacre and that the Beijing regime has not improved its human rights record since that time, which has been confirmed in a report presented by Chris Patten, the E.U. commissioner in charge of external relations, on Nov. 16.

Furthermore, the minister said, Beijing has never denounced the use of force as a means of resolving its dispute with Taiwan, and a lifting of the arms embargo will boost Beijing's military intimidation of the country.

The E.U. is expected to have a summit with the mainland Dec. 8 and the question of the arms embargo is almost certain to be raised. Taiwan is worried that the E.U. could remove the embargo, to its detriment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OPENS TRADE OFFICE IN NIGERIA

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) opened an office in Lagos, Nigeria Nov. 30, according to a press release issued by TAITRA headquarters Thursday.
With a population of 130 million, TAITRA said, Nigeria is the second-largest economy in Africa, next only to South Africa, and has the potential to grow into a big market for Taiwan products.
The trade office in Lagos will help Taiwan businessmen to explore the Nigerian market, as well as promote trade exchanges between the two countries, said the press release.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 3, or the 22nd day of the 10th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Madrid surrenders to French forces led by Napoleon Bonaparte.
1810: Britain captures the island of Mauritius from France.
1818: Illinois becomes the 21st state of the United States.
1828: John Quincy Adams loses the U.S. presidential election to his arch-rival Andrew Jackson.
1894: Robert Louis Stevenson, Scottish writer of essays, poetry and novels, dies at the age of 44. He authored "Treasure Island," "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" and "Kidnapped."
1901: American film producer and film animator Walt Disney is born. He created such immortals as Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck.
1943: The Joint Declaration of the Cairo Conference is issued simultaneously in Chungking, Washington and London.
1944: U.S. forces advance across the Saar River in Germany during World War II.
1948: Republic of China government troops evacuate Hsuchow in eastern China.
1958: Dutch businesses are nationalized in Indonesia.
1960: Chou Tao-chi graduates from National Chengchi University and becomes the first student to earn a national doctorate in the Republic of China.
1966: The Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone is inaugurated.
1966: Macau imposes a curfew after massive riots allegedly incited by the Communist Chinese.
1967: South African surgeon Dr. Christiaan Barnard successfully performs a human heart transplant, the first of its kind in the world.
1971: Pakistani planes attack northwest India in a dispute over Kashmir. India responds by declaring a state of emergency.
1975: Communists take control of Laos, declare an end to the 600-year-old monarchy and set up the People's Democratic Republic of Laos.
1976: Rear Adm. James H. Morris, commander of the amphibious forces of the U.S. 7th Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1983: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) wins a landslide victory in supplementary parliamentary elections. The KMT captures 62 of 71 seats up for grabs in the Legislative Yuan. The opposition wins six seats and independents take three.
1989: U.S. President George Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev end a summit meeting on Malta in the Mediterranean Sea, signaling the end of the Cold War and entry into a new era of peace and cooperation.
1992: Millions of gallons of crude oil spill into the sea off the coast of La Coruna, Spain, threatening ecological disaster.
1993: Ukraine and the United States fail to resolve a dispute over Ukraine's stockpile of some 1,000 long-range nuclear warheads.
1994: The first popular elections for the governor of Taiwan Province and the mayors of Taipei and Kaohsiung municipalities are held. James C.Y. Soong is elected governor of Taiwan. Chen Shui-bian and Wu Den-yih win the mayorships of Taipei and Kaohsiung, respectively.
1995: Chun Doo Hwan, former president of South Korea, is arrested on charges of military rebellion stemming from a 1979 coup and a later massacre of civilians by the army.
1997: South Korea signs a letter of intent with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for a loan of US$57 billion, the largest of its kind ever provided by the IMF, to help South Korea get through its financial crisis.
1999: Visiting Malawian President Bakili Muluzi and his ROC counterpart Lee Teng-hui sign a communique reconfirming the friendship between their two countries.
2000: Francis Ng wins the "Best Leading Actor Award," Maggie Cheung wins the "Best Leading Actress Award," and To Kei-Fung wins the "Best Director Award" at the 2000 Golden Horse Awards.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says his party's dramatic win in legislative elections will not change his commitment to improving relations across the Taiwan Strait.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says that he is willing to share political power and resources with other political parties on the basis of mutual respect, to promote political stability, national identity and democratic reform.
Motse's lesson of the day: "We are certain that heaven desires to have men love and benefit one another and abominates to have them hate and harm one another."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: State of calamity in 7 regions
Interior and Local Government Secretary Angelo Reyes announced yesterday seven regions in Luzon are now under a state of calamity to facilitate the implementation of relief and rehabilitation as the country braced itself for the wrath of super-typhoon "Yoyong," which was expected to hit land last night.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: 'Yoyong' slams Luzon
EVEN before it made landfall last night, super Typhoon "Yoyong" (international code name: Nanmadol) had already brought more death and destruction to the provinces of Southern and Central Luzon still reeling from Typhoons "Violeta" and "Unding" and tropical depression "Winnie."
The Philippine Star: 'Yoyong'slams eastern Luzon
Typhoon "Yoyong" slammed into the Bicol Region yesterday, killing one man in Catanduanes and tearing down power lines as rescuers struggled to reach victims of tropical depression "Winnie" which also hit eastern Luzon last Sunday.
The Manila Times: 'Yoyong'smashes into East Luzon
Typhoon "Yoyong" slammed into the eastern Philippines Thursday, killing one man and tearing down power lines, as rescuers battled to reach victims of an earlier storm that left nearly 600 people dead or missing.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES
DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TAKES PRESIDENT CHEN AT HIS WORD: ARMITAGE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The United States takes President Chen Shui-bian at his word that he will not move toward Taiwan independence, Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage has said recently.

Armitage was quoted as saying during a recent interview with a journalist from Japan's Yomiuri Shimbun daily that U.S. officials had discussions with Taiwan authorities in late November and were told that President Chen "has come forward and made a pledge that he would not break his pledge about going forward with independence."

The deputy secretary of state added that the U.S. stance of being opposed to any unilateral moves to change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait has been made "crystal clear, " adding that "it's well known to our Taiwanese friends."

Armitage made the remarks in response to the journalist's question about whether Washington is ready to put more pressure on Chen not to pursue a more aggressive policy if the ruling Democratic Progressive Party wins a majority in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan in the Dec. 11 elections.

THE Chinese government-linked parent of China Aviation Oil (CAO) sold off a block of its shares in the company even though it knew, but failed to publicly disclose, that speculative trading losses were ballooning to crisis point.
Reliable sources said CAO's chief executive, Mr Chen Juilin, told them this. Mr Chen, who has been suspended from his duties, disclosed this while in Singapore, before he flew back to China on Wednesday.
The disclosure is yet another bombshell in the debacle unfolding over the US$550 million losses racked up by listed CAO when it made wrong bets on oil prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA ACTIVATES PREVENTION MECHANISM AS WINTER TYPHOON APPROACHES

TEXT.P: With a rare winter typhoon approaching Taiwan, the Council of Agriculture (COA) activated its disaster prevention and relief mechanism Friday.

Taking seriously the "super" Typhoon Nanmadol, which has killed or left missing at least 1,000 people in the Philippines since early Thursday, the COA warned against possible landslides and mudslides in mountainous areas.
The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a sea warning for Nanmadol at around 2: 30 a.m. Friday after the typhoon turned north toward Taiwan after making landfall in the Philippines.

Nanmadol, the 27th typhoon reported in the Pacific area this year, was located some 450 kilometers south-southwest of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Hengchun at 11: 30 a.m. Friday, moving in a west-northwest direction, turning north-northeast, toward Taiwan at a speed of about 16 km/h, CWB forecasters said.
The Central Weather Bureau is expected to issue a land warning for Nanmadol at around 2: 30 p.m. Friday should the typhoon continue to sweep in the same direction toward Taiwan.
If Nanmadol makes landfall in Taiwan later Friday or early Saturday, it will be the first typhoon to hit Taiwan in December in the island's recorded meteorological history.

Typhoons are extremely rare in the Western Pacific in December because of the colder weather, according to the CWB meteorologists. The last time that the CWB issued a sea warning for a December typhoon was in 1964.

The weather bureau warned that while approaching Taiwan, typhoon Nanmadol is expected to interact with the northeast monsoon, causing torrential rains in most areas of the island, particularly in the north, northeastern and eastern parts of the country.

Meanwhile, due to heavy rains and strong winds, authorities in Taitung County, eastern Taiwan on Friday morning announced the closure of all public offices and schools for the day. The Taitung airport has been closed on and off since Friday morning, and many flights have been delayed.
All flights to and from Hualien airport in eastern Taiwan have also been suspended, and civil aviation authorities there have given no timetable on when they will be resumed.
Tainan County saw some rare rain Friday morning. Wintertime is usually the dry season in the southern county.
Meanwhile, Mount Ali railway officials announced Friday morning that rail services up the scenic mountain in southern Taiwan would be suspended Friday and Saturday due to the approaching typhoon.

Daniel Wu, deputy director of the Central Weather Bureau, forecast that Nanmadol's influence on Taiwan should peak Saturday, after which the typhoon will sweep away from the island, hopefully on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush set to name ex-chief of police for top security post
Bernard B. Kerik, the street-savvy former New York City police commissioner, has been selected by President Bush to replace Tom Ridge as secretary of homeland security, a senior administration official and associates of Kerik said Thursday. The former announcement would be made Friday.
Wall Street Journal: As crises mount, global aid groups tap Islamic money
As humanitarian crises multiply across the globe, straining Western contributions, relief organizations are moving in on a source of money that has eluded them in recent years: the Islamic world. Muslim governments and individuals have long been generous donors to charity, heeding the Islamic obligation to give a portion of annual savings to the poor. Most of their giving has flowed through Islamic charities that fund their own projects, or directly from one government to another.
Relatively little has gone to the international organizations that do the bulk of the feeding, housing and healing in crises around the world.
Now, these organizations' appeals are getting a better reception in the Islamic world. Donors are looking for more globally respected organizations, while they found that greater contributions to multinational humanitarian efforts can improve their image in the West.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE BUST FAKE-SELLING WEB SITE

TEXT.P: Police arrested a man Friday for selling fake brand-name products on his Web site, according to the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB).
The suspect, Wang Kuo-chieh, was apprehended after police raided his premises in Taipei and found many counterfeit brand-name goods.

A CIB official said Wang. who holds both Republic of China and Canadian nationalities and is fluent in English, operated a Web site that sold the products to overseas customers at a cheap price, which could be as low as one-tenth of the price of the genuine articles.

To stave off police attention, the Web site was written entirely in English and registered under a Yahoo U.S. domain name. He only accepted orders from overseas customers and items were paid for via the online payment system Paypal.
Among the goods seized in the crackdown were bracelets, rings and necklaces with fake brand-name labels, including Chanel, Christian Dior and Louis Vuitton.

The CIB received early this year a report from Chanel's Asia-Pacific regional office that counterfeits of the company's products were being sold on a Web site. Police immediately began an investigation but it was not until Friday that they were able to gather enough evidence that led to the suspect's arrest.
Wang was arrested for violating the Trademark Act.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HANDLING MAINLAND DISSIDENTS' APPEAL: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been handling in an appropriate manner the appeals of two mainland Chinese dissidents seeking political asylum and settlement in third countries, an official of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday.

MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said the government has arranged "in three stages" for mainland Chinese pro-democracy activists Chen Rongli and Yan Peng to settle in third countries in accordance with their wishes.

Relevant government agencies, including the MAC, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of the Interior, have been collaborating in handling Chen and Yan's cases by verifying their identities, respecting their requests and providing assistance, Chiu noted.
Chiu said it takes time and patience in handling such cases.

The MAC vice chairman made the remarks in response to a Reuters report Dec. 1 that 70 mainland dissidents have urged President Chen Shui-bian to free Chen and Yan, who fled to the island earlier this year to seek political asylum.

According to the report, Chen swam to Taiwan in January after finishing an eight-year prison term on the mainland in 2003 for attempting to establish a political party, while Yan swam to Taiwan in June after he was jailed in 2001 for 18 months.

The report quoted Liu Qing, president of the New York-based watchdog Human Rights in China as saying in a statement that "detaining democracy activists who are fleeing persecution on the mainland is hardly consistent with the Chen Shui-bian government's professed emphasis on human rights."

Chiu denied the watchdog's accusation in the statement that Chen and Yan were denied telephone contact with the outside world and not allowed to watch television or listen to the radio while they were detained at the Chinglu Detention Center in Ilan, eastern Taiwan.
He said Chen and Yan have enjoyed the freedom of communication, exchanging dialogue freely with relatives and friends outside Taiwan and officials from the Taiwan Association for Human Rights.
Chiu said it was justifiable to incarcerate Chen and Yan at Chinglu -- a detention center for illegal mainland Chinese immigrants -- because they stole into Taiwan.

Despite this, Chiu argued, based on humanitarian grounds, officials from the MAC and the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation have visited Chen and Yan at the detention center many times over the past several months to gain further understanding of their situations as well as their wishes.

Chiu continued that the MAC has now completed the verification work and is in the process of contacting third countries, including Australia, New Zealand, Canada and the United Kingdom, as well as other democratic nations, in which the dissidents have expressed the wish to settle.
Claiming that the MAC has not dragged its feet in handling the requests, Chiu said that the third countries also need to be given time to ponder the requests.

Chiu said that the government has been active in offering assistance to pro-democracy activists. For instance, he said, the government helped ex-mainland dissident Tang Yuanjun to settle in the United States in 2002 and helped Xu Po settle in the Marshall Islands in 2003.
The Taiwan Association for Human Rights criticized the government at a news conference in early August for its slow progress in handling Chen and Yan's case.

Ku Yu-chen, an association executive, said the government should set up a special task force to handle the case. He also urged the government to formulate a statute governing asylum for political refugees.
"We should work out operational procedures and regulations that meet general international standards and norms in handling political refugee asylum," Ku added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WARNED: TALKING DOLLAR DOWN A 'DANGEROUS GAME'

TEXT.P: The Economist has warned in an editorial in its Dec. 4 issue that it is a "dangerous game" now that American policymakers seem to be talking the dollar down, because people will be reluctant to invest in a currency that will almost certainly depreciate.

The British weekly magazine said America's challenge is not just to cut its budget deficit, but also to persuade existing foreign creditors to hang on to their vast stocks of dollar assets, estimated at US$11 trillion.

A fall in the dollar sufficient to close the U.S. current account deficit might destroy the currency's safe-haven status. This would lead America's creditors to start cashing their checks, causing the dollar to tumble further. Consequently American bond yields, or long-term interest rates, would soar, quite likely causing a deep recession, the Economist said.

The magazine noted that over the past three years, the dollar has fallen 35 percent against the euro and 24 percent against the yen. "But its latest slide is merely a symptom of a worse malaise: the global financial system is under great strain."

The Economist blamed the weak dollar on America's "inappropriate" habits, including rampant government borrowing, furious consumer spending and a huge current-account deficit, estimated to rise to US$825 billion by 2006, or 6.4 percent of America's GDP.

While suggesting that the United States should cut its budget deficit and increase its household saving, the Economist also said China and other Asian economies should let their currencies rise, relieving pressure on the euro.
On the other hand, it said, Europe needs to accept that a weaker dollar will be a good thing if it helps to reduce America's deficit and curb the risk of a future crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: S&P REPORT BASED ON INSUFFICIENT KNOWLEDGE OF TAIWAN: CEPD

TEXT.P: A lack of deep understanding of Taiwan has led the Standard & Poor's Ratings Services (S&P) to slap a negative credit outlook on the island, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng claimed Friday.

Hu was referring to a report released by the world-renowned expert body Tuesday, wherein its outlook for Taiwan was revised to negative from stable as a result of the rising tensions in Taiwan-mainland China relations, high structural fiscal deficits and a growing government debt burden.
Hu admitted that the revision should be viewed as a warning to Taiwan, but claimed it also reflected some "mistaken concepts" about Taiwan that the government must try to address.

On cross-strait relations, Hu pointed out that President Chen Shui-bian has repeatedly expressed his goodwill to the mainland by offering to enhance economic and trade exchanges between the two sides and pledging to maintain peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.
The government is also trying to start negotiations with Beijing on the launch of cross-strait passenger and cargo charter flight services, Hu said.

Hu said the S&P assessment could have been "misled" by the temporary disturbance in the domestic political scene, as it was conducted at a time when Taiwan was gearing up for the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

On the fiscal deficits, Hu said, the government has lessened its capital expenditure over the past few years since Taiwan experienced the first negative economic growth in 50 years in 2001 and an obvious decrease in tax revenue.

However, the deficits as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) started to decline last year as the economy recovered and the economic growth is expected to reach 5.93 percent and even 6 percent this year, Hu noted.
The combined public and private investment is predicted to account for 20 percent of the GDP this year, with the ratio of private investment likely to hit 24 percent of GDP, Hu said.
Hu said he believes S&P will change its opinion of Taiwan after the new figures are released.
Meanwhile, he said, the government's "10 major construction projects, " costing NT$500 billion over a five-year period, will raise the ratio of public investment to a desirable level.
The growth of government investment is forecast at 3.1 percent next year, the first positive figure after five years of negative growth, he added.
