DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., TAIWAN CURRENCY EXCHANGE RATE TO AVERAGE 1:31.7 IN 2005: CIER

TEXT.P: The Taiwan currency against the U.S. dollar is expected to average 31.7: 1 in 2005 if the greenback continues to fall in value while major Asian and European currencies soar by comparison, the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) forecast Friday.
The average NT$-greenback exchange rate is estimated to top 31.34:1 in 2006 if similar conditions persist, CIER researchers said.
At a meeting on global economic prospects for 2005, CIER economists also forecast that Taiwan's economy will advance by 5.91 percent this year, the biggest jump since 2000.
This year, they forecast, Taiwan's domestic investments will top NT$1.94 trillion (US$60.25 billion) , with the growth of investment from the private sector surging a whopping 24.32 percent.
Export and import trade will grow 18.95 percent and 20.18 percent, respectively, for the year, the researchers forecast.
The export trade will post net contributions worth NT$1.14 trillion to the nation's economy, up NT$86.5 billion over the year-earlier level.

The CIER economists foresee less advantageous factors that will adversely impact the growth of the world economies in the coming months, such as continuously rising interest rates in the United States that will in turn drag down investments and productivity, as well as the cooling off of mainland China's overheated economy.
They see increased oil output by oil-producing countries and falling oil prices as potentially advantageous factors.

They also predict uncertainties, including fluctuation trends of interest rates in Japan and the European Union; whether the mainland Chinese economy is able to secure a soft landing; and the political situation in the Middle East.

Meanwhile, the economists also forecast that Taiwan's economy will grow around 4.37 percent in 2005, relatively slower than this year's prospective 5.91 percent, mainly as a result of a slower pace in the world's overall economic advancement, coupled with a rising NT dollar, which will exert a negative impact on the country's export trade, the prime mover behind economic growth.
In 2005, they forecast, Taiwan's per capita income will surpass the US$15,000 level to reach about NT$15,646.

Consumption in the private sector is expected to grow 3 percent, about the same as this year's 2.95 percent, while domestic investment will post a growth of 7.54 percent, relatively much lower than this year's 24.32 percent, the researchers concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Putin Meets Kuchma and Slams a Repeat Vote.
Outgoing President Leonid Kuchma brought Ukraine's disputed election to Moscow on Thursday and won President Vladimir Putin's support for an entirely new election rather than a repeat of the runoff as demanded by the opposition. A grim-faced Putin said a repeat vote would be pointless, during a brief meeting with Kuchma at Vnukovo-2 Airport. "A re-vote could be conducted a third, a fourth, a 25th time, until one side gets the results it needs, " Putin said in televised comments.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR URGES PUBLIC TO TREAT GUIDE DOGS WELL

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou called on the public Friday to treat guide dogs for the blind in the proper manner.

Ma made the remark during a meeting with 10 blind citizens and six guide dogs at Taipei City Hall. The meeting was organized by the Taiwan Guide Dog Association as part of a campaign to allow guide dogs to enter public places.

While guide dogs leading the blind are allowed to enter public places and shops in developed countries, many stores and bus drivers in Taiwan still see them as pets and refuse to allow them entry to their premises and vehicles.
Chang Chiu-hsiung, chairman of the Taiwan Guide Dog Association, urged the public to be aware that guide dogs are not pets but working animals.
The mayor also thanked the guide dogs by awarding them with certificates during the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SAYS HE WILL NOT BE SWAYED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that as a national leader, he will holds his stance firm and will not be easily swayed.
Chen made the remarks when he received U.S. Congressman James Langevin at the Presidential Office.

The president said that after he won a second term in the March 20 presidential election, he felt an ever greater sense of responsibility. As Taiwan is in a very difficult plight, he said that as the nation's leader, he must consider cross-strait relations, international factors and the different views within Taiwan when dealing with national affairs.
With only one week before the crucial Dec. 11 legislative elections, "our stance is firm, and we will not be swayed by other factors," Chen said.

He said Taiwan has the determination to safeguard itself and that the Executive Yuan has proposed a special budget to purchase submarines, anti-submarine aircraft and Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries from the United States.

He told his visitor that if the "pan-green camp" of his party and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, can command a clear majority in the Legislative Yuan, it will facilitate the passing of the arms procurement deal in the legislature.

The president also expressed his appreciation for Langevin's support for Taiwan's bid to be an observer in the World Health Organization, his urging for the United States to abide by its commitment to Taiwan's security in a meeting to mark the 25th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act, and his opposition to the European Union's lifting of an arms embargo against mainland China.

He also apologized to Langevin that first lady Wu Shu-chen, who originally wanted to accompany him to receive the U.S. congressman, was not well enough to be present, but he thanked Langevin for taking time to see Wu during the first lady's visit to Washington, D.C. in 2002.

Chen noted that Langevin was the first U.S. Congressman to serve while paralyzed and that his wife was also paralyzed from the waist down after being run over by a truck 20 years ago. She was also the first legislator in a wheelchair when she was elected as a legislator in 1986.
The president expressed his admiration for Langevin perseverance, noting that he has been confined to a wheelchair for 24 years.

James Huang, vice secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said later that Chen's long-standing stance is seeking a better economy and major reforms to make Taiwan a normal and complete country, and to pursue a lasting cross-strait peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VISITORS TO ENJOY VISA-FREE ENTRY TO JAPAN BEYOND EXPO 2005
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Visitors from Taiwan will enjoy visa-free treatment during and after the EXPO 2005 AICHI, based on revised laws, Japanese Foreign Minister Nobutaka Machimura confirmed Friday.
Machimura told a news conference that the Japanese government has in principle decided to continue to offer visa-free entry to Taiwan visitors after the six-month EXPO 2005 AICHI ends on Sept. 25.

The Japanese government had previously agreed to grant the privilege to Taiwan people entering the country during the EXPO period in an effort to lure a larger number of Taiwan tourists to the exhibition.
According to Machimura, the Japanese government will put forth a special law in January and an amendment to the exit and entry law after April to push through the move in two phases.
Taiwan is Japan's second-largest source of tourists after South Korea, with the number so far this year expected to exceed the 1 million mark next week.
Currently, only visitors from countries that maintain diplomatic ties with Japan are provided with visa-free entry. Tokyo switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1972.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREVALENCE OF OBESITY AMONG TAIWANESE CHILDREN EXPANDS

TEXT.P: The results of a survey released Friday show that the prevalence of obesity among Taiwanese children has increased to 12 percent from 3 percent or 4 percent some 20 years ago, a worrisome phenomena caused mainly by inadequate exercise and overeating.

The report also indicates that the number of female Taiwanese people with a waist of more than 80 cm has been 40 percent of the female population over the past 20 years, far higher than the 20 percent of the males on the island.

However, the prevalence of obesity among males aged over 19 has been growing in recent years, said Chu Nien-feng, a physician at the department of public health of the Taipei-based Tri-Service General Hospital, while announcing the survey results at the two-day Symposium on Nutrition Monitoring and Health Policy Development that opened Friday in Taipei.
Chu noted that weight control measures popular among Taiwanese women might be the reason their obesity rate has not expanded.
The physician said that obesity is linked to deadly diseases such as cardiac and vascular disease, making it important that people control their weight.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLEDGES TO CONTINUE TO DEVELOP KINMEN

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun pledged Friday to continue to enhance community building on Kinmen and to develop the outlying island into an international tourist attraction.

Yu made the remarks during a tour of Kinmen to inspect major development projects such as the Kinmen National Park and the Shuitou port, which operates direct ferry services to the mainland Chinese port of Xiamen.
Yu pointed out that the Kinmen National Park is the sixth of its kind in Taiwan and the first that abounds with heritage, including historic vestiges of wars and nature reserves.

The efforts to maintain traditional communities in Kinmen have been especially remarkable, with the custody of 37 ancient houses having been taken over by the Kinmen National Park Administration and 90 others having been restored, Yu said.
Yu said the preservation of the historic properties will help boost the tourism industry on the island.
Meanwhile, the Council for Cultural Affairs will assist Kinmen with fostering a community-building work force comprising members of Kinmen's younger generation.
Yu said the government has a responsibility to develop Kinmen and Matsu, which have long been the frontline of Taiwan's defenses against mainland China.

The government has budgeted NT$4.3 billion (US$133.54 million) to fund more development projects on Kinmen next year in addition to ongoing projects such as building a cultural park and local culture museum, expanding the Tashan power plant, improving the water resources and upgrading flight safety at the Shangyi airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS TO DEAL WITH ASEAN-PLUS-ONE EFFECT CAUTIOUSLY: THINK TANK

TEXT.P: Taiwan has to deal cautiously with the effects of a free trade agreement (FTA) between the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and mainland China to avoid the hollowing out of its industry, the head of a local think tank said Friday.

Vincent Siew, chairman of the Chung-hua Institution for Economic Research, was referring to the signing of the FTA, dubbed "ASEAN-plus-one" during an ASEAN summit meeting in Laos Monday, with the aim of creating the world's largest free trade area -- a sprawling market of 1.8 billion people -- by 2010.
Under the agreement, both sides have set a timetable for cutting tariffs starting next July, with tariffs on 7,000 items to be cut to between zero percent and 0.5 percent by 2010.
Siew noted that Japan and South Korea are also keen to begin FTA discussions with ASEAN. Even India, Australia and New Zealand could sign similar agreements, he added.
This "ASEAN-plus-six" would usher in a completely new era very different to the situation that exists at present, he said.

He said the most adverse impact on Taiwan of an expanded ASEAN would be the exodus of local manufacturers to places with low or no tariffs unless Taiwan can produce goods that the world needs, which he said is unlikely at present.

The former premier and economics expert expressed worry that if the government cannot come up with a strategy to cope with the changes in five years, the worst scenario could be a further hollowing out of Taiwan's industry.

"With Taiwan's economic strength, there is no reason, other than objections from Beijing, for it to be shut out of an East Asia free trade area." He added that with its rising economic might, the mainland is playing the role of a locomotive to orchestrate Asian integration.
"Without the consent of China, it will be difficult for Taiwan to seek cooperation with ASEAN," Siew said.

"The real impact will start from 2010, " he said, urging the government to think carefully about how to make a breakthrough in the next five or six years, adding that a resolution of the cross-strait impasse will be crucial if Taiwan is to have any chance of joining the major trade bloc.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO CONSIDER EXPANDING 'MINI THREE LINKS': PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun Friday ordered the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) to study the possibility of expanding the "mini three links" between Taiwan and mainland China.
Yu issued the directive in response to a proposal by Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng during an inspection tour of the frontline island.

Kinmen and Matsu maintain direct trade, transport and postal services with the mainland Chinese ports of Xiamen and Fuzhou -- generally known as the "mini three links." However, the services are applicable only to local residents of Kinmen and Matsu and Taiwanese businessmen with operations on the mainland.

Lee said it is time the government reviewed its "mini three links" policy, as the mainland will soon allow its nationals to travel to Kinmen for sightseeing purposes, with arrivals estimated at 600 people per day.

According to Lee's proposal, the services should be expanded to apply to Kinmen-born and Matsu-born people residing on Taiwan and a five-day, four-night package tour to Kinmen and Xiamen should be launched to attract Taiwanese tourists.
Meanwhile, international tourists and overseas Chinese should be allowed to travel to Xiamen via the "mini three links" and transfer from Kinmen to Taiwan, Lee suggested.
Also, Lee proposed that the government set up an export processing zone on Kinmen and permit imports of mainland workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 231 DOMESTIC FIRMS ALLOWED TO RUN OPERATIONS HUBS AT HOME

TEXT.P: A government project to have Taiwan companies retain their value-added operations at home has made noticeable progress, as more than 200 local businesses have gained approval to do so over the past two years, an expert said Friday.

Tsai Hui-mei, a researcher at the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, said that a total of 231 domestic companies were verified as qualified as of Nov. 25 to set up their business operations centers at home amid their globalization efforts since the government launched the plan in 2002.
The project is overseen by the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs in cooperation with the institution under the auspices of the Executive Yuan.

According to Tsai, 191 companies from the manufacturing sector, including the Hon Hai Group, the Acer Group, the BenQ Group and Quanta Computer, and 22 from the service sector, such as the Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp., Shanghai Commercial and Savings Bank Ltd., and the President Chain Store Group, gained government permits to run a business operations hub from Taiwan.

The opening of a business operations center at home will allow these operations to enjoy greater access to land acquisition and talent recruitment, including hi-tech personnel from mainland China and other countries, as well as lower tax rates and production costs, Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SUSPENDS FRIDAY, SATURDAY CAMPAIGN ACTIVITIES DUE TO TYPHOON

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has instructed the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to suspend all campaign activities Friday and Saturday because of the approach of Typhoon Nanmadol, DPP officials said.

DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said that he was notified by the Presidential Office that the key campaign managers for the DPP -- Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh and Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang -- must prepare for disaster relief efforts, should they be necessary.
A Saturday rally in Taipei that was expected to draw 100,000 people has also been canceled out of concern for the safety of the participants, he said.

Lee Ying-yuan, a deputy DPP secretary-general, said that Nanmadol is the first typhoon to hit Taiwan in the winter and is unpredictable, adding that the president called him Friday morning to tell him that the focus of the nation's officials must now be on disaster relief and prevention.

Along with the Taipei rally, the DPP had scheduled a large campaign event for Saturday night in Kaohsiung, with President Chen and former President Lee Teng-hui attending to cement support for candidates from the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).

The DPP has now rescheduled the events. Former President Lee and Chen will appear at a rally on Dec. 8 and a number of DPP luminaries will give speeches on the eve of the Dec. 11 legislative elections. Venues for the campaign events have yet to be decided.
The DPP hopes that it and the TSU can win a clear majority in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.

Meanwhile, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said that a large-scale rally planned for Sunday in Taipei will be held as scheduled. It will revolve around the theme of "unity and safeguarding the Republic of China." Weathermen predict that northern Taiwan will be out of the influence of the typhoon by that time.

The pro-independence TSU also said that a rally to advocate "rectifying the name of the country, writing a new constitution and establishing a Taiwan nation" will go on as planned on Sunday in Taipei.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who concurrently serves as a KMT vice chairman, canceled his stumping trips in central and southern Taiwan Friday and Saturday to take charge of disaster relief and prevention in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUTSAL CHAMPIONSHIP TO RAISE SOCCER INTEREST IN TAIWAN: TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Holding the 2004 FIFA Futsal World Championship in Taipei is a way to create interest in soccer in Taiwan, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Friday.
Ma made the remarks when he received Mohammed Bin Hammam, president of the Asian Football Confederation.
The mayor said that there are an estimated 100,000 fans of the game in Taiwan and one goal is to organize local leagues such that over the next three years, 100 teams can be formed.

The 2004 FIFA Futsal World Championship is being held at the National Taiwan University and the National College of Physical Education and Sports between Nov. 21 and Dec. 5, with 16 countries competing.
Currently, the final round of the tournament is underway, with teams from Brazil, Spain, Argentina and Italy competing for the championship.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS PROPER PRECAUTIONS BE TAKEN AGAINST TYPHOON NANMADOL

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun Friday ordered authorities to take proper precautions against damage likely to be caused by Typhoon Nanmadol.
Yu urged the public to be watchful of the storm, a very rare one to hit the island in the winter, according to Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai.

In light of the large number of temporary campaign signboard and banners set up in the streets around Taiwan ahead of the Dec. 11 legislative elections, Yu demanded local governments to take measures to prevent the loosely installed posters and banners from coming loose and hitting neighboring buildings, cars and people.
Yu also instructed the Water Resources Agency to closely monitor the rise of rivers and make sure all pumping facilities are operating properly.

While early warnings must be issued to residents living downstream should authorities preparing to drain a reservoir, authorities must plan in advance measures to evacuate residents living in flood-prone and mudslide-prone areas, Yu said.
Meanwhile, Yu requested authorities to broadcast information on the typhoon through the fishery radio station so that boats operating in the sea could prepare themselves for the storm.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ALLOW M'LAND SHIPS TO SEEK SHELTER AT TUNGSHA ISLANDS

TEXT.P: Hainan-registered mainland Chinese fishing ships will be allowed to wait out Typhoon Nanmadol in the Tungsha (Pratas) Islands as a humanitarian gesture, officials from the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) said Friday.

However, the Taiwan officials said that the mooring facilities at the Tungsha Islands are only rudimentary, and docking there could be dangerous. They told mainland Chinese officials that it would be safer if the boats returned to the mainland.

The officials said that they received a message from the Chinese Rescue Association via the Mainland Affairs Council Thursday that said that there are around 45 Hainan-registered mainland Chinese fishing vessels with 1,125 people operating in waters near the Tungsha Islands, located 240 nautical miles southwest of Kaohsiung, and that they planed to seek haven in the Tungsha Islands.
As of Friday afternoon, there were still 24 Chinese fishing boats near the Tungsha Islands.

The officials called on all ships operating in the Bashi Channel, Tungsha waters and the Taiwan Strait to be on high alert, urging them to sail to nearby harbors to sit out Typhoon Nanmadol, the first typhoon ever to hit Taiwan in December.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS LEADERS URGE CENTRAL BANK TO WATCH RISING LOCAL CURRENCY

TEXT.P: The central bank should keep a close eye on the rise in the new Taiwan dollar, as a rapidly surging local currency has kept increased pressure on domestic companies, officials of various prominent business associations said Friday.

Lo Huai-chia, an executive of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association, said that domestic exporters are facing strong pressure due to the rising new Taiwan dollar and he urged the Central Bank of China (CBC) to do something to avert a further appreciation of the local unit to keep the country competitive.

Pointing out that the recent strengthening of the new Taiwan dollar is just an effect of an influx of international hot money rather than an upgrading of Taiwan companies' competitive edge, Lo argued that the CBC should not sit idly by and allow for manipulated profiteering.
He forecast that the local currency will appreciate rapidly again should the daily transaction value in the domestic market surpass the US$1 billion level.

He strongly suspects that much of the foreign hot money has moved to mainland China or other countries on the grounds that the domestic stock market's weighted index remains below 6,000 points. He called on the government to pay special heed to the situation.

The currency ended at NT$32.2 against the U.S. dollar on the same day in the Taipei foreign exchange market, a fall of NT$0.21 from Thursday's finish of NT$31.99 -- a key psychological barrier for many businesses.

Chen Cheng-i, spokesman for the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China, claimed that the recent gain by the local currency against the greenback from NT$35 to NT$32 has been quite obvious, putting Taiwan companies in a very difficult situation to flight against low-priced products from mainland China.
The sole comfort for Taiwan businesses for the time being is that the Japanese yen and the South Korean won have strengthened more than the new Taiwan dollar, he added.
During the October-November period, the new Taiwan dollar appreciated by some 3 percent against the U.S. dollar, a range lower than the 4.5 percent posted by the euro and other Asian currencies.

Industry analysts predicted that Taiwan's hi-tech sectors will suffer bigger losses than expected in their revenues figured in U.S. dollars, in particular notebook computer and motherboard makers, if the local unit continues to rise.

To effectively minimize the impact of a stronger new Taiwan dollar, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh a day earlier urged domestic industries to make currency exchange hedge efforts for the short term and sharpen their productivity for the long term.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, SENEGAL DISCUSSING FIVE-YEAR COOPERATION PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Senegal are discussing a five-year cooperation program which will further bolster bilateral relations, officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday.
The officials said that Senegalese State Minister Cheikh Tidiane Sy held talks with Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen on the matter during his just-concluded visit to Taiwan.
The officials declined to give details but said that Sy left for the United States Friday after concluding a five-day visit in Taiwan.
During the visit, they added, Sy also met with President Chen Shui-bian and delivered a personal letter from Senegalese President Abdoulaye Wade.

The Senegalese minister told Chen during the meeting that Senegal greatly appreciates its relations with Taiwan and the assistance Taiwan has extended to it in infrastructure construction, education, agriculture, social welfare and others, and that both the people and government of Senegal are satisfied with the results of cooperation with Taiwan, according to the MOFA officials.
Sy also conveyed Wade's regards to Chen during the meeting while promising Chen that Senegal will continue supporting Taiwan in the international community.

In response, the officials said, Chen told his guest that Taiwan is willing to further strengthen cooperation with Senegal and that he is pleased to see the two countries getting closer based on the common values of democracy, human rights and freedom.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INCREASINGLY OPEN TO MORE MAINLAND GOODS: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan has always been pushing for normalized trade ties with mainland China and the government will increasingly open the Taiwan market to mainland products, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Friday.

Ho made the remarks in a year-end gathering with members of the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT), many of whom urged Taiwan to open its markets wider to foreign imports, including those from mainland China, to help them lower production costs.
ECCT members asked the Ministry of Economic Affairs to permit an additional 200 products from the mainland to enter Taiwan, including automobile accessories and cell phones.

Ho promised to do this and said that the Bureau of Foreign Trade under her ministry is moving toward the goal by periodically revising a mainland import list every two months. Mainland products that have less impact on Taiwan's industries will be first allowed in, she noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL ACQUIRES SYNDICATE LOAN OF NT$5 BILLION FOR NEW AIRCRAFT

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) , Taiwan's largest carrier, inked a syndicate loan agreement Friday with the Bank of Taiwan, securing a 12-year loan worth NT$5 billion (US$156 million) for planned purchases of 747-400 jet planes.
CAL Chairman Chiang Yao-chung and Bank of Taiwan Chairman Lu Chi-cheng clinched the accord on behalf of the two sides.

According to Chiang, the purchase plan forms a key part of the airlines' efforts to phase out its aging planes. By the end of this year, CAL will own a fleet of 63 planes, which will be further expanded next year with the delivery of three 747-400 cargo planes, two 747-400 passenger planes and five Airbus 330-300 jets, he added.

The syndicate loan at an annual interest rate of 1.87 percent is the most preferential long-term loan that the carrier has in recent years ever acquired, Chiang said, adding that the loan is expected to help CAL save estimated costs of NT$150 million in the face of a rising new Taiwan dollar.
The syndicate loan is provided by a seven-member banking group led by the Bank of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR DEC. 4 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, Dec. 4:
09: 00, A roundtable meeting on Taiwan-Japan exchanges organized by the Association of East Asia Relations will be held at the Grand Formosa Regent Taipei.
10: 00, The opening ceremony of the 2004 Information Technology Month activities will be held at the Taipei World Trade Center.
10: 00, The 2004 Graduate Schools Expo will open at the Taipei World Trade Center.
14: 00, The 2004 Non-smoking restaurant awards ceremony will be held at Howard Hotel in Taipei.
18:00, The 2004 Golden Horse Awards ceremony will open at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taichung City, central Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO TAKE MEASURES TO DEAL WITH IMPACT OF ASEAN-CHINA FTA

TEXT.P: The government will take a series of measures to deal with effects of a free trade agreement between the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and mainland China, a government official said Friday.

Yeh Jun-rong, chairman of the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) , said that his commission had presented proposals for relevant government agencies' reference in dealing with the ASEAN-China FTA impact based on a study by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) under the RDEC's commission.

On the economic and trade aspect, Yeh noted that the government will use the World Trade Organization's framework to promote substantive bilateral ties with other nations and will support trade liberalization based on multilateralism.

The government will also actively seek to sign an FTA or a closer economic partnership agreement (CEPA) with the United States, Japan and ASEAN nations and to seek the possibility of forming a free trade area with Japan and South Korea, he went on, adding that Taiwan will continue to promote its trade liberalization.
Also, he said, Taiwan will continue to promote the implementation of Bogor goals of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

With regard to domestic enterprises, Yeh said that the government will provide them study results and analyses of effects that various international economic integrations may bring to Taiwan for their reference and encourage them to set up overseas strongholds to enjoy benefits brought by FTAs.

The government will also encourage private organizations to take part in international discussions on the impact of regionalism to Taiwan and will help Taiwan businesses establish regional trade networks.

In the long-term, Yeh said, Taiwan will actively improve its investment environment, facilitate the development of non-trade industries in the nation, increase domestic demand and sharpen the nation's international competitiveness.

In the political field, Yeh said that the government will highlight the unjustified economic sanction-like treatment toward Taiwan by the international community by shutting out Taiwan from all bilateral and multilateral free trade areas.
Moreover, Taiwan will continue to enhance bilateral ties with ASEAN nations by offering them a generalized system of preferences.

According to an estimate by the RDEC, Yeh said, Taiwan will suffer losses of around NT$4.7 billion (US$146 million) a year, or 0.05 percent of its gross domestic product, due to the implementation of the ASEAN-China FTA signed Monday in Laos.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPAIN, ITALY ADVANCE TO FUTSAL WORLD CHAMPIONSHIP FINAL

TEXT.P: Spain and Italy advanced to the 2004 Futsal World Championship final Friday by defeating Brazil and Argentina, respectively, in the semifinals.
Repeating a drama to win the world championship in Guatemala four years ago, Spain beat Brazil 5:4 on penalties after two hours of the highest quality of futsal tied at 2:2.
In the other semifinal game played on that same day, Italy overpowered Argentina 7:4.
Spain and Italy will compete for the championship Dec. 5 while Brazil and Argentina will vie for the third place of the tournament.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 4, or the 23rd day of the 10th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1154: Nicholas Breakspeare becomes the first Englishman to become the pope.
1795: Thomas Carlyle, Scottish historian and essayist, is born. His works include "Sartor Resartus" and "The French Revolution."
1892: Gen. Francisco Franco, Spanish dictator from 1939 until his death in 1975, is born.
1893: Britain and France reach an agreement on Siam (Thailand).
1912: Turkey reaches an armistice with all the Balkan allies except Greece.
1947: Tennessee Williams' play "A Streetcar Named Desire" premiers on Broadway, with Marlon Brando and Jessica Tandy in the leading roles.
1936: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of the Republic of China leaves Loyang for Xian to meet with Chang Hsueh-liang.
1939: Wu Pei-fu, a noted Chihli faction general of the Peiyang army, China's first modern fighting force, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 66.
1963: Pope Paul VI approves the decision of the Roman Catholic Vatican Council to authorize the use of vernacular languages instead of Latin in performing the sacraments.
1963: The Kuomintang Central Standing Committee approves the resignation of ROC Premier Chen Cheng, who is concurrently serving as the vice president, and names Yen Chia-kan as the new premier.
1965: The United States successfully launches "Gemini 7," which would orbit the earth for a record 14 days.
1966: Beijing's Red Guard arrests communist leaders such as Peng Chen, Tien Han and Wan Li.
1973: Jordanian Minister of Tourism and Antiquities Ghaleb Z. Barakat arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1975: The Third Conference of East Asia Economists opens in Taipei with 30 Japanese and 50 Chinese delegates attending.
1975: Defense Minister Kao Kuei-yuan announces that the fighting capability of the ROC armed forces has nearly quintupled over the last quarter of a century.
1975: Willem Pretorius, the new South African consul-general to the ROC, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1976: The Central African Republic becomes the Central African Kingdom, and President Jean Bedel Bokassa is crowned king.
1976: A seminar on agricultural engineering and development is held at National Taiwan University to mark the 60th anniversary of the establishment of the Chinese Agriculture Society.
1977: A hijacked Malaysian airliner carrying 100 people crashes in Singapore, killing everyone onboard.
1989: Members of East Germany's Politburo and Central Committee resign, and Head of State Egon Krenz is forced to step down only six weeks after replacing a beleaguered Erich Hoenecker.
1994: U.S. Secretary of Transportation Federico Pena visits the ROC, becoming the first U.S. secretary to carry out the new U.S. policy governing high-ranking official visits to Taipei.
1998: A trial is held in Shanghai for a Chinese entrepreneur accused of providing e-mail addresses to an online democracy magazine.
1999: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian leaves for a five-day European visit.
2000: The fourth Global Semiconductor Industry Seminar opens in the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, with more than 200 of the leading lights of the global semiconductor sector participating.
2000: David Yen, one of Taiwan's most prominent anti-smoking activists, is granted a Thai royal decoration in Taipei for his contributions toward successfully controlling tobacco consumption in Thailand.
2001: Kinmen Deputy Magistrate Yen Ta-jen goes to Xiamen City opposite to the Taiwan-held frontline island aboard a passenger vessel for a four-day visit, the first of its kind for a Republic of China official in more than 50 years.
2001: The remains of 14 crew members of a surveillance aircraft affiliated with the former Republic of China Air Force's 34th Squadron, nicknamed the Black Bats Squadron, that was shot down by mainland Chinese fighters in Jiangxi province nearly four decades ago are airlifted back to Taiwan.
Motse's lesson of the day: "The interest of the wise ruler lies in carrying out what makes for order among the people and avoiding what makes for confusion. When the administration of the ruler answers the desires of the people, there will be order, otherwise there will be confusion."

President Bush will name Bernard Kerik, a plain-spoken career law enforcement officer who was New York City's police commissioner during the Sept. 11 attacks, as secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, senior administration officials said.

DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: P1-M typhoon aid for each town - GMA
President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo yesterday ordered the immediate release of P1 million for each town most affected by the series of calamities that hit the country for them to begin their own relief and rehabilitation efforts.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Arroyo: Together we'll rise as one
"It is time for the country to come together, for individuals to do heroic deeds together, for everyone to help in whatever way, for all to reach out to those who need help," President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo said yesterday in the wake of four tropical cyclones that ravaged a wide area of Luzon.
The Philippine Star: 'Yoyong' barrels out to sea
Super typhoon "Yoyong" blew out of the country into Taiwan's area of responsibility yesterday, sparing eastern and northern Luzon from additional destruction but leaving 35 people dead, 13 missing and nine injured.
The Manila Times: Unburied bodies pose health threat
Disease is now the biggest threat to those who survived this week's savage storms, which decimated large sections of Eastern Luzon, health officials said on Friday.

DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times:PM calls for bold, new moves for a global city.
As a city, Singapore cannot afford to slacken. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong yesterday raised the ante for urban planners, builders and architects by identifying how Singapore can be transformed into a global city.
He gave four approaches but they boil down to one stark challenge: giving Singapore the X- factor.
The quality eludes definition but looking ahead, Mr Lee is clear on what is needed for the city of Singapore to grab the world's attention: boldness, experimentation, setting new standards and pushing new frontiers.
The Lianhe Zaobao:PM Lee: Build the unique Singapore city.

Bush will name Bernard Kerik, a career law-enforcement officer who was New York City's police commissioner during the Sept. 11 attacks, as secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, senior administration officials said Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL WEATHER BUREAU PARTIALLY LIFTS TYPHOON WARNING

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau lifted its warning against Typhoon Nanmadol in some areas Saturday as the storm moved quickly away from Taiwan.

The northern part of the island was clear of the typhoon's influence at around noon, weather officials said, adding that the typhoon warning in other parts of the island will be lifted later in the day.
Noting that Nanmadol has weakened to a mild storm, the officials said it is not expected to have a great impact on Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST REACH OUT FOR CEPA WITH OTHER NATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan must develop Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement (CEPA) with other nations to soften the impact that will result from the new free trade agreement (FTA) between the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and mainland China, an economics official said Saturday.

Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, was responding to the FTA signed by China and ASEAN Monday during an ASEAN summit in Laos, under which both sides agreed to lower all tariffs starting next July and cut tariffs for 7,000 items to between zero percent and 0.5 percent by 2010.

Hu noted that the new agreement and one that might be made in the future with ASEAN and Japan and South Korea will have an adverse impact on Taiwan, but he has some reservations as to whether the new cooperation framework would run as smoothly as the signatories believe.
He said that there will be difficulties during bilateral discussions and that during this time, Taiwan has to actively advocate its inclusion.
"With Taiwan's economic strength, it should be 'ASEAN plus four," with Taiwan being the fourth," he said.

But he pointed out that signing an FTA will involve issues of national sovereignty, which would put Taiwan at a disadvantage. As the CEPA does not involve sovereign issues, Hu said it should be easier for Taiwan to reach CEPA agreements with its major trading partners.
He said Taiwan should step up efforts in CEPA negotiations to minimize the impact of the China-ASEAN FTA.
Nevertheless, he said Taiwan must also continue trying to be included in an FTA with the ASEAN, Hu said, adding that if negotiators from Taiwan can convince one member state, others should follow.

He noted that Taiwan currently has only signed an FTA with Panama, and it needs to do more in this aspect, adding that some have suggested that in addition to seeking to be included in FTAs, Taiwan could also look for opportunities to develop CEPAs.

In addition, to avoid being excluded from regional economic integration blocs, Taiwan must also seek cooperation with nations outside ASEAN, although Taiwan must keep a low profile to avoid being harassed by mainland China.
A day earlier, the head of a local think tank warned that the biggest adverse impact for Taiwan of an expanded ASEAN would be Taiwan's manufacturers flocking to low-tariff areas.

Vincent Siew, chairman of the Chung-hua Institution for Economic Research, said that he was worried that the government will not be able to come up with a strategy to deal with the new situation in Asia by 2010, with the worst-case scenario being the "hollowing out of Taiwan's industry."

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTRY TO DEAL HARSHLY WITH BOGUS BUSINESS TAX REBATES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance said Saturday that it will be relentless in its crackdown on rogue manufacturers who try to claim business tax rebates through false export documents.

In view of the growing number of cases of manufacturers who lie about export prices or obtain false documents to try to claim a business tax rebate of 5 percent later, officials have been paying more attention to certain business dealings that could be manipulated.

Finance officials said that they recently busted six companies engaging in this illegal practice, among them a high-tech company that inflated the export price to falsely claim over NT$10 million (US$312,500) in business tax rebates. The company later had to pay the tax as well as a fine of NT$70 million.
The officials said that to maintain a just tax system and to crack down on tax evasion, steep fines will be imposed on violators.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. UNIVERSITY OPENS TAIWAN STUDIES RESOURCE CENTER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: George Washington University in Washington, D.C. inaugurated a resource center on Taiwan studies Friday as part of is efforts to reinforce research on Taiwan's history and contemporary developments.
David Ta-wei Lee, the Republic of China representative to the United States, was invited to cut the ribbon to open the Taiwan Studies Resource Center at the inaugural ceremony.
Lee thanked the university for establishing the resource center.
The center is the first of its kind ever established in the United States. Several public and private institutions in Taiwan have donated books and periodicals to help enrich its collection.

Lee said even though Taiwan-U.S. trade reaches US$50 billion annually and the two countries have cooperated closely in maintaining peace in the Asia-Pacific region and in countering terrorism, there still exist barriers to mutual understanding between them because of a combination of factors, including the absence of formal diplomatic ties, the language barrier, geographic distance and cultural differences.

Lee said he is hopeful that the new resource center will not only serve George Washington University students for Taiwan studies but can also become a U.S. think tank and even an information center for U.S. authorities.

The Taiwan Studies Resource Center at George Washington University's library collects numerous Chinese and English books and periodicals on Taiwan history and contemporary developments as well as magazines and newspapers published in Taiwan. The center is connected with Taiwan's major academic institutions through the Internet.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE SPEAKER ATTACKS DPP FOR POOR PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng on Saturday criticized the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as performing poorly in administering the country, claiming the problem will worsen if the party gains majority control in the legislature after the Dec. 11 elections.
Wang, who is also a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), blamed the DPP for sending Taiwan's economic growth plummeting to 5.27 percent from the 9 percent registered during the KMT rule.
While one million people have migrated to mainland China, two million people are on the verge of unemployment, and the gap between rich and poor is widening, Wang said.

Wang further accused the DPP of squandering away taxpayers' money, saying the DPP government has spent NT$8.2 trillion (US$254.65 billion) in five years, compared with only NT$5.7 trillion during the previous five years in which the KMT ruled.

Refuting the DPP's claim that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and People First Party is hampering the country's development by being antagonistic toward the government, Wang said the opposition-controlled legislature passed nearly 600 legislative bills in the past five years, which he said is even more effective than the time when the DPP was in the opposition.

Furthermore, Wang said the DPP's maneuvering the ethnic issue has severely divided Taiwan society and that the DPP's provocative manner in handling cross-Taiwan Strait relations is providing the country a negative outlook.
Wang claimed the "pan-blue alliance" must be allowed to maintain majority control in the legislature to ensure the security of Taiwan.

On reports that KMT Chairman Lien Chan plans to announce three days before the legislative elections that he will step down from the chairmanship after the vote, Wang said he has no knowledge about this matter.
Lien has denied the reports.
Wang had previously said that he would not rule out the possibility of running for KMT chairman.
In response to Wang's criticism, DPP lawmakers said Wang hopes the "pan-blue alliance" will continue to dominate the legislature because he wants to retain his speakership in the legislature.

Tsai Huang-liang, the whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said Wang is responsible for the disorder in the Legislative Yuan, as he has always sided with the "pan-blue alliance" and failed in his role as a neutral mediator.
Tsai said he does not think Lien will step down from the KMT leadership even if the KMT suffers a setback in the upcoming elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL WEATHER BUREAU LIFTS SEA, LAND WARNINGS FOR TYPHOON NANMADOL

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau lifted sea and land warnings for Typhoon Nanmadol at 2:30 p.m. Saturday.

Bureau meteorologists said the strength of the rare December typhoon was greatly reduced after it made landfall in southern Taiwan's Fungliao township, Pingtung County at 7: 40 a.m. It left eastern Taiwan's Taimali township, Taitung County for sea at 9: 30 a.m.

A woman was killed during the storm when she was hit by a flying billboard while riding her scooter in Tainan County. Rescuers are currently searching for two people who went missing in Hualien. One was swept into a river while driving, and the other was engulfed in a mudslide as he was checking his water main.
Sixty-two places around the island reported rainfall of more than 300 mm over a 24-hour period. The Pulowan mountainous community in eastern Hualien County recorded 800mm of rain.
No major casualties were reported in Taipei, but Mayor Ma Ying-jeou urged the public to be on alert as there could still be heavy rain.
In Taipei, Yangmingshan registered the most rainfall in the mountainous area at 160 mm, while Nankang registered the most in the plains at 125 mm.
The Council of Agriculture (COA) estimated that the typhoon caused agricultural losses of NT$2.60 million (US$81,250).
COA officials said that 675 hectares of fields in Pingtung County were damaged, with crops of wax apples, watermelons and onions being the most severely affected.
The Ministry of Transportation and Communications said that as of 10 a.m., Nanmadol had damaged 12 highways, with the most problems in eastern Taiwan and Kaohsiung.

Taiwan Power Company reported that electricity was briefly interrupted in some areas in the counties of Kaohsiung, Changhua, Yunlin and Hualien, affecting 94,334 households. Except for 231 households in Tiensiang, Hualien, 99.8 percent of homes have resumed normal power supply.

Falling rocks onto mountainous roads in the scenic Tiensiang area have hampered repair work, Taipower said. However, after the roads are clear Sunday, the power supply can be resumed quickly to those still without electricity.
Meanwhile, weathermen said that the island can expect a cold front to hit, with temperatures dropping to around 12 degrees Celsius between Sunday night and early Monday morning in some coastal areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU LAWMAKER QUESTIONS POLICE DECISION TO PERMIT 'PAN-BLUE' RALLY

TEXT.P: The Taipei City police should not have issued permits allowing two rival parties to have rallies on the same day in the same city, Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Legislator Chen Chien-ming, said Saturday.

Both the "pan-blue alliance, " made up of supporters of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) , and the TSU plan to mobilize more than 100,000 people to attend events on Sunday afternoon ahead of the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
While the "pan-blue alliance" will march from the Taipei City Council offices to the Legislative Yuan, the TSU will gather on Ketagelan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.
Chen pointed out that the TSU filed its application with the police a month ago on Nov. 3, and the application by the "pan-blue alliance" was filed much later than that.
He said the police are negligent for issuing the two permits since the potential for conflict between the parties with different political views is obvious.

Also, Chen said, the TSU has received information indicating that some radical supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" might take the opportunity to attack former President Lee Teng-hui, who will participate in the TSU rally.

In addition to promoting the writing of a new constitution and rectifying the name of the country, Lee will also try to give voters a clear idea of the differences between the TSU and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in order to consolidate the TSU's support base in the elections, sources said.

In response to Chen's concerns, officials at the Taipei City Police Department said the two rallies were permitted according to law and that the order in which the applications were submitted was not a consideration.
A large police force will be deployed to maintain order at the rallies to prevent any violent incidents, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTORCADES, RALLIES PLANNED AS CAMPAIGNING ENTERS HOME STRETCH

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) announced Saturday that major party campaign managers will lead motorcades in central Taiwan Sunday as stumping for the Dec. 11 legislative elections enters the home stretch.

Su Tseng-chang, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said that looking at the breakdown of the vote count in the presidential elections in 2000 and 2004, one can see that the DPP gained 13 percent in central Taiwan over the past four years, with Taichung County jumping 15 percent.

But he said that the DPP hasn't fully reached all of its potential supporters for the upcoming elections, shown by the fact that the support for one political party is higher than for individual candidates. Since many of the DPP's candidates are not so well known this time, the party must do all it can to help them raise their visibility.

Su estimated that the DPP can gain four seats over what it currently holds; this and the two to three seats from the Taiwan Solidarity Union, the ally of the DPP, will ensure that the "pan-green camp" wins a clear majority in the 225-seat legislature.

DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung will lead a motorcade in Nantou, while Premier Yu Shyi-kun will lead one in Changhuwa. Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh will lead a motorcade in Taichung, and Su himself will lead a procession of campaign vehicles in Yunlin. The motorcades will converge in Fengyuan, Taichung County before heading toward Taichung City to meet with President Chen Shui-bian.

Lee Ying-yuan, a deputy DPP secretary-general, also announced that there will be a big rally in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Thursday, or the eve of the 25th anniversary of the "Kaohsiung Incident" -- a pro-democracy peaceful rally in 1979 in which political dissidents used the occasion of marking the Dec. 10 World Human Rights Day to criticize the government. The day ended in police raids and arrests. Some participants, including Vice President Annette Lu, were jailed.

Lee said that this will be a rally that is expected to draw 50,000 people in front of the Kaohsiung Museum of Fine Arts that night, and the party is arranging for President Chen to appear with former President Lee Teng-hui.

Lee noted that President Chen, DPP Secretary-General Chang, Kaohsiung Mayor Hsieh, and Presidential Secretary-General Su were all defense lawyers for the defendants of the "Kaohsiung Incident, " and they will all be at the campaign event.

Lee noted that 25 years ago, the supporters carried torches, but the supporters will carry roses and lanterns Thursday to try to revitalize the spirit of human rights, love and peace in memory of the night the "Kaohsiung Incident" took place.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISABLED CANADIAN OFFICIAL RECEIVES FIRST LADY OF TAIWAN AWARD

TEXT.P: Lawrence Euteneier, a visually impaired staff member at the Canadian Department of Industry, received the 2004 First Lady of Taiwan/The Wu Shu-jen Career Award at a World Disabled Day celebration dinner in Ottawa Friday.

Chen Tung-pi, the Republic of China representative to Canada, presented the award to Euteneier on behalf of the ROC first lady at the Celebration of People Awards Dinner at Tudor Hall in the Canadian capital.

Euteneier has headed a team of engineers and programmers at the Canadian Department of Industry in setting up a "Web-4-All" Web site with special software and hardware designs to enable the physically challenged to surf the Internet easily.

Chen read Wu's congratulatory message at the presentation ceremony. Wu thanked Euteneier for offering her and the people of Taiwan an opportunity to express concern and friendship for disabled Canadian people through the presentation of the award.
On behalf of Wu, Chen also presented a book detailing Wu's visit to the United States in 2002, titled "Journey of Democracy and Goodwill," to Euteneier.

The events organizers presented an outstanding achievement award to Wu in 2002 in recognition of her efforts in public service despite her disability. Wu has been paralyzed from the waist down since being run over by a small truck in 1985. With Wu's consent, the ROC representative office has since set up the First Lady of Taiwan/The Wu Shu-jen Career Award to be presented annually as part of Canada's celebration of Dec. 2 World Disabled Day.

This is the third consecutive year that the award has been presented to honor outstanding Canadian professionals with disabilities. Several Canadian lawmakers, including Sen. Mac Harb and Rep. Don Boudria, and former Ottawa Mayor Jacquelin Holzman, were on hand to witness the presentation ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, CHINA URGED TO BE MORE FLEXIBLE FOR CROSS-STRAIT RESOLUTION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 4 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China should be more flexible and practical in finding a resolution that is acceptable to both sides to end their deadlock, an American scholar said Saturday.

David Shambaugh, director of the China Policy Program at the Elliott School of International Affairs of George Washington University, made the remarks during a seminar on cross-Taiwan Strait relations organized by the school.
Shambaugh said it will not help solve any problem for Taipei and Beijing to insist on preconditions that the other side will never accept.
For example, China has been trying to sell its "one country, two systems" formula for unification despite the fact that very few people in Taiwan are in favor of this proposal, Shambaugh said.
On the other hand, Taiwan is insisting that it is an independent sovereign state, which is objected to by Beijing and finds little support from Washington, Shambaugh said.
He said remarks by U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell in October that "Taiwan does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation" should not be taken as a slip of the tongue.
He suggested that Taiwan and China consider the model of the European Union, which he said is closest to the positions of the two sides.
Michael Swaine, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, urged Beijing to drop its "one China" principle on reopening dialogue with Taipei.

Swaine said China should seriously consider President Chen Shui-bian's proposals to restart talks based on the basis of the first cross-strait meeting in Hong Kong in 1992 and to discuss the issue of "one China" with Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS PROMISING ECONOMIC OUTLOOK DESPITE GLOBAL RECESSION: DPP

TEXT.P: The economic prospects for Taiwan are very promising with economic growth expected to reach 4.5 percent and unemployment to drop to 4.25 percent next year, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator said Saturday.

Tsai Huang-liang, DPP legislative caucus whip, made the remarks in response to claims by Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng that the DPP has done a bad job in administering the country, especially in terms of the economy.

According to Tsai, the economic growth rate of Taiwan dropped to around 5 percent during the time that the Kuomintang was in power, and the first term of President Chen Shui-bian happened to be the start of a global economic recession.
However, Taiwan has managed to create a "new miracle" by seeing its foreign reserves double despite the global recession, Tsai said.
He said Taiwan has survived the recession and is now ready to welcome a promising future.
While economic growth is estimated at 4.5 percent next year, the unemployment rate is expected to fall to 4.25 percent, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL LOSSES FROM TYPHOON AT NT$55.59 MILLION IN KAOHSIUNG CO.

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County's agricultural losses resulting from Typhoon Nanmadol, which pounded southern Taiwan with strong winds and torrential rains Saturday, have surged to NT$55.59 million (US$1.68 million), officials of Kaohsiung County's Bureau of Agriculture said Saturday.

According to bureau tallies, 1,275 hectares of farmland was affected by Nanmadol, the 27th typhoon reported in the Pacific Ocean so far this year. The hardest-hit crops included leafy vegetables, bananas, guavas, and other in-season fruits.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF PITCHES FOR ACADEMIC CONFIDENCE-BUILDING MECHANISM

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu came up with a new initiative Saturday aimed at breaking the political stalemate across the Taiwan Strait, saying the two sides can start by forging a confidence-building mechanism among academics.

According to Wu's proposal, each side could designate an established scholar to be stationed on the other side to do research and concurrently serve as a conduit for information exchanges between the two governments.
By so doing, Wu said, the Taipei and Beijing governments can avoid misjudgments due to confusing information.

"I think this kind of confidence-building mechanism in the academic community is less political and should be more feasible than the one suggested by President Chen Shui-bian early this year, " Wu said.

Chen suggested Feb. 3 that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait exchange representatives to establish rapprochement and mutual trust. As cross-strait relations have remained deadlocked, Wu said he thinks the possibility of Chen's proposal being implemented is low, if not nil, for the moment.

Under Wu's proposal, the scholar to be posted on the other side can be chosen from political, legal or international relations fields. The scholar can lead several graduate students pursuing doctoral degrees on the mainland to study its political problems while serving as the government's cross-strait information exchange conduit, Wu said, adding that the duration of the stay could be for two to three years.

Wu urged mainland China to show sincerity to improve cross-strait ties by accepting his proposal after Taiwan's Dec. 11 legislative elections. "I believe this academic confidence-building mechanism can mark a new start for cross-strait engagements," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: VANUATU SUPREME COURT SET TO RULE ON NO-CONFIDENCE VOTE FOR PM: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Supreme Court of Vanuatu is scheduled to release on Dec. 6 its ruling on parliament's plan to launch a no-confidence vote for Prime Minister Serge Vohor in the wake of the establishment of diplomatic ties with the Republic of China, according to the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Saturday.
The opposition in Vanuatu, which is angry with Vohor's firm support of the diplomatic relations between the south Pacific nation and Taiwan, is planning to vote Vohor out of office.
The Vanuatu Supreme Court held a hearing Saturday on the legality of the vote and other constitutional issues, ministry spokesman Michel Lu said.
Vohor and ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen signed a joint communique to establish diplomatic relations Nov. 3, making Vanuatu the 27th ally of the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: IT MONTH COMPUTER FAIR OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2004 Computer Fair of the Information Technology (IT) Month opened on Saturday at the Taipei World Trade Center, drawing a huge crowd of visitors.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun and Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-Yueh attended the opening ceremony for the annual fair, which has become a high-profile consumer trade fair for computer-related products since its beginning in 1980.

Addressing the ceremony, Yu suggested IT Month organizers that in addition to traditional awards for excellent designers of information products and excellent creations, they should set up other awards to encourage innovative inventions.

Yu said that the Taiwan IT industry, which has made successful inroads into world markets, should keep developing to maintain its international competitiveness. He noted that facing the challenge of shrinking profits from sales of computers and peripherals, the sector should not only accelerate its drive to create advanced technologies, but also use its imagination to create products for the future.

The premier also praised the industry for its marvelous achievements over the past 25 yeas, saying that two major IT sectors -- the semiconductor and color monitor manufacturing sectors -- created an accumulated output of NT$1.55 trillion (US$48.21 billion) last year.
Yu added that Taiwan's TFT-LCD monitor manufacturing sector saw a world market penetration rate of 40.6 percent this year, a figure that made Taiwan the largest monitor supplier in the world.

In addition, he said, Taiwan ranked as the world's fourth in the 2004 Global Competitiveness Report of the World Economic Forum, while being listed as the first among Asian economies the third year in a row.

The premier's remarks were echoed by the economics minister who pointed out that Taiwan's export have increased to NT$160 billion from NT$20 billion 25 years ago, a six-fold increase. Ho said the growth contributed to the IT industry's strong export abilities.
She said proudly that today, every eight of 10 notebook personal computers in the world were made by Taiwanese manufacturers.
A total of 350 companies joined in the computer fair that will run until Dec. 12. No entrance fee is required.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, JAPAN SHOULD ASSIST IN CHINA'S POLITICAL REFORM: MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Japan should cooperate in helping mainland China carry out political reform, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said Saturday.
The nation's top mainland policy planner made the call at a seminar on Taiwan-Japan relations and the changing global order being held in Taipei.

Noting that Taiwan and Japan are two most important democratic countries in Asia, Wu said the two countries can come up with joint proposals to help mainland China plan political reform projects and work out measures to weather through disorder or instability that may arise from those reform steps.

Wu said the proposals can be jointly presented by Beijing authorities by the Democracy Foundation of Taiwan and the Democracy Foundation of Japan. By so doing, Wu said, the two countries will contribute greatly to long-term regional stability in East Asia.
He added that Taiwan is not only willing to take active steps to improve relations across the Taiwan Strait but also intends to make positive contribution in mainland China's national development.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER OCAC STAFF MEMBER INDICTED FOR INVOLVEMENT IN HUMAN SMUGGLING

TEXT.P: A former Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) staff member was indicted Saturday on charges of colluding with a local human smuggling ring in smuggling mainland Chinese citizens to the United States three years ago.

Shen Chieh-jen, an OCAC staff member posted at the Kaohsiung Airport, was accused of having lobbied aviation police to offer courtesy treatment to two smuggling ring members and three mainland citizens holding bogus Singaporean passports in October 2001 by claiming that the visitors were Singaporean civil servants.
Aviation police rejected Shen's request and insisted on inspecting their travel papers in line with official procedures. Immigration officers later uncovered that the passports were fake.

Shen was later fired by the OCAC. Also indicted Saturday was Yeh Chin-jung, one of the human smuggling ring members who had lobbied Shen. The other accomplice, identified as Feng Sheng-hsiung, has been put on the wanted list.

Yeh and Feng allegedly had colluded with mainland Chinese human smuggling rings in counterfeiting Taiwan and Singaporean passports for smuggling mainland citizens to the United States via Hong Kong and Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE PEOPLE SUPPORT SMOKE-FREE RESTAURANTS: POLL

TEXT.P: More local people support the smoke-free restaurants campaign, the Department of Health (DOH) said Saturday.

According to a recent survey conducted by the DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion, 93.1 percent of the respondents gave a thumbs-up to the DOH-launched smoke-free restaurants campaign, compared to 88.3 percent recorded in a similar survey conducted last year.
The latest survey found that 76 percent of those interviewed support the proposal that a law be legislated to ban smoking in restaurants.
Meanwhile, 87.9 percent of restaurant operators surveyed said they support the DOH's smoke-free restaurants campaign.
As of the end of November, DOH officials said, there were nearly 5,000 smoke-free restaurants around the island.

The court's ruling was a surprising and decisive victory for Viktor A. Yushchenko, the opposition leader who asserted that he had been denied his rightful victory.

DOC.HEADLINE: YANG KUEI-MEI WINS BEST LEADING ACTRESS AWARD AT FILM FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan-born actress Yang Kuei-mei won the "Best Leading Actress" award at the 41th Golden Horse Film Festival Saturday in the central city of Taichung.
"I finally make it after having been nominated for four times. It's a great honor for me," Yang said at the presentation ceremony.
Yang won the award for her gorgeous portrayal in the film "The Moon Also Rises."

Andy Lau, a Hong Kong pop singer-actor, captured the "Best Leading Actor" award for his outstanding performance in the gangster film "Infernal Affairs III." This was the third time that he has been nominated and finally succeeded in winning the trophy.
Meanwhile, the mainland Chinese film "Kekexili," which depicts how Tibetan people in the Kekexili area has fought poachers to protect antelopes, won the "Best Feature Film" award.

Lu Chuan, the film's director, said he appreciates the panel of judges' recognition of his efforts at overcoming enormous difficulties producing the film. He also expressed his heartfelt gratitude for Taiwan journalists' encouraging him to travel to Taiwan to attend the star-studded presentation ceremony.
The "Best Director" Award went to Hong Kong-born director Johnnie To for his brilliant directing of the film "Breaking News."

Hundreds of celebrities attended the award presentation ceremony at the Chungshan Hall in Taichung. Government Information Office Director-General Lin Chia-lung and Taichung Mayor Jason Hu were were among the dignitaries attending the ceremony. Noted New York-based director of Taiwan origin Ang Lee and Holleywood director John Woo were among award presenters.
Winners of major 2004 Golden Horse Awards are:

Best Director-- Johnnie To ("Breaking News");

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 5, or the 24th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1782: Martin Van Buren, the eighth president of the United States, is born.
1791: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Austrian composer considered among the greatest and most prolific composers in history, dies in Vienna of kidney failure at the age of 35. He had written more than 600 works.
1792: George Washington is reelected president of the United States.
1904: The Russo-Japanese War breaks out, with Japanese troops occupying Height 203, the ideal position for capturing Lushun, west of the port city of Talien.
1906: Russian Adm. Niebogatov goes on trial on charges of surrendering ships to the Japanese.
1915: Chen Chi-mei, a follower of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, leads a revolt against Yuan Shih-kai by trying to seize the warship Chaoho. His attempt fails the following day.
1928: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China is formally established.
1933: The United States celebrates the end of 14 long years of prohibition when the government nullifies the 18th Amendment, which outlawed the production, transportation or sale of alcohol.
1945: Six U.S. Navy aircraft carrying 27 airmen go missing without a trace in the Atlantic Ocean near Bermuda.
1946: A strong earthquake hits southern Taiwan, killing 69 people and injuring 170.
1949: Li Tsung-jen, acting president of the Republic of China, leaves Hong Kong for the United States.
1950: North Korean and Communist Chinese troops recapture Pyongyang as United Nations forces are forced to withdraw southward.
1957: The Dachien to Lishan section of the Central Cross-Island Highway opens to traffic.
1957: The Indonesian government orders the expulsion of all Dutch nationals.
1968: The Taiwan Provincial Government launches a one-person-one-dollar movement to raise money for national sports development.
1972: The Chase Manhattan Bank of New York opens a branch office in Taipei.
1975: Campaign activities for the Dec. 20 legislative elections open with 61 candidates contesting 37 Taiwan area seats.
1976: Professional golfers Kuo Chi-hsiung and Hsu Sheng-san leave for Palm Springs, Calif., to take part in the 24th World Cup professional golf tournament.
1978: The Soviet Union signs a 20-year treaty of friendship with Afghanistan.
1984: Ninety-three miners are killed in an accident at the Haishanyikeng mining pit in Shanhsia township, Taipei County.
1984: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang unanimously supports a bill to amend the Firearms Control Act, imposing heavy punishments on the unauthorized manufacture of deadly weapons, with a maximum sentence of death.
1985: The United States decides to pull out of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
1985: Four businessmen are sentenced to prison terms ranging from two-and-a-half years to 12 years by a military court under the Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters for conducting direct trade with the Communist Chinese.
1995: Javier Solana, the Spanish foreign minister, is appointed the secretary-general of NATO.
1999: Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chang Chang-pang leaves for Miami to attend the annual Miami Conference on the Caribbean and Latin America.
2000: A total of 105 young Indonesians begin to receive two years of professional training in Taiwan as part of the ROC's efforts to help its major Southeast Asian trading partner develop small- and medium-sized enterprises.
2001: Beijing authorities sternly rejects Taiwan's proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait commence dialogue on the "three direct links" issue under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO). The "three direct links" refers to direct cross-strait trade, postal and transportation links.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler answers to the desire of the subjects, it manifests an understanding of approvals and disapprovals of the people. When there is such an understanding, the good will be discovered and rewarded and the bad will be discovered and punished, and the country will surely attain order."
