DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE' HOLDS CAMPAIGN PARADE IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and its political allies, the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party, held a campaign parade in Taipei Sunday afternoon with less than a week to go before the Dec. 11 elections.
Liao Feng-teh, the director of the KMT Department for Organization Affairs, said the parade was for "the defense of the Republic of China and the salvation of Taiwan".

Touting the parade as a struggle between the defenders of the ROC and those who want to destroy it, Liao had urged the supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, PFP and New Party "to turn up and participate in the parade in flocks.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan was scheduled to give a speech to parade participants in the square in front of the Legislative Yuan at the end of the parade, instead of leading the parade all the way from the Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall as initially planned because of safety concerns.

KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said the parade is to voice seven appeals, including opposing tampering with history, opposing the creation of a constitution aimed at realizing Taiwan independence, opposing the government's arms procurement plan, opposing the hike in commodity prices, opposing the worsening of social peace and order, and opposing the government's overlooking of farmers' welfare.

In order to underline the participants' support for the Republic of China, Chang urged the parade-goers to carry ROC national flags or other things to underline their determination to defend the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WON'T NECESSARILY BE MARGINALIZED IN ASIA: CHINA HAND
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will remain an important player in Asia and will not be marginalized even if China further bolsters ties with other countries in the region, so long as the island's economic prosperity and science and technology development continues, a Hong Kong-based academic said Saturday.
David Zweig, director of the Center on China and Transnational Relations of the Technology University of Hong Kong, made the comments in a telephone interview with the Central News Agency.

Zweig noted that China was previously considered by most countries in Asia as a threat. However, in recent years, particularly after the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) summit in Laos last month, China has demonstrated the "soft" side of its diplomacy, he added.
China has shown that it is willing to engage in regional affairs, which has in turn spurred the ASEAN members' interest in further exploring the huge Chinese market, he continued.

Disagreeing with the view of some that China is aiming to isolate Taiwan by bolstering its ties with ASEAN, Zweig said that China's expanding ties with ASEAN and the so-called Taiwan issue are two separate matters. China is primarily aiming at expanding its economic activity in the ASEAN markets, he added.

China has also tried to demonstrate its "peace-loving" side by seeking peaceful solutions to controversial issues in the region, such as the question of who has sovereignty over the Nansha Islands (Spratlys). For example, Zweig said, China and the Philippines have decided recently to jointly tap crude oil in the Nansha Islands area.

Zweig, however, said he does think that China's increasing engagement with ASEAN is weakening the United States' relative influence in Asia. "As far as I know, there are people in the United States who have shown concern over this issue," he added.

Although Taiwan is not recognized by most of the Asian countries politically, it remains an important player in Asia's economic arena, Zweig said, adding that Taiwan is still seen actively taking part in the markets of China, Japan and ASEAN member nations.
"Taiwan's economic role in Asia will not regress," Zweig claimed.
Nevertheless, another Hong Kong-based "China hand" disagreed with Zweig's comments regarding Taiwan.

Dixon Sing, an associate professor with the Public and Social Department of Hong Kong's City University, said that Taiwan will inevitably be isolated in the process of China strengthening its interactions with ASEAN members and other countries around Asia.
China is poising to take a leading role in Asia with its go-go economic development and soaring status in the region, Sing claimed.

Seconding Sing's opinions, Qiang Jiang, a researcher with the Center of Asian Studies, the University of Hong Kong, said that Taiwan will "certainly have trouble" in its efforts to enter the shaping of a "pan-Asian bloc" as China's clout across Asia swells.

At the recently concluded ASEAN summit, which was also attended by leaders of Australia, China, India, Japan, New Zealand and South Korea, the leaders focused their discussions on accelerating ASEAN's economic integration and narrowing the economic divide among the group's wealthier and poorer members.

The leaders agreed to convene an East Asia Summit in Malaysia next year, which could signal the start of a pan-Asian bloc which would include India, Australia and New Zealand, in addition to the ASEAN's traditional dialogue partners, China, Japan and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Musharraf: Bin Laden's Location Is Unknown; Pakistani Presses U.S. on Rebuilding Afghan Army.
Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf said yesterday that the search for Osama bin Laden has gone completely cold, with no recent intelligence indicating where he and his top lieutenants are hiding.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOPES CAMPAIGN PARADES OF OPPOSING CAMPS WILL BE PEACEFUL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday that he hopes the two campaign parades being held simultaneously by the two opposing political camps Sunday afternoon in Taipei will be carried out peacefully.

Speaking at a news conference at the Taipei Headquarters of his ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the president said he has ordered the National Police Administration to prevent any confrontations between participants in the two parades.

One of the parades is being held by the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT), the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party. The other parade is being held by the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , which is allied to the DPP in the "pan-green camp."

As both groups have branded themselves as true loyalists of Taiwan, they should not do anything to stir up chaos which would be detrimental to the country, the president said at the news conference which was called to unveil the DPP's latest campaign strategy in the lead up to the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

The "pan blue alliance" parade will proceed from the square in front of the Taipei City Hall to the Legislative Yuan, with KMT Chairman Lien Chan, PFP Chairman James Soong and New Party leader Yok Mu-ming all taking part in the parade, an organizer said.
The organizer said he expects some 100,000 people from around Taiwan to take part in the parade, with some 500 tour buses bringing supporters into the capital from other parts of the island.

The TSU parade will proceed from the 228 Peace Park to the square in front of the Presidential Office, which is located just across from the KMT headquarters. Organizers said some 150,000 people from around the island will take part in the parade, with 2,500 buses bringing supporters to the capital.
Former President Lee Teng-hui, who is the spiritual leader of the TSU, will give a speech at the square in front of the Presidential Office, the organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TAIWAN' TO BE USED IN NAMES OF OVERSEAS MISSIONS: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The word "Taiwan" will be used in the official designations of all of the Republic of China's overseas missions and state-run companies within two years, President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday.

Noting that the country's official title is "the Republic of China" and that the ROC is Taiwan, Chen said that the word "Taiwan" will be used for the overseas missions and state-run enterprises in order to distinguish them from those of the People's Republic of China and thus avoid any confusion in the international community.

The first step will be replacing "China" with "Taiwan" in the official designations of state-owned enterprises, to be followed by the government's representative offices abroad, Chen said while giving a speech at the headquarters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to help boost public support for the party in the Dec. 11 legislative elections. Chen also serves as DPP chairman.
In the future, all the nation's overseas offices will be called "Taiwan representative offices, " he added.
The president vowed that he will never deviate from the policies and promises that he unveiled in his May 20 inauguration speech for a second term and in his Oct. 10 National Day address.

Chen claimed that he is ready to fight for Taiwan's sovereignty forever but added that he will not act rashly by altering the country's official name for the sake of national unity as a majority of Taiwan's 23 million people are in favor of keeping "the ROC" as the nation's official title for the time being.
Tsai Huan-liang, a whip of the DPP at the Legislative Yuan, called the name change plan a pragmatic approach to better reflect Taiwan's present situation.

According to Tsai, maintaining "the ROC" as the country's official designation, while using "Taiwan" in the names of state companies and overseas representative offices is not expected to cause a further split at home.

Using "Taiwan" instead of "the ROC" in some fields is aimed at strengthening the people's identification with the country and is a move which does not equate to altering the country's official designation, he claimed.

Tsai also reiterated that the DPP will not go beyond the "four noes plus one" pledge outlined by the president in his first inauguration speech in 2000 while pushing for a new constitution for Taiwan.
The DPP whip made it clear that sensitive issues such as the nation's title and flag will not be touched in the DPP's constitutional re-engineering task.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM UNION VOTES TO ALLOW STRIKES

TEXT.P: The labor union of state-owned Chunghwa Telecom passed a resolution in an islandwide members' vote Sunday to enable workers of Taiwan's largest telecommunications company to go on strike as a means of safeguarding their rights and interests.

The resolution was passed overwhelmingly by 17,118 votes in favor of allowing Chunghwa Telecom workers to strike to protect their rights and interests. Altogether, 17,356 out of the labor union's 28,000 members cast their ballots.

This marked the first time in Chunghwa Telecom's 47 years history that the union has held a referendum-style vote to vote on enabling the workers to strike. It was also the first time that a vote was held via teleconference islandwide, in three locations across northern, central and southern Taiwan.

Chunghwa Telecom Labor Union Chairman Chang Hsu-chung said that Sunday's vote was held after management ignored the labor union's appeals for guarantees that benefits and work conditions would not be altered after Chunghwa Telecom is completely privatized.
He added that it is hoped that the vote will give the labor union more bargaining leverage in future negotiations with management.

Chang said that if the Chunghwa Telecom workers decide to go on strike, it must be done in a way that has the least adverse impact on the convenience of subscribers and users of Chunghwa Telecom services.

In response to passage of the labor union's resolution, Chunghwa Telecom Vice President Chang Feng-hsiung said that if a strike is unavoidable, the company will try its best to maintain the company's services.
"I guarantee that Chunghwa Telecom will do whatever it can to prevent subscribers' rights from being compromised under any circumstances," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CRITICIZES PRESIDENT FOR EDGING TO INDEPENDENCE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has abandoned the "middle road" policy that he claimed he would follow when assuming the presidency four years ago by tilting toward Taiwan independence, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) spokesman Chang Jong-kung said Sunday.

Chang made the remarks after the president said earlier the same day that state-run businesses and the government's overseas offices will carry the word "Taiwan" in their official names instead of "China" to differentiate them from those of the People's Republic of China. Chen, however, also said that the country's official name -- the Republic of China -- will not be altered.

According to Chang, President Chen made the remarks mainly to secure backing from pro-independence voters for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) amid fierce competition from the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) in the runnup to the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Claiming that Chen's words form the latest in a series of moves by the DPP to promote Taiwan independence, Chang described the ruling party's strategy as a "soft coup" designed to weaken and eventually topple the ROC in a gradual fashion.
He called on the people to cast their votes for the "pan blue alliance " of the KMT, the People First Party and the New Party for the sake of cross-Taiwan Strait peace and the status quo.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAME CHANGE FOR O'SEAS OFFICES AIMED AT AVOIDING CONFUSION: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's vow to change the name of the country's overseas offices and state-run enterprises by including the word "Taiwan" is aimed at distinguishing them from those of mainland China, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) chairman said Sunday.

In an apparent attempt to preempt criticism that president is moving another step closer toward Taiwan independence, Joseph Jaushieh Wu said that the move was made to avoid foreigners confusing Taiwan, whose official designation is the Republic of China, with the People's Republic of China on the mainland.
Wu cited the example of ROC diplomats in Panama, with which the ROC maintains formal diplomatic ties, once wrongly being referred to as diplomats from the PRC by the host country.
Changing the official names of the country's overseas offices will avoid such embarrassing mistakes and is desired by the people of Taiwan, Wu said.

Wu stressed that the move does not mean a change in the nation's official title and should not elicit ire from Beijing which frowns on any moves that could be construed as steps toward Taiwan independence.
President Chen announcement has been seen by some as a move to gain support from pro-independence voters for Democratic Progressive Party candidates ahead of the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEEKING TO HOST 2005 INTERNATIONAL JUNIOR SCIENCE OLYMPIAD

TEXT.P: Taiwan is seeking to host the 2005 International Junior Science Olympiad (IJSO) , Ministry of Education officials said Sunday.

The officials said that Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng had instructed the Taiwan delegation to the 2004 IJSO in Jakarta to vie for the right to host next year's event and to deliver to IJSO authorities a letter in which he personally expresses Taiwan's desire to host the event.

The Taiwan delegation, composed of six junior high school students and their teachers, left for Jakarta earlier the same day to take part in the international scientific competition for students under the age of 15.
A total of 38 countries are taking part in the 2004 IJSO, the first of its kind in the world. The event is being held Dec. 5-14.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CONSTITUTION TO BRING TAIWAN'S HUMAN RIGHTS UP TO INT'L PAR: CHEN

TEXT.P: The proposed new constitution for Taiwan will bring the country's human rights protection into line with the international standards, President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday.

Speaking at a seminar jointly organized by a unit under the Presidential Office and the Council for Cultural Affairs under the Executive Yuan, the president said the definition of human rights has expanded to include such things as "social rights" and "development rights."

The president said the current ROC Constitution is obviously inadequate in terms of the new definition of human rights and falls short of the public's expectations, adding that the new constitution will address these issues and bring Taiwan into line with international norms regarding human rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPAIN WINS FUTSAL WORLD CHAMPIONSHIP IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Spain beat Italy 2-1 Sunday to win the 2004 FIFA Futsal World Championship held in Taipei.
Earlier in the day, Brazil overpowered Argentina 7-4 to capture third place in the tournament which kicked off Nov. 21 in Taiwan's capital.
A total of 16 countries took part in the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO WORK TO BE IN LINE WITH NAME-CHANGE POLICY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has been making efforts over the past several years to change the formal designation of all of the nation's official outposts in countries that do not maintain formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan, a MOFA spokesman said Sunday.
"Such efforts will be boosted further to be in line with the policy put forward in President Chen Shui-bian's remarks Sunday, " MOFA spokesman Michel Lu.

President Chen said Sunday that the formal names of the Republic of China's overseas official missions and state-run enterprises should be changed within two years to include the word "Taiwan" to differentiate them from those of the People's Republic of China and thus avoid any confusion.
Lu noted that to change the name of any of its overseas offices, Taiwan needs to first acquire the consent of the host country.

In response to President Chen's remarks Sunday, the state-run China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) said it will do whatever it can to cope with the policy. Fan Kuang-nan, acting chairman of the CSBC, said that a name change for the company is a challenging task, with more than 100 contracts overseas needing to be altered.
Despite these difficulties, the CSBC will try its best to come into line with the plan, Fan added.
Meanwhile, the formerly state-owned China Steel Corp., which is now a listed company, said Sunday that the company currently has no plans to change its name.
A CSC spokesman said it is up to the company's investors and shareholders to decide whether the company should be renamed "Taiwan Steel Corp."

DOC.HEADLINE: COMBINED MARKET VALUE OF LISTED COMPANIES IN TAIWAN UP OVER LAST WEEK

TEXT.P: The combined market value of listed companies in Taiwan hit NT$13.431 trillion (US$417.12 billion) at the close of trading Friday, up NT$258.82 billion, or 1.96 percent, over the week-earlier level, according to statistics compiled by the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX).
The weighted index -- the benchmark index of the domestic bourse -- moved up 114.62 points, or 1.98 percent, for the whole week to finish at 5,893.27 on Dec. 3.
The surge was mainly due to a rebound in U.S. stock markets and stronger buying support by investors, the TSEC report noted.

Share prices for most of the 20 main categories gained ground, with textiles stocks moving up the most at 3.54 percent, while electrical appliance, cable, machinery, and automobile stocks suffered setbacks.
There have been 230 trading days on the Taiwan Stock Exchange so far this year, with a combined turnover of NT$22.925 trillion.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNAL STRIFE POSES LARGEST THREAT TO TAIWAN IT SECTOR: CEPD HEAD

TEXT.P: Internal strife, rather than a lack of brand names, is the largest threat to Taiwan's information technology sector, the chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Sunday.

In an exclusive interview with CNA, Hu Sheng-cheng said that despite providing the world with over 50 percent of key components and devices, Taiwan's IT sector has failed to become a major player because of heated competition among domestic companies.
This competition has led to a price war that has only benefited foreign multinationals, Hu said, urging Taiwan computer makers to bolster cooperation to end this detrimental situation.

Asked about which industry will emerge as a new star in Taiwan's industry in the face of strong competition in the information industry, Hu predicted that the automobile industry has the potential to reach annual production of more than NT$1 trillion (US$30.5 billion) -- which would make it the fourth domestic industry after the semiconductor, display panel and telecommunication sectors to do so.

Basing his analysis on the fact that Taiwan produces world-class car accessories, he claimed that there is ample room for the domestic automobile industry to further develop in conjunction with the country's car electronics makers thanks to Taiwan's advanced opto-electronics and display industries.

He stressed that training skilled workers and professionals is extremely important for industry and also for the government in its bid to build Taiwan into a business operations center and a financial hub in the Asia-Pacific region.
The government also plans to cut the number of the many public banks and financial holdings companies in Taiwan by half in an effort to reduce overlap and sharpen the industry's competitiveness.

Citing Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budgets, Accounting and Statistics figures, Hu said that meeting the government's forecast of economic growth of 5 percent and unemployment of 4 percent for next year will be a challenge amid a slowing world economy.

To achieve the two targets, the government will keenly promote local demand by injecting NT$100 billion into public construction projects through the new 10 development plans to offset an expected decline in the export sector, he explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION CAMPAIGN PARADES IN TAIPEI ENDS PEACEFULLY

TEXT.P: Two campaign parades in Taipei for the Dec. 11 legislative elections, organized by the opposition "pan blue alliance" and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), respectively, ended peacefully Sunday.

The "pan blue alliance " march of the Kuomintang (KMT) , the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party (New Party) attracted more than 100,000 people across Taiwan to take part in, starting at the Taipei City Hall and finishing at the Legislative Yuan.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan, PFP Chairman James Soong and NP Chairman Yok Mu-ming accompanied their backers through the march under the slogans such as unity, protecting the Republic of China and saving Taiwan.
Lien called on the public to help the "pan blue alliance" gain a majority at the 225-member Legislative Yuan in the coming legislative polls to secure the ROC's constitution and the nation's future.

Soong accused the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) of pushing Taiwan toward the edge of war with mainland China by promoting Taiwan independence, and he claimed that a "pan blue alliance" majority at the Legislative Yuan is necessary to check and balance the government led by Chen.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who is also a vice chairman of the KMT, also gave a speech on the occasion, pointing out that under the DPP rule, Taiwan is confronting major problems on the financial, economic and ethnic fronts as well as in its relations with mainland China.

Political uncertainties, ethnic confrontation, economic dwindling and social disorder will continue to worsen if the "pan green camp" of the DPP and TSU grabs more than half of the seats at the new legislature, Wang pointed out.
At the same time, about 150,000 supporters participated in the parade led by the TSU, which kicked off at the 228 Peace Park and ended at the square in front of the Presidential Office.

Former President Lee Teng-hui, spiritual leader of the TSU, said that the "pan blue alliance" has betrayed most of the Taiwan people by boycotting the government's constitutional and democratic reforms.

He clamored for voters' support to help the "pan green camp" to form a majority at the new legislature in order to create a new constitution for Taiwan and push through the government's major military procurement plan worth of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion).

The president's remarks in his weekly ra dio address came a day after a powerful Senate Republican, John W. Warner of Virginia, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, expressed doubts about the bill, which would enact the major recommendations of the Sept. 11 commission and create a cabinet-level director of national intelligence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 6, or the 25th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Austria becomes the first nation to establish a state education system.
1889: Jefferson Davis, the first and only president of the Confederate States of America, dies at the age of 81. He was captured by Union soldiers in 1865 and imprisoned for two years. Although indicted for treason, he was never prosecuted.
1907: One of the worst coal mine disasters in U.S. history occurs at Mononagh, West Virginia, killing 361 people.
1911: Mongolia is declared a Russian protectorate.
1917: The Republic of Finland is proclaimed.
1917: The steamship Mont Blanc collides with the steamship Imo in Halifax, Canada, killing more than 1,500 people, injuring 8,000 others, and destroying a large part of the city.
1921: Britain signs a peace treaty with Ireland under which the Irish Free States is established and Ireland accepts Dominion status.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt appeals to Japan's Emperor Hirohito for peace.
1943: The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union issue the Joint Declaration of the Tehran Conference.
1957: The United States fails in the launching of its first satellite.
1960: Taiwan Province implements the use of media broadcasts for the first time in the history of Republic of China military service in order to muster the required number of reservists.
1971: India recognizes the Democratic Republic of Bangladesh.
1973: The United Nations decides to establish the United Nations University in Tokyo.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford arrives in the Philippines for talks on new terms for U.S. air and naval basses in the country.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan receives Mrs. Paul Norman Brown, national president of the American Legion Ladies' Auxiliary, at the Presidential Office.
1979: The Communist Chinese ban the sticking of "big character posters" on Beijing's wall of democracy.
1980: The 1980 Supplementary Parliamentarian election sends 70 members to the Legislative Yuan and 76 to the National Assembly.
1986: Eighty-four members are newly elected to the Legislative Yuan and seventy-three members are newly elected to the National Assembly in the 1986 legislative by-elections. Voter turnout is 65.4 percent of the 11.8 million eligible registered voters.
1988: The ROC Legislative Yuan is paralyzed by fist-fighting, as the chairman for the first time asks police to maintain order.
1989: The worst mass killing in Canadian history takes place when a gunman shoots 13 female students to death at the University of Montreal before killing himself.
1990: President Saddam Hussein announces that all 3,400 foreign hostages held in Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait are now free to leave.
1990: Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad steps down at the height of a pro-democracy movement in Bangladesh.
1996: The Legislative Yuan revises the Labor Standards Law so that employees in nearly all industries will be covered by the end of 1998.
1999: The ROC-Japan Economic Conference opens in Tokyo.
2000: The Republic of China's Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs removes restrictions on workers from the Philippines, with the change effective retroactively to Dec. 1.
2000: Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez arrives in Taipei for an official visit.
2001: Taiwan's two largest opposition parties, the Kuomintang and the People First Pary, decide not to participate in the "national stabilization alliance" that has been proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: The computer virus "Goner, " first found in the United States, is rampant in Hong Kong with at least 16 companies' computer systems being hit.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler does not answer to the desires of the subjects, it shows a lack of understanding of the approvals and disapprovals of the subjects. When there is no such understanding, then the good will not be discovered and rewarded and the bad will not be punished."

DOC.HEADLINE: 180 TSMC STAFF MEMBERS VOLUNTEER AS SCIENCE MUSEUM GUIDES
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A total of 180 staff members of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) have signed up as volunteer guides at the National Museum of Natural Science in Taichung.
The TSMC volunteers, who work in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan or in Tainan in the south, take turns heading to Taichung to serve as guides in the museum's special "IC World" section on the weekends.

TSMC, the world's first and largest IC chip foundry, lent financial and technical support to help build the "IC World" at the museum six years ago. Last year, in order to attract more visitors, the head of the TSMC Cultural and Educational Foundation decided to set up the volunteer guide program.

The idea has been well-received, attracting some 180 TSMC staff members, including top-level directors, engineers, technicians, and members of their families to sign up almost immediately. Some 240 more TSMC staff members and members of their families are expected to join the volunteer program next year.

Over the past year, the volunteers have used their professional expertise to help ordinary museum goers get to know the scientific world of ICs. While serving as guides, the TSMC volunteers have also constantly consulted among themselves and even made some changes to the displays and environment in an effort to provide "perfect" service at the museum.

"Even at the museum, the TSMC volunteers demonstrate their 'zero defects' spirit that has been cultivated through years of professional training, " said Kuo Shan-shan, chief secretary of the TSMC Foundation.

Wu Chung-ming, a director with the TSMC DVPSOC (digital visual processing and silicon-on-chip) Lab, said she and her two college student sons have enthusiastically worked as volunteer "conductive agents" at the IC World over the past year. The volunteer program also serves as a real-life education for TSMC staff family members who take part, she added.

Hsueh Tsung-chih, a senior engineer working at a TSMC Clean Room, said he feels blessed to have such a great job with an excellent company and wants to repay society by taking part in the volunteer program. He called working as a museum guide a piece of cake compared to his past volunteer experiences, including as a firefighter and as a paramedic's assistant aboard an ambulance.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'NO DIFFICULTIES FORESEEN' IN NAME CHANGE POLICY: MOTC

TEXT.P: There are currently no difficulties foreseen in state-run enterprises under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) carrying out the name-change policy espoused by President Chen Shui-bian Sunday, the MOTC vice minister said Monday.

President Chen said Sunday that the formal designations of the Republic of China's overseas official missions and state-run enterprises should be changed within two years to include the word "Taiwan" in order to distinguish them from those of the People's Republic of China and thus avoid any confusion in the international community.

Vice Minister Tsai Duei said that Chunghwa Telecom, Chunghwa Post and China Airlines, the three business operations under the MOTC's supervision, will experience different problems in their attempt to come into line with the name-change policy put forward by President Chen.
Basically, the name-change work can be implemented without any technical problems, Tsai said, adding however that these companies will need time to assess the situation.
"Currently, there is no timetable for the implementation of this project," he pointed out.

Meanwhile, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said state-run enterprises under the supervision of her ministry, including the Chinese Petroleum Corp., won't require the full two years to carry out the name change policy.
"What should be done should be done quickly, so long as it is to the benefit of the country," Ho added.

Meanwhile, Ho said, the formerly state-owned China Steel Corp.(CSC), which is now a listed company, would not necessarily come into line with the name-change plan as the Ministry of Economic Affairs now only holds a 23-percent stake in the company.
It is up to CSC's investors and shareholders to decide whether the company should be renamed "Taiwan Steel Corp," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMPLETES 2ND ROUND FTA TALKS WITH NICARAGUA

TEXT.P: A second round of free trade agreement (FTA) bilateral consultations between Taiwan and Nicaragua has just completed in San Francisco, marking a step forward in efforts for the two countries to eventually sign an FTA, the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) reported Monday.

Officials headed by ROC Vice Economic Affairs Minister Steve R.L. Chen on the Taiwan side and Alejandro Arguello, Nicaragua's vice minister of development, industry and commerce on the other, reached consensus upon the conclusion of the consultation on several issues, including market access, trade facilitation and cooperation for the attainment of a third round of such talks, BOFT officials said.

In detail, the two sides reached consensus on areas including animal quarantine, technical trade barriers, fair competition, labor, intellectual property rights, telephone and other telecommunications, investment, and trade regulations as well as procedures, the officials said.

The two sides agreed that the third round of talks will be held between Jan. 31 and Feb. 4, 2005, in the hope that the two countries can complete their bilateral consultation talks and ink a formal FTA in the first half of next year.

Based on the conclusion reached in San Francisco, the two countries will shortly hammer out lists of their own on tariff elimination or tariff concessions on agricultural imports from each other's country, BOFT officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low but closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 25.9 points to close at 5,919.17.
The bourse opened at 5,864.45 and fluctuated between 5,922.8 and 5,857.64 during trading. A total of 2.67 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$56.2 billion (US$1.75 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares, plastics and chemicals shares and paper and pulp issues all moving up at 0.7 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.6 percent, textile stocks at 0.4 percent and machinery and electronics shares and foodstuff issues both at 0.3 percent.
Construction issues moved down 0.8 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 359 to 267, with 193 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Thai military drops peace cranes.
Origami airdrop aimed at dÃ©tente in south BANGKOK AP Millions of folded paper cranes fluttered down from warplanes in the skies over southern Thailand on Sunday as the air force completed a mission of peace aimed at expressing the nation's hope for an end to separatist violence in the Muslim-dominated region.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO CONTINUE TALKS WITH FOREIGN COUNTRIES OVER NAME CHANGE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will continue talks with host countries of Taiwan representative offices overseas on the government's plan to change the name of the nation's representative offices in countries that do not diplomatically recognize the Republic of China, a senior official said Monday.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu made the remarks after President Chen Shui-bian said a day earlier that his administration will push for changes of the designation of ROC missions abroad and certain state-owned enterprises in two years by including the word "Taiwan" to clearly distinguish them from those of the People's Republic of China (PRC).
Lu said the president's name change proposal does not involve changes to the nation's status or title.
Therefore, he said, the designation of the ROC embassies and consulates in countries that maintain formal diplomatic ties with the ROC will not be subject to change.

As for missions in countries with no diplomatic ties with the ROC, Lu said, the MOFA has been working on name change issues for the past few years. Now that Chen has given a timeframe for attaining the goal, he went on, the MOFA will continue negotiating the "name change" issues with the relevant countries.

The ROC forged diplomatic relations with the Pacific island nation of Kiribati in November 2003. As the embassy is situated opposite a building that used to house the PRC embassy, the ROC embassy's name plaque already bears a word "Taiwan " to avoid confusion.
Asked whether the ROC embassies in other countries will follow this practice, Lu said it requires a further study before a decision can be made.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Post: Military Commanders See Gains from Iraq Offenses. Generals predict no easy victory in pressing attack, remain concerned about rising campaign of intimidation. by Wennie Chi)

DOC.HEADLINE: GREY MULLET CONGREGATING OUTSIDE TAMSUI INSTEAD OF MIGRATING SOUTH
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Despite the arrival of this year's first cold front, schools of mullet -- the "fish that lay the golden eggs" -- have continued to congregate around Tamsui, northern Taiwan, instead of heading south in their normal migratory movement.
Fishermen in southern Taiwan have only caught about 1,000 of the fish over the weekend as so few have made the journey south along Taiwan's western coast.

Officials from the Council of Agriculture's Taiwan Fisheries Research Institute in Kaohsiung contacted Monday attributed the situation to the fact that the water in the southern part of the Taiwan Strait has remained too warm for the fish, which prefers colder water.

Grey mullet, the roe of which is an expensive hors-d'oeuvre on dinner tables in Taiwan and Japan, normally swim from the cold North Pacific in great shoals to the southern Taiwan Strait between early December and February every year to spawn before returning to the north.
These mullet schools usually show up off the coast just north of Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, which has long been mapped as a prime winter fishing ground.
About a decade ago, fishermen in southern Taiwan could catch big hauls of gravid mullet between December and February, particularly when cold fronts approached, making fortunes out of their catches.

In recent years, however, catches have declined year after year as a result of several factors, including water pollution, increased dynamite fishing by mainland Chinese fishermen, and interception of the shoals by mainland fishermen before they reach the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ANNOUNCES BALLOT ALLOCATION IN 10 CITIES, COUNTIES

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) announced a ballot allocation scheme in 10 of the nation's 25 cities and counties Monday to try to counter the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union as the campaign for the crucial Dec. 11 legislative elections enters the home stretch.

Lin Fong-cheng, KMT secretary-general, and Liao Fung-teh, director of the KMT's Organization and Development Committee, made the announcement as it is seeking to maximize the number of Legislative Yuan seats it can win.
According to Lin, polls have shown that nearly 30 percent of the respondents are willing to accept the ballot allocation plan, especially among voters in urban areas.

The DPP has in the past used ballot allocation scheme with great success, but this will be the first time the KMT has employed the scheme to ensure the maximum number of seats in the multi-seat constituency system.

Lin said that except for people in three categories, voters will be asked to vote for a certain KMT candidate based on voter criteria such as gender, township, or month of birth, in order to ensure that each candidate gets the maximum number of available votes.

He defined the three categories as voters who can be persuaded by KMT branch officials to vote for a specific candidate; retired servicemen -- traditional core supporters of the KMT -- who are assigned to support specific candidates; and those who have made up their minds to vote for a specific KMT candidate irrespective of any instructions from party officials.
Other KMT voters who have yet to decide for whom to vote should follow the vote allocation system, Lin said.
The 10 cities and counties in which the KMT want to use the scheme are Taichung and Tainan cities, Kaohsiung, Pingtung, Taoyuan, Yunlin, Tainan, Miaoli, Taichung, and Changhua counties.
He also said that the party is still coordinating in areas such as Taipei city and county and Kaohsiung city, in the hope that it can announce a plan Tuesday.

As for the ballot allocation scheme between the KMT and its "pan blue alliance" ally the People First Party (PFP), Lin said that a consensus has yet to be reached and the situation will have to be dealt with in each city and county individually.

Nantou County is reported to be the most likely place to adopt the ballot allocation scheme between the two parties, Lin said, adding that the KMT could allocate some of its diehard ballots to the PFP.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December gained three points to close at 5,883, with 25,694 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January moved up two points to finish at 5,884, with 219 contracts traded, while March futures gained 18 points to finish at 5,890, with nine contracts traded.
June futures lost three points to finish at 5,872, with five contracts traded, while September futures moved up 22 points to close at 5,810, with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,880 for December, 5,882 for January, 5,872 for March, 5,875 for June and 5,788 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
December TE futures moved down 0.3 points to close at 219, with 2,742 contracts traded, while January TE futures lost 0.45 points to finish at 219, with 63 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.
December TF futures gained four points to finish at 1,016.6, with 4,941 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved up 5.2 points to end at 1,015.4, with 192 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, dropping NT$0.13 to close at NT$32.070.
A total of US$754 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.200 and hit a low of NT$31.965.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTEROVIRUS INFECTION EXPANDS IN TAIPEI CITY

TEXT.P: Enterovirus infections in Taipei City have increased since mid-November, a city department of health official said Monday, adding that a total of 673 cases were reported by local clinics and hospitals during the period from Nov. 16-29.
The figure shows a major growth compared with the 237 cases reported in the same period of last year, Tsai Yi-chen said, quoting data compiled by the health department.
Tsai said schools reported that a total of 19 classes of students have been forced to stay home due to the outbreak during the two-week period. As of Monday, he added, four classes were still closed.

However, he indicated that despite the infection having broken out on a larger scale than last year, it poses less of a threat because the outbreak is mainly caused by the less severe Coxsackie viruses rather than the much more serious Enterovirus 71. In the past two weeks, only one case of acute infection has been reported in Taipei City, Tsai said.

Nevertheless, the official said the cases in the recent outbreak are lasting longer than in past years and that therefore, the public should stay alert and pay attention to personal and environmental hygiene to prevent infection.
Everyone is at risk of enterovirus infection, although infants and children are more susceptible, he warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: New Ukraine Runoff Set for Dec. 26.
Handing a major victory to the opposition, Ukraine's Supreme Court on Friday invalidated the Nov. 21 runoff and ordered a repeat vote for Dec. 26. But political turmoil continued to grip the country Sunday after parliament refused to pass reforms backed by outgoing President Leonid Kuchma that would weaken the presidency and failed to amend election laws to help ensure a fair presidential vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGES PRESIDENT TO `RESPECT MANDATE' WHEN FORMING CABINET

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian should respect the mandate that will be revealed in the Dec. 11 legislative elections when he forms a new Cabinet, the legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Monday.

Huang Teh-fu, KMT legislative whip, was elaborating on KMT Chairman Lien Chan's remarks the previous day on the campaign trail in which he claimed that if the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) win a majority in the 225-seat legislature, it can form a Cabinet "according to the Constitution."
Huang claimed that "according to democratic norms, " if the legislative majority forms the Cabinet, it will be key to stable executive and legislative relations.

He noted that President Chen Shui-bian has the right to appoint the premier according to the Constitution but added that the president should respect the mandate as shown in the legislative election results.

According to Huang, if the "pan-green camp" is in charge of the forming of a Cabinet even if the "pan-blue alliance" wins a majority in the legislature, then the legislative elections will be rendered meaningless.

He claimed that the chaos in recent years can be attributed to what he described as Chen's "lack of respect for the majority" in the legislature. A minority Cabinet has resulted in the constant bickering between the executive and legislative branches, he said.

The "pan-blue alliance" currently holds a slim majority in the 225-seat legislature and Chen is urging voters to give the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally Taiwan Solidarity Union a clear majority so that the government can push through its policies smoothly rather than having them thwarted at every turn by the opposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX OVERSEAS SCHOOLS TO BE DESIGNATED AS 'TAIWAN' SCHOOLS: MOE

TEXT.P: The six Taiwan-financed Chinese schools in Southeast Asia will be designated as "overseas Taiwan schools" in line with government policy, Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng said Monday.

Tu made the remarks after President Chen Shui-bian said the previous day that the nation will identify itself as "Taiwan" when taking part in international activities, to clearly distinguish it from mainland China.

According to the president's plan, the Republic of China's representative offices in countries with which it does not maintain formal diplomatic ties will be designated as "Taiwan" representative offices and the word "China" in state-owned firms will be replaced by the word "Taiwan."
Asked about his views on Chen's proposal, Tu pointed out that as the Ministry of Education is a government organ, its job is to implement government policy.
"So if the proposed name change becomes policy, the MOE will implement it," he said.
At the moment, there are six Taiwan-financed Chinese schools in six Southeast Asian cities -- Ho Chi Minh City, Bangkok, Kuala Lumpur, Penang, Jakarta and Surabaya.

Tu said that although those schools are private establishment, they have traditionally received financing from the ROC government. Moreover, he went on, the ROC government has sent conscripts to teach at those schools to fulfill their alternative military service. The six schools now have more than 1,500 students in total.

As for several local universities that bear the words "China" or "Chinese" in their names, MOE officials said since those schools are all private, the MOE is not in a position to require them to change their designations.

DOC.HEADLINE: EAST ASIA EDUCATION FORUM TO OPEN IN HSINCHU

TEXT.P: The 7th East Asia Education Forum is scheduled to be held in Hsinchu City Dec. 7-8, with the participation of 60 members from six countries and area -- Japan, South Korea, Mongolia, mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan.

The two-day event, organized by the National Teachers' Association, will discuss the issue of teachers' status and educational reforms. The purpose of the association's hosting of the forum is to review Taiwan's educational affairs by conducting an exchange of opinions among the participants so that the country can learn from other countries, the organizers said.

Aside from the opinion-sharing forum, the organizing committee will also try to familiarize the foreign participants with Taiwan culture by offering them visits to the National Palace Museum in Taipei City and various places of historical importance in Hsinchu, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEXTILE CONFERENCE OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A three-day textile conference organized by the government and industry representatives to discuss various textile-related topics opened in Taipei Monday.

The "Technical Textile Conference and Exhibition", jointly held by the Department of Industrial Technology of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Taiwan Textile Research Institute and the Taiwan Technical Textiles Association, is to discuss health, medical care, warning labels and digital watermarks issues in the textile industry.
A total of 32 panel discussions will be held during the three-day meeting, which will also feature an exhibition of 164 of the latest innovations in textile products developed by Taiwanese firms.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh indicated that Taiwan's industrial-use textile production accounts for only 2 percent of world's total output. "There is still major room for future growth," she said.
From January to October this year, Taiwan exported US$2 billion-worth of industrial-use textile products, while the world generated US$100 billion during the same period.
Other participants also suggested ways for Taiwanese firms to survive in the market.

Hwang Yao-tang, chairman of the Taiwan Textile Research Institute, said that as the global textile market will enter a "non-quota" age next year, firms in Taiwan should focus more on the fast-growing industrial-use textile market if they want to succeed amid fierce competition.
The industrial-use textile market grows at a rate of 50 percent every decade.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO BE CAUTIOUS AMID DIPLOMATIC SUPPRESSION BY BEIJING

TEXT.P: Taiwan should make greater efforts to spotlight the country's mainstream public opinion internationally so as to effectively curb Beijing's diplomatic blockade under the pretext of "quelling Taiwan independence, " scholars have urged.

At a recent seminar sponsored by the National Development Outlook Foundation on Beijing's diplomatic strategy toward Taiwan since the re-election of President Chen Shui-bian, scholars unanimously urged the government to take countermeasures in the international community in the face of Beijing's description of "Taiwan independence" as the source of disaster in East Asia.

Chen I-shin, a professor at the Graduate Institute of American Studies under Tamkang University, said that Beijing's relentless suppression of Taiwan independence seems on the surface to be detrimental to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the pro-Taiwan independence movement.
But Chen pointed out that the country as a whole would be hurt the most should the Beijing's rhetoric become the basic tone of the international stance on Taiwan independence.
If remarks on Taiwan's lack of sovereignty made by U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell "were accepted by the international community," it would do immeasurable damage to Taiwan, according to Chen.
He contended that Taiwan must seek to maintain a balance in the delicate Beijing-Washington-Tokyo ties to ensure the maximum benefits in Taiwan's interests to protect the country's security.
Powell said in late October in Hong Kong that Taiwan is not independent and does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation.

Chi Shun-chieh, deputy secretary-general of the Taiwan International Studies Association, said that Beijing's scheme to align other countries to stem Taiwan independence by using its growing economic and diplomatic power has kept increased pressure on Taiwan.
Beijing's influence, Chi said, has even expanded to Latin America, the backyard of the United States and the diplomatic stronghold of Taiwan, home to most of the country's diplomatic allies.

Commenting on Beijing's claim that there only is the "Taiwan independence problem" rather than the "Taiwan problem, " he called it a Chinese communist strategy to fan a diplomatic war against Taiwan with stronger foreign support to clamp down on the independence movement.

However, he also agreed that it is very difficult for Taipei to directly confront Beijing when the Chinese communist regime can use its vast resources to conduct a diplomatic war. He proposed that the government make concrete moves to allow the voice of Taiwan people to be heard clearly on the world stage.

Wang Kun-i, a deputy professor at the Graduate Institute of International Affairs and Strategic Studies of Tamkang University, said that the Beijing regime has taken anti-independence as a priority over advocating unification between the two sides.

At a time when member states of the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) are increasingly tilting toward Beijing, the Chinese communists are trying hard to win backing from the United States regarding the Taiwan independence issue after Taipei and Beijing suspended bilateral negotiations, he warned.

The scholars spoke out in unison that Taiwan should exercise tremendous caution when facing Beijing's voracious diplomatic offensive and when the United States is also seeking cooperation from Beijing on issues related to the international anti-terror campaign and on nuclear power problems on the Korean peninsula.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPI ANNUAL INCREASE SHOWS NO INFLATION PRESSURE: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The annual increase of the consumer price index (CPI) was only 1.49 percent in November, showing that there is little pressure of inflation, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Monday.
DGBAS officials said that the CPI in November was 101.23, down 1.2 percent from October, mainly because November is harvest time for winter vegetables, with resultant drops in price.

The officials estimated that the average increase of the CPI in the first 11 months was 1.61 percent, compared with an increase of 4.1 percent for the first 10 months in mainland China, 3.7 percent in South Korea, 2.5 percent in the United States and 1.7 percent in Singapore, a sign of very modest or "non-existent" inflation.
On the wholesale price index (WPI) , the index was 111.72 in November, down 1.78 percent from October, mainly because prices of agricultural products and crude oil dropped.

Compared with the same month of last year, there was an increase of 9.06 percent, but this was still a dramatic drop from between 10 percent and 11 percent in the third quarter. The average WPI increase in the first 11 months was 7.16 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE TERRESTRIAL TV STATIONS BEGIN BROADCASTING CAMPAIGN VIDEOS

TEXT.P: Five local terrestrial television stations began broadcasting legislative campaign commercials produced by major political parties Monday, five days ahead of the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

According to regulations governing political parties use of televised broadcast media for campaigning, the Central Election Commission (CEC) is required to arrange at least two time slots on terrestrial TV stations for political parties to air campaign material.

A political party must have fielded five or more candidates to be qualified for the CEC-sponsored TV campaign time slots. For the upcoming elections, five parties are eligible to share the TV campaign time slots, which are to be distributed in proportion to the number of each party's candidates.

CEC officials said they have arranged to broadcast campaign material of the five parties on five local terrestrial TV stations from 9 p.m. to 10 p.m. Monday through Friday. The broadcasts will start with a four-minute film produced by the CEC to raise public awareness of the upcoming legislative elections and rules governing them.

The remaining time will be allocated to the five political parties as follows: the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, 20 minutes; the Kuomintang (KMT) , 16 minutes; the People First Party, nine minutes; the Taiwan Solidarity Union, six minutes; and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union, five minutes.
The CEC approved all of the campaign videos late last month presented by the five political parties.

Chi Chen-nan, a CEC commissioner who headed the video screening committee, said that even though the opposition KMT-produced video contains defamatory slogans against the CEC, the commission still agreed to its broadcast based on the principle of freedom of speech.
Chi said the CEC screened the campaign videos using objectivity, impartiality, neutrality and legality.
According to Chi, the KMT video contains slogans such as "the Central Election Commission violates the law; is not impartial and not fair," and "Chen Shui-bian used illegal means to gain power."

As those words do not violate Article 54 of the Public Functionary Election and Recall Law or Articles 21 and 22 of the Radio Broadcasting and Television Law, Chi said the CEC's screening panel gave the green light to the video.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Marines' raids underline push in crucial area.
The U.S. Marine Strike Force Two, in a convoy of unlit Humvees, entered some of Iraq's deadliest terrain. For the 10 weeks since thier battalion began operating in this area south of Baghdad, raids like this one by Strike Force Two have captured more than 250 people identified as suspected insurgents. Others, fleeing or resisting, have been killed. The raids have taken an American toll, too. Since late September, the Second Battalion of the 24th Marine Expeditionary Unit has lost eight men. It has deployed in what has become, since November's battle for Falluja, one of the war's most crucial battle zones.
Wall Street Journal: Unlikely democrat leads the charge in Ukraine's revolt.
Yulia Tymoshenko who issued her marching orders to the crowd to blockade the Council of Ministers and applied the radical use of "peopple power" brought the Ukrainian government to the negotiating table. Unlike Walesa or Vaclav Havel, a Czechoslovakian playwright who rose to the presidency, the leaders of Kiev's "orange revolution" aren't idealistic outsiders. Many stood at the helm of Ukraine's government and business establishment just a few years ago under current President Leonid Kuchma, whom they now decry as a dictator. Ms. Tymoshenko herself is a former billionaire who made a fortune through political connections in the murky aftermath of the Soviet Union. As a deputy prime minister in 1999-2001, she kept an office in the same Council of Ministers building her supporters now block. "Tymoshenko is posing as a folk heroine, but her history is a history of oligarchic clans in Ukraine, " says Stepan Havrysh, head of the pro- government Democratic Initiatives faction in Ukraine's parliament. "All these people in the opposition didn't just work for Kuchma, they got their influence, their visibility, their importance thanks to him. They know very well how this system works, and now they're simply trying to take it over."

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN WELCOMES ONE-MILLIONTH TAIWAN VISITOR IN 2004
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Japan celebrated the arrival Monday of the one-millionth visitor from Taiwan this year.
The visitor, Cheng Tao-lung, received a commemorative citation and souvenirs from Japanese tourist promotion authorities in a ceremony held at Narita International Airport on the outskirts of Tokyo.

Cheng arrived at Narita via a Japan Asia Airways (JAA) flight along with his newlywed wife Monday afternoon for a five-day honeymoon trip. JAA and the two Taiwan carriers operating regular Taiwan-Japan flight services -- China airlines and EVA Airways --also presented souvenirs to Cheng at the ceremony.
"I'm very lucky to become the one-millionth visitor," Cheng said, adding that he would buy lottery tickets in Taiwan after his return to see if his luck was still holding.
Both Cheng and his wife, Liu Hsiu-pao, work at an optoelectrical company in northern Taiwan.
With the slogan "visit Japan, " Japan has selected Lin Chih-ling, a popular Taiwan fashion model, as its goodwill envoy to help attract more Taiwan tourists to Japan.

According to official tallies, Japan's tourist arrivals have already exceeded six million so far this year, with one million from Taiwan. Japan is expected to attract 1.3 million Taiwan tourists next year. To reach that goal, it has decided to offer visa-free entry for Taiwan citizens for a six-month period from March 2005 in concert with the eco-friendly world exposition to be held in Aichi prefecture. If all goes well, the visa-free privilege for Taiwan citizens may become permanent after EXPO 2005 Aichi.
In contrast, the number of Japanese tourists to Taiwan has not increased as fast as expected. As of Oct. 31, Japanese citizens had made about 710,000 visits to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO HOLD INTERNATIONAL SEMINAR ON HEALTH IN CITIES

TEXT.P: An international seminar on health issues in cities will be held by the Taipei City Bureau of Health Dec. 14-16, and the event is open to the public.
The health bureau said 16 experts from 12 overseas cities will share their experiences in promoting health.
Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will sign a "healthy city charter" and will vow to work together with other international cities to promote health.
The seminar, conducted in English, has interpreters to help participants though sections presented in Chinese.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHING BOAT DETAINED BY INDIA IS NOT TAIWAN'S: MOFA

TEXT.P: The fishing boat seized by the Indian navy in waters near the Andaman Sea in the Bay of Bengal Nov. 30 with dozens of suspicious crewmen aboard belongs to Thailand, not Taiwan, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs official said Monday.

Ministry spokesman Michel Lu was responding to foreign wire service reports that two Taiwan boats with 40-plus suspicious crewmen on board were seized late last month for intruding into Indian territorial waters.

Lu said the reports were not correct. Lu confirmed that a Taiwan fishing boat -- the "Yumanhsiang No. 20" -- was intercepted by Indian naval ships in the Bay of Bengal Oct. 27. He said the three Taiwan crewmen aboard were released on bail Nov. 29 and that Indian judicial authorities will hold a hearing Dec. 9 to decide whether the fishing boat will also be released on bail.

As to the fishing boat seized by the Indian navy Nov. 30, identified as the "Haihsiang No. 67, " Lu said it is registered in Thailand, not in Taiwan. The "Haihsiang's" skipper, however, is a Taiwan citizen, Lu said, adding that the ship's owner in Thailand has commissioned an Indian firm to handle the case. Lu said Taiwan's representative office in India will offer assistance to the Taiwan skipper if needed.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM ASSURES A SMOOTH VOTE COUNT OF LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Chunghwa Telecom has assured the Central Election Commission (CEC) that the vote count for the Dec. 11 legislative elections will go smoothly despite a walkout threat by the company's labor union, a CEC official said Monday.

CEC Deputy Secretary-General Deng Tian-you said that executives assigned by Chunghwa Telecom visited the CEC Monday and presented it with well-thought out contingency plans should any disruptions occur on voting day.

The labor union for the state-owned telecommunications company passed a resolution in an islandwide members' vote a day earlier to enable workers to go on strike as a means of safeguarding their rights and interests.
The union did not rule out the possibility of carrying out the resolution on the day of the legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TRUTH INVESTIGATION COMMISSION' POSTS 10 QUESTIONS ON WEB SITE

TEXT.P: A commission created to investigate the presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu has posted 10 questions surrounding the March 19 shooting on its Web site, and is asking scholars and experts to come forward to provide their expertise to help solve the case.

The "March 19th Shooting Truth Investigation Special Commission," which was created under a special bill that cleared the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan in August, called a news conference Monday and unveiled the 10 questions: 1. Where did the lead bullets come from? 2. Was there a second gunman? 3. Why did the two shell casings picked up by bystanders show no sign of being fired? Why were no shells recovered that did indicate that they had been fired? 4. Was President Chen Shui-bian's abdomen wound the result of a gunshot or a knife? 5. Why was there so little blood from the wound? 6. Why was a microscopic examination of the wound not directly obtained and why was it only taken days later and then transferred via a number of people? Was the president's white blood cell count abnormal? 7. Why are the two holes in Chen's shirt marking the entry and exit points of the bullet on the right side of his abdomen and why is the distance between the two 7.5 cm when the wound is 11 cm? 8. What caused the holes in the shirt and the trousers of the president? 9. Why did the president's jacket show signs of having been melted by heat? 10. Why were the fibers attached to the lead bullets, which were found to be similar to fibers of the president's jacket, underwear and shirt, in an inconsistent pattern? The commission's Web site is: http://www.the319.org.

The shooting took place on March 19, 2004 while President Chen and Vice President Lu were canvassing for votes in the streets of Tainan, southern Taiwan, in an open-top jeep. Both of them sustained minor injuries.

Chinese-American forensic expert Henry Lee, who was invited to help with the investigation, confirmed in his report that the wound suffered by the president to his abdomen was caused by a bullet and that it ran from right to left across the abdomen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FORECAST TO PUT OUT 31 MILLION CD-ROM RECORDERS IN Q4

TEXT.P: Taiwan is forecast to produce 31 million CD-ROM recorders in the fourth quarter of this year, up by 14.4 percent over the previous year's level, according to the findings of a panel under the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI).

The country made a total of 27 million CD-ROM recorders in the third quarter, with a production value of US$920 million, marking a 2.7 percent increase year-to-year, a spokesman for the Industrial Technology Intelligence Services (ITIS) under the ITRI said.

He attributed the increase in Q3 output value to the timely marketing of new products, such as more advanced DVD recorders, as the average price of a locally made CD-ROM recorder rose to US$33.8 during the three-month period.

The growth in both production quantity and value in the third quarter was mainly boosted by strong demand for personal computers (including desktops and notebooks) from across the world ahead of the winter peak season, he explained, predicting that the Q4 number of the world's PCs will rise by 10 percent over the Q3 figure.
DVD recorders absorbed 19 percent of the country's total CD-ROM production in the third quarter, a growth as compared to the 14 percent posted in the second quarter, ITIS statistics show.
The ratio of DVD-related products, such as DVD-ROM readers and DVD-ROM combos, as a percentage of Taiwan's overall CD-ROM recorders has outstripped that of CD-related goods.
The former group grabbed 58 percent of Taiwan's overall output of CD-ROM recorders in the third quarter, an advance from the Q2 level of 55 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-GREEN' MAJORITY TO FACILITATE 'NAME CHANGE' CAMPAIGN: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Monday if the "pan-green" camp can win a clear majority in the new legislature to be elected this weekend, it will greatly facilitate the "name change" campaign to clearly distinguish Taiwan from mainland China.

Yu was responding to President Chen Shui-bian's announcement of his plan a day earlier that the Republic of China's representative offices in countries with which it does not maintain formal diplomatic ties will be designated as "Taiwan" representative offices and the word "China" in state-owned firms will be replaced by the word "Taiwan" in two years.

Yu said if the "pan-green" camp of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- can win a clear majority in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, the "name change" campaign will get a big boost.

Yu said the DPP is facing difficulties in the Taipei County's first and third constituencies as well as the Taichung and Kaohsiung constituencies. He urged "pan-green" supporters to pool their strength to back DPP nominees in the upcoming elections so that the "pan-green" camp can win a legislative majority to end domestic political chaos. (By Sofia Wu) ednitem

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SHOOTING INVESTIGATION COMMISSION' TO FINE THREE SENIOR OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: The "March 19th Shooting Truth Investigation Special Commission" will fine three senior officials for defying the commission's demand to cooperate and for not surrendering documents in their charge, Shih Chih-yang, convener of the commission said Monday.

Shih said the commission decided Monday to impose a fine of NT$300,000 (US$9,372) each on Secretary-General of the National Security Council Chiou I-jen, Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan and Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan.

Shih said Chen ignored the commission's order to assign several prosecutors to work for the commission as provided for by the statute that created the commission, and Su is accused of telling agencies under his ministry not to grant any requests from the commission.
Shih said his commission has asked 23 government agencies to present 52 documents, but most of these agencies did not reply in a timely fashion.
In order to carry out its duty of investigating the presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian, Shih said his commission will exert its power to impose fines.

The commission was formed according to a statute railroaded through the Legislative Yuan by the opposition parties but has been decried as an unconstitutional organization by the Executive Yuan, which has not followed any orders of the commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, GUATEMALA TO BEGIN FTA TALKS

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh will sign a free trade agreement (FTA) consultation framework Tuesday with her counterpart from Guatemala, Marcio Cuevas, and begin their first meeting on FTA issues.

Ministry officials said that two-way trade between Taiwan and Guatemala totaled US$92.1 million in 2003, and it is hoped that an FTA will help Taiwan businesspeople better engage in the Central American market.
The officials said that Guatemala is the largest economy in Central America, and its gross domestic production totaled US$24.7 billion last year, or one-third of Central America's GDP.

They noted that the United States completed FTA talks with five countries in Central America -- Nicaragua, Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador and Costa Rica -- last December and that the Guatemala central bank has predicted that its economic growth this year could reach 2.6 percent with the economic rebound that began early this year.

The five Central American nations signed the U.S. FTA and will establish a common market in one or two years, they said, adding that if Taiwan can sign an FTA with Nicaragua or Guatemala, it will help the island make inroads into the Central American market.

Taiwan and Nicaragua just concluded a second round of FTA talks last weekend in San Francisco and decided to hold the third round of talks in February before signing a formal FTA in the first half of next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT PLANS TO HOST TAIWAN EXPO IN 2008

TEXT.P: The government will host the country's first Taiwan Expo in 2008, and hopes to attract 5.5 million visitors, create 13,000 job opportunities and business worth NT$54.6 billion (US$1.7 billion), a government official said Monday.

Tu Tze-chun, director-general of the Commerce Department under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, made the announcement following a meeting of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) . CEPD members adopted a resolution commissioning the economics ministry to assess the project across the board, Tu said.

To sponsor a colossal international event like Taiwan Expo 2008, the first of its kind for the country, the government will put in NT$19.5 billion to construct buildings and relevant facilities in three planned exhibition compounds in northern Taoyuan County and southern Chiayi and Tainan counties, he said.

As Taiwan is not a member of the Bureau of International Exposition (BIE), which bans its members from taking part in similar exhibitions held by non-BIE countries, the government plans to invite Taiwan's diplomatic partners that are not BIE members and 19 U.S. states that maintain a trade office in Taiwan, as well as large multinationals to take part in the Taiwan Expo 2008, he added.
The exhibition will run from May to September that year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO IMMEDIATE VANUATU COURT RULING ON NO-CONFIDENCE VOTE: ROC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Kau Ying-mao said Monday that the final ruling from Vanuatu's court deliberating on parliament's call for a no-confidence vote on Prime Minister Serge Vohor may take some time.
Kau is currently on the south Pacific island nation to try to cement diplomatic relations with the ROC's latest ally.

Kau was referring to a ruling by a Vanuatu high court Tuesday on parliament's plan to launch a non-confidence vote regarding Vohor over his decision to establish diplomatic ties with the Republic of China.
The opposition in Vanuatu, which is angry with Vohor's firm support of diplomatic relations between Vanuatu and Taiwan, is planning to vote Vohor out of office.
Kau said in a telephone interview with CNA that regardless of the ruling, the case can still be appealed to a higher court.
Kau said that he would return to Taiwan on Wednesday.
Vohor and ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen signed a joint communique to establish diplomatic relations Nov. 3, making Vanuatu the 27th ally of the ROC.
However, China has continued to woo Vanuatu from the ROC, and a diplomatic tug-of-war between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is playing out in the South Pacific island state.
