DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS MISSION SHOULD REFLECT 'TAIWAN' IN NAME: CABINET SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will come up with a method to change the names of the country's overseas representative offices and state-run enterprises to highlight their Taiwan identity, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Monday.
The spokesman, Chen Chi-mai, said Premier Yu Shyi-kun has appointed Minister without Portfolio Shu Chih-hsiung to draw up a plan to do this within two months.

Chen said the names used by Taiwan in international organizations including Taipei China; Taipei, China; Chinese Taipei; and China (Taiwan) fail to underline their Taiwan identity and the fact that Taiwan is separate from China.
The name of Republic of China, which is used by Taiwan in dealing with countries that recognize it, will remain unchanged, Chen said.

The names, used by Taiwan to call its representative offices in countries which don't recognize it diplomatically, such as the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office and the Institute of Chinese Culture, fail to indicate that they are from Taiwan, Chen said.
These names should be converted into the Taiwan Representative Office through negotiations with the host countries in the future.

State-run enterprises or foundations which used the name China or Chinese, including Chunghua, will be changed to avoid being mistaken as enterprises or foundations from the People's Republic of China.
In order to change their names, the charters of these companies and foundations should be revised first according to law, Chen went on.

The name-changing campaign has nothing to do with the Democratic Progressive Party's cause for an independent country named Taiwan, Chen said, adding that Taiwan, as a term, is more popular than China on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 8, or the 27th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Austria becomes the first nation to establish a state education system.
1889: Jefferson Davis, the first and only president of the Confederate States of America, dies at the age of 81. He was captured by Union soldiers in 1865 and imprisoned for two years. Although indicted for treason, he was never prosecuted.
1907: One of the worst coal mine disasters in U.S. history occurs at Mononagh, West Virginia, killing 361 people.
1911: Mongolia is declared a Russian protectorate.
1917: The Republic of Finland is proclaimed.
1917: The steamship Mont Blanc collides with the steamship Imo in Halifax, Canada, killing more than 1,500 people, injuring 8,000 others, and destroying a large part of the city.
1921: Britain signs a peace treaty with Ireland under which the Irish Free States is established and Ireland accepts Dominion status.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt appeals to Japan's Emperor Hirohito for peace.
1943: The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union issue the Joint Declaration of the Tehran Conference.
1957: The United States fails in the launching of its first satellite.
1960: Taiwan Province implements the use of media broadcasts for the first time in the history of Republic of China military service in order to muster the required number of reservists.
1971: India recognizes the Democratic Republic of Bangladesh.
1973: The United Nations decides to establish the United Nations University in Tokyo.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford arrives in the Philippines for talks on new terms for U.S. air and naval basses in the country.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan receives Mrs. Paul Norman Brown, national president of the American Legion Ladies' Auxiliary, at the Presidential Office.
1979: The Communist Chinese ban the sticking of "big character posters" on Beijing's wall of democracy.
1980: The 1980 Supplementary Parliamentarian election sends 70 members to the Legislative Yuan and 76 to the National Assembly.
1986: Eighty-four members are newly elected to the Legislative Yuan and seventy-three members are newly elected to the National Assembly in the 1986 legislative by-elections. Voter turnout is 65.4 percent of the 11.8 million eligible registered voters.
1988: The ROC Legislative Yuan is paralyzed by fist-fighting, as the chairman for the first time asks police to maintain order.
1989: The worst mass killing in Canadian history takes place when a gunman shoots 13 female students to death at the University of Montreal before killing himself.
1990: President Saddam Hussein announces that all 3,400 foreign hostages held in Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait are now free to leave.
1990: Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad steps down at the height of a pro-democracy movement in Bangladesh.
1996: The Legislative Yuan revises the Labor Standards Law so that employees in nearly all industries will be covered by the end of 1998.
1999: The ROC-Japan Economic Conference opens in Tokyo.
2000: The Republic of China's Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs removes restrictions on workers from the Philippines, with the change effective retroactively to Dec. 1.
2000: Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez arrives in Taipei for an official visit.
2001: Taiwan's two largest opposition parties, the Kuomintang and the People First Pary, decide not to participate in the "national stabilization alliance" that has been proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: The computer virus "Goner, " first found in the United States, is rampant in Hong Kong with at least 16 companies' computer systems being hit.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler does not answer to the desires of the subjects, it shows a lack of understanding of the approvals and disapprovals of the subjects. When there is no such understanding, then the good will not be discovered and rewarded and the bad will not be punished."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. 'TAIWAN CAUCUS' CONGRESSMAN VISITING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: U.S. congressman Steve Chabot (R-Ohio) , a co-chairman of the pro-Taiwan U.S. Congressional Taiwan Caucus, arrived in Taipei Wednesday for a week-long visit.
According to Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, Chabot is in Taiwan mainly to observe Saturday's legislative elections.

Chabot is also scheduled to meet with President Chen Shui-bian to exchange views on a wide range of topics, with Taiwan's name-change plan for its overseas representative offices and state-run enterprises expected to be a major focus of the talks.

Chabot and the other Congressional Taiwan Caucus co-chairmen recently wrote a letter to President Chen to express their support for Taiwan's plan to change the name of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States to the Taiwan Representative Office in the United States. The office is Taiwan's de facto embassy in the United States in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.

In the letter, Chabot said that a new name for the office with the word "Taiwan" in it would much more precisely reflect the characteristics of the government in Taiwan, and that he would extend whatever help he could to facilitate the name-change effort.

During his stay in Taiwan, Chabot is also expected to meet with Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen for talks on various issues, including U.S. arms sales to Taiwan and diplomacy exchanges between Taiwan's Legislative Yuan and the U.S. Congress.

President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo will preside today a Cabinet meeting at the National Disaster Coordinating Council (NDCC) to assess the overall damage caused by the four weather disturbances that hit the country and killed more than 700 persons.

The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore researchers invent new weapon to destroy cancer cells.
And after seven years of research,Singapore scientists have discovered a way to stop the cancer cells from dividing.
They have developed a synthetic protein fragment that disrupts cell division, killing cancer cells in the process.
The research team,Biomedical Sciences Group at the Intellectual Property Management Division of Exploit Technologies, is confident that the new drug can be introduced into the market in about five years' time.

Close to four decades after deserting the U.S. Army for North Korea, Charles Jenkins was greeted by cheering crowds in his wife's hometown on a remote island in northern Japan, where he said he plans to live out his remaining days.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA SAYS DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH ROC TO REMAIN UNCHANGED
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Panamanian First Vice President and Foreign Affairs Minister Samuel Lewis Navarro reiterated Tuesday that Panama's formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China on Taiwan have been solid and will remain unchanged.

Lewis said during a press conference marking the 100th day in office of the new Panamanian government led by President Martin Torrijos that although Panama has maintained strong business and trade ties with mainland China and that these ties will continue to increase, this does not necessarily mean that Panama should change its diplomatic relations with Taiwan.

Lewis made the remarks in response to a question by a Xinhua News Agency reporter about whether Panama plans to further rev up its diplomatic relations with China, which is generally considered an important player in world trade with a huge market and which maintains close interactions with Latin America.
The first vice president noted that Panama has on many occasions reiterated its stance of maintaining formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan while continuing to bolster commercial ties with China.

Lewis claimed that China indeed has played an ever-increasingly important role in the world's trade arena and that it is one of the key users of the Panama Canal and that these are the reasons why Panama has maintained strong business and trade ties with that country.

He said that expanding commercial ties with countries around the world remains one of the government's priority tasks. For example, he pointed out, Panama is currently engaging in the sixth round of free trade agreement talks with the United States. Once the talks are concluded, the Panamanian government will hold similar talks with other countries, and mainland China will naturally not be left out, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP URGES SUPPORTERS TO COME OUT IN LARGE NUMBERS

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) said Wednesday that Taiwan has in recent years experienced a massive exodus of people and that "pan-blue alliance" supporters must throw their weight behind the alliance's legislative candidates in Saturday's legislative elections.
The PFP legislative caucus made the appeal in a get-out-the-vote drive amid reports that voters are apathetic about the elections,

Liu Wen-hsiung, PFP whip in the Legislative Yuan, noted that a majority of the Taiwanese who have emigrated overseas in recent years are traditionally "pan-blue" supporters. As they are unlikely to return to vote this time, he urged the "pan-blue" supporters in Taiwan to come out to vote in large numbers.

PFP Legislator Pang Chien-kuo said that between 1983 and 2000, there were about 290,000 Taiwanese who did not return to Taiwan after heading overseas, and that the figure reached nearly 105,00 for the 2002-2003 period. He said the exodus has become serious, pointing out that the figure for just the first four months of this year was about 72,000,

Meanwhile, Pang's colleague Lin Cheng-yi claimed that a lot of overseas Taiwanese are dissatisfied with President Chen Shui-bian's performance and that many of them have thus helped their relatives emigrate.
As many of these people are skilled professionals, Lin expressed concerns about a "brain drain" that could undercut the nation's competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: House Easily Passes Intelligence Reform Bill.
Legislation creates new directorship position but allows for less than full control over intelligence agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York State votes to reduce drug sentence
New York State lawmakers voted Tuesday evening to reduce the steep mandatory prison sentences given to people convicted of drug crimes in the state, sanctions considered among t he most severe in the nation. The so-called Rockefeller drug laws instituted in the 1970's put some low-level first-time drug offenders behind bars for sentences ranging from 15 years to life. Under the changes passed Tuesday, which Gov. George E. Pataki said he would sign, the sentence for those same offenders would be reduced to 8 to 20 years in prison. The law will allow more than 400 inmates serving lengthy prison terms on those top counts to apply to judges to get out of jail early.
Wall Street Journal: As chaos mounts in Iraq, U.S. Army rethinks its future
Shortly after the U.S. deposed Saddam Hussein's regime in April 2003, the Army kicked off its annual "war game," a mock battle in which U.S. forces set out to topple another Middle Eastern regime. However, the exercise stands as an example of how senior Army leaders and Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld in the years leading up to the Iraq invasion were guided by a flawed understanding of how future enemies would fight.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE GROUP PROTESTS U.S. MEDDLING

TEXT.P: A group of pro-independence activists staged a demonstration outside the American Institute in Taiwan Wednesday to protest what they called the United States' interference in Taiwan's internal affairs.

Members of the Alliance to Campaign for Rectifying the Name of Taiwan and several legislative candidates of the Taiwan Solidarity Union staged the demonstration one day after U.S. State Department deputy spokesman Adam Ereli said Washington is not supportive of the island's plan to change the names of its foreign missions and state-run enterprises to include the word "Taiwan."
Alliance leader Peter Wang said it is ridiculous that a democratic country like the United States does not support Taiwan calling itself "Taiwan" just because of pressure from China.
Wang pointed out that the United States has always used the word "Taiwan" to refer to the island and that Taiwan's exports to the United States are also labeled "made in Taiwan."

The protesters claimed that mainstream public opinion in Taiwan is in favor of rectifying the names of Taiwan's overseas missions and state-run companies and that President Chen Shui-bian's name-change proposal was put forth in response to this popular demand.
The demonstrators urged the United States to respect the rights of the people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO SPEAK AT FORMOSA FOUNDATION BANQUET
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By L.S. Chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Los Angeles-based Formosa Foundation announced Tuesday that President Chen Shui-bian will give a keynote speech at a dinner banquet after an international conference sponsored by the foundation in Taipei next Monday.

Foundation Chairman Donald Lee said that the foundation is honored to have President Chen serve as a keynote speaker, adding that "we are very humbled by the personal sacrifices President Chen and his family have made for Taiwan's democracy and human rights."
Peng Ming-min, senior advisor to President Chen, and June Teufel Dreyer, a professor and political science department head at the University of Miami, will also speak at the banquet.

Dreyer also serves as commissioner of the U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission, which presented a report to the U.S. Congress this June in which it suggested a revising of the long-standing "one China" policy of the United States, saying that the policy is no longer in the United States' interests.

The conference, to be held right after Taiwan's Dec. 11 legislative elections, will consist of four panels: the 2004 elections in Taiwan, cross-strait relations and Taiwan's economic future, the implications of the elections on the political and strategic relationship between the United States and Taiwan, and revisiting the "one China" policy.

Participants to the conference will include prominent U.S. experts John Tkack, Shelly Rigger, Daniel Lynch and Ross H. Munro. Former Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen will be the keynote speaker at the luncheon meeting.

The Formosa Foundation is a non-profit corporation formed in 2001 to promote greater understanding of the relationship among Taiwan, the United States and the People's Republic of China, and to preserve and enhance democracy, human rights and the freedom of the people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S VISA-FREE PLAN FOR TAIWAN VISITORS REMAINS UNCHANGED: MOFA

TEXT.P: Japan's plan to offer visa-free treatment to visitors from Taiwan during the six months of the EXPO 2005 AICHI beginning March 1, 2005 remains unchanged, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Wednesday.

Lu made the remarks in response to a report by Japan's Kyodo News a day earlier that the Japanese government would not grant "permanent" visa-free treatment to Taiwan visitors beginning from the EXPO 2005 AICHI.
Lu noted that the Japanese government had never said that it would grant "permanent" visa-free privilege to visitors from Taiwan from the EXPO 2005 AICHI.
He said that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials contacted Japanese authorities Tuesday and were told that the six-month visa-free plan beginning next March remains unchanged.

Japanese Foreign Minister Nobutaka Machimura said last Friday that based on revised laws, Japan will offer visa-free entry to Taiwan tourist during the EXPO 2005 AICHI from March 25 through Sept. 25, 2005, in order to attract more visitors from the island.
After that, Machimura said, Japan may consider granting "permanent" visa-free treatment to Taiwan visitors if they have not done anything wrong or illegal in Japan during the period.

An official in charge of general affairs at the Interchange Association's Taipei Office told CNA Wednesday that his office had not received any information from the Interchange Association headquarters in Tokyo about any change in the visa-free plan as reported.

The official said that as far as he knows, plans to change relevant laws are currently in the pipeline to pave the way for the Japanese government to grant visa-free treatment to Taiwan people from March 25 to Sept. 25 next year.
Taiwan is Japan's second-largest source of tourists after South Korea, with the number already exceeding the one million mark this week.
Currently, only visitors from countries that maintain diplomatic ties with Japan are provided with visa-free entry. Tokyo switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1972.

According to Japanese official tallies, the number of tourist arrivals to Japan has already exceeded six million so far this year, with one million arrivals from Taiwan. Japan is expected to attract 1.3 million Taiwan tourists next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 32.77 points to close at 5,892.51.
The bourse opened at 5,908.92 and fluctuated between 5,908.92 and 5,879.88 during trading. A total of 2.43 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$49.17 billion (US$1.52 billion).
Three of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with cement stocks, foodstuff shares, and paper and pulp issues all moving up by 0.2 percent.

The other major stock categories lost ground, with electronics and machinery issues dropping the most at 0.9 percent, followed by construction shares at 0.4, textile issues at 0.3 percent, and banking and financial shares and plastic and chemical stocks, both at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 450 to 206, with 176 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. 'TAIWAN CAUCUS' CONGRESSMAN TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: U.S. Congressman Steve Chabot (R-Ohio) , a co-chairman of the pro-Taiwan U.S. Congressional Taiwan Caucus, is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Thursday for a four-day visit.
Chabot was originally scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Wednesday but rescheduled his itinerary when his original Taiwan-bound flight was delayed.
According to Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, Chabot is visiting Taiwan mainly to observe Saturday's legislative elections.

He is also scheduled to meet with President Chen Shui-bian Friday to exchange views on a wide range of topics, with Taiwan's name-change plan for its overseas representative offices and state-run enterprises expected to be a focus of the talks.

Chabot and the other Congressional Taiwan Caucus co-chairmen recently wrote a letter to Chen expressing their support for Taiwan's plan to change the name of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States to the Taiwan Representative Office in the United States. The office is Taiwan's de facto embassy there in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.

In the letter, Chabot said that a new name for the office that includes the word "Taiwan" would better reflect the characteristics of the government in Taiwan, and that he will extend whatever help he can to facilitate the name-change effort.

During his stay in Taiwan, Chabot is also expected to meet with the foreign affairs minister for talks on various issues, including U.S. arms sales to Taiwan and diplomacy exchanges between Taiwan's Legislative Yuan and the U.S. Congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES SUPPORTERS TO HELP DPP WIN 10 SEATS IN TAIPEI CITY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called on supporters Wednesday to follow the voter allocation measures announced by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to help the party win 10 legislative seats in Taipei City.
The DPP has fielded five candidates in the city's north constituency and another five in the south constituency.

While accompanying the candidates to temples to pray for victory in Saturday's legislative elections, Chen told supporters the elections are even more important than the presidential race of earlier this year.

Chen said the DPP's victory in the March 20 presidential election will be meaningless unless the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union can seize a majority in the Legislative Yuan.

He said most of the lawmakers of the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party, which dominates the current legislature, always oppose the DPP government's policies "for no reason, " which he noted has made him a "lame duck president."
Chen urged voters to give the "pan-green camp" a chance to control the legislature and promised to step down in two years should the DPP still fail to improve its performance.
If the "pan-blue alliance" continues to dominate the legislature, the country will be thrown into a situation of disorder and unrest, he warned.
He asked DPP supporters to solicit their friends to vote for the party's candidates and to follow the voter allocation measures to ensure that all DPP candidates are elected.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Putin Urges Iraq to Welcome Business.
President Vladimir Putin said Tuesday that he expects the new Iraqi leadership to respect Russian business interests after Moscow's announcement that it would write off $9 billion in debt owed by Baghdad. "We did it in the spirit of solidarity with the Iraqi people. But at the same time we based our action on the expectation that the interests of our companies will be taken into account, " Putin said in televised remarks after a meeting with visiting Iraqi Prime Minister Iyad Allawi.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT 'CAUTIOUSLY OPTIMISTIC' ABOUT LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Chairman Lien Chan of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Wednesday that he is "cautiously optimistic" about the party's performance in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
Lien made the remarks as the campaign for Saturday's elections was gearing up for the final stretch.
Lien noted that the party has adopted a two-pronged strategy -- a restrained nomination approach and measures to bolster trailing candidates -- which he claimed has produced great results.
In addition, the KMT has announced a voter allocation scheme in 12 of the country's 25 cities and counties, Lien said.
"The voter allocation strategy is new to us, but in these bitterly contested elections, and since the rival party uses the strategy, we have to follow suit," Lien said.

Lien also defended his earlier remarks that if the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party garners a majority in the elections, a "pan-blue" figure must be appointed as premier to form a Cabinet.
According to Lien, the Constitution stipulates that the Executive Yuan must report to the Legislative Yuan and that if there is a new legislature and a new mandate, "one must respect the majority."
Meanwhile, the KMT legislative caucus lashed out at President Chen Shui-bian, claiming that it is him who has plunged the nation into six crises.

Huang Teh-fu, KMT whip in the legislature, named first and foremost what he claimed is Chen's "authoritarian administration, " saying that except for the Legislative Yuan, the president holds the personnel appointment power in the Executive, Judicial, Control, and Examination yuans.

There is no clear line between the nation and the party, he said, adding that the president concurrently serves as party chairman and claiming that he has asked the officials and the heads of the state-owned enterprises to solicit donations for the DPP.

The DPP has also depleted the national coffers by spending NT$500 billion a year, and the president has continued to create rifts between ethnic groups, Huang claimed, adding that the KMT feels Chen has continued to edge toward what he described as a "red line" set by the United States and alienating the country's most important ally, while continuing to provoke mainland China, which could trigger war.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET MEMBER DEFENDS DAUGHTER'S RUN FOR LEGISLATIVE SEAT

TEXT.P: The head of the Cabinet-level Council of Aboriginal Affairs defended Wednesday the legitimacy of his daughter Chen Ying's running for a legislative seat.
Chen Chien-nian pointed out that his daughter has legitimately registered with the Central Election Commission for the legislative elections in accordance with the country's laws.
He denied categorically that he is using "public resources" to broaden a support base for his daughter.
Calling for "fair competition like gentlemen, " Chen appealed to Chen Ying's rivals, particularly from the opposition parties, not to besmirch him and his daughter any longer.

Earlier in the day, Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung, a party whip of the opposition People First Party, claimed it is unfair that Chen Ying is "enjoying all the Council of Aboriginal Affairs' resources" in her bid to win a seat at the Legislative Yuan simply because she is the daughter of Chen Chien-nian.
What is even more outrageous, he said, is that Chen Ying has not even lived in Taiwan longer than four months over the past three years.

He poured further ridicule on Chen Ying, saying that the aboriginal voters do not need a lawmaker representing them who cannot speak any of their languages and who has only lived in Taiwan for a few months since the presidential election earlier this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY TAIWAN'S MOST CROWDED: MOI

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City tops the list of most crowded areas in Taiwan, while Taitung County ranks lowest, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).

The MOI tallies indicate that the population density of Kaohsiung City was 9,848 people per square kilometer as of Nov. 30, followed by Taipei City with 9,649. Taitung County, on the other hand, had a population density of just 68 people per square kilometer.
Calculations by the MOI also show that as of the end of November, approximately 22,678,940 people lived in 7,167,786 households.
The male-female ratio was 1.04: 1. Lienchiang County (Matsu) had the highest ratio of 1.38: 1, while Taipei City was the lowest, with a ratio of 0.96:1.
Compared to the results of a year ago, the population had increased by 85,300, of which 20,858 were newborns.

DOC.HEADLINE: RENT INCENTIVE PROGRAM IN INDUSTRIAL ZONES TO BE EXTENDED

TEXT.P: In view of the good results of a rent incentive program in the country's industrial zones, the Executive Yuan decided Wednesday in a floor meeting that the program will be extended for another two years.

Chen Chi-mai, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan, noted that to help manufacturers solve the problem of land acquisition, the Executive Yuan approved the program May 16, 2002 for manufacturers who want to rent land in the industrial zones -- zero rent in the first and second years, 60 percent of the rent in the third and fourth years, and 80 percent of the rent in the fifth and sixth years.

Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chen Ruey-long said that since the launch of the program, 634 manufacturers have been approved to rent 381 hectares of land or buildings in the industrial zones. They have invested NT$244.2 billion (US$7.63 billion) with an annual production of NT$367 billion, have created 44,046 jobs, and have contributed NT$5 billion in tax revenues for the government annually.

After the extension of the program, and an increase of a loan quota of NT$30 billion, it is estimated that 307 manufacturers will be attracted, increasing investment by NT$111.2 billion and creating annual production of NT$136.1 billion. The government will increase tax revenue by NT$1.9 billion and 21,917 jobs will be created.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN EVASIVE ON RETIREMENT QUESTION

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan declined Wednesday to answer a reporter's question on whether he will step down automatically next March when his term as KMT chairman expires, saying only that "things will be arranged in accordance with party rules."
"We will follow the party's charter and regulations when arrangements are made, " Lien said in response to a foreign wire service reporter who asked about his retirement plans.

Lien and other KMT officials met the media from abroad Wednesday at a press meeting, the first of a series of press conferences sponsored by the Government Information Office with regard to the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD HEED U.S. VIEWS FOR SECURITY'S SAKE: TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taiwan should take heed of the views and stance of the United States for the sake of Taiwan's own security, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday.

Ma, an incumbent vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, said that although some politicians have said that "the United States is not our father" and that "the United States is treating Taiwan with an imperialist mentality," Taiwan should pay close heed to the U.S. views and stance if it is going to rely on the United States for security.

Speaking at a campaign rally for a KMT legislative candidate in the northern county of Taoyuan, Ma said the government's recent talk about plans to have the formal designation of Taiwan's overseas missions, as well as the names of state-run enterprises, changed from either "Taipei" or "China" to "Taiwan, " have stirred up yet more confusion and doubt in the international community.
He called for those in office to bear Taiwan people's security and wellbeing in mind and to avoid rash speeches and actions that could compromise the country's future.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.160 to close at NT$32.260.
A total of US$960 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$32.201 and was traded between NT$32.103 and NT$32.299.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE KEEN ON PARTICIPATING IN RALLIES

TEXT.P: As of the end of October this year, police authorities across the country approved a total of 3,285 demonstrations involving more than 10 million people, according to statistics provided by the National Police Administration (NPA).

A total of 245,400 policemen were mobilized to maintain order in the protests and rallies, some 83 percent of which were politically motivated, NPA statistics show. The January-October demonstration number reflects a noticeable rise of 2,395 over the previous year's level.
NPA officials attributed the large growth to the March 20 presidential election and historic referendum, as well as the July 17 by-election of Kaohsiung city councilmen.

NPA officials estimated that more than 10 million people took part in the more than 3,000 gatherings, mainly in Taipei City, Kaohsiung City and Taipei County, an indication that protests and rallies are conducted mainly in urban areas.

A total of 456 demonstrations were held in Taipei City, Taiwan's largest city, so far this year. Estimated crowds of around 3.25 million people participated in a series of protests led by the opposition "pan blue alliance" in the wake of the March 20 presidential poll, in which President Chen Shui-bian secured a second term by a slim margin.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAUNCHES VCD TO MARK 25TH ANNIVERSARY OF FORMOSA INCIDENT

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) launched a VCD Wednesday to commemorate the 25th anniversary of the Formosa Incident.
The 15-minute documentary records the major developments in Taiwan's democracy, which include the birth of the opposition movement, the foundation of the DPP and the coming to power of the DPP.

The Formosa Incident, also known as the "Kaohsiung Incident, " occurred Dec. 10, 1979, when a demonstration organized by opposition activists and Formosa Magazine to mark Human Rights Day in Kaohsiung City turned into a bloody riot. It led to the arrest of a group of then-dissidents, many of whom are now heavyweight DPP members.

Recalling the heavy-handed authoritarian rule of the Kuomintang (KMT) in the past, DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said the people on the island went through a long period of martial law and were deprived of the right to form political parties and to elect the Legislative Yuan.
The DPP was able to win the support of the people because it responded to their expectations for freedom, democracy and human rights, Chang said.
Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh said the efforts and devotion of the DPP have proven to be worthwhile in light of the freedom of speech and democracy enjoyed by the people of Taiwan today.
Hsieh said he counts himself lucky for having had the chance to witness these accomplishments.
Su Tseng-chang, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said the DPP must follow the mainstream public opinion in Taiwan in order to continue to secure the support of the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved down 10 points to close at 5,880, with 17,107 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January dropped 17 points to finish at 5,889, with 463 contracts traded, while March futures lost seven points to finish at 5,881, with 11 contracts traded.
June futures moved down five points to finish at 5,873, with six contracts traded, while September futures decreased nine points to close at 5,800, with four contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,890 for December, 5,906 for January, 5,888 for March, 5,878 for June and 5,809 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both lost ground.
December TE futures moved down 1.35 points to close at 218.65, with 1,843 contracts traded, while January TE futures lost 1.75 points to finish at 218.85, with 85 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.
December TF futures slid 0.4 points to finish at 1,015.4, with 2,433 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved down 0.6 points to end at 1,014.6, with 204 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR ALL-OUT EFFORTS TO ENSURE DEFECT-FREE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun directed the Central Election Commission (CEC) and other relevant government agencies Wednesday to make every possible effort to ensure the smooth proceeding of Saturday's legislative elections.
Yu gave the directive at a weekly Cabinet meeting as the electoral campaign was entering the final stretch.
The premier urged CEC staff and election commissions at city and county levels to pull out all the stops to achieve accuracy and perfection in handling election affairs.
"All election staff should make concerted efforts to ensure defect-free elections and that the electoral results are made known to the general public promptly and accurately," Yu said.

The premier also called on all political parties and their legislative candidates to faithfully follow the provisions of the Public Officials Election and Recall Law in carrying out campaign activities because clean elections are a driving force behind political reform and a stable legislature will contribute to political reform.
The premier also urged all eligible voters to turn out Dec. 11 to cast their ballots at polling stations around the country.

"Voters should use their ballots to elect candidates with a clean image, professional abilities and passion to serve the country and people, thus putting an end to the current domestic political chaos resulting mainly from a hostile legislature, " Yu said.

Meanwhile, he instructed the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) and the National Police Administration under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) to cooperate closely in averting violence and vote-buying ahead of the elections.

Now that prosecution, investigation and police personnel at various levels have been working in the same offices since the 10-day official campaign period started Dec. 1, Yu said, the MOJ and the MOI should strengthen coordination to prevent "violence and money from polluting" the forthcoming elections.
Police authorities should also step up efforts to maintain security and order at polling stations on election day so that voting and vote counting can proceed smoothly.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAME CHANGE THE ROAD TAIWAN MUST FOLLOW: DPP OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Changing the names of Taiwan's overseas missions and state-owned enterprises is an "inevitable" path that Taiwan must follow and it will not budge under pressure, an official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday.

Tsai Huang-liang, the DPP's legislative whip, made the remarks one day after President Chen Shui-bian said he would continue to push for the name change issue, despite U.S. State Department deputy spokesman Adam Ereli's remarks Monday that the U.S. will not support the proposal, as it appears to unilaterally change the island's status quo.
Tsai said that Taiwan will never budge because of outside pressure, as the name change is the road Taiwan must follow and conforms to Taiwan's real situation.

He said the change will not involve the "four noes plus one" pledge made by Chen in his inauguration speeches -- no declaration of Taiwan independence if Beijing does not use force, no change of the nation's official name, no inclusion of the "state-to-state" theory in the Constitution, no referendum on Taiwan's future status regarding independence or unification and no abrogation of the National Unification Guidelines.
The U.S. decision not to support the proposal is because of pressure from mainland China, Tsai claimed, adding that Taiwan will continue to communicate with Washington on the matter.
The issue is an internal affair and no country should interfere with it, he added.

He also urged voters to support the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union in Saturday's legislative elections, saying that as long as the DPP obtains a majority, "the U.S. will address the mandate of the majority squarely. "

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO LAUNCH CRAFTS YEAR WITH WILLIAM MORRIS EXHIBITION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Cabinet-level Council of Cultural Affairs (CCA) has designated 2005 as the "year of crafts for life" and will sponsor a planned William Morris Crafts and Arts Exhibition late December to begin a 12-month series of cultural activities, a CCA official said Wednesday.

CCA Secretary-General Lin Cheng-yi witnessed the forging of an agreement between the Taichung-based National Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts and the China Times Group to co-host the exhibition at the museum from Dec. 24 to Feb. 17.

Lin said that William Morris, a renowned British craftsman and designer of the 19th Century, is a major figure in the craft world, whose works and creations have had a profound influence on numerous artists around the globe, including Yien Shuei-long (1903-1997) of Taiwan.

To mark Morris' influence on Yien, the CCA has also planned a special exhibition dedicated to Yien in coordination with the Morris event to give an insight into the relationship between the work of the two artists, Lin said.
Some 140 exquisite craftworks including jewelry, furniture, wallpaper, tiles, metal and glass products, as well as textile goods, will be displayed at the exhibitions.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN TO WORK WITH NAME CHANGE PLAN

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Wednesday that since President Chen Shui-bian has proposed changing the names of the country's overseas missions and state-owned enterprises, the Executive Yuan will work with the plan.
The premier made the remarks when he attended the inauguration of an expressway from Huwei to Taihsi in Yunlin County that will improve traffic in the central Taiwan county.

Yu was referring to Chen's proposal Sunday to push for changing the names of overseas missions and state-owned enterprises within two years to highlight the national identity and to avoid confusion with mainland China.
However, a U.S. State Department deputy spokesman has already said that the United States will not support the proposal, as it would appear to unilaterally change Taiwan's status quo.

Yu said that the issue is an internal affair that will not involve the change of Taiwan's status quo and will not violate Chen's "four noes plus one" pledge -- no declaration of Taiwan independence if Beijing does not use force, no change of the nation's official name, no inclusion of "state-to-state" theory into the Constitution, no referendum regarding Taiwan's future status as regards independence or unification with the mainland, and no abrogation of the National Unification Guidelines -- in his inauguration speeches.

The name-change plan has caused heated debate in recent days, with some people questioning the cost of changing the names of such state-controlled companies as China Shipbuilding Corp., Chunghwa Telecom and China Airlines, saying that the building of a name brand is not achieved in a short time.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLEDGES TO TURN YUNLIN INTO HI-TECH COUNTY

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun pledged Wednesday that the government will continue to develop Yunlin County and transform the agriculture-oriented county into a base for hi-tech industries.
Yu made the remarks while hosting the opening of the Huwei-Taihsi section of the No. 78 east-west expressway in Yunlin County.

While the Yunlin section of the Central Taiwan Science Park will help keep local talent in the county after its completion, the opening of the expressway has made the transportation network in Yunlin more complete, Yu said.
Other development projects being promoted by the government include a third Peikang Bridge and an international baseball stadium in Touliu, Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABOUT HALF OF TAIWAN ADULTS HAVE SLEEP PROBLEMS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: About 50 percent of adults in Taiwan who responded to an Asia-wide opinion survey said they have suffered from insomnia, according to the results of a report released Wednesday.

The survey was jointly conducted by media research firm ACNielsen and the Asian Sleep Research Society. More than 8,000 adults in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Malaysia and Japan were interviewed in the survey, which was aimed at exploring their sleep quality.
The results show that nearly half of those interviewed in Taiwan complained of sleep problems, with the ratio increasing to 80 percent among respondents aged over 45.
According to the survey results, 75 percent of those claiming to have sleep problems said they have never seen a doctor or received medical treatment for their complaint.

Analyzing the survey results, Lin Ching-ku, a family medicine physician, said that among advanced countries, Taiwan ranks second after the United States in terms of the percentage of adults with sleep problems.
Lin said anyone who suffers from insomnia three times a week in a month should immediately see a doctor.

For most people, Lin said, sleep problems can be solved by adopting orderly living habits and taking nutrients such as calcium, magnesium and vitamin B. Drinking a cup of hot milk or chocolate before going to bed is also a good method of ensuring a good night's sleep, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO SICK BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS RECOVER, TO BE SET FREE

TEXT.P: Two sick black-faced spoonbills overwintering in southern Tainan County have recovered and will be released into the wild next week, county authorities said Wednesday.

Officials of the Tainan County Animal Disease Prevention Center said that the two black-faced spoonbills, which were found late last month infected with botulism in their wetland habitat, have recovered after treatment and that they will be set free next Monday at the Chiku Wetlands Conservation Area.

Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-ji and officials from the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture will carry out the operation, they said, adding that the two rare birds will be tagged with a colored anklet to facilitate tracking in the future.

So far this year, more than 700 black-faced spoonbills have arrived in Chiku to overwinter in Taiwan -- a traditional ritual by the endangered migratory birds every year from their breeding grounds in the north.
According to a world investigation conducted in January this year, there are only 1,200 spoonbills across the globe.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLY 20% WHO NEED BONE MARROW TRANSPLANTS CAN AFFORD THEM EACH YEAR

TEXT.P: There are more than 1,000 patients who need bone marrow transplants in Taiwan every year, but only about 200 can afford the high medical costs involved, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Hematology Society of Taiwan.

While there are 1,000 new leukemia patients, 1,000 new lymph cancer patients and 500 new patients with other severe blood diseases every year, about half of these patients require bone marrow transplants, the statistics show.
Of the more than 2,000 patients who received bone marrow transplants over the past two decades in Taiwan, 50 percent of them survived.
The Taiwan Bone Marrow Transplant Association is scheduled to hold a charity art sale Dec. 11-23 to raise funds to help patients requiring bone marrow transplants.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT: NAME CHANGE IS THE RIGHT THING TO DO

TEXT.P: Changing the names of Taiwan's overseas missions to include the word "Taiwan" is the right thing to do, President Chen Shui-bian claimed while stumping for a legislative candidate of his Democratic Progressive Party in Taipei Wednesday.

One day after Washington expressed its disapproval of his move to rename the country's overseas missions to highlight their Taiwan connections, Chen said his promise to change the designation of the country's overseas missions to make them recognizable as offices of Taiwan is "necessary."

He also disputed critics' claims that his plan to replace the word "China" in the names of all state-run enterprises with "Taiwan" will cost these enterprises a fortune, arguing that the Formosa Plastic Group makes a lot of profit under the name of Formosa, which is the old term for Taiwan.
He urged his audience to back his name-changing move by voting for his party in Saturday's legislative elections.

In order to woo the votes of supporters of Taiwan independence, the president pledged Dec. 5 that he will rename the country's state-run enterprises and overseas missions within two years to emphasize their Taiwan identity.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH KOREAN TRADE GROUP TO HELP CUT TRADE IMBALANCE WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A South Korean trade organization agreed in a conference in Taipei Wednesday to cooperate with its Taiwan counterpart to try to balance two-way trade.

The Korea Trade-Investment Promoting Agency (KOTRA) promised to encourage South Korean businessmen to purchase in Taiwan to address the imbalance of trade between South Korea and Taiwan. KOTRA met at an annul conference with the Taiwan Trade Development Council (TAITRA), TAITRA Secretary-General Chao Yung-chuan said.

Taiwan suffered a trade deficit of US$4.1 billion out of two-way trade of US$13.26 billion with South Korea last year, and another trade deficit of US$4.3 billion in the first three quarters of this year.
Chao said the KOTRA also promised to exchange experiences in exploring foreign markets with TATRA during the conference, which was the 11th of its kind.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA NEWS SERVICES PERMITTED TO BE STATIONED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) announced Wednesday that it has officially permitted China News Services (CNS) to be stationed in Taiwan for news reporting.
The CNS is the fifth mainland Chinese media to have been allowed to be stationed in Taiwan, according to MAC officials.

During a trial period starting July 16 this year, two CNS correspondents at one time were allowed to stay in Taiwan for one month, and seven correspondents have rotated for the mission in the past four months, the officials said.

They said expanding the number of mainland media stationed in Taiwan is in line with President Chen Shui-bian's proposal to promote cross-Taiwan Strait journalistic exchanges, which was unveiled in his second inaugural address.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHERMEN PROTEST JAPANESE SEIZURES OF BOATS

TEXT.P: About 150 fishermen from Keelung protested in front of the office of the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA) in Taipei Wednesday because Japan impounded two Taiwan fishing boats in November, which had allegedly intruded into Japan's territorial waters.
The JIA represents Japanese interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

According to the demonstrators, Japanese coast guard authorities often impound and fine Taiwan fishing boats on charges that they were poaching in Japan's territorial waters. However, the demonstrators insisted that they have been operating legally in Taiwan's exclusive economic waters, not Japan's.
Just last month, Japan seized two Taiwan fishing boats and slapped them with fines of NT$1.8 million and NT$1.5 million, respectively.

The demonstrators demanded that Japan refund the fines. Otherwise, they said they will mobilize fishermen from around Taiwan to stage a massive demonstration at the JIA office in the near future to protest Japan's unlawful and unjust treatment of Taiwan fishermen.
The protestors pelted five or six eggs at the JIA office before police managed to stop them. Some of them scuffled with police while they were trying to storm the JIA office.

The protest ended after a JIA official accepted a petition letter from two representatives of the protesting fishermen. The official said that although the demonstration was not legally approved by Taiwan's police authorities, he decided to accept the petition in consideration of the fishermen's feelings. He said the JIA will convey the appeal to the Japanese government.

Some demonstrators said that since the two countries' exclusive economic zones overlap in certain areas, the ROC government should step up negotiations with Japan to find a mutually acceptable way for sharing maritime resources in those regions and thus resolve fishery disputes once and for all.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOLLOWS POPE'S CALL TO HELP TYPHOON VICTIMS IN PHILIPPINES
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Tony Fang & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Following Pope John Paul's call to help typhoon victims in the Philippines, Taiwan donated US$10,000 Tuesday to the Pontifical Council "Cor Unum" for relief operation, according to the Republic of China Embassy in the Vatican.
On behalf of the ROC government, the embassy delivered the donation to the Vatican's branch of humanitarian actions, officials of the embassy said.
Taiwan is willing to participate in international relief and charity operations, the officials said, adding that benevolence should have no boundaries.
The Philippines suffered a great number of casualties and property losses after being hit by four typhoons since November and needs international aid.
What Taiwan is trying to achieve is "wherever there are needy people, there is love from Taiwan," the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL TAKES DELIVERY OF FIRST PLANE WITH BOEING'S SIGNATURE INTERIOR

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) , Taiwan's largest carrier, took delivery of the world's first passenger plane with Boeing Co.'s award-winning signature interior in Seattle Wednesday.
The new B747-400 aircraft is scheduled to fly back to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway, Thursday, a CAL spokesman said.

According to the spokesman, CAL is the world's first commercial airline to have introduced Boeing's signature interior into its B747-400 passenger cabin. Boeing's signature interior once received the Industrial Design Excellence Award presented by the Industrial Designers Society of America.

The new B747-400 is also CAL's first aircraft with a colorful fuselage, the spokesman said, adding that both CAL's "red plum" logo and Boeing's brand new "dynamic blue" logo were painted on the plane's fuselage.
"Our new plane will have premier-grade cabin ambiance, " the spokesman said proudly.
The new aircraft will make its maiden commercial flight from Taipei to Tokyo Dec. 12, the spokesman said, adding that the plane will ply the routes between Taipei and Los Angeles, Hong Kong or Tokyo.

CAL now operates passenger and cargo flights to 48 destinations in 22 countries. According to tallies compiled by the International Air Transport Association, CAL ranked 26th in terms of passenger transport volume in 2003 and seventh in terms of cargo transport volume.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG AIRPORT NEEDS MAJOR EXPANSION TO BE INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Taichung Airport needs to make major expansions if it hopes to become the island's third international airport for flights to and from Hong Kong and Macau, an aviation industrialist said Wednesday.

One day before the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) under the Executive Yuan is expected to approve a plan to improve the facilities of the Taichung Airport, also known as the Chingchuankang Air Force Base, to make it an international airport, Le Ta-hsin, the general manager of Mandarin Airlines, said both the terminal and the runways of the airport need to be expanded to accommodate large commercial passenger planes and the great number of passengers that they carry.
The current runways of the Taichung Airport are too short to be used by jumbo aircraft, and the terminal is too small to handle the huge number of inbound and outbound passengers, Le said.

Moreover, the current restriction imposed by the air force on the time and the number of landings and takeoffs -- 40 flights per day between 7 a.m. and 10 p.m.-- should be relaxed or else the carriers will have difficulty coordinating their departures and arrivals.

Furthermore, air rights should be secured to start flights to and from Hong Kong and Macau since Taichung Airport is currently not covered by the existing aviation agreement between Taiwan and Hong Kong or Macau, Le said.

Although local carriers are interested in starting services between Taichung and Hong Kong and Macau, they are not certain their counterparts in Hong Kong and Macau will share their interest , Le went on.

Under the CEPD's plan, the government will spend NT$18 million (US$560,311) to improve the facilities at the airport and NT$1 billion (US$31.12 million) to expand the runway, terminal and parking apron.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU URGES CHINA TO RESOLVE DISPUTE WITH TAIWAN PEACEFULLY
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Lo Yuan-hsao and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The European Union reconfirmed its commitment to its "one China" policy Wednesday, but urged Beijing to resolve its disputes with Taiwan peacefully.

In a joint communique issued after a summit between visiting Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao and Dutch Prime Minister Jan Peter Balkenende, whose country holds the rotating EU presidency, in the Hague, the EU expressed its willingness to work towards removing the arms embargo against China, and both parties agree to continue negotiations on this issue.

Branding the embargo a discrimination against it, China said in the communique that it is unacceptable, and should be dropped immediately, while the EU said they are revising its mechanism for controlling arms exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARKET FORCES TO DECIDE MERGERS OF FINANCIAL HOLDINGS GROUPS: FSC

TEXT.P: Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) Chairman Kong Jaw-sheng said Wednesday that the government plan to merge Taiwan's many financial holding companies will be subject to market forces despite a government blueprint for the move.
Kong made the remarks after having paid an inspection visit to the Securities and Futures Bureau under the FSC.

Although the FSC has crafted a blueprint on mergers of Taiwan's financial holdings groups, Kong said that it is only an initial idea on the government side and stressed that all the processes and companies involved must be scrutinized by the market.

According to the FSC blueprint, three merger models are possible -- mergers between privately run groups, mergers between privately run and government controlled companies and consolidation of private, government companies and foreign investors.

President Chen Shui-bian recently said that there should be three financial holding companies each capable of having at least a 10 percent market share by the end of 2005, and that the current 12 government-controlled financial institutions should be merged into six by the end of 2006, with one of them being listed in foreign markets.

In an effort to create a "national champion" in the business, a merger of privately owned and government controlled financial holding groups will be better to clear the way for the creation of a "regional champion," FSC Vice Chairman Lu Daung-yen said.

To serve that end, the Ministry of Finance hopes to choose one or two from the three government run groups -- First Financial Holdings, Hua Nan Financial Holdings and Mega Financial Holdings -- early next year, if possible, to play the role as a catalyst to effectively promote the task, Lu said.
According to Lu, the FSC has reached consensus with the Ministry of Finance on the strategy. "That is what the government can do best," he noted.

Domestic and foreign banking experts share a common viewpoint that Taiwan's financial institutions are facing major problems on the small business scale, with backward product innovations, lax profit-making capabilities and insufficient regionalization and globalization, FSC officials said.

The government is in the position to design a set of standard indexes to help the domestic financial sector sharpen its competitiveness and enlarge its operational scale under the precondition that market mechanisms are fully respected, the officials said.
Meanwhile, a Mega Financial Holdings executive said that the group is open to all possibilities of a "big and beautiful" merger, as long as the other side is a company of high quality.

Spokesmen for the Hua Nan and First financial holding companies also displayed willingness to follow the government's merger policy. Consolidation between public institutions will be much quicker and easier to help the domestic banking industry move up its ranking in the world, they said.

The FSC was set up this year to oversee the domestic banking insurance, securities and futures industries, which were exercised in the past by the Ministry of Finance, the Central Bank of China and the Central Depository Insurance Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: NON-DPP MEMBERS TO ACCOUNT FOR OVER 50% OF NEW OMBUDSMEN: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that more than 50 percent of nominees for the 29 Control Yuan seats will not be members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Chen made the announcement while stumping for the five DPP candidates running in the Dec. 11 legislative elections in the Changhua County constituency in central Taiwan.
Noting that the Control Yuan is the nation's supreme watchdog body, Chen said the Control Yuan plays an important role in preventing the government from becoming corrupt.

Chen said he attaches great importance to the selection of Control Yuan members. He revealed that the ombudsmen recommendation screening team headed by Vice President Annette Lu has furnished him with a list of qualified candidates. Chen said he is scheduled to refer a final list to the Legislative Yuan in mid-December for legislative approval.

According to his plan, Chen said more than half of the nominees will be non-DPP members and that the number of female ombudsmen will more than double the present number. The present Control Yuan only have three female members.
Chen said the recommended list includes hopefuls of different ethnic origin and political stripes. Two Changhua-born former ministers from the opposition Kuomintang are on the list, he added.
Chen will nominate candidates for 27 Control Yuan seats, as well as for the Control Yuan presidency and vice presidency, by mid-December.

According to the present version of the Additional Articles of the Constitution, nominations for the Control Yuan require the consent of the Legislative Yuan. The present legislature is expected to vote on the nominations before its term expires Jan. 31, 2005.
The new Control Yuan members will assume office Feb. 1, 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CLAIM THAT EMIGRATION IS RISING IS INCORRECT: CABINET SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwan people emigrating has been on the decline, not on the rise as claimed by the opposition People First Party (PFP) , Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Wednesday.

Chen was refuting the PFP legislative caucus's claim earlier in the day that the number of ROC citizens emigrating has been increasing since the Democratic Progressive Party took power four years ago. In the first 10 months of this year alone, the PFP caucus claimed that 230,000 Taiwan nationals emigrated.
Chen said the PFP claim was not factual. The figure presented by the PFP included many of those who stayed abroad for 30 days or 180 days.

According to Taiwan household registration law, only those who have stayed abroad for two years should be listed as emigrants. The rule complies with the general international norm regarding emigration, Chen said, adding that under general international practices, those who have not returned after going abroad for either 30 days or 180 days have seldom been defined as emigrants.

Quoting official tallies, Chen said the annual number of Taiwan emigrants was 22,461 in 1989 and then rose steadily to reach a peak of 35,029 in 1995. The number has since declined continuously to 8,658 in 2003.
Chen said the PFP should not use implausible statistical reports to mislead local people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-THAILAND ECONOMIC CONFERENCE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: An economic cooperation conference between Taiwan and Thailand was held in Taipei Wednesday with the participation of more than 100 representatives from both sides.

The Taiwan delegation was led by Chen Fei-lung, chairman of the Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association (CIECA) while the Thailand delegation was headed by Praphad Phodhivorakhun, chairman of the Federation of Thai Industries.

According to statistics issued by the CIECA, Thailand is Taiwan's biggest trading partner in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, with two-way trade standing at between US$4 billion to US$5 billion in recent years.
The same statistics show that Taiwan is Thailand's third-largest source of foreign investment, pouring in US$10.9 billion as of the end of 2003, next only to Japan and the United States.

1961: Tanganyika declares independence.

1975: Hammer De Roburt, president of the Republic of Nauru, arrives in Taipei to preside over a ceremony marking the opening of flight services between Taiwan and Nauru.

He must study economy in the public expenditure, and love the welfare of the people. He must employ the people at the proper time of the year."

DOC.HEADLINE: GREENS HEAD OPPOSES LIFTING OF E.U. ARMS EMBARGO AGAINST CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin. Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Y.L. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The head of an important political group in the European Parliament said Wednesday that he is opposed to a lifting of the European Union's ban on arms sales to mainland China.

Speaking in an interview with the German National Broadcasting Co., Daniel Cohn-Bendi, president of the Greens/European Free Alliance Group, said that besides the lack of improvement in human rights in China, the Tibet issue and the Taiwan issue are two other reasons to keep the ban in place.
The European Union and mainland China held a summit meeting in the Hague the same day.

Pointing out that China continues to occupy Tibet and intimidate Taiwan, Cohn-Bendi said that the European Union cannot lift its arms embargo against China before the Tibet and Taiwan issues are resolved peacefully.
Nevertheless, Cohn-Bendit also admitted that most members of the European Parliament support the notion of working toward an eventual lifting of the ban.

Touching on whether the E.U. leaders will reach a consensus at their summit meeting next week, Cohn-Bendit said that its hard to say now and predicted that France will continue to press the other E.U. member nations to lift the ban, while Germany will express its reservations and the Scandinavian countries will voice their opposition.

During the E.U.-China summit, the E.U. side informed China that there is a willingness within the union to work towards a lifting of the arms embargo but said at the same time that this must be seen in relation to the adaptation of the E.U. code of conduct for arms exporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SATISFIED WITH RESULTS OF ANTI-VOTE-BUYING CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun on Thursday expressed satisfaction with the anti-vote-buying campaign, saying that it has produced good results.

Premier Yu said that "election" banquets, which were fairly common in past elections to solicit voters, have been dramatically reduced in number by 90 percent, and that prosecutors have so far filed more than 10 suits against violators during the vote-buying crackdown.

The premier made the remarks while stumping for five legislative candidates from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in Tainan, southern Taiwan with only two days to go before Saturday's elections.

Yu noted that the good results can be attributed to the move of stationing prosecutors and investigative agents at local police stations around the island so as to handle any vote-buying complaints quickly.

In addition, Yu said, the move of having local prosecutors who support the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and its ally Taiwan Solidarity Union check the legislative candidates from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party, while having prosecutors who support the "pan-blue alliance" check "pan-green camp" candidates has been effective.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWIN COURT OFFICIAL RETIREES AIM EVEN HIGHER AT 64
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The twin brothers whose record achievement of passing court clerk qualification tests with an elementary school education still remains unbroken after 30 years, are now preparing to take on the graduate school entrance exams at the age of 64.

Hu Shun-long and Hu Shun-ching, who were farmers until the age of 30, became publicly certified court clerks when they were 31 years old in 1973. They retired from their law careers in the same month in 2002.

The Hu twins, who are self-taught and who acquired their college diplomas from the Open University, are now studying together under the same roof in Taichung in preparation for graduate school entrance exams next year. Their story serves as another shining example of lifelong learning.

Born into a poor family of five children in Chiayi, the twins' father died when they were two years old. They were raised along with their three elder siblings by their farmer mother in barely subsistence-level living conditions.
The twins were forced by poverty to quit school after they completed their elementary school education to work on the family's rice paddies.
The Hus said that they would never have thought about taking the court clerk tests if it were not for an incident 30 years ago when Shun-ching was beat by police.

Being farmers with subsistence-level incomes, the twins also caught fish to make ends meet at a fishery pond jointly managed with other members of the neighborhood. At one point, the neighbors began complaining that their catch was continuously diminishing as a result of some unworthy police officers frequently fishing at the privately-run pond without paying.

With his limited vocabulary and total lack of legal knowledge, Shun-ching wrote an appeal letter to the Police Department under the then Taiwan Provincial Government, explaining how the police had stolen the fish from the pond and how the fishermen's living had been adversely affected.
The appeal letter was relayed to the local police authorities and as a result, Shun-ching was "invited" to a police station, where he was given a shellocking.

The Hus' bitterness had never been vented. They were later inspired by a friend who had passed a public examination to become prison guard to take the law clerk certification tests. The twins took the friend's advice, thinking that "if you can't beat them, then join them."

To enter the examinations, the twins first had to pass tests proving they had the academic ability equivalent to that of a high school graduate. After succeeding, they then biked hours to the nearest town to buy reference books to prepare for the civil servant examinations.

After following the routine of getting up each morning at 4 o'clock before going out to farm at 7 for months on end, the twins passed the exams the next year and were certified as court clerks, becoming the first people in Taiwan with only elementary school education to do so.

During their 31-year legal career, Shun-long and Shun-ching worked at district courts in Taipei, Chiayi and Taichung cities as well as in Nantou County before returning to the Taichung District Court where they retired as section chiefs.
