DOC.HEADLINE: DPP UNVEILS PLAN FOR ACHIEVING STABLE MAJORITY AFTER ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Thursday that it has a "two-staged approach" to achieve a stable majority after Saturday's legislative elections.
DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung made the remarks as he unveiled the party's latest legislative elections poll in a press conference held at the DPP headquarters.
Chang said the poll conducted last week shows that the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and its ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will be able to garner 113 seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.

According to the poll, Chang said, the DPP will secure 96 seats (plus or minus two seats) , while the TSU will obtain 17 seats (plus or minus one seats) , the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) 68 seats (plus or minus two seats) , the People First Party (PFP) 30 seats (plus or minus one seat), the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) six seats, and independent candidates eight seats.

Chang said the DPP will adopt a two-staged approach to achieve a stable majority, adding that the DPP is "cautiously optimistic" about the "pan-green camp" commanding a majority in the new legislature. He said that if the camp does not win a majority, it will cooperate with several NPSU and independent legislators, whom he said have expressed an interest in cooperating with the camp.
He said that if the "pan-green camp" wins a majority, the cooperation of the NPSU and independent lawmakers will further cement a "stable majority."
The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP, which currently holds a slim majority in the legislature, will lose its dominant status in the new legislature, he added.

On the ratio of votes that each party will garner, Chang said the poll shows that the DPP will increase its take to 39 percent from 33.4 percent in the previous legislative elections, while the TSU will increase to 8.2 percent from 7 percent, the KMT and the New Party (a splinter party of the KMT which is running under the banner of the KMT) will drop to 30.4 percent from 31.2 percent, the PFP will drop to 13.2 percent from 18.6 percent, and the other legislators (including independents and those of the NPSU) will increase slightly to 9.2 percent from 9.1 percent.

Chang also said that the DPP had originally estimated that the party would win 100 seats, but because of recent scathing criticism from the TSU aimed at President Chen Shui-bian, it has adjusted its estimate downward to between 96 and 98 seats.

He was referring to President Chen's proposal Sunday to rectify the names of Taiwan's overseas missions and state-owned enterprises, which the TSU criticized as not going far enough. The staunchly pro-independence TSU wants the nation's official designation to be changed, and not just what it called the "partial name-change" advocated President Chen.

President Chen, while proposing the name-change, also reaffirmed his pledge of no change of the nation's designation which is part of his "four noes plus one" pledges in his inauguration speeches, which also include no declaration of independence if mainland China doesn't use force, no inclusion of the "state-to-state" theory in the Constitution, no referendum on the nation's future status concerning independence and unification, and no abrogation of the National Unification Guidelines.
Chang said that both the DPP and the TSU are native political parties, but as the DPP is the ruling party, it shoulders greater responsibility.
" As the nation's leader, President Chen has to coordinate divergent opinions," Chang said, adding that "this is the responsible approach."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ACCUSES AUTHORITIES OF BEING UNFAIR IN VOTE-BUYING CRACKDOWN

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) on Thursday accused authorities of unfairly targeting the party's politicians in their crackdown on vote-buying ahead of the legislative elections.
KMT legislative caucus whip Huang Teh-fu claimed that prosecutorial, investigative and police authorities began probing 14 KMT candidates right from the start of the crackdown.

Noting that he has received information indicating that authorities will target certain KMT candidates in Taipei, Taoyuan, Taichung, Changhua, Yunlin, Tainan and Kaohsiung counties within the next couple of days, Huang claimed the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government is trying to influence the outcome of Saturday's elections by ordering the operations.

Luan Kang-meng, head of the KMT's Evaluation and Discipline Committee, alleged that the DPP is resorting to every means to attack the KMT in order to achieve its goal of seizing a majority in the Legislative Yuan.

Luan said that the KMT has been cooperating with private detectives to gather vote-buying information involving DPP candidates in Taipei, Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Changhua, Yunlin, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung.
However, the authorities have not taken the information seriously, Luan claimed.

Rejecting the KMT's accusations, DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said the DPP has never interfered in any individual cases, although the DPP-controlled Cabinet and Ministry of Justice might have ordered authorities to step up their crackdown on vote-buying.

If the DPP were able to interfere in judicial cases as the KMT has claimed, Chang said, then the party's candidate for Hualien magistrate, You Ying-lung, would not have been indicted for alleged vote-buying and President Chen Shui-bian would not have been summoned to attend a court hearing about the case early this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR GROUPS PROTEST AGAINST U.S. INTERFERING IN TAIWAN'S AFFAIRS

TEXT.P: Members of several local workers' rights organizations demonstrated at the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Thursday to protest what they considered the United States' interfering in Taiwan's internal affairs.
The demonstrators demanded that President Chen Shui-bian immediately protest to the United States.

They were angry about recent remarks by U.S. State Department deputy spokesman Adam Ereli that Washington is not supportive of Taiwan's plan to change the names of its foreign missions and state-run enterprises to include the word "Taiwan."

Ho Yen-tang, spokesman for the Committee for Action for Labor Legislation, said the United States has severely invaded Taiwan's sovereignty, and asked the Democratic Progressive Party government to stop acting like a coward.
Ho said the group has launched a signature drive against "Chinese hegemony" and "American imperialism" and will invite both the "pan-green" and "pan-blue" camps to join the campaign.
The pro-independence Alliance to Campaign for Rectifying the Name of Taiwan also staged a similar demonstration a day earlier at AIT, the de facto embassy of the United States in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 20 MAINLAND FISHING BOATS EXPELLED FROM TUNGSHA ISLAND

TEXT.P: More than 20 mainland Chinese fishing boats that were allowed to seek shelter from Typhoon Nanmadol on Dec. 3 near Tungsha Island were driven from the area Thursday by the ROC Coast Guard because they had overstayed their welcome.
Tungsha, located about 240 nautical miles southwest of Kaohsiung, is claimed by the ROC.
The mainland Chinese fishing boats were among 45 vessels from Hainan province that were allowed to anchor off the coast of Tungsha Island to avoid the brunt of Typhoon Nanmadol.

The Hainan boats were supposed to leave Tungsha after the typhoon left the area in the afternoon of Dec. 4. Nevertheless, more than 20 of them were still in the area four days after the deadline, prompting the ROC Navy detachment posted on Tungsha to notify the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) to take action.
Two CGA patrol frigates arrived near Tungsha Wednesday but could not properly maneuver the Chinese ships out of the area because of inclement weather.
However, as of noon Thursday, all of the 20-odd mainland Chinese fishing boats had left the area, CGA authorities reported.

The Mainland Affairs Council transferred a faxed letter filed by the Taipei-based Chinese Search and Rescue Association to the CGA Dec. 2 prior to the typhoon that requested that 45 Hainan fishing boats, with some 1,120 crew members aboard, be allowed to seek temporary shelter on Tungsha Island.

Based on humanitarian considerations, the CGA granted permission to the mainland fishing boats and allowed them to anchor off a coastal area near Tungsha, but did not allow the boats to anchor at Tungsha Port for security reasons.
The CGA also asked the ROC Navy detachment posted on Tungsha to help the mainland fishing boats if they were in need.

The archipelago of the Pratas Islands, comprising Tungsha Island and two coral reefs, is located in a strategically important position along a major sea route connecting the Pacific and Indian Oceans. The group is 140 nautical miles south of China's Guangdong province, 400 nautical miles northwest of Manila, 170 nautical miles southeast of Hong Kong and 240 nautical miles southwest of Kaohsiung.
Tungsha Island is a coral atoll with a land area of 2.4 square kilometers. Among the three islands, only Tungsha Island, which is shaped like a horseshoe, is always above water.
The ROC government set up a national monument on Tungsha Island June 30, 1989 to assert its sovereignty over the archipelago.

In addition to being a source of fish, salt and minerals, the island group is an outpost for the ROC Navy in the South China Sea. The ROC Navy has set up a hospital, a power station and a runway on Tungsha Island. A fishermen's service center also provides fishermen operating in the South China Sea with emergency shelter.

DOC.HEADLINE: MISSPELLED TAIPEI STREET SIGNS? TAIPEI GOVERNMENT IS LISTENING

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government is asking the public to be on the lookout for incorrect Romanization of the names of roads, streets and alleyways around the city and to send in corrections.

Beginning Thursday until Dec. 31, the public can submit their observations of instances where spellings do not reflect the Hanyu Pinyin system of Romanization to the Department of Civil Affairs under the Taipei City Government. The errors will then be corrected.

Civil Affairs Department officials said that although all the English names of the city's streets were changed from Tongyong to Pinyin several years ago, there are still many spelling errors. Taking street names in the Shihlin district as examples, they said many signs need to be corrected.
Under the Pinyin system, "Shilin" is correct, whereas the district in Tongyong would read "ShihLin," officials said.
Other examples included Bailing-BaiLing; Fuzhou-FuJhou; Fude-FuDe; Lanxing-LanSing; and Linxi-LinSi.
The public can send their corrections to the Civil Affairs Department via e-mail at: www.ca.taipei.gov.tw/civil/page.htm.
Those who offer suggestions will be entered in a lucky draw for prizes.
Taipei City is the only administrative area in Taiwan that uses Pinyin to spell the names of roads.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL MARITIME LAW CONFERENCE SET FOR DEC. 10 IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung City Maritime and Harbor Bureau is set to hold an international maritime law conference in the port city on Dec. 10 to discuss fishery-related issues, bureau officials said Thursday.

Although Taiwan is not a signatory to the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, Taiwanese fishing boats are supposed to abide by the rules set down in the convention while fishing in international waters, according to the officials.

While there have been constant reports of Taiwanese fishing boats being detained by foreign countries after they unknowingly trespassed into their territorial waters, the government can do very little to help owing to its limited diplomatic resources, they said.
At the conference, participants will try to work out solutions to the problem, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 21.46 points to close at 5,913.97.
The bourse opened at 5,894.66 and fluctuated between 5,923.54 and 5,886.79 during trading. A total of 2.89 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$63.81 billion (US$1.97 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 1 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.7 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.5 percent, cement stocks and textile stocks both at 0.4 percent, machinery and electronics shares and plastics and chemicals shares both at 0.3 percent and foodstuff issues at 1 percent.
Paper and pulp issues moved down 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 356 to 278, with 203 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIEFS OF ROC OVERSEAS MISSIONS RETURN FOR HOME CONSULTATIONS

TEXT.P: Chiefs of some 10 Republic of China overseas missions have returned to Taiwan for consultations, Ministry of Foreign Affairs sources said Thursday.

According to the sources, the returning overseas mission chiefs will exchange views with senior government officials on President Chen Shui-bian's plan to rectify the name of the nation's representative offices in countries with which the ROC doesn't maintain formal diplomatic ties by including the word "Taiwan" to clearly distinguish them from those of the People's Republic of China.
The foreign ministry is scheduled to hold a tea party Friday morning for returning overseas mission chiefs to meet with the media, the sources said.

The mission chiefs include Chiou Jong-nan, representative to France; Wang Shih-rong, representative to Switzerland; Wu Wen-ya, representative to Malaysia; Joseph Ting Shih, representative to New Zealand; Liu Jiunn-man, director of the representative office in Munich, Germany; Hwang Ju-hou, director of the representative office in Fukuoka, Japan; Matthew S. M. Lee, director of the representative office in San Francisco, the United States; and Henry Chen, representative to Ireland.
Meanwhile, foreign ministry officials said the Cabinet has approved a reshuffle of ambassadors to three of the ROC's diplomatic allies -- El Salvador, Paraguay and Sao Tome and Principe.

Hou Ching-shan, director of the foreign ministry's Central and South American Affairs Department, will be the new ambassador to El Salvador, while incumbent ROC Ambassador to Panama David C. Y. Hu will replace Yen Bing-fan as ambassador to Paraguay. Yen will retire.

Meanwhile, Yang Ching-yuan, director of the foreign ministry's Telecommunications Services Department, will replace Ko Jai-son as the new ambassador to Sao Tome and Principe. Ko will serve as director of the Central and South American Affairs Department.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December remained unchanged at 5,880, with 1,7047 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January moved down five points to finish at 5,884, with 957 contracts traded, while March futures lost 11 points to finish at 5,883, with four contracts traded.
June futures gained 12 points to finish at 5,870, with 10 contracts traded, while September futures moved down 15 points to close at 5,785, with six contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,880 for December, 5,889 for January, 5,872 for March, 5,858 for June and 5,800 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
December TE futures moved down 0.3 points to close at 218.35, with 2,478 contracts traded, while January TE futures lost 0.6 points to finish at 218.25, with 246 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

December TF futures gained 2.6 points to finish at 1,018, with 4,213 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved up 3.4 points to end at 1,018, with 483 contracts traded. March TF future lost 1.6 points to finish at 1,013.4, with one contract changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for June and September

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES VOTERS TO KEEP ON REWRITING TAIWAN'S HISTORY

TEXT.P: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CAN) Speaking on the eve of the 25th anniversary of the " Kaohsiung Incident, " President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday stressed that the road to Taiwan's democracy has been a bumpy one and urged the public to show the same spirit of bravery in rewriting history by supporting his party in Saturday's legislative elections.
The president made the remarks while he was stumping for legislative candidates from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in Taoyuan and Taipei counties in northern Taiwan.

The Kaohsiung Incident took place on Dec. 10, 1979 when a march by opposition activists and people associated with Formosa Magazine to mark Human Rights Day in Kaohsiung City turned into a bloody riot, which led to the arrest of a group of then-dissidents, including the current vice president, Annette Lu. The incident is generally believed to have been the seed that sowed the DPP.

The president, in recalling the bravery of the past dissident leaders in breaking the many taboos that existed at the time, urged the public to show the same bravery in pursuing democracy and end the present chaos in the legislature, which he blamed on the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party, which holds a slim majority in the legislature.

On the significance of the incident a quarter of a century ago, Chen said that it strengthened and cemented democracy on the island, leading to the lifting of martial law in 1987, the first fully democratic legislative elections in 1992, the first popular presidential election in 1996, the first power transfer between different political parties in 2000 and the first national referendum in 2004.

The president said that because of the persistence of the Taiwanese, history is continually being rewritten. He urged the public to continue the trend in Saturday's elections, and give the DPP its first majority in the legislature.

The president also asked supporters where KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong were during the infamous Kaohsiung Incident. Chen asked rhetorically whether either one of them had ever shed a drop of blood for Taiwan or been thrown into jail for even a single day. "They are the accomplices blocking Taiwan's democracy and undermining its human rights," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-GREEN,' 'PAN-BLUE' CLAIM THEY WILL WIN LEGISLATIVE MAJORITY

TEXT.P: Both the "pan-green camp" and the "pan-blue alliance" claimed Thursday that they will seize majority control in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan in the upcoming elections.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) is expected to win a majority in the legislature.
Even if it fails to meet its target, the "pan-green camp" can still gain a majority by joining forces with independent legislators, Chang said.
Disagreeing with Chang, Legislative Yuan speaker and opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman Wang Jin-pyng said it is hard to predict which camp will win a majority in the legislature.
However, Wang said the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) should be able to retain its majority by a narrow margin in Saturday's elections.

A total of 387 candidates are on the ballots, vying for 168 regional and eight aboriginal seats. The remaining eight overseas Chinese seats and 41 at-large seats will be allocated to the various parties according to the number of votes they garner.

While the DPP has nominated 92 candidates for regional seats, the KMT has named 74 candidates. The PFP is fielding 41 candidates, and the TSU and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union are fielding 30 and 26, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO U.S. CONGRESSMEN EXPECT PEACE AFTER TAIWAN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Two U.S. Congressmen said in Washington Wednesday that regardless of the outcome of the Dec. 11 legislative elections in Taiwan, cross-Taiwan Strait relations should remain peaceful and stable.

U.S. Congressmen Dan Burton (R-Ind.) , a member of the House of Representatives International Relations Committee, said that the U.S. is most concerned about stability across the Taiwan Strait, and that any move toward unification with China or independence by Taiwan should be made peacefully.
Congressman Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.) , also a member of the same committee, said the U.S. has been very careful in dealing with cross-strait issues.

Neither offered a prediction on the outcome of the Dec. 11 legislative elections, the results of which will determine if the opposition retains its majority in the lawmaking body or if the ruling Democratic Progressive Party wins its first majority.

Burton said the results of the elections are in the hands of the Taiwan people, while Flake said he hoped that the outcome will not affect existing U.S. policies toward the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA POISED TO TRY TO DISRUPT TAIWAN'S TOURISM: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Mainland China is preparing to use a number of ways to try to undermine Taiwan's tourism according to information collected from overseas missions, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Thursday.

Under Taiwan's plan to double tourist arrivals by 2008, the Executive Yuan has pooled various resources and manpower at home and overseas to promote Taiwan, said Yang Maysing, director of the foreign ministry's research and planning board.

However, according to Taiwan's overseas missions and other sources, China will soon begin to try to undercut Taiwan's image as a tourist destination by using such tactics as sensationalizing negative news events and trying to coax foreign governments into telling their citizens to avoid travel to Taiwan.
China will try to undermine the morale of the staff of Taiwan's Bureau of Tourism stationing overseas, she said.

China will also harass travel agencies that promote travel to Taiwan; for example, operatives will pose as customers at travel agencies and spread rumors and create as many problems as possible, she added.
She said that the decision was made to release the information about China' s plans to help inform the pubic of the ongoing efforts by China to undermine Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU MIGHT LIFT CHINA ARMS EMBARGO IN FIRST HALF 2005: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said Thursday that the European Union is likely to lift its arms embargo against China during the first half of next year and that Taiwan is closely monitoring the development.

Foreign ministry spokesman Michel Lu said the EU might make the decision in light of the close economic and trade relations between China and the EU and the constant exchanges of visits between their officials.
Yang Maysing, the head of ministry's research and planning board, said Taiwan and the United States will suffer the greatest impact if the arms embargo is lifted.

Yang said Taiwan should join forces with other countries to continue to pressure the EU not to lift the ban and work with Asia-Pacific neighbors to call the attention of the international community to the threat posed by China's military buildup to regional peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: RIVAL POLITICAL CAMPS URGED TO PRESENT POLICY INITIATIVES

TEXT.P: The nation's two rival political camps should present public policy initiatives and visions for future national development in the run-up to the upcoming legislative elections, social justice activists urged Thursday.
Chien Hsi-chieh, convener of the Pan-Purple Alliance -- a private association dedicated to promoting welfare services for the underprivileged, made the appeal two days ahead of the elections.

Both the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) have adopted only negative campaign strategies to smear each other while failing to present any policy initiatives on issues of public concern or visions for national development, Chien noted.
"Campaign literature and rallies are filled with empty slogans and rhetoric against the rival camp, while rational debates on major policy issues have been notably absent," Chien lamented.

He urged the two rival camps to show sincerity in conducting serious discussions on issues related to the people's livelihood, including the widening wealth gap, difficulties for young people in landing jobs, underprivileged people's human rights protection, environmental protection and forward-looking policy planning.

Chien also called for a rational debate on how to design a viable national pension system to avoid leaving huge debts to posterity, as well as whether the mandatory military service period should be further cut and whether the nation should implement an all-volunteer military service system.
"We need to face up to these issues squarely and address them prudently because they will have a crucial impact on our nation's future development," Chien added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LENOVO-IBM DEAL SHAKES UP TAIWAN COMPUTER MAKERS

TEXT.P: The acquisition of IBM Corp's PC division by mainland China's biggest personal computer maker, Lenovo Group, has dealt a heavy blow to Taiwan's information industry, which says that the impact will be comprehensive over the long term.

Taiwan's companies devoted to foundry and brand creation will be affected across the board, industry sources said, adding that the US$1.75 billion deal will turn Lenovo, already Asia's largest computer maker, into the world's third-largest.

Under the terms of the deal, Lenovo will be licensed to use the IBM "ThinkFamily " brand names over a five-year period, topping Taiwan companies' efforts to seize a larger slice of the mainland market and diluting their bids to create their own distinctive brand names.

Although short-term effects are not expected to be serious because IBM orders for Taiwan contractors are already due, they pointed out that the long-term impact will be unavoidably severe -- with secondary companies being hurt the most.

The Hon Hai Group, Quanta Computer, ASUSTeK Computer -- all Taiwan's leading companies -- are IBM's PC and notebooks contractors, while the Compal Group, First International Computer and Mitac International make computers for Lenovo.

Statistics show that IBM enjoys the largest notebook market share of 18.2 percent in mainland China as of the end of this year's third quarter, followed by Lenovo's 16.5 percent. ASUSTeK ranked sixth with a 5.4 percent stake, ahead of Acer, Taiwan's largest personal computer manufacturer, at a place out of the top 10.
Acer has long been keen on becoming the world's third-largest PC computer manufacturer, but the goal remains further away now with Lenovo's expansion, market analysts said.

The Lenovo's deal with IBM also deals a heavy blow to PC peripheral makers based in Taiwan, as many of them are worried that "future road will be more rugged" at a time when domestic PC and notebook manufacturers are already engaged in a heated price war.

Current suppliers for IBM acknowledged that "negative elements outnumber positive effects, " and business sources predicted that there will be a major shake-up for Taiwan's information industry, threatened by slim profits due to an intensively competitive world market.
Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, called the Lenovo move a major attempt by mainland enterprises to edge into the global market.

Chen Ruey-long, vice minister of economic affairs, said that Lenovo must still rely on Taiwan computer companies in the short term as they account for a high supply percentage for IBM. But he also pointed out that long-term adverse affects will be unavoidable.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER PROMOTES TAIWAN- U.S. FTA IN WASHINGTON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, who arrived Tuesday in the United States, is in Washington, D.C. to drum up support for a free trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and the United States.
Ho will attend a meeting of the International Institute of Economy, a Washington think tank, Friday, during which she will promote an FTA between the two countries.
In addition, she will also call on U.S. State Department officials.

Following the recent signing of an FTA between mainland China and the 10-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations, Taiwan is trying to avoid being marginalized, and the signing of an FTA with the United States is a priority goal.

In an interview with CNA, Ho said she hopes to have face-to-face communications with U.S. officials, adding that an FTA between the two countries will be a boost to bilateral trade relations. She admitted, however, that it will be a "long road," but said she hopes to quicken the pace.

Meanwhile, another ROC official, Deputy Minister of Defense Michael Tsai Ming-shian, is also in Washington at the head of a delegation. He is expected to meet with U.S. Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz and other officials to exchange views on military exchanges and other defense issues.

Tsai Ing-wen, former Mainland Affairs Council chairwoman, will also visit the U.S. after Saturday's legislative elections in her capacity as an at-large legislator-elect of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party. She is expected to attend a seminar Dec. 16 on the future of Taiwan at the Brookings Institution, another Washington think tank.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CANDIDATE BLAMES CHINA FOR FUELING TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE

TEXT.P: China has unwittingly fueled the sentiment for independence in Taiwan by going all out to stop the country using its official name of the Republic of China, a legislative candidate named by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Thursday.

Chen Shei-saint, a KMT legislator who is running for re-election, told a group of Hong Kong journalists and scholars who came to Taiwan to observe the Dec. 11 legislative elections that Beijing will only have itself to blame for the emergence of pro-independence parties in Taiwan should it keep overlooking Taiwanese people's desire to be their own master.

Worrying that the country is polarized politically, with one side favoring independence and the other favoring the eventual union of the mainland and Taiwan, Chen called himself a candidate who follows the middle course, adding that if he does not win re-election, the Legislative Yuan would be denied a rational voice.

He predicted that if re-elected, he, as well as other like-mind lawmakers, will play the role of power-brokers in the new legislature, because whichever party wins the most seats in the legislature will need their support to win the presidency of the Legislative Yuan.
After the brief meeting, the Hong Kong visitors followed Chen on the campaign trail to get first-hand experience of Taiwan elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT EYES CHIANG FOR PREMIERSHIP IF OPPOSITION CONTROLS LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan blue alliance" will recommend P.K. Chiang, a respected veteran technocrat in economic affairs, to serve as premier if the opposition camp wins a majority in the new Legislative Yuan, Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Thursday.

Lien made the remarks while campaigning for legislative candidates of the "pan blue alliance" of the KMT, the People First Party and the New Party in southern Tainan County, with less than two days to go before Saturday's legislative elections.

Should the "pan blue alliance" win more than half of the seats in the 225-member legislature, it will seek to persuade President Chen Shui-bian to appoint Chiang as premier to help improve Taiwan's economy, Lien promised.
Chiang served as chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development in the previous KMT-led government from 1996 to 2000.

A new Legislative Yuan will represent a new mandate of the Taiwan people and the public are entitled to ask for a more capable government and stronger checks and balances by the opposition, he said, hailing Chiang as a perfect option to lead the Cabinet and saying it is urgent that the government should save the country from being marginalized and hollowed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUDGET REVIEW TOP PRIORITY AFTER LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS: SPEAKER

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan will put a review of the 2005 general budget of the central government and the legislation of an ad hoc National Assembly as its top priorities when it resumes sitting after a one-month recess in preparation for Saturday's legislative elections, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday.
Wang made the remarks when he received a Hong Kong media group at the Legislative Yuan.

The ad hoc 300-member National Assembly, currently moribund, must be formed by May 2005 so as to pass constitutional amendments proposed by the Legislative Yuan in August, including the halving of the 225-seat legislature, the changing of the electoral system to a "single-sea, two ballots" model and the inclusion of a referendum law into the Constitution, as well as the abrogation of the National Assembly, by next July.
The sitting legislature will end Jan. 31 and the new one will be sworn in Feb. 1.

Addressing concerns on the impact on Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China of Saturday's legislative elections, Wang said the guidelines for Taiwan should be to step up its defenses and avoid war, when Beijing says it wants to avoid war but at the same time continues to step up its combat readiness.
"The best way would be for both sides to enter communications and consultations," Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 68% OF TAIWAN PEOPLE THINK LEGISLATURE IS CORRUPT: POLL

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan is considered by 68 percent of the Taiwanese respondents to a recent poll as the institution most affected by corruption, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by Transparency International.

The second-most corrupt institutions are political parties, which were named by 63 percent of the respondents, followed by the legal system and customs, which were both named by 44 percent of the respondents.
The military and police were perceived by 41 percent of the respondents as being corrupt, while utilities services were named by 33 percent of the respondents.

The Global Corruption Barometer 2004 survey was conducted by Gallup International at the commission of Transparency International from June to September among 52,682 people in 64 countries, including 500 in Taiwan.
This is the first time Taiwan has been included in the assessment.

The survey found that 84 percent of the respondents in Taiwan think that the problems of crime, violence and terrorism are serious, while 77 percent think the problem of political corruption is serious.

Forty percent of the respondents said they believe the corruption problem will worsen in the future, 32 percent said the situation will remain unchanged, and 16 percent said the situation will improve.
Only 1.4 percent of the respondents claimed to have experience of giving bribes, the survey shows.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAKES PROGRESS IN HUMAN RIGHTS PROTECTION: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan has made progress in its human rights protection over the past year, with judicial rights and women's rights posting the most significant progress, according to the results of a survey released Thursday.

The survey was conducted by the Chinese Association for Human Rights (CAHR) , which mailed questionnaires to elite members in various quarters, including academics, experts, elected representatives, government officials and non-profit organizations executives, to explore their views on domestic human rights conditions.

The measurement was based on nine indexes -- judicial rights, economic rights, the rights of the elderly and the mentally and physically challenged, women's rights, labor rights, children's rights, cultural and educational rights, and environmental rights. A total of 2,858 valid samples were collected.
CAHR President Hsu Wen-pin said judicial system reform and concerted efforts by the judicial authorities have contributed to substantial improvement in judicial rights.

"Judicial rights posted the greatest progress among all the indexes subjected to the evaluation, " Hsu said, adding that in the prosecutorial investigation stage, the situation of prosecutors using illegal means to take depositions from defendants or criminal suspects has improved.

Quoting the survey results, Hsu said, local judges have become more prudent while probing evidence, helping upgrade the accuracy and quality of their judgments. Moreover, Hsu went on, the survey found that the number of cases involving maltreatment or abuse of prison inmates has declined significantly.

Meanwhile, Hsu said, women's rights received the highest-ever score in this year's survey, with protection for women's social participation rights, health rights and education rights registering the greatest progress. Protection for women's personal safety has also improved, but their work rights have regressed, he added.

On economic rights, Hsu said the survey found that progress has been made in product safety and health management, while individual consumers now have easier access to filing complaints and better opportunities to receive compensation.

On labor rights, Hsu said there is still ample room for improvement in the crackdown on commercial piracy and underground companies, as well as restrictions on legally licensed companies, the labor retirement system and the gap in the business climate between private and state-owned firms.

On cultural and educational rights, Hsu said, college tuition fees are too high, while the quality of college education has been declining and the educational gap between urban and rural areas has continued to widen.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Snow to remain Treasury's chief, White House says.
U.S. President Bush asked Treasury Secretary John W. Snow on Wednesday to remain in his job, the White House said, after weeks in which Republicans close to the White House had talked openly about his impending departure and said administration officials were interviewing possible successors.
Wall Street Journal: A thirsty El Paso prompts a brawl in the Texas desert.
Until recently, the water wars in the southwest of the United States have been largely about who gets how much from rivers snaking down from the mountain snow packs. Now, battles are breaking out over who gets to control a newly emerging source: water stored underground that hadn't been economical to pull out of the earth and pipe to cities in the past.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAME CHANGES FOR OVERSEAS MISSIONS WILL TAKE TIME: MOFA

TEXT.P: A proposal to seek a name change for the country's missions overseas will need the consent of their host countries, which will be a time-consuming task that will take more than just two years, a government official said Thursday.

Any changes to the titles of Taiwan's missions abroad must first acquire approval from the countries in which they are located, according to Michel Lu, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA)

President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday that the government will seek to alter the names of the country's representative offices and missions abroad and those of state-run companies in two years by including the word "Taiwan" in their official titles in order to spotlight Taiwan's identity on the world stage.
Yang Maysing, head of the MOFA's Research and Planning Board, claimed that the name change issue can be dealt with flexibly on a case-by-case basis, depending on the situation in each country.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKER SUES PRESIDENT OVER ALLEGED VIOLATIONS OF ELECTION LAW

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Her Jyh-huei filed a lawsuit against President Chen Shui-bian Thursday, accusing Chen of intending to thwart his re-election bid by disseminating false information against him.

Her filed the suit with the Miaoli Prosecutor's Office on the grounds that Chen has violated the nation's Public Official Election and Recall Law by publicly urging Miaoli residents not to vote for him in Saturday's legislative elections.

Without referring to Her by name, Chen noted during a campaign rally in Miaoli County Wednesday that an opposition lawmaker who once served as Miaoli county magistrate fled to mainland China and stayed there for 11 months after being indicted by prosecutors on corruption charges last year.

"The lawmaker is the shame of Miaoli. Miaoli residents should not vote for such a corrupt candidate again because he may have to go behind bars before serving out his three-year legislative term. Should that be the case, it would be a loss for Miaoli voters," Chen said.
Her claimed after filing the suit against Chen that the president has violated the election law by making such an appeal three days ahead of the legislative elections.
Moreover, Her went on, Chen's remarks expose his attempt to use his political clout to interfere with the judicial system.
Stressing that the court has yet to try the indictment against him, Her claimed that the president "has handed down a verdict against me even before judges try the case."
"I feel regret that the president, a lawyer-turned-politician, has deliberately violated the election law and tried to meddle with the judicial system," Her said.
Asked whether he is worried about being imprisoned after the elections, Her said he will face up to the case squarely and believes that the court will clear his name.
Her has been indicted for alleged involvement in two high-profile land development scandals and prosecutors asked for an 18-year prison terms for him.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-SWEDEN DOUBLE TAXATION AVOIDANCE PACT EFFECTIVE IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: An accord devised by Taiwan and Sweden to avoid double taxation will become effective Jan. 1, 2005, benefiting both countries and stepping up two-way investment and exchanges, a spokesman for the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said Thursday.

From the beginning of the year, taxation on companies based in the two countries will be subject to the terms stipulated in the agreement, providing momentum for bilateral activities and cooperation in investment and technology, the MOF official said.
For instance, earnings made by the two countries' air carriers and shipping companies that conduct international routes will not be taxed by the other side in the future, he said.
In compliance with Taiwan's existing income tax law, foreign individuals and corporations must pay 30 percent and 25 percent, respectively, of their earnings made in Taiwan.

After the double taxation avoidance agreement takes effect, the tax rate will be cut to up to 10 percent for non-resident foreigners' business earnings and interest income chalked up on either side, he explained.
The parliaments of Taiwan and Sweden ratified the double taxation avoidance pact last month in the hope of further enhancing bilateral exchanges.
Currently, there are about 40 Taiwan companies with operations in Sweden, which is Taiwan's largest trade partner in Scandinavia. Two-way trade amounted to US$1 billion in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP VOWS TO UNVEIL LIST OF 'WHITE TERROR' PERPETRATORS NEXT MAY

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday the Presidential Office Human Rights Advisory Commission will unveil a list of the perpetrators of 10 major political prosecution cases during Taiwan's martial law era next May.

Lu made the remarks after unveiling the 10 major political prosecution cases during the 38-year-long martial-law era, also known as the "white terror" era, on the eve of Dec. 10 World Human Rights Day.
Lu said the plan to make public the list of "white terror" perpetrators is mainly aimed at pursuing the truth, not at revenge.
According to Lu, the list will also include prosecutors and presiding judges of the 10 cases.

"If the prosecutors or presiding judges were forced to make indictments or hand down outrageous judgments, they are welcome to tell their sides of the stories to help enrich historical records of that dark period," Lu said.

The 10 major political prosecution cases refer to the 1949 Shangdong students case; the 1952 Chungli Yiming High School case; the 1952 Luku case; the 1953 Tang Shou-jen and Kao Yi-sheng case; the 1960 Lei Chen case; the 1961 Su Tung-chi case; the 1964 Peng Ming-min case; the 1968 Chen Ying-chen and Chiu Yen-liang case; the 1972 Huang Chi-nan and Chung Chien-shun case; and the 1979 Formosa Incident.

Lu said the 10 cases were selected according to several indexes, including their representation, influence and absurdity. In addition to the Presidential Office Human Rights Advisory Commission, the Academia Historica, the Council for Cultural Affairs, the National Archives Bureau and the foundation handling compensation for victims of political prosecution cases during the martial law era had assisted in screening and selecting the major prosecution cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR DEC. 10 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, Dec. 10:
09: 00, Vice President Annette Lu will receive U.S. Congressman Steve Chabot at the Presidential Office.
09: 30, President Chen Shui-bian will receive Secretary of State for the Presidency Danilo Medina Sanchez of the Dominican Republic at the Presidential Office.
10:00, Chiefs of ROC overseas missions will meet the press at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
10:00, The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will hold a news conference at the Taipei 101 Mall.
10: 00, The opposition People First Party will hold a news conference at Howard Plaza Hotel in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICTIMS RECOUNT FORMOSA INCIDENT ON EVE OF ITS 25TH ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: Two victims of the 1979 Formosa Incident laid out the significance of the incident Thursday on the eve of its 25th anniversary.

Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, who is one of the 61 victims arrested and put behind bars after organizing a demonstration in Kaohsiung City Dec. 10, 1979 pressing for political reform when the island was ruled under martial law, told CNA that history has proved that the demonstration struck a chord with the public.

Yao said all the demands aired in the demonstration, including the lifting of martial law, the election of all legislators and the revision of the Constitution have been met through the efforts of its organizers and their sympathizers in the two decades since the incident.
The incident got its name because the demonstration was organized by political dissents who preached democracy through their political magazine, the Formosa.
The dissents later formed the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), which had grown into the biggest party in the legislature by 2001.
Yao said the incident opened a new chapter in the country's political development because it demonstrated to the rulers that the juggernaut of democracy cannot be stopped even by martial law.
Politicians will win the support of the people as long as they speak their minds, Yao said, urging today's politicians to draw lessons from the Formosa Incident.
Shih Ming-teh, another victim of the incident who is running as an independent in Saturday's legislative elections, said he would not boast about his suffering in the incident to win sympathy votes.

Some people may try to turn their status as former political prisoners into political assets in the elections, "but I don't want to debase myself by appealing to voters for support by stressing my role in that incident," he said.

However, he disagreed with President Chen Shui-bian's claims that the victims of the Formosa Incident were not the 61 political dissents who organized the demonstration but the 23 million Taiwan people who were ruled under martial law at the time, describing it as campaign rhetoric aimed to woo the voters by distorting the facts.
Instead of suffering from the incident, Shih said, Chen, who served as an attorney for the victims during their trial before a court-martial, benefited from it.
The trial earned Chen a reputation as a human rights activist and laid the groundwork for his political career, Shih said.
Once a chairman of the DPP, Shih left that party after falling out with other party leaders, and has since wandered in the political wilderness.
The DPP is lining up a parade in Kaohsiung Friday night to mark the anniversary of the.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD ENCOURAGES TAIWAN IT INDUSTRY TO INVEST IN INDIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's information technology industry should consider investing in India due to various advantages the South Asian nation has, officials of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Thursday.

India has been listed as one of the world's four big recently industrialized countries (BRICs) along with mainland China, Russia and Brazil, with an annual economic growth of 8.2 percent posted in 2003, the officials said.
Also, they added, India has a promising IT industry, particularly the software sector, which exported goods worth US$12 billion in 2003, four times over the figure registered in 1999.
India's National Association of Software and Service Companies (NASSCOM) has set a target for its software exports at US$50 billion for 2008, they went on.

India's booming IT industry, coupled with its strong ability in the research and development of software and relatively low labor costs, will attract more foreign investment and help promote the development of the country's other industries, they predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SPOKESMEN SCRAMBLE TO CONDEMN TERRORISM

TEXT.P: Government spokesmen scrambled to condemn terrorism Thursday after a pickup truck loaded with canisters of liquefied natural gas exploded in a fire ball and a hoax bomb warning was reported in Taipei City.
Chen Wen-tsung, director of the public affairs department at the Presidential Office said anyone who tries to air his political views through violence should be condemned.
Chen Chih-mai, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan, echoed his opinion, urging voters to keep calm and refrain from using violence to air their political views.

The explosion took place near the Taipei Railway Station. As the truck's license plate was missing and the gas valves on the canisters were all open, police suspect it was a plot to cause chaos. Fortunately, no one was hurt in that incident.
Meanwhile, several local television stations received warnings Thursday that explosives had been planted around the Taipei Railway Station with anti-Taiwan independence slogans sticking to them.
Police checked the station complex and found only four fake explosive devices.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 10, or the 18th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1898: Spain signs treaty with the United States, ending the Spanish-American War and ceding Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam and the Philippines to the United States in exchange for US$20 million dollars.
1901: The first Nobel Prize presentation ceremonies are held separately in Stockholm, Sweden, and Oslo, Norway.
1902: Construction of the Aswan Dam is completed in the upper section of the Nile River in southwest Egypt.
1911: French scientist Marie Curie wins a second Nobel Prize, becoming the first person to do so.
1929: Chen Tu-siu, one of the Chinese Communist Party's co-founders, issues a statement to party comrades calling Joseph Stalin an opportunist who caused a massive split within the Communist Party.
1936: Britain's King Edward VIII abdicates, becoming the Duke of Windsor. He is succeeded by his brother, George VI.
1941: Japanese warplanes sink the British battleships "Repulse" and "Prince of Wales," killing nearly 800 in the South China Sea.
1948: The Third United Nations General Assembly adopts the Convention on Genocide and Human Rights.
1949: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek flies from Chengtu, Szechwan Province, to Taipei.
1952: The ROC government drafts its first four-year economic development plan.
1955: Cambodian Prime Minister Norodom Sihanouk arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1959: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Ku Cheng-kang as the acting secretary-general of the National Assembly.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with Gabon.
1973: A five-day Seminar on Agricultural Development with special reference to Taiwan is opened at the JCRR (Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction) Building in Taipei.
1974: Toshio Urabe, newly appointed chief of the Taipei office of the Japanese Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1975: China Petroleum Corporation President Jerome Hu confirms the discovery of undersea oil deposits some 15 kilometers west of central Taiwan.
1975: A 12.5-kilometer section of the North-South Freeway between Chungli and Yangmei is completed. A 42-kilometer section of the roadway is now open to traffic.
1979: Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for her ceaseless work in helping the destitute.
1979: The Formosa Incident, during which Formosa magazine demonstrators clash with police, occurs in Kaohsiung.
1986: Lee Yuan-tseh is awarded as the co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry at the Stockholm Concert Hall in Sweden.
1988: Mainland Chinese troops shoot into crowds of Tibetans demonstrating for human rights in Lhasa.
1988: The Indigenous Defense Fighters (IDF), manufactured by ROC aviation experts, are formally named "Ching-kuo" class fighters by President Lee Teng-hui.
1993: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela says he and South African President F.W. de Klerk are bound by the Nobel Peace Prize they accepted to spend the rest of their lives building a democratic South Africa free of racial discrimination.
1996: The Cabinet-level Council of Aboriginal Affairs is established. The Taiwan Independence Party, which is a Democratic Progressive Party splinter group, is also established.
1999: The first human rights monument in Asia is officially inaugurated, on Green Island off the southeastern coast of Taiwan.
1999: Chen Shui-bian, the presidential candidate of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), formally names Annette Lu as his running mate for the 2000 presidential election.
2000: Under an amnesty decree issued by President Chen Shui-bian, 21 prisoners are released on International Human Rights Day.
2001: Fabrice de Murat, general manager of L'Oreal Taiwan, is re-elected chairman of the European Council for Commerce and Trade (ECCT).
2001: A delegation of high-ranking Taiwan police officers arrive in Beijing for a 12-day visit to the mainland. The delegation is the first of its kind to visit the mainland since the two sides separated following the end of China's civil war in 1949.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A young man, when at home, should be a good son; when out in the world, a good citizen. He should be circumspect and truthful. He should be in sympathy with all men, but intimate with men of moral character. If he has time and opportunity to spare, after the performance of those duties, he should then employ them in literary pursuits."

The political crisis that has gripped this nation for more than two weeks eased dramatically with parliament's overwhelming approval of a compromise package of laws strengthening safeguards against electoral fraud while weakening presidential powers.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times:Mandarin popular among the young.
A new survey has thrown up what to some is a surprise finding: Mandarin is alive and well - at home, at play and in school.
Almost four out of five Chinese Singaporeans in the 17 to 39 age group felt they could understand and speak Mandarin either 'well' or 'very well'.
More than three in five felt they had no problems reading Chinese. Only in the ability to write Chinese was the proportion lower, at 52 per cent.
More than half were more fluent in Mandarin than in English, and more than half used it to speak with their spouses and children. Only at the workplace is English usage more dominant - 59 per cent compared to Mandarin's 35 per cent.
These findings emerged from a Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) survey of 363 Chinese Singaporeans in the post-1965 generation, conducted in November ahead of the Dec 13 celebration of the Speak Mandarin Campaign's 25th anniversary.
The Lianhe Zaobao:Beijing may invest more money to save CAO.
China Government may invest more money to save China Aviation Oil (CAO) in crisis,a China Government officer said.
But Yang YuanYuan, the chief of Civil Aviation Administration Of China (CAAC) said, Government will make a decision after watching the following development of the CAO crisis.

The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Miners pull out 4 buried under ruins REAL, Quezon -- When miner Luis Balungay heard a faint call for help yesterday, he was convinced that it was coming from under the pile of rubble. Just minutes later, Balungay and others were lifting out four survivors from the ruins of Repador building, which collapsed amid the onslaught of tropical storm "Winnie".
The Philippine Star: Four survive for 10 days under collapsed resort Rescuers are frantically digging for more survivors after four people, including a toddler, were pulled alive yesterday from a two-story building crushed by a landslide that struck Real, Quezon at the height of typhoon "Winnie" 11 days ago.
The Manila Times: 4 alive in Real 'miracle' Four people, who survived by praying hard and drinking "any kind of liquid that dripped" from the rubble that entrapped them, were rescued Thursday from a building in Real, Quezon, that collapsed in mudslides 11 days ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: THICK FOG DELAYS CROSS-STRAIT EMERGENCY TRANSPORT OF PREMATURE INFANT

TEXT.P: The emergency cross-strait transport of the premature baby of a Taiwan businessman and his mainland wife scheduled to take place Thursday night has been delayed due to thick fog, sources from Shanghai said Friday.

Thick fog has caused the closure of the freeway connecting Shanghai and Wenzhou since Thursday evening, forcing the planned emergency transport of "Little Angel An-an" -- the seven-month old daughter of Taiwan computer businessman Chen Chao-fu and his Hangzhou wife -- from Shanghai to Xiamen to be postponed.
All relevant agencies and staff, including paramedics and hospital and sea-air-land transportation personnel, have been on hold because of the fog.

"Little Angel An-an," as she is called by doctors at the Shanghai Pediatrics Hospital, was originally scheduled to be carried Thursday night by ambulance 1,200 kilometers to the southern Chinese port city of Xiamen, where the baby, who is in critical condition, and paramedics were to board a ship bound for Kinmen before being helicoptered from Kinmen to the Veterans General Hospital in Taichung, central Taiwan. The whole trip was to take about 22 hours.
"An-an," who only weighed 900 grams upon birth, has been staying in an intensive care unit for infants for the last four months on a respirator. Currently, she weighs around 2.3 kilograms.

Chen Chao-fu, the baby's father who is a project manager with a Taiwan computer company on the mainland, met Yu Xiaoqing, a woman from Hangzhou, last year and got married soon afterwards. On May 1 this year, Yu gave birth to "An-an" just 28 weeks into the pregnancy. "An-an" has since suffered various lung malfunctions due to underdevelopment.

Chen said that he and his wife cannot afford the huge costs of medical treatment in Shanghai and therefore have decided to take the infant back to Taiwan where he enjoys national health insurance coverage.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN JOINS GET-OUT-VOTE DRIVE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and other top KMT officials on Friday joined the get-out-the-vote drive on the last day before Saturday's legislative elections.
Lien and KMT Vice Chairmen Chiang Ping-kun and Wu Poh-hsiung made the calls at the KMT branch in Taipei.
Lien also canvassed voters by phone for KMT candidates, saying this was the first time that he has engaged in this form of canvassing.
Lien would not predict the outcome of the election, saying only that he is "cautiously optimistic" about the chances of the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party.
Lin Fong-cheng, DPP secretary-general, estimated that 108 candidates from the "pan-blue alliance" will be elected to the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.

Lien also expressed the hope that President Chen Shui-bian would give serious consideration to his recommendation the previous day that Chiang Ping-kun, also vice speaker of the legislature and an economic expert and, serve as the premier if the "pan-blue alliance" wins a majority in the legislative elections.

President Chen Shui-bian, who has the sole right as ROC president to appoint the premier according to the Constitution, dismissed the idea upon hearing it, saying that "there are a lot of talented people from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and there will be no vacancy for Chiang."
Chiang also said Friday that if the president can accept Lien's proposal, it will show "his magnanimity."

Chiang noted that Lien only recommended him after seeing Taiwan being marginalized internationally as well as witnessing the hollowing out of the island's industry and the polarization of Taiwan society.

The KMT legislative caucus also said that democracy and the economy in Taiwan have made no progress during the more than four years of DPP administration. If the "pan-blue alliance" can command a majority in the legislature, President Chen should respect public opinion and consider Chiang, a former chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, because of his expertise and capability.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOMBING VIOLENCE AN ACT OF COWARDICE: DPP

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Friday condemned terrorism after a pickup truck loaded with canisters of liquefied natural gas exploded in a fireball in Taipei Thursday, calling it "a move of cowardice."

Tsai Huang-liang, DPP party whip at the Legislative Yuan, said that the people should express their political views in rational ways and that planting bombs in public places is a cowardly attack on democracy.

The explosion took place near the Taipei Railway Station. As the truck's license plate was missing and the gas valves on the canisters were all open, police suspect it was a plot to cause chaos. Fortunately, no one was hurt in the incident.

Several local television stations received warnings Thursday that explosives had been planted around the Taipei Railway Station with anti-Taiwan independence slogans sticking to them. Police checked the station complex and only found four fake explosive devices.

James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party, also condemned the act, saying that he disdains all forms of violence, particularly violence in the run-up to elections which could affect the results of the elections.
Meanwhile, the legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said that bomb terrorism and any other form of violence is poison to the development of democracy.
The KMT caucus also called for the ruling DPP to engage in soul-searching about whether it has caused social and ethnic divisions as well as hatred between the ruling and the opposition parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP EXPECTS TO WIN UP TO 41 LEGISLATIVE SEATS

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung predicted Friday that his party will win at least 32 to 34 seats and could grab up to 41 seats in Saturday's legislative elections.

Speaking at a press conference, Chang said the number is slightly lower than the 44 seats enjoyed by the PFP at present mainly because the party has nominated less candidates than it did during the last elections in order to meet the quota set by itself and its ally, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

Also, while supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" tended to vote for PFP candidates in the last legislative elections because PFP Chairman James Soong had won more votes than KMT Chairman Lien Chan in the 2000 presidential election, "pan-blue" supporters will be inclined to vote for KMT candidates this time around because Soong was Lien's running mate in the 2004 presidential race, Chang said.

On the voter allocation strategy adopted by the "pan-blue alliance, " Chang said it is difficult to tell what effect the strategy will have as only an estimated 20 percent to 30 percent of the voters are expected to comply with the policy.
However, Chang expressed optimism about how the PFP will perform in the elections, saying the nomination strategy of the party has been successful compared with those of other parties.

Chang pointed out that the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union has nominated an excessive number of candidates, and the KMT is also fielding too many candidates after including some New Party politicians who are running under the KMT's banner.

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. WON'T NECESSARILY LIFT ARMS EMBARGO AGAINST CHINA IN 2005: ROC REP

TEXT.P: The European Union will not necessarily lift its arms embargo against China in the first half of next year, Taiwan's representative to France said Friday.

Chiou Jong-nan, who has returned to Taiwan for consultations, made the remarks one day after Michel Lu, a spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said that the ministry would not rule out the possibility that the E.U. will lift its 15-year ban on arms sales to China.
Chiou said China's aspiration that the ban can be lifted by June next year "will not be easy" to achieve.

Chiou noted that it was French President Jacques Chirac who first broached the idea of lifting the ban but that this is not only an issue between France and China. Noting that the European Union makes decisions based on consensus, Chiou said that currently, the Central and East European members, and other members who uphold the ideals of freedom and human rights are not in favor of lifting the ban.

He also said that since France proposed the lifting of the ban, his representative office has exhausted every channel to let France know Taiwan's stance on the issue, adding that the French side has also conveyed its concerns and position to Taiwan.

Taiwan tried to let Paris know that the human rights situation in mainland China has yet to improve and that if the E.U. were to lift its arms embargo now, it would send a message that the E.U. would approve of China using force against Taiwan under certain circumstances, which he said would definitely affect security in the Asia-Pacific region.

France also explained that the lifting of the arms embargo ban will be a political decision based on its global strategic considerations and is part of a long-term goal to establish a strategic partnership relation with China.
The E.U. imposed the ban on arms sales to China over human rights concerns shortly after the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MUST DEAL WITH ASSETS BEFORE MERGING WITH PFP: PFP VICE CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) will only consider merging with the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) after the KMT resolves the problem of its ill-gotten assets and reaches a consensus with the PFP on cross-Taiwan Strait policy, PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung said Friday.
Chang made the remarks at a news conference held on the eve of the legislative elections.
Chang said the assets are a liability for the KMT and that the PFP will be accused of merging with the KMT for a share of the assets unless the problem is settled.
On cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Chang said the PFP favors maintaining the status quo and has "no other option."
However, he claimed that some politicians within the KMT, such as Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Legislator Apollo Chen, have advocated that "independence for Taiwan can be an option."
A merger will thus be impossible until both parties have come to a consensus on this issue, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 2.34 points to close at 5,911.63.
The bourse opened at 5,906.26 and fluctuated between 5,911.63 and 5,869.07 during trading. A total of 2.65 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$60.15 billion (US$1.85 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 0.6 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.2 percent and machinery and electronics shares at 0.1 percent.
Three other major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down at 0.5 percent and textile stocks and construction issues both dropping 0.3 percent.
Foodstuff issues and plastics and chemicals shares remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 321 to 283, with 232 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAMMY AWARD-WINNER TO GIVE CONCERT IN TAIPEI NEXT MARCH

TEXT.P: Grammy Award winning pop-jazz singer Norah Jones is scheduled to give a concert in Taipei next March during an Asian concert tour, according to an announcement on Jones' Web site Friday.
The Taipei concert is scheduled to be held at the Hsinchuang Stadium in Taipei County March 14.
According to the Web site, the 2005 Norah Jones Asian Concert Tour will begin in Singapore Feb. 27. Other concerts will also be staged in Thailand, mainland China, Hong Kong, South Korea and Japan.

Taiwan is so far the biggest market for Norah Jones records in Asia, with sales of her debut album, "Come Away with Me, " topping 130,000 copies. The sales of her second album, "Feels Like Home," had reached 70,000 copies as of last month.
Taiwan tickets will be sold beginning later this month and prices and other details will be made public by agents within a few days.
Jones' debut album, "Come Away with Me, " won her eight Grammy Awards in 2003, ranging from Grammy Award for Best New Artist, Best Record of the Year to Best Female Pop Vocal Performance.
The 24-year-old singer is the daughter of legendary sitar virtuoso Ravi Shankar, who is also a Grammy Awards winner and the mentor of the late George Harrison of the Beatles.
Jones' "Come Away with Me" was reviewed by Jazz Times in 2002 as "ranking among the most bracing and beautiful in recent memory."

Another review by Mojo magazine said that "... Jones' debut is a calming delight, a delicate acoustic dance that pulls country, blues and jazz into a gorgeous, soft-edged rootsy singer-songwriter world ... Soothing and substantial."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA'S RISING ECONOMIC STRENGTH WORRISOME: ENVOY

TEXT.P: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CAN) Taiwan's representative to Malaysia expressed worry Friday about the recent signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) between mainland China and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).
Wu Wen-ya made the remarks when he attended a tea party given by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
The mainland and ASEAN signed the FTA last week in Laos, with the aim of creating the world's largest free trade area -- a sprawling market of 1.8 billion people -- by 2010.
Under the terms of the agreement, the two sides have set a timetable for lowering tariffs from next July, with tariffs on 7,000 items to be cut to between zero and 0.5 percent by 2010.
Wu noted that bilateral trade between the mainland and Malaysia has far surpassed that between Taiwan and Malaysia, and the completion of the FTA will inevitably squeeze Taiwan.

He noted that exchanges between Malaysia and the mainland have been brisk and that Malaysia has great expectations for the vast mainland market. Two-way trade between Taiwan and Malaysia last year amounted to just US$7.8 billion, compared with mainland-Malaysia trade at US$20.1 billion.
Wu said that the government is currently conducting a feasibility study on signing an FTA with Malaysia, but he admitted that progress has been limited.

DOC.HEADLINE: CTOC TO HOLD SPORTS FESTIVAL FOR FOREIGNERS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) will hold a sports activity Sunday at the Ta-an Forest Park in Taipei to entertain foreigners living in Taiwan during the run-up to Christmas, according to a CTOC statement released Friday.
The statement noted that the event will include various performance activities, including shadow boxing, martial arts and "sport dances."

Foreign residents in Taipei, including some from the Philippines, Indonesia and Thailand, will also perform their nations' traditional dances at the event, which is aimed at boosting Taiwan's friendship with foreign friends, according to the statement.
The one-day event will be opened by CTOC Chairman Huang Ta-chou, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE TO HOLD SCHOOL ARTIFACTS EXHIBITION

TEXT.P: An exhibition of artifacts from 21 100-year-old elementary schools in Taiwan will kick off Dec. 13 at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei.
The exhibition, organized by the Ministry of Education, will display well-preserved items such as photos, yearbooks, and clocks made with bomb shells.
The items, donated by 21 schools around the nation that were built in 1904 or 1905, will give visitors the chance to get a taste of Taiwan's long education history, according to the ministry.
It also will mark the first time that Taiwan holds a school artifacts exhibition of such scale.

The 21 schools include Tayuan Elementary School in Taoyuan County, Neihu Elementary School in Taipei City, Lungching Elementary School in Taichung County, Mingkang Elementary School in Nantou County, Yichang Elementary School in Hualien, and Chengkung Elementary School in Kaohsiung City.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TAIEX Index futures for January moved down 23 points to finish at 5,861, with 1735 contracts traded, while March futures lost 22 points to finish at 5,861, with seven contracts traded.

December TE futures moved down 0.75 points to close at 217.6, with 2,049 contracts traded, while January TE futures lost 0.7 points to finish at 217.55, with 520 contract transactions. March TE futures lost 0.65 points to close at 217.1, with one contract traded.
