DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S BROADBAND WORLD TOP 10 IN ACCESSIBILITY, PRICE: STUDY

TEXT.P: In a study that measures broadband Internet services' accessibility and price, Taiwan ranks among the top 10 countries in the world in both categories, according to the International Telecommunication Union (ITU).

A report released Thursday by the ITU points out that in the category of broadband accessibility, Taiwan ranks fifth, with 13 out of every 100 inhabitants subscribing to the service, following the top-ranking South Korea, Hong Kong, Canada and Iceland.

In the price category, Taiwan's US$19.39 monthly subscription charges are world's eighth-lowest, with mainland China topping the list with US$9.66, followed by Lithuania, Jordan, Slovakia, Japan, Belarus and Macau.
In the category that measures the per-100 kb unit charge against subscriber's monthly income, Japan is the least expensive, followed by Sweden and South Korea.

The report also indicates a tremendous subscription rate, with over 100 million subscribers as of the beginning of this year in the global market. In addition, while cable services dominate the North American broadband markets, DSL (Digital Subscriber Line) is the main type of service format in other areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WATCHING DEVELOPMENT OF SITUATIONS IN VANUATU: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is paying close attention to development of situations in Vanuatu, MOFA spokesman Michael Lu said Friday.
Vanuatu's Appeal Court ruled Friday that their parliament has the right to hold a no-confidence vote on Prime Minister Serge Vohor.

Vanuatu's chief grand justice of the Supreme Court give a similar ruling Tuesday on the parliament's plan to launch a no-confidence vote regarding Vohor over his decision to establish diplomatic ties with the Republic of China.
However, Vohor appealed the ruling to the Appeal Court.
Lu said the MOFA does not know when the Vanuatu parliament will begin to discuss the issue, but will pay close attention to any new situations in the South Pacific country.
The opposition in Vanuatu, which is angry with Vohor's firm support of diplomatic relations between Vanuatu and the ROC, is planning to vote Vohor out of office.
Vohor and ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen signed a joint comunique to establish diplomatic relations Nov. 3, making Vanuatu the ROC's 27th ally.
However, Beijing has continued to woo Vanuatu away from the ROC, and a diplomatic tug-of-war between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is playing out in the South Pacific island state.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT FULLY PREPARED TO MAINTAIN ORDER IN ELECTIONS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday that the government is fully prepared to maintain order in Saturday's legislative elections.

Yu urged political parties and their candidates to be rational on the last day before the poll and to respect the decisions of the voters after the results of the elections are out, according to Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai.
Yu ordered the police to step up security at polling stations around the island and to take action against any social disorder.
He also instructed the Ministry of Justice to continue its efforts to crack down on vote buying, especially on the eve of polling day, when vote-buying is at its most prevalent.
The authorities must also be on the lookout for the new vote-buying method, in which voters are paid after the elections, Yu said.
He also instructed the Central Election Commission (CEC) to handle the technical matters of the elections properly to ensure the results are produced rapidly and accurately.
The polls will open at 8 a.m. and close at 4 p.m. and CEC Deputy Secretary-General Teng Tien-yu reminded voters to bring their identification cards, personal seals and voting notifications.

Voters will be forbidden from taking mobile phones or cameras into the polling stations and offenders will be subject to imprisonment of up to one year, community service or a fine of up to NT$30,000 (US$926), Teng said.
He urged voters to mark their choices in the designated space on the ballots, although a vote will also be counted as valid if it is marked at the number, photo or name of a candidate.
Voters cannot show their ballot to anyone or they will be subject to imprisonment for up to two years, community service or a fine of up to NT$200,000, Teng said.

Those who tear up their ballots can be fined up to NT$50,000, and those who take their ballots out of the polling stations will be subject to jail terms of up to one year, community service or a fine of up to NT$15,000, Teng added.
In addition, any candidates who continue their campaign activities after 10 p.m. Friday night can be fined up to NT$100,000, he said.

Meanwhile, railway, long-distance bus and airline operators on the island are providing extra services to cope with the busy traffic expected on the eve of the elections, when a large number of people will go back to their hometown for the polls.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS' CRACKDOWN ON DPP CANDIDATE TERMED 'MEDIA EVENT'

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lashed out Friday at two prosecutors in Taitung, eastern Taiwan for searching the campaign headquarters of DPP legislative candidate Chen Ying and the Taipei office of Chen Ying's father for evidence of vote-buying.

DPP Vice Chairman Lee Ying-yuan claimed that prosecutors Yang Ta-chih and Chiang Wen-chun's order to search Chen Ying's headquarters and the office of her father, Chen Chien-nian, chairman of the head of the Cabinet-level Council of Aboriginal Affairs, was an act designed and executed as a media event.
Lee said that the search, which he claimed was politically motivated, was controversial as the media were there even before the search was begun.
Meanwhile, Chen Chien-nian again defended the legitimacy of his daughter Chen Ying's running for a legislative seat.

Denying categorically that he is using "public resources" to broaden a support base for his daughter, Chen pointed out that his daughter has legitimately registered with the Central Election Commission for the legislative elections in accordance with the country's laws.

Describing Yang and Chiang as "deep orange" -- meaning they are stalwarts for the opposition People First Party -- Chen Chien-nian said the search, within 72 hours of the legislative elections, was politically motivated and meant to alter the outcome of the elections.
"Yang and Chiang will be to blame if my daughter is not elected, "Chen claimed.

Chen expressed ridicule as to why other candidates in Taitung, who have also offered sports jackets to supporters in return for their support, were not attacked by prosecutors Yang and Chiang, who are husband and wife.

Two days ago, PFP party whip Liu Wen-hsiung claimed that it is unfair that Chen Ying is "enjoying all the Council of Aboriginal Affairs' resources" in her bid to win a seat at the Legislative Yuan simply because she is the daughter of Chen Chien-nian.
What is even more outrageous, he said, is that Chen Ying has not even lived in Taiwan longer than four months over the past three years.

He poured further ridicule on Chen Ying, saying that the aboriginal voters do not need a lawmaker representing them who cannot speak any of their languages and who has only lived in Taiwan for a few months since the presidential election earlier this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.140 to close at NT$32.475.
A total of US$994 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.490 and fluctuated between NT$32.370 and NT$32.512.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO PUSH FOR PASSAGE OF 10 MAJOR BILLS AFTER ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed his determination Friday to push for the passage of 10 major legislative bills, including a special statute paving the way for a crucial arms procurement package, after the weekend legislative elections.

Chen made the reaffirmation while meeting with U.S. Congressmen Steve Chabot (R-Ohio) , a co-chairman of the pro-Taiwan U.S. Congressional Taiwan Caucus who arrived in Taipei Thursday for a four-day visit to observe the elections.

The president said he believes that the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) -- will be able to win a clear majority in the new Legislative Yuan to be elected Saturday.

With a working majority in the legislature, Chen went on, his administration will go all-out to have 10 long-stalled bills clear the legislative floor to kick-start his critical political and financial reform programs that have so far been stymied by the intransigence of the opposition.

Among the bills will be a special statute authorizing the government to use a special budget to procure advanced weapons from the United States worth an estimated NT$610.8 billion, Chen said. The arms to be purchased include eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six PAC-III Patriot anti-missile batteries.

Also high on the agenda are a bill on the creation of a financial reconstruction fund, revisions to the existing Judicial Yuan and Executive Yuan organizational laws, amendments to the securities transaction law and the real-estate security law, as well as revisions to the land value increment law to halve the increment tax rates.

So long as the "pan-green camp" wins a legislative majority, Chen said his administration will organize a cross-party commission to work for a thaw in the long-deadlocked cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Chen assured Chabot that his administration will pull out all the stops to forge contact with the mainland and pursue permanent cross-strait peace and Asia-Pacific regional security and stability through dialogue and consultations.
During their talks, Chen also said he admires U.S. President George W. Bush for managing to win re-election and enjoy a comfortable majority in both the House of Representatives and Senate.
Due to a lack of a legislative majority, Chen's administration has faced enormous difficulties implementing many of its policy initiatives since Chen assumed presidency in May 2000.
Chen said his re-election in March this year will be rendered meaningless if the "pan-green camp" fails to win a working majority in Saturday's legislative elections.
"We need a working majority in the legislature to implement our reform agenda and realize my campaign promises to our people, " Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA UNAWARE OF COMMUNICATION WITH U.S. OVER NAME-CHANGE PLAN

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen said Friday he is unaware of whether the government will send two officials from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to the United States after Saturday's legislative elections to communicate with Washington over a proposal to change the names of overseas missions and state-owned enterprises.

The foreign minister was referring to reports that Tsai Ing-wen, a former Mainland Affairs Council chairwoman and a shoo-in at-large legislator from the DPP, and Lee Ying-yuan, deputy DPP secretary-general, will make the trip.

"The ministry has not heard that Tsai or Lee will travel to the U.S. to communicate on the name-change issue, and the ministry also has no plans to send Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Kau Ying-mao to the U.S. over the matter," he said.

He said that the government will send a delegation to attend the inauguration ceremony of U.S. President George W. Bush, but claimed to have "no idea" about whether there will be a communication on the name-change proposals.

He noted that Taiwan and the United States have various channels available to them for communication and said any communications on name-change proposals would not necessarily have to be carried out by his ministry.

President Chen Shui-bian proposed Sunday changing the names of overseas missions and state-owned enterprises to include the word "Taiwan" within two years to highlight national identity and avoid confusion with mainland China.
But deputy U.S. State Department spokesman Adam Ereli responded the following day that Washington will not support the proposal as it appears to be a unilateral change of Taiwan's status.

Chen also said that in view of the new legislature that will be formed after Saturday's elections, the United States will be keen to learn about the latest situation and the government's promotion of related policies.

He noted that there are differences between Taiwan and the United States on certain issues, and said that although Washington may not be supportive to begin with, it will not necessarily continue to be unsupportive after communications.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Measure Would Broaden Law Enforcement Power.
Intelligence package approved by Congress would make it easier for the FBI to get surveillance warrants.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Stocks Drop $10 Bln in a Day.
Nearly $10 billion was wiped off Russian stocks Thursday as investors continued to bail out over fears that a surprise $158 million tax claim against No. 2 mobile phone operator VimpelCom signaled a new arbitrary onslaught against private business.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Armor scarce for big trucks serving in Iraq.
U.S. Congress released statistics Thursday documenting stark shortage of armor for the military transport trucks that ferry food, fuel and ammunition along dangerous routes in Iraq. Soldiers confronted Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld on Wednesday with complaints that the Pentagon was sending them to war without enough armored equipment to protect them. The House Armed Services Committee released statistics on Thursday showing that while many Humvees are armored, most transport trucks that crisscross Iraq are not.
Wall Street Journal: Behind slow growth in Europe: citizens' tight grip on wallets.
While American consumers devour goods from around the world and fuel global economic expansion, thrifty Europeans are contributing far less to growth. The strong euro -- up more than 10 percent since September against the dollar -- should enable consumers in the euro zone to buy more. Residents of the 12 countries usiing the euro save 10.5 percent of their disposable income c ompared with 0.8 percent for Americans, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NAME-CHANGE TASK SHOULD NOT BE SHELVED: ADVISOR

TEXT.P: Taiwan should stick to its determination to change the names of its overseas missions in non-allied countries and such efforts should not be daunted even in the face of mounting U.S. pressure, senior presidential advisor Koo Kuan-min said Friday.

"Only by opening the door wide can Taiwan walk on a wide path, " Koo said, adding that Taiwan should make more efforts to give Washington a better understanding of the "truth and reality" within Taiwan so that the U.S. attitude toward Taiwan will change.

Koo, who placed advertisements in the Washington Post and the New York Times at his own expense in early October to urge the U.S. government to reassess its "one China" policy, told CNA that he will probably take out another ad in major U.S. dailies prior to President George W. Bush's inauguration for second term, to optimize Taiwan's name-change plans.

Koo took out 2,000-word, full-page advertisements in both the Washington Post and the New York Times Oct. 6 urging the U.S. government to face the reality concerning Taiwan and rethink its "one China" policy, which Koo claims has only benefited the communist totalitarian regime in mainland China.

In the ad, titled "U.S. Adherence to One China Policy Only Benefits Communist Dictators: Let Taiwan Speak Out for Lasting Peace, " Koo said America's "one China" policy based on the 1972 Shanghai Communique no longer fits the political reality in Taiwan.
Koo said he hopes the U.S. government can reassess its "one China" policy in light of Taiwan's new mainstream public opinion and its new political reality.
Koo said that the "one China" policy is already outdated and that many practices in Washington today are making people question whether the United States has deviated from its founding principles.

As to the controversy regarding Taiwan's establishing formal diplomatic relations with the Pacific island country of Vanuatu, Koo said that although "one more" is welcomed, it should be no big deal if there is not a "new one" joining the list of Taiwan's allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO PROMOTE NINE MAJOR BILLS IF IT WINS LEGISLATIVE MAJORITY

TEXT.P: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CAN) Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Friday that if the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and its ally the People First Party can win a majority in Saturday's legislative elections, it will promote nine "wonderful" bills.

Lien made the remarks amid recent reports that substantive policy initiatives are conspicuously missing in the legislative campaign and that the voters have generally been apathetic about the elections.
He said that the KMT has since July been working on several major bills and proposed the nine bills two months ago.

The bills will cover stipends for youth education regulations, a revised bill for budget appropriation and management for education, the initiation of regulations on retirement, severance and relief for teachers; revision of farmers' health insurance regulations, revision on social assistance and relief regulations, the institution of a national annuity insurance bill, the institution of military recruitment regulations, the institution of a major military purchase bill and the institution of a financial discipline bill.

He also claimed that President Chen Shui-bian has used the shadow of his March 19 election-eve shooting to make him the major character of the legislative elections, targeting himself and PFP Chairman James Soong, even though they have not taken part in the elections, with personal attacks that have made the election campaign "lose focus."

He further claimed that the president and his Democratic Progressive Party "could not come up with any new initiatives" and can pander to its ally, the pro-independence Taiwan solidarity Union, to try to solicit ballots from TSU voters.

Meanwhile, the KMT legislative caucus claimed that only if the "pan-blue alliance" commands a majority in the legislature will it be able to effectively check the government and prevent it from corruption.

Huang Teh-fu, KMT whip at the legislature, was responding to earlier remarks by the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party claiming that if the "pan-blue alliance" gains the majority, it will result in paralysis of the legislature, financial bankruptcy, mainland China reaping the benefits, disappointment for local enterprises, and Taiwan going under.
Huang dismissed the DPP's remarks as showing a "lack of common sense."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL MARITIME LAW CONFERENCE OPENS IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A conference on international maritime law and Taiwan's fishery development opened Friday in Kaohsiung.
The event was attended by nearly 100 experts in international maritime law from Taiwan, the United States, Russia, Japan and South Korea.

Giving a speech at the conference, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh pointed out that Taiwan has been isolated internationally and is not a signatory to the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, yet despite this, the country has abided by the rules set down in the convention.
With the world's second-largest hauls of tuna and squid, Taiwan ranked among the top six high-sea fishing countries in the world last year, Hsieh noted.

Hsieh said Kaohsiung City has transformed from a small fishing port more than 100 years ago to become a major international container port in the world today, and the city government is also working to develop the city into a maritime capital.
He said the city government will try to attract international corporations to set up operations and research and development headquarters in the port city.
With the Kaohsiung Freeport set to start operation next year, the city government is also promoting law amendments to make export processing zones part of the freeport, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE PROMOTION GROUP'S AFRICA VISIT BEARS FRUIT

TEXT.P: A visit to three African nations by a trade promotion delegation has borne fruit, according to the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

MOEA officials said that 27 Taiwanese manufacturers took part in the trade promotion group that went to Morocco, Egypt and Nigeria, attracting interest from 1,053 foreign companies. Business deals and follow-up trade opportunities are expected to amount to US$11.22 million, the officials said.
Taiwan products such as machinery, construction materials and auto parts and components are especially welcome, they said.
The promotion group is one of the major projects of the MOEA this year, with Yeh Ming-shui, deputy secretary-general of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council, serving as the leader.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES TO SECURE TIES WITH VANUATU: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: The government will continue to work to consolidate its diplomatic relations with Vanuatu, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Friday.

Chen made the remarks in the wake of a ruling by Vanuatu's Court of Appeals that parliament has the right to hold a no-confidence vote on Prime Minister Serge Vohor over his decision to establish diplomatic ties with the Republic of China.
Chen said there remains some uncertainties before the Vanuatu parliament opens for session next week and Taiwan will do all it can to secure the relations with Vanuatu.

DOC.HEADLINE: FILM FESTIVAL TAIWAN VS. INDIA TO OPEN IN TAIPEI DEC. 31

TEXT.P: The Film Festival Taiwan vs. India is scheduled to open in Taipei Dec. 31, organizers of the event said Friday.

The film festival, co-organized by the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs and the Government Information Office, will be overseen by the Taiwan Film and Culture Association. It will begin in Taipei Dec. 31 and continue in Hsinchu Jan. 21-23 in 2005, Kaohsiung Jan. 25 to Feb. 6 and in Taoyuan Jan. 26 to Feb. 6, the organizers said.
A total of 28 films from Taiwan and India will be screened, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMEN'S PARTNERSHIP FORUM FOR PACIFIC ISLANDERS OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The first Women's Partnership Forum for Pacific Islanders opened in Taipei Friday in an effort by Taiwan to boost mutual understanding between Taiwan and other Pacific island nations.

A total of 13 foreign dignitaries, including ministers of women's affairs and interior affairs from Kiribati Republic and Marshall Islands, as well as female politicians from Tuvalu and Vanuatu, are attending the four-day forum organized by the state-sponsored Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD), according to TFD officials.

The officials said that representatives of Taiwan's leading women's organizations are also taking part in the forum, during which they are expected to build channels of communication and exchanges with the foreign leaders.
They indicated that the foundation hopes the event will allow the forging of cooperation relationships among women's groups in the Pacific area to jointly improve regional women's rights and welfare.

In addition to a series of symposia, the TFD officials noted, the foundation has also planned a series of activities for the foreign dignitaries, including a tour of the Taiwan Aboriginal Cultural Park in Pingtung, southern Taiwan. They will also be hosted by Vice President Annette Lu at a tea party Dec. 12 and are scheduled to call on President Chen Shui-bian Dec. 13.
The forum will run until Dec. 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT OFFERS FIVE PROMISES ON EVE OF LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian went into overdrive Friday on the eve of the legislative elections to campaign for ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidates, pledging to realize five promises during the rest of his term in office.

If the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , manages to win a majority in the new Legislative Yuan to be elected Saturday, Chen said his administration will give priority to the passage of 10 long-stalled bills in the first session of the new legislature.
With a "pan-green camp"-controlled legislature, Chen said he will also faithfully deliver on five promises in the coming three-plus years left in his term.

"I'll fulfill my duty as a president of 'all the people,' actively promote cross-party cooperation and strengthen partnership between central and local governments, write a new constitution for Taiwan, streamline the administration and form a cross-party commission to work for peaceful development on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, " Chen said.

The president made the remarks during a campaign rally in front of the world's tallest skyscraper, Taipei 101, to drum up support for DPP legislative candidates running in the two Taipei City constituencies where the opposition "pan-blue alliance" has traditionally had an edge.

The DPP headquarters especially chose Taipei 101 as the rally venue to signify its ambition to win 101 seats in the weekend elections so that the "pan-green camp" can easily secure a working majority in the 225-seat legislature. The TSU is expected to capture at least 20 seats. During the rally, 101 colorful balloons were released to symbolize the DPP's electoral target.

Chen said the upcoming elections are crucial as they offer a good opportunity to end more than four years of "war of attrition," mainly resulting from the antagonism of the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party, which controls a slim majority in the present legislature.

So long as the "pan-green camp" garners a working majority in the new legislature, Chen said his administration will go all-out to have the 10 major bills clear the legislative floor to kick-start various political and financial reform programs that have so far been stymied by the intransigence of the opposition.

Among the bills is a special statute authorizing the government to use a special budget to procure advanced weapons from the United States worth an estimated NT$610.8 billion, Chen said. The arms to be purchased include eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries.

Also high on the agenda are bills on the creation of a financial reconstruction fund, revisions to the existing Judicial Yuan and Executive Yuan organizational laws, amendments to the securities transaction law and the real-estate securitization law, as well as revisions to the land value increment law to halve current rates.

DOC.HEADLINE: VOTE COUNT FOR LEGISLATIVE POLLS TO FINISH BY 9 PM: CEC

TEXT.P: The voter turnout for Saturday's legislative elections is estimated at 67 percent and the vote count is expected to be completed by 9 p.m., Central Election Commission (CEC) Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung said Friday.
There are 13,930 polling stations around the island, with a total of 162,782 workers, according to the CEC.
Chang said the CEC has taken precautions against any hacker attacks or power interruptions, and the process of the vote count will be made public through the media.
The CEC has also worked out some backup plans to cope with a computer breakdown at any vote-counting office, Chang said.

Asked if the polls will be stopped in case of a bombing, Chang said the polls will continue if only a couple of polling stations are hit, and voters in the affected areas will be notified over the media and other channels to cast their ballots in other places.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIEFS OF ROC OVERSEAS MISSIONS FULLY SUPPORT 'NAME-CHANGE' PLAN

TEXT.P: Chiefs of eight Republic of China overseas missions who returned to Taiwan earlier this week for consultations, unanimously approved the government's "name-change" policy on Friday.

For the sake of clearly distinguishing the ROC from the People's Republic of China and underscoring Taiwan's separate identity, the eight overseas mission chiefs said the government's plan to rectify the name of the nation's representative offices in non-diplomatically allied countries by including the word "Taiwan" to clearly distinguish them from those of the PRC is "absolutely correct."
Speaking at a tea party with local journalists organized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Chiou Jong-nan, representative to France, said he fully supports the "name-change" plan.

Chiou said the "rectifying the name" drive involves negotiations with host countries of the nation's overseas representative offices. Taking the ROC representative office as an example, Chiou said that it is now designated as the "Bureau de Representation de Taipei en France (the Taipei Representative Office in France) ." Chiou said the designation was a hard-won result of lengthy negotiations with French authorities between 1994 and 1995.
Chiou admitted that the French government has so far not made any response to his office's request to change the designation to include the word "Taiwan."
"Whether we can succeed will hinge on the timing of negotiations and the overall relations between our two countries," Chiou said.

At present, Chiou said although the designation engraved on the office's nameplate has not changed, the reference "Taiwan" is commonly used in day-to-day operations, including telephone recordings and conversations.

Henry Chen, representative to Ireland, echoed Chiou's views, saying that all overseas missions are obligated to highlight their "Taiwan" identity in engagements with host countries and members of diplomatic corps in those countries. Chen said all ROC overseas missions chiefs should identify themselves as "ambassadors from Taiwan" to defend national sovereignty and dignity as well as to distinguish themselves from their counterparts from the PRC.
While endorsing the government's "name-change" policy, Chen said negotiations with host countries should adopt a pragmatic strategy.

Matthew S. M. Lee, director of the representative office in San Francisco, said domestic political developments have often caused squabbling among overseas Taiwan expatriates. Supporters of the "pan-green camp" have different views from the pro-"pan-blue alliance" expatriates in the San Francisco region, Lee said. If possible, Lee said, most expatriates there prefer to use the nation's full official title; otherwise, they would like to see the use of "Taiwan, " he explained. Green is the political color of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, while blue is the color of the opposition Kuomintang.

Other mission chiefs present at the tea party were Wang Shih-rong, representative to Switzerland; Wu Wen-ya, representative to Malaysia; Joseph Ting Shih, representative to New Zealand; Liu Jiunn-man, director of the representative office in Munich; Hwang Ju-hou, director of the representative office in Fukuoka, Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMICS MINISTER MEETS WITH U.S. OFFICIAL, SENATOR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh met with Deputy U.S. Trade Representative Josette Sheeran Shiner Thursday to discuss matters of mutual concern.
Ho, who arrived in Washington, D.C. Wednesday to lobbying support for the signing of Taiwan-U.S. free trade agreement (FTA) , said her meeting with Shiner marked a good start for Taiwan's FTA drive.
Ho said the government has listed FTA negotiations with major trading partners as a priority task and that the United States has been a primary target.

"It will require enormous efforts to realize the goal of striking an FTA deal with the United States. I hope we can speed up preparatory work," Ho said, adding that her current visit is aimed at holding direct dialogue with U.S. officials, academics and business executives to solicit their opinions about the FTA issue.

Later in the day, Ho paid a visit to Sen. Max Baucus, who concurrently serves as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, to seek his support for the signing of a Taiwan-U.S. free trade pact. Ho quoted Baucus as having said he is very supportive of signing such an agreement with Taiwan.

During her stay, Ho will also attend a seminar to be organized by the Institute for International Economics, a noted U.S. think tank, and deliver a speech to American business executives at the invitation of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council which groups U.S. companies with interests in Taiwan.
This is Ho's first visit to the U.S. capital since she assumed her current post in May this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE ON ALERT TO ASSURE ELECTION DAY IS PEACEFUL

TEXT.P: Security will be tight and the nation's police will be out in force to make sure that the Dec. 11 elections for lawmakers will proceed without incident, a police officer said Friday.
Police have assigned 238 officers to guard the 169 candidates who asked for police protection, the officer said.
The police also offered bullet-proof vests for those individuals who felt they needed such protection.
Security will be heightened around polling stations, vote counting centers and the headquarters of the various political parties Saturday, the police officer said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF REITERATES TAIWAN'S RESOLVE TO SEEK PEACE WITH CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwan is resolute in its pursuit of peace with mainland China, Joseph Jaushieh Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council said Friday.

In a meeting with visiting US Representative Steve Chabot from Ohio, who is also the co-chairman of the Congressional Taiwan Caucus, Wu predicted that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will win a majority in Saturday's legislative elections and the government's special budget for arms purchases from the United States will then clear the new legislature controlled by the DPP.

Wu told Chabot that President Chen Shui-bian's plan to change the names of the country's overseas missions and state-run enterprises was meant to distinguish Taiwan from China rather than disrupt the status quo across the Taiwan Strait.
It is China which imposes on Taiwan its territorial claims and threatens to absorb Taiwan with force, posing a risk to the status quo across the Strait, Wu said.

Chabot arrived in Taiwan Thursday night for a private visit and met with President Chen, Vice President Annette Lu, and Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng earlier Friday. He will leave Taiwan Saturday to continue his tour of Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT MEETS WITH U.S. CONGRESSMAN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu defended the government's plan to rectify the name of Taiwan's state-owned enterprises Friday, saying it is aimed at averting confusion and misunderstanding.

Lu made the remarks while meeting with U.S. Congressman Steve Chabot (R-Ohio), the co-chairman of the pro-Taiwan U.S. Congressional Taiwan Caucus, who arrived in Taipei Thursday for a three-day visit.

During this era of globalization, Lu said, corporate names are very important. Some of Taiwan's state-controlled enterprises still bear the words "China" or "Chinese" in their designations, such as the Chinese Petroleum Corp. and the China Shipbuilding Corp.

"It is very likely that those companies are mistaken as mainland China's, " Lu said, adding that the ROC government's plan to rectify the name of its state-owned companies is not politically motivated, but rather aimed at avoiding confusion.

For his part, Chabot said he supports Taiwan's "name-change" plan. He further said Taiwan's future should be determined by its 23 million people, not anybody else. He also said Taiwan's democratic achievements can serve as a model for other developing countries. Chabot promised to continue helping promote Taiwan-U.S. relations and cooperation in various fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR DEC. 11 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, Dec. 11:
08: 00, Polling stations for the legislative elections around Taiwan will open.
08: 15, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will cast his ballot at the 1185th polling station located at No. 8, Alley 180, Hsinlung Rd. Sec. 2, Taipei.
09: 00, Premier Yu Shyi-kun will cast his ballot at the 90th polling station in Lotung, Ilan County.
09: 00, Opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong will cast his ballot at Linkou Junior High School in Taipei County.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CORRECTS KMT'S LIEN OVER INTERPRETATION OF CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that the right to name a premier to form the Cabinet lies with the president, not the majority party in the Legislative Yuan under the ROC Constitution.

Chen was refuting opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's claim a day earlier that if the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party wins a clear majority in Saturday's legislative elections, it should have the right to name a premier to form a Cabinet on its own. Lien also said KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang, who is also the incumbent Legislative Yuan vice president, should be the next premier.
Chen ridiculed Lien as ignorant of the nation's constitutional provisions. He stressed that it is the president who has the power to name a premier.

According to the ROC Constitution, Chen said the majority party in the legislature can only initiate a no-confidence vote against a premier named by the president. Moreover, he said, the president can disband the legislature to pave the way for new elections if he does not accept the result of the no-confidence vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA SHOULD EMULATE TAIWAN RATHER THAN THREATEN IT: U.S. CONGRESSMAN

TEXT.P: Mainland China should follow Taiwan's example and allow its people to vote for government officials instead of spending its time resorting to threats against Taiwan, visiting US Representative Steve Chabot said Friday.

The co-chairman of US Congressional Taiwan Caucus said that although the elections in Taiwan appear somewhat chaotic, they are still a wonderful example of democracy for the world and mark the difference between Taiwan and mainland China, where people are not allowed to vote for their government representatives.
"I'd rather have a democracy that's sometimes messy than a dictatorship," Chabot said.

Chabot arrived in Taiwan Thursday night on a private visit and met with President Chen Shui-bian, Vice President Annette Lu and Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng earlier Friday. He will leave Taiwan Saturday to continue his tour of Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: REWARD OFFERED FOR INFORMATION ON ATTEMPTED FIRE-BOMBING

TEXT.P: The police offered NT$1 million (US$30,792) Friday for information leading to the arrest of the man who ignited a van loaded with gas tanks and fuel in a parking lot in downtown Taipei Thursday.
According to a picture released by police, the suspect is a man about 35, between 165cm to 170cm, wearing a fisherman's hat and gold-colored wire-rimmed glasses, and speaking perfect Mandarin.
The police said in its reward notice that the suspect bought 11 tanks of liquefied natural gas weighting 16 kilograms each, and 20 liters of petroleum that were contained in two buckets.
The van used by the suspect to carry these gas tanks and petroleum was stolen from Taya, Taichung County, central Taiwan, and
letters warning of the explosives in the Taipei Railway Station were sent to television stations from Chunli, Taoyuan County and Taipei City.

The van loaded with the gas and petroleum was set on fire in a parking lot near the Taipei Railway Station Thursday at noon and two local television stations had received letters warning of four explosives around the station and the Taipei 101 skyscraper at the same time.
Although the warnings were a hoax, the explosion of the gas tanks alarmed the public, who will go to the polls Saturday to elect legislators.
The fire gutted another vehicle in the parking lot but no one was hurt.

DOC.HEADLINE: YUNLIN COUNTY MAGISTRATE ARRESTED FOR IGNORING SUBPOENAS

TEXT.P: Yunlin County Magistrate Chang Jung-wei was arrested by police Friday for ignoring public prosecutors' subpoenas, officials of the National Police Administration said.

Chang was taken in the central Taiwan city of Taichung for further inquiries by prosecutors shortly after being detained by police officers at a private residence in Linnei, Yunlin County, the officials said.

The prosecutors office of the Yunlin district court issued a warrant for Chang's arrest Aug. 23 after he ignored two subpoenas summoning him to report to the prosecutors to assist with an investigation into an alleged corruption scandal surrounding a garbage incinerator project.
Chang was also given a one-year jail term in August for buying votes in 1994 when he was vying for re-election as speaker of the council of Yunlin County.
Chang, who served as speaker of Yunlin County Council from 1990 to 1997 and from 1999 to 2001, is allowed to appeal against the sentence for his vote-buying case.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 11, or the 30th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1816: The British restore Java, Indonesia, to the Dutch.
1853: Britain annexes Nagpur, one of the leading Mahrata states in India.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party stages a riot in Kwangchow (Canton) which results in massive burning and looting.
1935: The Nationalist government sets up the Hopei-Chahar Political Affairs Commission, with Soong Chih-yuan being appointed as chairman.
1936: George VI becomes King of England following the abdication of Edward VIII.
1941: The United States declares war against Germany and Italy during World War Two.
1951: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly is established, with Huang Chao-chin being elected as speaker.
1961: Two companies of U.S. military helicopters arrive in Saigon on an aircraft carrier, representing the first direct U.S. military support for the South Vietnam regime's battle against communist guerrillas.
1970: Taipei Mayor Henry Kao is impeached by the Control Yuan for breaking the law and for misfeasance.
1972: The U.S. Apollo 17 astronauts land on the moon and begin extensive exploration of the lunar surface.
1973: Maj. Gen. Slade Nash, newly appointed chief of the U.S. Military Assistance Advisory Group, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1974: The Executive Yuan of the ROC approves the Sino-Ivory Coast Agricultural Development Technical Cooperation Pact.
1974: Ten "outstanding entrepreneurs" of the year are awarded plaques and citations in Taipei.
1976: The opening ceremony of the National Conference on Atmospheric Science is held at the Central Weather Bureau in Taipei with some 100 experts participating.
1976: Eric G. Sandstrong Jr., deputy commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: Lt. Gen. Kung Ling-cheng becomes head of the National Police Administration and concurrently the director of the Taiwan Provincial Police Department, succeeding Lt. Gen. Chou Chu-tsun.
1977: Kaohsiung County's Hsingta Port, the largest fishing port in Taiwan, is inaugurated and formally opened for use.
1989: Liu Pin-yen, a mainland Chinese writer residing in the United States, arrives in Taipei with his wife for a visit.
1990: Albania announces it will allow the formation of independent political parties.
1991: Leaders of 12 European countries agree to establish a loose federation with a common foreign policy and a single currency by 1999.
1994: Russian troops and armored vehicles roll into Chechnya in a bid to restore Moscow's control over the breakaway region.
1996: Tung Chee-hwa, a shipping magnate, sweeps to victory in the election for Hong Kong's leader-in-waiting to take over when the British colony reverts to Chinese rule.
1998: A Thai Airways Airbus crashes into a flooded rubber plantation, killing 101 people in southern Thailand.
1999: Chinese Taipei wins an across-the-board victory at the Czech Table Tennis Open with both the men and women's teams gaining group singles and group doubles victories.
2000: David Hu, director-general of the South and Central American Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, is confirmed by MOFA to be the new ROC ambassador to Panama.
2001: Newly elected county magistrates and legislators from Kinmen and Matsu meet in Beijing with Li Bingcai, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, to discuss exchanges between the mainland and the two Taiwan-controlled islands.
2001: The Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, impeaches Ting Yuan-chin, former director-general of the National Police Administration, for filing a fraudulent report on payments for a luxury house.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man who is not serious will not inspire respect; what he learns will not remain permanent. Make conscientiousness and sincerity your first principles. Have no friends who are not as yourself. When you have bad habits do no hesitate to change them."

Manila Bulletin: RP, Singapore agree on air talks
Budget airlines from Singapore will soon gain frequent access to the Philippines, giving tourists and businessmen more choices for cheaper travel.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Water shortage looms
AFTER the rampage of four successive cyclones now comes the threat of a water shortage. A 13-km tunnel that brings in water to Angat Dam from Umiray River in General Nakar, Quezon, has been severely damaged, the Metropolitan Waterworks and Sewerage System (MWSS) said yesterday.

Rescuers recently buoyed by finding four people who survived 10 days of being buried under a collapsed building in Quezon instead found 15 more bodies yesterday, a senior military official said.

Weary rescue workers used picks and shovels to dig into a collapsed building in Real, Quezon, which has become a symbol of hope for the storm ravaged north eastern Luzon.

Japan yesterday unveiled new defence policy guidelines which for the first time point to China and North Korea as potential security threats.

About 16.5 million Taiwanese are expected to vote for representatives in the 225-seat legislature.All of the pan-blue and pan-green want to get for more than half seats in the legislature.
Democratic Progressive Party (DDP) estimated they can win the 95 to 101 seats to control the legislature,and together with DDP's ally,the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), win 25 seats,pan-green can win more than half seats in the legislature.
