DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VOTERS GO TO POLLS TO ELECT NEW LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Taiwan voters went to the polls Saturday to elect the nation's sixth Legislative Yuan, which is scheduled to open Feb. 1, 2005.

President Chen Shui-bian and his wife Wu Shu-jen were all smiles when they cast their ballots at a polling station at Mintsu Elementary School in the Taipei City's north constituency where their legal abode is located.
Chen was accompanied to the polling station by Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
Chen said after casting his ballot that the bright sunshine on election day is a good omen for the campaign for "a new Taiwan."

"This is a historic day. I believe that the people of Taiwan will use their democratic vote to change Taiwan's history. I also believe that the people of Taiwan will pursue love, peace, unity and stability through the democratic vote," Chen said.
The president saluted all election and security staff for their devoted services in carrying out election work and maintaining order.
In his brief speech, Chen also urged all eligible voters to go to the polls to elect the nation's lawmakers. "Don't forget to cast your ballots. Your votes will make a difference," he said.
A total of 13,930 polling stations have been set up around the country for the legislative elections.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun and his wife returned to their hometown in Ilan County early in the morning to cast their ballots.

Yu said after casting his ballot that he hopes the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- can win a clear majority in the elections to facilitate implementation of many reform programs.

"More than 200 critical bills related to the livelihood of the people are still stalled in the opposition-controlled legislature. If the 'pan-green camp' can control a majority in the new legislature, those bills will clear the legislative floor quickly and the DPP administration will be able to speed up many construction and reform projects," Yu said.
A total of 225 legisaltive seats are up for grabs, with the number of eligible voters reaching 16,559,254, according an announcement by the Central Election Commission earlier this week.

Of that total, 16,258,979 voters are eligible to vote for candidates running for regional seats, while 300,275 voters are eligible to vote for candidates running for aboriginal seats. There are 386 candidates competing for 168 regional seats and 18 candidates running for eight aboriginal seats.

Meanwhile, there are eight overseas community seats, as well as 41 at-large seats to be filled based on a proportional representation system according to the total number of votes each political party garners in the elections.
The constituencies that have over 1 million eligible voters are Taoyuan County (1.26 million), Taichung County (1.06 million) , and the first constituency in Taipei City (1.003 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Kerik Withdraws Name From Consideration.
Cabinet nominee had failed to pay taxes for a domestic employee with questionable immigration status.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA AWARE OF GRENADIAN PM'S MAINLAND CHINA TOUR

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is well aware of a planned visit to mainland China by the prime minister of Grenada, a longterm ally of the Republic of China, a MOFA spokesman said Saturday.

In reply to a journalist's question on a foreign wire service news report that said Prime Minister Keith Mitchell was leaving Friday on a visit to the mainland, Michel Lu said the MOFA is aware that Mitchell has been in contact with Beijing authorities for more than a year.

Although the Grenadian government has announced that Mitchell's plan to visit Beijing is aimed at seeking funds for hurricane relief and economic development, the MOFA believes the information was leaked deliberately by Beijing to affect Taiwan's legislative elections on the eve of Saturday's voting, Lu said.

He stressed that no matter in what ways Beijing tries to persuade Mitchell to engage in private talks with them, the MOFA will never play the game of "dollar diplomacy" with the mainland Chinese authorities to win votes at the United Nations.
The ROC forged diplomatic relations with the Caribbean country in 1989 and has won the latter's long-standing support for Taiwan's bid to join the U.N.
Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen visited Grenada in mid-September after Hurricane Ivan swept through the island state causing the worst damage and losses in nearly 100 years.
During the visit, Chen presented US$200,000-worth of food relief to the Grenadian government and met with Mitchell to discuss bilateral relations.

According to the foreign report, a spokeswoman for Mitchell said the prime minister, accompanied by the foreign minister and business leaders, will spend the weekend in London before heading to Beijing. She noted that the trip will focus on Grenada's reconstruction needs in the wake of Hurricane Ivan, as well as agricultural aid, job creation and infrastructure.
Lu said that his ministry is in control of the situation and has been keeping contact with the Grenadian government through every possible channel.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Petrol is cut by 3p a litre in stores' price war.
Supermarkets sparked a Christmas petrol price war yesterday by cutting more than 3p off a litre of fuel. Fuel costs for motorists are at their lowest for more than two months with the decision to reduce the price of a litre of petrol to 79.9p. Diesel is down to 83-84p a litre.
Financial Times: Retirement age to stay at 65 for five years.
British employers will be able to force staff to retire at 65 following an emphatic victory by business groups over trade union and age lobbyists who had called for a ban on compulsory retirement upon implementation of a European Union directive tackling discrimination. The decision - due to be announced shortly by Patricia Hewitt, UK trade and industry secretary - is certain to be highly contentious. It comes after months of wrangling over the issue both within and outside the government, exposing a fundamental policy divide over how to respond to an ageing population.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TRYING TO INFLUENCE TAIWAN ELECTIONS THROUGH VOHOR'S OUSTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen claimed Saturday that mainland China is trying to influence Taiwan's legislative elections by jeopardizing the newly established diplomatic ties between Taiwan and Vanuatu.

Chen made the remarks after Vanuatu's parliament held a no-confidence vote Friday, the eve of Taiwan's Dec. 11 legislative elections, against Primer Minister Serge Vohor due to allegations of corruption and his decision to establish diplomatic relations with Taiwan.

Vohor and Chen signed a joint communique in Taipei Nov. 3 for the establishment of diplomatic ties, making Vanuatu the 27th diplomatic ally of Taiwan. Vanuatu still maintains diplomatic ties with the mainland.

Chen claimed that the mainland's manipulation can be seen in Vohor's ouster, which he said was aimed at influencing Taiwan's legislative elections. He urged the voters to understand the fact that Beijing is using money diplomacy to ruin Taiwan-Vanuatu diplomatic relations.

According to Foreign Ministry spokesman Michel Lu, Vanuatu's parliament launched a no-confidence vote to oust Vohor Friday and elected Ham Lini and Sato Kilmam as prime minister and deputy prime minister, respectively, to form a new government.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's diplomatic personnel stationed in Vanuatu are still making efforts to communicate with officials of the new government in a bid to retain the diplomatic ties.

As long as the Vanuatu Cabinet has not made a decision to maintain or annul Vanuatu-Taiwan diplomatic relations, Taiwanese diplomats will try their best to convince the South Pacific nation's new government that the establishment of diplomatic ties with Taiwan will be of great interest to Vanuatu, Lu added.
He expressed hope that Vanuatu-Taiwan diplomatic ties will not be affected by the transfer of governments in Vanuatu for the sake of the South Pacific nation's sustainable development.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER CALLS FOR EARLY START OF TAIWAN-U.S. FTA TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh urged the U.S. government Friday to start negotiations with Taiwan as soon as possible for signing a bilateral free trade agreement (FTA).
Ho made the appeal in a speech delivered at a seminar on FTA issues organized by the Institute for International Economics (IIE) , anoted U.S. think tank.
Noting that Taiwan is the United States' eighth-largest trading partner, Ho said Taiwan can be an ideal bridgehead for U.S. companies seeking to tap into the booming Asian market.

Since the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) signed an FTA with mainland China last week, Ho said, the United States will face challenges in further expanding its trade and investment in Asia.
Ho said the Bush administration should start FTA negotiations with Taiwan as soon as possible for the two countries' mutual benefit.

If the United States were to sign an FTA with Taiwan, Ho said, Taiwan would be able to offer U.S. banking and financial service companies very good opportunities to expand their Asian market penetration.
Ho said the ROC government has listed FTA negotiations with major trading partners as a priority task and that the United States is a primary target.

"We believe that an FTA deal with the United States will help encourage other countries to follow suit, " Ho said, adding that she is fully aware that it will require enormous efforts to realize the goal of striking an FTA deal with the United States.
Nicholas R. Lardy, an IIE senior researcher, echoed Ho's view, saying that Taiwan would be able to achieve a breakthrough in its FTA bids if it managed to sign an FTA with the United States.

Taiwan has been absent from ASEAN's "ASEAN plus One" and "ASEAN plus Three" FTA talks with major East Asian countries, including China, Japan and South Korea, mainly because of Beijing's opposition, Nicholas said.
The mainland has warned other countries against signing FTAs with Taiwan. As a result, Taiwan has so far only managed to ink one with Panama.
Ho told journalists after the seminar that her visit is aimed at holding direct dialogue with U.S. officials, academics and business executives to solicit their opinions about FTA-related issues.

Ho, who arrived in Washington, D.C. Wednesday, met with Deputy U.S. Trade Representative Josette Sheeran Shiner Thursday to discuss matters of mutual concern. Ho said her meeting with Shiner marked a good start for Taiwan's FTA drive.

Also Thursday, Ho paid a visit to Sen. Max Baucus, who concurrently serves as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, to seek his support for the signing of a Taiwan-U.S. free trade pact. Ho quoted Baucus as having said he is very supportive of the proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHAIRMAN LEAVES FOR FOUR-DAY JAPAN VISIT

TEXT.P: The chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) left for Japan Saturday to attend a symposium organized by a Japanese society on relations between Taiwan and Japan, according to a MAC statement released that day.

During his four-day visit, Joseph Wu will also visit scholars and think-tank experts, as well as members of the Japanese Dietmen's Council on Relations between Japan and the Republic of China, to discuss issues concerning cross-Taiwan Strait relations and regional security, the statement said.
Wu is scheduled to return to Taipei Dec. 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC SHOULD VOTE TO DECIDE TAIWAN'S FUTURE: PRESIDENT'S TOP AIDE

TEXT.P: Taiwan voters should go to the polls enthusiastically to decide Taiwan's future, Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang said Saturday.

Su made the call after he and his wife cast their ballots of the legislative elections. Su went on to say he was afraid voter turnout would be low because there seemed to be few voters at the polling stations.

The voting rates across the nation for legislative elections in 2000, 1996 and 1992 were all around 60 percent, which lagged behind those of Spain, Greece and Indonesia, he added, without explaining the relevance of his statistics.

A total of 387 candidates are on the ballots, vying for 168 regional and eight aboriginal seats. The remaining eight overseas Chinese seats and 41 at-large seats will be allocated to the various parties according to the number of votes they garner.
The 225 legislators-elect will be sworn in Feb. 1 to form the country's new legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR CALLS FOR END TO SCHISM AFTER LEGISLATIVE ELECTION

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday he is hopeful that the political schism in Taiwan society will come to an end after the legislative elections.
Ma made the remarks in an interview with the Qatar-based Al-Jazeera television station after casting his legislative election ballot.
In the past few years, Ma said, the pervasive political culture has led to social schism in Taiwan.
"I hope Saturday's elections can put an end to this phenomenon. I hope our people will no longer feel compelled to take sides on major political issues in their daily lives," Ma said.

In addition to deciding whether the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally -- the Taiwan solidarity Union -- or the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party will take control of the Legislative Yuan for the next three years, Ma said, Saturday's elections will also have an impact on the future development of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

The results of nearly all pre-election public opinion polls show that the two rival camps have been running neck and neck and Ma noted that the final victor will not be determined until after the end of the vote count.

Ma, a KMT vice chairman, said no matter whether the "pan-blue alliance" can win a clear majority in the new Legislative Yuan, it should play a "loyal opposition" role and fulfill its "checks-and-balances" functions.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF URGES BEIJING TO RESUME TALKS AFTER LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top mainland China policy formulator has urged Beijing to resume stalled cross-Taiwan Strait talks after Taiwan's legislative elections Saturday.
Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, made the remarks when he was interviewed by Ming Pao, a major Hong Kong daily.

Wu noted that Taiwan has gone out of its way to look for issues that have few political implications, such as charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday and cross-strait cargo charter flights, so as to avoid the talks between the two sides of the strait from breaking down yet again.
"Once the issues with few political implications bear fruit, they will lay the basis for future talks," Wu said.

He pointed out that Taiwan has responded to requests by Beijing on two-way cross-strait charter flights without rerouting via third places during the Chinese New Year holiday, and the question now is whether Beijing is willing to talk.

Charter flights for Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland were opened on a trial basis during the 2003 Chinese New Year holiday, but it was only one-way and had to make stopovers in Hong Kong or Macau. The service was disrupted for the 2004 holiday after both sides failed to discuss Beijing's request for two-way service without stopping over in third places.

Wu said that past experience shows that as long as mainland China is willing to negotiate, a lot of issues can be handled in a flexible way. But if Beijing insists on accepting its "one China" concept as a prerequisite, it will continue to be a big hurdle for such talks.

Taiwan has observed since late last year that the mainland has no intention to negotiate because the Beijing authorities are worried about uncertainty following the recent presidential elections in the United States, the Dec. 11 legislative elections in Taiwan, and the change of guard in the mainland leadership.
"Now that all three factors have passed, it will be a good environment for both sides to resume talks, " Wu said.
He also urged Hong Kong to set up a representative office in Taiwan, saying that it would further cement Taiwan-Hong Kong relations.

He noted that Hong Kong's status changed after 1999, but "our Hong Kong policy or attitude toward Hong Kong has not changed. We continue to think Hong Kong is a very important place, especially because Hong Kong may be able to play a role when both sides of the Taiwan Strait still have no formal communication channel."

He pointed out the close trade exchanges between the two places, with Hong Kong as the second-largest export destination for Taiwan, and its third-largest trading partner, with two-way trade surpassing US$30 billion.

"From the angle of mutual benefits, we hope that Hong Kong can set up a representative office in Taiwan, " Wu said, adding that a lot of Hong Kong residents study in Taiwan, conduct business or go sightseeing there, and that if there was a representative office, administrative efficiency would be higher and relations between Taiwan and Hong Kong closer.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SABOTAGED VANUATU TIES TO INFLUENCE TAIWAN ELECTIONS: MOFA

TEXT.P: Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Kau Ying-mao accused mainland China Saturday of maneuvering the Vanuatu parliament into voting Prime Minister Serge Vohor out of office ahead of Taiwan's legislative elections in an attempt to sabotage ROC-Vanuatu diplomatic ties and influence the results of the polls.
Kau warned that the mainland's diplomatic isolation of Taiwan has hurt the feeling of the Taiwanese people and will further alienate relations between the two sides.
The Vanuatu parliament passed a no-confidence vote on Vohor early Saturday over his decision to establish diplomatic relations with the Republic of China last month.
The vote was called soon after Vanuatu's Court of Appeals ruled Friday that parliament has the right to hold a no-confidence vote on the prime minister.

According to Kau, the Vanuatu parliament had initially planned to meet Monday to consider the case, but the opposition, supposedly under strong interference from Beijing, requested the court's permission for the parliament to meet immediately.
This enabled the parliament to open a session Friday night and pass the vote at around 3 a.m. Saturday, just before the legislative polls opened in Taiwan, Kau said.
Kau said this is yet another "surprise" that the mainland has given Taiwan after it wooed away Nauru in 2002 around the time of the inaugural anniversary of President Chen Shui-bian.
Kau said he is deeply impressed by Vohor's firm support for the diplomatic relations between ROC and Vanuatu and expressed regret that he was forced to step down because of this.
Although Vohor was in office for only six months, he had started to push the Vanuatu government to switch recognition from Beijing to Taipei 12 years ago, Kau pointed out.
Kau said he is not optimistic about the subsequent development of ROC-Vanuatu relations in light of the pro-Beijing background of new Vanuatu Prime Minister Ham Lini.
Vohor and ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen signed a joint communique to establish diplomatic relations Nov. 3, making Vanuatu the ROC's 27th ally.
Beijing has continued to woo Vanuatu away from the ROC, and a diplomatic tug-of-war across the Taiwan Strait is playing out in the South Pacific island state.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CARRIERS SEE REVENUE DROP IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two major airlines saw their revenues drop in November, with revenues of China Airlines (CAL) falling 5 percent and those of EVA Airways dropping 2.4 percent compared to the October figures, according to statistics released by the two companies.
The statistics show that CAL revenues in November reached NT$8.43 billion (US$260.4 million), while that of EVA Airways totaled NT$7.40 billion.
On aggregate, the revenues of CAL in the first 11 months reached NT$87.40 billion, with its forecast for the year's revenue standing at NT$93.54 billion.

Meanwhile, the revenues of EVA Airways in the first 11 months totaled NT$75.09 billion, a growth of 27.35 percent over the same period of last year. The company has estimated that it will register revenues of NT$76.77 billion for the whole year.

As for their prospects for next year, an industry analyst noted that an expected increase in interest rates and a recent aviation agreement between mainland China and the United States that will see the number of flights and carriers flying between the two countries increase significantly in the future are expected to affect Taiwanese airlines next year.

Noting that JetStar Asia, an airline based in Singapore, will begin flight services between Taiwan and Singapore with cheap tickets, while Southwest Airlines of the United States is also expected to join the low-fare air market, the analyst estimated that profits for Taiwanese airlines will slow next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: WUCHIU VILLAGE FIRST TOWNSHIP TO COMPLETE VOTE COUNT

TEXT.P: Wuchiu village under the jurisdiction of the outlying Kinmen County was the first of nation's 319 villages and townships to complete its vote count after polling stations for Saturday's legislative elections closed at 4 p.m.

Wuchiu election center officials said there were two polling stations in the village, although despite having 262 eligible voters, only 46, or 17.56 percent of the electorate, voted. Wu Cheng-tian of the opposition New Party received the most votes of 24 out of the four candidates. The vote count was completed in 10 minutes.

Wuchiu village chief Tsai Yuan-cheng said that most of the residents of Wuchiu work in Taiwan proper. As the outbound traffic has to depend on navy vessels shuttling between Taiwan proper and Wuchiu every 10 days, this greatly affected the willingness of Wuchiu residents to return to vote.

Wuchiu, 72 nautical miles northeast of Kinmen, comprises Wuchiu and Hsiaochiu islets with a total size of around 1.2 square kilometers. Although 373 people are registered as living on Wuchiu, it has only 50 regular residents, making it the smallest township in the nation.
The sixth legislative elections, which lasted from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., ended without any major incidents.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMBINED MARKET VALUE OF LISTED COMPANIES IN TAIWAN UP FROM LAST WEEK

TEXT.P: The combined market value of listed companies in Taiwan hit NT$13.47 trillion (US$415.74 billion) , up NT$47.63 billion, or 0.35 percent, over the previous week, according to statistics compiled by the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX).

The statistics also show that gainers outnumbered losers in the 20 top major industries this week, with the market value of the listed companies in the automobile industry gaining the most at 1.92 percent, while the market value of the listed companies in the rubber, cement, foodstuff and plastic industries also showed an increase of over 1 percent. The market value of the logistics, steel and iron industries showed a decline.

The weighted index, the key barometer of the Taiwan Stock Exchange, ended at 5,911.63 Friday, an increase of 18.36 points, or 0.31 percent from the previous week, on a combined turnover of NT$282.95 billion for the week.
There have been 235 trading days on the Taiwan Stock Exchange so far this year, with a combined turnover of NT$23.2 trillion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR CABINET-LEGISLATURE COOPERATION AFTER ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Saturday he hopes individual candidates and political parties can accept the legislative election results so that life can return to normal quickly.
Yu made the call during an inspection tour of the central election vote counting center to extend his gratitude and respect for election staff.
"Whatever the results, I hope political parties and individual candidates can accept the legislative election results. And let's return to normal life as soon as possible," Yu said.

Yu further said he earnestly hopes that the new Legislative Yuan, which will be inaugurated Feb. 1, 2005, can cooperate with the administration so that major reform and construction projects can get underway to speed up Taiwan's economic upgrading and overall national development.

Saturday's election was the first time that a legislative election vote count was completely computerized. Vote counting proceeded smoothly after voting in the sixth legislative elections ended at 4 p.m. No major incidents were reported throughout the procedure.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INTERNATIONAL DOCUMENTARY FESTIVAL OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The fourth Taiwan International Documentary Festival kicked off Saturday in Taipei, with around 50 directors and filmmakers from around the world, including legendary French filmmaker Agnes Varda, attending the biannual event.

Over 130 documentaries from more than 40 nations will be screened during the one-week festival, which includes a series of exhibitions, symposia and workshops, as well as three competitions -- the International Competition, the Asian Vision competition, and the Taiwan Award competition -- according to a news release from the event's organizers.

The festival will open with the high-profile world premier of Japanese director Naomi Kawase's "Shadow, " the European premier of German Werner Herzog's "The White Diamond, " and the screening of a 1980 Israeli film -- "House" directed by Amos Gitai.
To draw the public to view high-quality documentaries from around the world, the tickets for each film screening are only NT$10 (US$0.31), according to the organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Kerik pulls out as Bush nominee for homeland security job.
Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York City police commissioner, abruptly withthdrew his name from consideration to be President Bush's secretary of homeland security late Friday night, citing questions related to the immigration status of a former household employee. Kerik was nominated only a week ago by President Bush to succeed Tom Ridge. His lawyer, Joseph Tacopina, said that Kerik called the president at 8: 30 p.m. to inform him of the decision. The White House had not pressured him to withdraw. Tacopina said, Kerik decided he had to do so because as homeland security secretary, he would be in charge of supervising the nation's immigration laws.
Wall Street Journal: Kerik withdraws nomination as Homeland Security Secretary.
In a surprise move, former New York Police Commissioner Bernard Kerik abruptly withdrew his nomination as President Bush's choice to be homeland security secretary Friday night, saying questions have arisen about the immigration status of a housekeeper and nanny he employed. Kerik said he feared that the disclosure of the issue would generate intense scrutiny that would "only serve as a significant and unnecessary distraction to the vital efforts of the Department of Homeland Security."

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN LAWMAKER PLEDGES TO PUSH FOR EXPANSION OF 'MINI THREE LINKS'

TEXT.P: Kinmen-elected Legislator Wu Cheng-tien pledged Saturday to continue to push for the expansion of the "mini three links" between Taiwan and mainland China during his next three-year term.
Wu, of the opposition New Party, made the promise on succeeding in his re-election bid, seizing the only Kinmen seat up for grabs.

Wu said his win represents a victory for the opposition "pan-blue alliance" consisting of his party, the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) and for all residents on the frontline island of Kinmen.

He said he will continue to promote the expansion of the "mini three links" to allow Kinmen- and Matsu-born people residing in Taiwan proper to travel between Taiwan and the mainland using the direct transport links, as well as launching a Kinmen-Xiamen package tour for Taiwanese tourists.

Kinmen and Matsu has maintained direct ferry services with the mainland ports of Xiamen and Fuzhou since 2001. However, only residents of Kinmen and Matsu, and Taiwanese businessmen with operations on the mainland, are currently allowed to travel across the Taiwan Strait via the services.
In Matsu, former opposition KMT lawmaker Tsao Erh-chung was elected to the only seat on the outlying island, defeating incumbent Legislator Tsao Yuan-chang of the PFP.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT THANKS VOTERS FOR HELPING 'PAN-BLUES' SECURE LEGISLATIVE MAJORITY

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng thanked "pan-blue alliance" supporters Saturday for helping the alliance to retain its majority in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan in that day's elections.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, People Firsty Party (PFP) and New Party seized a total of 114 seats in the polls, compared with 101 seats garnered by the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).
The newly formed Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) won six seats, while independents grabbed the remaining four.
Lin claimed that the victory of the "pan-blue alliance" reflects voters' discontent with President Chen Shui-bian.

However, he then went on to say that it was the nomination strategy of the "pan-blue alliance" that led to the its success because it set a strict quota on the total number of candidates nominated by the three parties.
In contrast, he said, the "pan-green camp" nominated an excessive number of candidates.
While the "pan-blue alliance" nominated a total of 115 candidates for regional seats, the "pan-green camp" named 122 candidates.
In addition, Lin said, the close cooperation between the KMT and its two allies, together with their voter allocation strategy, also contributed to their victory.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONTINUES TO SEEK CROSS-STRAIT PEACE DESPITE BEIJING'S THREATS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By C. N. Hsieh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top mainland China policy formulator said Saturday in Tokyo that despite relentless squeezing by mainland China and its constant military threat, Taiwan has continued to work toward cross-Taiwan Strait peace.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu made the remarks when he was invited by several Japanese civic groups to visit Japan and give a speech at a forum in Tokyo.
Wu elaborated on Taiwan's mainland policy, and reminded his audience that Japan, as well as Taiwan, faces the military expansion and potential threat from the mainland.
He stressed that Japan and Taiwan have common interests and said the two sides need to step up cooperation and exchanges for the stability and prosperity in the Taiwan Strait and East Asia.

He also took the opportunity to speak on a recent drive by President Chen Shui-bian to change the official name of the nation's overseas missions and state-owned enterprises to include the word "Taiwan, " as well as his proposed constitutional revisions, describing them as "the inevitable trend" of Taiwan's democratization.
But this democratization trend is deemed by the mainland as taboo and tantamount to Taiwan declaring independence, so it has resorted to verbal attack and military intimidation.
But, Wu said, Beijing's "one China" rhetoric, verbal attacks and military intimidation serve only to drive the two sides of the Taiwan Strait even further apart.
In addition to giving speeches, Wu will call on Japanese parliamentarians, experts and scholars during his four-day visit.
He is scheduled to return to Taipei Dec. 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE' MAINTAINS SLIM MAJORITY IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT), the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party maintained its slim majority Saturday, grabbing a combined total of 114 seats in the legislative elections.

But the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) remained the largest political party in the legislature with 89 seats in the 225-seat member legislature, followed by the main opposition KMT with 79 seats.
The PFP had 34 seats, the TSU 12 seats, the New Party one seat, the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union six seats, and independents or candidates who had not been nominated by their parties, four seats.
The "pan-green camp" of the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (12 seats) managed to take a total of 101 seats.
Seven New Party candidates ran in the elections under the banner of the KMT, while Wu Cheng-tian representing outlying Kinmen island, retained his New Party registration.

Out of 168 regional seats, the DPP came top with 69 seats, followed by the KMT (57 seats) , the PFP (25 seats), the TSU (seven seats) , the NPSU (five seats) , the New Party (one seat) , and independents or candidates who had not been nominated by their parties (four seats).
Out of eight aboriginal seats, the KMT came top with four seats, followed by the PFP (two seats), the DPP (one seat) and the NPSU (one seat).

Of the 41 at-large seats to be filled based on a proportional representation system according to the total number of votes garnered by each political party in the elections, the DPP came top with 16 seats, followed by the KMT with 15 seats, the PFP with six seats and the TSU with four seats.
Of the eight overseas community seats, based on the same proportional representation system, both the DPP and the KMT took three seats, and the PFP and the TSU one seat each.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE' HOLDS GRIP ON CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT), the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party kept its grip on central Taiwan in Saturday's legislative elections, which helped thwart the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) target of wresting control of the legislature.

The DPP originally hoped to gain new ground in central Taiwan to realize its goal of capturing a working majority in the new Legislative Yuan along with its "pan green camp" ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).

However, the "pan-blue alliance" managed to prevent the "pan-green camp" from gaining more than half of the seats in all four central Taiwan constituencies -- Taichung County, Taichung City, Nantou County and Changhua County.
In Taiwan's political landscape, the "pan-blue alliance" has traditionally dominated northern and central Taiwan, while the "pan-green camp" has enjoyed an edge in southern Taiwan.

In the March 20 presidential election, the "pan-green camp" ticket of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu beat the "pan-blue alliance" ticket of KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong in Changhua County and Taichung County, while the Lien-Soong ticket outperformed the Chen-Lu team in Taichung City and Nantou County. In terms of the number of votes, the Chen-Lu ticket won about 20,000 votes more than the Lien-Soong team.

That hard-won rare win prompted the DPP to have high expectations of expanding its ground in the four constituencies in Saturday's elections. However, it failed to reach the target because of an unexpected loss in Changhua County.

In the Taichung County constituency, the "pan-blue alliance" won six seats, compared to the "pan-green camp's" four seats. The remaining one seat was captured by a member of the newly established Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU).

In Changhua County, the "pan-blue alliance" secured five seats, while the "pan-green camp" gained only three seats; the remaining two seats went to the NPSU and an independent. In the present legislature, the "pan-green camp" holds four seats from that constituency.

In Taichung City, both camps garnered four seats each. In the previous legislative elections, the constituency had only seven seats up for grabs. This time around, the constituency had eight legislative seats due to an increase in its population. The additional seat went to the "pan-green camp."
In Nantou County, both camps captured two seats each, the same as in the previous election.
As the "pan-green camp" failed to gain more seats in the four central Taiwan constituencies, the DPP fell short of its target of wresting a majority in the 225-seat new legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN PRESIDENT ANNOUNCES TO SEEK RE-ELECTION

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Saturday that he will seek re-election as leader of the new legislature elected earlier that day.

With the initial election results showing that the "pan blue alliance" of the KMT, the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party (NP) has garnered more than half of the 225 seats in the new Legislative Yuan and Wang high on the at-large seats, he said he will solicit the support from all the new legislators and that if more than half of the legislators support him, his re-election bid will be easier.
The "pan blue alliance" won 114 seats in Saturday's elections, with the KMT garnering 79 seats, the PFP 34 seats, and the NP one seat.
The "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) took 101 seats, with the DPP winning 89 seats, and TSU 12 seats.
The Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) and independent legislators won six and four seats, respectively.
In reply to questions from the media, Wang said he will continue offering support to KMT Chairman Lien Chan if he also seeks re-election as leader of the party.

As to Lien's proposal, made known few days before the elections, that he will recommend P.K. Chiang, a heavyweight economic planner in the former KMT-led government and incumbent Legislative Yuan vice president, to serve as premier if the "pan blue alliance" was to win a legislative majority, Wang expressed hope that President Chen Shui-bian will consider the proposal if he wants to improve the country's economy.
Lien said recently that the new legislature will represent the new public opinion and most of the public hope for a new and capable administrative team to lead the country.

While congratulating the elected legislators, Wang also urged the leaders of the nation's political parties to work toward repairing the ethnic rift that the politicians have caused during their electoral campaigns.
He expressed hope that the political leaders will do their best to seek the country's progress and harmony, stressing that only pragmatism can satisfy the interests of the majority.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPSU TO BECOME CRUCIAL MINORITY IN LEGISLATURE: NPSU CHAIRWOMAN

TEXT.P: The Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU), which won six seats in Saturday's legislative elections, will play the role of a crucial minority in the Legislative Yuan in the next three years, NPSU Chairwoman Chang Po-ya said Saturday.
Chang said the outcome was less than satisfactory but should not be considered a failure for the NPSU, as the party made a late start to its preparation for the elections.
The NPSU, founded in June this year, had originally hoped to seize 20 seats.
Chang said the NPSU will become a crucial minority with strategic importance in the legislature in light of the fact that the "pan-blue alliance" only won a marginal majority.
The party will also seek to invite independent legislators to join the party in the future, she said.
NPSU Secretary-General Chen Chieh-ju, meanwhile, said the party will not rule out cooperation with either the "pan-blue alliance" or the "pan-green camp" and will not side with any particular camp.
Chen said the NPSU supports any policy that is to the benefit of the people and may change its cooperation partner based on the issues at hand.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang, People First Party and New Party garnered a total of 114 seats in the 225-member Legislative Yuan, while the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union won 101 seats.
Independents gained four seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CHAIRMAN REGRETS PARTY'S ELECTION PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: The chairman of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Saturday he was sorry to learn that the TSU could only maintain its present 12 seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan following that day's legislative elections.
Huang said he felt sad but that the party will respect the choice of the people.
He also said that former President Lee Teng-hui, the party's so-called "spiritual leader, " told him that the party needs to keep trying but should engage in some earnest soul-searching.

The TSU garnered seven regional seats, four at-large seats and one overseas seat which were filled on a proportional representation system according to the total number of votes each political party garnered in the elections, for a total of 12 seats, one less than in the previous legislative elections.
Su Ying-kuei, originally of the TSU, quit the party to run as an independent, but failed in his re-election bid in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.
But Huang was able to take some comfort from the fact that Huang Shih-chou, his son, also representing the TSU, won a regional seat.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN VOWS TO PUSH FOR MERGER OF 'PAN-BLUE' PARTIES

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Saturday he will push for close cooperation among the three "pan-blue alliance" political parties after they jointly wrested a slim majority in Saturday's legislative elections.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party jointly garnered 116 of the 225 legislative seats up for grabs in the just-concluded elections, Lien said, adding that this was a hard-won achievement through the three parties' concerted efforts.
In the future, Lien said, he will continue to push for close cooperation among the three parties and an eventual merger.
As to whether or when he will step down from the KMT chairmanship, Lien said "generational transition" is an important concept.
Lien said he will follow the party's charter, rules and system to accomplish an intraparty "generational transition."
According to KMT rules, Lien's term of office will expire next August.

DOC.HEADLINE: VOTER TURNOUT FOR LEGISLATIVE POLLS RECORDED AT 59%: CEC

TEXT.P: Voter turnout for Saturday's legislative elections amounted to 59 percent, compared with 66 percent for that of the previous elections in 2001, Central Election Commission (CEC) Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung said later that day.
Of the 16.55 million people eligible to vote, only 9.79 million went to the polls, according to Chang.

On the vote shares of the various political parties, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) gained 35.72 percent, or 3.47 million votes, while the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) obtained 32.82 percent, or 3.19 million votes, Chang said.
The opposition People First Party (PFP) won 13.89 percent, or 1.35 million votes, while the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) seized 7.78 percent, or 756,712 votes, he said.
The Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) got 3.63 percent, or 353,164 votes, independents gained 5.94 percent, or 577,292 votes, and the New Party garnered 0.125 percent, or 12,137 votes, he added.

Of the total of 225 legislative seats up for grabs in the elections, the DPP won 89 seats; the KMT gained 79 seats; the PFP obtained 34 seats; the TSU seized six seats; the NPSU got six seats; independents won four seats; and the New Party gained one seat.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO TAKE RESPONSIBILITY FOR DPP ELECTION FAILURE: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: As campaign manager of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Premier Yu Shyi-kun will take full responsibility for the DPP's worse-than-expected performance in Saturday's legislative elections, Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said.
Although the DPP's seats in the Legislative Yuan have seen a slight increase after the elections, the overall showing of the party failed to meet the expectations of its supporters, Chen said.
It is especially regrettable that a number of outstanding incumbent DPP legislators lost their re-election bids, Chen added.

The DPP seized 89 seats in Saturday's elections, compared with 87 seats it won in the previous polls in 2001. The DPP had originally expected to garner more than 100 seats and together with its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, secure a majority in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.

Meanwhile, DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung announced soon after the outcome was released that he has offered to resign from the party position and the post of at-large legislator to take responsibility for the setback.
DPP Deputy Secretaries-General Lee Ying-yuan and Chung Chia-pin have also offered to step down, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR DEC. 12 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, Dec. 12:
09: 10, Vice President Annette Lu will attend activities in celebration of the 101st anniversary of the Taipei First Girl's High School at the school's campus.
09: 30, A seminar on cross-Taiwan Strait relations after the legislative elections will be held at the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research.
09: 30, A carnival-style sporting event organized by the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee for "foreign friends" will be held at the Daan Park in Taipei.
10:00, Vice President Annette Lu will attend the inauguration of the Formosan Society at the Go Go Go Union Office.
13:00, Foreign observers of the legislative elections will hold a roundtable seminar at the National Taiwan University Alumni Hall in Taipei.
13:00, A seminar on Taiwan's political and economic situations in the wake of the legislative elections will be held at the Taipei International Convention Center.
14: 00, A children's chorus from Ukraine will hold a news conference at the National Concert Hall in Taipei.
15: 30, Vice President Annette Lu will host a tea party at the Presidential Office to entertain participants of the first Women's Partnership Forum for Pacific Islanders.
22: 20, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming will leave for Australia from the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS INDICT 149 SUSPECTS FOR ALLEGED VOTE-BUYING

TEXT.P: Prosecutors have indicted a total of 149 suspects involved in 37 alleged vote-buying cases related to Saturday's legislative elections, officials of the Supreme Prosecutor's Office said Saturday.
The officials said that prosecutor's offices around the nation had received 5,433 reports of alleged vote-buying prior to the elections.
The prosecution authorities will continue to investigate other alleged election irregularities, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA HOPES THINGS WILL RETURN TO NORMAL AFTER ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Saturday that Taiwan's political situation should return to normal now that the legislative elections are over.

Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chen Ruey-long said the ministry hopes the political situation will return to normal, saying that everyone must strive to improve the economy for the benefit of the nation.
Meanwhile, local entrepreneurs expressed hope that the new legislature will put aside its differences and work pragmatically toward upgrading the nation's competitiveness.

Douglas Hsu, chairman of the Far Eastern Group, said that the rivalry between the ruling and the opposition parties in recent years have stalled the nation's economic development and have allowed neighboring countries to catch up quickly.
Hsu expressed hope that the legislators-elect will pool their wisdom to pass bills and upgrade the efficiency of the legislature.

Tsai Ming-chung, chairman of Fubon Financial, said the business world and the public have long deemed the legislature as chaotic and that both the ruling and opposition parties are polarized on issues concerning cross-Taiwan Strait relations. He urged a return to rationality after the day's elections.
Kao Chin-yen, chairman of the Uni-President Group, urged all legislators-elect to listen to the views of the public and to work toward improving the economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO DISCUSS PERSONNEL RESHUFFLE ISSUE NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will discuss whether to reshuffle its leading personnel at the weekly meeting of its Central Standing Committee next week, a senior party official said Saturday.

DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung and his two deputies, Lee Ying-yuan and Chung Chia-pin, offered to resign after the party failed to reach its target of wresting control of the new Legislative Yuan along with its ally of the Taiwan Solidarity Union in Saturday's legislative elections.
Lee Ying-yuan said President Chen Shui-bian, who doubles as DPP chairman, has not immediately accepted their resignations.
"The issue will be addressed at the DPP's weekly meeting next Tuesday," Lee said.

The DPP garnered 89 of the 225 legislative seats up for grabs, up two seats from the present level, while its vote ratio also edged up 2.34 percent. Nevertheless, it fell far short of the DPP's target of winning 96 to 101 seats.
Asked whether Premier Yu Shyi-kun will step down and whether the Cabinet should be reshuffled, Lee said the issue has not been discussed.
"The competition was very fierce. The fact that we managed to gain more seats and more votes indicated that our reform agenda has received popular support," Lee said.

As 14 of the party's incumbent lawmakers failed to win re-election, Lee said the DPP headquarters, and himself in particular, will assume full responsibility for the failure of the party's "voter allocation" campaign strategy.

Meanwhile, DPP legislative whip Tsai Huang-liang said the DPP should take the initiative to push for reconciliation and cooperation with the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER HALF OF INCUMBENTS SUCCEED IN RE-ELECTION BIDS

TEXT.P: A total of 120 incumbent legislators won re-election, while 37 legislators failed to get another term, the Central Election Commission (CEC) said after Saturday's elections.
Among the 225 seats up for grabs, 179 were taken by male legislators, with 47 taken by female legislators. They averaged 49.4 years old.

Thirty-seven incumbent legislators failed in their re-election bids, including many popular legislators such as Duan Yi-kang, Shen Fu-hsiung, and Chiu Yi-ying of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, Chen Shei-saint, Chiang Chi-wen and Kuo Tien-chai of the Kuomintang and Lin Chi-lung of the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

The youngest legislator-elect is 30-year-old Hsieh Kuo-liang. Hsieh, currently a vice chairman of a middle high school in Keelung, was considered a very daring choice when nominated by the People First Party.
The youngest at-large legislator-elect is 28-year-old Huang Chi-hsiung, a taekwondo silver medalist in the Athens Olympics, who represents the KMT.

Wu Yu-sheng, a former spokesman of the Taipei city government, also making his debut in the elections, won 73,164 votes in one of the constituencies in Taipei County, the highest number of individual votes in the nation.

The children of political figures fared well in the day's elections. Wu Chi-yang, son of the KMT Vice Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung, came top in Taoyuan County. Kao Su-po, son of KMT Central Standing Committee member Kao Yu-jen, Huang Shih-chou, son of Taiwan Solidarity Union Chairman Huang Chu-wen and Chen Ying, daughter of the Council of Aboriginal Affairs Chairman Chen Chien-nien also secured seats.

Ke Chun-hsiung, a movie-star-turned-politician, was top in Hsinchu City, while Li Ao, a prolific writer who listed countering the "barbaric administration" as his major platform, said that he took victory in his stride, admitting that winning was not even his major interest.
Li also said, tongue-in-cheek, that "it is outrageous" for him to be elected because he did not post banners or canvass voters in his constituency.
Li also said that he would take advice from Sisy Chen, an incumbent legislator who acted as his chief strategist, to do something for society after his election.

The CEC said that there were 16,559,254 eligible voters this year, up 736,671 from the previous legislative elections. But the turnout rate Saturday was 59.16 percent, or 9.796,299 voters, setting a new low for voter turnout.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 12, or the first day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1642: Abel Yasman, a Dutch navigator, discovers New Zealand.
1787: Pennsylvania becomes the second state of the United States.
1804: Spain declares war on Britain.
1894: Japanese troops invade Korea.
1901: Italian physicist Marchese Guglielmo Marconi completes his first trans-Atlantic wireless radio transmission.
1906: The German company Telefunken successfully tests a wireless telephone.
1915: Yuan Shih-kai, the provisional president of the Republic of China who promised to establish a republican government, proclaims himself emperor.
1932: The ROC resumes diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.
1936: Chang Hsueh-liang's troops mutiny in Xian and hold Chiang Kai-shek and other ranking ROC government officials hostage.
1937: Japanese planes bomb and sink a U.S. warship in the Yangtze River in China, straining relations between Japan and the United States.
1941: The "Taiwan Revolutionary Alliance" is set up in Chungking and issues a statement urging all compatriots to unite against Japanese aggression.
1946: The ROC Ministry of the Interior rebuilds a national boundary monument at its southernmost boundary in the Nansha (Spratly) Islands.
1959: The "Hai Ming" freighter of China Merchants Steam Navigation Co. begins plying a route between Taiwan and the east coast of the United States, becoming the first Chinese ship to sail the route.
1971: Yiu Mi-chien, who was known as "the father of Taiwan's tourism industry," dies in Taipei at the age of 74.
1972: The Taipei City Council adopts a resolution on the establishment of sisterhood relations with Guam.
1972: The Sino-Guatemalan agricultural technical cooperation agreement is put into effect.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo declares that the ROC will become a nation of heavy industry after the completion of the "Ten Basic Construction Projects."
1979: Maj. Gen. Chun Doo-hwan and his colleagues stage an army coup and seize power in South Korea.
1982: The ROC wins a high proportion of medals, including 4 golds and 16 others as well as a special prize, at the 31st World Fair for Inventions held Dec. 4-12 in Brussels.
1984: An extradition treaty between the ROC and the Republic of Costa Rica is signed, the first such treaty signed by the ROC.
1991: Boris Yeltsin wins landslide approval in the Russian Parliament for his new Commonwealth of Independent States.
1992: Major earthquakes kill 2,500 people on Flores Island in eastern Indonesia.
1994: The Lien Chan Cabinet is re-organized, and new Cabinet members are sworn in three days later.
1995: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations passes a resolution to implement a treaty to set up a non-nuclear zone.
1999:A four-member delegation led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng departs for Panama to attend a forum of presidents of legislative assemblies of the ROC and Central American countries.
2000: Legislator Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, takes the helm of an association of lawmakers to promote relations between the Republic of China and the United States.
2001: Internet and media firm tom.com Ltd. and Taiwan's Business Weekly Publishing Inc. reach an agreement that tom.com purchases the magazine group's equity interest for NT$1.65 billion.
2001: Visiting Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique Bandeira Melo de Menezes, accompanied by his counterpart, ROC President Chen Shui-bian, visits the Sixth Naphtha Cracking Plant of the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) at Mailiao in Yunlin County, southern Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, in the matter of food, should never seek to indulge his appetite; in lodging, he should not be too solicitous of comfort. In this way, he may become a man of real culture."

Twenty-one of the 42 volunteer miners -- who were among those who successfully rescued four survivors trapped in the basement of a collapsed building in Real, Quezon -- returned yesterday to their base in Metro Manila as hopes dimmed in finding more alive victims from the rubbles and landslide areas in the calamity stricken area.
