Former New York Police Commissioner Bernard Kerik abruptly withdrew himself from consideration as the nation's next Homeland Security chief, saying he had determined that a former household employee might have been an illegal immigrant.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE SOUGHT POLITICAL BALANCE AFTER ELECTIONS: U.S. SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The results of Taiwan's just-concluded legislative elections show that the people of Taiwan are looking for some balance between the Chen Shui-bian administration and the Legislative Yuan, a scholar with a Washington-based think-tank said Saturday.

Alan Romberg, a senior associate and director of the East Asia Program of the Henry L. Stimson Center, said that many factors contributed to the victory Saturday by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Chinese Nationalist Party (KMT) and the People First Party, who retained a slim majority in the lawmaking body, but the outcome reflects "a degree of caution" on the part of voters about the handling of cross-Taiwan Strait issues.

"While the voters are perhaps supportive of the sentiment behind moves to deepen formal Taiwanese identity, their choice in this election would appear to demonstrate a desire for greater reflection by the government on the appropriate pace and extent of steps in that direction [on cross-strait relations]," Romberg said.

Constitutional revision was never going to be easy, but it now would appear that any radical changes that could upset cross-strait stability will be totally out of the question, said Romberg, who was formerly a deputy spokesman for the State Department.
Romberg said that he has always credited President Chen's pledges that he would not touch on sensitive cross-strait issues in any case.
However, Romberg said, President Chen was under pressure from some quarters either to modify or abandon those pledges, or to find a way around them.

That prospect would now seem to have been put to rest, he said, adding that whether the "good governance" aspects of constitutional revisions proposed by President Chen will be possible is yet to be seen, but most of those are quite separate from the question of cross-strait relations.
With less pressure on that front, this could be a moment for Beijing to reconsider some aspects of its own cross-strait policies, Romberg added.

With a greater sense of confidence that this is not contributing to momentum for "independence, " Romberg claimed that Beijing could possibly accede to Taiwan's application for World Health Organization observership, promote Mid-autumn Moon Festival charter flights, the broader issue of the cross-strait links, and even consider some level of authoritative dialogue.

Romberg added that the United States will be consistent in supporting Taiwan's well-being, but it will also continue to oppose steps by either side that would threaten to upset cross-strait peace and stability.

It remains to be seen how the Legislative Yuan will handle the special defense procurement budget, but based on the campaign, it would seem that some of the items put forward by President Chen will at the least be revised by the legislature, Romberg asserted.

"In terms of the impact on U.S.-Taiwan relations, I think it will be more important to see that Taiwan is willing to commit greater resources to its defense in effective ways than that particular weapons systems [to] be purchased," he said.

"That is, it is less important that Taipei appropriate funds to purchase submarines, for example, than that it demonstrate in its overall approach to the defense budget that it is willing to accept substantial responsibility for its own defense, not simply counting on the United States to rescue it in an emergency," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN URGED TO TALK WITH 'PAN-BLUES' ON PREMIER APPOINTMENT

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) urged President Chen Shui-bian Sunday to respect the voters' will and talk with the "pan-blue alliance" over the issue regarding appointment of premier.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance, " which groups the KMT, the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party, won a majority of 114 seats in the 225-seat legislature Saturday. The KMT now says that it has the mandate to demand a coalition government in accordance with the Republic of China Constitution, including collaboratively appointing the premier.

KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng said that the president is empowered in the Constitution to appoint a premier, but he should also exercise magnanimity as a national leader and respect the opinions of the legislature since the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is a minority in the lawmaking body.

Because the "pan-blues" retained their majority at the legislature, Lin said President Chen's persistence in trying to control all governmental branches is a move tantamount to "the minority raping the majority."

Meanwhile, Yao Chiang-lin, a member of the KMT Central Standing Committee, said that he will put forward a motion at a KMT meeting next Wednesday to ask President Chen to accept Chiang Ping-kun, a KMT vice chairman and the deputy speaker of the Legislative Yuan, as the new premier.

Yao said the motion is an active response to KMT Chairman Lien Chan's statement that if the "pan-blue alliance" retained its majority, the KMT would work to form a coalition government with the ruling DPP.

Yao said that if the "pan-blues'" appeal falls on deaf ears, the KMT will not exclude the possibility of promoting a motion of no-confidence in the premier at the Legislative Yuan or exerting pressure to achieve that goal.

DOC.HEADLINE: US STATE DEPARTMENT PRAISES TAIWAN'S LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The just-concluded legislative elections in Taiwan demonstrated the strength and vitality of Taiwan's democracy, a spokesperson for the U.S. Department of State said Friday.
The spokesperson said the elections show that the people of Taiwan, like Americans, cherishes the right to choose their representatives, and this is a tribute to the Taiwanese people.

Meanwhile, a U.S. expert in Chinese affairs said the results of the legislative elections in Taiwan, in which the opposition retained its small majority, suggest that the people of Taiwan are reluctant to endorse some of the more destabilizing proposals pertaining to sovereignty that were promoted by the last weeks of the campaigning.

David Lampton, director of China Studies at Johns Hopkins-SAIS and The Nixon Center said the results also suggest that great departures on policies with respect to sensitive issues will be difficult to produce, and in this sense the results should be somewhat reassuring to Beijing.

He said most of the U.S. political analysts will see these results as supportive of regional peace and stability, and both sides of the Taiwan Strait should seize this opportunity to move forward with practical steps to increase cultural, economic and other dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: IAEA Leader's Phone Tapped; U.S. Pores Over Transcripts to Try to Oust Nuclear Chief.
The Bush administration has dozens of intercepts of Mohamed ElBaradei's phone calls with Iranian diplomats and is scrutinizing them in search of ammunition to oust him as director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, according to three U.S. government officials, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMATURE BABY MAKES LONG JOURNEY FROM SHANGHAI TO TAICHUNG FOR HELP

TEXT.P: A sick baby who was born prematurely has arrived in Taichung via Kinmen for emergency treatment after making a 1,500-kilometer freeway journey from an intensive care unit in Shanghai and ensuing cross-strait sea and air transport.
The seven-month-old girl, "little An-an, " born in Shanghai, weighed only 900 grams at birth.
The average birth weight is roughly between 3 kilograms to 3.5 kilograms. The baby was born on May 1, just 28 weeks into the pregnancy. "Little An-an" currently weighs around 2.3 kilograms.

A medical group, led by the president of Li Shin Hospital in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, arrived in Shanghai last Thursday to escort the baby -- the daughter of a Taiwan computer businessman and his Hangzhou wife -- from Shanghai back to Taiwan as the premature child is in critical condition with breathing difficulties.
The father of the child took advantage of the "mini three-links" channel to return to Taiwan via the southern Chinese port city of Xiamen to Kinmen.
The entire journey from Shanghai to Xiamen, Kinmen and finally to the hospital in Taichung took about 22 hours.

Because the father of the baby is a Taiwan citizen, "little An-an" is covered by the country's national health insurance program and the family decided to bring the baby back to Taiwan rather than shoulder the costs of treatment themselves in Shanghai.

Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng and an official with the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council greeted the child and her parents upon their arrival in Kinmen and gave them a red envelope containing NT$6,600 as a token of their blessing to the youngest passenger that the "mini three-links" has ever served.

The emergency cross-strait transport of the premature baby was originally scheduled to take place last Thursday night but was delayed due to thick fog that closed the freeway connecting Shanghai and Wenzhou for the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU WILL CONTINUE WORKING WITH DPP

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will continue to work together with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the new legislature despite their fierce competition in the just-concluded legislative elections, TSU Deputy Secretary-General Huang Chin-lang said Sunday.

One day after TSU saw the DPP expands its power base in the legislature at its cost, Huang said the two parties share the same political cause of pushing for Taiwan independence, adding that there will be no political fall-out simply because they were competing to woo support from the same group of people.

However, Huang said, the TSU, which is more radical than the DPP in its efforts to establish a country named Taiwan, will keep a close eye on the DPP to see that the ruling party doesn't deviate from or drag its feet on this goal.

The TSU's spiritual leader, former President Lee Teng-hui, who turned up the heat on President Chen Shui-bian by organizing a mass rally in Taipei one week before the Dec. 11 elections to back up his call for changing the name of the country to Taiwan, was absent from public view Sunday.

Chen Wen-tsan, a director for the DPP Communications Department, said Lee's extreme rhetoric ahead of the election is understandable in light of his self-imposed mission to lead Taiwan to independence, and there is much common ground between the TSU and DPP in politics, which makes it easy to work together.

Giving that the country is set to change the electoral system for lawmakers by switching from a multi-member district system to a single-seat constituency system, political analysts said small parties like the TSU are likely to be wiped out, and TSU lawmakers will have to join the DPP to survive under the new electoral system.

Political analysts believe the TSU's setback in the elections suggests that Lee's political clout is waning, and President Chen's leadership in the pro-independence camp is reinforced, which means TSU lawmakers face a choice between demise in the TSU or survival in the DPP.
Chen Wen-tsan said the DPP would like to see TSU lawmakers join its ranks, but that it will not absorb the TSU against its will.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN CHAN TO STEP DOWN AS CHAIRMAN AS PROMISED: PARTY OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will step down as party chairman when his term is up as he promised prior to the legislative elections to optimize the party's resolve to accelerate "the passing-over of party torch, " KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng said Sunday.
"Lien is determined to step down and the plan remains unchanged," Lin said.

In a news conference held Saturday evening after the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, the People First Party and the New Party won a majority of 114 seats in the 225-seat legislature, Lien was evasive in answering a reporter's question on whether he will continue to lead Taiwan's largest opposition party next March when his term as KMT chairman expires.
Lien said, "We will follow the party's charter and regulations when arrangements are made."
According to Lin, the KMT's new party chairman will be elected before next August at a party congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG NIXES POSSIBILITY OF MERGER WITH KMT

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong on Sunday ruled out the possibility of a merger between his party and the Kuomintang ( KMT) after the PFP lost 12 seats in the just-concluded legislative elections.

During a tour of Tainan, southern Taiwan to thank supporters of his party, Soong said the KMT has closed the door on a possible merger by failing to honor its promises to the PFP. He did not elaborate.

He promised PFP supporters that his party will continue to focus on issues concerning the country's ties with mainland China, do its best to improve harmony among ethnic groups in Taiwan and play a role as a strong opposition party.
Meanwhile, PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung also said a merger with the KMT is out of the question.

Chang blamed the KMT for backing out of its agreement with the PFP, which is a KMT splinter party, that both parties should refrain from naming more candidates than their common supporters can afford to vote for.
The PFP vice chairman said that the KMT wriggled out of its promise by allowing its party members to run outside of the KMT ticket and therefore reduced the chances of PFP candidates' success.
Furthermore, Chang claimed, the KMT excluded PFP candidates from its vote-allocation scheme on the eve of the elections, which left the PFP candidates to fend for themselves.

The straw that broke the PFP's back was the fact that KMT party officials prevented Soong from soliciting votes at living quarters of family members of military personnel in Hsinchu City, northern Taiwan. Military personnel and their families are traditionally supporters of the KMT or the PFP.
As a result, Chang claimed that six PFP candidates led the list of losers in different constituencies. They could have won if there were fewer candidates on the ballots.
The PFP will continue to cooperate with the KMT on major polices in the legislature, but there is virtually no possibility of a merger between the two, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-MAC CHAIRWOMAN, DPP OFFICIAL TO VISIT U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By C. L. Chi and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Former Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen and Deputy Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will arrive in Washington for a visit in the coming days.

Tsai, who is set to be an at-large legislator for the DPP following Saturday's legislative polls, and Lee are slated to meet U. S. officials in charge of Asia-Pacific affairs, take part in a seminar held by the Brookings Institute on "the Future of Taiwan" and attend a news conference Dec. 16 at the "Twin Oaks" compound -- the former Republic of China embassy in Washington, D. C. before the two countries cut diplomatic ties in 1979.

According to officials of U.S. think tanks, the surprise defeat of the "pan-green camp" of the ruling DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union in the elections has aroused greater attention from the Bush administration on future political developments in Taiwan.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang, the People First Party and the New Party took 114 seats in the 225-member Legislative Yuan, constituting a setback for President Chen Shui-bian, and the opposition is expected to further put the brakes on some policies being promoted by the DPP, in particular those related to Taiwan-mainland China ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: SLIM CHANCE OF NO-CONFIDENCE VOTE IN NEW LEGISLATURE: DPP AIDES

TEXT.P: Although the opposition retained its majority in Saturday's legislative elections, officials of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claimed Sunday that chances of a no-confidence vote in the new legislature are slim if President Chen Shui-bian rejects its power-sharing proposal.

Lee Ying-yuan, deputy secretary-general of the DPP, predicted that the feasibility of a no-confidence vote against the premier in the new Legislative Yuan is extremely low, because such a move would allow the president to dissolve the legislature and lead to new elections, a situation that the opposition would not be happy to see.
If the elections were held again, it is questionable that the opposition would be able to retain more than half of the seats, he claimed.

Chung Chia-pin, another DPP secretary-general, said that society must return to normal now that the heated campaigning is over and he pointed out that the opposition parties will be punished by the voters in new elections should they rashly call for a no-confidence vote.

He said that room is ample for two-way discussions on creating a coalition government as President Chen has called for rational exchanges and cooperation between the governing and opposition parties after the elections.

Earlier in the same day, Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng urged President Chen to respect the new mandate in the sixth legislature and take the initiative to discuss possible options for the premiership with the opposition camp.

Lin made the remarks after the "pan blue alliance" of the KMT, the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party won 114 seats in the 225-member Legislative Yuan in Saturday's elections. The "pan green camp" of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union won only 101 seats.

The election results empower the KMT to back mainstream public opinion and to strongly check and balance the government led by President Chen, Lin said, urging the president to openly embrace the issue and hold negotiations with the opposition.

Opposition KMT Chairman Lien Chan said one day prior to the hotly contested polls that he would ask President Chen to respect the opposition's right to form a new Cabinet in compliance with the Constitution's spirit if it won a majority.

Lien also recommended P. K. Chiang, currently a vice chairman of the KMT and deputy legislative speaker and former chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development in the previous KMT-led government from 1996 to 2000, to serve as the new premier as part of the KMT's efforts to help improve Taiwan's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI-BEIJING, TAIPEI-WASHINGTON TIES UNCHANGED AFTER ELECTIONS: MAC

TEXT.P: The results of Saturday's legislative elections show that Taiwan is a pluralistic and democratic society and they will not affect Taipei-Beijing or Taipei-Washington ties, a government official said Sunday.

Chiu Tai-san, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , made the remarks while giving a speech at a seminar sponsored by the Institute of International Relations at National Chengchi University following the legislative elections.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT), the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party managed to retain a majority by winning 114 seats in the 225-member legislature, outperforming the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union who garnered 101 seats.

Chiu said that he believes that a "pan-blue alliance" majority in the legislature will help the U.S. maintain its basic stance toward Taiwan under the framework of the Taiwan Relations Act. Under these circumstances, Taipei-Washington ties will not be much affected, he pointed out.

On the other hand, there will be no drastic changes in relations across the Taiwan Strait, as the president has repeatedly pledged to follow his "four noes plus one" policy, he said, adding that trade and economic activities between the two sides will also continue to expand.

Chiu told another seminar held earlier the same day that the executive branch was already prepared to face the new legislature controlled again by the opposition and said that its impact on Taipei-Beijing links are hard to predict in the short term.

He contended that the administration must step up its lobbying at the Legislative Yuan to ensure political stability at home and called for the opposition camp and Beijing to jointly cooperate in making peace across the strait, such as reopening cross-strait negotiations as soon as possible.
Speaking on the same occasion, Chang Jung-kung, a spokesman for the KMT, said that cross-strait tensions have been temporarily soothed, but added that the current deadlock will remain.

As the "pan-blue alliance" is expected to play a "firewall" role in the new legislature, Chang said that Beijing is very likely to put aside its strong offensive to counter Taiwan independence. But he said that the existing political impasse between the two sides will remain in place since no solutions have been found to the "one China" issue and the DPP's de-sinicization moves.

Hsu Shu-feng, the head of the DPP's Mainland Affairs Department, said that Beijing may be reluctant to rekindle close exchanges with Taiwan in the short term. But she said that the DPP will continue to handle cross-strait issues pragmatically and wait patiently for a positive response from Beijing.

Wu Jui-kuo, a former PFP official in charge of international affairs, urged the ruling and opposition camps to drop their political feuding and consolidate their stances on priority issues, such as keeping the peace across the strait and mending Taiwan-U.S. relations.
He urged both camps to look to the fact that foreign influences are playing an increasingly bigger role in cross-strait affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA CANN0T AFFECT TAIWAN'S CHANCE TO EXPLORE VIETNAM MARKET

TEXT.P: China's free trade agreement with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) won't compromise Taiwan's chance to break into the market of Vietnam, a Vietnam trade official stationed in Taipei said Sunday.

The official, who requested to remain anonymous, told CNA that Taiwan's investment in Vietnam is increasing rapidly in recent years and is the second largest foreign investor in Vietnam now, with a total investment of US$7 billion, after Singapore which post an investment of US$7.5 billion.

As a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) , Taiwan can step up its economic ties with ASEAN states under the WTO framework which will not be influenced by the absence of a free trade agreement between it and the ASEAN, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
: New York Times: Kerik's position was untenable, Bush aide says.
U.S. President Bush readily accepted Bernard B. Kerik's decision to withdraw his nomination as homeland security secretary after the White House quickly concluded on Friday evening that it would be impossible for him to win confirmation for a post that supervises enforcement of the nation's immigration laws if he had had immigration problems in his own household, White House officials said on Saturday. White House officials were clearly annoyed at Mr. Kerik for not determining the nanny's immigration status before this week but said they had no evidence he had sought to mislead them. "It was Kerik's screw-up, it was that simple," the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SHOULD WORK WITH DPP, NOT CREATE CHAOS: DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: A leading lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) asked the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Sunday to work together with the DPP rather than create political chaos by insisting on having the president accept a premier selected by the KMT.

Ke Chien-min, the DPP whip at the Legislative Yuan, said the ROC Constitution does not give opposition parties the right to form a Cabinet regardless of the fact that the KMT and its political allies, the People First Party and the New Party, retained a slim majority in the Legislative Yuan after Saturday's elections.
The president has the mandate to rule the country, and this is not changed or diluted by any results of legislative elections, Ke maintained.

Ke urged the opposition parties to cooperate with the DPP for the well-being of the people rather than to keep boycotting the president's policies in the legislature to the detriment of the whole country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 13, or the second day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1784: Samuel Johnson, British writer and lexicographer known as "Dr. Johnson," dies at the age of 75. The leading literary figure in the second half of the 18th century, he wrote the "Dictionary of the English Language" and "Lives of the Poets."
1797: German poet and critic Heinrich Heine is born in Dusseldorf.
1897: Russian forces occupy Port Arthur on the Yellow Sea.
1904: The first electric train comes into service on London's Metropolitan Railway.
1916: Some 9,000 Austro-Hungarian troops are killed in an avalanche in the Alps.
1918: U.S. President Thomas Woodrow Wilson arrives in France, becoming the first American president to visit a European country.
1921: Britain, the United States, France and Japan sign the Washington Treaty, pledging to respect each others' claims over insular possessions in the Pacific.
1937: Japanese troops occupy Nanking. During the following two months, the aggressors rape and kill some 300,000 Chinese and lay waste to the city in what would become known as the "Rape of Nanking."
1944: A Japanese kamikaze pilot crashes his plane into the U.S. cruiser Nashville, killing 133 crew members.
1955: In the U.N Security Council, China vetoes the admission of Outer Mongolia to the United Nations.
1961: Anna Mary Robertson Moses, known as "Grandma Moses," an American painter noted for her colorful primitive-style paintings of rural scenes, dies in New York at the age of 101.
1963: The Junior Chamber of the Republic of China announces the list of winners of the ten "outstanding youth awards."
1968: The Hsin Hsin Bus Co. is established, becoming the first private bus company in Taipei City.
1972: On the last U.S. mission to the moon, Apollo 17 astronauts unveil a plaque on the lunar surface dedicated to peace.
1974: Malta, the former British crown colony which became an independent country in 1964, changes its form of government to that of a republic.
1976: A four-member Chinese judo team leaves Taipei for Spain to participate in the second world youth judo championships.
1978: The first council meeting of the Organization of African Freedom opens in Abidjan, Ivory Coast.
1982: An earthquake devastates Dhamar Province in Yemen, killing 3,000 people and injuring 2,000 others.
1988: South Africa signs an accord in Brazzaville granting independence to Namibia.
1989: The first Vietnamese refugees are repatriated from Hong Kong, escorted to an airplane at dawn by police in riot gear.
1991: A non-aggression agreement aimed at working toward negotiation of a permanent peace treaty is signed by North and South Korea.
1995: Wei Jingsheng, noted Chinese democracy advocate and a 1995 Nobel Peace Prize nominee, is imprisoned for 14 years for subversive acts.
1996: Ministers and officials from 128 countries, including those from the ROC, adopt a wide-ranging declaration at the end of the five-day World Trade Organization meeting in Singapore.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui reiterates that the "special state-to-state relationship" theory is the Republic of China's basic stance on relations with mainland China.
2000: The Executive Yuan approves a draft of rules governing the implementation of trial transport links scheduled to be established between Taiwan's outlying Kinmen and Matsu islands and mainland China beginning Jan. 1, 2001.
2001: Semiconductor designers from Taiwan meet in Beijing with mainland Chinese high-technology representatives to sound out the possibility of technological cooperation across the Taiwan Strait.
2001: Visiting Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique Banderira Melo de Menezes visits Taichung Port.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If in governing you depend upon laws and maintain order by enforcing those laws by punishments, you can also make the people keep away from wrongdoing, but they will lose the sense of shame for wrongdoing. If, on the other hand, in government you depend upon moral sentiment and maintain order by encouraging education and good manners, the people will have a sense of shame for wrongdoing and, moreover, will emulate what is good."

DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Russia Policy Under Review. The Bush administration is beginning a broad review of its Russia policy that could lead to a more confrontational approach toward Moscow over its treatment of neighboring countries and its own citizens, U.S. officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 319 SHOOTING INVESTIGATION GROUP MAKES HEADWAY IN CRACKING CASE

TEXT.P: Members of the special investigation group on the March 19 shooting of the president and vice president said Monday that they have made certain headway in cracking the case as several underground gunsmiths have admitted involvement.
Police recently rounded up more suspects after tracking a firearm remodeling and sales ring in Tainan with information provided by Ho Tun-ching, an underground gunsmith who was arrested in September.
The suspects, who collaborated with Ho in making and dealing illegal firearms, admitted that the two home-made bullets found at the scene of the March 19 assassination attempt were made by the ring.
The suspects also confessed that about 70 remodeled Beretta pistols from the ring's gunsmith have been sold on the black market around Taiwan.

More than 10 of these remodeled Berettas have been seized by the police, and the "machine marks" or "tool marks" of these weapons match the characteristics of the bullets found at the scene of the shooting, the special investigating task force members said.

Over the past eight months, the investigators said, they have followed up on more than 2,000 cases regarding violation of regulations on guns and ammunition. Of these cases, some 600 underground gunsmith operations were searched, and 22 involved ammunition that match the characteristics of the bullet found in President Chen Shui-bian's jacket.

U.S.-based forensic scientist Henry Lee, who had been invited by the government in early April to help in the investigation, said at the time that the best way to crack the case was to find the gun, which he said he believed was a remodeled gun, or the underground gunsmith where the weapon was made, or the gunman who fired the two shots.
He also suggested that an independent investigation committee be established and made up of members from across the political spectrum.
In his report released recently, Lee said that the president's injury to the abdomen was caused by a bullet and that the bullets retrieved were not used in standard handguns.

The most significant finding in his report was the special "tool marks" on a shell casing found at the scene. Lee suggested in the report that Taiwan law enforcement officers continue to aggressively search for and seize all illegal firearms in the country and "examine and compare all the guns."

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party has insinuated that the shooting was staged to win President Chen sympathy votes in the bitterly contested presidential election. Chen beat his rival, Lien Chan of the KMT, by aslim margin.

But with this extra, Mr Khaw indicated that people with huge medical bills are likely to pay half of what they do now: 30 per cent instead of 60 per cent or more.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTION GAINS ALLOW 'PAN-BLUE' TO CONTINUE ACTING AS A CHECK: WANG

TEXT.P: The significance of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" retaining its majority in the Legislative Yuan in Saturday's elections is that the alliance will be able to continue acting as a check on the administration, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Monday.

Wang, who concurrently serves as a vice chairman of the Kuomintang (KMT), said that only by following a "middle and rational path" can the "pan-blue alliance" monitor the administration and act as a check on it for the benefit of the country and people.

Wang also said he does not support the notion of the KMT putting forward a motion to request that President Chen Shui-bian respect the opposition's "right based on the spirit of the Constitution to form a new Cabinet" and pushing for a no-confidence vote against the premier in the new legislature if the request falls on deaf ears.

Wang said that a no-confidence vote against the premier would allow the president to dissolve the legislature and hold new elections, which he said would cause new tensions and further undermine the country's political stability.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party won 114 seats in the 225-member Legislative Yuan in Saturday's elections. The "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union won only 101 seats.
The elections result represents a strong mandate for the opposition alliance to continue its checks-and-balances role, Wang said.

Prior to Saturday's vote, KMT Chairman Lien Chan said that he would ask President Chen to respect the opposition's right to form a new Cabinet if the "pan-blue alliance" won a majority in the elections.

Lien also recommended P. K. Chiang, currently a vice chairman of the KMT and deputy legislative speaker and former chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development in the previous KMT-led government from 1996 to 2000, to serve as the new premier as part of the KMT's efforts to help improve Taiwan's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: SATURDAY'S LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS CLEANEST IN HISTORY: MINISTER

TEXT.P: The just-concluded elections for the sixth Legislative Yuan were the cleanest in Taiwan's history, Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan said Monday.

The previous legislative elections in December 2001 were rated by the British Financial Times as the cleanest in Taiwan's legislative elections history, but Chen said the latest elections were even cleaner.

As of the eve of Saturday's elections, Chen said prosecutors' offices around the nation had received 5,565 suspected vote-buying tip-offs and a total of 151 people involved in 39 of those cases had been indicted by Dec. 10. In comparison, 3,404 alleged vote-buying cases were reported ahead of the 2001 legislative elections.

Quoting the results of a pre-election public opinion poll conducted by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, Chen said 43.5 percent of the respondents said they felt an improvement in the election culture with the longstanding vote-buying in check and only 26.9 percent said they didn't find a decline in vote-buying.

Meanwhile, Chen said, the results of another survey conducted by a local news media on the eve of Saturday's elections showed that 41 percent of those interviewed said they felt a decrease in vote-buying deals, compared to 4 percent who said "no improvement" was seen.

Chen said the increase in the number of alleged vote-buying cases accepted by prosecution authorities in the run-up to the elections for the sixth legislature compared to the previous one could be attributed to a combination of factors, including the huge cash awards offered by the government for informers, an enhanced public awareness of the anti-vote-buying campaign and close cooperation among various law enforcement agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTIGATORS IDENTIFY MAKER OF BULLETS USED IN 319 SHOOTING

TEXT.P: Investigators on Monday confirmed that they have identified the maker of the two home-made bullets that were used in the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.

However, they admitted that there is still a long way to go before the case can be resolved, saying they are still trying to trace other essential clues such as the buyer of the bullets and the origin of the gun used in the shooting.

Hou Yu-ih, commissioner of the Criminal Investigation Bureau, who is a key member of a special task force probing the shooting, said the task force first discovered a batch of remodeled guns and bullets made by the suspect, identified by the surname as Tang, in southern Taiwan on August 15.
But no breakthrough was made until Oct. 12 when the task force raided Tang's residence on charges of drug dealing and found a bullet design sketch, Hou said.
The size and structure of the bullet shown in the design sketch closely resemble that of the two bullets found at the scene of the president's and vice president's shooting, Hou said.

After further analysis, Hou continued, investigators discovered that the bullets remodeled by Tang bore several special characteristics, including their machine marks and unique shell casing, that are not found in most remodeled bullets and they were a perfect match with those found on the two bullets.
In addition to making bullets, Tang is also good at remodeling guns, investigators said.
However, as the gun used in the March 19 shooting has yet to be found, there is no way to prove as to whether Tang is the maker of the gun as well, investigators said.
Based on Tang's testimony, the task force has tracked down eight buyers of the firearms remodeled by Tang but has ruled out their involvement in the shooting, they added.

DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Senate Republicans Are Ready for Filibuster Battle.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATION'S HOPE MORE IMPORTANT THAN 'PAN-BLUE' MERGER: PFP'S SOONG

TEXT.P: A merger of the parties within the "pan-blue alliance" is not the important issue now that the legislative elections are over; rather, bringing hope to the nation should be the alliance's aim, said People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong Monday.

PFP Chairman James Soong was responding to calls for a merger of the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT), and its two splinter parties, the PFP and the tiny New Party, while he was in Taipei County to thank his supporters.
Soong said that if anyone within the party has any interest in a merger, they can discuss the concept with the KMT, adding that he will not be involved in such talks.

On Sunday, Soong ruled out the possibility of a merger between the KMT and the PFP one day after the PFP lost 12 seats from the previous legislature to secure only 34 seats, saying that the KMT has closed the door on a possible merger by failing to honor its promises to the PFP.

Although Soong did not elaborate, PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung blamed the KMT for not restraining its party members and instead allowing them to run outside of the KMT ticket, and that the KMT had excluded PFP candidates from its vote-allocating scheme.

Soong said that the PFP is adamant about its opposition to a rapid Taiwan independence and will continue to work with the KMT on the matter as well as on other issues related to the general public to monitor the government and its handling of cross-strait issues.
He also said that the KMT is still burdened by its past, and that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has become corrupt after four years of rule, saying that only the PFP has a clean slate.

He also said that the PFP has always considered the big picture, although that has not always been appreciated, evidence that the presidential ticket of KMT Chairman Lien Chan and Soong did not win the March 20 presidential election.
He also said that he would not insist on heading the PFP, but he will "insist on being himself."

He said that the "pan-blue alliance" won a majority in the legislature because the public wants stability and to maintain the status quo. After the elections, the important thing is not about a possible merger, but whether the alliance can bring hope to the public, he added.
Meanwhile, KMT Vice Chairman and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou expressed the hope Monday that the "pan-blue alliance" can put aside their differences now and step up cooperation and coordination.

Ma said that without unity, there will be no victory, adding that it is "only an illusionary estimate" about reports that said the "pan-blue alliance" can command more than 120 seats in the 225-seat legislature if those legislators-elect who ran outside of the alliance's ticket join forces with the 114 seats garnered by the "pan-blue alliance."

Huang Teh-fu, KMT whip in the legislature, said that every political party is reviewing the outcome of the just-concluded elections, and it is not the best time to talk about a merger, although "everyone should move toward that direction with faith and patience."
But he expressed the hope that a merger can be completed by next February.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange ended lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 32.74 points to close at 5,878.89.
The bourse opened at 5901.45 and fluctuated between 5978.96 and 5818.28 during trading. A total of 4.09 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$85.35 billion (US$2.63 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up at 2.6 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.1 percent.

Six other major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down the most at 1.9 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.5 percent, textile stocks and machinery and electronics shares both at 0.2 percent and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 353 to 324, with 166 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREHISTORY MUSEUM ACQUIRES AUSTRONESIAN OUTRIGGER CANOE FROM PALAU
DOC.DATELINE: Taitung, eastern Taiwan, Dec. 13 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A new outrigger canoe, a traditional mode of transportation for Austronesian people across the Pacific Ocean, has been built in Palau and is now on display in Taiwan at the National Museum of Prehistory in Taitung.
A ceremony was held at the museum Monday to mark the building of the seven-seat outrigger canoe.

In the ceremony, museum officials practiced a traditional Puyuma worship ritual while four shipbuilders from Palau practiced their traditional craft. Betel nuts, azure stones and hemp knitting were offered in the rituals as sacrifices.
According to Tsuei Jui-ming, deputy director of the National Museum of Prehistory, the museum ordered a traditional outrigger canoe from Palau early this year to enrich the museum's collections.
The shipbuilders were appointed in person by Palau President Tommy Remengesau, he said.

Tsuei said that outrigger canoes have been used for thousands of years by the Austronesian people across the Pacific Ocean. A wooden structure that is fixed to the side of a boat is sturdy enough to allow its riders to ferry cross the seas even when the Pacific Ocean is stormy, Tsuei added.

Taiwan's indigenous people as a whole are believed to belong to the Austronesian-language group, which probably underwent the widest physical dispersion of a single language family prior to the European colonial expansion following Columbus, from the island of Madagascar off the east coast of Africa all the way to the tiny, isolated Easter Island (Rapa Nui) and extending to Taiwan, Vietnam, Northern Australia, New Zealand and most of the Melanesian and Polynesian islands.

Taiwan's indigenous people -- the native groups that predate all other ethnic groups in Taiwan -- could have originated either from the southern part of China or from a vast Austronesian-language region.

Taiwan's aborigines were considered the northernmost Austronesian people. Among them, the government currently divides them into 12 major mountain tribes and 10 Pingpu groups. While elements of the languages and culture of the 10 mountainous races have been maintained, most of the native languages of the Pingpu people have died out and no traces remain.
Among the mountainous aborigines, the Saisiat and the Atayal are believed to have migrated to Taiwan some 3,000 years ago.

Anthropologists have no idea what exactly happened, or when, to cause some of Taiwan's earliest natives to die out or disappear, but efforts to seek traces of the original natives' existence via anthropological, linguistic and historical studies have been continuing.
In a relatively newer theory developed in Australia and New Zealand in recent years, anthropologists believe that Taiwan is the place where the Austronesian-language people originated from.

Professor Geoffrey Chambers of Victoria University in Wellington believes that Maori people and other Polynesian peoples of the Pacific "island-hopped" from Taiwan through the Philippines and Indonesia to West Polynesia. From there, he says, they traveled to the islands of East Polynesia and then southwest, eventually settling in New Zealand.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO REBUILD TRUST WITH U.S. AFTER ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The government should try to rebuild mutual trust between Taipei and Washington in the wake of the misunderstandings caused by several controversial issues raised by President Chen Shui-bian during the run-up to last week's legislative elections, a domestic academic said Monday.

Lo Chih-cheng, executive director of the Institute for National Policy Research, made the remarks at a conference on post-elections relations between Taiwan, the United States and mainland China held in Taipei by the U.S.-based Formosa Foundation.

Lo pointed out that President Chen's proposal to hold a referendum in 2006 for a new constitution and his plan to change the names of Taiwan's overseas missions and state-run enterprises have caused misunderstandings with the United States and led Washington to lessen its support for Taiwan.
Under this circumstance, it is the government's top priority to rebuild mutual trust between the two sides, Lo said.

Although the ruling Democratic Progressive Party did not win a landslide victory in the legislative elections like it had expected, this should not be interpreted as a lack of support from the people for the establishment of the Taiwanese identity, Lo argued.

Meanwhile, Lo said the United States is expected to pressure for the passage of the budget for the NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) Taiwan-U.S. arms procurement. Its focus will be the Kuomintang (KMT) -led "pan-blue alliance" since it retained its majority in the Legislative Yuan, Lo added.

On the issue, opposition KMT legislative caucus whip Huang Teh-fu said the KMT will continue to block the arms procurement legislation proposed by the Executive Yuan unless it withdraws the budget bill and submits it again after the legislation is passed.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, dropping NT$0.025 to close at NT$32.450.
A total of US$623 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.497 and hit a low of NT$32.310.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIAN MERCHANT CHAMBER IN TAIWAN SEEKING BUSINESS ALLIANCES

TEXT.P: A group representing the Indian Merchant's Chamber (IMC) arrived in Taiwan Monday to expand procurements from Taiwan, woo Taiwan investors and look into the feasibility of creating business alliances.

The IMC, established in 1907, is one of the most influential trade organizations in India. It has more than 5,000 member companies, said Chao Yuen-chuan, secretary-general of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).
In addition to promoting trade exchanges, the IMC group is also in Taipei to invite Taiwan companies to take part in the 2005 Asia-Pacific Chamber of Commerce Conference -- the Indian Expo.

According to Chao, two-way trade between Taiwan and India has grown by leaps and bounds in recent years, with figures for the first 10 months of this year surging nearly 30 percent over the corresponding period of the previous year. Two-way trade is expected to top US$17 billion for 2004.
Business interactions between the two countries are expected to grow even closer in the years to come if more companies from the two sides forge strategic business alliances, Chao added.

Vijav Gokhale, chairman of the India-Taipei Association, said that many big-name Taiwan companies, particularly electronics and computer-makers, have made successful inroads into the huge Indian market in recent years.

Taiwan companies are promising to gain an even bigger foothold in the Indian market after many improvements have been made in streamlining cross-border trade paperwork and airlines and cargo transportation, Gokhale said.

Bhano Abhilashi, the Indian Export-Import Bank's representative in Singapore, said that India's gross domestic product (GDP) grew by 8.2 percent over the 2003-2004 period, while its export trade surged a whopping 20.4 percent.

It is expected that India's exports will further expand to post an annual growth of 24 percent for the 2004-2005 period, Abhilashi said, adding that the nation's economic growth will continue to flourish as India has forged a free trade agreement with ASEAN members Thailand and Singapore.
India is particularly promising in development of its energy, telecommunications, pharmaceutical, biotechnology, information technology and civil air industries, Abhilashi said.
Lee Chia-yi, a TAITRA researcher, said that Indian industrial and business sectors are also interested in exploring mainland China's huge market using Taiwan as a gateway.

The Times: New vaccine trials bring hope of cure for diabetes.
