In its twice-yearly Financial Stability Review, the BoE cautions that UK banks may be becoming more dependent on commercial property lending at a time when yields are falling and space remains empty.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WILL LOOK AHEAD TO 2007 LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will focus on victory in the next legislative elections and will only deal with cross-strait relations in a passive manner, a scholar said Monday.

Hsu Yung-ming, a researcher at the nation's highest research institute, Academia Sinica, made the remarks when he attended an international seminar sponsored by the Los Angeles-based Formosa Foundation in Taipei to discuss the new situation between Taiwan, the United States and China after Saturday's legislative elections.

Hsu noted that the DPP suffered a setback by failing to win a majority in the 225-seat legislature mainly because of two mistakes: overestimating the growth of supporters for the ruling DPP, and underestimating the impact a low voter turnout.

Now that the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and its ally, Taiwan Solidarity Union, managed to win only 101 seats compared with the 114 seats taken by the opposition "pan-blue alliance, " made up of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP), the outcome of the next legislative elections in 2007 will be crucial to the presidential election the following year. Predictably, the DPP will have much soul-searching to do this time and make every possible preparation for such issues as the drawing up of constituencies and other related issues, he said.
For this reason, the DPP will be more passive on cross-strait and international issues so as to concentrate on victory in the next elections, he said.

Meanwhile, Shelley Rigger, professor at Davidson College of North Carolina, said that it is too oversimplified to say that the outcome of Saturday's elections is tantamount to a denial of President Chen Shui-bian's pursuit for a bigger national identity.

Whether a series of issues raised by the DPP -- such as President Chen Shui-bian's demands that the opposition KMT change its party emblem within three months because it is too similar to the nation's emblem, and the advocacy of the name-change of its overseas missions to include "Taiwan" to highlight its national identity, and the writing of a new constitution -- had any impact on the elections outcome would require more study to make an accurate assessment, she said.

She also warned about the change of the electoral system from the present "multi-seat constituency," to "single seat, two votes" system in the next legislative elections, saying that the voice of the underprivileged groups are often ignored in the "winner takes all" system, which is not necessarily good for Taiwan society.

Daniel Lynch, a professor at the University of Southern California, said that now the DPP can't effectively persuade the international community that national identity is firmly established, and that the international community will now see that rapid Taiwan unification or independence is not the mainstream view of the Taiwan public.

The Formosa Foundation is a non-profit corporation formed in 2001 to promote greater understanding of the relationship between Taiwan, the United Sates and the People's Republic of China, and to preserve and enhance democracy, human rights and the freedom of the people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTRY ASSESSING IMPACT OF MAINLAND-ASEAN FTA ON TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has started assessing the impact on Taiwan of mainland China's economic outreach with Southeast Asian countries and is seeking to devise business strategies for Taiwan's industry, according to MOEA officials.

In a bid to tackle the new development after mainland China and the member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) inked a free trade agreement (FTA) in late November, the ministry has ordered the Industrial Development Bureau, the Bureau of Foreign Trade and the Industrial Development and Investment Center to evaluate the possible effects of the mainland-ASEAN FTA on Taiwan, the officials said.
Under the terms of the FTA, customs duties on some 7,000 items will be slashed to zero percent or 0.5 percent from 2010.

Given that Japan and South Korea are slated to begin FTA talks with ASEAN next year, while Australia, New Zealand and India have also shown keen interest in doing so, Taiwan is set to become an outcast once countries in the region succeed in forming the world's largest trade bloc with a population of three billion.

According to Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, Taiwan is left with the sole option to cope with the situation by using the multi-lateral trade mechanisms under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO) to break into the bloc.

Free trade unions in the European Union, ASEAN and America will also have to take that path to boost exchanges, she pointed out, suggesting that Taiwan companies minimize the impact through globalization and industrial upgrading.
Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long claimed that the mainland-ASEAN FTA will only have a limited impact on Taiwan in the initial stage on the grounds that product levels are different.
But Chen warned that Taiwan will face fiercer competition after the "ASEAN plus one" has been set up.

Saying that branching out is a global trend for enterprises seeking expansion, such as been done by U.S. and Japanese companies -- and as some Taiwan businesses have done in the mainland and countries in Southeast Asia -- he said that the mainland-ASEAN free trade pact will also benefit the many Taiwan investors in the two regions and that this is the reason behind the government's efforts to forge FTAs with other countries.
On the other side, Taiwan firms will have to step up the pace in industrial upgrading and engage in value-added creations to brace for coming challenges, he urged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ASKS LEGISLATURE TO PASS 33 PRIORITY BILLS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun on Monday urged the legislature to pass a list of 33 priority bills before the term of incumbent legislators ends in January.
Yu presented the list to Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng while paying a visit to Wang on the first day that the legislature reopened after last week's legislative elections.
Yu said he hopes the operation of the legislature will return to normal after the elections and that lawmakers will step up their pace in reviewing the bills.
Agreeing with Yu, Wang said it is time for the legislators to put behind the rancor seen during the elections and work together for the solidarity of the nation.

Wang said that the 2005 central government budget bill must be passed in this legislature, and the budget bill for the "10 major construction projects" will be submitted to a committee for review after an oral report by Yu.

On the budget bill for the NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement from the United States, Wang urged Yu to withdraw the budget bill as requested by the opposition and submit it again after the legislature passes legislation on the arms procurement.
In addition, Wang said the Legislative Yuan has the responsibility of passing laws governing the election method and execution of powers of the ad hoc National Assembly during this legislature.
Otherwise, there will not be enough time for the election of the National Assembly members and for the passage of a constitutional amendment package by May 26 next year, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CHAIRMAN WILL STAY ON FOR THE TIME BEING

TEXT.P: The chairman of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Monday that he has "reluctantly" decided to stay on as head of the party for the time being after the TSU made a poor showing in the latest legislative elections.
An emotional Huang Chu-wen offered to resign during a review meeting held by the party Monday to take responsibility for a performance that was "far below expectations," TSU officials said.

Since Huang was adamant in his desire ultimately to leave the post, the TSU central executive members decided that the matter will be further discussed Feb. 1, 2005, at which time a reshuffle of all central executive members will take place via an election, they said.
However, the TSU central executive members accepted the resignations of TSU Secretary-General Lin Jih-jia and his administration team, and said that their replacements will be announced next Monday.

The TSU, as an ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , had optimistically hoped that it could ride on the coattails of the DPP's victory in the March 20 presidential election and dramatically increase the number of its seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.
Instead of the gains that the party had hoped for, the TSU actually lost a seat from the number it held in the previous legislature.

Chen Chien-ming, a TSU party whip in the legislature who failed to win re-election, said that the party machine didn't function well this time, and someone has to take responsibility to show that the determination to make reforms is real.
Chen added that the party will still have to ask for the views of former President Lee Teng-hui, who serves as the spiritual leader of the TSU, after the disappointing results.
Chen also took a swipe at the DPP by saying that it did not do all it could to help the TSU.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG MUST COME UP WITH REFORM INITIATIVES TO WIN SPEAKERSHIP: PFP

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng must present visions for legislative reforms if he wants opposition People First Party (PFP) support in his bid to secure another speakership term, PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung said Monday.

Chang said Transparency International, a global non-government organization devoted to combating corruption, recently listed Taiwan's legislature, along with those of Argentina, Indonesia, South Korea and Ukraine, as the world's five most corrupt lawmaking bodies.
In his view, Chang said, both Wang, who has been speaker for six years, and Vice Legislative Yuan President P.K. Chiang, who has been in the post for three years, should be held responsible for this.

While seeking re-election as speaker of the newly elected legislature that will be inaugurated Feb. 1, 2005, Chang said, Wang should not just pay courtesy calls on those who won in Saturday's legislative elections.

"Wang, who has been re-elected as a legislator-at large, should instead come up with initiatives for upgrading legislative efficiency and quality," Chang said, adding that the legislature can improve its image by revising its internal operational rules.

Wang, a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) which won 79 of the 225 legislative seats up for grabs Saturday, will need the support of PFP lawmakers if he wants to win another speakership term.

Asked whether the PFP, which captured 34 seats in the just-concluded elections, covets the legislature's deputy speakership, Chang claimed that the party has no interest in winning either the speaker or deputy speaker posts.
"What we are concerned about at the moment is that Wang must unveil his legislative reform visions if he wants to secure PFP support for his speakership re-election bid," Chang stressed.
Chang would not comment on KMT Chairman Lien Chan's proposal that incumbent Legislative Yuan Vice President P.K. Chiang be named the next premier to form a new Cabinet.
"Our stance on the issue is that we will not express opinions on any specific candidate," Chang said.
He further said the three "pan-blue alliance" parties -- the KMT, the PFP and the New Party -- have a consensus that the new premier should be acceptable to a majority of legislators.

Lien said before Saturday's elections that if the "pan-blue alliance" wrests a majority in the new legislature, Chiang, a KMT vice chairman and a former chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, should be named the nation's new premier.

Lien's proposal has been rejected by President Chen Shui-bian, who pointed out that under the Constitution, the right to name a premier to form the Cabinet lies with the president, not the majority party in the Legislative Yuan.

According to the Constitution, the majority party in the legislature can only initiate a no-confidence vote against a premier named by the president. The president then has the power to dissolve the legislature to pave the way for new elections if he does not accept the result of the no-confidence vote.
Chang said it is the norm in most democratic countries that the president's nomination of a premier should be endorsed by the legislature.
The Constitution originally had a similar provision. However, it was deleted in a 1997 round of constitutional amendments made during former President Lee Teng-hui's tenure.
Chang said the PFP will work together with its "pan-blue alliance" allies in pushing for re-instatement of this provision.

"We'll also seek the support of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for this proposal because the re-instatement of this regulation would help contribute to domestic political stability, " Chang said.
Any constitutional amendment proposal requires the consent of three-fourths of the lawmakers. The DPP garnered 89 seats in Saturday's legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG HARBOR KEEPS GROWING IN OPERATION

TEXT.P: The operating volume of Kaohsiung Harbor grew considerably in the first 11 months of this year, with the loading and unloading volume of containers expanding the most at 10.24 percent over the same period of last year, according to statistics released Monday by the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau.
The statistics show that about 35,870 vessels entered or left the harbor over the past 11 months, with a total displacement of about 643 million tons.

A total of about 429 million tons of cargo was loaded and unloaded during the same period, representing a growth of 9.43 percent over the same period of last year, in addition to about 8,897,000 containers.

Kaohsiung's proportion of the country's total is 74.49 percent in terms of loading and unloading volume of containers, 68.05 percent in terms of loading and unloading volume of cargo, 48.81 percent in terms of the number of vessels entering and leaving, and 61.95 percent in terms of combined displacement of vessels entering and leaving.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP PRESSES GOVERNMENT TO SET TIMETABLE FOR NEW CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: The pro-independence Alliance to Campaign for Rectifying the Name of Taiwan demanded that the government put forth a timetable for changing the name of the country and drawing up a new constitution.

Alliance leader Peter Wang said the fact that President Chen Shui-bian has recently unveiled his plan to change the names of Republic of China's overseas missions and state-run enterprises to include the word "Taiwan" proves that the campaign promoted by the alliance is making progress.

Of a group of more than 60 "pan-green camp" candidates who joined a united front supporting the name-change during the run-up to last week's legislative elections, 37 were elected and are expected to promote the goal of changing the name of the country and drawing up a new constitution in the next legislature, Wang said.
According to the draft of a new constitution released by the alliance, the name of the country would be changed to "Republic of Taiwan" if anyone were to act on its demands.

Wang also argued that the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) failed to achieve its goal of gaining a majority in the legislature mainly because a lot of "pan-green" supporters did not go to the polls.
The fierce competition between the DPP and TSU in the elections also caused many "pan-green" candidates to lose their bids, he claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN GOVERNMENT TRAINING TOURISM PROFESSIONALS

TEXT.P: The Kinmen county government held a one-day seminar for personnel in the cross-Taiwan Strait tourist business Monday in an effort to upgrade the outlying island's services for mainland Chinese tourists.

A total of 236 people in tourism-related businesses such as hotels, restaurants, bus companies and souvenir shops attended the seminar to take courses on mainland policies and laws, the tourism regulations relating to mainland tourist groups entering Kinmen, as well as the laws on transportation between Kinmen and Fujian, according to county officials.
Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng addressed the opening ceremony of the seminar and said the tourism industry is the only sector from which Kinmen can benefit in terms of economic development.

Lee said that Kinmen is now allowed to take in 600 mainland tourists every day but claimed that if the current tourism and security services were further improved, the number of mainland visitors could be expanded to 6,000 per day.

Dozens of mainlanders, including members of a coal association in Fujian, landed on Kinmen Dec. 7 from Xiamen for sightseeing, becoming the first mainland tourists in decades to visit the frontline island fortress, located some 10 km west of Fujian.

Taiwan opened limited links between Kinmen and Xiamen, as well as between Matsu, another island off the Fujian coast controlled by Taiwan, and the mainland's Mawei port in January 2001 in the absence of full-scale direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait.
To facilitate bilateral exchanges, as well as to boost tourism on Kinmen and Matsu, up to 600 mainland people are allowed by Taiwan to enter the islands on a daily basis.

But Beijing allowed none of its subjects to make sightseeing trips until late September this year, when the Fujian authorities announced that they would allow 80 to 100 residents from the province each day to make tourism trips to Kinmen and Matsu.
Kinmen was officially discharged from its 40 years as a military preserve and began embracing tourism in 1993.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO FACE UP SQUARELY TO MAINLAND CHINA'S RISE

TEXT.P: Taiwan should squarely face up to the rise of mainland China as an economic power and acclerate industrial upgrading to deal with this new challenge, a noted U.S. political scientist said Monday.

Edward Friedman, Hawkins Chair professor of political science at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, made the call at an international seminar on possible new developments in relations across the Taiwan Strait and Taiwan-U.S. relations in the wake of Taiwan's Dec. 11 legislative elections, as well as Taiwan's economic prospects and Beijing's "one China" policy. The seminar was organized by the Los Angeles-based Formosa Foundation and held in Taipei.

With more and more Taiwan businessmen flocking to mainland China to set up footholds to penetrate its vast market and cash in on its cheap labor, Friedmen said Taiwan should not adopt ostracism and should instead face up to this reality squarely.

Friedman said Beijing has made it clear that any Taiwan businessman operating in mainland China who dares to take part in the pro-independence movement or the anti-China movement back in Taiwan will be punished. For instance, the mainland subsidiary of Taiwan's Chimei Group has been "penalized" because of its chairman's pro-independence remarks.

"Mainland China has made no secret of its attempts to win the loyalty of Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland, " Friedman said, adding that the mainland has spared no effort to use its economic clout to sway Taiwan's political development in its favor.

Now that the legislative elections have concluded, Friedmen said, Taiwan should speed up domestic reforms in various domains and take effective steps to upgrade its industries, as well as adopt a multi-racial cultural policy to boost domestic ethnic harmony and ensure political stability.

In his view, Friedmen said, Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties should stop their war of attrition that has plagued its legislature for the past more-than four years. Taiwan must rev up its economic vitality, Friedmen said, otherwise its industry will be hollowed out.

Friedmen also lamented that although Taiwan is an independent sovereign state, the mainland's rise as an economic power has made many countries afraid to recognize Taiwan's statehood. He further said it is unfair to blame Taiwan for provoking the mainland when Beijing is quickly expanding its defense budget and military arsenal.

Speaking on the same occasion, Jacques deLisle, a professor of law and a faculty member of the Center for East Asian Studies of the the University of Pennsylvania, said Taiwan should avoid becoming overly reliant on the mainland economically and should diversify its industries to maintain its competitive edge.

After the legislative elections, deLisle said, Taiwan should pay heed to three key problems -- whether the legislative procedures continue to slow down, whether the confrontation between its two political camps will continue to plague its legislature and whether the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can begin negotiations on the opening of direct air and shipping links.

Chang Jung-feng, vice president of the Chunghua Institution for Economic Research, a Taipei-based economic think tank, noted that President Chen Shui-bian said in the run-up to Saturday's legislative elections that he will do three things if his "pan-green camp" could wrest control of the new legislature -- improve cross-strait relations, push for sweeping domestic political reforms and write a new constitution that fits Taiwan's present reality.

Since the "pan-green camp" failed to win a majority, Chang said, Chen now can only focus on improving cross-strait relations. He reminded Chen that he should not sacrifice Taiwan's interests while seeking a breakthrough to the long deadlocked cross-strait ties.

The Formosa Foundation is a non-profit corporation formed in 2001 to promote greater understanding of the relationship between Taiwan, the United Sates and the People's Republic of China, and to preserve and enhance democracy, human rights and the freedom of the people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOO EARLY TO TALK ABOUT COALITION GOVERNMENT: DPP

TEXT.P: It is too early to talk about a coalition government, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) legislative whip said Monday.

Ker Chien-ming was responding to questions surrounding a proposal by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang, the People First Party and the New Party, that it should form a Cabinet after winning a majority in Saturday's legislative elections.
Ker noted that even PFP Chairman James Soong is opposed to such a proposal and that there is no need to ask the DPP about its views on the subject.

"Any scenario of any cooperation is possible, " Ker said, but it is too early to talk about the "coalition government" before Feb. 1, when the newly elected legislators will be sworn in and Premier Yu Shyi-kun's Cabinet will resign en masse according to practice.

He noted that the DPP will need some time for soul-searching after its setback in the legislative elections, adding that President Chen Shui-bian is in a position to make an overall consideration on such issues as the formation of the Cabinet, the party caucus, and the local city and magistrate elections scheduled for next year.
"The DPP has weathered a series of grueling tests before, " Ker said, adding that he has confidence in Chen's wisdom in handling the latest setback.
He also urged the KMT not to be overswept by joy in its victory in the just-concluded legislative elections. "It had better sober up," he added.

DPP Legislator Lee Chun-yi also said that KMT Chairman Lien Chan's request to form a Cabinet is "outrageous" and shows no respect for the constitutional procedure. He told Lien not to be so arrogant and said that Chen could not possibly agree to such a demand.

But Lee said he supports the idea of a "coalition government" to meet the aspirations of the new mandate after the elections, saying that it would also be possible to consider cooperating with the PFP.
Chen must consider the lineup of the new Cabinet before the inauguration of the newly elected legislators, he said.
Meanwhile, a KMT party whip in the legislature said that the party will respect the Constitution in that the president has the sole power to appoint a premier.

But Huang Teh-fu also said that the Taiwan people have expressed their views through the elections and that the KMT recommendation of economic expert P.K. Chiang, the vice legislative speaker and a KMT vice chairman, to serve as the premier, is based on this new mandate.
The KMT will be open to any possibility, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ENVOY TO BRITAIN TO BE SWORN IN TUESDAY

TEXT.P: New Republic of China Representative to Great Britain Lin Chun-yi will be sworn in Tuesday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday.

Lin, who was originally ROC ambassador to the Gambia, will fill the post left vacant by Tien Hung-mao, who resigned in July to assume political responsibility for an incident in which two staffers at the representative office in London mistakenly issued a passport and legal documents to the wife of a high-profile fugitive arms dealer involved in the Lafayette frigate scandal in March and May this year.

MOFA officials said several other ROC overseas mission chiefs, including Teng Chu-lin, new representative to Poland, Chou Shu-yeh, new representative to Brazil, Liu Jung-tsou, new representative to Bolivia and Shih Cheng-mao, new Consul-General in Colon, Panama, will also be sworn in at the same ceremony scheduled for Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN BLUE' LEGISLATIVE WIN EXPECTED TO BOOST CHINA CONCEPT SHARES

TEXT.P: The "pan blue alliance" majority in the new legislature is expected to dilute tension between Taiwan and mainland China and help provide leads for China concept shares over the short term, market analysts said Monday.

Market watchers said that the election results are proof that Taiwan's people are keen for peace and maintaining the country's status quo and that it also marks a setback for President Chen Shui-bian and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), but they also view the election outcome as a strong public demand for effective checks and balances of the executive branch.

The "pan blue alliance" of the Kuomintang, the People First Party and the New Party managed to retain a majority by grabbing 114 seats at the 225-member Legislative Yuan in Saturday's elections, outperforming the "pan green camp" of the ruling DPP and its ally Taiwan Solidarity Union which won only 101 seats.

As political disputes are likely to gradually fade with the president's call for conciliation and cooperation, they said, the domestic stock market will eventually return to performing on economic fundamentals.

They contended that transport and shipping company shares and stocks related to the mainland market will benefit in the wake of the legislative elections on wider pubic expectations that Taiwan and the mainland might reopen talks on setting up direct transport, trade and postal links across the Taiwan Strait at an earlier date.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange's weighted index closed at 5,878.89 points Monday, a drop of 32.74 points from last Friday's finish. Market turnover reached a moderate level of NT$85.351 billion (US$2.63 billion).

Despite the fall, the so-called China concept shares and shipping and transport companies stocks all picked up in the day's early trading session, analysts said, adding that the course of the new Taiwan dollar, corporate operations reports and the world economy will affect the domestic bourse more now that the heated election is over.
In the face of the new political developments, business and industry leaders called for unity to work for Taiwan's economy.
Political feuding over the past few years has dragged down the country's economy, allowing South Korea to outperform Taiwan, according to Douglas Hsu, chairman of the Far East Group.

Polaris Financial Group Chairman Pai Wen-cheng urged the government to deliberate on how to bolster foreign investor confidence in Taiwan and recruit high quality talent to sharpen the country's core competitiveness.

Stressing that the governing and opposition parties must try their best to compromise in order to secure Taiwan's economic and business interest, Pai said the country needs more hi-tech professionals and foreign capital. He suggested that the government quickly revise the relevant laws to allow qualified professionals and foreign investment into Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH KOREAN PROVINCIAL GOVERNOR VISITS TAIPEI COUNTY

TEXT.P: A South Korean provincial governor visited the Taipei county government headquarters Monday to promote economic and cultural exchanges and cooperation between the two sides.
Kim Tae-ho, governor of Gyeongsangnam Do, was warmly greeted by acting Taipei Magistrate Lin Shyi-yao upon his arrival at the county hall.

During the meeting, Lin said that Taipei County and Gyeongsangnam Do have many common characteristics, such as populations of more than 3 million, as well as promising industrial and commercial sectors.
Lin expressed hope that the two sides can further increase exchanges and cooperation in the economic, information technology and cultural fields for their mutual benefit.
Sharing Lin's views, Kim said his province and Taipei County can advance hand-in-hand toward globalization.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO STEP DOWN AS DPP CHAIRMAN FOR ELECTION SETBACK

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has expressed his intention to step down from his concurrent post as chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to take responsibility for the party's setback in Saturday's legislative elections, a DPP official said Monday.

Ker Chien-ming, DPP whip in the Legislative Yuan, made the remarks after he and other key campaign members for Saturday's legislative elections were asked by Chen to go to the Presidential Office for a one-hour meeting.

Also on hand were Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Yu Shyi-kun, National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang, DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung and Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, according to Ker.
Chen said he will announce his resignation from the chairmanship during a regular DPP central standing committee meeting Tuesday.
Although all participants urged the president to stay on to lead the party, Chen said he would take all the responsibility for the loss in Saturday's legislative elections.
Yu, Chang, Su and Hsieh said they should share the responsibility, but the president said he will "take sole responsibility," Ker said.

According to the DPP charter, if Chen steps down, the 35 Central Executive Committee members will recommend one among them to serve as the acting chairman, and a new chairman will then be elected through popular elections among its members.

Ker said that whether the president concurrently serves as party chairman is not important, adding that the president does not have to decide everything and that major policies can be handled by the coordination system between the party and the administration.
He said that the DPP was deemed a loser in the elections because it only managed to increase its legislative seats by two, far less than its pre-election target.

He urged the opposition Kuomintang and its ally, the People First Party, which together garnered 114 seats compared with the combined 101 seats of the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, not to be overwhelmed by its victory, saying that both camps need to work for the nation's future.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNTIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Pentagon weighs use of deception in a broad arena.
The Pentagon is engaged in bitter, high-level debate over how far it can and should go in managing or manipulating information to influence opinion abroad, senior Defense Department civilians and military officers say. Such missions, if approved, could take the deceptive techniques endorsed for use on the battlefield to confuse an adversary and adopt them for covert propaganda campaigns aimed at neutral and even allied nation. Critics of the p roposals say such deceptive missions could shatter the Pentagon's credibility, leaving the American public and a world audience skeptical of anything the Defense Department and military say.
Wall Street Journal: As math skills slip, U.S. schools seek answers from Asia Answers From Asia.
About five years ago, a statewide test in Massachusetts revealed that students' math skills deteriorated sharply as they went from fourth to sixth grade. Alarmed, the Massachusetts education commissioner suggested an unconventional fix: importing the math curriculum used in Singapore. Students in Singapore routinely score among the highest in international math tests. The hope was that American kids taught the Singaporean way would improve their math scores. The approach has been adopt ed in about 200 schools nationwide, from rural Oklahoma to the inner cities of New Jersey. Early indications suggest that many U.S. students taught with textbooks imported from Singapore do perform better in math. Some children who once found the subject frustrating say they now like it.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES US$50,000 TO HELP PHILIPPINES TYPHOON VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government donated US$50,000 to the Philippines Monday to help with its post-typhoon relief work.

ROC Representative to the Philippines Wu Hsin-hsing presented the check to Philippine Secretary of Social Welfare and Development Corazon Juliano-Soliman on behalf of the ROC government in a ceremony held at the Department of Social Welfare and Development office.
Four typhoons have swept eastern and southern parts of Luzon Island in the past two weeks, causing heavy casualties and property damage.

Juliano-Soliman said the Philippines is grateful for the ROC government's relief aid. The Philippine official also expressed gratitude for several private Taiwan groups' assistance in post-disaster relief. Among them are the Taiwan Chamber of Commerce in the Philippines, as well as the Philippine chapters of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation and the Buddha's Light International Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW OMBUDSMEN NOMINATION LIST TO BE REFERRED TO LEGISLATURE DEC. 20

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will refer a list of nominees for Control Yuan seats to the Legislative Yuan for approval before Dec. 20, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) legislative whip said Monday.

Ker Chien-ming said Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng has suggested that the new ombudsmen nomination list be sent to the legislature before Dec. 20 so that the legislature can arrange a schedule to screen it.
With only a month to go before the current legislative session comes to an end, Ker said, the legislature still has many critical bills pending, including the government's 2005 budget plan.
Ker said the DPP legislative caucus has yet to discuss with its opposition counterparts the timing for the legislature to exercise its power of screening the new ombudsmen nomination list.

According to the Additional Articles of the Constitution, nominations for the Control Yuan require the consent of the Legislative Yuan. The present legislature has to vote on the nominations before its term expires Jan. 31, 2005. The new Control Yuan members will assume office Feb. 1.
The Control Yuan is the nation's supreme watchdog body overseeing government operations.
In the run-up to Saturday's legislative elections, Chen said at a campaign rally that more than 50 percent of the nominees for the 29 Control Yuan seats will be non-DPP members.

After the DPP and its "pan-green camp" ally of the Taiwan Solidarity Union failed to reach its target of wresting control of the new legislature, it remains unclear whether Chen will uphold this promise.

Chen said he has attached great importance to the selection of Control Yuan members and that the ombudsmen recommendation screening team headed by Vice President Annette Lu has already furnished him with a list of qualified candidates. Chen said he is scheduled to refer a final list of candidates for the 27 Control Yuan seats, plus nominations for the Control Yuan presidency and vice presidency, to the Legislative Yuan in mid-December for approval.
Chen said the number of female ombudsmen will be more than double the present number. The present Control Yuan only has three female members.
Chen said the recommendation list includes hopefuls of different ethnic origin and political stripes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN SHANGHAI HOPING FOR NEW YEAR CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan businessmen in mainland China are very concerned about the possibility of exclusive charter flight services for the coming Chinese New Year holidays in the wake of Taiwan's hotly contested legislative elections.

Hsieh Lee-chun, an executive of the Taiwan Businessmen's Association in Shanghai, told CNA that he is looking forward to seeing the long-discussed charter flight services realized to carry mainland-based Taiwan businessmen home for the lunar new year holidays.
"The issue will be highly indicative of the state of cross-Taiwan Strait ties after Taiwan's legislative elections Saturday," he said.

The opposition "pan blue alliance" of the Kuomintang, the People First Party and the New Party retained its majority by seizing 114 seats in the 225-member Legislative Yuan. The "pan green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union won just 101 seats.

It is widely assumed that a "pan blue" majority in the new legislature will put the brakes on some policies being promoted by President Chen Shui-bian, such as putting forth a new constitution in 2006 or changing the name of the country's missions overseas by including the word "Taiwan" in their official titles.

Chang Wu-ueh, director of the Institute of China Studies at Tamkang University, said that the election results should be conducive to reducing tension between Taiwan and mainland China arising from Chen's pro-independence stance.

As the Taiwan people have displayed their mandate in the elections, the mainland authorities should know how to assess cross-strait ties pragmatically, he said, urging the opposition to play their role adequately in this regard.

Under the current circumstances, the question of whether or not there will be charter flights for Taiwan businessmen coming home to spend lunar new year holidays will be highly symbolic in gauging cross-strait relations and to helping rebuild two-way negotiation mechanisms, he pointed out.
Should the mainland side still refuse to reopen such practical talks with Taiwan, it will risk losing a good opportunity to improve bilateral ties, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIAN BUSINESS LEADER PITCHES TAIWAN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Although business has been flourishing between Taiwan and India, the flow of trade and investment between the two countries is below its potential, an Indian business leader told CNA Monday.

Dilip Dandeka, an India business leader who is heading a delegation of the India Merchants' Chamber to Taiwan to explore the market, said this can be seen by the small percentage of their exports to each other to their total exports in 2003.
For Taiwan, which exported US$7.7 billion-worth of goods to India, it was 3.9 percent, while for India, which exported US$5.32 billion-worth of goods to Taiwan, it was only 11.9 percent.

These figures do not reflect the fact that India is the world's fourth-largest economy in terms of purchasing power parity, and the second fastest-growing economy, said Dilip, who arrived in Taiwan Sunday on a trade-promotion trip.

Citing the ratings given by a foreign consultancy, Dilip said India is a good destination for foreign investment because of its strong economic fundamentals, such as a 6.5 percent growth in GDP in 2004-05, an inflation rate of 6.5 percent, a foreign exchange reserve of US$125 billion and a 24 percent growth in exports.
Dilip said India's GDP will equal that of the U.S.'s present GDP in 25 years, not to mention its 1 billion population and 200 million middle class, which constitute a vast market.

There are other strengths for India in attracting foreign investment, Dilip said, citing its well-educated population, which has the world's second-largest English-speaking population, as well as its high-skilled and low-cost workforce.
Last but not least, Dilip said, is the government's policy of encouraging foreign investment, with many sectors open to 100 percent foreign direct investment.
As a democracy, the ruling party in India is changing with the elections but the policy of deregulation and glasnost laid down in 1991 remains unchanged, Dilip said.
Dilip, who has already visited Taiwan twice before, pointed out infrastructure as a potential sector for Taiwan investment.
He said the Indian government envisions a total capacity addition of 113,000 megawatts by 2012, entailing an investment of more than US$115 billion in power generation, transmission and distribution.

Furthermore, the Indian government is focusing on expansion and modernization of the country's roads. Forty-eight new road projects worth US$12 billion are under construction. Development and upgrading of roads will require an investment of US$24 billion until 2008.

There is also potential for investment in the expansion and modernization of ports, which will require US$33 billion investment in the next 10 years and 100 percent foreign direct investment is permitted for operation and maintenance of ports.

The food processing industry will require investment of about US$28 billion, and the healthcare industry will require investment of US$23 billion by 2012, all of which offers great opportunities for foreign investment, Dilip said.

India, with an abundance of computer engineers, is good at software development, while Taiwan is the world's largest manufacturer of computers, Dilip said, adding that there are great prospects for the two countries to work together in this sector.
Noting that both Taiwan and India cherish democracy and market economy, Dilip said, this will facilitate their cooperation in business.

However, he went on, the lack of diplomatic ties between Taipei and New Delhi has posed some difficulties for business exchanges. For example, he said, he had to turn to Taipei's representative office in New Delhi for a visa to enter Taiwan, although he and his Indian Merchants' Chamber are based in Mumbai. Also, Taiwan refuses to issue multiple entry visas to Indian people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS TO LIVE WITH CONSEQUENCES OF ACTIONS: U.S. SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: Several scholars from the United States have offered mixed opinions on Taiwan's recent name-change campaign to include "Taiwan" in the names of its overseas missions and to write a new constitution, but they agree on the risks of such a drive and of deteriorating trust between Taiwan and the United States.

They expressed their views in an international seminar on possible new developments in relations across the Taiwan Strait and Taiwan-U.S. relations in the wake of Taiwan's Dec. 11 legislative elections. The seminar was sponsored by the Los Angeles-based Formosa Foundation and held in Taipei.

Edward Friedman, professor at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, said he believes Taiwan is a sovereign independent country and is free to make any decisions, although it may have to "live with the consequences."

Asked whether this will mean that the United States will not intervene if war is triggered by Taiwan's recent name-change drive and its promotion of a new constitution, Friedman said nobody knows how Washington will respond.
He pointed out, however, that the United States has not made any commitment to defend any countries, including its allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).

He also said that if the United States and other countries think that mainland China is a threat to peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region and is the one making the provocation, then it will be in the best interests of Taiwan, but if Taiwan is considered to be the provoker, it will not be in Taiwan's interest.

He said President Chen Shui-bian's recent name-change proposal was a political risk, which he said is normal with politicians, although in this particular case, Taiwan might have to pay "the ultimate price."

Shelley Rigger, a Brown associate professor at Davidson College in North Carolina, expressed the opinion of nothing ventured, nothing gained, adding that no action will have disastrous consequences, although action could also lead to the same consequences.

Rigger and two other scholars also said that the United States is angry because a proposed NT$610.8 billion special budget for military procurement from the United States was stalled in the Legislative Yuan, as well as the recent name-change drive and the promotion of a new constitution.

There is a "great deal of annoyance" in Washington, she said, adding that she has heard people say it is "incredible" that Taiwan hopes for protection from the United States but will not provide for its own defenses.
She said that the mood in Washington "is very critical" and that it is very irritated about the arms procurement project.

Many people in the United States question whether Taiwan has a plan to protect its own interests, because it does not want to buy the arms it originally asked for. There is also a perception in the Washington that Taiwan wants to stall its talks with mainland China, and that it will not make efforts to improve relations with the United States.
Ross H. Munro, director of Asian Studies, Center for Security Studies in Washington, D.C., and Richard Kagan, professor of Hamline University in Minnesota, expressed similar views.
Kagan said that if the arms procurement project does not pass the legislature, Taiwan's voice in the United States will be weakened.

Munro said that U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell's recent remarks that Taiwan is not a sovereign state highlight an unfortunate fact -- a deterioration of communication and trust between Washington and Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARSHALL ISLANDS PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President of the Marshall Islands Kessai Note will arrive in Taipei Tuesday for a five-day official visit, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
During the visit, Note will meet with President Chen Shui-bian to exchange views on the international situation and cooperation between the two countries, MOFA officials said.
Note will also meet with other government officials and visit various economic and cultural establishments around Taiwan before departing Dec. 18.
It will be Note's third visit to Taiwan since 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, ALASKA FORM TRADE COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: Taiwan formed a committee with Alaska Monday to promote trade and investment between the two sides, signing a contract for a coal deal.

The Taiwan Alaska Trade, Investment & Cooperation Committee was initiated by the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, with the association's chairman, M.H. Huang, as well as Minister without Portfolio Lin Yi-fu, as its co-chairmen along with Mike Barry, an Alaskan energy official.
Huang said Alaska, with its great deposits of oil and coal, can be an alternative energy sources for Taiwan. He said he sees great opportunities for the two sides to cooperate.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 14, or the third day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1783: William Pitt, known as "Pitt the Younger," is made British prime minister and chancellor of the exchequer at the age of just 24. He accomplished the Act of Union between Ireland and Britain but was unsuccessful in his efforts at achieving Catholic emancipation.
1808: James Madison is elected the fourth president of the United States. His presidency was marked by the War of 1812.
1858: The French and Spanish announce a blockade of the port of Taku near the Chinese city of Tientsin prior to an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing which saw the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1887: The first U.S. hospital for cancer patients is inaugurated in New York.
1902: Thomas Nast, an American political cartoonist who was born in Germany in 1840, dies at the age of 62. He was the first to depict the Democratic Party as a donkey and the Republican Party as an elephant.
1917: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson declares war on Austria.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing 2,400 men and destroying many aircraft and battleships.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat of power to Taipei.
1951: The Communist Chinese launch the "three antis campaign" -- anti-corruption, anti-extravagance, and anti-bureaucracy.
1971: An unmanned Soviet space capsule sends back radio and television signals from Mars.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center formally opens in Shanhua, Tainan County.
1974: A three-month exhibition of Chinese products is opened in Taipei by Economics Minister Y.S. Sun. The exhibition has 10 pavilions with 859 showrooms and 465 retail booths.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford delivers his "New Pacifism" speech in Hawaii.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo announces the ROC government's plan to build Asia's most modern farm villages under the first Six-Year Economic Development Plan beginning in 1976.
1975: Indonesian troops enter East Timor as civil war breaks out after the Portuguese, rulers of East Timor for three centuries, leave the colony.
1978: Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira forms a new Cabinet.
1982: Robbers make away with more than NT$14 million from an armored truck of the United World Chinese Commercial Bank in Taipei.
1984: The Legislative Yuan passes the Special Education Law after its third reading.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severing of diplomatic ties with the Republic of Nicaragua.
1986: The new Taipei City Zoo is inaugurated in the Taipei suburb of Mucha.
1988: A massive earthquake claims over 100,000 lives in Soviet Armenia.
1989: Lithuania abolishes the constitutional guarantee of Communist Party supremacy and legalizes the multiparty system.
1993: Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving ruler, dies.
1996: The space shuttle Columbia and its crew return safely to earth after ending the longest space shuttle flight ever at nearly 18 days.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew accepts the resignation of Cabinet member Peng Tso-kwei as chairman of the Council of Agriculture and appoints Ling Shiang-nung to fill the vacancy.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan appeals to the government of France for judicial cooperation between the two countries to help in the investigation of kickback allegations surrounding the ROC Navy's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates some 10 years earlier.
2001: A rehearsal for the formal commission of Taiwan's first F-16 fighter wing is held at Chiayi air force base in southern Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is indeed a pleasure to acquire knowledge and, as you go on acquiring, to put into practice what you have acquired. A greater pleasure still is when friends of congenial minds come from afar to seek you out because of your attainments."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. GLAD TO SEE SUCCESSFUL ELECTIONS IN TAIWAN: STATE DEPARTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 13 (CNA) (By Oliver LIn and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Monday that the United States was glad to see a successful legislative election in Taiwan, adding that he would not speculate on the political implications of the elections result.
"We're glad to see the strength and vitality of democracy in Taiwan, " Boucher said, basically reiterating the state department's response immediately after Saturday's elections.

Asked what President Chen Shui-bian will do and what the new legislature will on the defense bill or other issues, the spokesman said that "our positions on these policy issues are quite clear. But I really am not going to join you in speculating on what the various parties might do after this election."

"They had a successful election. That's a good thing. We're glad to see it. What they decide to do within their political system now on some of these issues is going to be decided in Taiwan," he added.

The rapid turnover of top-level managers and highly trained specialists since Sept. 11 is causing disorder within the FBI and undercutting its efforts to meet the mandate of Congress to dramatically expand its intelligence and count- er-terrorism capabilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'QUALITY IS EVERYTHING' FOR TAIWAN AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS: COA

TEXT.P: Quality is everything in terms of Taiwan's agricultural products being able to compete with those of other nations, Taiwan's top agricultural official said Tuesday.
Lee Chin-lung, chairman of the Council of Agriculture (COA), made the remarks while attending an award ceremony for the nation's premium dairy farms in Tainan County, southern Taiwan.
Lee promised dairy farmers that the COA will provide needed assistance to ensure the quality of domestically produced milk.
He also cited statistics to show that the impact on Taiwan of the island's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 2002 has not been as great as had originally been expected.

Taiwan had estimated that in the first year after WTO entry, agricultural losses would reach NT$24 billion (US$740.74 million) and the agricultural population would drop by 22,000. But in fact, agricultural losses only amounted to NT$1 billion, while the agricultural population actually increased by 3,000, Lee noted.

Lee stressed that quality is the most important factor in terms of Taiwan's agricultural products being able to compete internationally. He said that the rice competitions held in Taiwan have led to Taiwan rice exports to Japan after a 33-year hiatus.
Taiwan also holds tea competitions, and its oolong tea is the best in the world, Lee said.

The Washington Post: EPA's Leavitt Nominated To Replace Thompson.
Former Utah governor moves to HHS as White House seeks to put its Cabinet selection process back on track.
