Singapore and Malaysia have agreed to resume talks on a range of thorny outstanding bilateral issues.
The Lianhe Zaobao:Singapore and Malaysia make the progress in the negotiations.
Singapore Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong and Malaysian Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi signalled this small but significant shift in bilateral relations when they agreed yesterday to 'move forward' on issues which had stalled in discussions since October 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: FPJ in critical condition
Movie queen Susan Roces, ever the serene and God-fearing person that she is, said yesterday that she is prepared to accept God's will as her husband, movie king Fernando Poe, Jr., felled by a stroke Saturday night continues to be listed in critical condition in a Quezon City hospital.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Poe's condition worsens -- doctors, spokesman
MOVIE actor Fernando Poe Jr.'s condition has deteriorated, according to a bulletin his doctors issued on Monday. "He is still in a coma and has multiple organ system involvement. His blood pressure is being supported by medicines," neurologist Abdias Aquino said, reading from the only statement they released for the day.
The Philippine Star: FPJ placed on life support
Philippine movie icon Fernando Poe Jr.'s condition has deteriorated, prompting doctors to put him on life support following a massive stroke over the weekend, his spokesman said yesterday.
The Manila Times: Poe's condition worsens
THE movie actor Fer-nando Poe Jr.'s condition has deteriorated and only medicine and a life-support system keep the thump in his blood pressure.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO RESIGN EN MASSE AFTER PRESENT LEGISLATIVE SESSION ENDS: YU

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun reaffirmed Tuesday that the Cabinet will resign en masse at the conclusion of the present legislative session.

Yu told journalists after delivering a report at a legislative plenary session on the budget bill for the "10 major construction projects" that although the present Constitution doesn't require the Cabinet to resign en masse after legislative elections, his Cabinet will follow established practice by doing so.

With only about a month to go before the present legislative session ends, Yu said he hopes the legislature can give priority to passing 33 critical bills, including the central government's 2005 budget plan, the "10 major construction projects" budget bill and a special arms procurement statute to facilitate Taiwan's purchases of advanced defensive weapons from the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OFFICIALS CANCEL U.S. TRIP

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Deputy Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan announced Tuesday that a planned visit to the United States by himself and former Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen has been canceled.

Lee and Tsai were originally to leave for Washington, D.C. after the legislative elections. They had expected to meet U.S. Department of State officials and exchange views with members of major U.S. think tanks including the Brookings Institute on issues concerning changes in Taiwan's political landscape after the elections.
Lee said the trip was canceled because he needs to deal with some post-elections party affairs and Tsai is ill.
Lee said they will arrange a trip to the United States some other time.

Lee on Saturday offered to step down from the post of DPP deputy secretary-general over the DPP's failure to achieve its goal of winning 100 legislative seats in the elections and together with its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, gain a majority in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO MONITOR HOW NEW VANUATUAN CABINET HANDLES RELATIONS: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan will closely monitor how the new cabinet in Vanuatu handles its relations with Taiwan and will work to the last minute to secure its relations with the South Pacific island state, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.
MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said that after Vanuatu's parliament voted Prime Minister Serge Vohor out of office Saturday, a new cabinet headed by Ham Lini has been formed.

Lu said there are two possible developments. The first is that the nation will maintain formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan after "having thought it through" and realizing that this is in its best interests in terms of its long-term development. The second is that it will sever ties with Taiwan and accept the financial assistance that mainland China has promised if it does so. Beijing is willing to offer Vanuatu US$32 million, and more if it severs ties with Taiwan.
As Taiwan is unwilling to engage in "dollar diplomacy" with mainland China, it is possible that the new government in Vanuatu will tell the staff of the ROC embassy to leave the country, Lu said.
He stressed that the ministry will by no means give up efforts at this stage and that the ROC embassy staff will stay on to observe developments and "fight to the last minute."
Vohor and ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen signed a joint communique in Taipei Nov. 3 to establish diplomatic relations, making Vanuatu the ROC's 27th ally.
Beijing has continued to try to woo Vanuatu away from the ROC, and a cross-strait diplomatic tug-of-war is playing out in the South Pacific island state.

Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Kau Ying-mao said over the weekend that he is not optimistic about the development of ROC-Vanuatu relations in light of the pro-Beijing background of Prime Minister Lini.

Meanwhile, the ROC's relations with the Caribbean nation of Grenada have become another focal point following Grenadan Prime Minister Keith Mitchell's departure for mainland China for a visit last week.
Lu claimed that the Grenadan government has had contacts with both sides of the Taiwan Strait over the past year in the hopes of using the cross-strait rivalry to gain maximum assistance from Taiwan.

Although Grenada hopes to reap benefits from both sides, the ministry will never increase the amount of assistance because of the Beijing factor, Lu said, adding that the ministry will no longer engage in "dollar diplomacy."
The ministry has learned that Beijing told Mitchell that the assistance it will offer is several times more than that provided by Taiwan, although Mitchell didn't elaborate on the amount.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN RESIGNS AS DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday resigned from the position of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman due to the party's setback in last week's legislative elections.

Bowing before the party's Central Standing Committee to apologize for the failure, Chen said the DPP has stuck to its democratic and reforming ideals, persisted in the mainstream pursuit of Taiwanese identity, and is committed to building Taiwan into a normal, complete, progressive, beautiful and great country.
Chen expressed the hope that the ruling and opposition parties in Taiwan will engage in a fair competition and drop their confrontation for cooperation.

The DPP, which garnered 89 seats in the 225-member Legislative Yuan in the elections, had expected to win 100 seats and together with its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, gain a majority in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT WILL NOT TAKE OVER DPP LEADERSHIP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Tuesday that she has graciously declined becoming the acting chairwoman of the ruling Democratic Progress Party (DPP), adding that the top priority during her tenure of office is to help the president allow the citizens of Taiwan to have healthy bodies and minds.

Lu, who made the remarks while attending a meeting on the subject of a "Healthy Life Strategic Alliance, " said that she and some other high-ranking governmental and DPP officials were invited by President Chen Shui-bian to participate in a consultation held Monday to discuss his intention of resigning as DPP chairman.

Despite the fact that several of her senior colleagues would support her becoming the acting DPP chairwomen, Lu said that she declined their support because she will push for two important projects -- activities related to living a healthy life and the establishment of the Democratic Pacific Alliance.
"These will keep me very busy next year and, therefore, I dare not accept the post," Lu said.

Touching on issues regarding various elections held this year and those to be held in the future, including the presidential election in 2008, Lu said that the whole nation's resources will be used up by holding elections if the Legislative Yuan does nothing to reform electoral institutions.
Social resources are expended each time an election has been held and they also destroy human nature and values, the vice president said, adding that this is a price of democracy.
For her, Lu said that rulers should not just be passionate about elections, but remember that it is more important to govern the nation and to love the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 30.76 points to close at 5,909.65.
The bourse opened at 5,908.13 and fluctuated between 5,909.65 and 5,873.4 during trading. A total of 2.32 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$47.34 billion (US$1.45 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 1.2 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.9 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.7 percent and plastics and chemicals shares and banking and financial shares both at 0.3 percent.
Three other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 0.7 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 0.5 percent and cement stocks at 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 466 to 193, with 177 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: '10 MAJOR PROJECTS' TO CONTRIBUTE TO ECONOMIC GROWTH BY 0.6%: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday the government's plan to launch "10 new major construction projects" next year will contribute to the nation's overall annual economic growth by an estimated 0.6 percent.
Yu made the remarks while speaking at a legislative plenary session on a special budget plan for the "10 new major construction projects."

The premier told lawmakers that the Cabinet has appropriated NT$93.91 billion for a special budget for the "10 new major construction projects, " which will begin next year. The special budget will be raised by selling NT$15 billion worth of government stakes in state-controlled Taiwan Power Co. and floating NT$78.91 billion worth of state bonds.

Noting that Taiwan's 2005 economic growth is projected at 4.56 percent, Yu said, the "10 new construction projects will contribute at least 0.26 percent to the nation's economic growth. In addition, he went on, the projects will help boost private investments and thus result in a total of 0.6 percent contribution to next year's economic growth.

Moreover, Yu said, the new major construction projects will help increase the government's tax revenues by NT$70 billion to NT$150 billion in the next five years. As the government has worked out various complementary measures, Yu assured lawmakers that the projects will not "leave debts to posterity" as some critics have claimed.

In addition to quantitative economic effects, Yu said, the "10 new major construction projects" will also contribute to upgrading manpower resources and economic quality as well as creating cultural value, enrich the daily life of local people and inspire technological advances.

According to the Cabinet's special budget plan, NT$10 billion will be earmarked for the top-rate university development plan; NT$1.4 billion for construction of a world-class arts center; NT$2.8 billion for the "Mobile Taiwan" plan; NT$2.2 billion for the Taiwan EXPO plan; NT$1.9 billion for the Taiwan railway modernization plan; NT$9 billion for the new expressways construction plan; NT$13.7 billion for the Kaohsiung Harbor intercontinental container terminal construction plan; NT$48 billion for mass rapid transit systems construction in northern, central and southern Taiwan; NT$3.4 billion for new sewer systems construction; and NT$400 million for construction of new reservoirs.

The aim of the "Mobile Taiwan" project is to set up the basic infrastructure to combine cellular phone network service, IT computer platforms, and broadband Internet links, Kao Tien-tzu, head of telecommunication and information section at the advisory group, was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: North Korea denies regime gripped by divisions, dissent.
North Korea's leadership said Monday its control of the Stalinist regime remained as firm as a rock, angrily dismissing reports of political instability as a U.S.-Inspired smear campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December gained 30 points to close at 5,901, with 14,177 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January moved up 48 points to finish at 5,903, with 12,635 contracts traded, while March futures gained 23 points to finish at 5,876, with nine contracts traded.
June futures gained 46 points to finish at 5,865, with three contracts traded, while September futures moved up 70 points to close at 5,775, with 51 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,871 for December, 5,855 for January, 5,853 for March, 5,819 for June and 5,705 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

December TE futures moved up 1.65 points to close at 221.15, with 3,412 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained 2.9 points to finish at 221.5, with 3,787 contract transactions. March TE futures gained 4.1 points to close at 220.5, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

December TF futures gained 4.4 points to finish at 1,004.4, with 4,390 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved up 2.4 points to end at 996.8, with 4,457 contracts traded. June TF futures lost 0.6 points to finish at 994, with 13 contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for March and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO EXCUSE FOR DPP'S DEFEAT: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday there is no excuse for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) defeat in last week's legislative elections as he resigned from the position of DPP chairman to take responsibility.
Chen said the DPP must learn a lesson from the election outcome and reflect upon whether the party has became over-confident after a series of victories since the 2000 presidential election.
Chen said it certainly feels bad to be defeated, but the DPP must admit its defeat since it failed to attain the goal it set and failed to meet the expectations of its supporters.
Though the DPP managed to win 89 seats in the elections, up two seats compared with the previous polls in 2001, the figure was far from the target of 100 seats the party had expected to gain.
Chen said the DPP will not try to console itself after the setback but will conduct self-examination using the highest standard.

The president pointed out that the DPP set three goals during the party's 17th anniversary celebration last year, which included holding the first referendum in Taiwan's history, winning the 2004 presidential election, and gaining a majority control in the legislature.

Although the DPP succeeded in achieving the first two goals, it failed in the final one, Chen said, adding that he must apologize to all DPP members and supporters and take full responsibility for the failure.
However, he said the DPP will not be knocked out by a temporary setback but will review its policies, adjust its pace and make improvement.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, dropping NT$0.006 to close at NT$32.444.
A total of US$499 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$32.450 and fluctuated between NT$32.395 and NT$32.452.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEETING BETWEEN KMT, PFP, NEW PARTY HEADS BEING ARRANGED: KMT

TEXT.P: Chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Lien Chan hopes to meet with his counterparts -- James Soong of the People First Party (PFP) and Yok Mu-ming of the New Party -- this week to try to resolve possible misunderstandings and discuss the cooperation of the three parties of the "pan-blue alliance, " KMT officials said Tuesday.

The officials made the remarks amid reports that despite a call for the merger of the three parties after the "pan-blue alliance" gained more seats than expected in Saturday's legislative elections to maintain its majority, Lien and Soong had not spoken to each other since mid-November because of bickering over the allocation of more than NT$100 million in subsidies for ballots garnered by the "Lien-Soong" ticket in the March 20 presidential election.

Soong was also angry about KMT's vote-allocation scheme, which sidelined the PFP, in the just-concluded legislative elections. The KMT and all eight but one of the New Party candidates ran under the banner of the KMT, garnering 79 seats while the PFP slipped 12 seats to 34 seats from the previous elections. The New Party had one seat.
The officials said that the KMT and the PFP have been busy since the legislative elections, and that they are still arranging for a meeting of the three chairmen.
Meanwhile, Wang Jin-pyng, speaker of the Legislative Yuan and a KMT vice chairman, said that the KMT and the PFP are like brothers. Even if there is no merger, they should at least cooperate.

A PFP caucus whip said that cooperation between the KMT and the PFP has never stopped, but the atmosphere and conditions for a merger between the two are not yet ripe, and it is meaningless to talk about a merger now.

PFP Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung said that a merger should not be done for the sake of doing it, and it should not be done to expand a "certain party." When the opposition forces can bring the people hope and the atmosphere and the environment are ripe, then it will be time to talk about a merger.
He also said that the ill-gotten assets of the KMT should be discussed, adding that as a young party, the PFP has no reason to shoulder the burden.

Soong has said over the past two days that a merger of the parties within the "pan-blue alliance" is not an important issue now that the elections are over. The important thing is whether the alliance can bring hope to the nation.
Soong also said that he had no intention to be head of the PFP, nor was he interested in serving as the second fiddle in the KMT, adding that he would only "be himself."

DOC.HEADLINE: YULON MOTOR TO FORGE COOPERATIVE TIES WITH GENERAL MOTORS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Yulon Motor Co. and General Motors Corporation (GM) of the United States are expected to sign a memorandum Wednesday to forge cooperative relations between the two companies, according to a statement released Tuesday by Yulon Motor.
The statement said that the expected ties are one of Yulon Motor's efforts to form contacts with various brand name companies for original equipment manufacture to enhance its output capability.
It is reported that under the new relationship, Yulon Motor will manufacture many models of vehicles with brand names belonging to GM, including Buick.
This will be Yulon Motor's largest cooperation project since it forged ties with Japan's Nissan Motor in 1957, reports said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS WHIP TO SERVE AS ACTING PARTY CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Ker Chien-ming, legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , was recommended to serve as acting DPP chairman after President Chen Shui-bian stepped down from his concurrent post as party chairman Tuesday.

President Chen bowed deeply during a regular DPP Central Standing Committee meeting to apologize to all party officials and supporters over the less-than-expected performance of the party in Saturday's legislative elections and said that he would resign as party chairman to take responsibility for the setback.
The DPP Central Standing Committee then recommended Ker to serve as the acting chairman.

According to the DPP charter, when the chairmanship is vacated, the Central Standing Committee will recommend a pro tem chairman, and the acting chairman's main task will be to preside over the election of a new chairman through a popular vote among party members.
Ker stressed that the post is not a glorious one, but a responsibility, adding that the time he will be in the position will be rather short, and his mission should be simple and clear.

He noted that his main work will include the maintenance of the normal functioning of party affairs, the preparation for the election of the party chairman through popular vote among party members in the shortest time, and the completion of the tasks assigned by the president.

DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said that the DPP Central Standing Committee members and all local DPP chiefs had hoped that the president would stay on to lead the party, but the president said his resignation is not to shirk responsibility, but to shoulder greater responsibility for Taiwan.
The president said that his departure will be to create a "broad-based" presidency to brace for a minority government in the next three years.
He wants to be a coordinator, which he said is more important than being the chairman of the ruling party.
The president also stressed that the DPP did not lose, but he himself lost in the elections, and he alone must take the responsibility.

The DPP, which garnered 89 seats in the 225-member Legislative Yuan in the just concluded elections, had expected to win over 100 seats and together with its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, gain a majority in the legislature. The TSU garnered 12 seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC CALLS FOR GOVERNMENT ASSISTANCE FOR PETROCHEMICAL PARK PLAN

TEXT.P: A plan by the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) to build a petrochemical industrial park in central Yunlin County has gained a warm response from the domestic industry, prompting a CPC executive to call for government assistance for the investment project.
CPC General Manager Chen Pao-lian issued the call earlier this week after having intensively and repeatedly explained the investment project to mid- and downstream businesses in the industry.
According to Chen, the major investment plan, valued at more than NT$300 billion (US$9.1 billion) , will be one of the biggest investment projects that the state-run CPC has launched in recent years.
The plan represents a worthy investment opportunity and many companies have responded positively to the idea, he said, urging the government to give its full support to the plan.

As an upstream supplier of crude materials to industry, the CPC is keen on creating an industrial park with the participation of mid- and downstream companies, he said, adding that it would also help breathe new life into the domestic petrochemical industry, as well as boosting the country's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAD'S RESIGNATION MUST NOT OBSCURE PARTY'S SHOWING IN POLLS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's resignation as chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should not obscure the fact that the party's performance in last week's legislative elections was "its best ever, " DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday.
Chen resigned from the party chairmanship to take responsibility for the party's failure to win a majority in the Legislative Yuan.
Chang offered Saturday to step down from the post of secretary-general over the DPP's setback.
However, Chang noted that the party garnered the largest number of legislative seats and the highest vote share in the elections.

He admitted that the DPP's mismanaged voter allocation strategy was responsible for the defeat of a number of incumbent DPP legislators who enjoy a high support rating in opinion polls, saying the party will conduct a thorough review of the error.
Meanwhile, many DPP politicians thought that there is no hurry for the party to hold a direct election for the position of party chairman after Chen's resignation.

DPP Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung said the party's legislative caucus leader, Ker Chien-ming, should act as party chairman until the government has completed a Cabinet reshuffle, which will take place at the same time the new legislators are sworn in Feb. 1.

Agreeing with Shen, Lin Yu-sheng, another DPP legislator, said it makes no difference as to whether or not there is an election for the DPP chairmanship, nor does it make any difference who is chairman, because, he claimed, the party is "only a machine for elections."

DOC.HEADLINE: MND TO EXPAND RECRUITMENT OF MILITARY VOLUNTEERS NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Tuesday it will greatly expand recruitment of military volunteers from 2005 with the aim of reversing the present conscript-volunteer ratio of 60:40 by 2008.
Speaking at a regular news conference, Wu Kuo-sheng, an MND division chief in charge of manpower planning, said the MND plans to recruit a total of 45,000 volunteer soldiers between 2005 and 2008.
In 2005 alone, Wu said, the MND expects to recruit 6,561 volunteer soldiers, both male and female.

Volunteers can apply via two channels, Wu said. Senior high school or vocational school graduates aged under 25 who have been enlisted for mandatory military services for one month can take part in qualification tests. Meanwhile, senior high school or vocational school graduates who have completed mandatory military service in three years and are aged under 26 can also apply to take qualification tests.
In connection with the increased recruitment of volunteer soldiers, Wu said, the MND will phase out recruitment of non-commissioned officers from next year.

Hereafter, Wu said, all non-commissioned officers will be promoted from the ranks of volunteers. All privates who have joined the military for one-and-a-half years can apply to take tests to become volunteer non-commissioned officers.

In the initial stage, salaries for volunteers will still fall short of the level seen in the business sector. Basic monthly pay for privates will range between NT$27,105 and NT$29,870 depending on rank. They can also get additional pay in terms of the special types of work and service areas. Those who work aboard submarines can get a maximum additional pay of NT$12,000 per month.

Volunteers who have served for more than three years can receive a retirement pension of at least NT$130,000. If they serve as non-commissioned officers and remain in the military for 20 years, they will be entitled to receive a monthly pension for the rest of their lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET WILL OPEN FEB. 14 AFTER LUNAR NEW YEAR

TEXT.P: The stock market is slated to close Feb. 3 prior to the lunar new year holidays and to reopen Feb. 14 after the holiday season, the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) announced Tuesday.
Chinese New Year this year falls on Feb. 9. The annual holiday season for the Chinese people around the world will kick off a day earlier and run through Feb. 11.
As the first two days of each year are also national holidays, the bourse will open Jan. 3 for the first time in 2005, TAIEX officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAND JUSTICES TO RULE ON 'TRUTH COMMISSION' DISPUTE WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: The Council of Grand Justices is set to hand down Wednesday its ruling on a constitutional dispute over the "truth investigation commission" and on whether to suspend the operations of the commission, according to a high-ranking official.
Grand Justice Lin Yung-mou said the council has reached a consensus on the two cases but still needs some more discussion to finalize the wording of its interpretation, set to be issued at 5 p.m.
He declined to disclose as to whether the council considers the statute governing the formation of the commission constitutional or unconstitutional.
The commission, established Oct. 4 according to the statute, is tasked with probing the March 19 presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party pushed through the statute Aug. 24 and the legislature upheld the statute in a second vote held Sept. 14, following the Executive Yuan's request that the bill be reconsidered.

Arguing that the statute is unconstitutional because it violates the constitutional powers of other government agencies, a group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party and Taiwan Solidarity Union legislators requested a constitutional interpretation from the Council of Grand Justices and asked the council to issue a temporary injunction to suspend the operations of the commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Google is adding major libraries to its database.
Google, the operator of the world's most popular Internet search service, plans to announce an agreement today with some of the nation's leading research libraries and Oxford University to begin converting their holdings into digital files that would be freely searchable over the Web. It may be only a step on a long road toward the long-predicted global virtual library. Collaboration of Google and research institutions that also include Harvard, the University of Michigan, Stanford and the New York Public Library is a major stride in an ambitious Internet effort by various parties to expandt its current value.
Wall Street Journal: After 18-month battle, Oracle finally wins over PeopleSoft.
Larry Ellison, chief executive of Oracle Corp., a won a measure of vindication yesterday, when rival PeopleSoft Inc. agreed to be acquired for US$10.3 billion, capitulating after 18 months of resistance. To seal the deal, Ellison prevailed over the U.S. government, which sued to block the merger on antitrust grounds. And he defied skeptics who warned that a hostile software takeover couldn't work because the target company's technical and management talent would walk out the door. Once it is finalized, the PeopleSoft acquisition will radically reshape the market for software that companies use to run their financial, human-resources and other business functions, leaving just two big suppliers -- Oracle and Germany's SAP AG. More broadly, the deal creates a four-way battle among tech giants Oracle, SAP, Microsoft Corp. and International Business Machines Corp., each of which wants to offer corporations a broad menu of software and reduce their customers' reliance on other vendors.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO REIN IN KINMEN FOODSTUFF QUALITY

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation urged the government Tuesday to allow the frontline island of Kinmen to import certain daily necessities from mainland China under the World Trade Organization (WTO) framework to facilitate quality control of foodstuffs sold there.

Acting on a request from the Control Yuan, the nation's supreme watchdog body, the foundation purchased three categories of food items at major marketplaces and sightseeing spots on Kinmen in late November for testing, including 14 fresh fish, poultry, pork and beef items, 16 kinds of fresh fruit, vegetables and tea, as well as three brands of rice wine.

Among the fresh vegetables and tea subject to testing, the foundation said, residue of the banned insecticide alphacypermethrin was found in celery, and residue of dicofol, a banned chemical that kills mites, were found in green tea samples. The packagings of the two substandard items did not identify the country of origin.
All the remaining items tested met standards set by the health authorities, the foundation said.

Following the opening of Kinmen -- which lies closer to mainland China's Fujian Province than to Taiwan -- to the direct "mini three links" with Fujian, many mainland foodstuffs have made inroads into the Taiwan-held defense outposts, either legally or clandestinely.

Consumers' Foundation Secretary-General Huang Yi-teng said that some dried foodstuffs, including mushrooms, sold in Kinmen have been found to contain excessive amounts of heavy metals and preservatives.

Huang suggested that the government further liberalize Kinmen-Fujian trade under the WTO framework. Both Taiwan and mainland China are WTO members. By so doing, Huang said, the government can establish a comprehensive foodstuff screening system to ensure food quality and protect public health.

Several Control Yuan members are scheduled to meet Wednesday with officials from the Council of Agriculture, the Coast Guard Administration, the Ministry of the Interior, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Department of Health, the Mainland Affairs Council and the Kinmen county government, to discuss the cross-strait "mini three links" issues, including contraband goods smuggled into the Kinmen area from the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA UNIT EXPANDS OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: A unit under the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) has been given a new name and will begin offering more comprehensive information and services on international trade, a TAITRA spokesman said Tuesday.

The Trade Information Services -- now renamed the "International Trade Information Center" -- will from Wednesday be able to provide across the board services based on a more complex databank, including newly added export and import statistics, trade opportunities around the world, U.S. shipping customs tallies, market analysis and studies and trade rules and regulations of countries in different continents, the official said.

The center plans to launch a special collection of Taiwan products in the near future to help promote locally made products in the global market, in addition to its existing publications such as Catalogue Collection and Doing Business with Taiwan, he said.
TAITRA, formerly titled the China External Trade Development Council, is Taiwan's leading non-profit trade promoter. It was set up in 1970 to help boost international trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WILLING TO HELP PANAMA WIDEN PANAMA CANAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that the Republic of China is willing to help Panama widen the Panama Canal.

Receiving the credentials presented by new Panamanian Ambassador to the ROC Julio Mock at the Presidential Office, Chen told the Panamanian envoy that his government is willing to help Panama accomplish the construction project, which is one of President Martin Torrijos' campaign promises.

Chen also expressed his satisfaction with the implementation of the ROC-Panama free trade agreement that was put into effect at the beginning of this year, saying that two-way trade amounted to US$140 million in the first half of this year, equal to the whole of the last year and an increase of 164 percent year-on-year.
It is estimated that Panama's exports to the ROC this year will increase to US$25 million, four times the previous year's level, he added.
Chen also asked Mock to convey his invitation to Torrijos to visit Taiwan.
On hand at the ceremony were Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen and James Huang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUTUAL-TRUST MECHANISM DEPENDS ON BEIJING'S RESPONSE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's idea of a military mutual-trust mechanism with mainland China is no more than pie in the sky unless Beijing responds to it positively, a defense official said Tuesday.

Lt. Gen. Hu Cheng-pu, the administrative vice defense minister, said at a news conference called to unveil the 2004 Defense White Paper that the defense ministry has set up three panels to work on the mechanism, which includes norms for military conduct across the Taiwan Strait and a declaration from Taiwan and mainland China the end of hostility between them.
The results of their work will be presented to the president by January next year and will be translated into the country's policy and made public after being approved by the president, Hu said.
However, he admitted that the whole thing will just be a waste of time unless Beijing responds positively.
As usual, the 2004 Defense White Paper stresses the military threat posed by Beijing to Taiwan, and the necessity for Taiwan to improve its defense capability.
In the same breath, the paper echoes the president's call for peace with the mainland.
In the paper's preface, Chen said Taiwan should be the defender of security, rather than a dependant on security.

Branding the mainland as the biggest threat to Taiwan's security, Chen encourages the armed forces to improve their battle capability by making good use of knowledge and turning knowledge into real power.

He also made a case for his call for a military mutual-trust mechanism with the mainland, including the renouncement of weapons of mass destruction, the laying down of a military buffer across the strait and a set of norms for military conduct across the strait.
Defense Minister Lee Jye said in another preface to the paper that security of the country lies in its strength to defend itelf rather than the mercy of its enemy.
"The task of preserving peace is all the more difficult when anti-war becomes an universal trend," he said.
Lee added that no investment is more worthwhile than the efforts put in to strengthen the defense capability.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND ISSUES NEW DEFENSE WHITE PAPER

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) issued its biennial defense report Tuesday outlining Taiwan's military buildup plans and analyzing mainland China's military threat and the possibility of a mainland attack on the island.

In addition to introducing Taiwan's standing forces, including missile defense and electronic warfare forces, the 298-page defense white paper also introduces for the first time the nation's four types of reservist units -- coastal defense, urban and rural defense, critical places defense and extra reservists mobilization.

Military spokesman Navy Capt. Liu Chih-chien said the MND has regularly issued a defense white paper once every two years since 1992 in line with the nation's defense law to enhance military transparency.

Speaking on the same occasion, Vice Defense Minister Lt. Gen. Hu Chen-pu said both mainland China and Taiwan are changing their strategies for a possible war across the Taiwan Strait that separates them.

"It is not impossible that China will come directly across the sea to attack, but the possibility is low, " Hu said, adding that the mainland is more likely to try and paralyze Taiwan and after paralyzing the island, mount a blitzkrieg-style attack.
Hu said the mainland could use electronic warfare to shut down Taiwan's communications systems before launching missile strikes or starting a naval blockade.

As a result, Hu said, Taiwan's annual round of war games next year will take anti-terrorism as a major theme. The Han Kuang series of exercises used to include amphibious landings and attacks on approaching vessels.

Hu said next year's drills will focus on anti-terrorism, including fending off cyber warfare. "The computerized war games of the Han Kuang series of exercises will be aim at drills to suppress terrorist attacks at the earliest possible time," Hu explained.

The newly published defense report also says the mainland's rapid arms build-up will cause an imbalance of power in the Taiwan Strait by 2008 and increase the likelihood of war if Taiwan fails to beef up its defenses quickly.
By 2006, the report says, the military advantage in the Taiwan Strait will tilt in favor of the mainland.

"If the situation continues to deteriorate, there will be an imbalance of military power between the two sides, which will be extremely unfavorable for our national security, " the report says, adding: "The imbalance of military power will be conducive for communist China to resolve the 'Taiwan issue' through military means."

The defense report further says the mainland's 2.23 million-strong army would most likely launch a surprise attack, such as invading offshore islands, firing missiles or imposing a sea blockade, and seek to paralyze government and military command.
The mainland has deployed 610 ballistic missiles and can mobilize 250,000 ground troops, 1,000 fighter aircraft and 730 warships against the island, according to the report.

Although the military denied the report is part of its efforts to drum up support for the government's plan to purchase NT$610.8 billion-worth of advanced defense weapons from the United States, the MND made it clear that time is not on Taiwan's side.

The opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan has blocked the deal for six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-electric submarines and 12 P-3C Orion submarine-hunting aircraft, saying they are overpriced. The deal is expected to be stalled until the new legislature, elected last weekend, takes office in February.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARSHALL ISLANDS PRESIDENT MAKES OFFICIAL VISIT

TEXT.P: President Kessai Note of the Marshall Islands arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a five-day visit, according to aspokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
Note will call on President Chen Shui-bian and meet other high-ranking government officials, as well as visiting cultural and economic establishments, the spokesman said.
This is Note's third trip to Taiwan following visits in 2002 and in May this year. He is accompanied by his wife.
The island nation in the South Pacific set up diplomatic ties with Taiwan in 1998. Taiwan now maintains formal diplomatic relations with 27 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMED FORCES LIST ANTI-TERRORISM OPERATION AS PART OF ANNUAL DRILL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has made anti-terrorism operations a part of the armed forces' 2005 Han Kuan war games, Vice Defense Minister Lt. Gen. Hu Cheng-pu said Tuesday.

In a news conference called to unveil the ministry's 2004 Defense White Paper, Hu said Beijing may choose to launch a terrorist attack against Taiwan instead of an all-out war, with the aim of paralyzing the island's military command chain or administrative system with the least amount of force.

Noting that illegal mainland Chinese migrant workers are often nabbed by police in Taiwan, Hu said it is only reasonable to gear up for a fight against terrorists who could be working for the mainland in Taiwan.
The anti-amphibious raid drill that has featured past war exercises will be preceded by an anti-terrorism operation next year to prepare the armed forces for war within the country, Hu went on.

Regional armed forces commanders have been asked to prioritize strategic targets in their regions and to work out plans to suppress terrorist attacks against these targets as soon as possible, Hu said.
However, the general said Taiwan will not launch a counterattack against the mainland even if Beijing is found to have been behind terrorist attacks against Taiwan.
He said Taiwan will not resort to counterattack unless Beijing conducts the first strike, and only the defense minister has the power to order such a counterattack.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SEEKING TO BECOME HEALTHY CITY: MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that the municipal team he leads is seeking to make Taipei a healthy city, which will be good for living, productivity and sustainable development.

Ma made the remarks during a meeting with Dr. Trevor Hancock from Canada, a keen promotor of healthy cities/communities. The meeting was a warm-up to the first Taipei international seminar on healthy cities that will run through Thursday.

Stressing that he has always tried hard to create a comfortable living environment for Taipei's citizens since assuming office, Ma said that his efforts are evident in that the Taipei city government has built many sports centers and swimming pools, as well as organizing numerous sporting activities, in addition to improving the city's traffic system and imposing various environmentally friendly measures.

According to Hancock, a healthy city must be built upon sound foundations on the environmental, economic and social fronts. The private sector should cooperate closely with the government to achieve that goal by making efforts from the ground up, he said.

Scores of experts and scholars from home and abroad will exchange views and share experience in the first international healthy city seminar ever sponsored by Taipei. The mayor will sign a declaration during the event to pledge to make Taipei a vigorous and healthy city.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP RULES OUT FORMING COALITION WITH DPP

TEXT.P: The People First Party (PFP) will neither form a coalition with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , nor will it file a candidate as a running mate for a DPP candidate in the race for the presidency of the Legislative Yuan, PFP Chairman James Soong said Tuesday.
Soong said his party is not against current Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng's attempt to run for re-election, but Wang should win his party's support with a new vision for the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH TARGET FOR NEXT YEAR SET AT 5 PERCENT: CEPD

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) has set a target for Taiwan's economic growth for next year at 5 percent, CEPD Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng said Tuesday.
Hu based his estimation on the grounds that Taiwan's economic fundamentals remain good and its political situation is expected to return to normal after the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

In addition, he added, the ratio of the government's financial deficit to the gross domestic product will decrease gradually given that the government tax revenues will surpass the budget for this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FITCH RATINGS KEEPS TAIWAN'S RATING UNCHANGED

TEXT.P: The international rating agency Fitch Ratings kept Taiwan's rating unchanged Tuesday, with an A+ for its long-term foreign currency, an AA for its domestic currency, and a stable outlook for its long-term prospects.

A spokesman for the Ministry of Economic Affairs welcomed the news, calling it an affirmation of the sound fundamentals of Taiwan's economy, which will further improve now that the fierce legislative elections are over.
The ratings are based on a country's foreign debts, investment and finance.

The Fitch Ratings said the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) failure to win a majority in the just-concluded legislative elections will slow down President Chen Shui-bian's movement toward revising the Constitution, which will please Beijing and therefore ease the strain between the two sides.

However, the agency does not think Chen will give up his attempts to rewrite the Constitution because of his party's worse-than-expected performance in the legislative elections. Rather, the agency predicted, Chen will postpone his reforms for the time being.
The possibility that Taiwan's political tension with the mainland might culminate in a military conflict has dampened Taiwan's prospects for an upgrading in its rating, Fitch Ratings said.

On the other hand, the agency said, the DPP's failure to control the legislature means its financial reforms will continue to be bogged down in the Legislative Yuan, which will result in an increase of its middle-term debt to an alarming level of 40 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP).

An opposition-controlled legislature is certain to put the brakes on the government's big price-tag projects such as the NT$601.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms purchase and its NT$500 billion "10 New Major Projects" program and ease the government's financial burden, which is all the more important at a time when the government's revenues have decreased to 13 percent of the GDP, according to the agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 15, or the fourth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1891: The Bill of Rights, the first 10 amendments to the U.S. Constitution, goes into effect.
1915: Noted Taiwan folklore writer Chung Li-ho is born.
1920: China and Austria are admitted into the League of Nations.
1927: The Republic of China government orders the closure of the Soviet consulate in Shanghai and begins rounding up communists following an attempted communist coup in Canton the day before.
1931: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman and premier of the Nationalist government, retires, citing the interests of party unity as the reason for his move.
1938: The United States agrees to lend US$25 million to China under a Sino-American oil loan agreement.
1944: Chinese expeditionary forces capture Bhamo in northern Burma.
1946: The U.N. General Assembly decides to set up its permanent headquarters in New York City.
1948: France completes the construction of its first nuclear reactor.
1949: The ROC Executive Yuan names Wu Kuo-chen as governor of Taiwan.
1952: Beijing rejects India's plan for a Korean armistice.
1961: The U.N. General Assembly votes against a Soviet proposal to admit Communist China as a member.
1965: The U.S. Mariner spacecraft flies past Venus and relays data about the planet to scientists on Earth.
1966: Walter Elias Disney -- the U.S. animator, showman and film producer known as "Walt" -- dies at the age of 65.
1970: The first Sino-American Conference on Mainland China is opened in Taipei.
1971: The state-run Bank of China becomes a private bank and changes its name to the International Commercial Bank of China.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1972: The Japanese embassies in Taipei and Kaohsiung are closed.
1973: Tachien Dam, which had been under construction in central Taiwan for four years, becomes operational.
1977: A newly built integrated steel plant of the state-run China Steel Corp. starts operating in Kaohsiung.
1978: U.S. President Jimmy Carter announces that he will establish diplomatic relations with Communist China from Jan. 1, 1979, and break off relations with the Republic of China at the same time.
1978: The "Chang Sheng," the first Taiwan-built 20,000-ton container vessel, is launched in Keelung.
1980: The ROC's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park is inaugurated.
1988: The U.N. General Assembly overwhelmingly calls for the convening of an international Middle East peace conference.
1993: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves a revision of the University Law, giving more autonomy to colleges and allowing students to participate in meetings related to school affairs.
1995: Beijing sentences Wei Jingsheng, a noted dissident, to 14 years in jail for "conspiring to subvert the government," a move that arouses international condemnation.
1999: The U.S. State Department clarifies its stance on the ROC's bid to join the World Health Organization, saying the U.S. supports Taiwan's "meaningful participation," not its membership, in the body.
2000: Chiang Peng-chien, a member of the Control Yuan and founding chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), dies of pancreatic cancer at the age of 61.
2001: The Second International Bio Science and Technology Exposition opens at the Taipei World Trade Center, with over 300 firms from home and abroad participating.
2001: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan leaves for Japan for a week-long visit, making him the first KMT chairman to visit Japan since the party moved its headquarters to Taiwan in 1950.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Think how anxious your parents are when you are sick, and you will know your duty toward them. The duty of a good son nowadays means only to be able to support his parents. But you also keep your dogs and horses alive. If there is no feeling of love and respect, where is the difference?"

DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Jurors Say Scott Peterson Should Die for 2 Murders. A divided jury came together to decide that Scott Peterson should die for murdering his wife and unborn son, voting for death shortly after reviewing photos of the decomposing bodies of his victims--Laci Peterson, missing her arms and head, and Conner Peterson, barely recognizable as a fetus.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Manila Bulletin: Funeral rites set for FPJ Mourning for movie icon and highly-popular opposition leader Fernando Poe, Jr. cut across all social strata, from the posh Makati villages which divorced themselves in his campaign for the presidency, to the nation's heartland where he touched so many lives, and where FPJ's greatest strength lay.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: RP united in mourning Poe's death HE WAS not even a martyr for democracy but the outpouring of grief from across the land over the death of Fernando Poe Jr. came like a river.
The Philippine Star: Filipinos mourn FPJ Filipinos went into mourning yesterday after the country's top movie star Fernando Poe Jr. -- the man who would have been president -- died shortly after midnight Monday.

Energy and chemicals giant Shell is powering ahead with plans to pump more than US$1 billion (S$1.6 billion) into its petrochemicals operations here in partnership with the Economic Development Board (EDB) after its original partner pulled out.
The Lianhe Zaobao:Shell moves ahead with US$1b petrochemical factory in Singapore.

The naphtha foctory project is potentially worth at least US$1 billion.

Tokyo, Dec.15 ( CNA) The Japan Times: Blaze at Don Quijote kills three; Serial arson suspected after two stores hit.
