DOC.HEADLINE: HAKKA AFFAIRS COUNCIL WORKING TO SAVE ENDANGERED DIALECTS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Hakka Affairs (CHA) is sponsoring the establishment of three language teaching centers around Taiwan in an effort to save the endangered dialects of the Hakka language.

Three of the five major Hakka dialects, namely the Rao-ping, Dah-pu and Shao-an dialects, are on the verge of dying out in Taiwan as few people speak them. Most of Taiwan's Hakka people, numbering about 3 million, speak one of the two other major dialects, namely the Si-hsien or Hai-lu dialects.

Former CHA Chairwoman Yeh Chu-lan once said that the endangered Hakka dialects, particularly the Shao-an dialect, are like Taiwan's endemic land-locked salmon which faces extinction if replenishment action is not taken to save it.

The first of the three proposed Hakka dialect teaching centers was formally inaugurated at Tunghsing Elementary School in the rural township of Lunpei in Yunlin County Wednesday in a ceremony presided over by CHA Vice Chairman Chuang Ching-hua.

Chuang said the tasks of the center will include teaching the Shao-an dialect, compiling a Shao-an dictionary, and setting up a cyber data bank and a teaching corner on Hakka language and culture in general and the Shao-an dialect in particular.
The two other Hakka language teaching centers are expected to be inaugurated later this month in Hsinchu City and Taichung County, respectively, Chuang noted.

Also speaking at the ceremony, Tunghsing Elementary School principal Chen Hsin-huang said that Hakka people of Shao-an origin mostly reside in the rural townships of Siluo, Erlun and Lunpei in the south-central county of Yunlin. Only the elderly Hakka people there know how to speak the Shao-an dialect, he noted.

Chen pointed out that the Shao-an dialect contains many words and pronunciations that are similar to languages that originated in central mainland China, including the Hoklo dialect on which Taiwanese is based. He said this proves that the Hakka people and the Taiwanese people have common ancestors who came from central China near the Yellow River.
To beef up the language center, Chen said, teachers and volunteers will also step up field studies and material collections in an effort to preserve the Hakka culture as much as possible.
Although there isn't an exact figure on the Hakka population in Taiwan, the Hakka people are believed to number at least 2.86 million.

After a detailed survey of residents of 368 cities, counties and townships nationwide over the past year, the CHA found that the number of Hakka people and people of Hakka origin in Taiwan totals 6.08 million, representing 26.9 percent of the country's entire population.
According to the survey, about 1.66 million people in Taiwan who are of Hakka origin had not been considered as Hakka people. Of these people, many cannot speak any of the Hakka dialects.
Some 42.5 percent of the survey respondents said that only those people who are of Hakka origin and can speak a Hakka dialect can be considered Hakka.

In addition, 85 percent of the Hakka people think that their mother tongue has increasingly lost ground in Taiwan due to a variety of factors. About 72 percent of the Hakka people surveyed said they are proud to be Hakka, although 46 percent said that they would not mention their ethnic origin without first being asked.

The Hakka people, whose ancestors originated in central China more than 1,000 years ago, have been scattered around the world since the early 19th century due to their trademark characteristics of hard-work and perseverance.
Last year, three top political leaders in Taiwan discovered that they all have Hakka ancestors from the same area in today's Zhaoan County in the mainland Chinese province of Fujian.

After a series of activities heralding Hakka culture, President Chen Shui-bian had his ancestry traced back to the village of Baiye in Taiping Township, Zhaoan County. According to the Chen clan family tree records, President Chen is a descendant of the first official dispatched by the Tang emperor to explore the southern lands during the Tang Dynasty (618-907 A.D.).
President Chen is the ninth generation offspring of Chen Wu (1739-1796) , the first Chen ancestor to cross the Taiwan Strait and settle in Taiwan, according to the Chen family tree.

Meanwhile, Vice President Annette Lu said in January 2003 that she is half Hakka as her ancestors on her mother's side came from Zhaoan, which is a well-known Hakka area. "Hakka" means "the guest people" in Mandarin Chinese.
The Hakka people were so defined during the Yuan Dynasty (1277-1367) when residents from central and north-central China fled to the south to escape famine and calamity.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun's ancestors have been traced to a village only some 12 kilometers from where the president's ancestors resided.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN CALLS FOR CONSULTATIONS AMONG PARTIES FOR STABILITY

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chen on Wednesday called for consultations between the ruling and opposition parties for the sake of the nation's political and economic stability.

Lien, fresh from the "pan-blue alliance's" strong showing in Saturday's legislative elections in which the alliance of the KMT, the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party won a majority of seats, made the remarks during a regular KMT Central Standing Committee meeting.
He said that the for the sake of political, economic as well as cross-Taiwan Strait stability, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition parties must cooperate.
"One should not misconstrue such consultations as being aimed at grabbing power, but instead at sharing responsibility," Lien said.

Lien also said that the DPP, hemmed by its de-sinicization campaign and independence ideology, is incapable of handling relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. With the KMT's new mandate after the elections, the party wants to take the opportunity to contribute in this matter, he said.
On a merger of the "pan-blue alliance" parties, Lien noted that the KMT has promised its supporters that it will continue to push to achieve the goal with "patience and determination."

PFP Chairman James Soong said after the elections that the KMT had shut the door on a merger. He didn't elaborate, but reports said that he and Lien had not been on speaking terms since mid-November because of bickering over the allocation of the more than NT$100 million (US$3.1 million) subsidies for the "Lien-Soong" ticket in the March 20 presidential elections.

Soong was also reportedly angry because the "pan-blue alliance" voter-allocation strategy shut the PFP out. The KMT garnered 79 of the 225 Legislative Yuan seats in Saturday's elections, or 11 seats more than in the previous elections, mostly at the expense of the PFP, which managed to gain only 34 seats, or 12 less than in the previous elections.
A KMT-arranged meeting among the heads of the KMT, the PFP and the New Party for this week was postponed after Soong's trip to the United States Wednesday.

Meanwhile, PFP legislative whip Liu Wen-hsiung expressed that the party-to-party consultations proposal is a good idea. However, he added that the consultations should be completely transparent. The parties should set an agenda, embark on pre-talk meetings, and start by building mutual trust, he said.

Liu said that issues that to be discussed in such consultations should include the system of government, responsible politics, national policies, as well as how to improve the economy, beef up defense and better cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAS ENGAGED IN SOUL-SEARCHING SINCE ELECTIONS: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has devoted much of his time to soul-searching since Saturday's legislative elections and has not met with politicians as local news media reported, a senior Presidential Office official said Wednesday.

James Huang, a Presidential Office deputy secretary-general, was responding to media reports that President Chen has met with several political heavyweights at his official residence after the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) failed to reach its target of winning a majority in Saturday's legislative election.

According to media reports, Chen had met with former Vice Premier Lin Hsin-yi and two Judicial Yuan vice presidents -- Cheng Chung-mo and Lai Ying-jaw -- in the past few days to discuss a possible Cabinet reshuffle to cope with the post-election political situation.
"The reports are not factual, " Huang said, adding that the only person that the president has received at his official residence since the elections is his mentor Lee Hung-hsi.

Lee, a scholar versed in constitutional affairs who now heads the Ketagalan Institute -- a school founded by President Chen to nurture a new generation of leaders in public affairs, paid a visit to Chen Sunday to encourage him not to be daunted by the elections setback. Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Council Approves Altered Stadium Deal.
Requirement for 50 percent private financing leaves The Washington Nationals' future in question. -- David Nakamura

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN'S WIFE WINS SUIT FOR UNAUTHORIZED USE OF HER IMAGE

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court ruled on Wednesday that a local bio-technology firm must pay Lien Fang Yu, wife of opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, NT$500,000 (US$15,432) in compensation for using her image without her authorization.
Lien Fang sued the firm in July after it had used her image in an advertisement promoting a freckle removal cream.
She had asked for NT$5 million in compensation and said the money would be donated to charity organizations if she won the suit.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO ELECT NEW CHAIRMAN BY FEB. 1

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will elect a new party chairman before Feb. 1, 2005, DPP acting chairman Ker Chien-ming said Wednesday.
Ker, DPP party whip at the Legislative Yuan, said that the new party chairman will be directly elected by DPP members.
President Chen Shui-bian resigned from the DPP chairmanship Tuesday to take responsibility for the DPP's failure to win a majority in the Legislative Yuan in last Saturday's elections.
Ker was appointed by the DPP Central Standing Committee to be acting chairman immediately after President Chen resigned.
Ker said that the DPP Central Executive Committee is scheduled to meet next Tuesday to work out the details for the party chairmanship election.
Meanwhile, Ker said that a Cabinet reshuffle is not expected until January after the Executive Yuan passes the general budget bill for fiscal year 2005.
Ker denied media reports that President Chen has been meeting with political heavyweights since Saturday's elections to discuss a Cabinet reshuffle, including choosing a new premier.
Meanwhile, DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung also offered to step down from the post of secretary-general last Saturday over the DPP's setback.

In his resignation remarks, Chang noted that the DPP garnered the largest number of legislative seats and the highest vote share among all the parties in the elections, although he admitted that the DPP's mismanaged voter allocation strategy was responsible for the defeat of a number of incumbent DPP legislators who enjoyed a high support rating in opinion polls. Chang said that the DPP will conduct a thorough review of the error.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: The sun sets on Britain's old diplomatic empire.
Britain is to downgrade or turn over to local staff dozens of consulates in Europe, Africa and Latin America to pay for new embassies and diplomatic outposts in Iraq, Libya, Afghanistan and other crisis areas.
Financial Times: Auditors to face jail threat.
Auditors could face jail for "knowingly and recklessly" giving false opinions, under measures agreed in principle by ministers as a quid pro quo for limiting the big accounting firms' liability.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-VANUATU DIPLOMATIC TIES STILL STAND: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Vanuatu parliament has not nullified formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan and the bilateral ties are still valid, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said that although Taiwan's diplomatic personnel have departed Vanuatu for Fiji under a cloud of uncertainty, this does not mean that the formal diplomatic relations are now invalid.
Lu said the new Vanuatu Cabinet, which was formed last weekend, has not announced or informed Taiwan about any flip-flop on bilateral ties.
Vanuatu's parliament ousted Prime Minister Serge Vohor out of office Saturday in a no-confidence vote and a new Cabinet headed by Ham Lini has been formed.
Lu said that so far, Taipei has not heard a word from the new Vanuatu government about any change in the Taiwan-Vanuatu diplomatic relations established Nov. 3.

Lu discounted a claim by the Beijing authorities earlier in the day that Vanuatu will repeal all accords and consensuses reached with Taiwan, adding that the Taiwan-Vanuatu formal diplomatic ties are not built on claims made by Beijing.

He stressed that the ministry will not give up its efforts at this stage and that the Republic of China embassy staff will stay "around the corner" to observe developments and "fight to the last minute."
The MOFA staff can return to Vanuatu at any minute, Lu noted.
Vohor and ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen signed a joint communique in Taipei Nov. 3 to establish diplomatic relations, making Vanuatu the ROC's 27th ally.

The diplomatic ties, however, have been since hanging in the balance, mainly as a result of Beijing's interference. With Beijing continuing to try to woo Vanuatu away from Taiwan, a cross-strait diplomatic tug-of-war has been playing out in the South Pacific island state.

The MOFA is closely monitoring how the new Vanuatu Cabinet handles its relations with Taiwan, Lu said, adding that there are two possible developments. The first is that Vanuatu will maintain formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan after "having thought it through" and realizing that this is in its best interests in terms of its long-term development.

The second is that Vanuatu will sever ties with Taiwan and accept financial assistance promised by the mainland if it does so. Beijing is willing to offer Vanuatu US$32 million, and more if it severs ties with Taiwan.

Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Michael Y.M. Kau said over the weekend that he is not optimistic about the development of ROC-Vanuatu relations in light of the pro-Beijing background of Prime Minister Lini.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Missteps cited in Kerik vetting by White House.
The Bush administration failed to get a full picture of the legal and ethical problems of Bernard B. Kerik, its nominee for homeland security secretary, because the White House did not consult with the one person in the West Wing who knew the most about Mr. Kerik's background, Frances Townsend, because Ms. Townsend, President Bush's adviser on homeland security and a former federal prosecutor in New York, was under consideration for the position herself, said an official, who would speak only on condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the issue.
Wall Street Journal: In global food-trade skirmish, safety is the weapon of choice.
As new food emerge, the drive for free trade around the world is blunting the traditional tactics governments once employed to shield their domestic industries. Now, food safety is becoming the stealth weapon of protectionism in the US$522 billion market for global agricultural exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Kagalovsky Makes New Yukos.
Offer Former Yukos shareholder Konstantin Kagalovsky made another offer to save Yukos on Tuesday, this time to buy what remains of the embattled oil company after its main production unit is sold off this week.

DOC.HEADLINE: WIDOW OF LATE PRESIDENT CHIANG CHIANG-KUO DIES

TEXT.P: Former first lady and widow of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo died of pulmonary disease Wednesday at Taipei Veterans Generals Hospital. She was 90.

The Russia-born Faina Chiang, whose Chinese name is Chiang Fang-liang, had a history of obstructive pulmonary disease, stroke and asthma. She was admitted to the hospital in early October after suffering from inflammation of the windpipe and acute asthma.

Chiang had led a secluded life over the past decade because of her poor health. Her last public appearance was when she paid tribute to her late husband at his temporary mausoleum in Touliao, Taoyuan, in April this year.

The public also had a rare glimpse of the reticent former first lady in her waning days when a local newspaper ran a photo of her offspring and former guards and friends celebrating her 90th birthday in May.

The former first lady met her husband, who was sent to Russia for study but was later banished for political reasons, while both were working in a factory in the Ural mountains in 1933. They got married two years later. After their eldest son, Chiang Hsiao-wen, was born in Russia in 1937, they returned to mainland China and lived there for 12 years.

During her 53-year marriage, she kept her distance from politics, although the two Chiangs -- late president Chiang Kai-shek and his son Chiang Ching-kuo -- maintained a dynastic grip on Taiwan's politics after they retreated to the island in 1949.
Instead, she remained a quiet and modest person with her family being the focus of her life.

Opposition People First Party James Soong, who formerly served as Chiang Ching-kuo's English secretary, once said that Chiang Ching-kuo and his wife maintained a simple and frugal life even at the zenith of their power.

Chiang raised three sons and one daughter. After her husband died in 1988, she lost her three sons consecutively in the following eight years. This series of blows made her even more reticent, sources closed to her said. She is survived by her daughter Chiang Hsiao-chang and a dozen grandchildren and great grandchildren.
In 1992, Minsk city mayor of Belarus visited Taiwan, the first time that Chiang had met someone from her hometown since leaving there in 1937.

Although in declining health in recent years, she went to her husband's temporary mausoleum whenever her physical condition permitted. At the 15th anniversary of Ching-kuo's death in 2003, she went as usual despite a severe cold weather.
Many Taiwan people were disheartened to see the frail lady, in a wheelchair and intubated, being helped to stand up before Ching-kuo's picture in the mausoleum.
President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu visited the former first lady at the Veterans General Hospital, and the vice president also praised her as a gracious Taiwan woman.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT, POLITICAL LEADERS MOURN WIDOW OF LATE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Leaders of government and major political parties in Taiwan shared their condolences Wednesday on the death of Faina Chiang, widow of late President Chiang Ching-kuo.
Chiang died of respiratory failure aged 90 at the Taipei Veterans General Hospital Wednesday.

Soon after receiving the news, President Chen Shui-bian, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou all went to the hospital to extend their condolences to her family.
Chen said he regrets the death of the former first lady, who he described as a "role model for women."

Though born and raised in Russia, Chiang had the virtues of a traditional Chinese woman and made her family her top priority, spending most of her time taking care of her husband and children, Chen noted.
Vice President Annette Lu said Chiang spent most of her life in Taiwan with the late president and that she believes her virtuous and gentle manner will be missed by the Taiwanese people.

Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said the government will offer every possible help to assist with Chiang's funeral, while KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said the party will set up a special task force to help arrange the funeral.
Chang said the KMT expresses its deepest condolences and sadness on Chiang's death, praising her as an ordinary yet great first lady who was always humble, thrifty, mild and patriotic.
Opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong, who is on a trip to the United States, phoned to send his condolences to the bereaved family.
Soong said he visited Chiang before he departed for the United States and never expected it would be his last meeting with her.
Soong, who served as an English secretary to the late president for 15 years, noted that the former first lady led a simple life and never interfered in national affairs.
Soong said she seldom asked the late president's staff to do her any favors except for when she wanted to write in English to some foreign friends.

Meanwhile, ruling Democratic Progressive Party spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan and Taiwan Solidarity Union Secretary-General Lin Chih-jia also extended their condolences on Chiang's death on behalf of their respective parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN HAS NO PLANS TO VISIT BEIJING: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan has no plans to pay a visit to mainland China presently, KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said Wednesday.

Chang quoted Lien as saying at a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday that the KMT -- the backbone of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, the People First Party and the New Party -- will make even greater efforts to optimize cross-Taiwan Strait peace and stability now that the "pan-blues" have retained a majority in the Legislative Yuan after Saturday's legislative elections.

Lien, however, said he has no plans to visit the mainland, although he said prior to the presidential election in March that he would like to travel to Beijing to facilitate cross-strait reconciliation if he were elected, according to Chang.

Mainland China's State Council Taiwan Affairs Office spokesman Li Weiyi said at a press conference in Beijing earlier the day that the mainland has been calling and will continue to call for Taiwan politicians, regardless of political affiliation, to visit Beijing to exchange views on efforts to strengthen cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, moving up NT$0.003 to close at NT$32.447.
A total of US$737 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$32.495 and was traded between NT$32.353 and NT$32.512 during the day's trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on the Taipei stock futures market moved up Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December gained 116 points to close at 6,017, with 14,600 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January surged 112 points to finish at 6,015, with 40,003 contracts traded, while March futures soared 121 points to finish at 6,000, with 30 contracts traded.
June futures gained 125 points to finish at 5,980, with 15 contracts traded, while September futures moved up 148 points to close at 5,923, with 14 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,901 for December, 5,903 for January, 5,876 for March, 5,865 for June and 5,775 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

December TE futures moved up 4.35 points to close at 225.5, with 3,281 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained 5.2 points to finish at 226.7, with 5,949 contract transactions. March TE futures gained 3.5 points to close at 223.6, with five contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

December TF futures gained 8.8 points to finish at 1,013.2, with 3,351 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved up 9.2 points to end at 1,006, with 6,794 contracts traded. June TF futures lost 7.6 points to finish at 1,002, with three contracts changing hands.
September TF futures fell one point to close at 999.8, with one contract traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE' COALITION A CERTAINTY: LEGISLATOR-ELECT

TEXT.P: A coalition or merger of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" parties of the Kuomintang (KMT) , People First Party (PFP) and the New Party is the mainstream consensus among the parties for the cause of political stability, New Party legislator-elect Joanna Lei said Wednesday.

The "pan-blues" must consolidate themselves and "there are no ifs or buts about it, " said Lei, hostess of a TV talk show, who has a prominent resume behind her, including being the first Asian woman to become a vice president of the American Broadcasting Corp. (ABC).
Lei, nevertheless, reminded the "pan-blue" leaders that a three-party coalition is by no means a distribution of power or "booty sharing."
She called for "pan-blue" leaders to deliver on their campaign promises now that the "pan-blues" have retained a majority in the Legislative Yuan after Saturday's legislative elections.
"Any political figure who does not heed public opinion will eventually be dumped by the voters," she asserted.

Lei's remarks were believed to be directed at PFP Chairman James Soong, who has wavered in his stance on the much-discussed "pan-blue" merger after Saturday's legislative elections, in which the PFP suffered a major defeat by losing 12 seats.

In comparison, the relatively much smaller New Party scored an enviable performance in the elections, with the party taking four seats out of seven candidates who ran, after it adopted an election strategy of having its candidates run under the KMT banner, except Legislator Wu Cheng-tien who ran a victorious re-election campaign as a New Party candidate in Kinmen, a "win-win" approach that pushed the "pan-blues" ahead to win the majority.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS CONTINUATION OF VOTE-BUYING PROBE AFTER ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun ordered law enforcement authorities Wednesday to continue to investigate vote-buying cases reported during the legislative elections last week.

Speaking at the first Cabinet meeting since Saturday's elections, Yu said the authorities must make sure no voters were paid bribes after the polls, which has become a popular new method of vote buying among corrupt politicians.

Yu said there were some 5,000 alleged vote-buying cases reported during the run-up to the elections and that the authorities should complete their investigation as soon as possible and bring the cases to trial.
He instructed the Ministry of the Interior review the discrepancies existing in the country's election and recall laws and to work out draft amendments to the laws to address the problem.

In addition, he went on, the ministry must coordinate with the Legislative Yuan to ensure that a bill governing the election method of the ad hoc National Assembly is passed as soon as possible in order to facilitate the preparation for a National Assembly election.
Members of the National Assembly are supposed to be elected by May 26 to consider a constitutional amendment package passed by the Legislative Yuan Aug. 23.

Meanwhile, Yu requested all Cabinet members to coordinate with legislators to assist the passage of 33 priority bills, including the 2005 central government budget bill, before the term of incumbent legislators ends in January.
Yu said these 33 bills are very urgent and important and must be passed as soon as possible.
According to law, any bills that are not passed by the end of a legislative term will be scrapped.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATUTE FOR TRUTH INVESTIGATION COMMISSION `PARTLY UNCONSTITUTIONAL'

TEXT.P: Two articles of the statute under which the so-called "Truth Investigation Commission" was formed are unconstitutional, according to a ruling passed down by the Council of Grand Justices Wednesday.
The council said parts of the eighth article and all of the 13th article of the Organic Statute for the Truth Investigation Commission are unconstitutional.

The statute was railroaded through the legislature by the opposition Aug. 24 to provide the legal basis for the establishment of a commission with sweeping extra-judicial powers to investigate the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu which, the opposition claim was a political scheme cooked up to help Chen win the March 20 presidential election. The opposition has provided no evidence to support its claim.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS UNDERSCORE TAIWANESE IDENTITY: CABINET

TEXT.P: The just-concluded legislative elections have further underscored Taiwan's separate identity and the unmarketability of Beijing's "one country, two systems" unification scheme, Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Wednesday.

Chen made the remarks after mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) claimed that peace with Taiwan can only be ensured if the island's authorities agree to unify with the mainland and that the top Taiwan leader's flirting with statehood "has been the source of chaos in the Asia-Pacific region."

In Beijing's first official response to Taiwan's legislative elections, in which the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its pro-independence allies failed to win a majority, TAO spokesman Li Weiyi said there can be no peace if Taiwan becomes independent.

Li further said there can only be a change in cross-Taiwan Strait relations "if the authorities in Taiwan recognize that there is only one China in the world and Taiwan is a part of it, and if they give up their Taiwan independence stance and stop Taiwan independence activities."
Commenting on Li's remarks, Chen said the mainland should not misinterpret the results of Taiwan's legislative elections.

Whatever the electoral results, Chen said, the elections per se signified Taiwan's own identity as opposed to that of the mainland. Moreover, he said, only one of those who publicly support Beijing's "one county, two systems" overture was elected in the legislative elections. This, coupled with the fact that few candidates dared to mention Beijing's cherished "one China" principle or its "one country, two systems" scheme in the run-up to the elections, indicates that Beijing's unification overture is unpopular and unmarketable in Taiwan.
"The Beijing authorities should not misread the electoral results and the mainstream public opinion in Taiwan," Chen said.

He also rebutted Beijing's accusation of President Chen Shui-bian as the "source of chaos in the Asia-Pacific region, " saying that the mainland is actually the biggest threat to Asia-Pacific security.

"China's military budget reaches US$50 billion to US$70 billion annually and the amount has continued to grow at a double-digit rate, posing a grave threat to Asia-Pacific security, " Chen said, adding that Beijing has also deployed more than 500 ballistic missiles against Taiwan.

He stressed that the DPP administration's fundamental policy of promoting peace, stability and rapprochement across the Taiwan Strait as clearly expounded in the president's May 20 inauguration speech, Oct. 10 National Day address and statements concerning Taiwan's constitutional re-engineering plan, has remained unchanged.
He urged the mainland leaders to work with Taiwan with wisdom to create a viable mechanism for peaceful cross-strait engagement and development.

The most urgent task for the moment is for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to negotiate the opening of direct cross-strait charter flights during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday to facilitate the return of a large number of Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland for family reunions, Chen said, adding that the opening of two-way, non-stop holiday charter flights could benefit both sides.

With Beijing's consent, Taiwan carriers operated special charter flights between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau during the 2003 Chinese New Year period. The services were not offered during the 2004 Chinese New Year holiday because Beijing insisted that mainland carriers be allowed to also provide the same flight services while declining to negotiate the necessary technical details with Taiwan.

The ROC government said that as the opening of two-way, non-stop cross-strait charter flight services involves the exercise of public authority, prior negotiations are necessary. The upcoming lunar New Year holiday falls between Feb. 6, 2005 and Feb. 13.

At Wednesday's news conference, TAO spokesman Li Weiyi didn't address whether Beijing would allow direct cross-strait charter flights during the forthcoming Chinese New Year holiday, saying only that Beijing's position is unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SURGE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange surged Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 92.93 points to close at 6,002.58.

The bourse opened high at 5,930.85 and fluctuated between 5,912.95 and 6,011.12 during trading. A total of 4.8 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$101.66 billion (US$3.15 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 3.2 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 2.1 percent, cement issues at 1.4 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.1 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 1.0 percent, financial and insurance issues and foodstuff issues each at 0.8 percent, and textile stocks at 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 593 to 120, with 120 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN VISITS SAN FRANCISCO
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By Chiang Ying and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong has reiterated that if the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) wants a merger with the PFP, it will have to cast away its past burdens and hold out new vision for the public.
Soong made the remarks upon arriving at the San Francisco International Airport.

Despite the call for a merger of the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, the PFP and the New Party after it managed to maintain a majority by garnering 114 seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan in Saturday's elections, Soong said after the elections that it was the KMT who had shut the door to a merger.

Reports said that Soong and Lien have not been on speaking terms since mid-November because of bickering over the allocation of a NT$100 million (US$3.1 million) subsidy for the Lien-Soong ticket in the March 20 presidential election and the voter-allocation scheme used Saturday that shut out the PFP.
The KMT garnered 79 seats, 11 seats more than in the previous elections, mostly at the expense of the PFP, which managed 34 seats, 12 seats fewer than in the previous elections.
Soong, who said he would not cling to the party chairmanship or play second fiddle in the KMT, said Tuesday that he was not jockeying for any position.

But he said the KMT has to first display its sincerity by drawing a line between "the corrupt `black gold' politics of the era of former chairman Lee Teng-hui," and work out a reform plan, or the PFP will pursue its own path.
Soong also named three urgent tasks faced by Taiwan -- cross-Taiwan Strait reconciliation, ethnic reconciliation at home and economic development.
On newspaper speculation that the PFP could cooperate with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), he said categorically that "it is out of the question."

Soong criticized the DPP for its tilt toward the Taiwan independence and for what he described as its "disrespect to the Constitution" and said that the two parties could not possibly cooperate. Only in public policy will the PFP consider such cooperation with the DPP, he said.
Soong is here to visit his family and he also plans to visit the East Coast of the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CALLS FOR FORMATION OF DPP-KMT COALITION GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan proposed Wednesday the formation of a coalition government of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the KMT.

KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said the KMT insists that any members who join the new Cabinet must do so in the name of the party and is opposed to any members joining the government in their personal capacities.
Chang said there should be a mechanism for cooperation between the KMT and DPP under which they can exchange views on the formation of a coalition government.
Speaking at a weekly meeting of the party's Central Standing Committee, Lien said the ruling and opposition parties in Taiwan must cooperate for the sake of national development.

Lien said the KMT does not wish to see a repeat in the future of the ruling-opposition confrontation that has been going on over the past four-and-a-half years, which he said has left the country in a deadlock.

Pointing out that a new legislature was elected in Saturday's elections, Lien urged the DPP to respect the legislative majority and draw up its new Cabinet lineup according to the outcome of the elections.

The KMT, which won 79 legislative seats in the elections, is the second-largest party in the 225-member Legislative Yuan after the DPP, which seized 89 seats. However, the KMT, together with its "pan blue alliance" allies the People First Party and New Party, controls a legislative majority with 114 of the 225 legislative seats.
Lien said it will be the responsibility of the next premier and Cabinet to boost the country's economy, stabilize cross-Taiwan Strait relations and improve the life of the people.
He emphasized that the KMT's proposal to form a coalition government is a means of sharing responsibility and should not be mistaken as a bid to jockey for power.
He called on the DPP to drop its petty mindset and accept the goodwill offered by the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LEGISLATOR KEEN ON SEEKING LEGISLATIVE VICE SPEAKERSHIP

TEXT.P: Opposition Legislator Shen Chih-hwei of the People First Party (PFP) made known her intention Wednesday to run for the vice presidency of the Legislative Yuan.

Shen, 47, fresh from her victorious re-election campaign in Saturday's legislative elections, made the remarks as the issue of a new speaker and vice speaker has emerged with the conclusion of the elections.
The new legislators will be sworn in Feb. 1 and a new speaker and vice speaker will be elected that day.
Shen said that as a six-time legislator, she is behind only Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who is a 10-time legislator, in seniority.

She made known her intention to run for the vice speakership during a PFP meeting a day earlier and said she had also reported her intent to PFP Chairman James Soong, who did not stop her from soliciting support from the other newly elected legislators.

She said that only if the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, PFP and the New Party cooperate -- the three parties together garnered 114 seats -- can it make effective use of its majority in the 225-seat legislature.

"A KMT-PFP ticket for the presidency and vice presidency of the legislature should be acceptable, " she said, adding that she will continue to work toward that goal. However, she also said that a consultation between the top brass of the two parties will have the final say on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOVEMBER FOREIGN RESERVES FROM IMPORTS, EXPORTS HIT NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports earned US$18.612 billion in foreign reserves in November, while imports cost US$19.186 billion, both posting record single-month highs, according to central bank statistics.
The figures formed an unfavorable trade balance of US$574 million, the largest amount since 1992, the statistics show.

Given the flourishing development of the international economy, Taiwan's imports of agricultural raw materials and machinery equipment grew, while crude oil prices on the international market rose in the past months. These were two major reasons that led to the unfavorable balance, according to a central bank official.

However, accumulated earned foreign reserves from exports during the period from January to November reached US$182.822 billion, while the spending of foreign reserves on imports totaled US$172.806 billion, resulting in a favorable balance of US$10.016 billion, the statistics show.
The statistics note that the two figures registered growth of 25.7 percent and 34.4 percent, respectively, in comparison with those of the same period of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES 28 POLICE MOTORCYCLES TO THE PHILIPPINES
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By Emerson T. Lim and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has donated 28 police motorcycles to the central Philippine province of Capiz on Panay Island, officials said Wednesday.
Officials of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in the Philippines said they presented the vehicles during a recent visit to the province, and they were accepted by Governor Vincente B. Bermejo.
During the visit, the Taiwanese officials also discussed issues concerning fishery cooperation with Capiz officials.
Both sides are expected to sign a memorandum on joint fishery development soon, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHAMBERS OF COMMERCE OF TAIWAN, NICARAGUA TO CONCLUDE SISTERHOOD TIES

TEXT.P: The General Chamber of Commerce (GCC) of the Republic of China and the Nicaragua Chamber of Commerce will conclude sisterhood ties next year to promote exchanges between the two countries, GCC Chairman Wang Ling-lin said Wednesday.
Wang said the understanding was reached last Saturday when a delegation from the Nicaragua Chamber of Commerce called on the GCC during a visit to Taiwan.
Wang said the sisterhood relationship between the two organizations will accelerate bilateral cultural and commercial exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MOVIES MUST BE CONSUMER-ORIENTED: GIO HEAD

TEXT.P: Taiwan films must be commercially viable and strike a chord with local viewers if the domestic movie industry is to pull out of its current slump, the director-general of the Government Information Office (GIO) said Wednesday.
Lin Chia-lung noted that Taiwan is a rich society, and that if stories that take place on the island can be made into movies, they will surely attract a large audience.
He also said that the GIO will provide investment incentives and encourage local productions to shoot at overseas locations.

DOC.HEADLINE: 61 PERCENT OF UNMARRIED ADULTS WANT TO MARRY: SURVEY

TEXT.P: More than 60 percent of unmarried people between 20 and 39 years old want to get married, while about 16 percent want to remain single forever, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday.
The Cabinet-level Department of Health conducted the survey on unmarried young adults' attitude toward marriage in September and collected 2,546 valid replies.
According to the survey, 22.5 percent either said they do not know or declined to answer the question.

Among those who wanted to remain single, women outnumbered men. Only 10.7 percent of men interviewed said they would not marry, while 24.9 percent of woman said they wanted to be single forever, or one out of every four unmarried women.
Some 22 percent of male respondents said they were not sure whether they would marry, compared to 23.9 percent of women who said the same.

Among bachelors intending to marry, 36.4 percent cited "poor economic conditions" as the major reason they had yet to marry, while the top cause cited by women was that they have not yet met their "soul mate."

Key factors cited by bachelors who want to stay single forever included poor economic conditions, preferring a carefree way of life, failing to meet a "soul mate, " and afraid of troubles that may arise from marriage, in that order.
Causes cited by single women who would not marry included the desire for a carefree life, poor economic conditions, afraid of troubles, and failure to meet a "soul mate," in that order.
Meanwhile, 61 percent of respondents who would not marry said they believe that the advantages of staying single outnumber the benefits of marriage.
The survey also found that the intention to marry was the highest in the 25- 29 age group and that the intention to stay single forever increase along with age after 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC FACTORS DISCOURAGE PEOPLE FROM HAVING CHILDREN: POLL

TEXT.P: Economic factors and high education costs have discouraged local couples from having a second child, according to the results of a public opinion survey released Wednesday.
The telephone survey of 2,546 randomly chosen people aged between 20 and 39 was conducted by the Department of Health in September to explore local people's attitude toward having children.

According to the survey, 70 percent of those interviewed agreed with the notion that having two children is ideal, but 51 percent of those who have already had a child do not want to have a second one.

The willingness to have a second child was especially low among women aged over 30 and with middle-level education, survey results showed. Major reasons cited by them were that they didn't have enough financial resources to have a second child and that education costs were too expensive.
The poll also found that those residing in urban areas with a monthly family income of less than NT$80,000 were most likely to opt for "having only one child due to economic reasons."
Thirty percent of the respondents said that having no children is best.

Asked what the government should do to encourage couples to have more children given that the nation's birth rate has declined by 50 percent over the past four decades, the respondents cited four measures -- improving the education system and lowering education costs; improving the social welfare system; improving public order, and offering financial aid or incentives to encourage couple to have more children.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUJIAN TOURISM CHIEF VISITS KINMEN VIA DIRECT VOYAGE

TEXT.P: A 21-member mainland Chinese delegation, headed by Huang Xiaoyen, director of the Fujian Provincial Government, arrived in the Taiwan-held frontline island of Kinmen Wednesday via the direct "mini three links" route for a three-day visit.

It was the first official delegation from Fujian since mainland Chinese authorities began earlier this month to allow Fujian residents to travel to Kinmen for sightseeing trips via the "mini three links" route.

Taiwan opened its two offshore defense outposts of Kinmen and Matsu for direct trade, shipping and mail links, commonly known as "mini three links, " with Fujian province Jan. 2, 2001. Until early this month, mainland authorities only allowed Fujian officials or special professional groups to visit Kinmen and Matsu, both of which lie closer to Fujian than to Taiwan, on a case-by-case basis.
Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng and other local officials greeted the Fujian delegation at Shuitou wharf.

Huang said he takes pleasure in visiting Kinmen to see for himself tourist attractions and travel service development on the island. He said he believes that the opening of Fujian residents to make sightseeing trips to Kinmen will bring new business opportunities to the island.
Huang said mainland authorities may also allow residents in other mainland provinces to make sightseeing trips to Kinmen and Matsu via the "mini three links" route in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: MERGER OF KMT AND PFP IS INEVITABLE: KMT CHAIRMAN LIEN

TEXT.P: The path that will lead to the merger of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) is one that the parties will inevitably travel, KMT Chairman Lien Chan said Wednesday.
Lien said his party is resolute in seeing this happen and will stay the course with patience, persistence and enthusiasm.
He urged former KMT members who deserted the party for various reasons in the last decade to return to its fold and work together with the party.

Recalling a resolution by the KMT Central Standing Committee on May 19 that advocated a merger with the PFP, a KMT splinter, Lien said his party would not back out of the commitment because it would disappoint party supporters.
Any political group that reneges on its promises and swims against the tide will lose its credibility with voters, Lien said.
The reunion of the two parties will satisfy the desire of their supporters, and the KMT will do whatever it can to bring this about, Lien said.

He made the comment two days after PFP Chairman James Soong backed down on his pre-election promise to merge hisp arty with KMT, saying that a merger was out of the question because, among other things, the KMT failed to fulfill its promise to allocate voters between the two parties evenly.
The two parties command a slim majority of 114 seats between them in the new 225-seat legislature, with the KMT gaining 10 more seats over the last legislature, while the PFP lost 12 seats.

Lien also said that the party has a new vision after it performed better than expected in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, declaring that the KMT is willing to form a coalition with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to rule the country.

He promised to rejuvenate the party by bringing in a new leader, streamlining the party apparatus to make it smaller and more efficient, and dispose of party assets that have dubious origins in a transparent manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT ADMINISTRATION HAS AMPLE ROOM TO IMPROVE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that the government administration has an ample room to improve.

In a written statement read by Vice President Annette Lu at the 2004 Golden Axe Awards ceremony, Chen said that Taiwan was ranked 27th in the world in terms of the quality of public institutions and policies in the 2004-2005 Global Competitiveness Report by the prestigious World Economic Forum (WEF), although it was listed as the world's fourth most competitive economy.

The Golden Axe Awards are a local competition for government agencies in the categories of administration reengineering, deregulation and innovation, attracting investments and cross-agency cooperation.
The awards are given to recognize government agencies for their excellence in promoting institutional reforms, innovations, efficiency and improvements in service.

The government should first conduct "extensive reforms" to improve the economic development of the nation, Chen said, adding that only if the government continues unhindered in carrying out reforms can Taiwan's economic development be sustainable.
The government has been promoting institutional reforms and revisions to existing laws and regulations to stimulate the private sector's dynamism for national development, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING HAS MISREAD TAIWAN'S LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland China's misinterpretation of Taiwan's just-concluded legislative elections is counterproductive to relations across the Taiwan Strait, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Wednesday.

The mainland policy planning agency issued the statement in a news release after mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) said earlier in the day that peace with Taiwan can only be ensured if the island's authorities agree to unify with the mainland and that top Taiwan leader's flirting with statehood "has been the source of chaos in the Asia-Pacific region."

In Beijing's first official response to Taiwan's legislative elections, in which the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its pro-independence allies failed to win a majority, TAO spokesman Li Weiyi said there can be no peace if Taiwan becomes independent.

Li further said there can only be a change in cross-Taiwan Strait relations "if the authorities in Taiwan recognize that there is only one China in the world and Taiwan is a part of it, and if they give up their Taiwan independence stance and stop Taiwan independence activities."

In response, the MAC said the international community has offered positive comments on Taiwan's Dec. 11 legislative elections. For instance, U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Monday that Taiwan's weekend legislative elections showed the strength and vitality of the island's democracy.
The MAC said in its statement that mainland authorities have made "unrealistic and erroneous" interpretations mainly because they can't understand the values and meaning of democratic elections.
The MAC also said it would not respond to the TAO's irrational criticism against Taiwan's top national leader.

Instead, the MAC urged mainland China to negotiate with Taiwan for the opening of two-way, non-stop charter flights across the Taiwan Strait for the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday to facilitate the return of a large number of Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland for family reunions.
Noting that Taiwan has unveiled principles and a feasible consultative formula, the MAC said Beijing should show its sincerity to improve cross-strait ties by deeds.

With Beijing's consent, Taiwan carriers operated special charter flights between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau during the 2003 Chinese New Year period. The services were not offered during the 2004 Chinese New Year holiday because Beijing insisted that mainland carriers also be allowed to provide the same flight services while declining to negotiate the necessary technical details with Taiwan.

The ROC government said that as the opening of two-way, non-stop cross-strait charter flight services involves the exercise of public authority, prior negotiations are necessary. The upcoming lunar new year holiday falls between Feb. 6, 2005 and Feb. 13.

At Wednesday's news conference, TAO spokesman Li Weiyi didn't say whether Beijing would allow direct cross-strait charter flights during the forthcoming Chinese New Year holiday, saying only that Beijing's position is unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY TO GROW 4.21 PERCENT NEXT YEAR: THINK TANK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy will grow 4.21 percent next year, less than the 5.95 percent estimated for this year, according to a report issued Wednesday by a private think tank.

The report on Taiwan's economic prospects for 2005 by the Taiwan Research Institute shows that the private sector's confidence in investment will remain unchanged after the Dec. 11 legislative elections while both the domestic and international economic growth will slow down in the next year.
The annual growth rate of private investment will fall to 8.34 percent from this year's 25.32 percent, it adds.
Private consumption will increase by 2.76 percent next year, less than the 2.95 percent estimated for this year, the report continues.
Taiwan's unemployment rate will register 4.42 percent next year, it states.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE '319 COMMISSION' RULED PARTLY UNCONSTITUTIONAL

TEXT.P: The Council of Grand Justices undercut a commission formed to look into the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian by declaring its judicial investigation powers modeled on that of prosecutors unconstitutional Wednesday.

The council said in an interpretation of the Constitution that the Legislative Yuan is working within its authority to set up a commission to conduct investigations but that it could not give the commission the power the legislature itself doesn't have.

The council declared parts of Article Eight and Article 13 of the Organic Statute for the Truth Investigation Commission unconstitutional and, therefore, are no longer effective from the day the interpretation is handed down.

The paragraphs of Article Eight that were declared unconstitutional tried to give the commission the same powers as those of prosecutors and military prosecutors in carrying out investigations into the March 19 shooting, and no individual or government organization may invoke whatever law to exempt themselves from giving testimony, handing over documents or extending assistance to the commission.
These paragraphs also attempted to give the commission the power to impose fine and overseas traveling bans on people when it considered such actions necessary.
The paragraphs of Article 13 that were declared unconstitutional tried to give the commission the power to prosecute persons involved in the shooting.

The council also said the Legislative Yuan's authority to form an investigation commission should be exercised by the legislature using due process of law; this means the members of the commission should be appointed by the president of the Legislative Yuan with the approval of the legislature.

The interpretation was made at the request of lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) who claimed the statute was bulldozed through the legislature by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) and was unconstitutional.
They also asked the council to impose a temporary moratorium on the commission's operations before the council made its ruling on the statute's constitutionality.
The council turned down their second request on the grounds that a temporary moratorium is unnecessary now that its decision on the statute's constitutionality is handed down.
The DPP was pleased with the council's decision, saying it bore out their repeated claims that the commission had infringed on the powers of the Ministry of Justice.
They asked the commission to stop operations immediately now that it is virtually powerless after the two articles empowering it to investigate the shooting were declared null and void.

Minister without Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung lauded the council's decision, calling the Legislative Yuan to address the unconstitutional parts of the statute immediately, and the commission should not probe the March 19 shooting outside its authority.

Since the current commission was packed with members named by the two opposition parties without the approval of the legislature, Hsu called it an unconstitutional commission and one that should stop operations immediately.

Shih Chi-yang, the KMT-appointed convener of the commission said the council's decision has robbed the commission of its major investigating powers and has made it even more difficult to find the truth behind the March 19 shooting.

PFP lawmaker Liu Wen-hsiung criticized the council for what he said was just serving politics, adding that it betrays the government's attempts to block any investigations to find out what really happened regarding the shooting.

Chang Jung-kung, a spokesman for the KMT said his party regrets the council's decision, adding that the government's all-out effort to disrupt the investigation of the shooting only fuels the public's suspects that the shooting was a political scheme.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 16, or the fifth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar canlendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:

1922: Tu Tsung-ming is granted a medical doctorate at the Kyoto University, becoming the first Taiwanese to gain the doctorate during the Japanese colonial period.
1949: Chinese Communist Chairman Mao Zedong visits Soveit Union for the first time.
1962: The United States launches the "Explorer 16" satellite into orbit.
1975: Chinese Communist Central Committee Vice Chairman Kang Sheng dies in Beijing at the age of 77.
1978: The United States and mainland China announce that they will establish diplomatic relations from Jan. 1, 1979.
1988: The United States and the Palestinian Liberation Organization hold a meeting in Tunis, Tunisia, for the first time.
1991: Taiwan Provincial Government Chairman Lien Chan presides over a ceremony to inaugurate the South-Link Line of Taiwan's railway system.
1991: The Association for Ralations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), mainland Chinese quasi-official organization responsible for talks with Taiwan on cross-strait issues, is formed in Beijing.
1996: Former South Korean Presidents Chuan Doo Huan and Roo Tae Woo are sentenced life imprisonment and 17-year jail term, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WELCOMES JAPAN'S DECISION TO GRANT VISA TO FORMER ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu and Amy Huang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Thursday welcomed the decision by the Japanese government to issue a visa to former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui.
Lin Huan-chang, director of the MOFA's Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said the ministry had seen related reports and welcomed the decision.
Lin also said that Lee's trip to Japan will be private in nature and that the ministry has not helped arrange the visit.
Japanese Chief Cabinet Secretary Hiroyuki Hosoda said Thursday that the government has decided in principle to issue a tourist visa to Lee.

Hosoda said Lee requested a visa to take a sightseeing trip with his family to Japan and that the Japanese government decided to issue him a visa, which he said is not expected to affect chilled relations between Japan and mainland China in the wake of the incursion into Japanese waters by a Chinese submarine last month.

Japanese media reported that Lee and his family want to travel to hot spring areas in Japan and that the Japanese government saw no reason to deny him a visa now that Taiwan's legislative elections have concluded.

Lee had revealed in September that he hoped to go to Japan for sightseeing. Japanese officials from the Liberal Democratic Party which is friendly toward Taiwan then sounded out the Japanese government's reaction to Lee's request. The Japanese government responded by asking Lee to delay his application until after the Dec. 11 legislative elections out of concerns that the matter might affect the outcome of the elections.

Japanese media quoted government sources as saying that Japan has notified China through diplomatic channels of its decision to grant Lee a visa, and that China, which considers Lee to be an advocate of Taiwan independence, seemed to be upset by the news.
Lee's last visit to Japan was in 2001 to receive treatment for a heart condition.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUNUN HUNTERS RETURN TO DANDAH FOREST REGION AFTER 15-YEAR HIATUS
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, Dec. 16 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Four aboriginal Bunun hunters headed out on their first hunting trip in the mountains of the Dandah Forest Region in 15 years Wednesday after the Hsinyi Rural Township Office in Nantou County recently lifted a ban on hunting in the region.
Bunun tribesman Si Wen-chung and his aide set off on their four-day hunting trip into the mountainous Dandah Forest Region near an upstream location of the Chuoshuei Creek.
Prior to their departure, Si and his aide offered rice wine and betel nut to the gods, praying for a successful hunt and a safe return for themselves.
"It's like being back in the good old days, " Si said in high spirits.

Another Bunun hunter, Sung Ching-nan, and his aide started their journey from another creek. Sung, an old hand in upstream exploration and rock climbing, was set on trying his luck in areas near the water.
The prey that Si and Sung are hunting for include wild goats, Formosan sambars, Formosan Reeve's muntjacs, squirrels and several feathered species.
Sung said he doesn't expect the hunting trip to be as "thrilling" as he wants, "because there are too many restrictions and regulations."
The Bunun people, who have made the high mountains in central Taiwan their home for hundreds of years, are said to be the best hunters among the 12 officially-recognized aboriginal tribes in Taiwan.

In the past, according to the Bunun elders, hunting in the mountains was thrilling and rewarding, although there were many taboos. The taboos included continuing a hunting trip even after missing the prey with the first shot, letting a female touch the hunting weapon, eating garlic or hot chili before hunting, killing pregnant animals, and trespassing into others' hunting grounds.

The Hsinyi Rural Township Office recently lifted the hunting ban after consulting with wildlife and forestation specialists from National Taiwan Normal University (NTNU) , allowing a total of 32 aboriginal hunters to return to the mountains to hunt for a certain amount of prey in a trial period of 10 days beginning Dec. 15.

Hsinyi Rural Township Chief Tian Ping-yuan quoted NTNU academics as saying that wild animal numbers in the Dandah Forest Region have recovered over the past 15 years to the point of being able to sustain limited hunting.

However, over the past two days, wildlife conservationist groups have expressed doubts about whether the lifting of the ban is a wise move, saying that without proper protection measures, the re-opening could signal the start of an ecological catastrophe.

Brushing off such concerns, NTNU professor Wang Ying said that after six years of field studies, the researchers found that allowing hunting on a regulated basis would not disturb the ecosystem in the mountains, given that the Bunun hunters traditionally know how to get along with the Mother Nature and given that wild animal numbers have sufficiently recovered to allow limited hunting.
Regulated hunting can also serve as a means to stem poaching and even inhumane slaughter, Wang added.

Echoing Wang's ideas, Tian said that the Hsinyi Rural Township Office may consider in the future opening the Dandah Forest Region to "paid game, " allowing hunters from other counties to hunt in the region for a fee. His office may also train rangers to offer bird-watching and animal-watching tours for ordinary tourists, Tian added.
