DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times: Nara girl's murderer calls again Message to grieving mother: Your other daughter is next The mother of a 7-year-old girl who was kidna- pped. and murdered here last month has received another email from her daughter's cell phone- apparently sent by the killer-saying her 2-year -old daughter will be next.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PAYS LAST RESPECTS TO LATE ROC FIRST LADY FAINA CHIANG

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday visited Taipei Veterans General Hospital to pay his last respects to former ROC first lady Faina Chiang who passed away at the hospital a day earlier.
Faina Chiang, widow of the late ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo, died of respiratory failure Wednesday. She was 90 years old.
In addition to President Chen, Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng, former Premier Hau Pei-tsun and former Taiwan Governor Chiu Chuang-huan also paid their respects.
Meanwhile, opposition Kuomintang Legislator John Chang, Ching-kuo's illegitimate son, said he will talk with the Chiangs to make a decision as to whether to attend Faina Chiang's funeral.
Chang said that he shares the sadness of the Chiangs and the Taiwanese people on the death of such a remarkable woman and that he misses her very much.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO SPEAK IN HONG KONG ON CHINESE URBAN CULTURE

TEXT.P: The University of Hong Kong said Thursday it will invite Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou to deliver a speech on urban cultural development next month.
A spokesman said Ma will speak on urban cultural development and the role of Chinese cities in global cultural development in the 21st century at the university Jan. 11.

According to the spokesman, Ma will make the lecture tour of Hong Kong after attending the closing ceremony for the 2005 Deaflympic Games in Melbourne, Australia. Taipei will be the host city of the next Deaflympics -- an Olympic-style sports event for the hearing-impaired -- to be held in 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKER OPPOSED INDIVIDUAL JOCKEYING FOR LEGISLATURE VICE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: An opposition People First Party (PFP) legislator Thursday expressed his opposition to any individual attempt to jockey for the position of Legislative Yuan vice speaker among his colleagues.

Lee Hung-chun voiced his opinion after some PFP legislators had proposed that the party should vie for the post of vice speaker while supporting a bid for the post of speaker by its ally, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).
The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, PFP and New Party managed to win a slim majority in the legislature in Saturday's elections by garnering 114 of 225 legislative seats.
Lee said no individual within the party should make a plan for the race until a consensus on the issue is reached within the party.
Otherwise, Lee said, it will create a negative impression that the PFP is giving its support for the KMT in exchange for the position of vice speaker.

Meanwhile, Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who has had the KMT's endorsement for his bid to run for the next speakership, said PFP Deputy Secretary-general Ma Chieh-ming has called him to express the PFP's support for his bid.
Ma did not mention anything about the candidate for vice speaker, Wang said.

Wang said it is too early to talk about whether the KMT and PFP should share the positions of speaker and vice speaker, noting that the top priority of the legislature is to pass a number of urgent bills before its term end in January.
The new legislators will be sworn in on Feb. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: ORBIS TAIWAN HELPS TRAIN 60 'SEED' EYE DOCTORS IN MYANMAR

TEXT.P: The Taiwan branch of ORBIS International has just completed an anti-blindness mission in Myanmar, successfully recovering the sight for 30-odd people and training 60 "seed" ophthalmologists.

At a news conference held at the Taipei Mayor's Residence Arts Salon to announce the achievements of the mission, Cliff Chien, executive director of ORBIS Taiwan, said that about 25 percent of the people in Myanmar are living below the poverty level, and some 250,000 of these being blind.
ORBIS International is a non-profit organization dedicated to the prevention of blindness and saving the sight of the visually impaired.

Chien said that two senior Taiwan ophthalmologists -- Dr. Liu Jung-hung, president of the Cheng Hsin Rehabilitation Medical Center, and Lu Ta-wen, chief of the Ophthalmology Department of Tri-Service General Hospital -- joined an ORBIS Flying Eye Hospital program earlier this month to help treat Burmese suffering from blindness or other vision problems.

During their stay in Myanmar Dec. 6-10, Liu and Lu performed operations to heal glaucoma and cataracts on more than 30 Burmese, including two medical doctors, and most of them have regained at least some vision, Chien said.

Liu and Lu also gave instructions to local Burmese health care workers in the treatment and prevention of blindness to enable them to become "seed" eye doctors who will in turn train other eye doctors to better care for their compatriots, Chien added.
The ORBIS Taiwan mission in Myanmar, the first of its kind, was co-sponsored by the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, according to Chien.

The Flying Eye Hospital program was also part of the annual World Sight Day activities, which have regularly been sponsored by ORBIS International, the World Health Organization (WHO), the International Agency for the Prevention of Blindness, the Lion's Club International, Rotary International and 10 other public interest organizations from around the world.

Of the 42 million people in Myanmar, about 252,000 suffer from blindness or severe vision problems. Nationwide, there are only 183 eye doctors, 32 optometrists and 150 ophthalmology nurses, Chien said.
According to Chien, there are 45 million blind people around the world and 135 million others with severe visual impairment, 90 precent of whom live in countries with inferior medical resources.

Mohan Jacob Thazhathu, chief operating officer of ORBIS International, who came to Taiwan in August for a promotional event, cited an estimate by the WHO that blindness costs society some US$25 billion every year, with Southeast Asian countries bearing approximately US$5.6 billion of that burden.
The number of people suffering from blindness in the world can be stopped from increasing further by merely investing US$200 million per year in blindness prevention and treatment programs, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 16.65 points to close at 6,019.23.
The bourse opened at 6,007 and fluctuated between 6,025.46 and 5,990.59 during trading. A total of 3.94 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$84.31 billion (US$2.59 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 1.2 percent, followed by construction issues at 1.1 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.8 percent and machinery and electronics shares at 0.4 percent.

Four other major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 1.1 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent, cement stocks at 0.4 percent and textile stocks at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 372 to 297, with 172 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIAN-TAIWAN TRADE EXCHANGES FAR BELOW POTENTIAL: IMC

TEXT.P: There is much room for India and Taiwan to further expand trade and investment exchanges, an Indian business leader said in an exclusive interview with CNA recently.

Although business has been flourishing between India and Taiwan, two-way trade between the two countries amounted to only US$1.3 billion over the past two years, said Dilip Dandekar, an Indian business leader who headed a delegation of the India Merchants' Chamber (IMC) to Taiwan Dec. 12-15 to explore the market.

India, with an abundance of computer engineers, is good at software development, while Taiwan is the world's largest manufacturer of computers, Dilip said, adding that there are great prospects for the two countries to work together in this sector.
India and Taiwan can also cooperate in other areas, including medical equipment, pharmaceuticals, auto parts and machinery, Dilip said.

He noted that, India, the world's fourth-largest economy in terms of purchasing power parity and the second fastest-growing economy, has great potential for Taiwan investment. Infrastructure development, including building of roads and ports, power generation and distribution, as well as food processing industry, are areas that are particularly suitable for Taiwan investment, he added.
Noting that both Taiwan and India cherish democracy and a market economy, Dilip said this will facilitate their cooperation in business.

However, he went on, the lack of diplomatic ties between Taipei and New Delhi has posed some difficulties for business exchanges. For example, he said, he had to turn to Taipei's representative office in New Delhi for a visa to enter Taiwan, although he and his Indian Merchants' Chamber are based in Mumbai.

Also, he said, Taiwan refuses to issue multiple entry visas to Indian people, making Taiwan relatively less attractive for Indian business people than other Asian countries such as Japan or Hong Kong.

Meanwhile, Chen Hsin-hung, a department director of the think tank Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, said that although India is a rising economy with huge market potential, most of its domestic markets remain off limits for foreign investment.

Compared with China, which is a "world factory, " India is a "world market, " Chen said. This is the reason why he has discouraged Taiwan investors from using the same business strategies that they have taken toward mainland China, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: MLB: 'Wholly Unacceptable'.
Bob DuPuy says the stadium financing plan approved by the D.C. Council "does not reflect the agreement."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Defense missile for U.S. system fails to launch.
An important test of the United States' fledgling missile defense system ended in failure early Wednesday as an interceptor rocket failed to launch on cue from the Marshall Island. After a rocket carrying a mock warhead as a target was launched from Kodiak, Alaska, the interceptor, which was intended to go aloft 16 minutes later and home in on the target 100 miles over the earth, automatically shut down because of "an unknown anomaly, " according to the Missile Defense Agency of the Defense Department. The launching which had been planned as the first full test in two years had been delayed several times because of bad weather or problems with equipment at the Pacific test range on Kwajalein Atoll, where officials must now try to determine what went wrong.
Wall Street Journal: Client comes first? On Wall Street, it isn't always so.
The National Association of Securities Dealers' regulatory arm has examined Knight's trading from the period in question, March 2001, and other periods. The incident points to one of the hardest-to- eradicate conflicts of interest on Wall Street. Securities laws generally require brokerage firms to put the client first. But it's an open secret that they or individual traders sometimes take advantage of their role as middleman to profit, at clients' expense, from what they know about clients' investing intentions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January gained five points to close at 6,020, with 21,458 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February moved up 11 points to finish at 6,029, with 30 contracts traded, while March futures gained five points to finish at 6,005, with nine contracts traded.
June futures gained 23 points to finish at 5,995, with 10 contracts traded, while September futures moved down three points to close at 5,920, with 12 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,015 for January, 6,018 for February, 6,000 for March, 5,972 for June and 5,923 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

January TE futures moved down 0.35 points to close at 226.35, with 4,197 contracts traded, while February TE futures gained 1.2 points to finish at 226.8, with six contract transactions. March TE futures gained 0.4 points to close at 224, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

January TF futures gained seven points to finish at 1,013, with 5,997 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved down 1.8 points to end at 1,013, with 92 contracts traded. March TF future gained 11 points to finish at 1,013, with 16 contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, dropping NT$0.107 to close at NT$32.340.
A total of US$575 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.447 and hit a low of NT$32.301.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CALLS FOR UNMASKING OF CHINA'S 'FAKE PEACE'

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged the international community Thursday to unmask what she called the "fake peace" of China.
Lu pointed out that China, while continuing its military threat against Taiwan, is planning to draw up an "anti-separatism law" in an attempt to legalize its invasion of Taiwan.
Lu made the remarks at the 10th Taipei roundtable co-organized by the Chinatrust Commercial Bank and the U.S.-based Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS).
Lu said although China has advocated a "peaceful rise, " the international community should recognize the "fake peace" of China and the "true peace" of Taiwan.
It is China's strategy to use its economic and cultural powers to force the United States' influence out of Asia under the mask of peace, Lu said.

In addition to using its military power to intimidate Taiwan, China is carrying out legal, psychological and media warfare against the island and has sent several thousand secret agents to Taiwan, according to Lu.
On the status quo of Taiwan, Lu asserted that Taiwan is a de facto independent country, regardless of what its name is.

Lu accused China of deceiving the world by claiming that Taiwan is part of China's territory, saying Resolution No. 2758 of the United Nations dealt with the U.N. representation of China but not that of Taiwan.

She called the international community's attention to the fact that a new national identity wishing for a release from the "one China spell" has been established in Taiwan over three decades of Taiwanization and democratic development.
She urged the United States to review its "one China" policy and expressed the hope that cross-Taiwan Strait relations will be normalized soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, U.S. SHOULD DEAL WITH BEIJING'S GOOD-NEIGHBOR DIPLOMACY

TEXT.P: Taiwan and the United States should deal with China's new good-neighbor diplomacy aimed at enhancing its influence in regional and global affairs, a visiting U.S. scholar said Thursday.

Gill Bates, Freeman Chair in China studies at the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), made the call in a speech delivered at an annual roundtable discussion on Taiwan-U.S.-mainland China relations and regional developments. The CSIS is a noted U.S. think tank.
Bates said mainland China has been actively promoting good-neighbor diplomacy in global and regional contexts free of U.S. factors in recent years to boost its clout in international affairs.

Its efforts have achieved remarkable results, Bates said. For instance, mainland China has pushed for the establishment of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization with Russia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan to strengthen confidence-building and disarmament in border regions.

Bates further said he was surprised by mainland China's diplomatic progress in relations with Southeast Asian nations. Bates said he originally thought that conflicts might erupt between mainland China and its Southeast Asian neighbors over South China Sea territorial disputes. However, Bates said, such scenarios didn't appear and its trade and economic relations with neighboring countries have made substantial headway.
In addition, Bates said, mainland China has projected an image in the international community of being willing to resolve disputes peacefully.

Noting that China has also expressed willingness to cooperate with other countries in military fields, Bates said its ultimate goal is to forge a non-U.S. security framework through its good-neighbor diplomacy.

Touching on Taiwan-U.S. ties, Bates acknowledged that bilateral relations truly have encountered bottlenecks recently and that the United States has strongly asked Taiwan not to try to change the present status quo across the Taiwan Strait.
Bates said although U.S.-China relations are getting increasingly close, conflicts of interest between the two countries will increase in the years ahead.

When mainland China's military strength becomes strong enough to resolve cross-strait issues, Bates said, military confrontation is likely to break out between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait because of misjudgments.

In the face of changing world situations, Bates said Taiwan should pay more heed to issues of world concern, such as anti-terrorism and anti-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. "Taiwan should show willingness to cooperate with other countries to cope with such major global challenges," he added.
The roundtable is being co-sponsored by Taipei-based Chinatrust Group and the CSIS. (By Sofia Wu) ednitem/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE DEFENSE MINISTER LOBBIES FOR PASSAGE OF ARMS PROCUREMENT BILL

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of National Defense Lei Kuang-shu visited Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng on Thursday to lobby for the quick passage of an arms procurement bill.

The piece of special legislation, governing the government's NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement from the United States, has been blocked by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party on numerous occasions.
The alliance is against the arms procurement and has insisted that the Cabinet withdraw its budget bill for the procurement before the legislature will consider the piece of legislation.
During the meeting, Lei did not promise to withdraw the budget bill as requested by the opposition.
Wang said he will consult the opinions of legislators to decide whether to call a ruling-opposition party negotiation meeting on the issue next week.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SILVER HAIR SUMMIT' DEMANDS BETTER WELFARE FOR SENIORS

TEXT.P: The government should help agencies governing social welfare and senior citizens improve their efficiency so that policies can be carried out more smoothly, participants to the fifth nationwide "silver hair summit" resolved Thursday.
The participants said that the government ought to establish an asset and property trust system for senior citizens to stem fighting among offspring even before their elders have died.

The summit, attended by about 120 senior citizens, also resolved that all the old people in the country should be treated equally and be entitled to the same retirement benefits regardless of different professions.
The summit was organized by the League of Welfare Improvement for the Elderly in the Republic of China.
League Secretary-General Wu Yu-ching said that recommendations reached during the summit will be forwarded to the Ministry of the Interior for reference.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN SPEAKER RESPECTS RULING ON '319 COMMISSION'

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday that he will respect the ruling of the Council of Grand Justices on the constitutionality of a statute governing the formation of a commission to investigate the election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian.

Wang made the remarks one day after the Council of Grand Justices, at the request of lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for an interpretation, ruled on the "319 truth investigation commission statute, " which greatly undercut the power of the commission established under the statute.

Wang said that he welcomed the part of the ruling that gives the legislature the right to form a commission to investigate the shooting, but he will have to convene a meeting between the ruling and opposition parties to discuss the other parts.

He also said that new members of the "truth commission" will have to be produced through a consultative process among the various political parties, and the names will be submitted to the Legislative Yuan for approval. The speaker only has a nominal right to appoint members, he said.

The term of the members of the current "truth commission" will run until this legislature ends on Jan. 31, and the new members of the "truth commission" will be decided by the new legislature, which will be sworn in Feb. 1.

Meanwhile, a DPP legislative whip said that the 10-member "truth commission, " which started operations in early October but had gone nowhere because the executive branch wouldn't cooperate with what it termed an "unconstitutional" body, should stop operations now that the ruling has been made official.

Legislator Tsai Huang-liang said that the DPP was gratified by the ruling of the Grand Justices, which effectively rendered the key parts of the special statute null and void, adding that the present commission should suspend operations immediately.

Responding to a call by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) for a revision of the statute, Tsai said that there will be not enough time for such a revision with the current legislative session ending on Jan. 31.
He urged the KMT and the PFP to support the DPP's own version of the statute to embark on the investigation in a legal and constitutional manner.
The KMT caucus said it will respect the ruling of the Grand Justices, but would soon submit a revision to the statute targeting those parts that the Grand Justices deemed unconstitutional.

PFP Legislator Chou Hsi-wei said the Legislative Yuan retains the right to examine documents now that it is accorded with the power to investigate after the ruling, adding that it should keep digging for information that could lead to solving the mystery of the presidential election-eve shooting.

Chou pointed out that the Grand Justices also ruled that the duties of the "truth commission" overlap with those of the Control Yuan's, and that work on a constitutional amendment should begin now to abolish the watchdog body.
PFP Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung was displeased with the ruling that reduced the "truth commission" to a body under the jurisdiction of the Legislative Yuan, instead of being an independent body.

The PFP and the KMT will ask for Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang to convene a coordination meeting among the parties and will not rule out a "radical approach" to dealing with the situation, Liu said, he didn't elaborate.

According to the ruling of the Grand Justices, the commission should be made into a special commission under the jurisdiction of the Legislative Yuan. The commission can exercise its investigative rights on issues that it is concerned about, but it will not have the same powers as those of civilian and military prosecutors in carrying out investigations.

Several paragraphs of Article Eight of the special statute, which the current commission members consider to be paramount in carrying out an independent investigation, such as no individuals or government organizations may invoke any legal protection to exempt themselves from giving testimony, handing over documents or extending assistance to the commission, were also deemed to be unconstitutional.

The paragraphs of Article 13 that gave investigators recruited by the commission the power to prosecute persons suspected to be involved in the shooting were also ruled unconstitutional by the Grand Justices.

DOC.HEADLINE: '319 COMMISSION' TO CONTINUE OPERATIONS DESPITE SETBACK: STATEMENT

TEXT.P: A commission set up to investigate the March 19 presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian issued a statement Thursday that it will continue its operations despite a ruling by the Council of Grand Justices that reduced it to little more than an ceremonial body.

The statement by the "319 truth investigation commission" came one day after a ruling by the Council of Grand Justices which was considered to have greatly undercut the powers of the commission, which began operations in early October.
The commission said the ruling of the Grand Justices runs counter to the five-branch government system under the ROC Constitution, and may have unleashed a constitutional crisis.

It said that when the commission was formed, it was modeled on the Warren Commission in the United States which was to investigate the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, or an independent body, not as a body under the jurisdiction of the Legislative Yuan according to the ruling of the Grand Justices.

It pointed out that the ruling has circumvented a constitutional amendment procedure to bestow comprehensive investigation rights to the Legislative Yuan, which under the present Constitution is non-existent.

Under the present five-branch government system, the right of investigation belongs to the Control Yuan, the statement said. For this reason, the ruling has infringed on the rights of the Control Yuan, adding that the investigation into gross dereliction on the part of the government will now be divided between two government agencies.

The commission said that the ruling by the Grand Justices has overstepped their authority under the Constitution, and this has not only obstructed the investigation of the shooting, but may also trigger a constitutional crisis.

The commission concluded by saying that despite the setbacks encountered by all members since its inauguration, it will continue to operate in view of the public's expectation that the truth must come out.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Yukos Files for Bankruptcy in Houston.
Yukos has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the United States and called on a Houston court judge during emergency hearings Wednesday for a last-minute stay of the sale of Yuganskneftegaz.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUDGET AIRLINE FLIGHT LANDS IN TAIPEI FROM SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: JetStar Asia, a budget air carrier based in Singapore, began regular flight services between Taipei and Singapore Thursday.

JetStar Asia executives said the air carrier offers ticket prices 20 percent and 40 percent cheaper than traditional air carriers. A special price of NT$1,788 (US$55) is being offered during the first week of flight services on the route.
As Singapore is currently on school holidays, the inaugural flight to Taipei was fully booked, while Taipei-Singapore route was 80 percent full.

The executives said that reservations for the seats are mostly done via the Internet, and extra charges will be added for booking tickets through passenger service centers or specific travel agencies.

The airline, which is scheduled to open a Singapore-Kaohsiung route in the first half of 2005, announced the launch of flight services on the Singapore-Hong Kong route Dec. 13 and will open a Singapore-Pattaya route Dec. 17.
The opening of the no-frills budget air carrier was a new experience to most Taiwan passengers, and has already triggered a looming air-ticket price war between air carriers in Taiwan and Singapore.

Singapore Airlines now offers a promotional round-trip air ticket of NT$1,688 until the end of next March, although the seats available will be limited, but China Airlines will unveil its promotional project in the next few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER PROPOSES BOOSTING POWER OF LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng proposed Thursday a revision to the Law Governing Legislators' Exercise of Power to beef up the investigative power of the legislature according to the latest interpretation by the Council of Grand Justices.

Wang was referring to the interpretation released a day earlier on the constitutionality of a statute governing the formation of the so-called "truth investigation commission" aimed at probing the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian.

According to the interpretation, the legislature's investigative power is not confined to accessing government materials, and it should also include the right of the legislature to require the attendance and testimony of witnesses.

Saying the interpretation is most welcomed by the legislature, Wang suggested that the law be revised to include a special chapter on investigative power to specify the legislature's right to hold policy and legislative hearings.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SCHOLAR SEES WINDOW OF OPPORTUNITY IN CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: A visiting U.S. scholar said Thursday he sees a "window of opportunity" in relations across the Taiwan Strait, even though cross-strait ties are not in a state of "perfect calm."

Gerrit Gong, a research fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) , a noted U.S. think tank, made the remarks at a roundtable discussion in Taipei co-sponsored by the CSIS and the Taipei-based Chinatrust Holding Group.

After both President Chen Shui-bian and U.S. President George W. Bush won re-election, Gong said the development of triangular Taiwan-U.S.-mainland China relations will hinge on flexibility shown by all three parties.

Gong predicted that there will be a "window of opportunity" for improving cross-strait relations in the coming two years and said the top leaders on both sides should grasp this opportunity to resolve their disputes with creative and ingenious initiatives.

Feasible measures, he said, include expanding exchanges, gradual cooperation in military affairs, formation of a task force to work out a code of conduct, and formulation of a policy framework to enhance transparency and clarify the "one China" definition.

He further said the United States should play a more active role in pushing the two sides to conduct direct dialogue. With Taiwan gradually losing its bargaining chips, Gong said, the country's senior officials should exercise more prudence in deeds and rhetoric to avoid provoking Beijing.
While Taiwan should participate in international activities, Gong said, it should avoid extremism in its moral appeal to prevent any possible "moral hazard."
Acknowledging that Taiwan-U.S. relations were hurt by rhetoric and moves made by certain Taiwan officials in the past year, Gong said Taiwan should take steps to mend the rifts and rebuild trust.

As to Taiwan's arms procurement plan, Gong said modernization of Taiwan's military arsenals is in U.S. interests, but he added that Taiwan's security also relies on several other critical factors, including domestic political stability, cross-strait relations and economic growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO INJECT LARGE FUNDS INTO NANOTECHNOLOGY PROJECTS: VP

TEXT.P: The Taiwan authorities are planning to spend NT$21.5 billion (US$663.27 million) over six years on a national project to develop the nanotechnology and relevant industries, Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday.

Addressing the 2004 Taiwan Chemical Technology Forum at the Taipei International Convention Center, Lu said the goal of the project is to create an output value of NT$300 billion in the nanotechnology industry by 2008, with more than 800 companies in the business, while by 2012, the output will expand to NT$1 trillion, with over 1,500 companies in the sector.
The project is expected to help local industries to upgrade or transform and to further sharpen Taiwan's national competitiveness, she noted.

In her speech, the vice president pointed out that Taiwan is now in good shape in terms of technological development compared with other countries in the world, quoting the 2004 global competitiveness report of the Switzerland-based World Economic Forum, which put Taiwan in first place in Asia and second in the world in terms of national competitiveness in technological manufacture and research.

Despite the achievement, Lu said, Taiwan must still try to seek advanced development to maintain its competitiveness. She raised the island's chemical technology industry as an example, saying that the sector's output has amounted to NT$2.2 trillion, a figure that makes the sector one of the country's most important basic industries.

The industry is closely connected to a broad spectrum of manufacturing sectors, including petrochemicals, plastics, rubber, high-tech textiles, chemical textiles, high-tech electronics and semiconductors, Lu said, noting that the sectors' demand for key chemical raw materials is expected to reach NT$600 billion by 2006.

However, the nation should not content itself with the optimistic prospects and in the face of stronger competition in the international market, the chemical technology industry should still think of the possibility of transforming, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL MARKS 45TH ANNIVERSARY WITH ROSY PROSPECTS

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) held a celebration at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Thursday to mark the carrier's 45th anniversary, CAL officials said Thursday.
The celebration was attended by CAL Chairman Chiang Yao-chung, General Manager Philip Wei, and Chang Kuo-cheng, director general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, the officials said.

In spite of high oil prices and the threat of terrorism, Chiang said, CAL's financial surplus for the year is expected to increase, primarily due to the staff's assiduous efforts. Securing flight safety, offering creative services and tightening cost controls are three of the best ways to boost CAL's global competitiveness, Chiang added.

Meanwhile, Wei said CAL is scheduled to begin offering flight services from Taipei to Vienna and Auckland next year and that five new Airbus jetliners and five new Boeing jetliners will begin operations next year, bringing the fleet to 67 airplanes in operation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAY NOT FOLLOW U.S. ON INTEREST RATES: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan is not likely to follow the U.S. move to raise its key interest rates, as the country's inflationary pressure has been eased due to an appreciating local currency, according to a domestic economist.

Wu Tsai-i, vice chairman of the Taiwan Research Institute, said that the central bank is not expected to follow the interest rate hike made by the U.S. Federal Reserve Wednesday on the grounds that Taiwan has avoided the threat of inflation due to the strengthening of the new Taiwan dollar on a weakening U.S. dollar.

If the Central Bank of China (CBC) thinks bringing down inflationary pressure by maintaining the local currency at a relevantly high value is a sound measure, it undoubtedly will not make any increase to its key interest rates, Wu pointed out.
The U.S. Federal Reserve lifted its key interest rates by a quarter percentage point to 2.25 percent a day earlier, the fifth hike since the beginning of this year, to stem inflation.
Wu based his argument on economic forecasts that oil prices and consumer product prices in the international market will fall next year as a result of a slowed global economic upturn.

He elaborated that Taiwan's wholesale price index and consumer price index for 2005 are estimated to grow at an average of 2.04 percent and 1.61 percent, respectively, down from this year's average of 7.04 percent and 1.68 percent.
A stronger new Taiwan dollar will reduce import product prices, and helping choking inflationary pressure at home.
On the other hand, an appreciating local currency will eat up earnings made by Taiwan businesses, he said.

If the Japanese yen can maintain its value at 100 to US$1 next year and mainland China's renminbi appreciates moderately by only 5 percent, it would be easier for the CBC to hold out against appreciating pressure on the local currency by keeping the bottom line at NT$31 to US$1 despite a sound economy that will push up its currency, he explained.
Taiwan's economy is predicted to expand by 5.95 percent for the whole of 2004, while the mainland and Japanese economies are forecast to grow by 9.1 percent and 4.1 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN COMPANIES RESPOND KEENLY TO TAIWAN INVESTMENT CALL: MOEA

TEXT.P: German companies have responded favorably to invitations from Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh to invest in Taiwan by displaying keen interest in opening research hubs here and forging two-way cooperation, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Thursday.

The MOEA made the comment in a press release. Ho is currently visiting Germany, her first trip to Europe since assuming the post, to court investment in line with the Cabinet's flagship "two-star, two-trillion" project aimed at strengthening Taiwan's promising high technologies, such as the biotechnology, nanotechnology and digital content industries.
According to the MOEA, Ho is planning to visit Leybold, AFC, Merck, Festo, Trumpf, Bosch, Schering, Landesbank Baden-Wuerttemberg and Dr. Willmar Schwabe.

So far, AFC has promised to build a new production plant next year at the Tainan Science Industrial Park in southern Taiwan, while Merck will invest NT$900 million (US$27.7 million) in setting up a research and development center in the Kuanying Industrial District in northern Taoyuan County, the MOEA said.
Ho also invited Dr. Willmar Schwabe and Landesbank Baden-Wuerttemberg to send officials to study the investment climate in Taiwan, as the two companies have not spelled out investment projects.
The economic affairs minister flew to Germany Dec. 11 from the United States and is slated to return to Taiwan Dec. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 DEAFLYMPIC LOGO, MASCOT UNVEILED

TEXT.P: The Taipei green tree frog -- a species endemic to Taiwan -- has been selected as the 2009 Deaflympics mascot, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou announced Thursday.

Ma made the announcement at a news conference where scores of children from a municipal kindergarten dressed up as tree frogs and performed frog-like dances to celebrate the selection of the indigenous animal as the Deaflympics mascot.
Ma said the slender, delicate tree frog was selected for its lovely appearance and skill at hopping and walking on walls.

Noting that the Deaflympics is an Olympic-style sports event for the hearing-impaired, Ma said the tree frog mascot symbolizes deaf athletes' self-confidence and perseverance in pursuing honor and excellence on the sports field.
Also unveiled was the 2009 Deaflympics logo -- red and blue logo featuring a running man.
Acknowledging that hosting the Deaflympics is a great challenge for the Taipei city government, Ma said his administrative team has begun various preparatory work.

He said he will head a delegation of municipal officials to Melbourne, Australia next month to attend the closing ceremony of the 2005 Deaflympics. "We hope to learn from Australia's experience, " Ma said.

According to Ma, the government will have to spend a large sum of money hosting the 2009 Deaflympics, adding that major sporting facilities for the athletic meet will be completed in the next few years.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR SIGNS PLEDGE TO MAKE TAIPEI CITY `VIGOROUS AND HEALTHY'

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou signed a declaration Thursday vowing to make the largest city in Taiwan a vigorous and healthy metropolis at the closing ceremony of an international healthy city seminar.

Witnessed by 21 scholars from 14 cities around the world, municipal bureau chiefs and representatives from the private sector, Ma inked the international pledge and officially inaugurated a "healthy city" Web site for Taipei at the end of the two-day seminar at the Grand Hotel -- a global event in line with the Healthy City Project affiliated to the World Health Organization.

It was the first time Taipei had held such an activity, which will help the city connect more closely with the rest of the world in this regard, according to a spokesman for the Taipei city government.

Dr. Trevor Hancock of Canada claimed that Taipei possesses key elements to become a healthy and vigorous city. People exercising in the morning and enthusiastic shoppers at night markets gave him a strong feeling about the vigor and strength of the city, he said.

Pointing out that building a healthy city is a continuing process that has no stopping point, Hancock stressed that the medical care system, environmental protection, education and traffic are also vital factors in a so-called healthy city.

A convenient traffic network helps boost people-to-people exchanges, while reduction in environmental and noise pollution are extremely important in maintaining citizens' mental and physical condition, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSPECTS FOR CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS GROWING DIM: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Thursday that the prospects for opening two-way, non-stop charter flights across the Taiwan Strait during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday have grown dim.

Wu made the remarks after mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office sternly criticized President Chen Shui-bian a day earlier and gave a lukewarm response to a question about whether Beijing will allow direct cross-strait charter flights during the forthcoming Chinese New Year holiday to facilitate the return of a large number of Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland, commonly known as "Taishang," for family reunions.

Noting that the mainland interpreted the results of Taiwan's just-concluded legislative elections, in which the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its pro-independence allies failed to win a majority, as a success of its containment policy against the DPP administration, Wu said he is not optimistic about the prospects for a resumption of cross-strait talks any time soon.

He added that he is also pessimistic about the possibility of opening the special charter flight services for "Taishang" during the Chinese New Year holiday, which falls between Feb. 6 and Feb. 13, 2005.

With Beijing's consent, Taiwan carriers operated special charter flights between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau during the 2003 Chinese New Year period. The services were not offered during the 2004 Chinese New Year holiday because Beijing insisted that mainland carriers also be allowed to provide the same flight services but refused to negotiate the necessary technical details with Taiwan.
The ROC government said that as the opening of two-way, non-stop cross-strait charter flight services involves the exercise of public authority, prior negotiations are necessary.

Taiwan has unveiled principles and a feasible consultative formula for holiday charter flight negotiations. However, Beijing has so far not made any positive response to Taiwan's repeated calls for negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: NYUST PRESIDENT TO HEAD APIEM 2007-2008

TEXT.P: National Yunlin University of Science and Technology (NYUST) President Lin Tsong-ming has been elected chairman of the Asia-Pacific Conference on Industrial Engineering and Management Systems (APIEM) for 2007-2008, according to a news release issued Thursday by the university.

Lin was nominated by incumbent APIEM Chairman Mitsuo Gen of Japan's Waseda University to head the organization for 2007-2008 in the just-concluded 2004 APIEM held in Gold Coast, Australia Dec. 12-15, and the nomination was approved unanimously by the directors and supervisors of the organization, NYUST officials said.

The conference is aimed at providing a forum for the exchange of ideas on the latest developments in industrial engineering and management systems and to seek opportunities for collaboration among the participants.
During his stay in Australia, Lin also visited Queensland University of Technology to promote cooperation and exchanges between the two universities, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN KEEN ON PROMOTING WOMEN'S RIGHTS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan called a meeting Thursday on the promotion of women's rights and issues, hoping to increase Taiwan's visibility on the world stage through upgrading women's status and gender equality.

Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan chaired the inter-ministerial meeting, in which it was decided that the functions of a panel under the Executive Yuan dedicated to women's issues at the activities held by the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum will be expanded in an international context so as to help boost Taiwan's international presence.
According to Yeh, women's issues are the world's mainstream agenda. Taiwan's efforts in advocating women's rights and status should be made known to the world, she said.

Citing the results of a recent investigation by a private human rights group in Taiwan, she reported that the country has made noticeable progress in improving women's issues and sex equality by scoring a passing mark of 60 points in women's rights this year for the first time.
The central government has allocated a combined budget of NT$4.72 billion (US$145.3 million) for women-related activities for 2005, up from the 2004 level of NT$3.61 billion, she noted.

In addition to APEC, the United Nations and many other world bodies and non-governmental organizations are paying a higher degree of attention to women's issues nowadays, a development which would allow Taiwan to share its experience more actively in this field with other countries, Executive Yuan officials said.
Missions of the newly expanded Executive Yuan panel will be convened by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of the Interior will assist the panel in carrying out operations, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-MARSHALL ISLANDS RELATIONS TO BE STRENGTHENED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian pledged Thursday to further promote cooperation and relations between Taiwan and the Marshall Islands.

Speaking at a state banquet he hosted to entertain his Marshall Islands counterpart Kessai Note in Taitung, eastern Taiwan, Chen said that Taiwan and the South Pacific island nation have many common characteristics and should increase cooperation and exchanges for their mutual benefit.
In response, Note thanked Chen for inviting him to visit Taiwan again and said that he is pleased to see that the relations between the two nations have been strengthened over the years.
He assured Chen that the relations will get even closer.

Accompanied by Chen, Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, Note also visited various cultural and economic establishments in Taitung, including the National Prehistory Museum and aboriginal tribes.
Note arrived in Taiwan Tuesday for a five-day official visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 17, or the sixth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1888: The Ching dynasty establishes its Peiyang (northern) navy and appoints Ting Ju-chang as the admiral.
1891: Hu Shih, a noted Chinese scholar who proposed that literature be written in the vernacular language rather than in the classical style, is born in Shanghai.
1902: Classes begin for the first time at National Peking University, China's first university and most prestigious institution of higher education.
1903: American aviation pioneer Orville Wright and his brother Wilbur make the world's first successful sustained flight in a heavier-than-air vehicle, which they invented, flying over sand dunes near Kitty Hawk, North Carolina.
1919: Pierre Auguste Renoir, French impressionist painter whose warm luminous works include "Child with Watering Can" and "Luncheon of the Boating Party," dies at the age of 78.
1925: The Anping Canal in Tainan, southern Taiwan is inaugurated.
1941: Japanese forces invade North Borneo during World War II.
1948: The Dutch attack Indonesia and arrest President Sukarno and other leaders.
1949: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China announces the severing of diplomatic relations with Burma.
1957: The United States successfully test-launches its first intercontinental ballistic missile.
1967: Australian Prime Minister Harold Holt disappears while swimming at Portsea, Victoria.
1968: The Chinese National Committee of the International Press Institute is established in Taipei.
1971: Pakistan and India end a two-week war over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1971: The International Commercial Bank of China (formerly the Bank of China) is inaugurated, becoming a complete private enterprise.
1973: Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez, Costa Rican speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1973: Denzo Okubo, president of the Federation of the Japan-ROC Association, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: Economics Minister Y. S. Sun and Korean Deputy Premier Nam Duck Woo sign a joint communique calling for further economic cooperation.
1975: A boxing tournament opens at the Tainan City Gymnasium, with boxers from the Philippines, South Korea, Japan and the ROC competing.
1978: More than 5,000 people stage an angry protest outside the U.S. embassy in Taipei.
1979: Tsiang Yien-si succeeds Chang Pao-shu as the secretary-general of the Central Committee of the Kuomintang.
1986: The 1986 Nobel Prize winner in chemistry, Lee Yuan-tseh, a member of the Academia Sinica, returns to the ROC. Lee and his wife are received by President Chiang Ching-kuo on Dec. 18.
1986: New Costa Rican Ambassador to the ROC Ruben Acon Leon calls on President Chiang Ching-kuo to present his credentials.
1989: Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, who succeeded Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell as commander of the U.S. forces in China during World War II, dies in Washington D.C.
1991: Boris Yeltsin and Mikhail Gorbachev agree to dissolve the Soviet Union and proclaim a new commonwealth on New Year's Day.
1993: Lee Yuan-tseh succeeds Wu Ta-you, becoming the 7th president of the Academia Sinica.
1996: The Ching dynasty's last eunuch Sun Yao-ting dies in Beijing at the age of 93.
1997: A treaty eradicating bribery in international business is signed by the representatives of 34 countries.
1999: Mandarin Airlines, a subsidiary of the Republic of China's former flag carrier China Airlines, opens direct flights between Taipei and Thailand's northern city of Chiang Mai.
2000: Ten king penguins from the United States arrive in Taipei. They are introduced into Taiwan by the Taipei Zoo.
2001: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan meets with about 100 party representatives from Japan's Tokyo and Yokohama areas over a dinner in Tokyo.
2001: Five Japanese Lower House members belonging to the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) arrive in Taipei for a three-day visit at the invitation of the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Confucius: "A wise man will not make himself into a mere machine fit only to do one kind of work. A wise and good man is one who acts before he speaks, and afterwards speaks according to his actions. A wise man is impartial, not neutral. A fool is neutral but not impartial."

DOC.HEADLINE: RENOWNED FORENSIC EXPERT IN TOWN

TEXT.P: Renowned Chinese-American forensic expert Henry Lee arrived in Taiwan from New York Friday for an eight-day visit.

Lee said that he has come at the invitation of the Bureau of Investigation under the Ministry of Justice (MJIB) , and that the visit is mainly to prepare for an international forensic meeting to be held in Taiwan next year.
The meeting will discuss the implications of the latest high-tech advancements on the field of forensic science as well as international trends in the field, he said.

Lee, who conducted a forensic investigation into the March 19 election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu in the summer, said that if time permits, he will also visit the Criminal Investigation Bureau to learn the latest developments in the case.

Noting that an underground gunsmith has recently been detained by the investigation team for making firearms and bullets, one of which grazed President Chen's abdomen and lightly injured him, Lee said that the team has found key evidence in the case after sifting through myriads of seemingly unrelated things, which he said is a "breakthrough."

Pointing out that a forensic investigator starts by collecting physical evidence, then gathers clues which lead to suspects, and then determines the motives in a case, Lee said he was glad to learn that Taiwan's investigation team has proceeded along this path in its probe.

Lee urged those who have purchased the guns from the underground gunsmith to come forward and cooperate with the authorities, and called for the government to offer amnesty to those who give themselves up. He said that questioning those who have bought the guns may lead to the apprehension of the person or persons involved in the assassination attempt in Tainan, southern Taiwan.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party has said that the shooting incident won sympathy votes for President Chen and unfairly swayed the election outcome in Chen's favor. Chen beat his rival, KMT Chairman Lien Chan, by a slim margin in the election.

Sources said that members of the investigation team are expected to meet with Lee during his stay in Taiwan, and if necessary, physical evidence, including remodeled bullets, will be given to Lee to take back to the United States for further examination.
Lee is scheduled to take part in an activity introducing his forensic works in Shihlin, Taipei, Dec. 19. The activity is being sponsored by the National Taiwan Science Education Center.
Lee, who is a graduate of Central Police University in 1959, will also return to his alma mater to give a speech Dec. 20.
He will then shuttle between Taipei and Hualien Dec. 21-23 to attend meetings to prepare for the international forensic conference in Taiwan next year. He is scheduled to leave Taiwan Dec. 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: BALL IN BEIJING'S COURT ON CROSS-STRAIT FLIGHTS DURING NEW YEAR: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan has made its stance explicitly clear on cross-strait charter flights for the Chinese New Year holiday period, and the ball is now in Beijing's court as to whether such flights will materialize, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Friday.

Taiwan has unveiled a set of principles and a feasible consultative formula for holiday charter flight negotiations. However, Beijing has so far not made any positive response to Taiwan's repeated calls for negotiations, Chiu said.
Whether the two-way, non-stop charter flights across the Taiwan Strait during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday can be implemented hinges on Beijing's willingness, he said.

Chiu noted that the MAC convened a meeting Nov. 12 with representatives from six major industrial and business associations in Taiwan on issues concerning the Chinese New Year charter flights, adding that the MAC values the entrepreneurs' opinions and heeds them when formulating related policies.
Chiu also once again urged Beijing to heed the will of the Taiwan people.
Chiu's remarks came a day after MAC Chairman Joseph Wu said that the prospects of cross-strait charter flights being implemented have grown dim.

Wu made the remarks after mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office sternly criticized President Chen Shui-bian a day earlier and gave a lukewarm response to a question about whether Beijing would allow direct cross-strait charter flights during the forthcoming Chinese New Year holiday to facilitate the return of large numbers of Taiwan businesspeople operating on the mainland for family reunions.

Noting that Beijing interpreted the results of Taiwan's just-concluded legislative elections, in which the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its pro-independence allies failed to win a majority, as a success of its containment policy against the DPP administration, Wu said he is not optimistic about a resumption of cross-strait talks any time soon.
He added that he is also pessimistic about the possibility of opening the special charter flight services during the Chinese New Year holiday, which falls between Feb. 6 and Feb. 13 in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC AFFAIRS MINISTER MEETS WITH GERMAN COUNTERPART IN BERLIN

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-Yueh on Wednesday paid an official visit to German Economic and Labor Affairs Minister Wolfgang Clement in Berlin and exchanged views with him on possible cooperation between the two countries in various industrial fields.

Ho, who is currently heading a delegation to seek cooperation and business opportunities in Germany, said that her meeting with the German minister is significant since bilateral meetings between ROC and German economics ministers had been suspended for two-and-half years.

During the meeting, Ho said that she not only expressed Taiwan's hope of having further cooperation with Germany in the fields of wind power and solar energy, but also discussed ideas of cooperation in the bio-technology and auto spare parts sectors, as well as voiced Taiwan firms' willingness to participate in Airbus' manufacturing.

She also paid official visits the same day to German Acting Minister of Environment Affairs Margareta Wolf and Transportation Minister Manfred Stolpe and discussed with them the feasibility of cooperation between the two countries in various fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SECURITY DRAWS GERMANY'S ATTENTION
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Dec. 16 (CNA) (By Y.L. Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Several members from the ruling and opposition parties in the German Bundestag voiced in a parliamentary debate Wednesday their concerns about Beijing's military threat against Taiwan, demonstrating that the island's security has drawn the attention of the German government and people.

The Bundestag held the debate on German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's request that the European Union lift its arms embargo against mainland China. The E.U. imposed a ban on arms sales to China shortly after the Tiananmen Square Massacre in 1989.

During the debate, Hermann Groehe, a parliamentarian from the main opposition Christian Democratic Union, criticized Schroeder's request, saying that China has 600 missiles aimed at Taiwan and that under such circumstances, any intention of selling weapons to China is irresponsible.

Pointing out that Taiwan is a nation based on the rule of law and democracy and that China can still obtain weapons from other countries despite the fact that it is not a democratic country, a parliamentarian from the opposition Liberal Democrats, said that one should first consider what kind of signal would be sent to Taiwan by lifting the arms sales ban against China.

Lamwaker Winfried Nachiwei, of the Green Party, which is part of the ruling coalition, said that the European Union should not increase tensions in the Taiwan Strait or help China to strengthen its military force as Beijing has still not renounced the option of the use of force against Taiwan.

Defending Schroeder's request, a senior member of the ruling Social Democrats caucus in the Bundestag, said that besides human rights, regional stability and security are also important elements in the current revised E.U. draft of code of conduct for arms exports, and therefore, Taiwan will be included in it.

The E.U. will also take into account the security of its allies and friendly countries, he further said, adding that it is impossible that the E.U. will export a large quantity of arms to China after a lifting of the ban.

Meanwhile, Hans Martin Bury, German minister of state at the foreign office, also reiterated in the debate that the German government has continuously asked Beijing and Taipei to avoid escalating cross-Taiwan Strait tensions, promising that Germany will not sell arms to countries in regions where a high-level of tension exists.
Touching on issues related to Taiwan's Dec. 11 legislative elections, Bury said that the elections results have helped reduce cross-strait tensions.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC GOVERNOR DENIES BEING LEADING CANDIDATE FOR PREMIERSHIP

TEXT.P: Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Perng Fai-nan on Friday denied rumors that he is likely to be named by President Chen Shui-bian as the next premier.
The academic-turned-banker said at the Legislative Yuan that he has not met with President Chen recently nor has heard anything about a new assignment.

Perng made the remarks in response to a question raised by Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Lin Chih-lung about the veracity of the rumors that the CBC governor and Finance Minister Lin Chuan are two leading candidates to replace Premier Yu Shyi-kun in a possible Cabinet reshuffle in the near future.
According to the rumors, President Chen is aiming to select a technocrat with a strong background in finance or economics with no particular political affiliation to be the next premier.
