DOC.HEADLINE: NO PROBLEMS WITH ROC-HAITI RELATIONS: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 16 (CNA) (By M.H. Huang and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top envoy in Haiti guaranteed Thursday that relations between the two countries remain stable despite the fact that Beijing has sent its ambassador to the United Nations to visit the Caribbean country.

Noting that he knew about the meeting that day between Beijing Ambassador to the U.N. Wang Quang-yi and Haitian officials, Ambassador Hsieh Hsing-ping said the main issues they discussed were related to cooperation between mainland peace-keeping police stationed there and local government.

Although topics regarding mainland-Haiti relations were also mentioned during the meeting, Hsieh said he was guaranteed by the Haitian government after the meeting that diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Haiti remain sound.
He also guaranteed that bilateral relations will remain unchanged as long as he remains ambassador.

According to Hsieh, except for a trade mission to Haiti and an inspection of peace-keeping troops in 1998, no other mainland diplomats have been allowed to visit Haiti. Wang, who arrived in the capital of Port au Prince Tuesday to inspect the troops, was scheduled to leave Friday.

Touching on ROC-Haiti relations, Hsieh said that the two countries have very close cooperation, adding that Taiwan has recently helped Haiti to construct a national medical examination center, a health center, a market and a 26-km road. The country also made donations to Haiti after it was hit by Typhoon Jenny earlier this year.
He further noted that Taiwan and Haiti have maintained very close cooperative relations and that no Haitian officials have visited the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACAU URGED TO FACILITATE EXCHANGES WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) called for the Macau government Friday to facilitate exchanges between Taiwan and Macau in a pragmatic manner.

In an analysis of the development and prospects of Taiwan-Macau relations five years after the former Portuguese enclave returned to mainland Chinese rule, MAC officials urged both Beijing and Macau to reduce exchange and communication barriers so that interactions between Taiwan and Macau can be accelerated based on the existing framework.
MAC officials appealed to the Macau government to raise the administrative level of the agency in charge of Taiwan affairs and related communications.
MAC officials also called for the Macau authorities to push for closer cooperation with Taiwan, efforts that would include considering the establishment of a Macau representative office in Taiwan.
They said that bilateral exchanges between Taiwan and Macau have gradually heated up in recent years since Taiwan adopted a series of policies to facilitate interaction.

These policies include Taiwan's decision to issue from February 2003 travel documents to Macau citizens and foreign nationals from Macau planning to visit Taiwan; that Taiwan has twice, in 2001 and 2002, relaxed regulations on 14-day stays for Macau citizens; and that Taiwan is scheduled to open cyber applications beginning Jan. 1, 2005 for visas to Macau citizens wishing to visit Taiwan, MAC officials said.

They added that Macau and Taiwan people have exchanged visits frequently, with Taiwan visitors to Macau ranking the third-highest in terms of arrival number. Quoting tallies from the Bureau of Immigration, MAC officials said that more than 915,000 Taiwan citizens visited Macau in the first 11 months of this year, up a whopping 19 percent over the year-earlier level, while some 17,000 Macau citizens traveled to Taiwan during the same period, up 6 percent.

The analysis also points out that Beijing has established an affiliate of the China Council for Promoting Peaceful Reunification in Macau, which Macau Chief Executive Edmund Ho and other elite members in the special district have supported.
This shows that Beijing is now using Macau as another important arm in its united front efforts toward Taiwan, according to MAC officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 9.91 points to close at 6,009.32.
The bourse opened at 6,019.8 and fluctuated between 6,028.75 and 6,002.39. A total of 3.08 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$60.21 billion (US$1.86 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 2.7 percent, followed by cement stocks at 2.2 percent, textile stocks at 1 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.1 percent.

Three other major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down at 0.5 percent and paper and pulp issues and banking and financial shares both moving down at 0.1 percent.
Foodstuff issues remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 373 to 295, with 175 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRMS HIRING DISABLED WORKERS ENTITLED TO GOVERNMENT GRANTS

TEXT.P: Local companies hiring disabled workers are entitled to government grants of up to NT$60,000 per employee in a nine-month period, sources from the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) reported Friday.

The CLA made public Friday a preliminary plan on subsidies to businesses that hire physically challenged citizens, in an effort to encourage the private sector to help improve treatment of the disabled and to provide them with better access to jobs.

According to the plan, a company hiring disabled workers can apply to the government for up to NT$10,000 per month for each worker in the first three months of employment. The grants will be halved to NT$5,000 from the fourth month of employment.

The NT$5,000 subsidy plan is applicable for six months, meaning that the company can apply for subsidies totaling NT$30,000 in six consecutive months, boosting the total of government grants up to NT$60,000 in nine months for each disabled worker.
The plan is scheduled to be implemented in January 2005, but with the number of beneficiaries restricted to 210 nationwide, CLA officials said.
The disabled who are first time job seekers or who have been unemployed for a long time will be considered on a priority basis, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARSHALL ISLANDS GOVERNMENT MODEL IS FOR PUBLIC REFERENCE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's proposal to change the government system to one similar to the parliamentary-presidential system of the Marshall Islands is only a constitutional amendment idea for public reference, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday.
Chen said a day earlier that the government system of the Marshall Islands, under which the president is both the head of state and head of government, might be a model that Taiwan can follow.

He pointed out that the president of the Marshall Islands is elected by the parliament with majority support from among its members, meaning that the majority party in the parliament has the right to form the government.
The proposal was put forth in response to an argument by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) that the majority in the Legislative Yuan should enjoy the right to form the Cabinet.

Yu said that any proposal for constitutional amendment must be based on a consensus among the people, noting that a consensus is still lacking in Taiwan as to whether the government system should be changed to a three-branch presidential system or a parliamentary system.
Yu said Chen's proposal should not be taken as meaning that he intends to act concurrently as premier.

In reaction, KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung claimed that the purpose of Chen raising the proposal was to turn down the KMT's suggestion for a legislative majority to form the Cabinet and insist on his "minority government."
The KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" allies, the People First Party and New Party, gained a slim majority by winning 114 of the 225 seats in the legislature in Saturday's elections.
Earlier this week, KMT Chairman Lien Chan suggested that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party should cooperate with the KMT to form a coalition government.
Chang claimed that the "Marshall Islands model" will never be accepted by the people of Taiwan because there would be no popularly elected president under the system.

Chang argued that according the Constitution, the government framework now is a semi-presidential system and he claimed that the party with majority control in the legislature has the right to name the premier.

In fact, it is the president who has the authority to name the premier. While the legislature may launch a no-confidence vote on the premier, the premier may request the president to dissolve the legislature after the passage of a no-confidence vote.
Meanwhile, Tseng Yung-chuan, head of the KMT's policy committee, said Taiwan will enter an era of dictatorship if the president is allowed to act concurrently as premier.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE PEOPLE HOPING TO CHANGE JOBS: POLL

TEXT.P: Thanks to an improved economy, more people have shown interest in changing jobs this year as the Chinese New Year holiday approaches, according to the results of a recent survey by a headhunting Web site.

As of Dec. 13 since the beginning of this year, a total of 60,547 people have logged on to www.104.com.tw seeking a job transfer after the lunar new year -- a traditional high season for people wishing to change to a new job, a Web site executive said. This year's lunar new year falls on Feb. 9.

The job seeker figure represents a marked increase over the previous year's number of about 44,000, the executive said, attributing the growth to a better domestic economy that has prompted people to search for work with better pay.
Over the past three years, a vast majority of the people wishing to change jobs were mainly employees laid off amid a serious recession.

According to the poll results, some 34.7 percent of the job seekers wish to get work in the manufacturing sector, ahead of 28.2 percent keen on an administrative job. An equal ratio of 16.2 percent expressed hope of getting a job in public relations and sales, respectively.

In terms of industry, 22.2 percent and 17.1 percent of the respondents, respectively, said they wish to join the electronics manufacturing and semiconductor sectors, while 14.2 percent and 13.6 percent, respectively, are interested in seeking a job in computer-related companies and the opto-electronics sector. Around 11 percent said they would like to have a job related to foreign trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION PARTIES PUT FORWARD NT$10,000 NATIONAL ANNUITY DRAFT

TEXT.P: Three opposition parties jointly put forward a draft bill Friday on the implementation of a NT$10,000 monthly annuity insurance for each of the country's citizens aged 65 or older.

Spokesmen for the legislative caucus of the Kuomintang (KMT), the People First Party (PFP) and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) said at a press conference at the Legislative Yuan that the three parties will jointly push for the passage of the NT$10,000 annuity bill to provide better care for the elderly, in the face of Taiwan's ageing society.
KMT legislative party whip Tseng Yung-chuan said the implementation of the program would not affect the existing implementation of the NT$3,000 senior citizen subsidy program.

After the NT$10,000 national annuity program is implemented successfully for three or five years, military, education and labor personnel who have been recipients of other insurance benefits can also be included in the program, making it a truly "national" welfare, Tseng said.
According to the program, potential recipients of the national annuity insurance should pay NT$800 per month once they join the program, with the government paying 40 percent of the amount for them.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January lost one point to close at 6,019, with 13,086 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February moved down 10 points to finish at 6,019, with 18 contracts traded, while March futures lost 10 points to finish at 6,005, with two contracts traded.
June futures lost seven points to finish at 5,988, with 17 contracts traded, while September futures moved down 17 points to close at 5,903, with 18 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,020 for January, 6,029 for February, 6,015 for March, 5,995 for June and 5,920 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
January TE futures moved down 0.7 points to close at 225.65, with 2,605 contracts traded, while February TE futures lost 0.95 points to finish at 225.5, with 10 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

January TF futures gained one point to finish at 1,014, with 3,988 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved down 0.6 points to end at 1,012.4, with 30 contracts traded. March TF future gained one point to finish at 1,012, with two contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.02 to close at NT$32.360.
A total of US$339 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.392 and hit a low of NT$32.236.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT'S JAPAN VISA APPLICATION SENT TO INTERCHANGE ASSOCIATION

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui's application for a tourist visa to Japan was accepted Friday by the Taipei office of the Interchange Association, according to an association official.
Toshio Matsumura, spokesman for the de facto Japanese embassy in Taipei, said the application will be transferred to Japan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs for processing.
He declined to disclose when the visa will be issued.
Japanese Chief Cabinet Secretary Hiroyuki Hosoda announced Thursday that Tokyo had decided in principle to issue a tourist visa to Lee.

Lee revealed in September that he hoped to go to Japan for sightseeing and the Japanese government reportedly requested him to delay his visa application until after the Dec. 11 legislative elections out of concern that his trip might influence the outcome of the elections.
Lee last visited Japan in 2001 to receive a heart by-pass surgery.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA URGES RECONSIDERATION OF REPORTED RALLY TO SUPPORT 'RICE BOMBER'

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) urged civic groups Friday not to stage a rally to lend support to the "rice bomber, " a terrorist responsible for more than a dozen bomb threats in Taipei over the past year, less they send "the wrong message" to the public.

COA Vice Chairman Lee Chien-chuan was responding to news reports that several civic groups are planning a 10,000-man rally in Erlin, in the central Taiwan county of Changhua, to support Yang Ju-men, who they believe is not a terrorist but only "a tragic figure or a sacrifice" for the government's entry into the World Trade Organization. They feel that the government should attach importance to the agricultural problems that have emerged since Taiwan's WTO entry.

The civic groups, which include the Democracy Action Alliance and Erlin Community University, also said that they plan to establish an anti-WTO action alliance and will seek to establish ties with other anti-WTO organizations around the world to highlight their cause.

Lee stressed that since Taiwan joined the WTO Jan. 1, 2002, the government has stepped up its efforts to take care of the nation's farmers to mitigate the impact of entering the WTO. In addition, Taiwan's agricultural products are being exported in ever-greater amounts.
Lee pointed out that Yang is a threat to society and that no matter what his motives are, he should be condemned by society.
The civic groups who are attempting to raise Yang's status to that of a tragic hero have distorted social values, he continued.

He said that the COA welcomes civic groups to communicate with the COA and expressed the hope that the groups will gain a better understanding as to whether WTO membership is a positive or negative factor for Taiwan.
"A rash mobilization of the people will definitely send the wrong message," Lee said.

He said that Taiwan, honoring its promise upon entering the WTO, started to import a limited amount of 144,000 tons of rice annually. But the government has in the meantime adopted several measures, including purchasing rice at guaranteed prices, subsidizing fallow land, readjusting irrigation, and increasing its purchase of domestic rice, to ease the farmers' plight.
He noted that the price of rice is currently NT$20.2 (US$0.62) per kilogram, the highest in recent years.

The effect of rising fertilizer prices has had only limited impact on the production cost of rice (adding only between NT$0.15 and NT$0.19 per kilogram) , he said, adding that the government has also immediately provided subsidies for transporting the fertilizer.

Pointing out that the WTO demands that all its members allow imports of rice and agricultural products, and that not only Taiwan, big other major rice producers such as Japan, South Korea and mainland China also import 650,000, 205,000 and 1.1 million tons of rice, respectively, every year.
Taiwan's agricultural products have had far greater global market access since the country joined the WTO, which he described as an inevitable trend.

Since November last year, Yang, who claims to oppose the government's policy of permitting rice imports, has placed home-made explosives in public areas such as parks, trains, railway stations and mobile toilets in the greater Taipei area. He is suspected of having been involved with 11 of the 16 cases discovered so far.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN TO CONTINUE TO PUSH FOR NAME-CHANGE CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday that the government will continue to push a proposal to change the names of state-owned enterprises to include the word "Taiwan."
The premier made the remarks when he was fielding questions in the Legislative Yuan.

President Chen Shui-bian recently advocated including "Taiwan" in the names of its overseas missions and state-owned enterprises to highlight a separate national identity from mainland China, although the United States does not support such a plan, believing that it would unilaterally change Taiwan's status.

The premier said that changing the names of state-owned enterprises is an internal affair and will not involve the ideology of unification versus independence, or any change of the status quo. The government will step up communications with the United States in this regard, he said.

Legislator Alex Tsai of the opposition Kuomintang also asked Perng Fai-nan, governor of the Central Bank of China, if he wants to change the name of the central bank to Central Bank of Taiwan. According to Perng, this would require "a careful study of the English translation of the bank's name." He declined to elaborate.

Although the government will continue to pursue the name-change campaign of state-owned enterprises, the premier said he will respect the decision of the private enterprises and will not force them to change the "China" aspect of their names.

Meanwhile, the premier refused to comment on whether the president will name him as the new premier. He will lead his Cabinet to resign en masse Feb. 1, the swearing-in day of the new legislature, according to practice.
Asked about possible candidates for the position, he noted that only President Chen Shui-bian has the right to appoint a premier according to the Constitution.
But he said that Presidential Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang and Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh are both old friends who are very capable and could serve well in any post.

Vice Legislative Speaker Chiang Ping-kun is also very experienced and well-rounded and as for the possibility of naming Finance Minister Lin Chuan or Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan for a financial Cabinet, the premier said only that both are experts in their respective fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4.5 MILLION TAIWAN PEOPLE LACK SENSE OF BELONGING: POLL

TEXT.P: An estimated 4.5 million people in Taiwan lack a sense of belonging and a quarter of the population feel they do not have enough time for relaxation and rest, according to the results of a survey released Friday by the Mental Health Foundation.
The 2004 mental health index survey was conducted by the foundation Nov. 2-8 among 1,083 Taiwan adults, with a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent.
The overall mental health index is 80.6, which is only slightly higher than the passing score of 80, the results show.

The survey found that over the past year, 65 percent of the respondents always or often felt that they belonged to a certain group of people such as colleagues, neighbors, classmates, friends and families.
The figure compared with 8 percent who had the feeling occasionally and 27 percent who seldom or never had such a feeling.

Based on the results, the foundation estimated that there are 4.5 million people in Taiwan who lack a sense of belonging and who, according to the foundation, are more susceptible to anxiety than others.
While 56 percent of the respondents said they always or often have enough time to relax and rest, 17 percent said they do so only occasionally, and 27 percent said they seldom or never do.
The results indicate that people with a high educational background and income and those who maintain frequent contact with their families and friends tend to have a higher sense of belonging.
Also, the sense of belonging is higher among working people and students than among jobless and retired people.

The major factors that affect mental health include economic changes, the political situation, social stability, negative news reports, public safety and terrorist activities overseas, according to the foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS TENTATIVELY APPROVE ROLE OF NATIONAL ASSEMBLY

TEXT.P: Lawmakers agreed in principle Friday on the role of a new National Assembly (NA) devised exclusively for future constitutional reforms, granting NA delegates the power to vote on amendment proposals but not the power to revise them.

The draft on the future NA functions was approved at a consultation meeting by legislators from the various political parties. The bill still has to go through a second and a third reading before it can be made into law by the Legislative Yuan.

In order to complete the legislation as soon as possible, lawmakers will continue their negotiations next week to allow the NA to start operations next year in time for the constitutional reform task.

According to the draft bill on the power and rights of the NA designed especially to carry out constitutional amendments, the NA delegates fielded by different parties must sign their names on the ballots when voting on amendment bills in compliance with their party's stance. Ballots which do not bear the names of the voters will be considered invalid.

Any constitutional revision bills put forward by the Legislative Yuan must be directly voted upon by the NA delegates without prior discussions. The bills must gain approval from more than half of the NA delegates to become law.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTION FOR DPP CHAIRMAN TO BE HELD BY END OF JANUARY

TEXT.P: A direct election for a new chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will be held by the end of January, acting DPP Chairman Ker Chien-ming said Friday.
Ker said members of the party's Central Executive Committee will meet next Tuesday to discuss related details such as the date for registration and polling.
The committee members will also discuss a revision to DPP rules on elections for party officials to add requirements for party chairman candidates, Ker said.
Another issue on the agenda is the DPP preliminary process for next year's elections for mayors and magistrates, he added.

Ker, who is whip of the DPP legislative caucus, was appointed acting chairman after President Chen Shui-bian resigned from the position on Tuesday over the DPP's worse-than-expected performance in last week's legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECORD NUMBER OF CONTESTANTS ENTER ING TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL MARATHON

TEXT.P: A record high of nearly 17,000 contestants have registered for the 2004 ING Taipei International Marathon, set for this Sunday, officials said.

A total of 16,591 people have registered for the marathon (42.195 km), half-marathon (21 km) and nine km races as of Friday, according to officials of the Taipei City Government, a main organizer of the event.
Sixteen international long-distance runners will also take part in the event, which is being held for the third year in Taipei, the officials said.
The participants are expected to hit 40,000 if including those who join the three-km fun run for which on-site registration will be accepted, they said.

The prizes for the event are also very attractive, with the champions to be awarded NT$1 million (US$30,959) if they break the 134-minute record for men and the 155-minute record for women, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF REITERATES HIS WILLINGNESS TO STEP DOWN IN AUGUST

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan reiterated his willingness Friday to quit his post as head of the party in August next year when his term expires, but refused to say who might succeed him.

"It's a promise fulfilled or good riddance, however you want to look at it, " an exultant Lien said in an interview with the media five days after his party increased its seats in the Legislative Yuan by 11. Observers had predicted that the KMT would not do nearly as well in the elections.
The KMT should institutionalize the succession of its chief to keep the party young and the process transparent, Lien said.
After stepping down, Lien said he would serve as a "lifetime volunteer" for the KMT.

He said he did not wish to play favorites between KMT vice presidents Ma Ying-jeou -- Taipei mayor, and Wang Jin-pyng -- speaker of the legislature, the two tapped as likely to succeed Lien, saying both of them are well suited for the position, "But I should remain neutral while they are vying for the chairmanship."

As to the party's possible merger with the People First Party (PFP), Lien said it was agreed by both parties before the election to merge by February, and it is the overwhelming desire of their supporters; therefore, the KMT is working toward this end.

PFP Chairman James Soong said Sunday after his party lost 12 seats in the Dec. 11 elections that merging with the KMT is out of the question for the time being. He blamed the KMT for breaking its promises to the PFP during campaigning about vote-allocation, which strengthened the KMT as the expense of the PFP.

Rebutting allegations that he refused to take Soong's phone calls during the heat of campaigning, Lien said, "There have been no problems of communication between Soong and me. The KMT's door is always open to a merger with the PFP."

Regard Soong's claims that a merger with the KMT would be impossible unless the KMT ridded itself of the political line of ex-chairman and former President Lee Teng-hui and returned its assets that where obtained illegally, Lien said the KMT's political line is totally different from Lee's. "I don't think that any of 'Lee's line' remains in the current KMT," he said.

"The KMT will dispose of its assets according to law. Anyone who challenges the KMT's ownership of any of its assets is welcome to bring legal action against the party, and the party will be more than willing to settle these disputes in court," Lien said.
However, Lien added that the Democratic Progressive Party's attempts to enact special legislation to dispossess the KMT of its assets "is unacceptable political persecution."

Lien said he supports the re-election of Legislative Yuan President Wang and Vice President Chiang Ping-kun, both of whom are members of the KMT, but added that he would speak with Soong on the matter if the PFP chairman wished to field a candidate for the vice presidency.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Donors consider large increase in air to Palestinians.
The United States, Europe and Arab countries are considering greatly increasing aid to the Palestinians on condition that they and Israel take certain steps toward reducing their conflict. The possibility of an aid increase was the subject of intense discussions at a donors meeting on Dec. 8 in Oslo. According to American and Palestinian officials, a four-year package of US$6 billion to US$8 billion would be forthcoming, if the Palestinian elections set for Jan. 9 occurred successfully and if the new government cracked down on militant groups and Israel lifted scores of roadblocks and checkpoints to ease the transit of goods and people in Palestinian areas.
Wall Street Journal: A hidden cost of China's growth: mercury migration.
The airborne output of Chinese power plants was once considered the price of China's economic growth, and a mostly local problem. But just as China's industrial might is integrating the country into the global economy, its pollution is also becoming a global concern. Among the biggest worries: the impact of China's vast and growing power industry, mostly fueled by coal, on the buildup of mercury in the world's water and food supply.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF URGES BEIJING TO LOOK BEFORE LEAPING INTO 'UNIFICATION LAW'

TEXT.P: What Beijing is trying to achieve ultimately with a planned law is to unilaterally alter the cross-strait status quo by fabricating a "legal basis" for a future invasion of Taiwan, a government official said Friday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu warned Beijing of the serious consequences of a "unification law" that it is planning to craft, stressing that such a law will not go down well with the people of Taiwan and will pose a grave threat to peace in the region.
Wu issued the warning at a news conference. The Cabinet-level MAC is Taiwan's top mainland policy-planning agency.

According to Hong Kong media reports, the mainland authorities will soon put forth legislation for the law and mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao is expected to make an announcement on the issue during a trip to Macau next week.

Wu urged the Beijing regime to carefully think over the matter and not to again miscalculate the Taiwan people's firm determination to deter any military threat, warning that such a move is set to further alienate Taiwan from mainland China and that it will also become the biggest threat to peace in the Asia-Pacific region.

It would be extremely "unwise" for Beijing to reject President Chen Shui-bian's offers of goodwill and turn a cold shoulder to the Taiwan people's aspirations for peace if it goes ahead with the legislation at the expense of cross-Taiwan Strait stability and prosperity, he pointed out.

According to the MAC chief, the planned legislation for the "unification law" or an "anti-subversion law" forms one pillar of a three-tier war strategy by Beijing against Taiwan on the legal, psychological and public opinion fronts.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA SHOULD BE ONLY PART OF TAIWAN BUSINESSES' GLOBAL DEPLOYMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan businesses should see mainland China as only a part of their global deployment, Premier Yu Shyi-kun suggested Friday.
Replying to questions raised at an interpellation session of the Legislative Yuan, Yu said that Taiwan businesses should diversify their investment destinations.
In addition to taking investment risks into consideration, Taiwan businesses should also consider their global deployment when they are to make investments in the mainland, he said.

Taiwan's trade with the mainland accounts now for about 20 percent of its total foreign trade, followed by 18 percent with the United States and 15 percent with Japan, the premier stressed, adding that "Taiwan should not put all its eggs in one basket."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEADER VOWS TO COOPERATE WITH U. S. ON MILITARY PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan vowed Friday to cooperate closely with the United States on Taiwan's military procurement and promised to do his best not to waste a penny of the Taiwan people's money.

Saying that the previous KMT-led government also worked closely with the United States on acquiring weapons that Taiwan needed, Lien said that the KMT will continue to do so in the future after the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, the People First Party and the New Party retained a majority in the Legislative Yuan.
Lien made the comment during a trip to Taipei County to thank voters for their support for the "pan-blue alliance" in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

The "pan-blue alliance" won a majority in the 225-member Legislative Yuan by gaining 114 seats, exceeding the 101 seats garnered by the "pan-green camp" of the governing Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

A major military procurement plan with a budget totaling NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) put forth months ago by the Ministry of National Defense to the Legislative Yuan has failed to gain legislative approval due to its controversy over the large price tag.

Now with the inauguration of the new legislature slated for Feb. 1 next year, the disputed military procurement project has been widely viewed again as a focal point in future fierce wrangling between the opposition and ruling forces.

"Pan-blue alliance" legislators have repeatedly said that they are not opposed to purchasing necessary defensive arms to safeguard Taiwan's security, but they have also made it clear that such deals must be rational and adequate in order not to waste the money of Taiwan's taxpayers.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACAU URGED TO SET UP REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) urged the Macau government Friday to set up a representative office in Taiwan for promoting bilateral ties.

In a report issued on the eve of the fifth anniversary of the transfer of the former Portuguese colony's sovereignty to China, the MAC stated that private exchanges between Taiwan and Macau have been flourishing continuously over the past five years.

A total of 915,000 Taiwan people visited Macau in the first 11 months of this year, up 19 percent from the previous year's level, while about 17,000 Macau people visited Taiwan, an increase of six percent year-on-year, according to statistics compiled by the Immigration Office under the National Police Administration.
Taiwan's representative office in Macau has been authorized to grant entry to Macau people and visas for foreigners in Macau since Feb. 2003, Taiwan's top mainland policy planning agency said.

Taiwan has eased regulations twice on the granting of permission for Macau-born people to visit Taiwan since Aug. 8, 2001 and plans to open an Internet application process for Taiwan entry for Macau people beginning from Jan. 1, 2005.
The MAC urged both the Beijing and Macau governments to see the increasing Taiwan-Macau exchanges in a pragmatic light and to upgrade and institutionalize its communications channels with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR DEC. 18 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, Dec. 18:
09: 30, A seminar on the Taiwan Strait security will be held at the National Taiwan University Alumni Hall.
10: 00, Marshall Islands President Kessai Note will bid farewell to President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office.
10:10, Vice President Annette Lu will attend the opening ceremony of a flowers and plants exposition in Pali, Taipei County.
14: 00, The opposition Kuomintang will hold a rally to thank its supporters in the Dec. 11 legislative elections at the former tobacco plant in Sungshan, Taipei.
14: 00, The awards for the nation's 10 best managers will be delivered at a ceremony at the Howard International House, Taipei.
14: 30, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu will give a speech at the Ketagalan Institute.
16:00, A 10,000-person ceramic flute performance to challenge the Guinness world record will be held at the Chungcheng Stadium in Kaohsiung.
19:30, Vice President Annette Lu will attend a concert in memory of a late Taiwanese musician in Lungtang, Taoyuan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OPPOSES BEIJING'S PLANNED LAW AIMED AT TAIWAN: MOFA

TEXT.P: Washington is opposed to Beijing's plan to establish a so-called "anti-separatism" law that is aimed at addressing the question of Taiwan, and Taipei will protest the law in the international community because of its inference of future military action, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Friday.
Foreign ministry spokesman Michel Lu made the remarks at a news conference, citing information from diplomatic personnel stationed in the United States.

Mainland China's Xinhua New Agency reported earlier the same day that the Standing Committee of the 10th National People's Congress will discuss creating an "anti-separatism" draft during a meeting slated for Dec. 25-29.

Saying that the Beijing move is apparently aimed at Taiwan, Lu pointed out that the planned law will provide the Chinese Communists with what they expect to be a legal pretext to invade Taiwan, which will change the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo and leading to a catastrophe in the Asia-Pacific region.

To underscore the seriousness of the matter to the international community, the foreign ministry is planning to summon foreign ambassadors stationed in Taipei and ask overseas missions to express Taiwan's grave concern to their host countries, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECT INVOLVED IN TERRORIST THREAT IN TAIPEI NABBED

TEXT.P: A suspect involved in a terrorist threat case in Taipei last week was nabbed by the police in Taichung, central Taiwan, officials of the Criminal Investigation Bureau said Friday.
The suspect, 46, surnamed Kao, confessed guilty to the police in preliminary inquiries, the officials said.
The suspect was delivered to the prosecutors office of Taipei District Court for further inquiries, they added.

A pickup truck loaded with canisters of liquefied natural gas exploded in a fire ball near the Taipei Railroad Station and a hoax bomb warning was reported at the same place Dec. 9, two days before a nationwide legislative elections.
Police checked the station complex according to warnings received by several local TV stations and found four fake explosive devices with anti-Taiwan indepedence slogans sticking to them.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER SECURITY OFFICIAL TALKS ABOUT CHEN'S POLITICAL IDEAS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 17 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: An former security aide to President Chen Shui-bian talked in the U.S. about Chen's policies and ideas Thursday, claiming that how to strike a balance between the consolidation of democracy and regional security is a huge challenge facing the president.

Antonio Chun-nan Chiang, a former deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council, told a seminar organized by the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, D.C. that Chen's training and career as a successful lawyer has developed strength in pragmatic problem-solving and negotiations and made him a conciliator and arbitrator.

Chen, with a humble origin, worked his way through university and earned his reputation as a successful lawyer through hard work. This experience bred in him a personality of a striver and challenger, trying to be the first and the best in whatever he does. This may explain why he would challenge his own country's constitution and political structure, according to Chiang.
Looking at Chen, Chiang said, you have to see these two forces in contention; his professional role as an arbitrator and his aggressive ambitions nature as a challenger.

However, Chiang said, when Chen plays the role of conciliator his own side claims he is betraying core principles. When he lets his ambition rip, he is portrayed by the opposition at home as a messianic crackpot looking for trouble, and Chen himself has yet to find the right equilibrium between these two sides of his nature.

Chiang disputed claims that Taiwan's situation is more unstable under Chen than it was under his predecessor, Lee Teng-hui, saying that the problems with which Chen has to deal are of a different nature from those of his predecessor.
During Lee's presidency, Chiang said, Taiwan was an successful model of the so-called "third wave of democracy, " and China was considered an international pariah after the Tiananmen Square massacre.
For Chen, the world has turned upside down. Security has been the dominant geopolitical fixation after Sept. 11, 2001, and China is a more significant player than Taiwan can hope to be.

At home, Lee enjoyed the huge power of his Kuomintang (KMT) party apparatus, the support of the KMT-controlled legislature, while Chen has had to contend with a constant minority government, the intractable hostility of the opposition, and a split political identity.
Therefore, Chiang said, it is unfair to ascribe Taiwan's worsening stability, if it were true, to Chen.

Chen's success in re-election has bred some extent of conceit which tends to lure him into overestimating his own powers, and this is visible in his party's hubristic Dec. 11 legislative elections, Chiang said.

When the legislative campaign started, Chen took the right direction by focusing on practical issues such as the support of farmers, director links with China for businessmen and pensions for the elderly, Chiang said.
As the campaign progressed, Chen digressed to the ideological topics concerned with Taiwan's identity which did not play well in previous legislative elections, Chiang claimed.

Maybe he thought he had to compete with Lee Teng-hui's Taiwan Solidarity Union for the independence fundamentalist vote. He appealed to the core supporters only, but scared away the swing voters, and this mistake, Chiang said, was rooted in Chen's own self-confidence.

Chiang said in Chen's remaining years in office, the DPP is unlikely to make any radical changes because the party has transformed itself from being a revolutionary party to more of a "middle class party" whose main task is to safeguard the status quo.
As with any other ruling party, Chiang said, how to hold onto power becomes much more important than any other agenda for the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 18, or the seventh day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1787: New Jersey becomes the third state of the United States.
1825: Tsar Nicholas I succeeds to the Russian throne.
1829: Jean Baptiste Pierre Antoine de Monet Lamarck, one of France's best scientists, dies at the age of 75. His most important work was the study of evolution.
1865: The United States abolishes slavery.
1911: Wu Ting-fang, representative of anti-Ching revolutionaries, holds peace talks in Shanghai with Tang Chao-yi, representative of the Ching government.
1913: Willy Brandt, German statesman and chancellor of West Germany from 1969 to 1974, is born.
1913: Lo Fu-hsing, who participated in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's overthrow of the Ching dynasty and was a leader of the "Miaoli Incident," is arrested by the Japanese in Tamsui.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, who was appointed commander of the National Revolutionary Army on June 5, 1926, captures Wuhan (Hankow), which had been proclaimed the capital of the Nationalist government by a left-wing group of the Kuomintang on Jan. 1, 1927.
1941: German forces retreat in North Africa during World War II.
1956: Japan is admitted into the United Nations.
1961: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic ties with Upper Volta.
1965: Nine African states break diplomatic ties with Britain over Rhodesia.
1969: Britain formally abolishes the death penalty.
1969: The ROC's first satellite ground station is established, enabling satellite communications with the United States, Japan and Thailand.
1976: Thanat Khoman, former Thai foreign minister, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1980: Soviet Premier Aleksei Nikolayevich Kosygin, who succeeded Nikita Khrushchev but was often overshadowed by the Communist Party secretary, Leonid Brezhnev, dies at the age of 76.
1985: Chang Fu-lin, the first Chinese-American astronaut, flies aboard the space shuttle Columbia.
1987: The Taiwan Provincial Government announces that it will cease to issue lottery tickets starting in 1988.
1987: In South Korea, Roh Ta-woo is declared the winner of the first presidential election to be held in 16 years. However, students riot, claiming electoral corruption.
1987: The "Hai Lung," a submarine purchased by the Republic of China from the Netherlands, arrives in Kaohsiung.
1989: The European Economic Community signs a 10-year trade pact with the Soviet Union.
1991: The first international project to save the world's rainforests is launched when the World Bank, the European Commission, and the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations grant Brazil US$250 million for conservation work in the Amazon basin.
1992: Kim Young-sam, a member of South Korea's Democratic Liberal Party, is elected the country's first civilian president after 32 years of military rule.
1998: Andrew Lavern Smith is put to death in the state of South Carolina, becoming the 500th person to be executed in the United States since capital punishment was reinstated in 1977.
1999: Construction on Taiwan's first national children's hospital, to be operated by National Taiwan University Hospital, is begun.
1999: TransAsia Airways formally opens passenger flight services between Taipei and the Thai island of Phuket.
2000: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC), the world's biggest semiconductor manufacturer, sets a record by delivering the world's first batch of 12-inch wafers ordered by a customer.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian presides over a ceremony marking the commissioning of the nation's first F-16 fighter wing into service held at Chiayi Air Base in southern Taiwan.
2001: The Central News Agency (CNA) and the MiTAC-Synnex Group enter into a strategic alliance to offer speedy corporate news and commercial and industrial information services in Chinese to domestic and global enterprises.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Study without thinking is labor lost. Thinking without study is perilous. To give oneself up to the study of metaphysical theories -- that is very injurious indeed. Shall I teach you what is understanding? To know what it is that you know, and to know what it is that you do not know -- that is understanding."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The China Times:
China to enact anti-secession law.
The United Daily News:
China to legislate anti-secession law.
The Liberty Times:
China's anti-secession law to unilaterally change Taiwan Strait status quo.
The Taiwan Daily:
Legal battle is being waged across the Taiwan Strait.
The Central Daily News:
KMT chairman to step down next August.
The China Post:
China law to oppose Taiwan secession.
The Taiwan News:
MAC warns PRC is altering the status quo.
The Taipei Times:
Station bomber arrested in Taichung.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Season of terror.
Osama bin Laden, in what could be described as a new phase in his terror campaign, has called on his followers to mount strikes aimed at preventing the United States from obtaining Middle Eastern oil.
He made the call in a new audiotape and, within hours of the recording being posted on an Islamic website, the US Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) concluded with 'a high degree of confidence' that the speaker was Osama, a US intelligence official said on Thursday.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore to fine mosquito breeders S$100 on first offence as dengue peaks from February next year.
The number of dengue fever cases this year in Singapore has hit a record 10-year high and the National Environment Agency is taking no chances.
It's getting tougher with first-time offenders who breed mosquitoes by imposing an instant S$100 (around US$60) fine on them, from February next year.
Right now, first-time offenders get away with just a warning letter.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Social Security "Crisis Is Now," Bush Says in Pitch for Overhaul. President Bush said that he was determined to send a message to Congress, Wall Street and the American people that fixing Social Security's long-term cash shortfall was as crucial as reducing budget deficits and addressing other, more immediate problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Manila Bulletin: Speaker's daughter dies in fire Kristina Casimira "KC" de Venecia, youngest daughter of Speaker Jose de Venecia and Gina Vera Perez de Venecia, died in a late-night fire that struck their Dasmarinas Village residence in Makati City on Thursday. She was 16.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Arroyo approval rating still down negative 5% PRESIDENT Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo suffered another drop in her public satisfaction rating in the latest survey of the Social Weather Stations, which showed the President's performance being uniformly deplored throughout all classes and regions of the country, giving her a net approval rating of negative 5 percent.
The Philippine Star: 'Ate, help! Help!' Sixteen-year-old Kristina Casimira de Venecia, trapped in her family home by raging flames, tried calling several relatives for help through her cell phone before she died of suffocation Thursday night.
The Manila Times: Fire kills JDV daughter The 16-year-old daughter of Speaker Jose de Venecia died early Friday in a fire that gutted his house in Dasmarinas Village, Makati City.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times: Two to serve time over fatal crush on overpass Municipal officials get off with suspended terms KOBE A police officer and a former security co- mpany official were sentenced Friday to 30 months in prison for failing to prevent a fatal crush on a pedestrian overpass after a fireworks show in Akashi, Hyogo Prefecture.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO SUPPORT DPP-PROPOSED BILL TO INVESTIGATE KMT ASSETS

TEXT.P: A leading opposition People First Party (PFP) legislator said Saturday that the party will support a piece of legislation proposed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to probe the Kuomintang's (KMT's) assets.
Liu Wen-hsiung, convener of the PFP legislative caucus, said the party is giving its support because the DPP has shown its goodwill by removing the term "ill-gotten" from the bill.
Liu said the KMT assets have always been the target of attack by the DPP during elections, and some people have even accused the PFP of eyeing a share of the assets by planning a merger with the KMT.
The PFP believes the passage of the bill will help clarify the controversies surrounding the KMT assets and facilitate the merger of the KMT and PFP, Liu said.

Liu pointed out that although the PFP will clear the way for the bill to enter legislative proceedings, it is against any discriminatory articles in the bill that are designed to liquidate a certain party.

The DPP is expected to submit the bill next week to the Legislative Yuan's procedures committee, which is in charge of scheduling the legislature's agenda. It is unlikely that the bill will be included on the agenda if it doesn't have the support of the PFP.

According to the bill, the assets owned by a political party and its affiliated organizations are to be returned to the government with the exception of membership fees, political donations and campaign funding from the government.
The bill also applies to assets that were sold after May 1, 1991, with parties having to return a payment equivalent to the value of the assets sold.
Also, any transactions taking place after March 10, 2004 will be declared invalid, according to the bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIRTH OF GRANDKIDS SYMBOLIZES STABLE ROC-MARSHALL ISLANDS TIES: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Saturday said the almost simultaneous birth of another grandchild to the first families of both Taiwan and the Marshall Islands this week symbolizes the stability of relations between the two countries.

Chen made the remarks while sharing his joy for the birth of his second grandson with Marshall Islands President Kessai Note, who was bidding farewell to Chen before his departure upon concluding a five-day visit in Taiwan.
Chen's elder daughter, Hsing-yu, gave birth to her second son on Friday, one day after Note's sixth grandchild was born.
Chen said the births are a very special blessing to the two first families.
While bidding farewell to the Marshall Islands president, Chen presented him with a jewelry music box and a piece of traditional Paiwan pottery as souvenirs.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. URGES TAIPEI, BEIJING TO TALK, NOT TO HARDEN POSITIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 17 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government exhorts both sides of the Taiwan Strait to really focus on engaging in dialogue and to refrain from hardening their positions or taking any unilateral actions to change the status quo, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Friday.
Boucher was responding to media reports that mainland China is considering passing anti-secession legislation, with Taiwan as its main target.
Speaking at a daily news briefing, Boucher confirmed that the Bush administration has had conversations with both mainland and Taiwan authorities on the anti-secession law issue.
The spokesman said that since the U.S. government has not yet seen the text of China's new legislation, it is not in a position to comment on the law at the moment.
"We have not seen the law. We've not had a chance to study it, so we're not in a position to comment in any detail, " he said.

However, Boucher reiterated the U.S. stance on cross-strait issues. "I would repeat our longstanding position that we've stated many times that both sides should really focus on engaging in dialogue and try to peacefully resolve their differences."
Neither side should do anything to unilaterally change the status quo, Boucher said, adding: "So we think it's the time to focus on dialogue and not for hardening of positions."

Asked about his views on a senior Taiwan official's statement earlier in the day that the U.S. government is against mainland China's new anti-secession law, Boucher only confirmed that the Bush administration has kept in contact with all the relevant parties on the matter.

"We certainly keep in touch with all the parties on this subject. We talked to the Chinese and talked to some people in Taiwan and are following this development. But our view is the that it's important for both sides to focus on dialogue, it's not time to harden positions or take unilateral stances," Boucher said.

As to whether Beijing's anti-secession legislation coincides with the United States' one-China policy and stances on maintaining the cross-strait status quo, Boucher said Washington will have to see the actual text of the legislation before making any further comments.
Anyway, Boucher said, the United States has consistently encouraged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to "look for dialogue and not to look for staking out positions or hardening their positions."
Asked whether enacting such a law is hardening the position, Boucher said: "I'd just leave it at what I said. I think we said the same thing in other cases as well."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Celebrex Trial Halted After Finding Of Heart Risk; Similar Side Effects Led To Withdrawal of Vioxx.
A clinical trial of the blockbuster arthritis drug Celebrex was shut down yesterday after researchers found an increase in the risk of serious heart disease and strokes in those taking the drug, the same side effects that caused the related painkiller Vioxx to be taken off the market this fall.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP NOT TO COOPERATE WITH DPP FOR LEGISLATIVE VICE SPEAKER POST

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) will not take the initiative to vie for the position of Legislative Yuan vice speaker or cooperate with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the race, a leading PFP legislator said Saturday.

PFP legislative caucus convener Liu Wen-hsiung said the caucus will not express its opinion on any candidates for the speaker or vice speaker posts before it meets to seek a consensus among its members.
Liu denied reports that the DPP has sought to cooperate with the PFP in the race for the vice speaker post, saying the PFP has made it clear that it will not join forces with the DPP on this matter.
Liu said the PFP will not take any proactive steps to jockey for any Cabinet positions or the posts of speaker or vice speaker of the Legislative Yuan.
A minority of PFP legislators have proposed that the party make a bid for the vice speaker post while supporting the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) bid for the post of speaker.
Incumbent speaker Wang Jin-pyng has won the KMT's endorsement for his bid to continue in the post in the new legislature and is expected to gain the PFP's support as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE SENIOR MINISTER SENDS CONDOLENCES TO FAMILY OF FAINA CHIANG
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By Charles Kang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Singaporean Senior Minister Lee Kuang Yew has sent a letter of condolence to the family of former Republic of China first lady Faina Chiang, who died of pulmonary and cardiac failure Wednesday at the age of 88, Lee's press secretary said Saturday.

Lee wrote the condolence letter in his private capacity, the secretary said, adding that the letter was addressed to Chiang-Hsu Nai-chin, the eldest daughter-in-law of Faina Chiang, widow of the late ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo.

In his letter, Lee said he was a good friend of the late ROC president. He also recalled how during his previous visits to Taiwan, he had taken lunch with the Chiangs at their official residence in suburban Taipei on several occasions.

Russian-born Faina Chiang met her husband while he was in the Soviet Union in the 1930s. A woman of simple tastes with a technical school education, Faina Chiang left her homeland in 1936 when she joined her husband to return to China. She had to adjust to joining one of China's most powerful families at the time. China was ruled by her father-in-law, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, and the Kuomintang during the period.

She fled to Taiwan along with her family in 1949 after the Chinese Communists took control of the mainland. Her husband became president in 1978 and ended 38 years of martial law just months before he died in 1988. He also oversaw the island's spectacular economic development in the 1980s.
Faina Chiang avoided the spotlight and was known to be Taiwan's most low-key first lady.
The couple had three sons and one daughter. The three sons all died, while the daughter, Chiang Hsiao-chang, lives in the United States with her family.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO TAKE STEPS TO COPE WITH CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Academics and pro-independence activists called Saturday for the government to take active steps to deal with mainland China's plan to introduce an anti-secession law that they claim is directed against the island.

A draft of the law, which is seen by some as aimed at crushing the pro-independence movement in Taiwan, is expected to be discussed at an upcoming meeting of the National People's Congress Standing Committee, according to reports.

To cope with the situation, Ng Yuzin Chiautong, leader of the World United Formosans for Independence, proposed in an interview with CNA that the government should seek international support by releasing publicity materials to call Asia-Pacific countries' attention to China's intent to change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait and upset regional stability.

Ng said that Beijing's claim of sovereignty over Taiwan is totally groundless and that it has never been recognized by the international community. He said the anti-secession law is meaningless internationally, although he added that it may be used for the purpose of political propaganda.

Meanwhile, Taiwan New Century Foundation Chairman Chen Lung-chu said at a seminar on cross-Taiwan Strait security held in Taipei that the anti-secession law is part of Beijing's psychological, propaganda and legal warfare aimed at making Taiwan collapse without the use of force.
He argued that China's laws do not apply to Taiwan because Taiwan is a sovereign state.

To protect itself from an invasion by China, Taiwan must draw up a new constitution and adopt a new name to normalize its status and must step up its bid to join the United Nations to declare to the world that it is a sovereign state, Chen said.
China's military threat against Taiwan is in violation of international laws and the United Nations Charter and is unacceptable to the international community, Chen added.

Also at the seminar, Lin Wen-cheng, a professor of mainland China studies at National Sun Yat-sen University, said China lacks the confidence to win a war against Taiwan in the short run and is therefore trying to suppress Taiwan by pressuring the international community.
Lin urged the government to beef up its relations with the United States, which he said plays a key role in the national security of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD FORMULATE 'RED-LINE' MECHANISM: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan should formulate a "red line" mechanism to cope with mainland China's anti-secession legislation, a scholar said Saturday
Hsu Yung-ming, an assistant researcher at Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute, made the suggestion in a telephone interview with the Central News Agency.
Hsu said both mainland China and the United States have their own "red lines" regarding cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
"Taiwan should also formulate its own 'red line' mechanism in the face of Beijing's anti-secession legislative plan," Hsu said.
For instance, Hsu said, Taiwan should legislate an "anti-annexation" law to protect itself from being taken over or absorbed by mainland China.

Hsu said the proposed "anti-annexation" law can set the conditions for when the "red line" mechanism should be activated, such as when the total number of Taiwan's diplomatic allies falls below a certain level or when Taiwan's sovereignty is weakened to a certain point, for example.
He said the "anti-annexation" law concept has nothing to do with the "unification vs. independence" debate and is instead aimed at protecting the status quo of Taiwan's sovereignty.
According to media reports, Beijing's anti-secession law is aimed at crushing the pro-independence movement in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO START INTERNATIONAL PUBLICITY DRIVE AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will launch an international publicity drive against China's plan to introduce an anti-secession law targeting Taiwan, ministry spokesman Michel Lu said Saturday.
Lu said the ministry will call the international community's attention to Beijing's move, which he said will severely upset peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.
Lu said the law is obviously aimed at building a legal basis for China's plan to invade Taiwan, and he urged the international community to step in to stop the plot.

Reports said the law is designed to crush the pro-independence movement in Taiwan, and the National People's Congress of China is expected to discuss a draft of the law in an upcoming meeting set for later this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP TO PROMOTE DEVELOPMENT OF 'GOLDEN COAST OF TAIWAN'

TEXT.P: Taiwan should develop its tourism with a uniquely local flavor by using the island's own special cultural resources and characteristics, Lu said in an address at the opening ceremony of a flower exhibition in Pali, Taipei County Saturday.

Lu also noted that she will promote the development of a "golden coast of Taiwan, " noting that she plans to invite administrators of coastal cities and townships around the island to hold talks on developing tourism.
The vice president said she hopes the local authorities can jointly discuss and work out plans to build Taiwan's coastal areas into numerous tourist resorts and attractions with a local character.

Lu pointed out in her address that she has discovered that the coastal township of Pali has developed many tourist spots, including the "Left Bank" -- a tourist attraction modeled on the "Rive Gauche" in Paris. However, she said, tourist authorities and businesses should stop copying from foreign cultures.

Taiwan should make more efforts toward developing tourism with a uniquely Taiwanese flavor by using the island's own cultural resources and creative technology, Lu said. She added that as Taiwan is surrounded by seas on all sides, it should also take advantage of its marine resources in developing tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUTTERFLY ORCHID BOUTIQUE TO OPEN AT CKS INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT

TEXT.P: A butterfly orchid boutique set up by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture is scheduled to open at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport's second terminal Dec. 27, council officials said Saturday.

To promote butterfly orchids, the council intends to familiarize passengers from home and abroad with the flower by displaying the beautiful Taiwan floral species, offering an online search system for information about the flower and screening butterfly orchid films, the officials said.

According to statistics compiled by the council, 47 million pots of butterfly orchids were produced in Taiwan last year, with half being exported to Japan, mainland China, Hong Kong, the United States and Vietnam. Japan absorbed the lion's share with 43 percent of the exported butterfly orchids, the officials said.
Taiwan's butterfly exports last year amounted to 3,094 tons, worth around US$24 million, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FINANCIAL SERVICES ROUNDTABLE TO BE FORMED

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-based Chinese National Futures Association approved Saturday a proposal to establish the Taiwan Financial Services Roundtable (TFSR).
The proposal to set up the TFSR was passed during a meeting of the association held in Taoyuan County.

Wu Nai-jen, chairman of the Taiwan Stock Exchange Co., who has been assigned to head a panel preparing for the TFSR's establishment, said he will invite leaders of banking, securities and insurance associations to take part in the preparatory effort.

After the TFSR is set up, Taiwan will be able to interact with similar organizations in Europe and the United States to expand international cooperation and exchanges and to upgrade the competitiveness of Taiwan's financial services sector, according to the association.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO MONITOR DEVELOPMENTS IN GRANADA'S CONTACT WITH CHINA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will closely monitor developments regarding recent contact between China and Grenada, a longstanding diplomatic ally of Taiwan, ministry spokesman Michel Lu said Saturday.
Lu said the ministry has been informed that Grenadian Prime Minister Keith Mitchell has returned home after a week-long visit to China.
The ministry will continue to watch whether Mitchell makes any moves concerning his country's ties with Taiwan following the trip, Lu said.
The Grenadian government had announced that Mitchell's visit to Beijing was aimed at seeking funds for hurricane relief and economic development.

However, the ministry said it believes that the information about Mitchell's trip to China was deliberately leaked earlier by Beijing in an attempt to influence the outcome of the Dec. 11 legislative elections in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW HIGHLIGHTS BEIJING'S SUPPRESSION OF TAIWAN: VP

TEXT.P: Mainland China's plan to legislate a so-called anti-secession law will only help the international community to better understand Beijing's ubiquitous suppression of Taiwan, Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday.
Stressing that Taiwan has never been a part of the People's Republic of China (PRC) , Lu said that the introduction of an anti-secession law by Beijing "could not alter this fact."

"The law would only show Beijing's true face by spotlighting its suppression of Taiwan in the international arena," Lu told a group of journalists after attending a seminar on higher education at National Taiwan Normal University.
Noting that Beijing has been waging "psychological, media and legal warfare" against Taiwan, Lu said the anti-secession legislative plan is part of Beijing's "legal warfare."
However, Lu said she is convinced that even if China does introduce the law, Beijing's claim that Taiwan is a part of the PRC would not be recognized under international law.
Meanwhile, Lu urged domestic political parties across the political spectrum to cooperate closely in forming a cross-party action committee to promote peace in the Taiwan Strait.
"The ruling and opposition parties should stop their partisan wrangling and instead work hand-in-hand to promote national development in a stable environment," Lu said.
Earlier in the day, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said the United States has discussed with Taiwan Beijing's anti-secession legislation plan.
"The U.S. government is fully aware of our stance, " Wu said, adding that both Taiwan and the United States are opposed to any unilateral move to alter the Taiwan Strait status quo.
Stressing that Beijing's anti-secession legislation is a unilateral move to alter the present status quo, Wu said the legislation is a provocative action which Taiwan strongly opposes.

Asked whether Taiwan is likely to file an international lawsuit to counter Beijing's new legislation, Wu said relevant government agencies will make a comprehensive evaluation and will discuss the issue with international friends before working out response strategies.

According to a Friday report by Beijing's state-controlled Xinhua News Agency, mainland China's National People's Congress (NPC) is set to enact an anti-secession law, which will be submitted for deliberation at the 13th session of the 10th NPC Standing Committee scheduled for Dec. 25-29 in Beijing. Accordign to the report, the law is directed against Taiwan and would not apply to Hong Kong and Macau.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, INDONESIA SIGN LABOR MANAGEMENT COOPERATION PACT

TEXT.P: Taiwan has formally signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Indonesia on labor management cooperation, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Saturday.
The Cabinet-level council said the agreement was signed by CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu and her Indonesian counterpart, Fahmi Idris, in Indonesia earlier this week.

According to CLA officials, Chen left for Indonesia Thursday at the head of a delegation of labor officials. The CLA has kept a low key about Chen's Indonesia visit to avoid possible sabotages by mainland China.
Idris was originally scheduled to visit Taiwan to sign the MOU late last month, but he was reportedly forced to cancel the visit because of pressure from Beijing.
Chen was the first ministerial-level official from Taiwan to visit Indonesia since the new Indonesian government was inaugurated in October.

CLA officials said now that Indonesia has signed the MOU to cooperate with Taiwan in preventing Indonesian workers in Taiwan from absconding, the CLA will soon lift the ban on importing Indonesian blue-collar workers.

The CLA has imposed an across-the-board ban on the import of Indonesian workers since Aug. 1, 2002 in retaliation for Indonesia's failure to cooperate with Taiwan in fixing the high absconding rate of Indonesian workers in Taiwan as well as unreasonable brokerage fees charged by the Indonesian side.

CLA Chairwoman Chen made a visit to Jakarta earlier this year to discuss a labor management cooperative agreement. The CLA originally expected to sign an MOU soon after Chen's Jakarta visit. However, the signing was delayed by Indonesia's presidential election.

Indonesian citizens mostly serve as caregivers in Taiwan. Before the ban was imposed, the number of Indonesian workers once exceeded 90,000 in 2001. At the end of August this year, the number of legal Indonesian workers declined to slightly more than 30,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAN ON IMPORTING INDONESIAN WORKERS TO BE LIFTED BEFORE YEAR'S END

TEXT.P: The ban on importing Indonesian workers will be lifted before the end of this month, Council of Labor Affirs (CLA) Chairwoman Chen Chu said Saturday.
Chen made the remarks after her return from an unannounced visit to Indonesia.

During her visit, Chen said she signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with her Indonesian counterpart on labor management cooperation to pave the way for re-opening Taiwan's door to Indonesian workers.
Chen left for Indonesia Thursday at the head of a delegation of CLA officials. The CLA has kept a low key about Chen's Indonesia visit to avoid possible sabotages by mainland China. Saturday.

Indonesian Minister of Manpower and Trans-Immigration Affairs Fahmi Idris was originally scheduled to visit Taiwan to sign the MOU late last month, but he was reportedly forced to cancel the visit because of pressure from Beijing.
Chen was the first ministerial-level official from Taiwan to visit Indonesia since the new Indonesian government was inaugurated in October.

Chen said now that Indonesia has signed the MOU to commit itself to assisting in preventing Indonesian workers in Taiwan from absconding, the CLA will soon lift the ban on importing Indonesian workers.
Chen said she will give more details about the new agreement at a news conference to be held Sunday morning.

The CLA has imposed an across-the-board ban on the import of Indonesian workers since Aug. 1, 2002 in retaliation for Indonesia's failure to cooperate with Taiwan in fixing the high absconding rate of Indonesian workers in Taiwan as well as unreasonable brokerage fees charged by the Indonesian side.

Chen made a visit to Jakarta earlier this year to discuss a labor management cooperative agreement. The CLA originally expected to sign an MOU soon after Chen's Jakarta visit. However, the signing was delayed by Indonesia's presidential election.

Indonesian citizens mostly serve as caregivers in Taiwan. Before the ban was imposed, the number of Indonesian workers once exceeded 90,000 in 2001. At the end of August this year, the number of legal Indonesian workers declined to slightly more than 30,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TAKES DPP TO TASK FOR STRAINED CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman LIen Chan said Saturday the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration is to blame for strained relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Lien made the remarks during a rally in Taipei organized by the KMT to celebrate the three "pan-blue alliance" parties' success in retaining its majority in the new legislature to be inaugurated next February.
Lien claimed that the DPP administration's incompetence and inexperience has resulted in deterioration of cross-strait. He said neither hasty unification nor hasty independence is the KMT's choice.

"We want to maintain the status quo and shelve political dispute to facilitate cross-strait dialogue," Lien said, adding that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should negotiate to create a "win-win" situation.

Now that the "pan-blue alliance" has managed to win more than half of seats in Saturday's legislative elections, Lien said the DPP administration should respect this new situation and organize a new administrative team in cooperation with the opposition camp to ensure domestic political stability.

The three "pan-blue alliance" parties refer to the KMT, the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party. While New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming attended the rally, none of PFP leading figures appeared at the rally.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Pricey drug trials turn up few new blockbusters
Three major drug companies - Pfizer, Astra Zeneca and Eli Lilly - each disclosed serious problems with important medicines yesterday, throwing a spotlight on the fact that the US$500 billion drug industry is stumbling badly in its core business of finding new medicines. The decline in drug research and deve lopment has been an open secret among analysts and scientists for years. Drug company executives have tried to off set their weakness in creating profitable new drugs by pursuing aggressive campaigns to market existing drugs to doctors and patients, impose big price increases and make efforts to extend patents on existing medicines. Those tactics have protected their profits but irritated consumers and governments that pay for drugs, causing a political reaction in the United States and Europe.
