DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 19, or the eighth day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1036: Chinese poet Su Tung-po is born.
1154: Henry II accedes to the throne of England.
1741: Vitus Bering, the Danish navigator and explorer who in 1728 sailed through the Bering Strait while exploring a route around Siberia to China, dies of scurvy at the age of 60.
1793: French troops under Napoleon Bonaparte capture Toulon.
1842: The United States recognizes the independence of Hawaii.
1932: The third plenary session of the fourth Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves the convening of an assembly that will meet regularly and which will give the public a voice in governmental affairs.
1941: Adolf Hitler dismisses his chief of staff and takes personal command of the German army after military setbacks.
1946: War breaks out in Indochina as Ho Chi Minh's troops launch widespread attacks against the French.
1950: General Dwight D. Eisenhower is named by the North Atlantic Council as Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers, Europe.
1965: Charles de Gaulle defeats Francois Mitterand in the French presidential election runoff.
1969: President Apollo Milton Obote of Uganda is shot and injured. He would later be overthrown by the Ugandan army in 1971.
1972: The Apollo 17 spacecraft splashes down on target in the Pacific Ocean, bringing to an end the United States' Apollo program of landing men on the moon.
1980: The States-General of the Netherlands approves the selling of two submarines to the Republic of China.
1984: Britain and mainland China sign an agreement determining the fate of Hong Kong after a 99-year lease of the territory to Britain expires in 1997. The joint declaration signed by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and mainland Chinese Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang spells out the terms for Hong Kong's return to Chinese sovereignty on July 1, 1997.
1985: U.S. Sen. Edward Kennedy announces that he will not run in the 1988 presidential campaign.
1988: Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi visits Beijing.
1990: The first stock exchange on the Chinese mainland opens in Shanghai.
1990: Albanian authorities formally recognize the country's first non-Communist party.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as president of the United Soviet Socialist Republic, a country that effectively ceased to exist on Dec. 12 of the same year.
1992: The Kuomintang wins 53.02 percent of the popular vote and the Democratic Progressive Party gets 31.03 percent in the elections for the Second Legislative Yuan.
1996: The ceiling on foreign institutional investments on the Taiwan Stock Exchange is raised from US$400 million to US$600 million.
1997: A Singapore SilkAir Boeing 737-300 airliner crashes near Palembang in Indonesia, killing all 104 people on board.
1997: South Korea's newly elected president, Kim Dae-jung, proposes dialogue with North Korea as a step toward reconciliation.
1999: Chen Shui-bian calls on voters to support the DPP's Chen-Lu ticket in the March 18 presidential election and says he will do what he can to finish off the KMT's "black gold" dealings and to distribute the money held by the KMT to the populace.
1999: Macau is formally handed over to mainland China at midnight after 442 years of Portuguese colonial rule.
2000: Peter Banko, managing director Taiwan and country manager of the Bank of America, is elected as the new president of the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei.
2001: ROC Vice President Annette Lu departs for Gambia to attend the inauguration of re-elected Gambian President Yahya Jammeh Dec. 21 on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.
Confucius: "Read and learn everything, but suspend your judgment on anything of which you are in doubt; for the rest, be careful in what you say: in that way you will give few occasions for men to criticize what you say. Mix with the world and see everything, but keep away and do not meddle with anything that may bring you into trouble; for the rest, be careful in what you do: in that way you will have few occasions for self-reproach."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: De Venecia couple remain strong despite death in the family
Although there is much pain in their hearts because of the untimely demise of their youngest daughter Kristina Casimira (KC) , House Speaker Jose de Venecia and Mrs. Gina Vera Perez de Venecia remain strong with the help of their friends who are helping them overcome this tragic event.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: 'Don't exploit FPJ burial'
SENATE Minority Leader Aquilino Pimentel Jr. yesterday called on the fans and followers of the late Fernando Poe Jr. not to allow themselves to be used as "pawns in a political game."
The Philippine Star: US freezes Janjalani assets
The US Treasury Department has ordered a freeze on all financial assets of Abu Sayyaf chieftain Khadafi Abubakar Janjalani in the US, the department posted this on its website yesterday.
The Manila Times: Palace: No letup in corruption war
MALACANANG vowed no letup in the government'sfight against corruption in a determined effort to stamp it out in the next three years or before President Arroyo finishes her term in 2010.

DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: U.S., Europe strike deal for informal climate talks
BUENOS AIRES A marathon U.N. conference ended early Saturday with a vague plan for informal new talks on how to slow global warming, but without a U.S. commitment on the next steps, including emissions controls.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: FDA Warns of Celebrex Heart Risk.
The Food and Drug Administration warned physicians to consider alternatives to the popular arthritis drug Celebrex because of new evidence that, like the similar drug Vioxx, removed from the market in September, it doubles the chances of heart attacks and strokes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MADE AD HOC OBSERVER OF OECD TRADE COMMITTEE
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has recently become an ad hoc observer at the Trade Committee under the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) , enabling it to take part in certain OECD-related meetings upon invitation under the title of "Chinese Taipei," OECD sources said Saturday.
Taiwan had not heard anything tangible from the OECD Secretariat since September 2003, when the island filed for observer status at the OECD Trade Committee.
However, the OECD authority has approved a "package arrangement" to include Taiwan, Israel and Romania into certain Trade Committee activities in their capacity as ad hoc observers.

The designation is a temporary arrangement and not a formal "status, " OECD sources said. Ad hoc observers of OECD committees have no rights nor obligations and they do not have to pay annual membership fees.
Taiwan has had formal observer status at the OECD Committee on Competition Law and Policy for nearly three years, also under the title of "Chinese Taipei."
The OECD, also known as the "rich men's club, " currently has 30 countries as full members. It plays a prominent role in fostering good governance in the public service and in corporate activity.
Best known for its publications and its statistics, the OECD's work covers economic and social issues from macroeconomics to trade, education, development, and science and innovation.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. MILITARY OFFICER TO BE STATIONED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A U.S. military officer is to be posted to Taiwan as staff at the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) -- the de facto U.S. embassy -- Hong Kong's Ming Pao Daily reported Sunday.

Quoting the latest Jane's Defense Weekly to be published Dec. 22, the newspaper said the move is based on a U.S. bill enacted in 2002 but which was not implemented over concern about protests from Beijing. However, these concerns are now overshadowed by Washington's worries about Beijing's military build-up, according to the report.

The U.S. military official will serve as chief of the military technology liaison officer under the AIT. The post used to be occupied by a business executive chosen by the U.S. Defense Intelligence Agency from defense contractors that manufacture weapons purchased by Taiwan from the United States.
Washington maintains unofficial ties with Taiwan and U.S. officials named by the government to work in Taiwan have previously had to retire from the government first or quit their government jobs.

Posting a serving military officer in Taiwan will be a departure from previous U.S. policy, although military exchanges between Taiwan and the United States are intensifying, with former commander-in-chief of U.S forces in the Pacific, retired Adm. Dennis Blair, regularly visiting Taiwan to observe its annual military exercises over the last three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC AFFAIRS MINISTER RETURNS FROM GERMANY

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh returned from Germany Sunday and said that German businesses have keen interest in investing in Taiwan and that the outlook for cooperation between Taiwan and German companies is promising.

Describing her trip as fruitful, Ho said she met German Economic and Labor Affairs Minister Wolfgang Clement, the first meeting of its kind after a hiatus of more than two years, as well as Transportation Minister Manfred Stolpe and acting Minister of Environmental Affairs Margareta Wolf.

According to Ho, she also held a series of seminars in Germany attended by a total of over 200 German enterprises, including Leybold, AFC, Merck, Festo, Trumpf, Bosch, Schering, Landesbank Baden-Wuerttemberg and Dr. Willmar Schwabe. They all responded positively to her calls to invest in Taiwan, she said.
There is ample room for two-way Taiwan-Germany cooperation, in particular in the fields of biotechnology, nanotechnology and digital content industries, she added.

The economic affairs minister flew to Germany Dec. 11 from the United States, where she took part in meetings sponsored by Taiwan-based U.S. businessmen who expressed high expectations for a free trade agreement between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LIFTING FREEZE ON INDONESIAN WORKERS

TEXT.P: Beginning Monday, Taiwan will lift a freeze on imports of workers from Indonesia, ending a two-year-and-four-month hiatus, Taiwan's top labor affairs official announced Sunday.

Chen Chu, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) , said at a press conference that Taiwan decided to resume the introduction of workers from Indonesia after the Indonesian government demonstrated sincerity and goodwill in efforts to improve that country's brokerage treatment of Indonesians coming to work in Taiwan.

According to Chen, she joined her Indonesian counterpart, Minister Fahmi Idris, at a ceremony held in Bali last Friday marking the signing of a memorandum on labor affairs cooperation between the two countries. The memorandum was signed by Taiwan's representative to Indonesia, Lin Yung-lo, and Indonesia's representative to Taiwan, Ferry Yahya, on behalf of their respective governments, Chen said.

The memorandum deals with affairs pertaining to Indonesian workers being introduced to Taiwan to work, including the rights of Indonesian workers in Taiwan; a mechanism governing labor-management disputes; health and medical services to the Indonesians and related costs; closer supervision of labor brokerage; and accelerating a "direct hiring" mechanism, according to CLA officials.

Officials from the two sides also agreed that the first Taiwan-Indonesian Labor Affairs Conference will be held in Taiwan in January 2005 to continue an exchange of views on such cooperation between the two countries.

The memorandum marked the first exchange of official documents between the two countries after the new Indonesian government led by President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono was sworn in Oct. 20. Yudhoyono is Indonesia's first directly elected president.

The CLA suspended the introduction of Indonesian laborers and caregivers to Taiwan Aug. 1, 2002 as a result of several factors, including high absconding rate of the Indonesian workers; the Indonesian labor brokers forcing their Taiwan counterparts to withhold "guarantee" deposits from the workers; and Indonesia's failure in lowering brokerage charges as demanded by Taiwan.
Most of the Indonesian workers in Taiwan work as caregivers. In 2002, in their heyday, more than 90,000 Indonesians worked in Taiwan. But the number has declined to 30,000.

Meanwhile, Chen, who kept her recent Bali visit low-profile to avoid Beijing's interference, noted that the cancellation of the freeze on Indonesian workers has nothing to do with affairs involving Thai or Vietnamese workers employed in Taiwan.

Chen added that Taiwan will respect a promise made by the Vietnam Economic and Culture Office (VECO) late last month that it will see to it that some 2,000 Vietnamese absconders will be nabbed before the end of this year to meet the deadline set by CLA as a condition to prevent Taiwan from adopting a freeze on the import of Vietnamese laborers.
Chen claimed that "anything (punitive measures) is possible" if the goal is not reached in time and related situations are not improved as expected.

VECO accelerated its moves to round up absconders after a visit to Taiwan in October by Nguyen Luong Trao, Vietnam's deputy minister of labor, war invalids and social welfare, who promised the CLA that he would see to it that the problem is tackled in a timely manner.
In a sweeping operation, Taiwan police authorities managed to capture nearly 500 absconders in the October-November period with the help of Vietnamese officials.

Under mounting pressure from the Taiwan authorities, who had threatened to freeze imports of Vietnamese laborers if absconding was not checked before the end of 2004, the Vietnamese authorities have summoned some 100 labor brokerage personnel from Vietnam to Taiwan to help find the Vietnamese absconders, who are believed to be still in Taiwan.

The Vietnamese labor brokers were able to help the local authorities because they had detailed information about the absconders, including the addresses and telephone numbers of their direct relatives in Vietnam. Since most of the Vietnamese workers regularly send money back to their hometowns, "it's easy to find them via their contact information, " the VECO official said.

According to CLA talles, 11,000 of the some 84,000 Vietnamese workers currently in Taiwan had absconded as of the end of October. Since about half of all the absconded foreign laborers in Taiwan are Vietnamese nationals, Vietnam posted the highest rate of absconding among all foreign laborers as of the end of August in terms of nationality, followed by the Philippines and Thailand.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA'S ANTI-SEPARATISM BILL CATERS TO HAWKS: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: An anti-separatism bill mainland China is mulling is intended to please the hawks on the mainland, rather than mark the beginning of a period of confrontation between the mainland and Taiwan, a scholar said Sunday.

Hsu Su-chien, an associate researcher of Academia Sinica, said the proposal presented to the National People's Congress for discussion next week indicates a further straining of relations between Taiwan and the mainland after the Dec. 11 legislative elections in Taiwan, in spite of Taiwan's repeated reach-outs to Beijing.
This bill, once enacted, would soothe mainland hawks who are irritated by what they see as increased schism in Taiwan and are leaning on Beijing's leaders to do something to check it, Hsu said.

The mainland leaders agreed to accelerate economic exchanges with Taiwan just before it came up with the anti-separatism bill. These seemingly contradicting gestures indicate that Beijing is taking an iron hand in a velvet glove approach to Taiwan, according to Hsu.
This approach is widely employed by politicians both on the mainland and in Taiwan and does not mean that a period of confrontation is looming large, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: 3 More Held in Charles Subdivision Arsons; One Had Interest In Firefighting.
Federal agents arrested three more suspects yesterday in the massive arson fires that ravaged a Charles County subdivision Dec. 6 -- including a volunteer firefighter whose company was dispatched to the blaze.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ANTI-SEPARATISM LAW' MAY HAVE LITTLE IMPACT ON TAIWAN BOURSE

TEXT.P: News of Beijing's plan to draw up an "anti-separatism law" aimed at Taiwan may have a psychological impact on the Taiwan stock market over the short term, but the effects will be limited, market analysts said Sunday.

Claiming that short-term negative effects on the Taiwan Stock Exchange will be unavoidable in the wake of Beijing's move, market watchers predicted that the domestic bourse will still rise moderately in the coming days fueled by a continued influx of foreign capital taking advantage of an appreciating new Taiwan dollar.

They contended that the inflow of investment capital has been especially obvious since the Dec. 11 legislative elections, but pointed out that the 6,500-point mark will pose a major hurdle amid mounting pressure at a time when investor confidence has been shaken.

The value of the stock market totaled NT$ 1.37 trillion (US$42.2 billion) as of Friday last week, an increase of NT$22.38 billion, or 1.66 percent, compared to the previous week's level. But Friday's market turnover slid to a low of NT$60.21 billion, with the bourse's key weighted index standing at 6,009.32, a fall of 9.91 points from Thursday's finish.

Analysts called that a sign of eroded investor confidence and pointed out that the stock market might plunge again as it is moving toward a relatively high level range between 6,088 points and 6,135 points.

Some Taiwan businessmen based in mainland China see Beijing's move as an attempt to reiterate its sovereignty over Taiwan in the international community, imposing greater political risks on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Meanwhile, foreign exchanges experts predicted that the new Taiwan dollar will further strengthen against the U.S. dollar this week on the back of a firmer yen that finished higher against the greenback last Friday. They forecast that the local currency will hover between NT$32.2 and NT$32.5 to the U.S. dollar in the days ahead.
The new Taiwan dollar ended at 32.36 against the U.S. dollar Friday, a rise of NT$0.115 over the level of a week ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S STOCK MARKET VALUE UP OVER LAST WEEK

TEXT.P: The combined market value of listed companies in Taiwan hit NT$13.702 trillion (US$425.55 billion) at the close of trading Friday, up NT$223.84 billion, or 1.66 percent, over the week-earlier level, according to statistics compiled by the Taiwan Stock Exchange Co. (TSEC).
The weighted index -- the benchmark index of the domestic bourse -- moved up 97.69 points, or 1.65 percent, for the whole week to finish at 6,009.32 Dec. 17.
The surge was mainly due to stronger buying support by domestic and foreign investors in the wake of the Dec. 11 legislative elections, the TSEC report noted.
Most of the investors believe that the outcome of the elections contributed to maintaining Taiwan's political stability, analysts said.

Share prices for most of the 20 main categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 10.64 percent. Only three categories -- foodstuffs, plastics and chemicals, and banking and insurance, suffered setbacks.
There have been 240 trading days on the Taiwan Stock Exchange so far this year, with a combined turnover of NT$23.589 trillion.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S ANTI-SEPARATISM BILL MAY SPUR TAIWAN MEMORANDA: ANALYST
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 19 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Beijing's anti-separatism bill, although still in the pipeline, may trigger counterattack moves in Taiwan, including a memorandum for independence, a China hand with a Washington-based think tank said Saturday.
Alan D. Romberg, senior associate and director of the East Asia Program of the Henry L. Stimson Center, noted that the anti-secession bill will cause more fallout than consolidation for China.

The most crucial issue at present is that leaderships in both Taiwan and mainland China refrain from making the opposite side feel that achieving the goal it cares for the most is now hopeless, Romberg said during a seminar sponsored by the U.S.-China Policy Foundation.

If Beijing adopts the anti-separatism bill, it is highly probable that Taiwan will adopt a series of counterattacks, measures that would be hard to be opposed even by the opposition Kuomintang, which is known as pro-unification, Romberg forecast.

Romberg said that Beijing did not show pleasure with the defeat of President Chen Shui-bian's Democratic Progressive Party in the Dec. 11 legislative elections as widely expected, instead, it mounted new wave of verbal attacks on Chen and reiterated its belief that Chen will push for Taiwan independence even harder than before.
Romberg said that he thought otherwise and that Beijing should have taken an opposite approach.
Noting that there still exist hopes across the Taiwan Strait, Romberg said that Beijing should adopt "active" and "positive" approaches toward Taiwan to avoid driving the island farther away.

Quoting a Confucian paraphrase that says "improve the nation's humanity and virtue if people faraway defy, " Romberg said that the mainland should try its best to understand the cross-strait situation as well as what the Taiwan people are thinking.
A kinder and more thoughtful mainland will be much more attractive to Taiwan, he added.
Romberg suggested that firstly, Beijing should not intervene any longer Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) , because WHO membership has nothing to do with politics.

Secondly, he said, Beijing should resume its previous stance of defining the "direct links" as "cross-strait transportation links, " rather than "domestic routes, " and try to facilitate the re-opening of direct charter flight exchanges across the strait during the Chinese New Year period for the convenience of Taiwanese businessmen operating on the mainland.
Thirdly and most importantly, Romberg suggested that the two sides resume the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue.

If Beijing continues to insist that Taiwan's acknowledgement of its "one China" policy should be the premise on resuming dialogue, it should at least let lower-level and officially authorized talks start first, rather than letting go-betweens shuttle across the strait to pass information that is not necessarily officially sanctioned, Romberg stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC ADVISORS POSTPONE BRIEFINGS TO PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A panel of economic advisors postponed their briefings on major economic issues to president Chen Shui-bian recently in order that they could review their opinions on the issues.

Chen Tain-jy, president of the Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research and a member of the advisory panel, told CNA the postponement was made partly because the president's aide could not fit the briefings into the president's heavy schedule.

Chen Tain-jy said a meeting of the economists of the panel was scheduled for Dec. 30 to review their recommendations to the president on the issues of higher education tuition, the loss-making national health insurance program, taxation reform and the shortage of hi-tech workers.

Higher education tuition is not very high compared to some Western countries, but has stirred up widespread discontent in Taiwan, and the president's economic advisers have recommended that the government ensure disadvantaged people's access to higher education by offering education assistance to people with low income, disabled people and aborigines.
The assistance may take the forms of scholarship offered by schools or education loans extended by banks, Chen Tain-jy said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO STEM TRADE RELIANCE ON MAINLAND CHINA MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan must stem its high trade dependence on the mainland China market, as the situation is highly risky for Taiwan due to long-standing political feuding between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, according to an economist.

Chang Chien-i, a researcher with the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, made the call while giving a speech at a seminar over the weekend shortly after it was reported that Beijing is planning to establish an "anti-separatism law" to quell Taiwan independence.

According to Chang, Taiwan's trade and economic reliance on the mainland market hit a high of 34.32 percent in 2003, meaning that about one third of Taiwan's total outbound shipments went to the mainland.
The ratio is far higher than South Korea's record of less than 20 percent, Japan's 12.18 percent and the United States' 3.93 percent, he reported.
Citing mainland customs statistics, Taiwan exports to the mainland in 2003 totaled US$49.362 billion, a 20-fold increase over the 1990 level of US$2.255 billion, he said.

Since 2001, the mainland replaced the United States as Taiwan's No. 1 export outlet, he pointed out, adding that Taiwan outbound shipments to the mainland in the first half of this year already exceeded US$30 billion in value.
Such close trade and economic relations represent a looming crisis for Taiwan, a development upon which he blamed Taiwan's long-term political wrangling with the mainland China.

The special political situation between the two sides has deprived Taiwan businessmen of adequate and normal channels to invest in the mainland, putting them at much greater risk, he said, warning that any uncertain factor on the mainland China may in turn pose a grave threat to Taiwan's economic development and its market deployment strategies.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE JAPANESE FEELS ESTRANGED FROM CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 19 (CNA) (By Amy Huang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: More Japanese feel estranged from China, as the two countries are at odds over several issues, according to an opinion poll released by the Office of the Prime Minister recently.

The survey, conducted from Oct. 7-17 among 3,000 adults around the country found that 61 percent, or 18.1 percent more than in a survey conducted the previous year, said "yes" when asked whether ties between Japan and China are good, against 28.2 percent, or 18.8 percent less than the previous year, who answered "no."

On the other hand, only 37.6 percent of the respondents said "yes" to the question of whether China is a friendly neighboring state. That figure is the lowest on record since the survey began in 1975, and far away from the peak of 78.6 percent in 1980.

Political analysts ascribed the chilled relationship between Japan and the mainland to Beijing's protest against Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's visits to the Yasukuni Shrine, Chinese soccer fans rioting in Beijing after Japan defeated China in the final of the 2004 Asian Cup soccer, and the recent intrusion of a Chinese submarine into Japanese waters.

DOC.HEADLINE: KENYANS WIN ING TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL MARATHON TITLES

TEXT.P: Kenyan runners won both the men's and women's titles of the 2004 Taipei International Marathon Sunday.
Chelal Wilson won the men's title by finishing the 42.195-km marathon in 2:14:58, 58 seconds longer than the event's record.
Meanwhile, Jennifer Lingakwiang Chensinon took the women's title with 2: 34 and collected a NT$1 million (US$30,959) prize for breaking the 155-minute record.
The organizers set the NT$1 million prize for the champions if they break the 134-minute record for men and the 155-minute record for women.

A record high of nearly 17,000 contestants registered for the marathon, while more than 30,000 others joined a half-marathon (21 km) , nine-km race and three-km fun run in the annual events jointly sponsored by the Taipei city government, ING Antai Insurance Co. and Chinese Taipei Road Running Association.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who also took part in the marathon, said that he was pleased to see so many people from around the world attending the event, which was the third international marathon to be held in the city this year.
He said he hopes more people will take up running for health and fun.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIG GAPS IN SALARY FOR THOSE WORKING IN MAINLAND CHINA: POLL

TEXT.P: The gap between job seekers and companies for work in mainland China is quite big, as job seekers hope for higher salaries while employers say that salaries should be the same as those paid at home, according to the findings of a recent survey.

The poll conducted by www.104.com.tw discovered that about 60 percent of the respondents willing to work on the mainland think that they will get a raise of at least 50 precent in pay to do so, while some 40 percent of Taiwan companies surveyed said that they would offer a salary on a par with the pay for the same work in Taiwan, an executive of the headhunting Web site said.

For the time being, there are an average 7,894 job opportunities on the mainland per day for job seekers in Taiwan, the highest number on record in recent years, while the daily number of job seekers willing to work on the mainland also averages an all-time high of 15,168, he said.

According to the poll, 46 percent of the respondents said they would be willing to work on the mainland in order to get a promotion in the future. Around 39 percent said they would do so to add value to their abilities in the workplace, while 37 percent view the mainland as a promising market and some 35 percent think that they would get better pay.

Some 60 percent of the people surveyed believe they would get a pay hike of at least 50 percent for accepting a job on the mainland, while 24 percent said they would ask for double their Taiwan salaries. About 36 percent think that the mainland pay should be between 1.5 times or double the Taiwan level.

But at the same time, only 39 percent of the Taiwan companies polled said they would be willing to pay double pay for a mainland job, and 50 percent said they would offer the same pay for Taiwan workers on the mainland, with their prime consideration being cost-cutting, according to the survey.
The poll was carried out from Nov. 24-29, recovering 2,872 valid questionnaires. It had a margin of error of 4.8 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Pentagon seeks to expand role in intelligence.
The Pentagon is drawing up a plan that would give the military a more prominent role in intelligence-collection operations that have traditionally been the province of the Central Intelligence Agency, including missions aimed at terrorist groups and those involved in weapons proliferation, Defense Department officials say. The proposal is an effort by the Pentagon to expand it s role in intelligence gathering at a time when legislation signed by President Bush on Friday sets in motion sweeping changes in the intelligence community, including the creation of a national intelligence director. The main purpose of that overhaul is to improve coordination among the country's 15 intelligence agencies, including those controlled by the Pentagon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON NORU FORMS NEAR GUAM

TEXT.P: A tropical depression located near Guam developed into a typhoon which was dubbed Noru Sunday, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported.

The 29th typhoon reported in the Pacific area this year was centered about 390 kilometers east of Guam and 3,000 kilometers southeast of Taiwan as of 6 a.m. Sunday, moving northwesterly at a speed of 19 kilometers per hour.
The typhoon has a radius of 100 kilometers and is not expected to pose any threat to Taiwan, CWB meteorologists said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT NOMINATES SENIOR ADVISOR AS CONTROL YUAN CHIEF

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has nominated Clement C.P. Chang, one of his senior advisors, as the new Control Yuan president, Presidential Office officials said Sunday.

The officials who asked not be identified said that Chen has also decided to name Michael Hsin-huang Hsiao, one of his national policy advisors, as Chang's deputy and a list of 27 members to the nation's highest watchdog body.

Secretary General of the Presidential Office Su Tseng-chang will visit Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng Monday morning to inform him the president's decision and solicit legislators' support, the officials said.
According to the Republic of China's Constitution, all nominations must be approved by the Legislative Yuan,

Following his visit to the Legislative Yuan, Su will hold a news conference at the Presidential Office to introduce Chang, Hsiao and other would-be Control Yuan members to the media, the officials went on.
Chang, who was a minister of transportation and communications 1989-1991, has a wide range of experiences in the academic and political fields.

He obtained his masters degree in the agricultural econimics in 1949 and Ph. D. in the education administration in 1952 at University of Illinois. He is a founder of Tamkang University in Taipei and served as president and chairman of board of trustees of the university.
He also served as speaker of Taipei City Council and a member of the opposition Kuomintang Central Standing Committee.

Hsiao, 54, specializing in sociology, obtained his Ph. D. at State University of New York, Buffalo in 1979. He is a fellow of the Institute of Sociology of the Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest research institution.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 20, or the ninth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1852: British troops annex Pegu, lower Burma, during a war with Burma.
1913: Taiwan's North-South Railway Trunk Line is completed.
1921: Mahathir Mohamad, Malaysian prime minister, is born.
1927: Kim Young-sam, former president of South Korea, is born.
1922: Fourteen republics of Russia form the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.
1924: Adolf Hitler is paroled after serving eight months of a prison sentence after being convicted of high treason.
1928: Britain recognizes the government of the Republic of China.
1941: The Flying Tigers, flown by U.S. Air Force volunteers, shoot down four Japanese planes in their first encounter near Kunming in southwest China.
1944: Young Chinese students begin to enter training camps in response to a call to join the armed forces and fight against Japan.
1945: Soviet troops move an estimated US$2 billion-worth of machinery from Manchuria to the Soviet Union.
1950: Fu Shih-nien, president of National Taiwan University, dies of a stroke at the age of 55. He collapses while answering interpellations at the Taiwan Provincial Assembly.
1968: John Steinbeck, the American novelist who won the Nobel Prize for literature for books such as "The Grapes of Wrath" and "East of Eden," dies at the age of 66.
1960: The Viet Cong, the armed wing of the National Liberation Front, is founded in South Vietnam.
1968: The ROC chooses 26 new members of the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan from among 52 candidates.
1971: President Agha Mohammed Yahya Khan resigns after Pakistan losses control over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1973: Spanish Premier Luis Carrero Blanco is killed when assassins bomb his car in Madrid, Spain.
1981: The Kuangfu River Tunnel in Taitung is formally open to traffic, becoming the first railway tunnel under a river in Taiwan.
1982: Arthur Rubinstein, Russian-born American pianist, dies at the age of 95 in Geneva.
1986: Some 30,000 students march for democracy through the streets of Shanghai in mainland China's largest demonstration since the Cultural Revolution.
1988: The first batch of five mainland Chinese students, who are studying in the United States, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1989: Some 12,000 U.S. troops join 12,000 already in Panama to unseat Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as head of that country.
1991: President Boris Yeltsin announces that Russia wants to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
1994: Mexico lowers the peso's trading floor, triggering a drastic devaluation.
1997: South Korean President Kim Dae-jung pardons Chun Doo-hwan and Roh Tae-woo, two former military dictators who had tried to kill him when he was a dissident.
1998: Nkem Chukwu of Houston, Texas, becomes the first woman to give birth to eight live babies.
1999: The Wang Kuang-ying Library, dedicated to a public-spirited ROC man who collected garbage for 35 years and used the money he earned to buy books and donate them to the local and overseas institutions, is inaugurated in Taipei.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui tells visiting U.S. Congresswoman Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) that the ROC's ultimate goal of seeking peaceful reunification with mainland China remains unchanged.
2000: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian says when receiving a seven-member Japanese parliamentary delegation that maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait is in the common interest of the ROC, Japan and the United States.
2001: Twenty-one city and county chiefs from around Taiwan are sworn in at official ceremonies, vowing to better serve the local people and to deliver on their campaign promises.
2001: A consortium of leading telecommunication companies launches services on the Asia Pacific Cable Network 2 (APCN 2), the world's first Asian submarine ring system that comprises 19,000 km of cable connecting mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, the Philippines and Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO MONITOR BEIJING'S ANTI-SECESSION LEGISLATION: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Monday the government will closely monitor developments in mainland China's plan to enact an anti-secession law.
Yu made the remarks at a breakfast meeting with a group of senior business executives. Many Cabinet ministers were also present at the meeting.

The premier said that as senior mainland leaders have yet to disclose details of the so-called anti-secession law, which is widely viewed as mainly targeting at Taiwan, the government will adopt a wait-and-see attitude.
"It would be premature for us to announce response measures at this time. We'll instead keep a close watch of the developments, " Yu said.

Meanwhile, Huang Mao-hsiung, president of the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, said the business community has continued its "business as usual" attitude and will go ahead with its investment plans.
"We have heard about mainland China's new legislative plan, but the details and spirit of the legislation remain unclear. We need an in-depth review before we can make any comments," Huang said.

Beijing's official Xinhua News Agency created a stir in Taiwan last Friday by reporting that the National People's Congress (NPC) , mainland China's rubber-stamp parliament, will screen an anti-secession law at a meeting of the NPC Standing Committee Dec. 25-29 and that the bill could be passed at the annual NPC plenary session in March 2005.

There had been widespread speculation that mainland President Hu Jintao might disclose details about the anti-secession legislation in his speech at a Monday ceremony in Macau marking the fifth anniversary of the former Portuguese colony's return to Chinese rule.

However, Hu didn't raise the Taiwan issue in his speech and spent most of his time praising Macau and the way it has adapted to the "one country, two systems" model, designed to give Macau a wide degree of autonomy.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN NOMINATION LIST SENT TO LEGISLATURE FOR APPROVAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has sent a Control Yuan member nomination list to the Legislative Yuan for approval, the president's top aide said Monday.

Su Tseng-chang, secretary-general to the president, noted that he earlier called on Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng to solicit his support for speedy confirmation of the 29 names on the list to serve as members of the new Control Yuan -- the nation's top watchdog body.
The president nominated Clement C. P. Chang, current presidential adviser, as the Control Yuan head, and scholar Michael Hsin-huang Hsiao as Chang's deputy, Su said.
The 27 other names were selected by President Chen from a list of 53 names recommended by a screening team appointed by the president himself, Su added.

Vice President Annette Lu serves as the convener of the five-member screening team -- which includes Su, current Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien, Clement C. P. Chang and Michael Hsin-huang Hsiao and Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) Chairwoman Nita Ing.

"The president has kept his promise to nominate someone from outside the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to serve as the head of the Control Yuan. Even the vice president is a non-DPP member," Su said.
"This shows the impartiality of the president in preparing the name list," he added.

Clement C. P. Chang, 75, who holds a doctoral degree in education administration from the University of Illinois, is a founder of the Tamkang University. He served as Taipei City Council speaker in the past. He also served as Transportation and Communications Minister from 1989 to 1991, when he resigned due to corrupt allegations involving the purchase of a large number of government bonds and shares in a life insurance company under the name of his daughter Chang Chia-yi. He was acquitted of any wrongdoing this year.

Su said that Chang is by no means a political appointment as the media has reported, pointing out that Chang has rich experience in various fields and is active, dynamic and clear-minded. "Chang's age is not a problem," he added.

Su also spoke highly of the clean image of Michael Hsin-huang Hsiao, a fellow of the Institute of Sociology of the Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute. Hsiao, 56, has a doctoral degree from State University of New York, Buffalo.

Su said that eight out of 29 people on the nomination list are women, almost three times more than the previous time. Six of those nominated are current Control Yuan members, while eight are current or former legislators. The average age of the those on the list is 59.2 years old.

Notable among those nominated is Chang Fu-mei, current chairwoman of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission. Meanwhile, Chao Shou-po, chairman of Broadcasting Corporation of China and former chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs, though widely-tipped, was not included on the list.

Addressing concerns about possible conflict of interest in having THSRC Chairwoman Ing as a member of the nomination screening team while the THSRC is under investigation by the Control Yuan, Su said that this is not the first time that Ing has served on such a screening team and that she has been praised for being a successful entrepreneur.
"If the opposition party rejects the name list and asks for a new one, the constitutional process will not operate smoothly and the public will be let down," he said.
The 29 current Control Yuan members took office on Feb. 1, 1999, and their six-year term will expire Jan. 31, 2005.

Wall Street Journal: Burden of proof At 32, a decision: Is cancer small enough to ignore.
Because detection methods have greatly improved in recent years, more people are being diagnosed with cancer at its earliest stages. This is creating new questions. When is cancer the kind that can kill you and needs to be treated -- with all the toxic therapies and damaging side effects that go along with that decision? And when is it too small to matter? Autopsy studies have shown that people who died of other causes sometimes have cancer in their bodies. Researchers at Wayne State University in Detroit found 8 percent of 1,027 men in their 20s, who died of other causes, had small amounts of prostate cancer. In its study of 1,500 men, which lasted more than a decade, the percentage of those with cancer rose during each decade of a man's life. Fully 80 percent of men in their 70s were found to have microscopic cancers in their prostates during autopsies. Other autopsy studies have found microscopic amounts of cancer in the lungs, breasts, and thyroids of people who have died of other causes and weren't known to have cancer.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION URGED TO CONFIRM NOMINATED CONTROL YUAN MEMBERS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged the opposition Monday to respect its confirmation right and not block the nomination list of the next Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, submitted by President Chen Shui-bian.

Ker Chien-ming, DPP party whip in the legislature, made the remarks after the opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party said they will not rule out the possibility of rejecting the 29-member list.
Ker said that a five-member screening team that was nominated by Chen, has met several times to work out the nomination list in an open and transparent manner.

The president nominated Clement C. P. Chang, presidential senior adviser, as the president of the Control Yuan, and academician Michael Hsin-huang Hsiao, as Chang's deputy. But the 27 other names were selected by President Chen from a list of 53 banes recommended by the screen team.

Members of the screening team are Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang, incumbent Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien, Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) Chairwoman Nita Ing, Clement C.P. Chang and Michael Hsin-huang Hsiao, and the meetings were convened by Vice President Annette Lu.

"Now that the legislative elections are over, the opposition should return to rationality and put an end to continued confrontation. The confirmation of the nominated members of the Control Yuan will be a move in the right direction, " Ker said.
If the opposition rejects the list, it will trigger a serious confrontation, he added.

Meanwhile, Huang Teh-fu, KMT whip in the legislature, criticized both Clement C.P. Chang and Michael Hsin-huang Hsiao as "forever pro-ruling party" and "core-members of the ruling administration" and that they are far from "just and impartial."

Huang claimed that Chang has no deep connections with the KMT, although he served as minister of transportation and communications under the previous KMT administration, and that he has wide connections with political and business figures, which makes him unsuitable to head the Control Yuan.
Although Hsiao is a scholar, he was "practically" a campaign team member for Chen in his presidential bid, he added.

Huang also expressed regret over the other nominations, noting that many incumbent Control Yuan members who have performed superbly have not been nominated, while those members who investigated possible abuses in the first family and the TRHSC were shut out of the list.
Although unsatisfied with the nominees, he said, the KMT will not reject the list outright, but will nevertheless screen the list rigorously.
The PFP said that the nomination list is "highly controversial" and claimed it will not be able to monitor the performance of the government.
Liu Wen-hsiung, PFP whip in the legislature, said the party will hold a caucus meeting to reach a consensus on the matter.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said that as the head of the body that will exercise the confirmation, he is not in a position to criticize the nominated president and vice president of the Control Yuan, saying only that "it will be left to the public to have their say on the matter."

Wang made the remarks amid criticism that Clement C.P. Chang and Michael Hsin-huang Hsiao, nominated by the president as the head and deputy of the Control Yuan, are also part of the five-member screening team, making them both "umpires and players" in the nomination process.

Chen Chien-ming, legislative whip of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, an ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, claimed that many of those nominated are unsuitable and said he will suggest that the list is rejected.
Chen said that even though TSU Secretary-General Lin Jih-jia is included on the 29-name list, the list still needs to be discussed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP TAIWAN, JAPANESE UNIVERSITIES FORGE SISTERHOOD TIES

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) forged a sisterhood relationship with the University of Tokyo (UOT) Monday, turning a new page in the ever-growing cultural and educational exchanges between Taiwan and Japan.

NTU President Chen Wei-jao and UOT President Takeshi Sasaki signed a memorandum of understanding on the establishment of sisterhood ties and bilateral academic exchanges in a ceremony held at the NTU's second conference hall in Taipei.
It marked the first time that the UOT has ever signed a cooperative agreement with a Taiwan university.
Chen said he hopes the cooperation with the prestigious Japanese university can contribute to NTU's ultimate goal of globalization.

Under the terms of the agreement, the two top universities will exchange and students, cooperate on research projects in various professional fields and share information and materials, as well as co-sponsor workshops and academic forums.
The UOT is the oldest university in Japan and famous in the international community for its academic achievements. Many elite members of various Japanese social quarters are UOT graduates.

Both NTU's precursor -- Taipei Imperial University -- and the UOT belonged to the same imperial university system during the Japanese colonial rule of Taiwan. In addition to this historical tie, the two universities have long maintained close interaction.
The two universities are similar in scale. While NTU has 27,000 students, the UOT's enrollment reaches 28,000.

Both NTU and the UOT are members of the Association of East Asian Research Universities (AEARU) , which was founded in 1996 by the member university presidents as a forum for leading research-oriented universities in East Asia to exchange faculty and students, develop common curricula and transferable credits, share facilities, information and materials, cooperate on research projects, and conduct other mutual academic endeavors. Both Chen and Sasaki have served as AEARU president.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAMBIAN FM TO ARRIVE IN TAIWAN FOR OFFICIAL VISIT ON DEC. 21

TEXT.P: Gambian Foreign Minister Sidi Morro Sanneh will arrived in Taiwan Tuesday for a seven-day visit during which he will call on President Chen Shui-bian and tour major economic and cultural establishments, according to a statement released Monday by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Sanneh, 57, has served in several international organizations, including the Development Bank of Africa and the United Nations Development Program, before being named foreign minister in October, the statement said.

During his stay, the statement said, Sanneh will also visit his Taiwan counterpart, Tan Sun Chen, and call at the Government Information Office, the Mainland Affairs Council, the Department of Health and the International Cooperation and Development Fund.

Sanneh will also visit Gambian students studying in Taiwan, as well as the Nankang Software Park and the World Trade Center in Taipei and Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan before his departure Dec. 27, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA INFLATION TO CONTINUE IN EARLY 2005: THINK TANK

TEXT.P: Inflationary pressure in mainland China will continue to exist until early 2005, a researcher of a local think tank, the Chung-Hwa Institution for Economic Research, said Monday.
In an analysis of inflationary pressure on the mainland, Yang Su-fei said that in the first 10 months of this year, the mainland's consumer price index rose by 4.1 percent.

Yang noted that the price of agricultural products and the service sector have continued to rise, while the long-term deficit of such public facilities as water, electricity and gas have also produced price hike pressure.
Coupled with an overheated real estate market and the continued inflow of "hot money," it is expected that inflationary pressure will continue to exist into early next year, Yang concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA HOLDS INTERNATIONAL NGO PARTNERSHIP FORUM IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) opened the 2004 International Non-Governmental Organization (NGO) Partnership Forum in Taipei Monday to enhance the exchange of experiences among Taiwan's NGOs and their counterparts in the Third World, according to a MOFA statement.

Discussions in the two-day forum will focus on problems and the movement of citizens in the Third World, and NGO global and regional cooperative development, the statement said, noting that leaders of many international NGOs, including International Association for Volunteer Effort President Liz Burns, took part in the meeting.

The statement said that the MOFA has arranged additional activities for the foreign dignitaries, including a visit to the Children Are Us Foundation and the Eden Social Welfare Foundation Dec. 22 to introduce Taiwan's efforts in helping challenged children and under-privileged women around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OFFICIAL URGES COOPERATION INSTEAD OF CONFRONTATION

TEXT.P: Now that the legislative elections are over, the ruling and the opposition parties should "replace confrontation with cooperation," an official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Monday.

Chang Chun-hsiung made the remarks at the DPP's central standing committee headquarters after receiving the certificates of at-large and overseas legislators of the DPP from Chang Cheng-hsiung, chairman of the Central Election Commission.

Commenting on reports that Lin Feng-cheng, secretary-general of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , said the DPP is continuing its "cut-throat" tactics -- wooing 15 KMT and independent legislators to the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, Chang said that he was not aware of such a thing, nor had he met the 15 legislators in question.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party managed to maintain its slim legislative majority after the Dec. 11 elections, compared with the "pan-green camp, " which ended up with only 101, below its original expectations.

Chang said that cooperation is different from the "cut-throat" competition in the elections and that the DPP will continue to solicit support from the opposition parties on the policies, bills and budget submitted by the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MAJOR PROJECT INVESTMENTS TOP US$27.19 BILLION IN 11 MONTHS

TEXT.P: There were 2,550 new major project investments amounting to NT$881.2 billion (US$27.19 billion) in the first 11 months of this year, accounting for 101.74 percent of the goal of NT$866.2 billion set for this year, according to a report published Monday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

The ministry defines a major investment project as one with total investment over NT$200 million. A total of 10 new major domestic investment plans, each valued at over NT$10 billion for a combined total of NT$408.3 billion were registered, while a total of nine investment projects each valued between NT$5 billion and NT$10 billion for an accumulated total of NT$61.3 billion were recorded.
According to the ministry, next year's goal is NT$867 billion for domestic investment projects such as those in the manufacturing industry, logistics service, shopping malls and private power plants.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS TAKE PRIDE IN TAIWAN'S ADMISSION TO OECD COMMISSION

TEXT.P: Taiwan officials took pride in the country's admission to the Trade Committee of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) Monday, calling it an affirmation of Taiwan's economic strength.

One month after the OECD allowed Taiwan to take part in the meetings of its Trade Committee as an "ad hoc observer, " Chen Chih-mai, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan, said the admission will facilitate Taiwan's efforts to explore foreign markets.

Although the OECD gave Taiwan the status under the name of "Chinese Taipei" rather than the "Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu, " the name the country used in applying for OECD access, Chen said the Bureau of Foreign Trade, which was in charge of the application, will keep negotiating with the OECD in hopes of having the designation changed.

Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade, said Taiwan has already been admitted to the OECD Competition Committee under the name of "Chinese Taipei" as an observer, but the country applied to join the Trade Committee under the same name it used in the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Michel Lu, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, echoed Chen's statement by saying that the country is trying every avenue to change its name in the OECD to match that used in the WTO.

Yeh Min-feng, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Executive Yuan, said the Trade Commission is the most important committee in the OECD and Taiwan's access to it will give the country a chance to get international trade information first hand.
It takes time for an ad hoc observer to become an observer, but Yeh said this was a good start.

DOC.HEADLINE: HENRY LEE MADE HONORARY CITIZEN OF TAIPEI BY MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou granted honorary Taipei citizenship to Dr. Henry Lee, a famous Chinese-American forensic scientist, Monday in recognition of his assistance in training the city's forensic personnel.

Lee was born in Jiangsu province in mainland China and came to Taiwan at the end of the Chinese Civil War when he was six. He graduated in 1960 from the Taiwan Central Police College with a degree in Police Science. Lee became the youngest captain in modern Chinese history when he was promoted at the age of 22 during his service at the Taipei City Police Headquarters.
Ma said Lee has helped the Taipei City Police Headquarters for years train a new generation of forensic professionals.
"The conferment of honorary citizenship represents our gratitude for Lee's contributions to our forensic investigation work," Ma said.
Lee is the ninth non-Taipei citizen to obtain the honor since the Taipei City Government set up the system for individuals who have make significant contributions to the city.
Lee, who is currently on an eight-day visit in Taipei, said he was honored to receive the recognition from the city of Taipei.
Earlier in the day, Lee visited the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) to discuss preparations for an international seminar on forensic science to be held in Taiwan next year.

Lee, who conducted a forensic investigation into the March 19 presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu this summer, said that if time permits, he will also visit the Criminal Investigation Bureau to learn the latest developments in the case.

Asked about his view on the controversial "319 truth commission" formed by the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan to pursue look into the mysterious shooting, Lee said he recognizes the necessity of setting up a special commission to look into the high-profile incident, but he added that the investigative work itself should be handled by the CIB.

"It's all too common in foreign countries to form a supra-ministerial and non-political commission to pursue the truth behind major cases that have caused widespread public concerns, " Lee said, adding that the most important thing is that the commission should transcend "ministries and politics."

Noting that the gist of forensic work lies in "letting the evidence speak for itself, " Lee said the conclusion of his forensic investigation of the March 19 shooting is that President Chen indeed sustained a gunshot wound.

Lee stressed that the conclusion has nothing to do with whether he sympathizes with Taiwan's "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its pro-independence allies or the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party.
If local individuals or groups have different views about the March 19 shooting, Lee said, they can convey their views to the "319 truth commission" for the reference of its members.
Lee said he himself has received at least 500,000 e-mails from the United States, mainland China and Taiwan about the March 19 shooting.
"I would have to stay in Taiwan for three years if I were to read all of them. But I have never read any of them because I don't want my professionalism being affected by speculation," Lee said.
He also hailed the recent identification of an underground gunsmith by the CIB investigative team as the one who made the bullets used in the shooting as a "breakthrough."

The team has sifted through a myriad of seemingly unrelated things to determine that the now-detained gunsmith, Tang Shou-yi, was the manufacturer of the bullets used in the shooting. One bullet grazed Chen's abdomen and slightly injured Lu.

Pointing out that a forensic investigator starts by collecting physical evidence, then gathers clues that lead to suspects, and then determines the motives in a case, Lee said he was glad to learn that Taiwan's investigation team has proceeded along this path in its probe.

Many "pan-blue alliance" politicians and supporters have disseminated a lot of outrageous speculation about the shooting, including that it was staged by President Chen to sway sympathy votes in his favor.

Chen beat his sole challenger, KMT Chairman Lien Chan, in the March 20 presidential election. Lien filed two lawsuits to nullify Chen's re-election victory and even the entire election so that a new one could be held. The Taiwan High Court rejected the re-election annulment suit, but Lien has appealed the case to the Supreme Court,which has yet to hand down a ruling.

DOC.HEADLINE: OIL PRICE RISE HEADS LIST OF 2004 TOP-10 INTERNATIONAL NEWS EVENTS

TEXT.P: The meteoric rise of oil prices on the international market -- once hitting US$55 per barrel -- was ranked by the Central News Agency (CNA) in Taiwan as the top international news event in 2004 because of its global economic impact.
The top 10 international news stories chosen by CNA are as follows: 1. International oil prices skyrocket to hit US$55 per barrel at one
point and affect global economic development. 2. U.S. President George W. Bush wins re-election by defeating John
Kerry in the Nov. 2 election. 3. The European Union expands May 1 with the entry of 10 countries
in central and eastern Europe to become a 25-nation organization. 4. The U.S. maintains its Olympic superiority by capturing 35 gold
medals in the 2004 Athens Olympic Games, followed by China and
Russia. 5. The World Health Organization and the Food and Agriculture
Organization of the United Nations warn against the spread of
avian flu. 6. A Russian school siege by Chechnya-based terrorists leaves at
least 338 people dead, about half of them children, and more than
700 injured. 7. The U.S. Federal Reserve Board in June makes its first interest
hike in four years, leading to a global wave of interest rate
adjustments. 8. Terrorism prevails the world with attacks in Indonesia, Iraq,
Spain, Egypt, Russia and Saudi Arabia. 9. Israel is ready to hold negotiations with new Palestinian leaders
following Yasser Arafat's death and the Israeli parliament
approves Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's proposal to withdraw
unilaterally from the Gaza Strip. 10. Greenhouse effects increase global warming and change the world
climate, causing a series of strong hurricanes or typhoons to
hit North America, the Philippines, Taiwan, Japan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA'S TOP-10 NEWS EVENTS FROM MAINLAND CHINA IN 2004

TEXT.P: Jiang Zemin giving up his position as chairman of the Central Military Commission was ranked by Taiwan's Central New Agency (CNA) as the most significant China-related story for 2004.
The top 10 China-related news stories chosen by CNA are as follows: 1. Jiang Zemin quits his job as chairman of the Central Military
Commission and is succeeded by Hu Jintao. 2. Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao declares measures to slow down
economic development to prevent overheating and ensure a soft
landing. 3. China signs an agreement with the Association of Southeast Asian
Natoins to build a free trade area by 2010. 4. The Standing Committee of the National People's Congress rules
out the possibility for Hong Kong to choose through a popular
election the chief executive in 2007 and the Legislative Council
in 2008. 5. China leads the world in attracting foreign direct investment in
2003, hitting US$53 billion. 6. China settles its last territorial dispute with Russia along
their 4,300 kilometer border by signing an agreement. 7. Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao says his government is contemplating

DOC.HEADLINE: MARCH 19 SHOOTING TOPS 2004 DOMESTIC NEWS EVENTS: CNA

TEXT.P: The March 19 election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu has been selected as the top news event in Taiwan in 2004 by the Central News Agency of Taiwan.

Chen and Lu were shot while they were campaigning in a motorcade in the southern city of Tainan on the eve of the March 20 presidential election. One bullet grazed Chen's stomach and another hit Lu's right knee. The gunman or gunmen managed to flee the scene.

The following are the top-10 domestic news events for 2004: 1. The president and vice president survive an apparent assassination attempt on the eve of the March 20 presidential election. The two were re- elected. 2. The Chen-Lu ticket wins re-election in the March 20 presidential election by a slim margin of fewer than 30,000 votes; the sole challenging ticket of Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong then file two lawsuits to nullify the Chen-Lu re-election victory and even the entire election on the grounds that the election-eve shooting was staged and the activation of the "national security mechanism" unfairly affected the election result. 3. The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, the PFP and the
New Party retains its slim majority in the new legislature
elected on Dec. 11; President Chen resigns from the ruling
Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairmanship to assume the
responsibility for the election loss; and veteran DPP Legislator
Ker Chien-ming is named acting DPP chairman. 4. Taekwondo fighters Chen Shih-hsin and Chu Mu-yen win gold medals
at the Athens Olympic Games, breaking Taiwan's "zero gold medal
count" record in its 72-year history of taking part in the

Olympics. 5. Taiwan's first-ever nationwide referendum on strengthening national defense and talks with mainland China are held along with the presidential election; both referendums are deemed invalid because the participation of voters fails to exceed 50 percent of all eligible voters. 6. The Legislative Yuan passes a bill paving the way for
implementation of a "movable" personal pension account system for

laborers from July 2005. 7. The Legislative Yuan passes a bill to amend the ROC Constitution that will set the stage for sweeping legislative reforms, including halving the number of legislative seats from the seventh Legislative Yuan, extending the term of office of legislators to four years and introducing a "single seat, two ballots" election system, 8. President Chen pledges in his May inauguration speech that a
constitutional re-engineering project will be completed during
his second term without touching on such sensitive issues such as
sovereignty, territory and the unification vs. independence
debate while giving birth to a new constitution through a
referendum to be implemented from 2008. 9. The Ministry of National Defense refers a special NT$610.8
billion arms procurement bill to the legislature for approval,
but the bill stalls because the ruling and opposition parties
cannot reach a consensus on the huge spending plan. 10. Taiwan's first self-developed, remote-sensing satellite --
ROCSAT-2 -- is successfully launched into orbit from the
Vandenberg Air Force Base in California at 1: 47 a.m. May 21
Taipei time. Taiwan now possesses its own high-resolution
imaging system that performs real-time remote sensing of the
oceans and land in the vicinity of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, JAPAN AND SOUTH KOREA MUST UNITE AGAINST CHINA: VP LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu called for the formation Monday of an alliance of Japan, South Korea and Taiwan to stand up to mainland China's nefarious schemes.

Meeting Japanese business leader Uichiro Niwa, chairman of ITOCHU Corporation, a globally integrated trading company, Lu said the world, attracted by mainland China's large market, has invested huge amounts in mainland China without realizing that it is developing into a military power with designs on other countries' territory.
To contain mainland China's expansion, Lu said Japan, South Korea and Taiwan -- the three democracies sharing Confucianism in East Asia -- should form a triangle to check mainland China's power.
Lu urged the ITOCHU Corporation to play a pivotal role in bringing about a Japan-South Korea-Taiwan triumvirate.

Albeit small in size, Taiwan can boast of having advanced, hi-tech industries and is devoted to bringing its trade practices in line with those of the international community in every field, Lu added.
Lu said Taiwan is working hard to develop itself into a global business hub where goods can be delivered to any corner of the world within 48 hours.

Meanwhile, noting that Taiwan is planning to build a rapid transportation system between Taipei City and the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan, Lu told Niwa that Taiwan encourages Japanese companies to bid for project contracts.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ONE COUNTRY, TWO SYSTEMS' NOT APPLICABLE TO TAIWAN: CABINET

TEXT.P: The "one country, two systems" formula used by Beijing to administer Hong Kong and Macau is not applicable to Taiwan because Taiwan is an independent sovereign state, Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Monday.

Chen made the remarks after mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao praised the merits of the "one country, two systems" formula in a speech delivered in Macau marking the fifth anniversary of the former Portuguese colony's return to Chinese rule.
Chen said Taiwan's status fundamentally differs from Hong Kong and Macau's, both of which were previously Western colonies.
Moreover, Chen said that since the two former colonies reverted to Beijing' s control, they have both retrogressed in democracy, freedom, human rights and the rule of law.

With the number of Beijing's violations of its "one country, two systems" promise in Hong Kong and Macau increasing steadily, Chen said the formula cannot withstand the test of time and a changing environment. Such a formula can never be applicable to Taiwan, he added.

Quoting tallies compiled by Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), Chen said that as of June this year, Beijing had violated "one country, two systems" promises 157 times in Hong Kong since the former British colony's return to Chinese rule in July 1997, including Beijing's veto of Hong Kong's popular election plan and requiring Beijing's prior consent to any of Hong Kong's political reform plans.
Nine major controversial cases also occurred in Macau in the past five years, Chen said.

The results of an MAC survey conducted shortly after Hong Kong's return to Chinese rule showed that 76 percent of Taiwan people interviewed said they were opposed to the "one country, two systems" unification formula, Chen said, adding that the ratio of "naysayers" had risen to 81 percent in a similar survey conducted in September this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER UNVEILS ECONOMIC GOALS FOR NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun unveiled the nation's economic goals for next year Monday, including a gross domestic product of NT$11 trillion (US$339.76 billion) , a national income average of US$15,000, an unemployment rate below 4 percent and an economic growth rate of 5 percent.

In a breakfast meeting with members of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, Yu complained that he was criticized as being too feeble when he was friendly to the opposition in the Legislative Yuan in the beginning of his premiership, and was criticized as being too arrogant when he found it was difficult to press through his legislative agenda and tried to bring public pressure to bear on the legislature.

Yu, who is supposed to resign with his Cabinet before the new legislature begins its session next February, said he found his premiership was like walking a tightrope between being too feeble and too arrogant.

Huang Mao-hsiung, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce said he would be surprised if the economic growth rate for next year could hit 5 percent, which is much higher than the forecast of many think tanks.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN DECIDES TO GRANT TOURIST VISA TO FORMER ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 20 (CNA) (By Amy Huang & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: The Japanese government will grant tourist visas to former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, his family members and medical personnel who will accompany him to visit Japan later this year, a senior Japanese government official said Monday.
Hiroyuki Hosada, chief Cabinet secretary, said at a news conference that Lee and his entourage will visit Japan late this year and the beginning of next year for sightseeing.
Their visits are private in nature and they will not participate in political activities during their stay, Hosada added.

Informed sources in Japan who asked not be identified said that the Japanese government is expected to grant visas to Lee and members of his entourage Dec. 22 and that Lee and his group will arrive in Nagoya Dec. 27 to start their visit, which will also take them to Kyoto and Kanazawa.
Lee and his entourage are scheduled to leave Japan for home Jan. 2, they added.

Lee presented his application for a tourist visa to Japan Dec. 17 to the Taipei Office of Japan's Interchange Association, the de facto Japanese embassy in Taiwan, one day after Hosada announced in Tokyo that the Japanese government had decided in principle to issue a tourist visa to Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. URGED TO STOP CHINA FROM PROCEEDING WITH ANTI-SEPARATISM LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 20 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: The United States should privately urge China not to proceed with proposed anti-separatism legislation, a China specialist with a Washington-based think tank suggested Monday.

Bonnie Glaser, a senior researcher of the Center of Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), said that U.S. officials should seek to explain to Beijing why doing so would be counterproductive to Chinese and U.S. interests in preserving peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

Taipei and Beijing should open talks to work out lunar new year charter flight services and direct cross-strait transportation links, she proposed, adding that the two sides should avoid taking steps that aggravate tensions and instead should pursue ways to defuse those tensions.

Taiwan has put forwards some useful suggestions for confidence building measures (CBMs) , Glaser went on, suggesting that the two sides can unilaterally implement CBMs aimed at building trust and averting accident or miscalculation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 21, or the 10th day of the 11th month of Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1620: Pilgrims on the ship Mayflower come ashore at Plymouth, Massachusetts.
1804: Mohammed Ali Jinnah, founder and first governor-general of Pakistan, is born.
1817: Governor Lachlan Macquarie formally adopts the name "Australia" for the British colony located on the continent with the same present-day name.
1876: Joseph Stalin, Soviet leader, is born.
1898: Scientists Pierre Curie and Marie Curie discover radium.
1901: The "Ching Yi Pao," a newspaper founded by Liang Chi-chao, who together with Kang Yu-wei initiated a reform movement in 1898, ceases publishing after the 100th issue.
1930: Hwang Thu-sui, Taiwan's first sculptor, dies at the age of 35.
1935: Walt Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" premieres in the United States.
1940: F. Scott Fitzgerald, the American author who chronicled the Jazz Age in books such as "Tender is the Night" and "The Great Gatsby," dies at the age of 44.
1945: George Smith Patton Jr., the U.S. general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany during World War II, dies in a car crash at the age of 60.
1958: Charles de Gaulle is elected president of France after a new constitution is adopted, marking the beginning of the Fifth Republic.
1968: The Apollo 8 spacecraft, as a part of the United States' Apollo program to land men on the moon, is launched.
1971: Hsieh Kuan-sheng, president of the Judicial Yuan, dies in Taipei.
1971: Kurt Waldheim, an Austrian diplomat who later become president, is chosen to be the secretary-general of the United Nations on his birthday.
1972: East and West Germany sign a treaty ending more than two decades of enmity.
1975: The convention of the World Chinese Language Education Association opens in Taipei.
1975: Oil ministers from 12 countries are taken hostage after terrorists raid an OPEC meeting in Vienna, Austria.
1975: The Executive Yuan announces that Taiwan's economy grew by 2.8 percent in 1975, with a GNP of US$14.4 billion and per capita income of US$700.
1988: Soviet cosmonauts Musa Manarov and Vladimir Titov return to earth after a record 365 days in space.
1988: A Pan American jumbo jet crashes in the Scottish border town of Lockerbie, killing all 258 people on board.
1990: The building of the ROC Navy's first missile frigate begins at the Kaohsiung shipyard of the China Shipbuilding Corp.
1991: The ruling Kuomintang wins 71 percent of the vote and 254 of the 325 seats in elections for the Second National Assembly.
1995: Under an agreement signed between Israel and the PLO in September 1995, Israeli troops withdraw from Bethlehem, ending their 28 years of occupation.
1998: Beijing sentences mainland Chinese dissidents Xu Wenli and Wang Youcai to prison terms of more than 10 years each for trying to register the China Democracy Party.
1999: Taiwan is listed as the 12th-most important maritime country in the world for the year.
2000: Taiwan's non-profit Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) announces the development of a commercial software package, dubbed Fast Local Alignment for Gigabases (FLAG), allowing rapid genomic DNA searches and comparisons.
2001: The Legislative Yuan approves an amendment to the Employment Services Act allowing foreign workers to work in Taiwan up to six years instead of three years.
Confucius: "Uphold the cause of the just and put down every cause that is unjust, and the people will submit. But uphold the cause of the unjust and put down every cause that is just, then the people will not submit."
