DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AN IMPORTANT INTERNATIONAL ECONOMY: AIT OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 20(CNA) (By C.J. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A senior official of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) has affirmed that Taiwan has become an important international economy and a driving force of world trade.

David, J. Keegan, deputy director of the AIT Taipei office, made the affirmation in his remarks given at a reception held recently in honor of the continuing competition policy dialogue between the AIT and the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office. The AIT published the remarks on its Web site Monday.

Taiwan is the world's 17th largest economy and the fourth leading economy in Asia, ranking behind only Japan, China and South Korea, the official said, adding that the island's GDP reached US$282 billion and its total trade hit US$271 billion in 2003.
He also noted that Taiwan is the United States' ninth largest export market and eighth largest trade partner, adding that it is also the sixth largest market for U.S. agricultural exports.

"Taiwan has seen a series of successful transitions over the last five decades, from import substitution to export-led growth, from labor-intensive products to more capital-and-technology-intensive goods, and from doing all operations in Taiwan to moving production off-shore to take advantage of an increasingly globalized economy, " Keegan said.

Pointing out that U.S. aid in earlier years had helped Taiwan's economic development, he said that one should also attribute the island's development to its appropriate policies, healthy economic foundation, excellent education system, high quality labor force and flexible industrial structures.

"At every stage, Taiwan's companies have been able to find opportunities that maximize the island's unique mix of resources. As a result, Taiwan has emerged as a ranking international economy and an industrial powerhouse," he said.

However, he also noted that Taiwan is at a crucial point where both international trade and domestic market reforms will figure prominently in its economic future. He suggested that "to take its economy to the next level, Taiwan will need economic policies that attract new investment in services and manufacturing."

He also suggested that in order to ensure the success of Taiwan's economy in the future, the island should continue to push forward with its financial reform, to improve its investment climate, to implement its commitments to the World Trade Organization, to further liberalize its trade in labor service and goods, and to further protect intellectual property rights.
The AIT is the United States' de facto embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENTAGON TO POST ACTIVE DUTY OFFICER IN TAIPEI: U.S. EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 20 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. Department of Defense is considering posting an active duty army officer in Taiwan to serve as a liaison with Taiwan's military, a U.S. expert with close ties to the Pentagon said Monday.

The expert, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told the Central News Agency that the United States will not be the first country with no diplomatic ties with Taiwan to have stationed an active duty officer in Taipei.

For example, the expert said, France has long posted an active duty officer in Taiwan. To the best of his knowledge, he said, a French military officer was promoted to the rank of major-general after concluding his stint in Taiwan.

Since the United States switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979, military exchanges with Taiwan have been handled by civilian contractors at the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT).

The expert said the current U.S. law must be revised before the Pentagon sends active duty military staff to Taiwan. Under its present law, active duty military personnel must first apply for duty suspension before going to Taiwan and their service stint in Taiwan cannot be counted into their seniority when they return to continue their service in the military. As the suspension of seniority can affect promotions, few U.S. military officers would be interested in serving in Taiwan.
The Pentagon will discuss possible law revisions with Congress with reference to French provisions, the expert said.

Jane's Defense Weekly reported Sunday that the Pentagon would gradually send active duty military personnel to replace civilian contractors at AIT, starting with the deployment of a U.S. army officer to head a Technical Liaison Section in mid-2005.

The Pentagon had considered stationing an active duty officer in Washington's de facto diplomatic mission in Taiwan in 2000, but put off the plan because of concerns about Beijing's protests, the weekly said, quoting an unidentified source.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOMINEE FOR CONTROL YUAN PRESIDENT TO SEEK OPPOSITION SUPPORT

TEXT.P: The controversial nominee for Control Yuan president, Clement C.P. Chang, said Tuesday he will visit opposition leaders in the near future to seek their support after coming under attack as being a corrupt politician siding with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The 75-year-old Chang resigned from the position of transportation and communications minister in 1991 over corruption allegations involving the purchase of a large number of shares in Kuo Hua Life Insurance at what appeared to be undervalued prices using his daughter's name.

Though he was acquitted of any wrongdoing when the case was closed in April this year, politicians from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) are challenging his nomination because of the case.
The opposition politicians pointed out that even President Chen Shui-bian, who was then a legislator, had criticized Chang as "taking the law into his own hands" for ignoring court subpoenas.
At a news conference, Chang dismissed the allegations as a "misunderstanding, " saying he was never indicted in the case and was only asked to testify as a witness.

Chang said he accepted President Chen's offer to assume the country's top position of the supreme watchdog body because he wanted to do something for Taiwan and end the confrontation between the "pan-blue" and "pan-green" camps.
Chang, who is a permanent member of the KMT and a member of the party's Central Evaluation Committee presidium, said it was totally unreasonable for KMT politicians to attack him.
Chang said he will not quit the KMT but will stop participating in partisan activities and suspend his membership immediately after becoming Control Yuan president.
Chang said he is trying to arrange a visit with KMT Chairman Lien Chan and will also visit PFP Chairman James Soong and former President Lee Teng-hui to try to win their support.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 1.91 points to close at 5,987.85.
The bourse opened at 5,981.97 and fluctuated between 6,000.77 and 5,975.73 during trading. A total of 2.64 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$53.83 billion (US$1.66 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.2 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 1.1 percent, textile stocks at 1 percent, cement stocks at 0.6 percent and foodstuff issues and banking and financial shares both at 0.2 percent.
Two other major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down at 0.3 percent and plastics and chemicals shares lost 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 447 to 205, with 196 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January gained 16 points to close at 5,978, with 13,598 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February moved up three points to finish at 5,978, with 16 contracts traded, while March futures lost two points to finish at 5,960, with one contract traded.
June futures gained 36 points to finish at 5,970, with four contracts traded, while September futures moved down 14 points to close at 5,851, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,962 for January, 5,975 for February, 5,962 for March, 5,934 for June and 5,865 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
January TE futures moved down 0.1 points to close at 223.9, with 1,563 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for February, March, June and September.

January TF futures gained 5.8 points to finish at 1,011.8, with 2,437 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved up 4.4 points to end at 1,009.4, with 15 contracts traded. June TF futures gained 10.8 points to finish at 1,009.8, with two contracts changing hands, while September TF futures moved up 16.4 points to close at 1,009.8, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, dropping NT$0.07 to close at NT$32.338.
A total of US$469 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$32.307 and fluctuated between NT$32.236 and NT$32.359.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE PUTS OFF CONSIDERATION OF CONTROL YUAN NOMINATIONS

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan Tuesday decided to put off its consideration of the Control Yuan nominations made by President Chen Shui-bian owing to objection from opposition lawmakers.

President Chen's request for legislators to consent to the nominations was shelved during a meeting of the opposition-controlled procedures committee held to schedule the legislative agenda for next week.
The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party are dissatisfied with the nominations, especially that of Clement C.P. Chang, who was nominated for Control Yuan president.

The nomination of Chang, who resigned from the position of transportation and communications minister in 1991 over corruption allegations, has been criticized by the opposition as representing the degeneration of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Disagreeing with the criticism, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said the nominations are very proper because they have taken into consideration partisanship, gender, ethnic and professional representation.

Yu said it is impossible for President Chen to present a nomination list that is satisfactory to everybody under the present political situation dominated by a rivalry of the "pan-blue" and "pan-green" camps.
DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan said nothing is perfect in the world and that it is very normal for people to have different opinions in a democratic country.

Meanwhile, DPP legislators, including Tuan Yi-kang, Shen Fu-hsiung and Lin Cho-shui, expressed their opposition to the party's plan to order all DPP legislators to vote in favor of the nominations or face punishment.
In response, DPP legislative caucus whip Ker Chien-ming said the caucus will seek to reach a consensus on the nominations among its members before the vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF U.S. TRAVELERS TO TAIWAN GROWS THIS YEAR
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 20 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: There were 346,250 travelers from the United States to Taiwan during the period from January to November this year, a growth of 44.93 percent over the same period last year when the island was affected by severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) , an official of tourist affairs from Taiwan's representative office in New York said Monday.
The 2004 figure also represented an increase of 1.89 percent over the same period two years ago, said Chang Cheng-yuan.
He was speaking at an event at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York to unveil the results of Taiwan's tourism efforts.
Nearly 50 officials and representatives of the tourist business, including Representative Andrew L.Y. Hsia of the office, and gourmet commentator Burt Wolf attended the news conference.

Chang described the growth in the number of American tourists to Taiwan as a "nice mark" this year -- the government-sponsored "2004 Visit Taiwan Year." He hoped that the number could expand to the goal of 640,000 by next year, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS TO SEEK PFP CHAIRMAN'S SUPPORT FOR ASSETS, ARMS BILLS

TEXT.P: Leaders of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus will visit opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong to seek his support for an arms procurement bill and another one aimed at facilitating the investigation into the assets of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , a DPP legislator said Tuesday.
Tsai Huang-liang, one of the caucus leaders, said the caucus is showing its goodwill in an effort to end the deadlock.
Tsai proposed that the DPP will cooperate with the PFP in the future on any issues, policies, legislation and budgets that involve no major controversy.
The two bills were again blocked by the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP at a procedures committee meeting held Tuesday to schedule the legislative agenda for next week.
While the PFP has always been against the arms procurement bill, it has recently softened its stand on the party assets bill.
PFP legislative caucus convener Liu Wen-hsiung said last week that the PFP would support the DPP-proposed party assets legislation because the DPP had dropped the term "ill-gotten" from the bill.

However, the PFP decided to put off its support for the DPP after the KMT promised to speed up the legislative proceeding of a political parties bill that will regulate the conducts and assets of political parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND TO INTRODUCE SECURITY CLEARANCE SYSTEM

TEXT.P: A plan to implement a security clearance system in the military is mainly aimed at protecting national security information and has nothing to do with investigating personal party affiliations, a defense official said Tuesday.

Speaking at a regular news conference, military spokesman Navy Capt. Liu Chih-chien said the Ministry of National Defense (MND) has drafted comprehensive regulations governing security clearance investigations.
Under the new system, Liu said, only those who have passed security clearance investigations can assume important or sensitive military positions.

A security clearance investigation generally refers to an inquiry into an individual military officer's loyalty, character, trustworthiness and reliability to ensure that he or she is qualified to be given access to national security information.
Asked whether having relatives in mainland China would affect an individual's security clearance, Liu said that will be decided on a case-by-case basis.
Those who admit to having relatives on the mainland but have no close contact and have been certified by security units will not be subject to monitoring, Liu said.
"We decided to adopt the security clearance measure after we found that human factors have played an important part in a spate of communist espionage cases uncovered recently," he said.

There is nothing unusual about implementing this kind of positive vetting, as it has long been employed in advanced democratic countries, including Britain, Germany and the United States, Liu said, adding that domestic civil servants have also been subject to similar security checks.
Liu said those who fail security clearance investigations will not suffer any loss in their work rights. But, he added, they will not be given important or sensitive positions.

According to the MND-drafted scheme, individual officers will be required to submit a self-confession statement that will be subject to in-depth investigation by police or other investigative authorities. The specific officer will be informed of the investigation results and those who are dissatisfied with the results can appeal their cases.

In an effort to protect the rights and interests of those who are subject to security clearance investigations, Liu went on, some existing rules concerning the service of military officers and non-commissioned officers will be revised to ensure that there are no violations of their human rights in the process of security clearance investigations.
"Abiding by due procedure, legal use of investigation results and protection of the legitimate rights of those subject to security clearance probes will be our top work guidelines, " Liu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WELCOMES JAPAN'S GRANTING OF VISA TO FORMER PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) welcomes Japan's granting of a visa to former President Lee Teng-hui and will if necessary extend him assistance during his planned visit to Japan, a MOFA spokesman said Tuesday.
Michel Lu made the remarks after being informed that Japan had granted a tourist visa to Lee despite a strong protest from Beijing.
Lu said that the MOFA will instruct its representative office in Japan to help Lee during his stay in Japan, including giving him preferential treatment at immigration and customs.
Lee presented his visa application Dec. 17 to the Taipei Office of Japan's Interchange Association, the de facto Japanese embassy in Taiwan.
Informed sources who asked not be identified said that Lee is scheduled to leave for Japan Dec. 27 for a five-day sightseeing tour of the Kansei area.
Hiroyuki Hosada, Japan's chief Cabinet secretary, said in Tokyo a day earlier that Lee's visit is private and he asked Japan's mass media not to bother him during his visit.
Japanese Minister of Foreign Affairs Nobutaka Machimura also urged Japanese lawmakers not to ask to meet with Lee during his stay.

DOC.HEADLINE: POSTING OF U.S. MILITARY OFFICER IN TAIWAN TO RAISE EFFICIENCY: AIT

TEXT.P: The United States is trying to upgrade its administrative efficiency by posting serving military and Department of Defense personnel in Taiwan, an American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) official said Tuesday.
AIT spokeswoman Dana Shell Smith said the policy was approved by the U.S. Congress in October 2002.
"Historically, AIT has hired retired American military officers as contractors to coordinate defense assistance to Taiwan, " Smith told the CNA.

"Non-uniformed active-duty military and Department of Defense civilian personnel will now replace these contractors. They are being detailed to the AIT as part of the normal rotation of personnel," she added.
Smith stressed this is nothing more than an effort to promote administrative efficiency in personnel matters and that Washington's policy towards Taiwan has not changed.

Smith made the statement after Jane's Defense Weekly reported Sunday that the Pentagon would gradually send active duty military personnel to replace civilian contractors at AIT, the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan.
This will start with the deployment of a U.S. army officer to head a technical liaison section in mid-2005, according to the magazine.

Meanwhile, Ministry of National Defense spokesman Liu Chih-chien said the ministry has not received formal notice from the United States about its plan, but said it will be a breakthrough if true and that the ministry welcomes the move.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREEDOM HOUSE RANKS TAIWAN'S CIVIL LIBERTIES IN TOP GRADE

TEXT.P: Taiwan continued to be rated as a "free country" in an annual Freedom House report released Tuesday, while its civil liberties were promoted from the previous year's second grade to the top grade for the first time.

Government Information Office Director-General Lin Chia-lung said the progress in the Freedom House's civil liberties rating is an honor for all local people and also marks recognition of the government's strenuous efforts in human rights protection and consolidation of Taiwan's young democracy.
Freedom House, a Washington-based nonpartisan group, ranks civil liberties and political rights in the world's 192 countries in terms of a seven-grade rating system.
A country is rated "free" if both its civil liberties and political rights rank as first or second grade.

Lin said Taiwan has been promoted to the "free country" category from the "partly free" category since 1997. Until 2003, both Taiwan's civil liberties and political rights were rated second grade. This year, its civil liberties were rated first grade for the first time, while its political rights remained at second grade.
In comparison, mainland China continued to rank in the "not free" category, with its civil liberties at the lowest seventh grade and its political rights at sixth grade.
Lin said the wide gap between Taiwan and the mainland in the rating system highlights the absurdity of Beijing's attempts to force Taiwan to accept its "one country, two systems" unification formula.
Freedom House was founded nearly 60 years ago by Americans concerned about threats to democracy. It conducts advocacy, research and training to encourage and nurture democracy.

Freedom House said that, on balance, the world saw increased freedom in 2004: 26 countries showed gains, while 11 showed declines. Of the world's 192 countries, it judged 46 percent as "free, " 26 percent as "not free" and the rest as "partly free." Eight rated among the most repressive -- Myanmar, Cuba, Libya, North Korea, Saudi Arabia, Sudan, Syria and Turkmenistan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: New F.B.I. files describe abuse of Iraq inmate.
F.B.I. memorandums portray abuse of prisoners by American military in Iraq that included detainees' being beaten and choked and having lit cigarettes placed in their ears, according to newly released government documents released on Monday in connection with a lawsuit accusing the government of being complicit in torture. The, documents also include accounts by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents who said they had seen detainees in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, being chained in uncomfortable positions for up to 24 hours and left to urinate and defecate on themselves. An agent wrote that in one case a detainee who was nearly unconscious had pulled out much of his hair during the night.
Wall Street Journal: Columbia's pursuit of patent riches angers companies.
In the fall of 2000, Columbia University faced a problem familiar to many drug companies: A group of lucrative patents was about to expire. The patents were based on the work of three Columbia professors who laid the groundwork for a powerful new way to manufacture biotechnology drugs. Columbia had licensed these methods to more than 30 biotech companies and was bringing in nearly US$100 million annually in royalties when, after 17 years, the patents ran out. Through legal maneuvering, Columbia won a new patent in 2002 with similar claims as the old ones. Soon, Columbia demanded more royalties -- until 2019 -- from various companies. Many balked. The Columbia case has added fuel to the debate over how aggressive universities should be in securing and protecting patents. Some argue that giving universities free rein to grab patent riches can damage academic values such as open inquiry and stifle basic research, since university scientists typically patent early- stage discoveries. Writing in the American Scientist last year, Arti Rai of Duke University and Rebecca Eisenberg of the University of Michigan compared patent-hungry universities to the Wright brothers, who tried to impede aeronautical progress until forced to license their patents by the U.S. government.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECORD HIGH ARRIVALS, DEPARTURES AT CKS AIRPORT EXPECTED

TEXT.P: The number of arrivals, departures and transit visits for the year at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport is expected to reach a record high of 20 million within the next few days, airport officials said Tuesday.

According to statistics compiled by CKS authorities, the numbers of departures, arrivals and transit visits as of Nov. 30 had reached 7.46 million, 7.4 million and 1.95 million, respectively, bringing the total to 16.81 million.
It is estimated that the total number for the year will reach 20 million. Airport officials attributed the growth in numbers to a gradual return to normal of tourism and commerce markets.

After the inauguration of the airport in 1979, the number of arrivals and departures for the year was only 4.04 million. In 1990, the number topped 10 million, with an annual growth of between 800,000 and one million afterwards. By 2002, the number had snowballed to 19.2 million, while the number for 2003 plummeted to 15 million, primarily due to the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome in Taiwan, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO ELECT NEW PARTY CHAIRMAN JAN. 30

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will hold a party chairman by-election Jan. 30, a spokesman said Tuesday.
The by-election day was set at a meeting of the DPP Central Executive Committee that was chaired by acting Chairman Ker Chien-ming, who is also a veteran legislator.

DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan said the by-election is aimed at electing a chairman to serve out the three-year-and-five-month term left by President Chen Shui-bian, who resigned from the DPP chairmanship last week to assume responsibility for the party's failure to win a majority in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

The new chairman will be elected directly by DPP members, Lee said, adding that anyone who has been a party member for a full year and who has paid a registration fee of NT$1.5 million is eligible to run for chairman.

Candidacy registration will start Dec. 27 and run through Dec. 31. The party headquarters will organize a televised campaign forum Jan. 22 in Taipei City and Jan. 29 in Kaohsiung City for qualified candidates to expound on their platforms or political visions. A civic forum will also be held in Taichung City Jan. 26 for similar purposes.
The election result will be formally announced Feb. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONGRESS WILL CALL SHOTS IN WAR AGAINST CHINA FOR TAIWAN: U.S.

TEXT.P: The U.S. Congress will decide whether the United States should go to war with mainland China should it attack Taiwan, U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage said here Monday.

In an interview with the PBS television station, the number two man at the State Department said the Taiwan Relations Act requires the United States to maintain sufficient force in the Pacific to be able to deter attack but does not require the country to defend Taiwan should it come under attack from the mainland. He added that the power to declare war rests with the Congress.

He admitted that Taiwan is "probably the biggest landmine" in U.S. ties with the mainland, although the United States has managed to develop relations with the mainland while maintaining good relations with the people of Taiwan.

He said the United States deals with the mainland based on the three comuniques with Beijing, including an acknowledgement that there is but one China, of which Taiwan is a part, and added that "we'll have to continue that way."

Armitage's statement caused ripples in Taipei political circles Tuesday, with a spokesman for the opposition Kuomintang calling it a warning to Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party, which has pushed for the country's permanent separation from the mainland.
KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said it is an indication that Washington is trying to keep Taiwan at arms length amid increased pressure from Beijing, which bodes ill for Taiwan.

Noting that many DPP leaders who push for Taiwan independence have claimed that Washington will come to the defense of Taiwan in case it is attacked by Beijing, Chang said they should mend their ways because Armitage has made it clear that Washington will not be drawn into a military conflict with the mainland if Taiwan makes a reckless pursuit of independence.

However, Huang Chieh-cheng, director of the Institute of American Studies at Tamkang University in Tamshui, Taipei County, described Armitage's remarks as no more than a reiteration of Washington's recent calls for both sides of the Taiwan Strait to refrain from taking drastic action against each other.
In an interview with CNA, Huang said he did not see any intention on Armitage's part to give a warning to Taiwan or to pressurize Taiwan into drawing in its horns.

DOC.HEADLINE: RING SELLING FAKE PASSPORTS CRACKED

TEXT.P: A ring that purchased Taiwan passports for resale in mainland China was cracked Tuesday, with its seven members nabbed in seven different places in northern Taiwan, according to police.

Agents from the Criminal Investigation Bureau said the ring would purchase Taiwan passports and use them to apply for visas to the United States, Canada and European states before selling them to mainland Chinese who would then use the passports to enter these countries.
The police searched eight locations in the Taipei and Taoyuan areas Tuesday and arrested seven suspects, as well as seizing 50 passports.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN URGED TO DIVERSIFY OVERSEAS INVESTMENTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan businessmen should diversify their overseas investments, putting India, Bangladesh, Latin America and new eastern European member nations of the European Union on their priority lists, government officials suggested Tuesday.

According to a report by a cross-Taiwan Strait trade observation panel established by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , the officials said, Taiwan investment in mainland China in the first 10 months of this year accounted for 65.3 percent of its total overseas investment.
Taiwan's overseas investment has been concentrated too heavily on the mainland in recent years, making it Taiwan's largest overseas investment destination and market, they said.

The government is seeking to sign free trade agreements with Taiwan's main trading partners, except for the mainland, to lower customs tariffs, lift trade barriers and simplify administrative processes in order to increase bilateral trade and avoid what the government sees as over-reliance on the mainland market, the officials added.

In order to facilitate Taiwan businesses' global deployment, they said, the government is also encouraging business groups to organize trade missions to promote their products in overseas markets and increasing financial assistance to them by granting export loans and offering export insurance.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA BANS U.S. APPLE IMPORTS AFTER DISCOVERING CODDLING MOTH LARVAE

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) imposed a temporary import ban on apples from the United States Tuesday after discovering a coddling moth larvae in a shipment of apples from Oregon State.

The suspension took effect immediately, COA officials said, adding that the ban will be lifted only after the United States conducts a thorough inspection and makes necessary improvements that are endorsed by the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine.

Quarantine officials discovered coddling moth larvae in apple shipments from the United States on Sept. 1, Oct. 7 and Oct. 14, respectively, and warned the U.S. authorities that they would have to make improvements in efforts to prevent the dangerous pest from making its way into apples destined for export.

However, quarantine officials discovered another coddling moth larvae in an apple shipment from Oregon Dec. 20. The insect was immediately sent to National Chunghsing University for DNA testing that confirmed the insect species.

According to a Taiwan-U.S. pact signed in August 2003 concerning working procedures for U.S. apple exports to Taiwan, the COA can suspend imports if the United States fails twice to improve the contamination situation.

Taiwan discovered coddling moth larvae in a shipment of U.S. apples for the first time in 1992 and imposed a temporary ban at that time. Imports resumed only after quarantine officials confirmed that the United States had made necessary improvements.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN KEEPING CLOSE EYE ON TIES WITH GRENADA: FM

TEXT.P: Taiwan is keeping a close eye on its ties with Grenada after Grenada's Prime Minister Keith Mitchell returned home from a trip to mainland China, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Tuesday.

Noting that Mitchell did not mention anything about switching diplomatic allegiance from Taiwan to the mainland in a nationally televised speech that morning, Chen said "We will wait and see how he develops this play."
As a ally of Taiwan, Mitchell caught Taiwan off guard last week with his mainland trip.

Chen said he can understand that Mitchell was trying to "get more money" from overseas after his country was ravaged by a hurricane in September and added: "We don't blame him for this but we won't give in to his blackmail for more money. We can only extend aid to Grenada within our means."

It is not unusual for tiny states to alternate their diplomatic allegiance between Beijing and Taipei in attempts to get the maximum amount of cash and aid from each. As former rivals in a civil war, Taipei and Beijing are now fighting against each other for diplomatic allies by promising generous aid to countries that forge diplomatic ties with them.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RATING KEEPS CHUNGHWA TELECOM'S OUTLOOK UNCHANGED

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Rating Corp. kept its ratings of the state-run Chunghwa Telecom's long-term and short-term credit at "twAAA" and "twA-1" maintaining its "stable" outlook on the company.

The Taiwan Rating Corp.'s rating is different from that of Standard & Poor's, which downgraded Chunghwa's outlook from "stable" to "negative" in line with a similar downgrading it made on the general outlook for Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN TAIWAN INCREASES

TEXT.P: Foreign investment in Taiwan increased by 10.69 percent to US$3.3 billion in the first 11 months of this year, according to statistics compiled by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The government approved a total of 107 foreign investment projects worth US$373.5 million in November alone, the tallies show.
Japan was the largest foreign investor, with investments accounting for 24.37 percent of the total.

By category, electronic and electrical manufacturing took the largest share of foreign investment with 33.27 percent, followed by the financial and insurance industry with 16.9 percent and wholesale and retail sales with 16.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 23, or the 12th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1888: Dutch painter Vincent van Gogh cut off one of his ears in an epileptic attack.
1948: Japanese war criminal Eiki Tojo is executed.
1957: Republic of China Premier Yu Hung-chun is impeached by the Control Yuan, the highest watchdog body.
1958: The construction of the 333-meter Tokyo Tower is complete.
1974: The test-flight of B-1 bombers by U.S. pilots proves successful for the first time.
1986: Soviet human rights activist Andrei D. Sakharov is released from exile and he returns to Moscow.
1989: Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife are arrested.
