DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times: U.S. probes devastating Mosul attack Lunchtime explo- sion in mess tent klls 22, including 14 American troops BAGHDAD The U.S. military launched an investi- gation Wednesday into the cause of a devastating blast in a base in northern Iraq that killed 22 people and injured 72 in one of the deadliest at tacks on U.S.troops since the start of the war.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Blast Kills 22 at U.S. Base. A powerful explosion tore through a mess tent at a U.S. military base near the northern Iraqi city of Mosul during the lunchtime rush Tuesday , killing at least 22 people and wounding 66, including U.S. and Iraqi soldiers and civilian contractors.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: FPJ finally raid to rest
Hundreds of thousands of people, mostly ordinary folk who look up to him as "Da King," accompanied the body of movie icon and political opposition leader Fernando Poe Jr. in a four-hour funeral procession from Sto. Domingo Church in Quezon City to his final resting place at the Manila North Cemetery yesterday morning.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Legions join last Poe blockbuster
FILM legend Fernando Poe, Jr.'s funeral march Wednesday was likened to a box office smash "unparalleled in [Philippine movie] history," with legions of fans and supporters lining up the streets where his horse-drawn casket passed, bidding their "king" farewell.
The Philippine Star: Peaceful farewell to FPJ
A massive crowd of sympathizers poured out into the streets of Manila early yesterday to bid a peaceful farewell to movie icon and former presidential candidate Fernando Poe Jr.
The Manila Times: Susan: Politics defiled FPJ burial
SUSAN Roces, the widow of Fernando Poe Jr., had wanted to keep politics out of his burial. On Wednesday she acknowledged her wish was all but impossible.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Factory land rents cut by up to 38%.
JTC Corporation, the largest industrial landlord here, will cut industrial land rents by up to 38 per cent next year to keep pace with an increasingly competitive global investment environment.
But the cuts will be offset by the announcement that rental rebates, which have cost the Government $2.4 billion since they were introduced in 1998, will be phased out by the middle of next year.
The Lianhe Zaobao:JTC Corporation cut industrial land rents by up to 38% next month.
JTC Corporation, the largest industrial landlord here, will cut industrial land rents by up to 38 per cent next month to keep pace with an increasingly competitive global investment environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMITAGE'S REMARKS SIMPLY A RESTATING FIXED U.S. POLICIES: STATE DEPT.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 22 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P. C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A senior State Department press officer said Wednesday that the recent remarks made by U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage regarding Taiwan were only a restating of fixed U.S. policies.

Spokesman Richard Boucher made the comments in response to media questions regarding Taiwan seeking U.S. clarification on Armitage's remarks. The Executive Yuan has asked Taiwan's representative office in the United States to gain a better understanding of the matter.
Armitage said in an interview with U.S. Public Broadcasting Service Dec. 10 that Taiwan is "probably the biggest land mind" in Bejing- Washington relations. The interview was televised Dec. 20.

"We have the requirement under the Taiwan Relations Act to keep sufficient force in the Pacific to be able to deter attack; we are not required to defend. And these are questions that actually reside with the U.S. Congress, which has to declare an act of war," Armitage also said in the interview.

Boucher said in Wednesday's press conference that he is unaware of whether there have been discussions between the United States and Taiwan on Armitage's remarks. However, he said that if Taiwan asked, the United States would tell it that all Armitage did was restate U.S. policy in very familiar terms.
"We all know that Taiwan is an important issue to many countries, to us, and it's an issue that comes up in not only our bilateral relationship with China but in the region as well," he further said.
"It's an issue that we spend a lot of time working on, and we try to help people move towards a peaceful dialogue and a peaceful resolution of the issues," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONTINUING TO DISCUSS ANTI-SECESSION LAW WITH CHINA: STATE DEPT.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 22 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department said Wednesday that Washington is continuing to talk with Beijing about mainland China's plan of enacting a so-called anti-secession law.
"I don't have any new news, but it does remain a subject of discussion with the Chinese, " State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said at a press briefing.

After Beijing announced last week that it was planning to enact an anti-secession law, which is widely believed to be aimed at Taiwan, Washington immediately talked with Taipei and Beijing about the matter and expressed the hope that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait would engage in dialogue and that neither side would take any unilateral actions that might change the status quo.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN REMAINS UNCHANGED: MOFA

TEXT.P: The United States' policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged, a Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman reaffirmed Thursday.

Michel Lu made the remarks after the Nielson Report in Washington, D.C. reported Tuesday that if Taiwan provokes mainland China, the United States will not come to the island's defense if it is attacked.

The report also said that since ROC President Chen Shui-bian broached his "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait" in the summer of 2002, U.S. President George W. Bush has changed his attitude from "whatever it takes" to defend Taiwan from a mainland Chinese attack in 2001 to clearly stating that if Taiwan makes moves similar to provocation, then it is almost certain that the United States will not come to Taiwan's defense.
Lu said that Taiwan is pragmatic and that it is out of the question for the island to provoke a war with mainland China.
Lu stressed that the U.S. policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged, adding that if Washington wants to change its policy, it will express it in a clear way.

He said that the Taiwan-U.S. relationship used to be one of "creative ambiguity" but that the United States has now clearly stated its stance. However, he added, Washington's basic policy remains the same.
Taiwan's communications with the United States have been good, and "the message we've received is that the U.S. policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged," he said.
What the United States wants is that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait resolve their differences in a peaceful way and not take any unilateral actions to change the status quo, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOTH SIDES OF TAIWAN STRAIT `OBLIGED' TO WORK FOR PEACE: MOFA

TEXT.P: Both sides of the Taiwan Strait are "obliged" to work for peace and Taiwan is more than willing to do its part to contribute to peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Thursday.
Lu was commenting on a report by the Rand Corporation, a noted U.S. think tank, speculating that mainland China is likely to launch an attack on Taiwan in 2012.

According to foreign wire service reports, the Rand Corporation has completed a study on the cross-strait situation at the request of the U.S. Army. The report predicts that the mainland will adopt a "conquer" strategy toward Taiwan after 2012. By that time, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait may have a showdown war and the mainland will probably send ground forces to occupy parts of Taiwan to force the nation's authorities to hold talks on cross-strait unification.
Lu said the Foreign Ministry is aware of the report. "We know it's professional research that will be presented to the U.S. Department of Defense for reference, " he added.

In his view, Lu said, maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait requires the joint efforts of both Taiwan and the mainland. Taiwan should not be held solely responsible for cross-strait peace and stability, Lu said, adding that the mainland's plan to enact an anti-secession law could sabotage regional peace and stability and lead to a change in the status quo.
Stressing that Taiwan has no reason to provoke a conflict with the mainland, Lu said Taiwan has always endeavored to work toward regional peace and stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. FACES SERIOUS CHOICE IN CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT ISSUE: MOFA

TEXT.P: The United States is facing a "very serious" choice in the cross-Taiwan Strait issue, Foreign Affairs Vice Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau said Thursday.

The United States has a strategic need to develop close cooperative relations with mainland China on the one hand, while having a keen interest in the security of Taiwan on the other, Kau said at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting.

However, Kau said, Washington is concerned about Taiwan's security despite the ambiguous wording of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) and seemingly pro-mainland remarks made earlier in the week by U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage.

Armitage said in an interview with the PBS television station in Washington Monday that the TRA requires the United States to maintain sufficient force in the Pacific to be able to deter attack but does not require the country to defend Taiwan should it come under attack from the mainland.
Armitage noted that the power to declare war rests with Congress and that Taiwan is "probably the biggest landmine" in Washington-Beijing relations.

Kau said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs is trying to verify Washington's position with the U.S. Department of State and the American Institute in Taiwan to better understand what Armitage actually meant by his remarks.

Opposition Kuomintang Legislator John Chang said he believes Armitage's remarks are related to President Chen Shui-bian's plan to change the names of Republic of China overseas missions in two years to include the word "Taiwan."
Chang said the government should not have put forth such an impractical plan.
Kau admitted that the name-change for U.S. offices would be the most difficult among all overseas missions because of Beijing's opposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 3.85 points to close at 5,997.67.
The bourse opened at 6,002.8 and fluctuated between 6,011.43 and 5,966.1 during trading. A total of 2.25 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$44.49 billion (US$1.37 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up at 0.8 percent and machinery and electronics shares gaining 0.1 percent.

The six other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 2.7 percent, followed by textile stocks at 0.7 percent, cement stocks at 0.5 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.2 percent and plastics and chemicals shares and banking and financial shares both at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 507 to 183, with 160 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Suicide Bomber Blamed For Deadly Mosul Attack.
Gen. Richard Myers says lone attacker to blame for deadliest attack on U.S. installation since beginning of Iraq war.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Policies Hurting Growth, Gref Says.
Lashing out at the government for following unclear and inconsistent policies, two liberal ministers warned on Wednesday that economic growth is slowing down and that the Cabinet is unlikely to meet President Vladimir Putin's goal of doubling the economy by 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTRY CONTINUES VOTE-BUYING PROBE

TEXT.P: The authorities are speeding up their investigations into alleged vote-buying reported in the run-up to the Dec. 11 legislative elections and are checking if any politicians have paid bribes to their voters after the polls, Ministry of Justice officials said Thursday.
The government has adopted some new practices in its efforts to crack down on vote-buying, the officials said.
For example, it launched a publicity drive against vote buying and set up a raider unit specialized in investigating vote buying, they said.

Although the corrupt practices have decreased following the efforts of the past four years, there is still room for improvement in light of the fact that some candidates who were indicted on vote-buying or corruption charges still won the support of voters.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January lost 23 points to close at 6,002, with 23,284 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February moved down 16 points to finish at 6,009, with 44 contracts traded, while March futures lost 36 points to finish at 5,992, with eight contracts traded.
June futures lost 45 points to finish at 5,950, with two contracts traded, while September futures moved down 28 points to close at 5,895, with five contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,025 for January, 6,025 for February, 6,028 for March, 5,995 for June and 5,923 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

January TE futures moved down 1.1 points to close at 224, with 2,420 contracts traded, while February TE futures lost 1.15 points to finish at 224.3, with nine contract transactions. March TE futures gained 0.05 points to close at 223.9, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

January TF futures lost two points to finish at 1,016, with 4,056 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved down 3.4 points to end at 1,013.6, with 23 contracts traded. March TF futures lost 10.8 points to finish at 1,005.2, with one contract changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, dropping NT$0.074 to close at NT$32.228.
A total of US$544.5 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.302 and hit a low of NT$32.157.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT APOLOGIZES TO CONTROL YUAN NOMINEES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian apologized Thursday to all 29 nominees of the new Control Yuan -- the nation's highest watchdog body -- for having been smeared following his nomination of them.

The president met with the 29 nominees, including Control Yuan President nominee Clement C.P. Chang and Vice President nominee Michael Hsin-huang Hsiao, over a tea party. Also on hand were Vice President Annette Lu and Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang.
Chen first explained the formation of a five-member screening panel and the nomination procedure, and expressed hope that all the nominees will be confirmed by the Legislative Yuan soon.

Noting that the nomination process was a daunting test and challenge, he said he told Lu that if possible, he wished all 53 of the people recommended by the screening panel could have been nominated instead of just 27 -- the Control Yuan president and vice president were decided by Chen himself.
For this, the president offered his deepest apology to those "jewels left behind."

Apologizing to all the nominees for being smeared after the list was unveiled earlier this week, Chen cited Fredrick Chien, incumbent Control Yuan president as an example, saying that Chien excels in his erudition, integrity and political experience. After he was asked by Chen to serve as the convener of a commission to investigate his election-eve shooting, however, he was viciously and relentlessly attacked.
"Some people in this society, because they are dissatisfied with me, oppose everything I do," the president said, adding that he does not feel this is a sign of a healthy society.

The president also said that after the Dec. 11 legislative elections, some people expressed the opinion that several excellent legislative aspirants who failed in the elections could have been included on the Control Yuan recommendation list.

However, out of respect for the screening panel, the president said, he dared not change the recommendation list, which was completed a week before the legislative elections, for which he also apologized.
Eight of the 29 nominees are women, six are incumbent Control Yuan members and eight are incumbent or former legislators.
The president also explained that the nominations were not put up for consultation among political parties because he wanted to preserve the clean image of the Control Yuan.

He said that from his past experience in nominating Control and Examination Yuan members through consultation among political parties or designated people representing political parties, he found that it did not contribute to harmony between the different parties or avoidance of confrontation, but rather was seen as a divvying up among the political parties.

The president defended his decision to nominate Clement C.P. Chang as Control Yuan president amid reports that he had blasted Chang as "brazenly playing with the judicial system as a rich and influential man" when he was a legislator. He was referring to Chang's alleged involvement in the buying of large numbers of stocks in his daughter's name. After a 13-year lawsuit, Chang was acquitted of any wrongdoing early this year.
Chen said Chang will be able to protect the innocent and be a guardian of civil rights.

On Nita Ing, chairwoman of the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC), who served as one of the five-member screening panel, while the THSRC has been the target of investigation by the Control Yuan, the president also said that Ing does not represent the THSRC and that she maintained impartiality throughout the screening process.

Lu presided over the screening panel, which also included Clement C.P. Chang, Michael Hsin-huang Hsiao, Fredrick Chien and Su Tseng-Chang in addition to Ing. Controversy also surrounded the fact that Chang and Hsiao served as both "umpire and player."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-MAINLAND CHINA WOMEN'S SEMINAR TO OPEN ON KINMEN

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-mainland China seminar on women's roles will open Friday on the Taiwan-controlled Kinmen Island, in which more than 70 representatives will try to increase the mutual understanding of women's issues on either side of the Taiwan Strait.

Women's association representatives, scholars and social workers from Kinmen, Taiwan proper and the mainland's Xiamen City in Fujian Province will participate in the two-day seminar sponsored by the Kinmen county government.

The participants will give keynote speeches and discuss issues related to women's roles amid increasing exchanges between Taiwan and the mainland, including mainland wives in Taiwan, women's policies, the protection of female workers and the impact of cross- strait marriages.
The Kinmen county government hopes that the seminar will lead to greater heed being paid to women's issues by the governments on both sides, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: '10 MAJOR PROJECTS' BUDGET BILL PASSES 1ST READING IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan's Budget Committee completed Thursday the first reading of a special budget bill for the government's "10 new major construction projects" program to be launched next year.

The Cabinet has appropriated NT$93.91 billion for the program, with the funds to be raised by selling NT$15 billion-worth of government stakes in state-owned Taiwan Power Co. and floating NT$78.91 billion-worth of state bonds.

The Budget Committee passed the first reading of the special budget bill without undercutting any of the listed costs for the program. The bill is now pending a second reading at legislative plenary sessions.
The program is the government's core work agenda following President Chen Shui-bian's campaign promises for his second term.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun said earlier this month that the program will contribute to the nation's overall annual economic growth by an estimated 0.6 percent in the coming year.

According to the Cabinet's special budget plan, NT$10 billion will be earmarked for a top-rate university development plan; NT$1.4 billion for construction of a world-class arts center; NT$2.8 billion for a "mobile Taiwan" plan; NT$2.2 billion for a Taiwan EXPO plan; NT$1.9 billion for a railway modernization plan; NT$9 billion for a new expressways construction plan; NT$13.7 billion for a Kaohsiung Harbor intercontinental container terminal construction plan; NT$48 billion for mass rapid transit systems construction in northern, central and southern Taiwan; NT$3.4 billion for new sewerage systems construction; and NT$400 million for construction of new reservoirs.

The aim of the "mobile Taiwan" project is to set up the basic infrastructure to combine cellular phone network services, computer platforms and broadband Internet links, Kao Tien-tzu, head of the telecommunication and information section of a special advisory group, was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH SUGGESTS OPTIONS TO PROP UP NATIONAL HEALTH INSURANCE PROJECT

TEXT.P: The nation's top health official said Thursday that if health insurance premiums cannot be raised to make up for losses in the national health insurance project, he would suggest either lowering reimbursements or raising the proportion of self-payment.

Department of Health (DOH) Minister Chen Chien-jen made the remarks in a legislative committee in which several legislators expressed concern about the dire financial situation of the nation's health insurance system.

Liu Chien-hsiang, CEO and president of the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) , reported that BNHI safe deposits currently stand at NT$4.2 billion (US$130.43 million) . As the revenues raised from health insurance premiums cannot cover expenses, he estimated that the system will have a shortfall of NT$12.8 billion by the end of next year.

He noted that according to current health insurance regulations, if the quality of medical care is to be maintained, the government has three options -- raise premiums, raise the self-payment ratio or lower reimbursement.
Chen said that BNHI revenues and expenditures have grown at a pace of 4 percent and 6 percent, respectively.

To learn more about the views of the public, the DOH will hold a meeting early next year in which representatives selected from the general public will listen to expert explanations of the national health insurance system, after which they will make suggestions regarding the future of the national health insurance system.
The report will be sent to the Legislative Yuan by the end of January, Chen said.

Meanwhile, on questions as to whether the repeated use of renal dialysis equipment has resulted in the squandering of health insurance resources, Chen promised to look into the matter and give a report within one month.

Legislators asked why, although the equipment can be repeatedly used, hospitals fraudulently apply for payment for new equipment but do not actually use the money for the stated purpose, a situation the Taiwan Health Reform Foundation (THRF) claims has resulted in losses of NT$12.1 billion in health insurance reimbursements.

The Taiwan Society of Nephrology said Thursday that the high-tech dialysis machines can indeed be repeatedly used, adding that the dialysis quality in Taiwan is on a par with Japan's, but the cost is only half of that in Japan at around NT$4,000 for each treatment.
The society also said that THRF's allegation that repeated use can cause infection has caused unfounded alarm and panic.

Yang Wu-chang, director of the department of nephrology at Taipei's Veterans General Hospital, noted that there are 4,000 patients in Taiwan who have survived on dialysis for 10 years and 1,000 patients who have survived for 15 years. He further said that the survival rate of dialysis patients in Taiwan is next only to that of Japan's, although treatment in Japan is four times as expensive as in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECOMMENDATION PANEL GUIDES CONTROL YUAN NOMINATIONS: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has fully respected the opinions of a screening and recommendation panel in nominating Control Yuan members, Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday.
Lu, who chaired the panel, said during a meeting with the nominees that the nominations were finalized one week before the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
However, many people have expressed concern as to whether Chen would reconsider the nominations after the polls to include some legislators who lost their re-election bids, Lu said.

She said she told Chen that if the nominations were to have been changed because of the election outcome, it would have undermined the impartiality of the panel and would have damaged the image of the Control Yuan.
Chen fully respected her opinion and did not change the nominations, Lu said.
She said the screening and recommendation process was open, creative and liberal.
While the Presidential Office placed advertisements in newspapers for the first time to invite public recommendations, members of the panel were forbidden from recommending any candidates, Lu noted.
In addition, the panel did not take the ethnic background, place of birth, partisan factors or gender of the candidates into consideration while screening their qualifications, she said.

Chen, meanwhile, pointed out that a relative of Lu and several of her former schoolmates were deliberately excluded for fear that their nominations would be mistaken as owing to their connection with the vice president.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CONFERENCE ON LIBRARY AFFAIRS KICKS OFF IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: A two-day conference on public library management exchanges between the two sides across the Taiwan Strait began Thursday in Taichung City, central Taiwan.

A total of 30 library administrators, scholars and experts in library science from Taiwan and mainland China attended the conference held by the National Taichung Library, 15 of whom are mainland scholars and experts who work for public libraries including the National Library and the Shanghai Municipal Library, as well as provincial libraries in Henan and Hebei.

On the Taiwan side, the participants include National Central Library Director Juang Fang-rung, Taipei Municipal Library Director Tseng Shu-hsien, Taoyuan County Cultural Affairs Bureau Director Hsieh Hsiao-yun, National Taichung Library Director Hsue Mao-sung, and scholars from National Chengchi University and National Taiwan Normal University.

Discussions during the conference focus on the management and operation of public libraries, including the best reading atmosphere, public libraries' efforts to promote reading, public libraries' e-services and their connection with local communities, according to the organizer.
The organizer said 16 papers will be presented during the conference, the purpose of which is to push for the upgrading and transformation of public libraries.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA HIGHLY OPTIMISTIC ABOUT TAIWAN BIOTECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is very optimistic about the outlook for Taiwan's biotechnology industry and will do everything it can do to promote it, Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh said Thursday.
Ho made the remarks at the 15th anniversary celebration of the Taiwan Biotech Association.

Claiming that biotechnology is the most promising domestic industry, Ho said that the MOEA will do its best to forge a sound environment for its comprehensive development, from the initial research to product marketing.

Taking as an example its encouragement for companies to develop vaccinations, the MOEA is poised to create a comfortable environment for biotech by making each segment closely pegged to each other, from initial research and commercial production by the companies to government procurement and market rules, she explained.

There are all kinds of possibilities in the biotech sector and Taiwan will be a winner as long as it finds worthy targets for development, she said, noting that the domestic industry is particularly strong in the fields of medical treatment instruments and clinical experience.
Taiwan's biotechnology stands a good chance of putting itself on the world map, much as the information industry has succeeded in doing, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORENSIC EXPERT FORWARDS '319 SHOOTING' REPORT TO TOP PROSECUTOR

TEXT.P: Dr. Henry Lee, a renowned Chinese-American forensic scientist, handed over the original copy of his forensic report on the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu to Taiwan's top prosecutor Thursday.
Lee said after forwarding the report to State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao that he now feels he can relax.

"The original copy of the report is extremely important. I have kept it with me since I arrived in Taipei Dec. 18. I did not place it in a safe nor was it taken by any other person. To my great relief, I finally handed it over to the state public prosecutor-general, " Lee said.
Wu expressed his heartfelt gratitude to Lee upon receiving the original copy, which bears the signatures of all the members of Lee's forensic investigation team.
Lee's team concluded a forensic investigation into the presidential election-eve shooting of Chen and Lu this summer. Duplicate copies were sent to Taipei in August.

Over the past more-than nine months, Lee said he has kept close contacts with Taiwan's investigation team. He said he is glad to learn that the team, headed by Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) Director Hou You-yi, has managed to determine that a now-detained underground gunsmith was the one who made the bullets and gun used in the shooting.
"It's a breakthrough. We should give the investigation team more encouragement," Lee said, adding that there is still a long way to go before the mystery case can be resolved.
During his current eight-day visit, Lee said he has offered the team some new suggestions concerning the direction of follow-up probes.

"The most important tasks now are to locate the gun used in the shooting and the person who bought the gun, " Lee said, adding that the chances of solving the case will increase greatly if these two tasks can be accomplished.
Chen and Lu were riding in an open-top jeep when they were shot while campaigning in the southern city of Tainan March 19. One bullet grazed Chen's stomach, while Lu was hit in the knee.

Chen beat his sole challenger, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, in the March 20 presidential election by a slim margin. Lien filed two lawsuits in an attempt to nullify Chen's re-election victory and even the entire election so that a new one could be held. The Taiwan High Court rejected the re-election annulment suit, but Lien has appealed the case to the Supreme Court, which has yet to hand down a ruling.

The CIB has offered a reward of NT$53 million for information leading to finding the weapon. CIB Director Hou You-yi called on people who had bought bullets and guns from the arrested suspect, identified as Tang Shou-yi, to come forward. The suspect had produced more than 3,000 bullets and remodeled scores of guns. The investigation team has managed to retrieve 19 of those guns and 300-plus bullets.

CIB officials also showed examples of what the weapon should look like to the media Thursday. The gun used in the attack was a converted 8-mm handgun with special marks, which would make it easier to trace the weapon, Hou said. The gun could fire two bullets in rapid succession, making it likely that one gun fired both shots in the March 19 shooting, Hou added.
Many opposition politicians and supporters have disseminated outrageous speculation about the shooting, including allegations that it was staged by Chen to sway sympathy votes in his favor.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Administration overhauls rules for U.S. forests.
The Bush administration issued broad new rules Wednesday overhauling the guidelines for managing the nation's 155 national forests and making it easier for regional forest managers to decide whether to allow logging, drilling or off-road vehicles. The long-awaited rules relax longstanding provisions on environmental reviews and the protection of wildlife on 191 million acres of national forest and grasslands. They also cut back on requirements for public participation in forest planning decisions. Forest S ervice officials said the rules were intended to give local foresters more flexibility to respond to scientific advances and threats like intensifying wildfires and invasive species. The rules give the nation's regiona l forest managers and the Forest Service increased autonomy to decide whether to allow logging roads or cellphone towers, mining activity or new ski areas.
Wall Street Journal: Continent's drift; at expense of U.S., nations of Europe are drawing closer.
Opinion polls show a big majority of Poles want their troops out of Iraq and also want Europe to have a common defense policy, something Washington views as a possible threat to the U. S.-led North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Washington's ebbing influence in this most pro-American swath of Europe reflects a broader phenomenon: Some of the largest challenges facing the U.S. now flow from the sources of its great power. America's sheer size and might breed resentment and, in the geopolitical marketplace, stir competition.Its economic example spurs Europe to band together to compete. Its faith in elections prompts an effort, in Iraq and Afghanistan, to impose democracy through arms. For many abroad, America' s goals inspire, but its actions often exasperate.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SETTLED FOR SOFTER 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW': SECURITY CHIEF

TEXT.P: Beijing originally wanted to put forward a harsher "unification law" targeting Taiwan that would have demanded that Taiwan return to the fold of China, but instead opted for an "anti-secession law, " the chief of Taiwan's National Security Bureau said Thursday.
Hsueh Shih-ming made the remarks while fielding questions in a national defense committee meeting at the Legislative Yuan.

Hsueh said that Beijing had floated the harsher law as a test balloon to see what sort of reaction the international community would have. Sensing that such a law, should it actually be put into effect, would necessitate a timetable for action and that the bill would be a move to destabilize the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, Beijing leaders decided to soften the bill to one less proactive.

Wang Hsi-tien, deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council, speaking on the same occasion, said that mainland China made similar rumblings several years ago to oppose moves by Taiwan toward independence and to promote cross-strait unification. At that time, Europe, the United States, Japan, and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) were all firmly against any expressions of independence by Taiwan.

Believing that the drive had gained sufficient momentum, mainland China unveiled a draft unification law in 1999. But since the law would have not only affected the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, but the United States, Japan, ASEAN and India as well, Beijing backpedaled on the bill.

Wang said that the standing committee of Beijing's National People's Congress will start to review the draft anti-secession law Dec. 25. Although in the past it has taken as long as two or three years to review a draft law, Beijing may want to pass this one quicker, he added.

Commenting on U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage's recent remarks that the U.S. was not obligated to defend Taiwan if a war were to break out across the Strait and that Taiwan was the main obstacle in U.S.-China relations, calling Taiwan the "biggest landmine," Wang said that Armitage is versed in East Asian affairs.
Armitage's words were meant to remind both sides of the Taiwan Strait not to change the status quo, which Wang said were not only for the ears of Taiwan, but also for mainland China.

Armitage said that although the Taiwan Relations Act requires that the U.S. maintain a sufficient force in the Pacific to deter attack, it does not require that the country defend Taiwan should it come under attack from the mainland. He also said that the power to declare war rests with Congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TOUTS ECONOMIC ACHIEVEMENTS DURING HIS TIME IN OFFICE

TEXT.P: Yu Shyi-kun Thursday touted the things he has done during his time as premier to improve the nation's economy, saying that economic growth is expected to reach a seven-year high of 5.93 percent this year.

Yu made the remarks to parry comments by members of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -led "pan-blue alliance" that the alliance should have the right to form the next Cabinet after winning a majority in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Criticizing the ruling Democratic Progressive Party as lacking in economic talent, the KMT has also recommended that Legislative Yuan Vice Speaker P.K. Chiang, an economics expert and former vice premier, be appointed as the next premier.
Yu dismissed the KMT's criticism as a myth, pointing out that this year's economic growth will be the highest since the 6.37 percent recorded in 1997.
Meanwhile, Yu said, the unemployment rate is expected to decline to below 4.5 percent this year from a high of 5.35 percent during the past two years of his term.

Taiwan's economic performance now is not inferior to the three years until May 2000 during which Vincent Siew was premier and Chiang was vice premier and chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, Yu said.
The economic growth rates in the three years of Siew's leadership were 4.33 percent, 5.32 percent and 5.78 percent, respectively, according to official statistics.
Yu's Cabinet is set to resign en masse next month in preparation for a Cabinet reshuffle simultaneous with the formation of a new legislature on Feb. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-U.S. TIES SOLID, BUT TAIWAN CANNOT ABUSE U.S. TRUST: MAC

TEXT.P: Relations between Taiwan and the United States are solid, but Taiwan cannot abuse the trust of the U.S., Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said Thursday.
Wu made the remarks after U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage said earlier this week that Taiwan is probably the "biggest landmine" in U.S.- China relations.

In an interview with PBS television, Armitage also said that the Taiwan Relations Act requires the United States to maintain sufficient force in the Pacific to be able to deter attack but does not require the country to defend Taiwan should it come under attack from China. He further said the power to declare war rests with Congress.
Wu said he has been to the United States twice since Taiwan's March 20 presidential election. During the two visits, Wu said he was very much aware of the firmness of Taiwan-U.S. relations.
In the future, Wu said he believes that relations between the two countries will remain steadfast.

Wu recalled that U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs James Kelly presented a lengthy policy statement during a congressional hearing in April this year. His testimony will serve as the basic guideline for future U.S. foreign policies.

"Kelly's testimony showed that the United States hopes Taiwan can refrain from taking any unilateral move to change the status quo. As far as mainland China is concerned, the United States is opposed to Beijing using force against Taiwan," Wu said.
In his statement, Wu said, Kelly clearly mentioned that Taiwan can cooperate with the United States in helping other countries to democratize.

"Kelly's statement let us know that we can continue to cooperate with the United States on some policy issues. We can also continue to rely on this good friend. But we certainly cannot abuse U.S. trust. We cannot take U.S. support as a blank check, " Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLACK-FACED SPOONBILL CONSERVATION FESTIVAL TO OPEN IN TAINAN

TEXT.P: The 2004 Black-faced Spoonbill Conservation Festival will be held from Dec. 25 to Jan. 31 in Tainan County, southern Taiwan, organizers of the festival said Thursday.

The event will showcase the fact that this year has seen the most overwintering of the rare birds in many years. As of Nov. 30 there were 727 black-faced spoonbills at the Tsengwen River estuary, the organizers said.

The festival will be in Shihfen village of Chihku township and will include "black-faced spoonbill dancing, " a display of fishing tackle, a Christmas music concert and folk song performances, the organizers said. The black-faced spoonbill museum at the Chienkung Elementary School will be open to the public with bird experts describing the habits and characteristics of the rare birds.
Aside from the festive activities, the organizers intend to create an area for artists to draw and paint compositions related to the birds.
There will also be local delicacies on offer for the public to try.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTMENT IN PUBLIC CONSTRUCTION TO TOP NT$200 BILLION NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Investment in public construction projects will hit NT$200 billion (US$6.21 billion) next year, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday.

Speaking at the Fifth Public Construction Golden Awards ceremony, Yu said that the Legislative Yuan had approved a special budget of NT$93.1 billion for the government's 10 major construction projects for next year, while private participation in public construction projects is estimated to top NT$110 billion.

The government's efforts to encourage private participation in public construction have produced results in light of the fact that the private sector's investment increased to NT$110 billion this year from NT$62.4 billion in 2003 and NT$7.2 billion in 2002.

The government has given increasing importance to investments in public construction in recent years now that they can not only create more job opportunities but also expand domestic demand, which are very contributive to the nation's economic development, Yu noted.

The ratio of the government's budget for public construction projects implemented has increased in recent years with an average of 93.5 percent for the past three years, far better than during Kuomintang-led administrations, the premier continued.
The government is also more closely monitoring public construction projects worth more than NT$100 million to improve budget implementation efficiency.

These listed projects had a combined value of NT$360 billion this year, Yu said, adding that the amount will increase to NT$400 billion if the public construction projects that are worth less than NT$100 million each are also taken into account.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW' UNACCEPTABLE TO TAIWAN: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland China's plan to enact an "anti-secession law" targeting Taiwan is unacceptable because it is a provocative, unilateral move to change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, the nation's top mainland policy planner said Thursday.
"It's an extreme and drastic move. We cannot tolerate it, " Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said.

For Taiwan, Wu continued, it's a very serious issue because the planned legislation not only implies that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait would eventually unite but also presumes that the present status quo is that the two sides are connected under the same roof.

"The reality is that the two sides are separate and do not belong to each other. We are the Republic of China on one side and they are the People's Republic of China on the other side. This status quo has existed for 55 years," Wu explained.
Stressing that Beijing's planned legislation, if passed, would unilaterally change the cross-strait status quo, Wu said it is also a grave provocation.

Since President Chen Shui-bian's inauguration for a second term on May 20, Wu said, the ROC government has continued to extend olive branches to Beijing. However, he said, Beijing has consistently responded with scathing criticism. "Their scornful rhetoric constitutes a provocation," he asserted.

In the face of Beijing's provocative legislative plan, Wu said, Taiwan has been compelled to step up communications with key countries around the world to help the international community understand the seriousness of the issue.

As to the U.S. views on the issue, Wu said the United States has told the mainland in private that its planned "anti-secession law" would have grave consequences and could trigger regional instability and insecurity.
Wu said the United States is fully aware of Taiwan's stance on the issue and is still watching how events unfold.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOVEMBER MANUFACTURING PRODUCTION INDEX GROWS: MOEA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's manufacturing production index in November stood at 130.89, up by 4.82 percent over the 2003 level, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Thursday.

MOEA officials predicted that the index for December will continue to pick up, hopefully helping achieve a double-digit growth rate for the whole of this year. Robust investment from the private sector and strong demand in the pre-holiday season will be the main factors, they said.
Meanwhile, the country's industrial production index stood at 128.78 in November, an increase of 5.43 percent over the previous year's level, according to the MOEA statistics.

By industry, the index for the home construction industry climbed by 35.78 percent compared to the level set in the same month last year, while the mining industry index posted a growth of 1.52 percent and the electricity, gas and water sector saw a rise of 1.51 percent in production.
The industrial production index averaged at 126.56 for the January-November period, reflecting a growth rate of 10.9 percent.

Looking to the future, business conditions in the domestic market are expected to maintain brisk, in part due to the government's efforts in launching and carrying out major public construction projects and in part owning to the continued influx of private-sector investment, the officials forecast.

They are confident that the manufacturing production index for this month will still record double-digit growth, in light of rising demand to be spurred by strong buying sprees prior to the Chinese Lunar New Year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOVEMBER EXPORT ORDER VALUE FOR TAIWAN COMPANIES 2ND HIGHEST: MOEA

TEXT.P: Foreign export orders placed for Taiwan companies in November hit US$19.75 billion, the second-highest monthly level on record, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Thursday.

The figure represents a noticeable growth of 30.11 percent over the previous year's level, MOEA statistics show. The combined value for the first 11 months of this year totaled US$195.29 billion, a rise of 26.56 percent year-to-year.
MOEA officials attributed the increase to strong demand in the pre-holiday season in foreign markets, particularly for computer- related goods and steel products.

But they also forecast the growth rate for the whole of next year will slow markedly, as the impact of this year's major factors, such as mainland China's economic cooling measures, a weakened U.S. dollar and soaring prices for crude oil and raw materials, is yet to be gauged.

According to MOEA tallies, foreign orders for domestically made information technology, telecommunications and electronics goods contributed the most in setting the second-highest level in single-month export order value, while the value of orders for precision machinery jumped by the largest level of 61.53 percent as compared to the 2003 record.

In terms of industry, November orders for electronics products reached US$4.338 billion in value, up by 35.52 percent compared to the year-earlier level. Orders for IT and telecommunications devices were worth US$3.933 billion, marking an annual growth rate of 16.19 percent.
Order values for textile goods and basic metals hit US$1.018 billion and US$1.754 billion, up by 0.1 percent and 37.46 percent year-to-year, respectively.
Annual increase rates for the rubber, machinery and electrical engineering industries all topped 30 percent, ranging from 35.59 percent to 39.18 percent, the same tallies show.

In terms of country, orders from the United States last month were worth US$5.56 billion, representing an annual growth rate of 33.69 percent. Hong Kong orders hit US$4.51 billion, up by 32.27 percent from the level a year ago. Order values from Japan and Europe expanded by 31.49 percent and 37.04 percent to US$2.13 billion and US$3.52 billion, respectively.

According to the findings of a recent survey by the MOEA, 20.65 percent of the companies questioned last month believe that the value of their orders will increase for December, while 45 percent think that business will maintain stable. About 34 percent contend that their business will slide.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORENSIC EXPERT OFFERS MORE ADVICE ON SOLVING '319 SHOOTING'

TEXT.P: Dr. Henry Lee, a renowned Chinese-American forensic scientist, said Thursday the ROC government should offer more cash rewards and offer to reduce sentences for cooperative criminals to help solve the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.
Lee, who arrived in Taipei last Friday for an eight-day visit, made the remarks while meeting with Premier Yu Shyi-kun.
Lee said the recent identification of the source of the gun and bullets used in the presidential election-eve shooting does not mean that the sensitive, high-profile case has been solved.
"We must discover where the gun is and then determine who fired the shots. This is no easy task," Lee said.
He suggested that the ROC government offer reduced sentences to encourage those who have bought guns and bullets from the now-detained underground gunsmith to come forward.

Moreover, Lee said, the government can increase cash rewards to encourage local people to offer leads that may be helpful in solving the case. The government has offered NT$53 million to whomever offers clues leading to finding the shooter or shooters.
For his part, Yu expressed his heartfelt gratitude to Lee for assisting in investigating the unprecedented assassination attempt on Taiwan's top leaders.

Lee had headed an expert team to conduct a forensic investigation into the shooting in April and concluded a comprehensive forensic investigation report this summer. While duplicate copies were sent to Taipei in August, the original copy was not handed over to Taiwan's top prosecutor until Thursday.
Before his meeting with Yu, Lee personally forwarded the original copy of his forensic report on the shooting to State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao.

"The original copy of the report is extremely important. I have kept it with me since I arrived in Taipei Dec. 18. I did not place it in a safe nor was it taken by any other person. To my great relief, I finally handed it over to the state public prosecutor-general, " Lee said.

Over the past more than nine months, Lee said he has kept in close contact with Taiwan's investigation team. He said he was glad to learn that the team, headed by Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) Director Hou You-yi, managed to determine that a now-detained underground gunsmith was the one who made the bullets and gun used in the shooting.
"It's a breakthrough. We should give the investigation team more encouragement," Lee said.
During his current visit, Lee said he has offered the team some new suggestions concerning the direction of follow-up probes.

"The most important tasks now are to locate the gun used in the shooting and the person who bought the gun, " Lee said, adding that the chances of solving the case will increase greatly if these two tasks can be accomplished.
Chen and Lu were riding in an open-top jeep when they were shot while campaigning in the southern city of Tainan March 19. One bullet grazed Chen's stomach, while Lu was hit in the knee.

Chen beat his sole challenger, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, in the March 20 presidential election by a slim margin. Lien filed two lawsuits in an attempt to nullify Chen's re-election victory and even the entire election so that a new one could be held. The Taiwan High Court rejected the re-election annulment suit, but Lien has appealed the case to the Supreme Court, which has yet to hand down a ruling.
Many opposition politicians and supporters have disseminated outrageous speculation about the shooting, including allegations that it was staged by Chen to sway sympathy votes in his favor.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WISHES PEACE FOR WORLD ON NEW YEAR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian wished the world peace in the coming year Thursday.
Speaking at a tea party preceding a year-end concerto organized by the Presidential Office, Chen said he wished peace for not only the country but also the world.

He also lauded the contribution of the country's professional and volunteer fire fighters whose representatives are invited to attend the concerto, saying they had make society a better place through their hard work.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 24, or the 13th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1491: Ignatius Loyola, Spanish founder of the Jesuit order, is born.
1524: Vasco da Gama, the Portuguese explorer who discovered the sea route to India around the Cape of Good Hope, dies.
1814: The War of 1812 between Britain and the United States ends with the signing of the Treaty of Ghent.
1851: Fire destroys part of the Capitol building in Washington, D.C., and the whole of the Library of Congress.
1905: Howard Hughes, American billionaire industrialist and film producer, is born.
1908: French President Armand Fallieres opens the first international aviation show in Paris.
1914: The first German bomb lands on British soil.
1919: Wealthy U.S. merchant John D. Rockefeller donates US$100 million for charitable use.
1921: Mahatma Gandhi is sworn in as chairman of India's Congress (I) Party, on a platform of non-cooperation.
1937: Japanese forces capture Hangchow in eastern China.
1943: President Roosevelt appoints Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as supreme commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force preparing for the invasion of France.
1945: Pope Pius XII promotes Republic of China Bishop Tien Keng-hsin of Chingtao to cardinal, making him the first cardinal in East Asia.
1951: Libya declares independence.
1967: Communist China conducts its seventh nuclear test, detonating a small device in northeastern China.
1976: Takeo Fukuda organizes a new Japanese Cabinet.
1978: Local movie and television actor Ku Ming-lun jumps to his death from the top of a building.
1983: The Taipei City Fine Arts Museum formally opens to the public.
1992: President George Bush pardons former U.S. Defense Secretary Casper Weinberger and five other Reagan aides involved in the Iran-Contra affair.
1993: Former ROC President Yen Chia-kan dies at the age of 90.
1999: Gen. Joao Batista Figueiredo, the Brazilian military ruler who ended 20 years of military government by restoring civilian rule in 1985, dies at the age of 81.
1999: Taipei's fifth rapid transit line -- the Pangnan Line -- is inaugurated, completing the foundation of the city's rapid transit network.
2000: About 5,000 Falun Gong practitioners from Taiwan and 18 other countries and areas take part in a peaceful street march in Taipei to call world attention to mainland China's persecution of Falun Gong practitioners.
2000: Thai Rangsit University confers an honorary doctoral degree on former ROC Premier Vincent Siew in recognition of his contributions to promoting political democratization and economic liberalization in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, in the matter of food, should never seek to indulge his appetite; in lodging, he should not be too solicitous of comfort. He should be diligent in virtue and learning in order to profit from their lessons and example. In this way, he may become a man of real culture."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN RELEASED ON BAIL AFTER BEING QUESTIONED FOR SUSPECTED SPYING

TEXT.P: A man from Hsichih, Taipei County, was questioned late Thursday night on suspicions of spying for the mainland Chinese military. He was released hours later on NT$30,000 bail.

The man, surnamed Tai, is alleged to have since August collected military intelligence, including taking pictures of the Hengshan Command Headquarters, and to have sent it to mainland China, officials from the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice said.
The Hengshan Command Headquarters is one of the most secretive and important military bases in Taiwan.

According to the investigators, Tai, in his 40s, mailed at least two parcels of military information, including hand-drawn pictures of Hengshan Command Headquarters' layout and terrain, to mainland Chinese military and public security authorities. The parcels were even directed to former mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, they added.

During the questioning, Tai admitted that he had collected information on the Hengshan Command Headquarters and sent it to mainland Chinese authorities out of indignation with Taiwan's tumultuous politics.

He denied, however, that any of the information he had sent was "military intelligence." He also accused the investigators of physical abusing him and asked to be sent to hospital to get documented proof that he had been abused.

Prosecutors from the Shilin District Prosecutors' Office released Tai early Friday morning after the questioning, deciding to conduct further investigations into the case before determining what crime to charge him with.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP HEADS SHOULD MEET AS SOON AS POSSIBLE: KMT SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: A meeting between the heads of the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) should be held as soon as possible, KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said Friday.

However, Chang added that the date for such a meeting has not yet been determined, pointing out that the date depends on the schedule of PFP Chairman James Soong, who is currently visiting the United States. Soong is set to return to Taiwan Sunday to attend the funeral Monday of Faina Chiang, widow of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo.
Chang said that it is a good thing for both party leaders to meet, adding that "the sooner the better."

Major topics expected to be discussed at such a meeting are a merger of the KMT and its two splinter parties -- the PFP and the New Party, the upcoming speaker and vice speaker elections in the Legislative Yuan, a bill concerning the KMT's assets, the confirmation of 29 nominees for the Control Yuan, and cross-strait relations.

The two leaders are also expected to discuss how to respond to a scheduled ruling Dec. 30 by Taiwan High Court on a lawsuit they filed to try to have the March 20 presidential election nullified for alleged widespread fraud.

Following the Dec. 11 legislative elections in which the "pan-blue alliance" surprisingly maintained its majority in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan, supporters of the alliance have called for a quick merger to solidify the opposition force.

However, Soong said right after the elections that the KMT had shut the door on a merger. Although he didn't elaborate, reports said that he and Lien had not been on speaking terms since mid-November because of bickering over the allocation of a more than NT$100 million (US$3.1 million) subsidy for the Lien-Soong ticket in the March 20 presidential election.

Soong was also reportedly dissatisfied that the KMT voter-allocation strategy excluded the PFP legislative candidates in the Dec. 11 elections. The KMT garnered 79 seats, up 11 seats from the previous elections, but mostly at the expense of the PFP, which managed to win only 34 seats, down 12 seats from the previous elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2005 TO BE YEAR OF CRIME FIGHTING: MOI

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan announced Friday that 2005 will be designated as the year for an intensified campaign against crime.
Su made the announcement while attending a joint SWAT forces live-fire training drill in the central Taiwan city of Taichung.
In addition to tackling major criminal cases, Su said, police will prioritize a crackdown on burglary as part of the government's all-out efforts to protect the safety of people's life and property.

Noting that many people have complained about rampant burglary, Su said the National Police Administration under the Ministry of the Interior will cooperate with other law enforcement authorities in fighting this crime in the coming year.
He further said the Interior Ministry is determined to increase the police headcount by 3,000 officers over the next two years to help local governments improve grassroots law and order.

Nevertheless, Su said, a manpower increase alone is not enough to fight crime and improve public order. "We need to put together the best, most agile and efficient SWAT forces deployed in different parts of the island to take on criminals and thwart their activities, " he said, adding that he hopes SWAT forces in various central counties and cities can strengthen cooperation in crime fighting.

SWAT forces in central Taiwan practiced live-fire shooting, land-air combined operations and anti-kidnapping skills during the training exercise. Taichung City Council Speaker Chang Hung-nien, Taichung Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi and many senior police officers were on hand to witness the drill.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SESSION TO END JAN. 21

TEXT.P: Legislators across the political spectrum have decided to extend the last legislative session of the present Legislative Yuan to Jan. 21, a legislative whip of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Friday.

Legislator Tseng Yung-chuan, who concurrently serves as executive director of the KMT Policy Committee, made the remarks after Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng convened a coordination meeting between the ruling and the opposition party caucuses on the length of the current legislative session.
The legislature resumed meeting after the Dec. 11 legislative elections following a one-month recess. New legislators will be sworn in Feb. 1.

Tseng said legislative caucuses of various parties hey agreed that the last session of this legislature will be extended to Jan. 21 and will review the general budget of the central government and various bills "related to the general public."
But Tseng said that the legislators have reached no consensus on matters related to the confirmation of the 29 nominees to the Control Yuan.

The 29 would-be members nominated by President Chen Shui-bian do not live up to the expectations and the public are not satisfied with them, he claimed, adding that under those circumstances, the KMT cannot screen the list.

Liu Wen-hsiung, caucus whip of the opposition People First Party, noted that Chen has the right to nominate the Control Yuan members and that the Legislative Yuan has the right to decide whether to confirm them.

"The Legislative Yuan can choose to either screen or not screen them. Even if they do screen them, they will not be confirmed completely, " Liu said, adding that even if the legislature cannot complete the confirmation by Feb. 1, there is no constitutionality question.

The six-year-term tenure of the current Control Yuan is due to expire Jan. 31 and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has urged the confirmation of the nominated new members so as not to trigger a constitutional crisis.

Liu said that for those nominees who have not met the expectations of the public, the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP will not approve them. The confirmation of the Control Yuan nominees will also not be put on the legislative agenda next week.
If President Chen Shui-bian redraws a list by Jan. 10, "then there is some room for discussion," he said.
Chen Chien-ming, caucus whip of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, an ally of the DPP, said his party will respect the name-list submitted by Chen but will screen the list rigorously.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORT ON 2012 TAIWAN-CHINA WAR HYPOTHETICAL: RAND
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Dec. 23 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A report by the Rand Corporation that outlines a war scenario across the Taiwan Strait in 2012 is hypothetical in nature and not a prediction, a senior policy analyst at the U.S. think tank said Thursday.

In the study titled "Assuring Access in Key Strategic Regions: Toward a Long-term Strategy" for the U.S. Army, Rand posited a scenario in which mainland China attempts a conquering strategy designed to seize part of Taiwan with ground forces in 2012 with the aim of pushing Taipei directly into a fast-track framework for unification talks.
Eric Larson, one of the authors of the report, said the purpose of the study is to help the U.S. Army better understand its regional military access in Europe, Asia and the Middle East.
It is not a forecast of a military crisis across the Taiwan Strait, Larson clarified.
He said the study mainly examines the anti-access strategies of potential adversaries and potential U.S. counters to these strategies.
On the cross-Taiwan Strait situation, Larson said he does not wish to see war break out between Taiwan and the mainland and expects both sides to resolve their disputes through peaceful means.
