Secretary of State shared views with president, British Prime Minister Blair in private talks following U.S. election.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERHAUL OF BASIC NATIONAL POLICIES NEEDED: RDEC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official in charge of research and evaluation said Friday that the nation should rethink the logic of interaction between the administration system and the legislative power hierarchy and overhaul important basic national policies while re-engineering the Constitution.

Yeh Jiunn-rong, chairman of the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, said that human rights protection and basic national policies on the country's economic future, as well as social and cultural development, should also be included when the nation is talking about constitutional re-engineering.
Yeh, a scholar-turned-official, made the call during a speech to the regular Sun Yat-sen monthly meeting held at the Presidential Office.

Yeh said the notion of Taiwan's constitutional re-engineering is by no means an isolated case in the world. Instead, he said, Taiwan's constitutional reform is an important section in the development of what he described as "global constitutionalism."

Yeh said that changes in the constitutions of various countries have been diverse but can be roughly divided into four modes -- a total rewriting of the constitution; a large-scale revision; gradual re-engineering implemented in different stages; and step-by-step rewriting.
In Taiwan's case, the third mode would be the best option, according to Yeh.

He claimed that it is "old-fashioned" to think that a country should hold a nationwide referendum only when it is writing a new constitution, Yeh said, adding that the new world constitutional reform trend has had many breakthroughs. For example, he said, some countries have held referenda even for simple constitutional reforms. Some countries, such as Hungary, have changed their national designation via constitutional reform, he added.

It is "pitiful" that Taiwan has ignored some aspects of the world constitutional reform trend when the country conducted constitutional reforms during the 1990s, aspects that include procedures, participation by the people, human rights protection and constitutional governance, Yeh argued.
He said that President Chen Shui-bian has planned to see the rebirth of a new constitution by 2006, paving the way for its implementation in 2008, the year his term concludes.

Yeh, who was vice president of the National Taiwan University Institute of Law before being appointed a Cabinet official, said that Taiwan's forthcoming "new constitutional movement" should at least have three "new" characteristics -- a new timeframe, a new procedure and a new arena.

Taking the "new procedure" as an example, Yeh said it should be a procedure during which democracy-strengthening moves are adopted, including large-scale public debates, civic meetings and education for the general public. The government can also set up an exclusive constitutional reform Web site to gauge public opinion.
He said Taiwan needs a constitution that is conducive to deepening democracy, fostering efficiency and consolidating its national identity.
Meanwhile, he said, Taiwan also needs a procedure for such constitutional reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 21.75 points to close at 6,019.42.
The bourse opened at 5,989.77 and fluctuated between 6,037.71 and 5,989.73 during trading. A total of 2.52 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$47.35 billion (US$1.46 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 2.1 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.9 percent, cement stocks, plastics and chemicals shares, machinery and electronics shares and banking and financial shares all at 0.3 percent and textile stocks at 0.2 percent.
Foodstuff issues remained unchanged
Gainers outnumbered losers 505 to 167, with 181 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATOR URGES NO BLOCKING OF ARMS PURCHASE BUDGET

TEXT.P: A legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Friday that what he described as the "irrational attitude" of the opposition parties to block a NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) special budget for arms purchases from the United States has become a "landmine" in Taiwan's security.

DPP Legislator Chiu Yung-jen was responding to recent remarks by U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage that Taiwan is "probably the biggest landmine" in mainland China's relations with the United States.

He stressed that Armitage's remarks underscore Taiwan's need to buy advanced weaponry to defend itself. Taiwan people have to realize that they cannot rely on others and have to beef up their defenses and have confidence in those national defenses, he added.

The NT$610.8 billion special budget is for the purchase of eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine P-3C aircraft from the United States.
He noted that a Japanese television station has reported that the United States has deployed forces in Japan that will be able to respond quickly in the event of a conflict in the Taiwan Strait.
DPP Legislator Lee Cheng-nan also said that Taiwan's safety depends on its own people, adding that the Taiwan people should not rely on the United States or succumb to the wishes of the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January gained 30 points to close at 6,032, with 23,814 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February moved up 23 points to finish at 6,032, with 51 contracts traded, while March futures gained eight points to finish at 6,000, with one contract traded.
June futures gained 20 points to finish at 6,000, with six contracts traded, while September futures moved up 45 points to close at 5,946, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,002 for January, 6,009 for February, 5,992 for March, 5,980 for June and 5,901 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
January TE futures moved up 1.3 points to close at 225.3, with 2,189 contracts traded, while February TE futures gained 0.55 points to finish at 224.9, with 10 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.
January TF futures gained 0.2 points to finish at 1,016.2, with 2,550 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved up 4.2 points to end at 1,017.8, with 13 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG TANGERINES TO GO TO BRUNEI

TEXT.P: Taichung County is preparing to sell 36,000 kg of its famous Tunghsih township tangerines to Brunei.
The Tungshih Farmer's Association has in recent years been helping farmers produce and export its superb agricultural products to try to upgrade their competitive edge.
The association said that Tungshih's sweet and juicy tangerines were exported to Brunei last year on a trial basis, where they proved very popular. Exports this year will increase dramatically.
A first batch of 20,000 kg of tangerines was shipped Friday, with a second batch of 16,000 kg scheduled to go in January. The two batches combined are worth about NT$2 million (US$62,110).

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANG-GUNG MEDICAL CENTER PROJECT BREAKS GROUND IN CHIAYI

TEXT.P: Formosa Plastics Group and Chang-Gung Memorial Hospital Chairman Wang Yung-ching Friday presided over a ground-breaking ceremony for the Chang-Gung Medical Center building in Chiayi County.

The building will comprise 13 stories above ground, two underground floors and will accommodate 1,500 beds, according to Wang Cheng-yi, superintendent of the Chiayi Branch of Chang-Gung Memorial Hospital.
The project is estimated to cost NT$8 billion (US$240.96 million) and is scheduled for completion in March 2006, he said.

Calling Chiayi his "second hometown," Wang Yung-ching said Chiayi is where he started his business career and that he hopes to do something meaningful to upgrade the standard of local medical services.
In the company of Chiayi Magistrate Chen Ming-wen, the tycoon later visited the designated site of a retirement community.
Chen said the community will cover an area of 265 hectares and will be the largest of its kind in Taiwan.

He pointed out that the community is a five-minute drive from the Taipao station of the Taiwan high-speed railway and 9 km from Chang-Gung's Chiayi Branch, adding that he welcomes FPG's decision to invest in the development of the community.
The NT$20 billion project will include a golf course, farm, hotel and theme park, Chen said.
Wang Yung-ching, meanwhile, said the community will not only be a retirement home but will also provide entertainment and recreational facilities, as well as care for senior citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROWTH RATE SECURED WITH BUDGET APPROVAL FOR MAJOR CONSTRUCTION PLANS

TEXT.P: The legislature's recent approval of the budgets for the Cabinet's "Ten New Major Construction Projects" plan will help the government meet the goal of achieving a 5 percent economic growth rate for 2005, according to an economist.

Kung Ming-hsin, a division chief at the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, said that the budget approval will provide massive momentum for the country's infrastructure development, helping secure a 5 percent economic growth rate forecast set by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development -- the highest ratio ever predicted by domestic or foreign agencies.
Kung's comments came after the Legislative Yuan gave its go-ahead Thursday to a special budget allocation by the Executive Yuan with a combined value of NT$93 billion (US$2.9 billion).
More than NT$71.1 billion of that money will go toward the traffic network development, while some NT$10 billion will be used to improve the quality of higher education.

The Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics forecast that the Taiwan economy will expand by a moderate 4.56 percent for the whole of next year as a result of a slowed global economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE REVISES LAW TO BOOST INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY PROTECTION

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan amended the Customs Law Friday to include new penalties for the import and export of counterfeit and pirated goods.
The amendment is aimed at enhancing intellectual property protection in Taiwan, lawmakers said.

According to the amended law, importers and exporters of counterfeit and pirated goods or travelers found to be carrying such goods at customs will be fined an amount up to three times the value of the goods.

To prevent the export of illicit goods such as stolen cars, the penalty for making untruthful customs declarations was also made harsher, with the fine for this offense raised to up to NT$1 million from NT$30,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE

TEXT.P: CNA WILL SUSPEND ITS CEP SERVICE ON DEC. 25, CHRISTMAS DAY, WHICH IS ALSO CONSTITUTION DAY OF THE REPUBLIC OF CHINA. WE WISH ALL OUR SUBSCRIBERS A HAPPY FESTIVE SEASON.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC GROWTH FOR 2005 WILL BE 5 PERCENT: CEPD CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth rate will hit 5 percent next year due to the government's public construction drive and continued investment by the private sector, a government official said Friday.

Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , made the remarks during a gathering with business leaders in central Taichung City. Minister of Finance Lin Chuan was also present.

Hu based his optimism on the fact that the country is set to achieve an economic growth rate of 5.9 percent for the whole of this year, the best performance in seven years, coupled with an improved jobless rate. Taiwan's November unemployment rate stood at a relatively low 4.14 percent -- the lowest level since May 2001.
According to Hu, the CEPD is confident of meeting its 5 percent target for 2005 on the back of start of the government's "10 New Major Construction Projects" plan.

However, Huang Mao-hsiung, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, was less upbeat about the domestic economy's performance in the coming year due to a slowed world economy as has widely been predicted by major international forecasting agencies.

Huang said that he would rather be "cautiously optimistic" in this regard and called for more investment from the private sector and speedier industrial upgrading to help the government achieve its target.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO ATTEND FORMER FIRST LADY'S FUNERAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will head senior government officials to attend the funeral of former first lady Faina Chiang scheduled for Monday, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Friday.

Speaking at an impromptu news conference, MND spokesman Navy Capt. Liu Chih-chien said President Chen had directed the ministry to help with funeral arrangements for Faina Chiang, widow of late President Chiang Ching-kuo.
Russian-born Faina Chiang, better known as Chiang Fang-laing in Taiwan, died of pulmonary and cardiac failure Dec. 15 at the age of 88.
As the Chiang family insisted on financing funeral costs on their own, Liu said, the defense ministry need not use its reserve funds to foot the bill.
The funeral will be held at the Chieh Shou Hall of Veterans General Hospital in suburban Taipei, Liu said.
At the start of the news conference, Liu and other MND officials observed a moment of silence in memory of the former first lady.

On Monday, a family service will begin at 7 a.m. The public will be welcome to pay their last respects to Faina Chiang from 8 a.m. onward. Opposition Kuomintang party elders, including Lee Huan, Hau Pei-tsun, Chiu Chuang-huan and Shih Chi-yang, will drape Chiang's casket with the ROC national flag and the KMT flag.
A memorial service will commence at 9:30 a.m. to be officiated by the Reverend Chou Lien-hua, who has been pastor to the Chiang family for decades.
At 11 a.m., Chiang's casket will be moved to the Keelung Municipal Crematorium. Her ashes will then be moved to her husband's temporary mausoleum in Touliao, Taoyuan County.
An exhibition of photos of Faina Chiang and some of her personal effects will open at an art gallery in the KMT headquarters in Taipei Saturday, a KMT spokesman said Friday.
On display will be 90 rare photos featuring Faina's life in Russia, mainland China and Taiwan, the spokesman said, adding that many of them have never been shown in public before.
The exhibits will also include 50-plus furniture items from her residence in suburban Taipei as well as some personal effects, including clothes, handbags and jewelry.
On Friday, the KMT also presented a plaque to honor Faina Chiang posthumously.

Faina Chiang met her husband while he was in the Soviet Union in the 1930s. A woman of simple tastes with a technical school education, Faina Chiang left her homeland in 1936 when she joined her husband to return to mainland China. She had to adjust to joining one of mainland China's most powerful families at the time. Mainland China was ruled by her father-in-law, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, and the Kuomintang during the period.

She fled to Taiwan along with her family in 1949 after the Chinese Communists took control of the mainland. Her husband became president in 1978 and ended 38 years of martial law just months before he died in 1988. He also oversaw the island's spectacular economic development in the 1980s.
Faina Chiang avoided the spotlight and was known to be Taiwan's most low-key first lady.
The couple had three sons and one daughter. The three sons all died, while the daughter, Chiang Hsiao-chang, lives in the United States with her family.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW' TO IMPACT TAIWAN INVESTORS: BUSINESS LEADER

TEXT.P: The "anti-secession law" that Beijing is planning to introduce will definitely have an impact on Taiwanese businessmen with operations in mainland China, a local business leader said Friday.

However, just how deep the impact will be depends on the actual contents of the law, which has yet to be revealed, according to Theodore M.H. Huang, chairman of the Taiwan-based Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce.

Reports said the law is designed to crush the pro-independence movement in Taiwan, and the National People's Congress of China is expected to discuss a draft of the law in an upcoming meeting set for later this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, giving up NT$0.038 to close at NT$32.190.
A total of US$469.5 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$32.130 and fluctuated between NT$32.050 and NT$32.198.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush tries again on court choices stalled in Senate
U.S. President Bush said Thursday that when the new Congress
convenes next month he will renominate 12 candidates to the
federal appeals courts who were denied confirmation in his
first term. In doing so, he signaled his willingness to begin
what is expected to be another bitter fight with Senate
Democrats over what they assert are his efforts to shift the
courts in a markedly more conservative direction. Although the
announcement appears at odds with Mr. Bush's post-election
remarks that he would reach out to opponents, it is in line
with what had been a principal campaign theme for him and Vice
President Dick Cheney, namely that Bush would battle Democratic
opposition to his judicial choices.
Wall Street Journal: Visible hand to fix Venezuela. ex-guerrillas want to make 'new man'
Venezuela's fiery president, Hugo Chavez is adopting a policy of "development from within, with materials from within, by those within for those within."
To accomplish that goal, the Chavez government is plowing billions of dollars into new programs, called "missions, " which act as social welfare agencies. The missions are largely devoted to health-care education and jobs training. Chavez plans to combine the dozen or so existing missions into a megaproject dubbed "Mision Cristo, " or Christ's Mission, which he proclaims will end poverty in Venezuela by 2021. The programs are a hit among Venezuela's poor and are helping solidify Chavez's political base. Chavez has made a political career of exacerbating Venezuela's bitter social divisions. Despite the country's oil wealth, about 61 percent of the people survive on less than US$2 a day, according to a survey the the Andras Bello Catholic University in Caracas.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN SHOULD LEAD PARTY TO VICTORY IN ELECTIONS NEXT YEAR: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Friday that the new chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should have the ability to lead the party to victory in the county and city chief elections scheduled for next year.
Lu made the remarks during a tea party with reporters covering Presidential Office news.
She said that before the next presidential election in 2008, there are six major elections and that the DPP needs to be well-prepared for each of them.

She stressed that anyone who aspires to serve as the next chairman of the DPP will have to pass the first major test in the mayoral and magistrate elections in 2005, adding that these elections are crucially related to the 2008 presidential election.

She noted that President Chen Shui-bian stepped down from his concurrent post as DPP chairman in the wake of the worse-than-expected performance of the DPP candidates in the Dec. 11 legislative elections. The next party chairman will also need to take responsibility for the performance of the DPP in the 2005 elections.
Lu said that "the party chairman must be capable of giving the DPP a victory in the mayoral and magistrate elections next year. It's as simple as that."
Lu quoted Chen as saying that he has no specific person in mind to serve the next chairman and that the new leader should be more capable than he is and one who can revive the party.

Lu also said that the next party chairman will have to be an election genius and should be well aware of all the problems that plagued the DPP in the Dec. 11 legislative elections. The DPP had expected more than 100 seats in the 225-seat legislature so as to clinch a majority with its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, but ended with only 89 seats.
Lu also said that while having lunch with Chen Friday, she asked him if the premier will be changed, but the president said he had yet to consider the question.

Chen said he had been busy with the nomination of the Control Yuan members and had not yet had time to think about the premiership. He said he will start to think about the question and will also listen to views from all sides, according to Lu.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun is expected to lead his Cabinet in a mass resignation Feb. 1, the day the new legislature is sworn in, in line with constitutional practice.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORENSIC EXPERT CONCLUDES TAIPEI VISIT

TEXT.P: Dr. Henry Lee, a renowned Chinese-American forensic scientist, departed Taiwan Friday after an eight-day visit.
Lee said prior to his departure that one purpose of his visit was to review preparations for an international seminar on forensic science to be held in Taiwan next November.
Lee said he hopes the seminar can provide a conduit for international exchanges of forensic expertise and for forging cooperative ties in forensic investigation technolog research.
During his stay, Lee met with Premier Yu Shyi-kun. Lee said he has suggested that the ROC government upgrade the status and authority of police to facilitate the campaign against crime.
With violent crimes, including kidnapping, homicide and arson, increasing, Lee said police need support and cooperation from the general public to maintain law and order.

Noting that public order and social stability are critical to a country's economic development, Lee said Taiwan should improve its crime-fighting operations, including upgrading forensic investigation technology.

Lee was born in Jiangsu province in mainland China and came to Taiwan at the end of the Chinese Civil War when he was six. He graduated in 1960 from the Taiwan Central Police College with a degree in Police Science. Lee became the youngest captain in modern Chinese history when he was promoted at the age of 22 during his service at the Taipei City Police Headquarters.

During his meeting with Yu, Lee also said the ROC government should offer more cash rewards and offer to reduce sentences for cooperative criminals to help solve the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.
Lee said the recent identification of the source of the gun and bullets used in the presidential election-eve shooting does not mean that the sensitive, high-profile case has been solved.
"We must discover where the gun is, who bought the gun and then who fired the shots. This is no easy task," Lee said.
He suggested that the ROC government offer reduced sentences to encourage those who have bought guns and bullets from the now-detained underground gunsmith to come forward.

Lee had headed an expert team to conduct a forensic investigation into the shooting in April and concluded a comprehensive forensic investigation report this summer. While duplicate copies were sent to Taipei in August, the original copy was not handed over to Taiwan's top prosecutor until Thursday. Lee personally forwarded the original copy of his forensic report on the shooting to State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao.

"The original copy of the report is extremely important. I have kept it with me since I arrived in Taipei Dec. 18. I did not place it in a safe nor was it taken by any other person. To my great relief, I finally handed it over to the state public prosecutor-general, " Lee said.

Over the past more than nine months, Lee said he has kept in close contact with Taiwan's investigation team. He said he was glad to learn that the team, headed by Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) Director Hou You-yi, managed to determine that a now-detained underground gunsmith was the one who made the bullets and gun used in the shooting.
"It's a breakthrough. We should give the investigation team more encouragement," Lee said.
During his just-concluded visit, Lee said he has offered the team some new suggestions concerning the direction of follow-up probes.
Chen and Lu were riding in an open-top jeep when they were shot while campaigning in the southern city of Tainan March 19. One bullet grazed Chen's stomach, while Lu was hit in the knee.

Chen beat his sole challenger, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, in the March 20 presidential election by a slim margin. Lien filed two lawsuits in an attempt to nullify Chen's re-election victory and even the entire election so that a new one could be held. The Taiwan High Court rejected the re-election annulment suit, but Lien has appealed the case to the Supreme Court, which has yet to hand down a ruling.
Many opposition politicians and supporters have disseminated outrageous speculation about the shooting, including allegations that it was staged by Chen to sway sympathy votes in his favor.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WILL SEE 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW' AS CHANGE TO STATUS QUO: FM

TEXT.P: The last thing that Washington wants to see is Beijing enact an "anti-secession law" aimed at Taiwan since it would change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Friday.

In anticipation of the upcoming debate of the draft law by Beijing's National People's Congress, Chen warned that the United States, which is busy handling the deteriorating situation in Iraq and the threat posed by North Korea, has repeatedly cautioned mainland China and Taiwan against trying to change the status quo unilaterally.
Chen said his ministry is sure that Washington will consider Beijing's "anti-secession law" a change to the status quo and will press Beijing to withdraw the draft bill.

Beijing has complained to Washington about Taiwan's possible plan to rename its overseas missions using the word "Taiwan, " and, consequently, Washington has expressed its disapproval to Taiwan. By the same token, Chen said, Washington will relay Taipei's disapproval of Beijing's "anti-secession law" to Beijing and will warn Beijing that it is tantamount to a change in the status quo.
Citing a government poll, Chen said that the people of Taiwan are without a doubt opposed to Beijing's creating an "anti-secession law."

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS CALL FOR CANCELLATION OF RALLY TO SUPPORT 'RICE BOMBER'

TEXT.P: A group of lawmakers, lawyers and scholars urged activists for farmer rights Friday not to stage a public rally in support of the "rice bomber, " a man now detained who is suspected of being responsible for a spate of bomb threats in Taipei over the past year.

They made the appeal as several civic groups announced that they are planning a 10,000-person rally in Changhua County's Erlin township in central Taiwan this Sunday to support Yang Ju-men, who they believe is not a criminal, but only "a tragic figure" or a "sacrificial lamb" on the alter of Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Legislator Chao Yung-ching of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party urged the civic groups to cancel the planned rally because it could send the wrong message to the public.

"Local farmers are indeed facing difficulties in their livelihoods. But nobody can rationalize terrorist actions for any excuse. If labor and farmer rights activists support Yang, the action might inspire other people to follow suit and eventually disrupt social stability and public safety," Chao said.
Yeh Yi-lan, a professor at Central Police University, said different opinions can be expressed through legal channels and rational debates.

"Supporting legitimate farmers rights and agricultural development should be delinked from any terrorist. We should never make a criminal a hero. Such a move could inspire emulation at the expense of society as a whole," Yeh said.

Yang, who claims to oppose the government's policy of permitting rice imports, allegedly placed homemade explosives in public areas such as parks, trains, railway stations and mobile toilets in the greater Taipei area since late last year. He is suspected of having been involved in 11 of the 16 cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: MATSU RESIDENTS UNSATISFIED WITH 'MINI LINKS': POLL

TEXT.P: Residents on Matsu Island are not satisfied with the direct transport and trade links maintained between the frontline island and Mawei Port in mainland China's Fujian province, according to the results of a recent poll.

Matsu residents responding to the poll gave the links a ranking of 59 on a 100-point scale, indicating that they were unsatisfied with the so-called "mini three-links, " which were started Jan. 1, 2001 between Taiwan-held Kinmen and Matsu islands and the Fujian ports of Xiamen and Mawei to compensate for the long-standing absence of full links between Taiwan proper and the mainland.

As the links near their four-year anniversary, analysts of the survey said that sentiments so close to the failure line of 60 points indicate that most of the people on Matsu are not pleased with the results of the links but consider them tolerable.

When asked how to increase Matsu's competitive edge, a majority of local residents pointed to traffic improvement between Matsu and Taiwan proper as their top concern, followed by economic development, job creation, administrative proficiency and security.

Academics praised the poll, the first of its kind with Matsu residents, on the grounds that its findings should serve as a valuable reference for the central government when crafting policy to help with local development. The poll was carried out by Ming Chuan University.

Taiwan and mainland China have been at odds since 1949, when the island split from the mainland in the wake of a civil war. Taiwan has banned direct transport, trade and postal services with mainland China since that year despite the fact that private-sector exchanges have become frequent and close in recent years.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF INVITES BEIJING RESPONSE FOR 'WIN-WIN' SITUATION

TEXT.P: Although relations between Taiwan and mainland China have remained deadlocked for some time, Taipei is still waiting for a response from Beijing to create an environment beneficial to both sides, a liaison official said Friday.

Hsu Sheng-fa, vice chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , made the remarks on behalf of SEF Chairman C. F. Koo at a board of directors meeting of the quasi-official organization.

Claiming that Taiwan has never rested in its efforts to try to build a "win-win" situation in its ties with mainland China, Hsu urged Beijing to respond swiftly with visionary moves to Taipei's overtures for peace and prosperity across the Taiwan Strait.

According to the SEF vice chairman, the two sides can talk about many mutually beneficial issues, such as reopening two-way institutionalized negotiations, charter flight services for Taiwan businessmen in mainland China wishing to spend the coming lunar new year at home and direct cargo transport.

Now that high emotions arising from Taiwan's recent legislative elections are already over, the two sides should put aside their political feuding and work jointly for the welfare and benefit of the people on both sides. Cross-strait relations have become kind of sensitive in recent months after the Taiwan authorities launched a series of activities to increase national identity among its people.
Taiwan and mainland China have long been at odds since 1949, when the nationalist party retreated from the mainland to the island in the wake of the Chinese civil war.
The SEF was set up in 1991 to deal with cross-strait civil contacts between Taiwan and mainland China. The Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait is its counterpart based in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR DEC. 25 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, Dec. 25:
09:00, Taiwan Peace-promoting Foundation will hold a Reconciliation Day activity at the 228 Park in Taipei.
09: 20, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh will hold a news conference at Fishermen Pier in Kaohsiung to mark his second year in office.
10:00, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will hold a news conference in Taipei to mark his six years in office.
10:00, The Kuomintang will hold a news conference for the opening of an exhibition of photos and personal belongings of the late first lady Faina Chiang.
11: 00, Premier Yu Shyi-kun will open the Pingtung Tropical Agricultural Fair in Changchih, Pingtung, southern Taiwan.
19: 00, Premier Yu Shyi-kun and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen will attend a Christmas Party organized by the International Cooperation and Development Fund in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 26, or the 15th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1792: Charles Babbage, British mathematician and inventor of the first computer, is born.
1797: John Wilkes, British political reformer noted for his published attacks on George III and for his support of the rights of American colonists, dies at the age of 70.
1890: Heinrich Schliemann, the German archaeologist who discovered the ruins of ancient Troy and excavated Mycenae, dies in Naples, Italy, at the age of 58.
1893: Mao Zedong, chairman of the Chinese Communist Party who proclaimed the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949, is born in Hunan Province.
1908: American boxer Jack Johnson defeats world heavyweight champion Tommy Burns at Rushcutter's Bay in Sydney, Australia, with a dazzling display of fighting skills, becoming the first black boxer to win the title.
1912: Mackay Memorial Hospital is inaugurated in Taipei.
1914: The United States pays back the remainder of a large sum of indemnities, totaling $11 million, that China was forced to pay in the signing of the Treaty of Peking in 1901.
1916: Tsai Yuan-pei becomes president of National Peking University.
1938: Chiang Kai-shek reiterates China's determination to carry on the war of resistance against Japan and charges that a recent statement by Japanese Prime Minister Prince Fumimaro Konoye clearly reveals Japan's intention to conquer China.
1941: The Unites States declares Manila an open city as Japanese forces approach.
1943: The British Royal Navy sinks the mighty German battle cruiser Scharnhosrt, making the sea lanes of the North Sea safer for Allied convoys.
1971: Sixteen U.S. veterans of the Vietnam War seize the Statue of Liberty in New York harbor to dramatize their anti-war stance.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. EXPERT CALLS FOR FREE TRADE PACT WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 25 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The United States should sign a free trade agreement with Taiwan, Greg Mastel, an international trade adviser at the law firm Miller & Chevalier in Washington, D.C. said in an article published in the Dec. 27 issue of the Washington-based Standard weekly.

Greg said Taiwan is the United States' eighth largest trading partner and the fifth largest economy in Asia, and is therefore a much more promising partner for a free trade agreement than any of the two dozen countries with which the United States is currently negotiating such agreements. He added that a U.S.-Taiwan free trade agreement would benefit American farmers and manufacturers and the U.S. economy as a whole.

Greg also noted that China is emerging as one of the world's largest economies and trading powers and is vigorously building a web of free trade agreements with its Asian neighbors which could effectively exclude Taipei from expanding its own trade with the rest of Asia.

Some have suggested that Taiwan could pursue enhanced trade ties with China directly, but many in Taiwan fear that increasing the island's economic dependence on the mainland would effectively strip Taiwan of its political autonomy.

As the world's leading democracy, the United States should offer Taiwan an alternative to dependence on totalitarian China, Greg said. Just as the threat of a Chinese invasion of Taiwan has secured U.S. military support for the island, so the threat of Chinese economic domination of the island should prompt the United States to offer an alternative to Taipei in the form of a free trade agreement, he argued.

Noting that the United States is now negotiating free trade agreements with Asian countries which have less to offer than Taiwan for fear of being shut out of the region by China's emerging web of free trade agreements, Greg said the United States should by the same token also negotiate a free trade pact with Taiwan.

Greg mentioned in his article that Taiwan's Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh visited Washington in early December to urge the United States to negotiate a free trade agreement with Taiwan but was given the cold shoulder.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANY FOREIGN CHINESE-LANGUAGE STUDENTS PREFER TAIWAN TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Many Chinese-language students think that Taiwan is a better place than mainland China to learn the language, given Taiwan's safer environment and better teaching force, among other reasons.

Febrana Tanudjaja, an Australian of Chinese origin who is currently a student at the Mandarin teaching center of Tunghai University, Taichung, said that it was her parents' vision that she learn Chinese in Taiwan to acquire proficient command of the language of their ancestors.
Tanudjaja said that although she could have studied Chinese in Australia, she found it difficult to secure a Mandarin-friendly environment there because few people back home speak Chinese.

Many of her seniors in the Chinese community in Australia suggested that she go to Taiwan instead of mainland China to study Chinese because Taiwan is safer and has better living conditions, Tanudjaja said.
Shida Akinobu, another student from the Tunghai Mandarin center, echoed Tanudjaja's words, saying that Taiwan is a better choice for foreign students trying to learn Chinese.

Akinobu, who had studied Chinese in Harbin, northeastern China during his college years, said the Chinese spoken in Taiwan is easier for Japanese speakers to master because the retroflex sounds are milder.
A Rotary Ambassador Prize winner, Akinobu said he found that the number of foreigners coming to Taiwan to learn Chinese has not declined since mainland China opened its doors to foreign students.

Akinobu said that he went to Harbin to learn Chinese on a student exchange program because he had no other options. However, he said, he decided to come to Taiwan to learn Chinese after he graduated from a university in Japan.
Meanwhile, both Tanudjaja and Akinobu said that the Tunghai center is by no means inferior to other similar centers in Taipei or elsewhere, because the center's teaching force is superb.

Tanudjaja attributes her ability to deliver a speech in Chinese after only three months of study in Taiwan to her "demanding" lecturers at the center who stressed the importance of proper pronunciation and use of tones.

Akinobu said that Taiwan's use of complex Chinese characters, as opposed to the simplified characters used in mainland China, as well as its National Phonetic Symbols make it easier for foreign students to pick up the language and speak it more proficiently.

Akinobu said he strongly encourages Japanese and Korean students to learn Chinese in Taiwan simply because the Mandarin phonetic symbol system used here is the most efficient system for helping foreigners pronounce Chinese correctly and eventually conversing with Taiwan people in the shortest possible period of time.
Max Woodworth, a European who studied Chinese culture at Washington's Georgetown University, is a prominent example of a foreigner successfully learning Chinese.
Woodworth went to Beijing and Nanjing to study Chinese for a year after his third year at Georgetown.

Five years ago, when his Chinese studies in China concluded and he had acquired a good command of mandarin Chinese, a Chinese teacher of his suggested that he go to Taipei to attend National Chengchi University's Sun Yat-sen Institute of Humanity and Social Studies, which has maintained academic cooperation ties with Georgetown University.
In Chengda, Woodworth said that he found the Chengda Mandarin Language Center to be one of the best in the world in terms of learning Chinese.
After studying for a year at the Sun Yat-sen Institute, Woodworth joined the English daily Taipei Times as a reporter covering mainly arts and literature news.

Now able to understand about 80 percent of Chinese-language news stories without the aid of a dictionary, Woodworth said he feels most confident in listening and speaking Chinese but still finds writing Chinese characters to be the most difficult part.
Woodworth, who is now even venturing into learning the Taiwanese dialect, said that the sky is the limit in learning Chinese.
Another young man, William Laxton from France, has been in Taiwan for more than two years, learning Chinese, which he described as "very difficult."
Laxon said that he was in Taiwan three years ago working on a post-production team for the film "Millennium Mambo" directed by Taiwan avant-garde director Hou Hsiao-hsien.
Finding Taiwan an interesting place to live, Laxon decided to return to Taipei six months after returning to France.
Fascinated by Chinese culture, Laxon said he has even studied the ancient Chinese philosophers Laoz and Chuangzhou.
John Vaughan, an associate professor in the Department of Music at Soochow University in Taipei, speaks mandarin Chinese so fluently that he has no foreign accent.
Vaughan's Taiwanese wife, Liu Yi-chih, a flutist, has been his Chinese teacher during their marriage of 15 years.
Like Woodworth, Vaughan has also developed a strong interest in learning the Taiwanese dialect.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT LEE TO TAKE LEISURE TRIP TO JAPAN DEC. 27-JAN. 2

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui is scheduled to depart for Japan Monday for a week-long sightseeing tour, informed sources said Sunday.
This will mark Lee's first visit to Japan since 2001 when he headed there to undergo heart by-pass surgery.

Lee will be accompanied by his wife, Tseng Wen-huei; their granddaughter, Lee Kun-yi; their daughter-in-law, Chang Yue-yun; as well as family friends Peng Rong-tsi and his wife; and Lee's physician, the sources said.

Despite strong protest from Beijing, the Japanese government granted a visa to Lee last week after the former president presented his visa application Dec. 17 to the Taipei Office of Japan's Interchange Association, the de facto Japanese embassy in Taiwan.

Officials from Taiwan's representative office in Japan said last week that their office will extend special assistance to Lee, including giving him preferential treatment at immigration and customs, during his stay in Japan.
Lee and his group will arrive in Nagoya Monday to start their visit, which will also take them to Kyoto and Kanazawa.

Hiroyuki Hosada, Japan's chief Cabinet secretary, said in Tokyo last Monday that Lee's visit is private and that he will not participate in any political activities during his stay. Hosada asked Japan's media not to bother Lee during his visit.
Japanese Minister of Foreign Affairs Nobutaka Machimura also urged Japanese lawmakers not to ask to meet with Lee during his stay.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SECRETARY-GENERAL SAYS HE WON'T RUN FOR PARTY CHIEF

TEXT.P: Chang Chun-hsiung, secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said Sunday that he will not run for DPP chairman and that he has informed President Chen Shui-bian, the outgoing DPP chief, of his decision.
However, Chang stressed that his decision has nothing to do with whether or not he'll vie for the position of Legislative Yuan speaker which depends on the DPP's overall needs.
Chang announced his decision at a news conference one day before the DPP begins registration of would-be candidates for the post of party chairman.

Noting that there will be seven important elections in Taiwan over the next four years, including the national assembly elections and local government chiefs elections in 2005 and the mayoral elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung in 2006, Chang said the party requires someone of great vigor and ability to lead it. The other elections he was referring to are the legislative elections of 2007 and the presidential and vice presidential elections of 2008.
Chang said he has informed President Chen that he has no intention of running for party chief. Chen was reported as saying that he understands Chang's decision.

Chen Shui-bian resigned as DPP chairman after his party failed to live up to his expectations in the Dec. 11 legislative elections. The "pan-green camp" of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union was unable to win a majority in the new legislature, instead gaining only a single seat over its pevious total.
The next DPP chairman will be chosen in a vote by DPP members.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HONORS WINNERS OF FILIAL PIETY AWARDS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presented awards to the seven winners of the annual Filial Piety Awards in Tainan county, southern Taiwan Sunday.
President Chen lauded the seven winners, all of whom were honored for taking care of their parents despite facing economical hardship or physical challenges.

Speaking at the event, Chen said that he has attended every Filial Piety Awards presentation ceremony since becoming president because he believes filial piety is the very basis of all virtue and helps stabilize the family, society and the country.
The president also urged the country's elected public officials and the general public to follow the example of the seven award winners by practicing filial piety.

Each of the award winners also received NT$300,000 in cash. The awards were set up by the Wu Tsun-hsien Foundation -- a public service organization established by late Tainan business tycoon Wu Tsun-hsien.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 39TH IN AVERAGE LIFE EXPECTANCY

TEXT.P: The average life expectancy in Taiwan was 76 years for 2003, ranking the island 39th among the 208 countries around the world, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics (DGBAS) reported Sunday.
The average life expectancy for men in Taiwan has risen by 1.7 years over the last 10 years, while that for women has increased by 1.5 years, the officials noted.
Life expectancy is an index reflecting a country's medical care and health standards, the officials said.

Quoting data from the U.S. Bureau of Census as well as Taiwan's Department of Health, the officials said that the global average life expectancy was 67 in 2003, two years higher than that posted a decade earlier.

Life expectancy among people in Asia and Latin America, Oceania, and North America has risen by three years, two years and one year, respectively, over the past 10 years, the officials said. By comparison, they said, life expectancy for people in Europe and Africa has decreased by one year and two years, respectively.
By gender, the global average life expectancy for women was 69 years in 2003, four years higher than that for men. North American women topped the list, with an average life expectancy of 80 years.

The African country of Mozambique posted the lowest life expectancy last year, at 34 years. Life expectancy in the southern African country of Botswana declined to 46 years in 2003 from 49 years in 1980, mainly as a result of the AIDS scourge.
According to the World Health Organization, the global average life expectancy is expected to rise to 73 years by 2025, with the average life expectancy in almost all countries exceeding 50 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECORD NUMBER OF BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS WINTERING IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A record number of 842 black-faced spoonbills have arrived in Taiwan to winter, according to a count conducted Sunday by conservationist groups in the various habitats of the endangered migratory birds.
The figure surpasses the record of 728 posted last year, the conservationists said.

The count was jointly conducted by the Wild Birds Associations of Tainan City and Tainan County, the Black-Faced Spoonbill Conservation Association, and the Black-Faced Spoonbill Family and Wild Birds Association.

By region, 587 black-faced spoonbills were counted at the main conservation area in Tainan County, southern Taiwan, 186 in the Sitsao wetland area in Tainan City, 33 in the areas along the Pachang River bordering the counties of Tainan and Chiayi, 20 in fishery pools north of Chiku village in Tainan County and 16 in the Dinshan area, Chiku.
According to a global survey conducted in January of this year, only 1,206 black-faced spoonbills remain in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF UNVEILS POLICY IN NEW LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said in Fengshan, Kaohsiung County Sunday that his party will press for the formation of an administration with economic can-dos and the establishment of a national pension program.

Speaking at a tea party organized by the KMT to thank its supporters in the Kaohsiung metropolitan area and Pingtung County, Lien also promised to push the government to invest more resources in education.

Citing forecasts made by foreign think tanks before the Dec. 11 legislative elections, Lien said that his party had been expected to lose more than 20 seats but that it actually gained 11 seats thanks to the enthusiasm of KMT supporters.
Lien said his party appreciates the supporters' enthusiasm and will faithfully play its role as the leading opposition in the new legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 90% SUPPORT NEW GARBAGE CLASSIFICATION POLICY: DOH SURVEY

TEXT.P: Some 90 percent of the people in Taiwan support the government's garbage classification policy set to be implemented at the start of next year in selected areas, according to the results of a recent government survey.

Nearly 80 percent of the respondents in the survey conducted Nov. 29-Dec. 2 by the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) said they are confident the classification policy will effectively help reduce the amount of rubbish.

Starting from Jan. 1, 2005, citizens in ten cities and counties, including Taipei City, Kaohsiung City, Keelung City, Hsinchu City, Taichung City, Chiayi City, Ilan City, Taichung County and Kaohsiung County, will have to sort their trash into three categories -- regular garbage, kitchen leftovers, and recyclable materials.
Those who fail to separate their garbage in line with the DOH requirements will be subject to fines of between NT$1,200 and NT$6,000 (US$185).
In the DOH survey, 70 percent of the respondents said they approve of the government's measure to impose fines under the policy.
The garbage classification policy will be implemented in the rest of the areas around Taiwan from Jan. 1, 2006.
A total of 2,474 people over the age of 20 islandwide were interviewed in the telephone survey, with 70 percent of them claiming to be in charge of garbage cleaning at their homes.

Regarding the existing recycling policy, about 80 percent of the respondents said they think it has been successful in reducing the amount of garbage by almost 40 percent, while some 30 percent said their garbage has been reduced by half since the policy was implemented.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTORS RESERVED ABOUT BEIJING'S ANTI-SECESSION DRAFT LAW

TEXT.P: Despite the fact that mainland China's National People's Congress has begun drafting a proposed "anti-secession law" widely believed to be aimed at Taiwan, foreign investors have been reserved about its impact on Taiwan's stock market, market analysts said Sunday.

Market watchers said that most foreign investors have in the current holiday season taken a wait-and-see attitude concerning the effects of the proposed legislation on the Taiwan Stock Exchange as the legislation's contents are still not clear at present.

The turnover in the domestic bourse hit a low of less than NT$45 billion (US$11.38 billion) on Friday due to the combined effect of the news of Beijing's move and the Christmas and New Year holidays, during which foreign investors traditionally prefer not to significantly move their capital in Asian markets, the analysts explained.

As Taiwan's economic fundamentals remain in good shape, foreign capital is expected to enter the domestic market in the wake of the New Year holidays, they forecast, pointing out that political factors should play a smaller role in the Taiwan bourse after various major incidents over the past decade.

They noted that the impact on the Taiwan stock market of political crises has reduced with each successive event, pointing out that the market dropped after the missile crisis in the Taiwan Strait in 1996, after former President Lee Teng-hui's "two states" theory remarks in 1999 and after President Chen Shui-bian's "one country on each side of the strait" comments in 2002, but to a lesser degree each time.

Although some foreign investors said they think it is good that domestic retail investors have become calmer when the market is hit by a political crisis, others expressed worry that as mainland China emerges as a world power, it will harden its stance toward Taiwan, as witnessed by the proposed legislation, which they said could pose a major threat to Taiwan's economic development and its capital market.

Meanwhile, domestic institutional investors also opined that the impact on Taiwan of the "anti-secession" law shouldn't be to significant so long as its contents do not go far beyond what is expected.

The effects should be limited because the legislation will not carry an immediate risk to Taiwan and because the stock market will eventually perform on economic fundamentals, they claimed, adding that political elements will be quickly digested by the market which is set to catch up with the rising streak in the world's major markets.

However, some are concerned that the latest development will cast a shadow over the so-call China-concept shares, which have strongly rebounded in Taiwan's stock market after the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Beijing's anti-secession draft law will put Taiwan and mainland China at greater political risks, unavoidably provoking a psychological effect on Taiwan investors, they said and asserted that shipping and transport stocks as well as real estate and property shares will mostly be affected.

Ahead of mainland China's expected passage of the "anti-secession" legislation into law in March next year, the Taiwan stock market will be jolted by political uncertainties over the short term, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO PROMOTE 'TECHNOLOGY DIPLOMACY'

TEXT.P: The government should further promote technological assistance to foreign nations, or the so-called "technology diplomacy, " as a means of breaking China's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan in the international arena, experts said Sunday.

The experts suggested in a technology forum organized by the Ketagalan Institute that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs integrate officials assigned by domestic economic, trade and technological agencies to work abroad for further promoting the country's overall diplomacy.

Tsan Ting-yi, a secretary of the Institute for Information Industry, said that Taiwan's experience in developing science-based parks, information industry and technology services can be used in its foreign aid.
Also, the government can offer scholarships to students in Third World nations to come to Taiwan to learn its agricultural technologies, she added.
Taiwan can also share its experience in technological, agricultural and economic development with less developed nations to help their national development, Tsan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGER NUMBERS OF THIRTY-SOMETHINGS QUITTING: DGBAS SURVEY

TEXT.P: With widespread business closures and company streamlining, more and more workers aged between 30 and 39 in Taiwan have been quitting the workplace, according to a recent survey by the government.

According to the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) survey, 1.78 percent of the country's workforce in the 30-39 age group quit the workplace, exceeding the 1.73 percent who found work.

Except for 2001, in which Taiwan was seriously hit by an economic recession, the number of thirty-something workers finding jobs has traditionally outstripped the number losing their jobs, DGBAS officials said.

The officials pointed out that this indicates that the job turnover rate among the country's most productive population is picking up despite the fact that Taiwan's economy recorded growth of 3.3 percent last year.
They ascribed the phenomenon to the fact that more and more Taiwan enterprises are relocating overseas, such as to mainland China, and to their streamlining strategies.

According to the DGBAS survey, the turnover rate of workers aged over 30 years increases with age. Last year, only the 20-29 year age group and workers older than 60 years and those younger than 20 years saw a drop in turnover rates over the previous year's levels.

Also according to the survey, respondents had worked an average of 6.13 years for the same company as of the end of December of last year. About 45 percent of the respondents said that they had worked for the same company for between one and five years, while 39 percent said that they had done so for more than five years, and 16 percent said they had worked for the same company for less than one year.
The DGBAS carried out the survey on workers at 9,600 companies in the manufacturing and service sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR DONATIONS TO HELP TSUNAMI-HIT NATIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun called for donations Sunday to help countries hit by massive tidal waves, or tsunami, set off by an Indonesian earthquake earlier that day.

Chen Chi-mai, spokesman of the Executive Yuan, said that Yu had instructed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to ask its overseas missions to convey Taiwan's regards to their hosting countries in the affected region and to collect related information in preparation for relief operations.

Yu also urged Taiwan's overseas missions to convey government's regards to Taiwanese businessmen operating in the afected region and to the overseas Chinese communities there and actively extend assistances to them if necessary.

The Premier also instructed the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to work together with the Republic of China National Federation of Travel Agents Associations to collect information on casualties of Taiwanese passengers in the disasters and to give a hand to the victims' families, according to Chen.

A Taiwanese tourist was killed in a resort center on the Phuket Island of Thailand after a 8.9-magnitude earthquake hit near the Indonesian island of Sumatra which set off tsunami striking coast areas of Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, India and Suri Lanka, claiming a large number of casualties and damage to properties.
At least 3,900 people were killed by the tsunami and millions of others were affected in the five Asian nations, according to wire reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 27, or the 16th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1571: Johannes Kepler, German astronomer and mathematician, is born. Considered the founder of modern astronomy, he formulated three laws to clarify the theory that the planets revolve around the sun.
1822: Louis Pasteur, French chemist and bacteriologist who founded modern microbiology, is born. He invented the process of pasteurization and developed vaccines for anthrax, rabies and chicken cholera.
1831: Under the command of Capt. Robert Fitzroy, the Royal Navy's HMS Beagle sets sail from Devonport, England, on a five-year voyage of scientific exploration around the world.
1927: Leon Trotsky, Russian revolutionary theoretician, is expelled form the Soviet Communist Party for his opposition to the authoritarianism of Stalin and for his emphasis on world revolution.
1945: The International Monetary Fund is set up in Washington, D.C.
1949: Republic of China government troops evacuate Chengtu, the capital of Szechwan Province.
1949: Ahmed Sukarno, leader of the Indonesian Nationalist Party, returns to Batavia (Jakarta) after A.H.J. Lovink, representative of the Netherlands government, signed a protocol transferring sovereignty to an Indonesian delegation.
1958: More than 10,000 Tibetans die in armed resistance against Communist Chinese atrocities.
1959: Japanese Prime Minister Shegeru Yoshida visits Taipei.
1969: Egypt, Sudan and Libya agree to the formation of a political, economic and military alliance.
1972: Lester Pearson, the former Canadian prime minister who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1957 for his part in settling the Suez crisis in 1956, dies at the age of 75.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Chad.
1975: Ten people are honored by the Young Entrepreneurs Association in Taipei for their inventions.
1975: The First International Children's Camp opens for two days of activities sponsored by the Camping Association of the Republic of China.
1975: The ROC's Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen announces it had given aid to 251,563 former servicemen as of the end of November.
1976: Jacques Baumel, member of the National Assembly of France, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1976: Dr. Charles E. Bishop, president of the University of Arkansas, and Rev. Malcolm Carron, president of the University of Detroit, arrive in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1978: Some 10,000 people demonstrate at the airport when a delegation led by U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Warren Christopher arrives in Taipei for talks after the United States severed diplomatic relations with Taipei in favor of Beijing.
1979: Afghan President Hafizullah Amin is executed by the Soviets. Babrak Karmal, a former deputy prime minister in exile in Czechoslovakia, is installed in his place.
1980: Twenty-two supplementary members are elected to Taiwan's Control Yuan from among 54 candidates by members of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, the Taipei City Council and the Kaohsiung City Council.
1987: The Taiwan Provincial Government issues its last lottery tickets.
1995: France stages the fifth in a series of nuclear weapon tests in the South Pacific.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan expresses his appreciation to Chinese-Japanese baseball star Sadaharu Oh for his active efforts after the devastating magnitude 7.3 earthquake hit Taiwan Sept. 21.
2000: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou says that the current political instability mainly results from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's failure to respect the Republic of China Constitution and its "one China" spirit.
2001: The National Taiwan Museum in Taipei represents an exhibition introducing the achievements of the late Dr. Joseph Needham (1900-1995) and the British scholar's contributions to Chinese and world civilization.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Gentlemen, why should you be concerned at your present want of official position! The world has long been without the order and justice of good government; now God is going to make use of your teacher as a tocsin to awaken the world."

DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Asia Quake's Tsunamis kill 9,000. A series of towering tidal waves triggered by a massive undersea earthquake killed more than 9000 people today in several south countries.
