DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times: Tsunamis slam South Asia Coasts. Death toll from 8.9-ma- gnitude quake tops 6,500 The most powerful earthquake in 40 years tri- ggered massive tidal waves that slammed into co- astlines across Asia on Sunday, killing more th- an 6,500 people in SrilLanka,India, Indonesia, Thailand and Malaysia.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Giant waves kill thousands in Asia.
More than 10,000 people are feared dead or missing and millions displaced as the strongest earthquake in the world in 40 years unleashed flash floods and giant waves on South and South- east Asia.
Terrifying walls of water, or tsunamis, some as high as four storeys, crashed at breakneck speed into coastal areas in Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia, Sri Lanka, India, Bangladesh, Myanmar and the Maldives on Sunday morning.
The Lianhe Zaobao:Stongest earthquake in Indonesia and giant waves on South and South-east Asia.
The world's biggest earthquake in 40 years hit south Asia and south-east Asia yesterday,unleashing a tsunami that crash into Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, Tailand, Malaysia, Maldives and Bangladesh,killing around 8,500 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO COOPERATE WITH KMT TO WORK OUT POLICY DIRECTIONS FOR ROC: SOONG

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said Monday that his party will cooperate closely with the Kuomintang (KMT) to work out feasible policy directions for the Republic of China.
The PFP chief made the comments at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport upon his return from a trip to the United States where he visited family.

According to Soong, the policy directions include maintaining the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo and pursuing peace. He also said that the Republic of China is the only option for the Taiwan people and that pursuing Taiwan independence would only lead the island toward war.

The most important thing is to push for the enactment of a cross-strait peace law and for ethnic equality in Taiwan, Soong said, adding that both the KMT and PFP are concerned about the well-being and future of the Taiwan people.

He noted that the basic policies and principles of the KMT-PFP cooperation have been set, saying that the Republic of China is the only option and that the two parties absolutely do not favor provoking the other side of the Taiwan Strait at the present time.
"We must use reform and the promise of a better future for all in order to win the confidence and trust of the people," he said.

Noting that the PFP will present clear and definite policies in order to give the Taiwan people peace of mind, Soong promised that his party will push for the enactment of a cross-strait peace law and will cooperate with the KMT in order to offer the people the best options -- namely maintaining the status quo, pushing for the opening of the "three direct links" across the strait, and rescuing Taiwan's economy.

Soong was greeted by Legislative Yuan President Wang jin-pyng, leading members of the PFP, and several of his supporters at the airport. He is scheduled to attend the funeral of former first lady Faina Chiang later in the day in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF U.S. TOURISTS TO TAIWAN EXPECTED TO HIT 400,000 FOR 2004

TEXT.P: More than 346,000 American tourists visited Taiwan in the first eleven months of this year, or an increase of 44 percent over the figure for the same period a year earlier, according to statistics released by Taiwan's representative office in the United States.

The statistics show that a total of 240,000 U.S. tourists visited Taiwan in 2003, marking a major drop of 30 percent over the previous year's level due to the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) on the island.
The fact that the number of U.S. tourists to Taiwan for the Jan.-Nov. period of this year was already over the figure for the whole of 2003 demonstrates that the shadow cast by SARS has been lifted.

As December is the peak season for Americans to travel abroad, it is expected that the total number of U.S. tourists to Taiwan for this year will reach 400,000, slightly below the target of 450,000 that had been set by the Taiwan Tourist Bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUNERAL SERVICE FOR FORMER FIRST LADY HELD

TEXT.P: People in Taiwan bid farewell Monday to former first lady Faina Chiang, who was born in Russia but dedicated most of her long life to helping Chinese people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

A formal funeral service for Faina Chiang, widow of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo, was held at Taipei Veterans General Hospital's Chieh Shou Hall, with at least 1,000 politicians and people from all walks of life paying their last respects to the beloved former first lady.

President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu attended the funeral service for Faina Chiang, who died of respiratory and cardiac failure Dec. 15 at the age of 90 according to the Chinese calendar.
President Chen issued a posthumous citation in honor of Faina Chiang, better known as Chiang Fang-liang, praising her as a "woman of talent and virtue."
Vladislav Verchenko, director of the Moscow-Taipei Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission, also attended the funeral service to pay his last respects to the former ROC first lady.

Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairmen Wang Jin-pyng, Lin Cheng-chih, P. K. Chiang and Ma Ying-jeou draped Faina Chiang's casket with the party flag, and four party elders, Lee Huan, Hau Pei-tsun, Chiu Chuang-huan and Shih Chi-yang, draped the casket with the ROC national flag in recognition of her contribution to the party and the nation.
The funeral was followed by a Christian memorial service led by Rev. Chou Lien-hua, who has been the Chiang family's pastor for decades.

At 11 a.m., Faina Chiang's casket was moved to the Keelung Municipal Crematorium. Her ashes were later taken to her husband's temporary mausoleum in Touliao, Taoyuan County. The couple's ashes will be buried together at a military cemetery next year.

Faina Chiang met her husband while he was living in the Soviet Union in the 1930s. A woman of simple tastes with a technical school education, Faina Chiang left her homeland in 1936 to accompany her husband back to mainland China. She had to adjust to joining one of mainland China's most powerful families at the time. Mainland China was ruled by her father-in-law, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, and the Kuomintang during the period.

She fled to Taiwan along with her family in 1949 after the Chinese Communists took control of the mainland. Her husband became president in 1978 and ended 38 years of martial law just months before he died in 1988. He also oversaw the island's spectacular economic development in the 1980s.

Faina Chiang avoided the spotlight and was known to be Taiwan's most low-key first lady. The couple had three sons and one daughter. The three sons have all passed away, while the daughter, Chiang Hsiao-chang, currently lives in the United States with her family.
An exhibition of photos of Faina Chiang and some of her personal effects opened at an art gallery in the KMT headquarters in Taipei Saturday.

On display are 90 rare photos featuring Faina's life in Russia, mainland China and Taiwan, a KMT spokesman said, adding that many of them have never been shown in public before. The exhibit also includes 50-plus furniture items from her residence in suburban Taipei as well as some personal effects, including clothes, handbags and jewelry.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Tsunamis Kill More Than 13,000 Across South Asia.
The toll was most devastating in Indonesia, Sri Lanka and India, where entire villages were demolished.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Putin Defends State Takeover of Yugansk.
State-owned oil major Rosneft's acquisition of the mystery buyer of Yukos' prize asset Yuganskneftegaz is legal and "perfectly normal, " President Vladimir Putin said Thursday. Putin's staunch defense of the deal came after Rosneft announced Wednesday night that it had bought 100 percent of Baikal Finance Group, the previously unknown shell company that won Sunday's disputed auction of Yuganskneftegaz with a bid of $9.37 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 33.48 points to close at 5,985.94.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 6,018.02 and hit a low of 5,973.17 during trading. A total of 2.45 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$37.74 billion (US$1.17 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up at 0.1 percent.

Six other major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down the most at 0.8 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 0.7 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.6 percent, construction issues at 0.2 percent and foodstuff issues and textile stocks both at 0.1 percent.
Plastics and chemicals shares remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 503 to 201, with 134 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January lost 16 points to close at 6,016, with 1,6581 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for February moved down 13 points to finish at 6,019, with 60 contracts traded, while March futures lost 49 points to finish at 5,988, with one contract traded. September futures moved down two points to close at 5,925, with five contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,032 for January, 6,032 for February, 6,037 for March, 6,020 for June and 5,927 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.
January TE futures moved down 0.8 points to close at 224.5, with 1,602 contracts traded, while February TE futures lost 1.1 points to finish at 223.8, with six contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

January TF futures lost two points to finish at 1,014.2, with 2,107 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved down 4.6 points to end at 1,013.2, with seven contracts traded. March TF futures gained 2.8 points to finish at 1,015, with one contract changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S MILITARY EXPANSION THREATENS REGIONAL SECURITY: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland China's military expansion has not only affected the situation in the Taiwan Strait, it has also seriously threatened the security in the Asia-Pacific region, an official in charge of mainland Chinese policy said Monday.

Chiu Tai-san, a vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), was responding to an 85-page white paper issued earlier in the day by Beijing's State Council on the Chinese military's modernization plans.

Chiu said that Chinese authorities ought to understand by now that " military expansion will not help the development of cross-strait relations, and will only instill bad feelings in the Taiwan people."
He noted that in recent years, mainland China has increased its national defense and arms procurement budgets, undermining regional security, something that South Korea and Japan have responded to.

"The international community will now wonder whether China will move...toward becoming an 'evil force,'" he said, adding that Beijing should squarely address the reaction of Taiwan and the international community regarding its actions.
Meanwhile, another MAC vice chairman also said that problems resulting from mainland China's recent policy to cool down its overheated economy have begun to emerge.

Liu Teh-hsun said that Beijing's overheated economy has been "controlled" to a certain degree through government policies, but inflationary pressures and an imbalance in supply and demand have yet to ease. Also, the unemployment rate continues to rise, the short-term credit for businesses is greatly reduced because of a tightening in the credit market, and the banks are awash with money, which he said will increase the risks of bad loans and the collapse of the financial system.

Liu said that mainland China's economic growth has relied too much on fixed investments and exports, and that if it can't effectively raise the ratio of private consumption in its gross national product, problems surrounding the overheating of its economy will still be present in the very basic structure of the economic framework.
Moreover, small- and medium-sized enterprises and farmers are the biggest victims of the policies, underscoring that fact that the gap between the rich and the poor has continued to widen, Liu said.

Liu said that since Beijing implemented its policies, two-thirds of mainland Chinese provinces still lack sufficient electricity. Energy shortages have become the biggest problem in the economic development of mainland China, and if this situation cannot be resolved, it will be difficult for mainland China to maintain its rapid economic development, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT NOT TO MENTION CHOICE OF PREMIER IN NEW YEAR'S MESSAGE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is unlikely to mention his choice for the next premier in his New Year's Day message, a Presidential Office spokesman said Monday.

Chen Wen-chung, director of the Public Affairs Department of the Presidential Office, was responding to a newspaper report that President Chen will announce his choice for the next premier in his New Year's Day message.

The report was incorrect, Chen Wen-chung said, adding that President Chen will only expound on his vision for future national development and the government's work agenda for the new year in his New Year's Day message.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun has on many occasions said he and all Cabinet members will resign en masse before the new Legislative Yuan is inaugurated on Feb. 1, 2005.

Speculation about who will be the next premier has been rife. After the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party managed to retain its slim majority party in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, senior KMT officials have claimed that the majority party in the legislature should have the right to form a new Cabinet. However, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has insisted that the right to name a premier rests with the president, not anybody else, under the existing constitutional provisions.

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. TO INCREASE COOPERATION IN E-HEALTH AND TECHNOLOGY WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The European Union has decided to send a group of information technology and e-health experts to Taiwan in April next year to explore bilateral cooperation, a spokesman for the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC) said Monday.

Under the E.U.'s Framework Programme for Research and Technological Development, its directorate general of Information Society Technologies hopes to increase contacts and understanding with Asian countries by inviting them to take part in various research and development projects, the spokesman said.

The 40-member E.U. delegation is slated to travel to Taiwan in late April and host a series of activities, including holding seminars with local counterparts and visiting the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park and the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park.
Taiwan is one of the four countries that the E. U. delegation plans to visit in line with its GAPFILL Project for the first half of 2005, in addition to Singapore, Malaysia and Thailand.

According to NSC Vice Chairman Chi Gou-chung, E. U. officials got a strong impression of the country's e-health industry's development after a local mission, jointly put together by National Taiwan University President Chen Wei-chao and medical school professors, showcased Taiwan's medical care technology at an annual exhibition, which opened Nov. 15 in The Hague.

That contact helped create an opportunity for the two sides to cooperate in related fields at a time when the E. U. is keen on developing a portable sensor that could be applied in the textile industry for broader uses in health care for babies, children, pregnant women and elderly people, he said.

E-health is defined as the use of advanced telecommunications, such as the Internet, portable and other sophisticated devices, advanced networks and new design approaches that are aimed at supporting health care, delivery and education.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING NIXES CHARTER FLIGHT SERVICE DURING CHINESE NEW YEAR: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland China is not interested in a proposed charter flight service for Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland that would operate during the Chinese New Year holidays, the head of the nation's top policy-planner for mainland Chinese affairs said Monday.
Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks on the sidelines of a seminar on mainland China's finances.

Wu noted that his council and other related government agencies had prepared for the charter flight service for the Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 9, 2005, and that they were hoping that a good time for both sides to discuss the matter would have been after the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

But information received by the MAC shows that Beijing will not consult with Taiwan on the issue or any others, and that Chinese officials even said that "they have no interest" in the charter flight service.

Wu said earlier that Beijing was lukewarm to the idea of charter flights, and that if cross-strait consultations became too difficult, Taiwan would have been willing to adopt the 2003 model -- meaning that six Taiwan air carriers would make the one-way service via a third place to pick up the Taiwan businessmen in the mainland for the Chinese New Year holidays.

The cross-strait charter flight service was inaugurated in 2003 on a trial basis, but the service was not continued during Chinese New Year holidays in 2004 because both sides failed to consult each other on Beijing's request for two-way flight services without stopping in a third place.

Meanwhile, officials from the government and civic groups have urged leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to promote the charter flight service for the welfare of the people and use it to break the cross-strait impasse.

They made the appeal in a public hearing sponsored by the Council for Industrial and Commercial Development (CICD) and the Friends of Hong Kong and Macau Association. Participants included Fu Don-cheng, director of MAC's Department of Economic Affairs, CICD President Kuo Tai-chiang, association Secretary-General Chang Wu-ueh, and representatives from six Taiwan air carriers.

Fu noted that the charter flight service would have required effort and goodwill from both sides, while Kuo said despite both sides being pessimistic about the flight service because of political factors, the service would have been crucial to cross-strait peace and the wellbeing of the people, and that even the slimmest hope must be maintained regarding the issue.
Chang noted that Beijing is now reviewing its "anti-secession law, " which he said will seriously affect cross-strait relations and deepen the differences between the two sides.
"Therefore, there are more reasons for both sides to cooperate to promote this charter flight service to resolve cross-strait misunderstanding and differences," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES GAMBIAN FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met with visiting Gambian Foreign Minister Sidi Morro Sanneh in the Presidential Office Monday.
Noting that Taiwan has just entered into a five-year cooperation agreement with Gambia, Chen said this will help promote bilateral exchanges.
Chen thanked Gambia for its support for Taiwan in its bid to join the United Nations and the World Health Organization, and extended an invitation to Gambian President Yahya Jammeh to visit Taiwan.
Sanneh relayed Jammeh's greetings to Chen and reconfirmed Gambia's support for Taiwan's access to international organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CHAIRMAN RESIGNS

TEXT.P: The chairman of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) resigned Monday to assume responsibility for the pro-independence party's setback in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, according to TSU officials.

The TSU Central Executive Committee approved Huang's resignation at a meeting held at the party's headquarters and appointed Huang Chung-yuan, convener of TSU legislative caucus, to serve as the party's acting chairman, the officials said.

Huang Chu-wen said upon leaving the party's headquarters that TSU will go on with its ideals to change the country's name and promote a constitutional re-engineering project, while "maintaining the stability of Taiwan's political situation."
The TSU managed to obtain only 12 legislative seats -- seven regional, four at-large and one overseas -- one fewer than in the previous legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO RECONSIDER ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The nation's top mainland China policy charter urged Beijing Monday to consider the impact on cross-Taiwan Strait relations of its proposed anti-secession law.

Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks amid reports that Beijing's National People's Congress (NPC) Standing Committee agreed Sunday to submit the proposed law to the full NPC for consideration next March.

Wu said that the MAC is trying to learn more about the details of the draft law, but he stressed that the proposed law is a provocation to Taiwan and a serious unilateral violation of the cross-strait status quo.
Nearly 80 percent of Taiwan's people are opposed to the proposed law, Wu claimed, which shows that the mainland's attempts to lure Taiwan people has in fact made them drift further away.
At a reception for foreign media, Wu also urged the international community to "block" the mainland from enacting the anti-secession law.
According to Wu, the international community will respond only after it sees the contents of the proposed law, but this, he said, "will be too late" as the law by that time will have been promulgated

He claimed that the international community is ignoring the mainland's hostility toward Taiwan, which he said seems to send a message to Beijing that it "can do whatever it wants with Taiwan, " including enacting a law that would be used as a legal basis for using force against Taiwan.

He noted that since 1949, the Republic of China and the People's Republic of China have been two separate independent entities that have no jurisdiction over each other. This is the cross-strait status quo, Wu said. Peaceful co-existence should be the common goal of both sides, he went on, adding that one side should not use force against the other or violate the status quo without prior peaceful consultations.
Through the proposed law, Wu said, Beijing has defined the cross-strait status as "unification" and that it has jurisdiction over Taiwan, which is a unilateral change of the status quo.

While Beijing returns Taipei's goodwill with intimidation, squeezes Taiwan's maneuvering space in the international community and continues to impose its "one China" principle, the international community has "remained silent," according to Wu.

Although Beijing's missile and submarine deployments have posed a serious threat to regional peace and stability, Wu said the international community has yet to express worry about its military expansion, nor has it opposed the anti-secession law.

He said Taiwan is willing to consult with Beijing on any issues, including political issues, so as to mitigate cross-strait tension, but until that time, the mainland must terminate and forego its anti-secession law.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL BANK MAY NOT RAISE RATES AS PRESSURE EASES: TIER

TEXT.P: The central bank may not raise key interest rates in a forthcoming meeting, as inflationary pressure has largely eased due to various factors at home and abroad, Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) President Wu Rong-i said Monday.
Wu made the forecast in a news conference, citing reasons such as falling international prices of crude oil, a rising New Taiwan dollar and growth rate drops in salaries.

The various elements have brought down inflationary pressure, greatly reducing the chances of the Central Bank of China (CBC) deciding to hike its key interest rates in the meeting scheduled for Thursday, despite an obvious rate gap with the United States, Wu said.

The U.S. Federal Reserve already increased key interest rates five times this year since June, with its latest hike Dec. 15. However, the CBC only lifted its interest rates once -- by a quarter percentage point -- in late September.

The TIER president forecast that the new Taiwan dollar will continue to appreciate on the grounds that it is widely assumed that mainland China's renminbi will pick up in value next year, prompting the local currency to gain in value as well.

The new Taiwan dollar is expected to remain at a relatively strong level for some time, as the CBC is unlikely to allow the local unit to fluctuate sharply, in order to secure continued economic development, he said.

Meanwhile, a monthly survey conducted by the TIER on the domestic business climate shows that most Taiwan enterprises are cautiously optimistic about their business conditions for the months ahead, despite the fact that the index for November fell to 102.58 points from October's 104.2 points -- the fourth decrease in a row.
It finds that 20.2 percent of the Taiwan companies polled in November felt positive about their business conditions in the first half of next year -- an increase from 11.7 percent in October.

Some 61.3 percent thought their businesses would remain stable, a drop from 65.7 percent, while the percentage of those that foresaw worsening business fell to 18.5 percent from 22.6 percent, the poll finds. It also indicates that car accessories, insurance, bicycle manufacturing, retail sales, steel and basic metal are promising businesses in the coming months.

TIER analysts attributed the optimistic sentiments to the government's "10 New Major Construction Projects" plan that will be launched next year with budget allocations approved recently by the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TAKES ACTION TO HELP EARTHQUAKE, TSUNAMI VICTIMS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian sent his condolences to the Asian countries hit by an earthquake and tsunamis Sunday that killed thousands of people in the largest regional disaster in a century, a spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Monday.

Michel Lu also noted that the MOFA has set up a taskforce, with Foreign Minister Tan Sun Chen serving as convener, to deal with Taiwan's relief to the affected countries, including Indonesia, Thailand and Sri Lanka, while opening a telephone hotline (0912-581-007) to accept donations from the public.
The 9.0-magnitude earthquake rocked Indonesia Sunday and triggered massive tidal waves that swept across the Indian Ocean, affecting areas as far away as Somalia on Africa's eastern coast.
The natural disaster hit at least nine countries -- Indonesia, India, Thailand, Malaysia, Sri Lanka, Maldives, Myanmar, Somalia and Bangladesh.

The MOFA official pointed out that his ministry has mapped out a preliminary relief plan, with US$100,000 cash aid to Indonesia, as well as US$50,000 for each of the three worst-hit countries -- Thailand, India and Sri Lanka.

Due to the fact that it normally takes two to three weeks to open an official account for relief funds, a situation that will slow down Taiwan's aid to the affected countries, the government might take the same action as that in aid to Iraqi war refugees last year -- having the MOFA chief launch a public activity aimed at calling for donations to non-governmental organizations (NGOs) in Taiwan that are able to transfer the relief to the affected countries in the shortest possible time, according to the MOFA spokesman.
Lu said the MOFA is scheduled to open a meeting with representatives of the country's nearly 20 NGO groups Tuesday to discuss the best ways to provide humanitarian aid to the affected countries.

Meanwhile, the MOFA has listed the Thai island of Phuket, Sri Lanka, the Maldives, and the Malaysian islands of Penang and Langkawi as yellow-alert zones for tourism because of the utter devastation wrought by the tsunami, while the whole of Indonesia has been put on the yellow list due to a potential danger of terrorist attack, according to the MOFA.

The MOFA reminded people who want to travel to those regions to check relevant information and warnings on the MOFA Bureau of Consular Affairs' Web site before setting off, and to pay more attention to their safety during their visits.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES CIVIL SERVANTS TO BE POLITICALLY NEUTRAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the country's civil servants Monday to be detached from politics, saying that their political neutrality is an inherent part of democracy.

Receiving a group of civil servants who made distinguished contributions in the last year, the president said his administration insists on ridding the government of the apparatus of any political parties.
Furthermore, Chen said, government employees are not allowed to abuse their office to campaign for any policial parties.
The president also called on the country's civil servants to embrace his administration's plan to reorganize the Executive Yuan, saying that their support is vital to the success of the plan.

According to the Basic Organic Law for the Central Government, passed by the Legislative Yuan in June, the Executive Yuan's eight ministries and 27 councils, commissions and administrations will be converted into 13 ministries, four commissions and five independent agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: 35 TAIWAN FISHING VESSELS CAST ASHORE ON PHUKET

TEXT.P: Thirty-five Taiwan fishing boats were beached on the Thai resort island of Phuket by tsunamis unleashed by a powerful earthquake off the Indonesian island of Sumatra Sunday, the Council of Agriculture's Fishery Administration said Monday.

There were about 60 Taiwan crew members and 120 to 200 foreign fishery workers aboard the grounded vessels, but no major casualties were reported, fishery officials said, adding that only a few of them sustained minor injuries.

More than 20,000 people were reported dead around southern Asia and as far away as Somalia on Africa's eastern coast, most killed by massive tidal waves that smashed coastlines after a magnitude 9.0 earthquake off the northern tip of Sumatra Sunday, followed by aftershocks in the region.

According to the officials, about 150 Taiwan fishing boats usually operate in the areas that were swamped by the tidal waves. They usually make port calls at Phuket, Malaysia's Penang, Sri Lanka's Colombo and the Indonesian resort island of Bali.

Because of often inconvenient communication services in those regions, the officials said, they could only get information through Taiwan's representative offices in those countries and local agents of Taiwan fishing companies.

To the best of their knowledge, the officials said, Taiwan fishing boats operating in waters off Colombo, Bali and Penang have not been affected by the devastating tsunami disaster. Only 35 Taiwan fishing boats operating in the waters around Phuket were beached and some of their fishing gear damaged. Several of the ships have already resumed operations after minor repairs, the officials said, adding that property and catch losses have not yet been estimated.
The officials said they will keep in contact with Taiwan fishing boats operating in those areas through local fishery radio stations in order to offer timely assistance.
Meanwhile, a six-member advance relief team organized by the Taipei city government will leave for the Indonesian city of Medan Tuesday on their way to the quake-stricken northern tip of Sumatra.
A municipal official said the team will bring with it 3 tons of relief goods, including food, tents and medicine to help the survivors.
The six-member team will be headed by Tsai Chia-lung, deputy chief of the municipal Fire Department's international rescue division.
A 35-member rescue team organized by the nation's post-disaster relief association will also leave for Phuket Tuesday for search and rescue missions.

Also on Monday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) listed Phuket, Sri Lanka, the Maldives and Penang as "yellow"-travel alert zones, and urged people intending to visit those regions to be careful. The whole of Indonesia has been listed as a "yellow"-travel alert area due to potential terrorist attack threats.
An infectious disease expert also advised local people to refrain from making non-essential visits to those areas for the time being because epidemics could break out in flooded areas.

Meanwhile, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said the ROC government will offer US$100,000 in relief aid to Indonesia and US$50,000 to each of the three other worst-hit countries -- Thailand, India and Sri Lanka.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT LEAVES FOR SIGHTSEEING VISIT TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui left for Japan Monday for a sightseeing trip.

Lee, accompanied by his wife, doctor and other friends and relatives, was seen off on his seven-day trip by Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen, former Republic of China representative to Japan Hsu Shui-teh, incumbent ROC Representative to Japan Koh Se-kai, ruling Democratic Progressive Party Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung and several friends.
Lee appeared in good spirits as he shook hands with each of the wellwishers.

According to Lee's office, he will visit Nagoya, Kanezawa, Kyoto and Ozu before returning to Taiwan Jan. 2. He also plans to visit Kyoto University to pay a visit to his mentor, 98-year-old Sukekata Kashiwa.
Lee's last visit to Japan was in 2001 when he traveled there to receive treatment for a heart problem.

Chang Chun-hsiung said that Lee's trip is mainly for tourism and that there is no need for mainland China to interfere with the trip. Even though he is no longer a public official, Beijing sees Lee as an agitator for Taiwan's tilt toward independence.
Chang said that Taiwan's people need dignity in the international community and freedom of movement, and he expressed the hope that Beijing will understand this.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 27 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui arrived at Japan's Nagoya airport Monday to the warm welcome of 500 Japanese friends and Taiwanese residing in Japan who braved 5 degree Celsius temperatures to greet him and hear him say "thank you" in Taiwanese.
Lee, accompanied by his wife, friends and relatives, as well as his doctor, was accorded VIP treatment for speedy customs clearance and left the airport for a waiting limousine.
Those waiting to greet him waved Japanese and ROC national flags, as well as unfurling banners and singing songs to welcome the former ROC president.

The Japanese government had asked the media to exercise self-restraint during Lee's visit, but the move only drew more media attention. More than 100 reporters and photographers from Taiwan and Japan were at the airport, as well as a heavy police and security presence.
Lee is scheduled to visit scenic spots in Kanezawa, Kyoto and Osaka during his seven-day tour before returning to Taiwan Jan. 2.
His last visit to Japan in 2001 was to seek a treatment for a heart condition.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO ADDRESS PERSONNEL RESHUFFLE ISSUE WITH NEW THINKING: DPP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will address personnel reshuffle issues involving the premiership, legislative speakership and chairmanship of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) with "brand new thinking, " a party heavyweight said Monday.
DPP acting Chairman Ker Chien-ming, who concurrently serves as the top DPP legislative whip, was responding to media speculation that Premier Yu Shyi-kun is likely to vie for the DPP chairmanship.

Ker said what is certain at the moment is that DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung will not vie for the post left vacant by Chen, who resigned as DPP chairman earlier this month to assume responsibility for the party's failure to reach its target of winning a majority in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
Ker said Chen will employ a "brand new angle" in tackling personnel reshuffle issues, including the DPP chairman and premier as well as the Legislative Yuan president and vice president.

Yu has on many occasions said he and all Cabinet members will resign en masse according to protocol before the new legislature is inaugurated Feb. 1, and speculation about who will be the new premier has been rife.

DPP members will elect their new party chairman Jan. 30 and candidacy registration began Monday. Ker said the Cabinet reshuffle situation might become a bit clearer after DPP chairman candidacy registration ends Dec. 31.

Meanwhile, Ker said Chen is also making an overall review of relations between the opposition and ruling camps, Taiwan-U.S. relations and relations across the Taiwan Strait, and will work out new strategies with new vision.
He also urged major factions within the DPP to stop squabbling over the legislative election shambles. As the ruling party, he said, the DPP should project a positive image of intraparty unity.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY STABLE, FLASHES GREEN LIGHT FOR NOVEMBER: CEPD

TEXT.P: The Taiwan economy remained stable in November compared to October, flashing a green light according to a government rating system, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported Monday.
In the five-color rating scheme designed by the CEPD, red means an overheated economy, yellow-red indicates a heating up economy, yellow-blue represents sluggishness and blue points to recession.

Meanwhile, the composite index for November stood at 29 points -- the same level as the previous month, according to the CEPD. The leading index and the current indexes came to 105.2 and 109.8, marking falls of 1.5 percent and 0.3 percent month-to-month, respectively.

Hu Chung-ying, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, said that five leading elements -- consumer product prices, interest rates, oil prices, staple commodity prices and Taiwan's relations with mainland China -- will significantly influence the domestic economy in the coming year.
CEPD officials forecast that international oil prices should remain between US$40 and US$45 per barrel next year. A price below US$40 a barrel will not be possible, they claimed.

As the world economy has widely been forecast to slow down in 2005, coupled with possible effects related to the course of the U.S. dollar and the mainland efforts to cool its overheated economy, most Taiwan companies are reserved about their business conditions in the three months to come, according to the results of a CEPD survey carried out in November.
Some 12 percent of the companies interviewed last month thought their operations would improve over the next three months, down from 13 percent in October.

A drop from 72 percent to 67 percent expected their business to remain regular, while a fall from 21 percent to 15 percent -- the largest decrease since April 2003 -- forecast a decline in their business, the survey discovered.

CEPD officials said that the domestic economy will continue to develop soundly, basing their argument on the fact that the jobless rate has declined for three consecutive months and that private-sector investment continues to grow, in addition to the much-expected massive momentum to be produced by the government's "10 New Major Construction Projects" plan.
Taiwan's jobless rate stood at 4.14 percent for November -- a new low since May 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: RENMINBI FORBIDDEN IN TAIWAN: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Mainland China's currency, the renminbi, cannot be used in Taiwan before a currency clearance mechanism has been put in place between Taiwan and the mainland, a mainland affairs official said Monday.

Johannson Liu, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, said the renminbi cannot be sold, purchased, exchanged or used as a form of payment, despite the close business exchanges between Taiwan and the mainland.
Citing the nation's laws, Liu said Taiwan people can bring in no more than 6,000 renminbi (US$724) and that any more than that will be confiscated.
Liu said his office has asked the customs authorities to enforce the regulation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD BLAMES MAINLAND CHINA FOR ALIENATING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Mainland China will draw fire from around the world and aggravate Taiwan's hostility if it resorts to force instead of peaceful means to solve its disputes with Taiwan, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Monday.

In a comment on Beijing's Defense White Paper in which the mainland vows to crack down on Taiwan independence by whatever means necessary, Wu said Beijing has exposed its naivety by believing it can stop Taiwan from moving toward independence with military intimidation.

The mainland is flying in the face of the civilized world by insisting upon keeping the option of force to iron out disputes in a world that, according to Wu, stresses peaceful dialogue as the only means of settling disputes.

He dismissed Beijing's claims in the white paper that it is disarming, claiming that the mainland is simply shifting its resources to develop missiles and submarines that pose a serious threat to its neighbors.

Wu said Beijing has bent over backward to set back its relations with Taiwan ever after President Chen Shui-bian was sworn in for his second term May 20, including spurning an olive branch from Chen in his double-ten National Day speech.
In a related development Monday, the Ministry of National Defense reserved its comment on Beijing's defense white paper.
Vice Defense Minister Huo Shou-yeh said his ministry has not yet read the white paper but added that he will not be surprised if it shows that Beijing is getting tough with Taiwan.

However, Huo said, his ministry will keep trying to build a military mutual-trust mechanism with Beijing which, according to Beijing's white paper, is possible only if Taiwan forsakes any attempts toward independence and acknowledges itself to be a part of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TO WORK WITH TAIWAN TO RESOLVE CODDLING MOTH CONCERNS

TEXT.P: The United States will work with Taiwan to resolve coddling moth concerns with regard to apples imported from the United States, the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said in a press release Monday.

The AIT was responding to a temporary import ban imposed by the Council of Agriculture (COA) on apples from the United States Dec. 21 after discovering a coddling moth larvae in a shipment of apples from Oregon.

The AIT said that the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), U.S. apple exporters and itself are all taking the matter extremely seriously and appreciate Taiwan's cooperative approach to resolving quarantine issues.

The goal of both the USDA Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) and the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine (BAPHIQ) is to prevent the introduction of coddling moths to Taiwan from the United States, according to the press release.
As a result of the recent detection, APHIS will begin an investigation of the most recent coddling moth discovery immediately, it continued.
COA officials said that the import ban will be lifted only after the United States conducts a thorough inspection and makes necessary improvements that are endorsed by the COA's BAPHIQ.

Quarantine officials discovered coddling moth larvae in apple shipments from the United States Sept. 1, Oct. 7 and Oct. 14, and warned the U.S. authorities that they would have to make improvement in efforts to prevent the dangerous pest from making its way into apples destined for export.

However, quarantine officials discovered another coddling moth larvae in a apple shipment from Oregon Dec. 20. The insect was immediately sent to National Chunghsing University for DNA testing that confirmed the insect species.

According to a Taiwan-U.S. pact signed in August 2003 concerning working procedures for U.S. apple exports to Taiwan, the COA can suspend imports if the United States fails twice to improve the contamination situation.

Taiwan discovered coddling moth larvae in a shipment of U.S. apples for the first time in 1992 and imposed a temporary ban at that time. Imports resumed only after quarantine officials confirmed that the United States had made necessary improvements.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF AMERICAN TOURISTS TO TAIWAN SHARPLY INCREASES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 26 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: A total of 346,000 American tourists visited Taiwan in the first 11 months of this year, up 44 percent from the previous year's level, according to statistics compiled by Taiwan's representative office in the United States.

The Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office (TECRO) in Washington, D.C. predicted that the number of American tourist arrivals to Taiwan will top the 400,000 mark for the whole of this year based on a consideration that December is a peak season for Americans to make overseas trips.

TECRO officials said that the number of American tourist arrivals to Taiwan has been back to the level of 2002 from a sharp drop in the previous year due to the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).
The figure registered this year shows that American tourists' fear of SARS has disappeared, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE DEEDS BELIE ITS DEFENSE CLAIMS: EXECUTIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: Mainland China's buildup of military forces belies its claims that its defense is focused on protecting its security, an Executive Yuan spokesman said Monday.

In a response to Beijing's 2004 defense white paper issued in Beijing earlier that day, Chen Chi-mai said Beijing's sharp increase in military spending every year and its deployment of missiles targeting Taiwan give the lie to its claims that its defense policy is aimed at protecting its territory.

Without revealing his sources, Chen said the mainland's defense budget is growing by double digits every year and has hit 211.7 billion renminbi (US$25.57 billion) this year, which represents an increase of 12.5 percent over the previous year and next only to the United States and Russia.
He claimed that the mainland has deployed 600 missiles and 730 bombers within range of Taiwan, and the range of its long-distance missiles cover Japan, South Korea and U.S. bases in Asia.
Chen said Beijing's aggressive military buildup has tipped the military balance across the Taiwan Strait in its favor and has effectively destroyed the peace between Taiwan and the mainland.
In order to address the military imbalance, Chen called on the Taiwan people to support the government's plan to purchase US$18.23 billion-worth of arms from the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 28, or the 17th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1836: Spain recognizes Mexico's independence.
1856: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, American statesman and Democratic president (1913-21), is born.
1881: China's first telegraph line linking Tientsin and Shanghai is made available for public use.
1908: The most violent earthquake ever recorded in Europe destroys the city of Messina in Sicily, killing more than half of its 150,000 inhabitants and causing a giant tidal wave.
1912: City-run streetcars in San Francisco, California, begin operating.
1919: Feng Kuo-chang, a warlord who led the Chihli faction of the powerful Peiyang army during the first decade of the Republic of China, dies in Peking (Beijing) at the age of 62.
1923: Alexandre Gustave Eiffel, the French engineer who designed the 300-meter-high Eiffel Tower for the Paris Exhibition of 1889, dies at the age of 91.
1931: The ROC government is reformed, with Lin Sen made chairman.
1945: The Big Three Foreign Ministers' Conference in Moscow announces agreements on the establishment of a Commission and Allied Council for Japan, the ultimate establishment of a free Korea, and the withdrawal of Soviet and U.S. troops from China.
1950: Mainland Chinese troops cross the 38th parallel in Korea.
1962: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs declares that the border agreements signed between the Beijing regime and Outer Mongolia and Pakistan are illegal and non-binding for the Republic of China.
1966: Mainland China detonates its fifth atomic bomb.
1968: The ROC opens a telecommunications satellite earth station on Yangmingshan.
1971: Grand Justice Tien Chun-chin is appointed as president of the ROC's Judicial Yuan.
1972: The Republic of China's Embassy in Tokyo and the consulates-general in Osaka, Yokohama and Fukuoka are formally closed.
1974: The Republic of China-Bahamas Cultural and Economic Association is inaugurated in Taipei.
1974: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with Gambia following the latter's recognition of the Peiping (Beijing) regime.
1976: The millionth visitor of the year to the Republic of China, Wilhelm Mulmann, professor of sociology and anthropology at the University of Heidleberg, Germany, and his wife are welcomed by officials of the Tourism Bureau.
1976: Education Minister Y.S. Tsiang presents a gold medal and citation to Yen Tjing-ling, board chairman of the Yue Loong Motors Co. Ltd., for his contribution to an industrial research center at National Taiwan University.
1987: The Development Bank of Shenzhen, the first private share-holding bank on the Chinese mainland, is inaugurated.
1988: The first instance of a baby born with Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) in Taiwan is recorded.
1993: A plane belonging to mainland China's Fujian Airlines is hijacked to Taiwan by Luo Chang-hua and his wife Wang Yu-ying in the 10th hijacking of the year.
1995: In Beijing, judges reject an appeal by dissident Wei Jingsheng, upholding his 14-year sentence on charges of trying to overthrow the Beijing government.
1995: Beijing names the committee responsible for steering Hong Kong through its transition from British colony to Chinese Special Administration Region in 1997.
1999: Taiwan changes the name of its representative office in Macau from Taipei Economic and Cultural Office to Taipei Economic and Cultural Center, Macau.
2000: The Formosa Plastics Group presents its first sedan -- the Formosa Magnus 2.0 -- which was manufactured via technical cooperation with South Korea's Daewoo Group.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Possession of power without generosity; courtesy without seriousness; mourning without grief -- I have no desire to look at such a state of things."

DOC.HEADLINE: THIS IS NOT A TIME TO ESCALATE TENSION IN THE TAIWAN STRAIT: POWELL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 27 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell said Monday that this is not a time to escalate tension in the Taiwan Straits.
Powell made the comments while responding to reporters' questions at a press conference regarding China's just-released defense white paper and its proposed anti-secession law.

Asked whether he is worried that the defense white paper, which emphasizes the possibility of the use of force against Taiwan, and the anti-secession legislation could have a negative effect on the situation in the Taiwan Strait, Powell said: "I'm aware that there is modernization taking place in the Chinese armed forces, and we are monitoring that closely, and we're in conversations with our Chinese colleagues about it."

"So I don't see reason for immediate concern at the moment. I think everybody realizes that this is not the time to escalate tension in the straits. And we hope that that will continue to be the case," he further said.
The secretary also reiterated that the United States is still committed to its one-China policy.
"It rests on the three communiques and our obligations under the Taiwan Relations Act. And we have always encouraged both parties to find ways to reach out to one another, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RICE MAKES INROADS INTO JAPAM

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture Chairman Lee Chin-lung said Tuesday he takes pride in seeing Taiwan-grown rice make successful inroads into Japan.
Lee made the remarks while presiding over a ceremony at Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan marking the delivery of 90 tons of "Fuli" rice grown in the eastern county of Hualien to Japan.
Noting that Japan has imposed extremely stringent standards in rice quality examination, Lee said the export of Fuli rice to Japan is a mark of pride for Taiwan.

It was the second shipment of Fuli rice to Japan, following an initial shipment of 18 tons in October of this year. With the October shipment receiving an enthusiastic response from Japanese consumers, Lee said, Japanese importers placed an additional order for 90 tons of Fuli rice. Lee said the export volume is expected to reach 300 tons next year.

Taiwan last exported rice to Japan in 1971. The resumption of rice exports to Japan indicates that the quality of locally grown rice has received foreign recognition and that the government's response measures to cope with the impact of Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization have been appropriate, Lee said.
The Fuli rice was grown in the unpolluted upper stretch of the Hsiukuluan Creek in Hualien with organic farming methods, Lee explained, adding that the rice has a wonderful taste and texture.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS MAINLAND CHINA'S MILITARY FOCUS: DEFENSE MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan is the prime motivator behind the military buildup in mainland China, an official of the Ministry of National Defense maintained Tuesday.

Wang Shih-chien, deputy director of the information center under the defense ministry's Office of the Deputy Chief of General Staff for Intelligence, was responding to questions about an annual defense policy report released by mainland China Monday.

Mainland China is increasing its efforts to modernize its military to better deal with threats of independence from Taiwan and because of ever-changing global situations, according to the white paper.

Wang noted that the 2004 white paper produced by the Chinese Defense Ministry is basically the same as in previous years; however, mainland China this year is emphasizing the buildup of its amphibious forces, the ability of its air force to have advanced defensive and offensive capabilities, and enhancing its artillery's ability to respond quickly to events as they happen.
"One can see from its [the white paper's] contents that the buildup is aimed at us," Wang said.

Mainland China's national defense budget expenditures have increased every year at a double-digit rate, he said, adding that the report only listed the budgets that Beijing believes ought to be made public. The paper also compared mainland China's national defense budget with those of the United States, Japan and Great Britain.
However, Wang said, the actual figure for mainland China's defense budgets should be three or four times that of the amount published.

The main aim of the paper, according to Wang, is to assuage concerns that mainland China is a global threat and to assure the world that it is only following the path of peace as a nation on the rise.
Wang said that Taiwan's military buildup aims at achieving effective deterrence and defense, and its arms purchases are based on defense purposes only.

Mainland China's rise in presence and power is the main threat to Asia-Pacific regional security, he said, urging the establishment of confidence-building mechanisms between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to safeguard stability and peace.

Faced with mainland China's continued military expansion, he also urged the public to support the government's proposed arms purchase of eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries from the United States to safeguard the nation's security.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 14.63 points to close at 6,000.57.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 5,980.13 and hit a high of 6,020.59 during trading. A total of 2.14 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$37.05 billion (US$1.15 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks, plastics and chemicals shares and machinery and electronics shares all moving up the most at 0.4 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 0.2 percent and paper and pulp issues at 0.1 percent.
Three other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down at 0.3 percent and textile stocks and banking and financial shares both losing 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 376 to 257, with 233 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January gained four points to close at 6,020, with 13,824 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February moved up two points to finish at 6,021, with 39 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,016 for January, 6,019 for February, 6,011 for March, 6,004 for June and 5,912 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
January TE futures moved up 0.8 points to close at 225.3, with 1,309 contracts traded, while February TE futures lost 0.4 points to finish at 224.65, with eight contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March, June or September.
January TF futures remained unchanged at 1,014.2, with 1,298 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures remained unchanged at 1,015, with nine contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March, June or September.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTRY RULES FOR PARTICIPANTS OF INTERNATIONAL MEETINGS TO BE EASED

TEXT.P: Taiwan will ease entry regulations for those people who come to Taiwan to attend international exhibitions or meetings, the Ministry of Economic Affairs reported Tuesday.
Economics ministry officials made the report during a floor meeting of the Executive Yuan.

The officials said that those not from mainland China coming to Taiwan for international meetings or exhibitions can apply for landing visas seven days before arriving in Taiwan, while mainland Chinese will be handled on a case by case basis with the economics ministry coordinating with the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the Ministry of the Interior.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun, after listening to the report by economics ministry officials, said the measure will help Taiwan develop its service industry for international conferences and exhibitions.

To ensure national security and social order, the economics ministry must work out operational procedures with the MAC, the interior ministry, the foreign ministry as well as other government agencies by the end of January, Yu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT MEETS WITH JAPANESE VISITORS AT HOTEL IN NAGOYA
DOC.DATELINE: Nagoya, Dec. 27 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui received Japanese visitors Tuesday, including political commentator Ryoko Sakurai, at his hotel during a sightseeing trip to the central Japanese city of Nagoya.

An official of the Nagoya Marriott Associa Hotel said that Lee began to meet with visitors after breakfast. He also noted that the hotel prepared Japanese dishes for dinner last night and breakfast for the former president, who is fond of Japanese cuisine.
No official visitors were among those who called on Lee at his hotel suite Tuesday morning, according to well-informed sources.

Meanwhile, Lee's granddaughter, Lee Kun-yi, and her mother, Chang Yue-yun, who are accompanying Lee and his wife on the seven-day private visit to Japan, shopped at the Takashimaya department store attached to the hotel Tuesday morning.
The Lee family is scheduled to tour Nagoya Castle, the Takugawa Art Museum and other scenic spots in Nagoya later in the day.
Lee and his family will also go to Kanazawa, Kyoto and Osaka before returning to Taiwan Jan. 2. Lee last visited Japan to undergo treatment for a heart condition in 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE VERSIONS OF DRAFT BILLS CONCERNING PARTY ASSETS PUT ON AGENDA

TEXT.P: Three versions of draft bills concerning party assets were put on the legislative agenda Tuesday for discussion in Friday's floor meeting.

The Kuomintang (KMT) tried in vain to block the version by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party -- a draft bill to examine and dispose of assets obtained by political parties and their subsidiary organizations -- and the one offered by its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, on ill-gotten assets of civic groups.
The versions by the DPP, the TSU, and the People First Party (PFP) followed a discussion in the Legislative Yuan on a political party draft bill proposed by the KMT earlier in the day.

However, the ruling and opposition parties could not agree on the draft bill, so Chiang Ping-kun, vice speaker of the legislature, who was presiding over the meeting, ruled that the draft bill be shelved until further consultations among the various political parties.

Faced with dogged controversy over its many party assets, the KMT proposed a draft bill that stipulates that sources of income for political parties must be transparent, restricts political parties from running businesses and regulates the scope of party assets.
Nevertheless, the DPP said the KMT's bill fails to address the use of party assets in the past and whether these assets can be recovered, and proposed its own draft bill.

PFP Legislator Sun Ta-chien said the PFP's draft bill aims to serve as a "reminder, " meaning that after the "pan-blue alliance" managed to maintain its majority in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, it should live up to expectations by the public for reforms regarding KMT party assets.

Sun said that the PFP's version of the draft bill on the examination and disposal of party assets will be a "reminder of good intentions, " adding that there will be little time for it to be enacted into law before this legislative session ends in late January.

Chen Chien-ming, TSU caucus whip in the legislature, said that the most troublesome part of the KMT's political party draft bill is the section that states that "a party should not hold more than 20 percent of shares in a business," and that before the bill is enacted into law, parties must seek to reduce their shares to less than 20 percent in two years.
Chen criticized the section as trying to give the KMT a legal framework for selling off its ill-gotten assets.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MEDICAL GROUP TO GO TO SRI LANKA TO PROVIDE ASSISTANCE

TEXT.P: A medical group in Taiwan will leave for Sri Lanka Wednesday, one of the countries hardest hit by the catastrophic tsunamis on Sunday, to provide medical service.
Liu Chi-chun, president of Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps, said the group will assess the damage and if needed, will arrange more groups to go there.

Taiwan Root has been to Sri Lanka three times for medical assistance, and it last returned from the country in late November. This time it will travel to Batticaloa and Pottubil in southern Sri Lanka.
The tsunamis has taken a heavy toll on the nation, with a jail in Galle City being flattened by the tidal waves and half of the inmates drowned.
Liu said that the group will carry with them related medical equipment and pharmaceuticals, and that medical services will focus on surgical assistance and the prevention of infectious diseases.
Latest information indicates that more than 12,000 people were killed in Sri Lanka and more than a million people were left homeless.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO COMMENT FROM MOFA ON REPORTS ABOUT VISIT BY SECRET U.S. ENVOY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) declined to comment Tuesday on media reports that the United States has recently sent a special envoy to Taipei to meet with President Chen Shui-bian.

Speaking at a regular news conference, Victor J. Chin, director of the MOFA's North American Affairs Department, said there have been close communication channels between Taiwan and the United States and that the two sides may also send special envoys from time to time to address matters of mutual concern under certain extraordinary circumstances.
While some of those exchanges could be made public, several other engagements could not be revealed due to the terms of a Taiwan-U.S. tacit understanding, Chin said.

As an example, he noted that the United States publicly sent Congressman Jim Leech to attend the May 20 inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian, while other engagements have been kept confidential. Consequently, Chin said, the Foreign Ministry must refrain from making any public comments on topics falling within that category.

According to a newspaper report, the Bush administration sent an "important representative" to Taipei a few days before Christmas to meet with Chen. During their meeting, the report quoted unidentified sources as saying that the envoy had assured Chen that the U.S. stance and attitude toward relations with Taiwan will remain unchanged.

The report further said the envoy was positive toward Chen's major policy statements outlined in his May 20 inauguration speech and that the two sides had discussed Beijing's plan to enact a so-called anti-secession law.

At Tuesday's news conference, Chin said that as the United States is still on Christmas holiday, it may be some time before the Bush administration comes up with a comprehensive response to the anti-secession legislation.

Nevertheless, he acknowledged that U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell said at a Monday news conference on the recent earthquake and tsunami disasters in South Asia that this is not the time to escalate tension in the Taiwan Strait.
Powell made the comments while responding to reporters' questions regarding mainland China's just-released defense white paper and its proposed anti-secession law.

Asked whether he is worried that the defense white paper, which emphasizes the possibility of the use of force against Taiwan, and the anti-secession legislation, could have a negative effect on the situation in the Taiwan Strait, Powell said: "I'm aware that there is modernization taking place in the Chinese armed forces, and we are monitoring that closely... I think everybody realizes that this is not the time to escalate tension in the straits."

Chin said the United States has consistently opposed any move that could lead to changes to the Taiwan Strait status quo. In other words, Chin said, the United States would definitely oppose Beijing's anti-secession legislation if it involves changes to the Taiwan Strait status quo.
Since Beijing announced its plan to enact an anti-secession law targeting Taiwan, Chin said the Republic of China government has continuously exchanged views with the U.S. authorities on the issue.

"Beijing has yet to reveal the text of the legislation and the government will continue to maintain close contacts with the U.S. authorities and express our grave concern about Beijing's new legislation," Chin said.

Since Chen's inauguration for a second term in May, Chin said, Taiwan has on numerous occasions extended olive branches to Beijing. However, Beijing has so far not made any goodwill response, Chin said, adding that the government will let the Bush administration fully understand this situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF PASSENGERS HANDLED AT CKS AIRPORT TOPS 20 MILLION

TEXT.P: The number of arrivals, departures and transit visits for the year at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport reached a record high of 20 million Tuesday, according to airport officials.
Lee Tung-yang, a Taiwanese passenger returning from a business trip that day became the 20 millionth passenger for the year and was mobbed by reporters in the arrivals hall.

He was awarded free flight tickets worth NT$100,000 (US$3,107.52) and tax-free gifts at an award presentation ceremony held by the airport authorities, as were the two passengers immediately before and after him.

After the inauguration of the airport in 1979, the number of arrivals and departures for the year was only 4.04 million. In 1990, the number topped 10 million, with an annual growth of between 800,000 and one million since then. By 2002, the number had snowballed to 19.2 million, while the number for 2003 plummeted to 15 million, primarily due to the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SUPPORTS KMT'S PROPOSAL FOR CHARTER FLIGHTS TO MAINLAND

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) fully supported the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) idea of inaugurating charter flights between Taiwan and mainland China during the Chinese Lunar New Year holidays, MAC Spokesman Chiu Tai-san said Tuesday.
Chiu made the statement after members of KMT caucus at the Legislative Yuan called on MAC Chairman Joseph Wu to exchange views with him about the KMT's plan.

The spokesman said the MAC would like to see the KMT go through with its plan of having charter flights between Shanghai and Taoyuan, and would agree to expand them to other mainland cities such as Guangzhou and Beijing.

The KMT is seeking the MAC's support to open charter flights following the pattern used in 2003 under which the Taipei authorities allowed local carriers to discuss charter flights with the Beijing authorities.
Once approved, the flights would be used exclusively for Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland during the Chinese Lunar New Year holidays, which begins on Feb. 9.

Beijing has insisted on having mainland carriers join their Taiwan counterparts in providing the charter services and the flights between Shanghai and Taoyuan should not stop in a third place, usually Hong Kong or Macau, as is necessary under Taiwan's policy of not having direct flight between Taiwan and the mainland.
Taiwan authorities said it was interested in the proposal but that details needed to be worked out between the two sides.

Beijing, which boycotts any official contact with Taiwan authorities for fear of giving credit to Taiwan's claim that it is an independent state, refused to negotiate this year. Instead it proposed to have private carriers apply for flight permission from aviation authorities in Taiwan and Shanghai separately.

With only 40 days to go before the Chinese New Year holiday, industry analysts said that the chances the KMT could succeed in lining up the charter flights for Taiwan businessmen who want to return to Taiwan for the holiday is slim.

It is estimated that there are 500,000 Taiwanese living on the mainland, and it won't be easy for them to get a flight ticket to return to their homeland during the new year's holiday, which is the traditional time for family reunions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INFORMATION SECURITY MARKET TO GREATLY EXPAND: ANALYST

TEXT.P: The scale of Taiwan's information security market is expected to expand to some NT$16.7 billion (US$522 million) in value by 2007 from this year's level of NT$9 billion, an analyst for the Institute for Information Industry's Market Intelligence Center said Tuesday.

Fang Yi-wen said that the total value of information security products such as anti-virus software, as well as network security mechanisms, purchased by domestic businesses amounted to NT$5.2 billion in 2004, an 18 percent increase over last year, while the market scale in terms of information security services was valued at NT$3.8 billion this year, a 38 percent surge.

The need for active self-defense mechanisms and efficient security appliances in the face of information security threats has accelerated Taiwan enterprises' moves to institute security facilities against information technology crime, Fang said.

He added that it is also expected that the market scale in terms of information security services will surpass that of security appliances for the first time by 2007, with an expected value of NT$8.5 billion for services and NT$8.2 billion for products.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: A Third of the Dead Are Said to Be Children.
Survivors of the gigantic undersea earthquake on Sunday that swallowed coastlines from Indonesia to Africa - which officials now describe as one of the worst natural disasters in recent history - recovered bodies today, hurriedly arranged for mass burials and searched for tens of thousands of the missing in countries thousands of miles apart.
The Wall Stree Journal: Tsunami Death Toll Hits 40,000.
Mourners in Sri Lanka buried their dead with bare hands Tuesday as rescuers rushed to check isolated pockets of Indonesia for survivors of explosive tidal waves that the United Nations said may be history's costliest natural disaster. Nearly 40,000 people were dead, and officials expected the toll to rise further.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER OPTIMISTIC ABOUT TAIWAN-U.S. TIES

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Tuesday he is firmly convinced that substantive Taiwan-U.S. relations are in good shape.

The minister was responding to a press inquiry about his views on a front page newspaper report a day earlier that the U.S. government sent a special envoy to Taipei a few days before Christmas to meet with President Chen Shui-bian, which the report claimed was a sign that there is no change in Taiwan-U.S. relations.

Tan Sun Chen did not respond directly to a question as to whether the report was correct. Instead, he said that after Deputy U.S. Secretary of State Richard Armitage described in a television interview earlier this month that Taiwan was the "biggest landmine" in U.S.-China relations, some domestic politicians and pundits have taken President Chen to task for so-called "deteriorating" Taiwan-U.S. ties.

Some politicians have even claimed that U.S. President George W. Bush dislikes President Chen and has cursed him. In the face of all those broadsides against the president, Tan Sun Chen said he has repeatedly clarified that all those allegations are unfounded.

"I firmly believe that Taiwan-U.S. relations are good and have not been clouded by any problems as some people have claimed, " the foreign minister said, adding that he "has a basis" for making such an optimistic assessment.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT SENDS CONDOLENCES TO THAI KING ON TSUNAMI VICTIMS
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Dec. 28 (CNA) (By Wu Shia-chang & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian sent a letter of sympathy Tuesday to King Adunyadet Phumiphon of Thailand to express his condolences over the victims of Sunday's tsunami, according to officials of the ROC representative office in Thailand.
The Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Thailand delivered Chen's letter to King Phumiphon via the general affairs department of the king's palace, the officials said.
TECO also donated on behalf of the ROC government US$50,000 to the Thai authorities as relief funds for victims of the disaster.
TECO has launched a campaign to encourage Taiwan businesses operating in Thailand and overseas Chinese communities there to make donations to help the victims.
Meanwhile, a 35-member rescue group from Taiwan arrived on the tsunami-hit Thai island of Pukhet that day to join the rescue efforts there, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 84% OF LOCAL COMPANIES WILL OFFER YEAR-END BONUSES TO EMPLOYEES

TEXT.P: A majority of Taiwan companies responding to a recent online survey said they will distribute year-end bonuses to their employees, with the amount reaching an average of 1.53 months-worth of salary.
The survey was conducted by www.999.com.tw -- an INternet job bank -- from Dec. 6-22, collecting 1,021 valid replies from human resources departments of the companies surveyed.
The poll results show that 83.55 percent of the respondents said their companies will definitely provide year-end bonuses for their employees.

Only 11.26 percent said they will not offer year-end bonuses, either because of poor business profits or poor performance of their employees. Meanwhile, 19.13 percent said that as they have adopted a contract work system, they will not offer any year-end bonus.
Among those that said they will not offer year-end bonuses, 67.83 percent said they will offer employees gifts or coupons.
According to the survey, the average amount of year-end bonus is equivalent to 1.53 months of salary, slightly higher than last year's 1.46 months.

By industry, financial services outperformed all other lines of business by offering an average year-end bonus of 2.59 months of salary, followed by export-import trade, transportation and commodity delivery, commercial services, and steel/metal/automobiles, in that order. The bottom three industries were the restaurant/audio-visual entertainment industry, the publishing industry and the retail business.

The survey also found that 46.91 percent of local companies registered gains in profits compared with the previous year's levels, 21.45 percent said their profits remained almost same as last year and 25.76 percent said their earnings declined.

Asked whether they had reached their business targets over the past year, 37.32 percent said "yes, " 17.43 percent said their business revenues exceeded their original targets, 40.06 percent said their business performance fell short of their target and 5.19 percent said they had yet to complete their tallies.
The online job bank also conducted a survey of local salaried people about their career expectations during the same period, collecting 5,738 valid replies.

According to the survey results, the majority of the respondents said would like to receive a year-end bonus of at least 1.73 months-worth of their salary rather than the average of 1.53 months on offer.
