DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PROMOTES MARITIME CULTURE

TEXT.P: Presiding over the opening of a maritime cultural and art museum financed by the Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp. in Keelung, a harbor city in northern Taiwan, Chen said Taiwan owes much of its marvelous economic achievements to the ocean.
Taiwan people, most of whose ancestors came to the island by sailing across the risky Taiwan Strait from mainland China, are predisposed to taking risks for a better future, according to Chen.
The risk-taking mentality of its people has played a big role in shaping the island's unique culture and has contributed greatly to the country's prosperity, Chen said.

Noting that Taiwan ranks 25th in the world in terms of average national income, first in the world in terms of the extent to which the government has made public government-related information, third in terms of the amount of foreign exchange reserves, seventh in terms of the amount of its overseas investments and 16th in terms of the volume of its international trade, Chen said all these factors depend to a large extent on the island's well-developed maritime shipping industry.
The president also lauded the performance of the Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp., which has been ranked first among the nation's marine shipping companies by CommonWealth, a local business weekly.
Chen said he hopes the maritime cultural and art museum founded by Yang Ming will further enrich the island's diversified culture.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI TO SEND MEDICAL TEAM TO SRI LANKA

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation -- Taiwan's largest charity group -- said Tuesday it will send a 29-member medical team to Sri Lanka Wednesday to help with post-disaster relief work there.
The team will be composed of medical professionals, as well as relief volunteers and counselors, a foundation spokesman said.

Sri Lanka is one of the countries hit hardest by massive killer tidal waves over the weekend. In addition to offering emergency medical services, the spokesman said, the team will survey the extent of the devastation, as well as provide relief goods to the people there most in need.
The team, to be headed by Wang Li-hsin, deputy chief of Tzu Chi Hospital in Hualien, will begin its work in Hambantona in southern Sri Lanka, which was one of the worst-hit zones.
The team will take with it 3,000 body bags, 8,000 blankets, antibiotics and other medicines, as well as various other medical equipment.

The Tzu Chi foundation, which has branches in many countries around the world, will launch a global fund-raising campaign to help the victims in nine countries affected by Sunday's strong earthquake off the Indonesian island of Sumatra and ensuing tsunami, the spokesman said.
According to the spokesman, Tzu Chi branches in Indonesia, Thailand and Malaysia have already begun post-disaster relief work in the three countries, including distributing relief goods.

Meanwhile, a team of 10 medical and relief workers organized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) left for Medan, Indonesia early Tuesday morning, bringing with them some 3.5 tons of food, medicine, tents and sleeping bags.

Another 35-member team, organized by the non-profit Rescue Headquarters of Taiwan, left for the Thai resort island of Phuket at around noon, carrying relief supplies and advanced rescue equipment, including an underwater robot.
Meanwhile, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said the government will offer US$100,000 in relief aid to Indonesia and US$50,000 to each of the three other worst-hit countries -- Thailand, India and Sri Lanka.
A Taiwan citizen was killed when a tsunami devastated Phuket, a popular tourist destination, while two others are still missing, Lu said.

A day earlier, MOFA listed Phuket, Sri Lanka, the Maldives and Penang as "yellow"-travel alert zones, and urged people intending to visit those regions to be careful. The whole of Indonesia has been listed as a "yellow"-travel alert area due to potential terrorist attack threats.
An infectious disease expert also advised local people to refrain from making non-essential visits to those areas for the time being because epidemics could break out in flooded areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHIEF UNVEILS ROUTE BETWEEN KMT, DPP

TEXT.P: The People First Party (PFP) will work together with the Kuomintang (KMT) in defending the existence of the Republic of China but will compete against it in pushing for reforms while firmly opposing the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) drive for Taiwan independence, PFP Chairman James Soong said Tuesday.

Soong, who took a break from a visit to the United States to return to Taiwan for Monday's funeral of Faina Chiang, widow of late President Chiang Ching-kuo, made the statement before flying back to the United States to continue his visit.
He said his party will not compromise on its stance of defending the existence of the ROC and the Constitution, opposing Taiwan independence and promoting peace across the Taiwan Strait.

As for its ties with other major political parties, Soong said the PFP cannot agree with DPP's policy of pursuing Taiwan independence, but will not rule out the possibility of cooperating with any party in dealing with issues concerning the public good.
The PFP will cooperate with the KMT -- from which it split several years ago -- in defending the ROC, but will compete against it in pushing for reforms, Soong said.
Claiming there are no urgent pending issues between the PFP and the KMT, Soong said he did not meet with KMT Chairman Lien Chan during his brief return to Taiwan.
Soong, who was Lien's running mate in the latter's unsuccessful second bid for the presidency in March, fell out with Lien after the PFP lost 12 seats in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
He blamed the KMT for contributing to the PFP's worse-than-expected performance in the legislative elections by backing out of its commitment to the PFP.

As a consequence of this, Soong reneged on a promise he made to merge his PFP with the KMT after Dec. 11 and was reported as having refused to meet with Lien to work out a united front between the two parties on many political issues in the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERDUE LOAN RATIO OF TAIWAN'S BANKS DROPS TO 3.22%

TEXT.P: The average overdue loan ratio registered by domestic banks had dropped to 3.22 percent as of the end of November, down 0.1 percentage points from the previous month's level, according to a report issued Tuesday by the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC).

According to FSC statistics, the amount of overdue loans had fallen by NT$9.3 billion to NT$494.3 billion (US$14.88 billion) as of the end of November, while loans considered prone to becoming non-performing and put under a monitoring scheme totaled NT$174.2 billion, down NT$7.1 billion month-to-month.
The figures indicate that the banks posted a broadly explained overdue loan ratio of 4.35 percent in November, down 0.16 percentage points from that of a month ago.

A total of NT$125.5 billion in non-performing loans was written off in the first 11 months of this year with the banks' own earnings, which indicates that their operations are improving, FSC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINSTER TO MEET REPRESENTATIVES FROM COUNTRIES HIT BY TSUNAMI

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen will meet Wednesday with representatives of four of the countries hit hard by Sunday's earthquake near the Indonesian island of Sumatra and the ensuing tsunami to see what aid Taiwan can extend to their countries.
The Foreign Ministry said Chen has called in representatives from Indonesia, India, Malaysia and Thailand for the meeting.
The earthquake and tsunami has killed more than 55,000 people in countries around the Indian Ocean.
Chen said a 10-member Taiwan team will head for Indonesia soon to see what Taiwan can do for that country.
Meanwhile, Chen Chien-jen, minister of the Department of Health (DOH), said a medical aid team organized by the DOH is ready to go to these countries.
The ruling Democratic Progressive Party has also decided to donate one day's salary-worth of each party official to buy relief for the earthquake victims.
A similar campaign has began in Taichung County, central Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALES AT TAIWAN'S EXPORT PROCESSING ZONES SHARPLY INCREASE

TEXT.P: The export processing zones (EPZs) around Taiwan are estimated to have combined sales of NT$360 billion (US$10.84 billion) this year, up 18.27 percent from the previous year's level, the head of the EPZ Administration (EPZA) said Tuesday.
Chou Yan said at a year-end news conference that the figures indicate that businesses established in the special economic compounds have enjoyed steady growth.
They will have a better business next year than this year, he predicted, based on the increasing investment in the zones.

The EPZA approved 46 new investment projects and 77 capital-added investment projects worth NT$36.16 billion this year, far above the original target of NT$30 billion set by his administration for the year, Chou added.
The EPZA has set the investment target at NT$34.5 billion for next year, he further revealed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 29, or the 18th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Andrew Johnson, the 17th president of the United States, is born. He took over as president after Abraham Lincoln was assassinated.
1857: British and French troops take Canton, southern China.
1911: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected the first president of Asia's first democratic republic -- the Republic of China.
1921: The United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan sign the Washington Treaty to limit naval armaments.
1924: John Davidson Rockefeller, an American oil magnate who amassed a great fortune through the Standard Oil Company, donates US$1 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.
1928: Chang Hsueh-liang pledges allegiance to the national government, thereby leading to the unification of China.
1931: The national government is reorganized, with Lin Sen as the new chairman.
1934: Japan renounces the Washington Treaty limiting naval armaments.
1938: Wang Ching-wei, who deserted the ROC government and left Chungking for Kunming on Dec. 18, issues a statement in Hanoi, Vietnam, advocating the termination of the War of Resistance against Japan and seeking peace with Japan.
1940: German bombers inflict the greatest damage on London since the Great Fire of 1666.
1948: The Executive Yuan appoints Chen Cheng as governor of the Taiwan Provincial Government.
1953: The Legislative Yuan revises the quorum for the National Assembly from the original one-half (1,523) to one-third (1,015) of the total number of members.
1968: The Yangtze River Bridge near Nanking, built by the Communist Chinese, is inaugurated.
1975: Some 100 scholars from Taiwan and abroad attend the Conference on Population and Economic Development. President Yen Chia-kan addresses the opening ceremony.
1980: Hsieh Kuo-cheng, Taiwan's so-called "father of baseball," dies at the age of 69.
1981: U.S. President Ronald Reagan announces a program of economic sanctions against the Soviet Union because of its alleged role in the imposition of martial law in Poland.
1981: Lee Tien-hui, who earned a mainland scholarship to study in the United States, defects and holds a press conference in Taipei.
1984: India's Congress-I Party, headed by Ragiv Gandhi, wins a landslide victory in India's general elections.
1986: Harold Macmillan, British politician, dies at the age of 92. As prime minister, he presided over the break-up of the British Empire.
1989: Vaclav Havel, a dissident Czechoslovakian philosopher, becomes the first elected non-Communist president without opposition.
1989: Thousands of Vietnamese refugees battle with riot police in Hong Kong.
1994: The first squadron of Ching-kuo indigenous defense fighters is officially commissioned, upgrading the combat ability of the ROC Air Force and demonstrating the initial results of local research and development.
1995: The Executive Yuan approves revised regulations governing the establishment of the Central News Agency.
1996: A peace accord is signed between the Guatemalan government and guerrilla leaders, ending 38 years of civil conflict and bringing Central America's last remaining and longest civil war to a close.
1999: Former ROC Minister of Education Lin Ching-chiang dies of respiratory failure at the age of 60.
2000: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung says that the government plans to spend NT$65.5 billion to create a total of 290,000 job opportunities within a year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is the moral life of a neighborhood which constitutes its excellence. He is not an intelligent man, who, in choosing his residence, does not select a place with a moral surrounding."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC RECALLS AMBASSADOR POSTED IN GRENADA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has recalled its ambassador posted in Grenada to express its indignation with the way that the Caribbean ally has handled its formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan, sources from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday.
Ambassador Allan L.S. Jiang returned over the weekend to Taiwan where he will stay "indefinitely," MOFA officials said.
The move is an uncharacteristically "sharp" one for Taiwan in dealing with diplomatic allies that have wavered between maintaining ties with Taipei and switching diplomatic recognition to Beijing.

Taipei notified the Grenadian government Dec. 24 of its decision to recall Jiang after Grenadian Prime Minister Keith Mitchell visited Beijing recently, during which Mitchell said that Grenada would seek to normalize relations with mainland China, MOFA officials noted.

Mitchell had hinted that Grenada would switch its recognition from Taipei to Beijing following his trip to China in mid-December. Mitchell reportedly said relations between Taiwan and Grenada have worsened since President Chen Shui-bian took office in 2000 and that "it is clear that Grenada is no longer important to Taiwan, " since "Taiwan has not taken its diplomatic relations with Grenada seriously."
Mitchell also disclosed that Beijing had promised to provide a large amount of funding to finance a number of development projects in Grenada.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu dismissed Mitchell's accusations as rude and unfair soon after Mitchell made the remarks upon his return to Grenada from Beijing Dec. 17. Lu said that the ROC government has treated all its diplomatic allies with equal respect and has not done any disservice to Grenada.

Noting that Taiwan refuses to engage in "dollar diplomacy, " Lu told Mitchell to "go ahead" if he believes Beijing will cash its checks. Lu said that Taiwan is prepared for the worst-case scenario as far as its diplomatic relations with Grenada are concerned.

According to Jiang, Mitchell's remarks made in a televised speech to the nation Dec. 20 showed that Grenada was paving the way for normalization of relations with mainland China, although the prime minister did not say that his nation was severing ties with Taiwan.
Jiang said he reckoned that Mitchell was trying to please Beijing and justify his trip to mainland China by intentionally criticizing Taiwan.
He said that bilateral cooperation projects between Taiwan and Grenada have never ceased since the two countries established diplomatic ties 15 years ago.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen even visited Grenada in September to show Taiwan's concern for the damage done by Hurricane Ivan, and Taiwan has offered US$4 million as relief aid to Grenada in the aftermath of the disaster.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: S'pore joins big global aid effort.
Singapore yesterday joined in a worldwide effort to help victims of Sunday's staggering underwater earthquake and tsunami disaster.
In a spontaneous outpouring of generosity among individuals, groups and companies, people queued at the Singapore Red Cross office to donate money, helping the group reach its initial target of $1 million in just two days.
The Government sent a planeload of relief and medical supplies to Medan in Indonesia yesterday.
The Lianhe Zaobao:The Singaporean and companies donated over S$1.5M for the victims of earthquake and tsunami disaster.
In a spontaneous outpouring of generosity among individuals, groups and companies, people queued at the Singapore Red Cross office to donate money, helping the group reach its initial target of S$1 million in just two days, the money already surpassed S1.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PROPOSES PFP HEAD SERVE AS HEAD OF CROSS-STRAIT PEACE COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: A leading member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Wednesday proposed that opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong serve as convener of the cross-strait peace development committee.

DPP Acting Chairman Ker Chien-ming made the proposal while talking about DPP-PFP cooperation issues at a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan. PFP Chairman James Soong said a day earlier that his party would not exclude the possibility of cooperation with any political parties on issues regarding the public interest and the well-being of the Taiwan people.

Welcoming the outcome of Tuesday's xxxx meeting in which three versions of draft bills concerning party assets were put on the legislative agenda for debate in Friday's meeting, Ker, who also serves as the convener of the DPP caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said that the outcome is a good start for interactions among the different political parties.

Pointing out that the people of Taiwan want to see reconciliation between the "pan-blue alliance" and "pan-green camp" and hope to see the two opposing camps engage in dialogue, the acting chairman said that he is well aware that the PFP head is for cooperation with the DPP on issues regarding the people's well-being.

Ker said that the DPP hopes to strengthen cooperation and engage in dialogue with the PFP, the KMT and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union on various issues, including judicial, political and financial reforms, as well as government restructuring, the economy, and issues regarding the people's well-being.

Touching on the PFP's different stances on unification versus independence issue, Kei said that the most important thing for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is to create stability and put aside issues related to unification versus independence.

Noting that the PFP has already proposed the enactment of a law to promote cross-strait peace, Ker said that it would be suitable to have Soong act as an "icebreaker" in cross-strait relations by serving as convener of the cross-strait peace development committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MONITORING SYSTEMS CAPABLE OF DETECTING TSUNAMIS: MOTC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's earthquake monitoring and detecting systems are among the most advanced in the world and are capable of detecting tsunamis, Vice Minister of Transportation and Telecommunications Oliver F. L. Yu said Wednesday.

Yu said that although there are not any regulations or laws in place in Taiwan regarding responses to tsunamis, the Executive Yuan, the Ministry of Transportation and Telecommunications (MOTC) , and harbor bureaus around the country have maintained standardized operational policies and measures against natural disasters.

It is believed that the earthquake detecting systems installed around the island are capable of monitoring and reporting tsunamis so that relevant agencies can issue alarms in time to prevent major damage, Yu noted.

Yu made the remarks during an interpellation session at the Executive Yuan, where opposition Legislator Lee Hsien-jung asked him whether and how Taiwan is capable of meeting challenges that would be brought by tsunamis. Lee's question came following Sunday's massive earthquake offshore western Indonesia and ensuing tsunamis which killed tens of thousands of people and caused major damage in many countries in the region.

Yu said the chances of Taiwan being hit by tsunamis are low because of the deep waters to the east of the island. He added that if tsunamis were to hit, the most likely spot would be Keelung harbor on Taiwan's northeastern cape. However, he said the waters off Keelung as well as the inner and outer dikes off the northern port city would absorb most of the devastating force.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH INSURANCE IC CARDS TO TAKE ON NEW FUNCTION JAN. 1

TEXT.P: The National Health Insurance IC cards will from Jan. 1 record information of major physical examinations and prescriptions for patients with chronic diseases, Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) officials said Wednesday.
The new function will help the bureau monitor repeat prescriptions and examinations and prevent a waste of medical resources, according to BNHI CEO Liu Chien-hsiang.

The new monitoring system was announced in the wake of reports that some chronic patients have visited different hospitals to get repeated prescriptions in order to give them away to their families and friends in mainland China or sell them on to other people.

Repetition of expensive examinations such as computed tomography scanning, magnetic resonance imaging and positron emission tomography is also very common, especially when a patient is being transferred from one hospital to another, Liu said.

He said the bureau will provide special counseling to any patients found to have obtained repeated prescriptions and will encourage hospitals to digitize the examination reports of their patients to facilitate the transmission of such reports between hospitals.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Tsunami death toll climbs past 43,000; biggest relief effort in history launched.
Mourners in Sri Lanka buried their dead with bare hands Tuesday as rescuers rushed to check isolated pockets of Indonesia for survivors of explosive tidal waves that the United Nations said may be history's costliest natural disaster.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Deaths Surpass 58,000; Disease Major Concern.
Health organization warns that tens of thousands of people could face death from cholera, typhoid, other diseases.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN CALLS FOR FAIR RULING ON PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION CASE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan Wednesday urged the Taiwan High Court to hand down a ruling which "offspring will be proud of" on an opposition lawsuit to nullify the March 20 presidential election.
Lien made the call at a weekly meeting of the party's Central Standing Committee, a day before the court is scheduled to release its ruling on the case.

Lien has alleged that the results of the election were swayed by various electoral scandals, a referendum held on the same day of the election, the activation of a "national security mechanism" that he claims barred a number of police and military servicemen from going to the polls, and the election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian.
According to Lien, the election has damaged the international image of Taiwan and the result of a recount was far from satisfactory.
Lien said the KMT will not give up on its effort to dig out "the truth" behind the election and he urged the judiciary to hand out a fair ruling.

The lawsuit is one of two cases brought by Lien and his presidential running mate, People First Party Chairman James Soong. The other, in which Lien and Soong asked for the invalidation of Chen's election, was turned down by the Taiwan High Court Nov. 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT LAND LEASE SYMBOLIZES U.S. AMITY TOWARD TAIWAN: MOFA REPORT

TEXT.P: A decision by the United States to lease a piece of land in Taipei to accommodate its representative office symbolizes its amity toward the Republic of China, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said in a report released Wednesday.

The ministry was referring to a 99-year lease on a 6.5 hectare plot of land in Taipei's Neihu district signed by the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) and its Taiwanese counterpart, the Coordination Council for North American Affairs (CCNAA), Dec. 22.

The MOFA report said the United States will invest US$160 million in building a new office complex on the land. As it will be a massive investment project, the report said, the U.S. authorities went for a 99-year lease according to U.S. practice in similar construction projects in many other countries.
The new lease will take effect Jan. 1, 2005, the report said.

Noting that Taiwan-U.S. relations are critical to Taiwan's development in the international community and Taiwan Strait security, the report said the U.S. decision to build a brand new office complex is a concrete move to show its amity toward Taiwan and will bring positive effects for Taiwan.

The report was supposed to have been delivered at a joint meeting of the Legislative Yuan's foreign affairs and budget committees, but the meeting was canceled when many of the legislators did not bother to turn up.
The AIT, which was founded under the terms of the Taiwan Relations Act, represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties. It has offices in Taipei and Kaohsiung.
According to the MOFA report, the ownership of the site that accommodates the AIT's existing office on Taipei's Hsinyi Road will be returned to the Taipei city government once the lease expires.

Addressing the new lease signing ceremony last Wednesday, Douglas Paal, head of the AIT Taipei Office, described the new lease as an important milestone in substantive relations between the people of Taiwan and the United States.
The lease was signed by Paal and CCNAA Secretary-General Chen Chung. ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen also attended the signing ceremony.

Paal said AIT is designing a new building to be constructed on the Neihu plot. Paal said he hopes the new building will not only help enhance the beauty of Taipei's landscape but will also become the pride of Taipei citizens.

According to MOFA officials, the rent will be paid in a lump sum of about NT$339 million at the start of the contract. If all goes well, the officials said, the new AIT building will be completed by the end of 2008 or early 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OLYMPIC GOLD MEDALIST TOLD TO TURN DOWN LECTURE OFFER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Olympic gold medalist Chen Shih-hsin will be told by the government to decline offers to teach in mainland China, the top official in charge of athletic and sports affairs said Wednesday.

Chen Chuan-shou, chairman of the Cabinet-level National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, said at the Legislative Yuan that taekwondo fighter Chen Shih-hsin will be instructed to follow the country's rules governing top athletes from national teams, including prohibition of such people from heading to the mainland for formal teaching jobs.

The top sports affairs official said that Chen Shih-hsin and her father called at his office Tuesday and clarified recent media reports that a Shanghai-based martial arts institute has presented her a letter of appointment inviting her to teach at the school.

Chen Shih-hsin said she indeed received a letter of appointment from the Shanghai Qingpu Martial Arts Institute during a recent tourism visit she made to Shanghai, but she said she thought it was just a kind of honor and that she received no payment from the school. "I didn't even bring the letter back to Taiwan," she said.

The sports affairs minister said that if Taiwan sporting talent intend to be employed in mainland China as coaches, they must first obtain approval from the Mainland Affairs Council and the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports.
Citing the country's regulations, Minister Chen said that recipients of national sports medals should also return their cash prizes to the nation if their behavior infringes upon national interests.
Chen Shih-hsin and another taekwondo fighter, Chu Mu-yen, won gold medals at the 2004 Athens Olympic Games, breaking Taiwan's gold medal duck in its 72-year history of taking part in the Olympics.

Meanwhile, a spokesman for a visiting nine-member delegation from the Shanghai Physical Fitness and Sports Association said Wednesday that the association has no precise ideas as to whether Chen Shih-hsin has promised the Shanghai martial arts institute to be a coach nor when she will be there coaching.

The spokesman noted, however, that outstanding Taiwan athletes like Chen Shih-hsin are always welcome to be coaches on the mainland so that "both sides will complement each other and in turn further rev up their overall athletic standards."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on the Taipei stock futures market moved up Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) capitalization weighted index for January soared 98 points to close at 6,118, with 29,184 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX index futures for February gained 95 points to finish at 6,116, with 154 contracts traded, while March futures surged 85 points to finish at 6,100, with 10 contracts traded.
June futures moved up 92 points to finish at 6,100, with 14 contracts traded, while September futures rose 95 points to close at 6,011, with 23 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,020 for January, 6,021 for February, 6,015 for March, 6,008 for June and 5,916 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.
January TE futures moved up 2.95 points to close at 228.25, with 3,287 contracts traded, while February TE futures gained 3.1 points to finish at 228.3, with 13 contract transactions.
March TE futures fell 0.25 points to close at 225.5, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
January TF futures gained 15.8 points to finish at 1,030, with 5,769 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved up 13.8 points to end at 1,029.2, with 76 contracts traded.
March TF futures surged 13.4 points to close at 1,027, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, losing NT$0.054 to close at NT$31.976.
A total of US$724 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$32.082 and was traded between NT$31.962 and NT$32.139 during the trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWENTY-THREE TAIWAN FISHING BOATS DAMAGED IN THAILAND TSUNAMI

TEXT.P: Twenty-three Taiwan fishing boats were reportedly damaged by tsunami unleashed by a powerful earthquake off the Indonesian island of Sumatra Sunday, the Council of Agriculture's Fishery Administration said Wednesday.

The boats were beached on the Thai resort island of Phuket by the tsunami that had claimed nearly 60,000 lives as of Wednesday, as well as causing major damage to the infrastructure in many countries around the Indian Ocean region.
The 23 vessels were among 35 Taiwan fishing boats operating near Phuket.

Only one crewman on one of the Taiwan fishing boats was known to be injured and it remains to be learned exactly how much property and catch losses the boats sustained during the disaster, Fishery Administration officials said.

The Fishery Administration has also not decided whether the administration will dispatch officials to Thailand or other South Asian countries that were swept by Sunday's tsunami to gain further understanding of the aftermath.

The Fishery Administration called for owners and operators of the affected Taiwan fishing boats and their crews to call the fishermen's associations with which they are registered for help and subsidies in the wake of the disaster.
Some 150 Taiwan fishing boats regularly operate in the Indian Ocean. They usually make port calls at Phuket, Malaysia's Penang, Sri Lanka's Colombo and the Indonesian resort island of Bali.
The officials said they will keep in contact with Taiwan fishing boats operating in those areas through local fishery radio stations in order to offer timely assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 87.92 points to close at 6,088.49.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 6038.14 and hit a high of 6,102.89 during trading. A total of 4.35 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$87 billion (US$2.72 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction shares moving up the most at 3.6 percent, followed by textile shares and paper and pulp issues both at 2.3 percent, banking and financial stocks at 1.8 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.6 percent, cement stocks and machinery and electronics shares both at 1.3 percent, and plastic and chemical stocks at 1.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 712 to 76, with 88 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BANKER URGES EASING OF CONTROLS ON MAINLAND BRANCHES
DOC.DATELINE: Changhua, central Taiwan, Dec. 29 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Allowing Taiwan's banking institutions to operate branches in mainland China would be a "win win" policy benefiting the economies of both Taiwan and the mainland, the chairman of Chinatrust Financial Holding Co. said Wednesday.

Taiwan's top banking magnate, Jeffrey Koo, said that the mainland is currently the largest financial market in the world, but Taiwan's financial institutions are not allowed to open branches there as a result of the political deadlock across the Taiwan Strait.
Against this backdrop, the mainland's financial market will be dominated by foreign banks in several years, Koo said.
It will be a daunting task for Taiwan banks to win the custom of Taiwanese businessmen operating on the mainland once they have established solid relations with foreign banks, Koo said.

Koo said that Chinatrust Financial Holding only maintains a representative office in Beijing. According to norms of the World Trade Organization, of which both Taiwan and the mainland are members, a bank's representative office can be upgraded into a branch after two years of operations as an office.

Nevertheless, Koo said, he has no answer as to whether and if the Chinatrust Financial Holding representative office in Beijing will be allowed to be upgraded into a branch, given the political situation across the Taiwan Strait.

Koo made the remarks during a ceremony to mark the 31st founding anniversary of the Lukang Folk Arts Museum, which was established by the Koo family in the building their ancestors lived in hundreds of years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO COMMENT FROM MND ON REPORT OF MINISTER'S RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of National Defense Michael Tsai declined to comment Wednesday on a report that Minister of National Defense Lee Jye offered to resign last week over the delay in the passage through the legislature of a NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement plan.
However, Tsai said that as political appointees, Lee and himself are supposed to tender their resignations in the process of a Cabinet reshuffle.

Tsai was asked about the report at the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee but said only that he regrets the fact that the legislature has shelved the arms procurement plan and admitted that the ministry should be held responsible for failing to win legislators' support for the plan.
Lee had previously said that he would step down if the arms procurement plan fails to obtain the legislature's approval.

On the shopping list are six Patriot-III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft from the United States. The Executive Yuan plans to pay for the weapons over a 15-year period starting in 2005.

On another report saying that nearly 100 military generals will retire or be transferred to other positions Jan. 1, Tsai pointed out that it is routine for the ministry to adjust the positions of military officers every year.
Also, he pointed out, the report contains a lot of false information.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES WARM WELCOME IN KANAZAWA
DOC.DATELINE: Kanazawa, Japan, Dec. 29 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui arrived Wednesday in Kanazawa, capital of the Ishikawa prefecture in central Japan, on the second stop of a seven-day sightseeing trip.
Lee was greeted by a crowd of well-wishers when he disembarked from an express train at Kanazawa railway station in the company of friends and members of his family.

The 300-plus well-wishers included Lee's Japanese friends and Taiwanese expatriates in Japan. They waved Japanese and ROC national flags and held up a Japanese banner that said: "Mr. Lee Teng-hui, welcome to Kanazawa."
Lee smiled and doffed his hat to wave to the cheering crowd. Later in the day, he toured major tourist attractions in Kanazawa where traditional Japanese urban landscape has been well preserved.

In addition to visiting Kenrokuen -- one of Japan's three most famous gardens, Kanazawa Castle and a kimono fabric production facility, Lee also paid a visit to the ancestral house of Yoichi Hatta, a Japanese engineer who designed the Wushantou reservoir in the southern Taiwan county of Tainan during Japanese colonial rule.

Lee and his entourage arrived in Nagoya Monday to start his trip, which will also take them to the ancient capital of Kyoto, where Lee attended university in 1943 when Taiwan was a Japanese colony, and Osaka.
Even though Lee's visit is private in nature, it still drew loud protests from mainland China.

Lee riled Beijing during his 12 years in office from 1988-2000 when he campaigned to raise Taiwan's international profile. He redefined the island's ties with China in 1999 as a "special state-to-state" relationship, causing Beijing to break off fence-mending talks which remain suspended to this day.
Japanese officials said Lee is visiting as a private citizen and as such, had no basis for turning down his visa application.
Lee last traveled to Japan in April 2001, when he had treatment for a heart condition. He will conclude his current visit and return to Taiwan Jan.2.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Toll Soaring, Survivors Face Disease Threat.
The waters that stole tens of thousands of peopl e from the shorelines of Asia and East Africa on Sunday spewed their bodies back onto beaches on Tuesday, leading officials to double the death toll again to more than 57,000.
The Wall Stree Journal: Death Toll Nears 70,000 As Huge Relief Effort Begins.
The death toll in southern Asia from Sunday's tsunami soared to nearly 70,000, and as rescuers struggled to reach remote outposts, attention turned to the Herculean relief efforts needed to prevent mass outbreaks of disease and to care for the millions made homeless.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LAUDS YOUTH VOLUNTEER CORPS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lauded the members of the Presidential Office Youth Volunteer Corps as a bridge between the people and the government Wednesday, saying their experience in the corps will turn them into new Taiwan citizens.

Chen made the statement at the commencement of the second Presidential Office Youth Volunteer Corps, saying that the practice gives the nation's youth a chance to take part in the government's policy-shaping process.

Noting that the Youth Conference on National Issues, organized by the National Youth Commission in September, has come up with a recommendation for a Youth Volunteer Corps in the administration, the president said it is a good idea that would give young people an outlet to help shape public policy.
Chen said he believes the National Youth Commission will work out a proposal to meet the desire of young people to be involved in public affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER MEETS WITH TSUNAMI-HIT NATIONS' REPRESENTATIVES

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen met Wednesday with representatives in Taiwan of tsunami-hit nations, including India, Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand, to find out what Taiwan can do to assist their countries.

The meetings were arranged after Premier Yu Shyi-kun announced earlier in the day that the government would offer US$5 million in humanitarian aid for the countries affected by deadly tidal waves triggered by a 9.0-magnitude earthquake under the Indian Ocean on Sunday.
Chen said after the meetings that Indonesia and Thailand are in dire need of aid, especially coroners and medical supplies.
Malaysia and India do not require any foreign assistance for the time being because the post-disaster situations are being taken care of by their governments, Chen added.
India, meanwhile, promised to help pass on Taiwan's assistance offer to Sri Lanka and the Maldives, which have no representative offices in Taiwan, according to Chen.
Chen said his ministry will comprehensively formulate how the money to be donated will be spent, based on the needs of the affected countries.

Also Wednesday, a 10-member advance team from Taiwan went to Aceh on Indonesia's Sumatra Island, one of the hardest-hit areas, to inspect local rescue centers to get first-hand information on what sort of assistance is needed, according to Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu.
The team was told that if Taiwan sends any medical missions to Aceh, they will have to make their own way regarding food, accommodations and transportation, Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF LOCAL ELDERLY CITIZENS TO DOUBLE IN 20 YEARS: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: The number of elderly citizens will double in the next 20 years, with those aged over 75 registering the fastest growth, a National Taiwan University (NTU) professor said Wednesday.

Wu Shu-chiung, a public health policy professor, said at a ceremony marking the 30th anniversary of the NTU's population and gender research center that with post-World War II baby boomers aging, Taiwan's elderly population will show "explosive growth."

According to the latest tallies by the Council for Economic PLanning and Development, Taiwan had about 2.14 million people aged 65 or older in 2004. Among them, 1.28 million aged between 65 and 74, accounting for 59.8 percent of the total elderly population, while 860,000, or 40.2 percent of the total, were aged 75 or older.

By 2031, Wu said, the number of elderly citizens will reach an estimated 5.65 million, with those aged between 65 and 74 totaling about 3.2 million or 56.7 percent, with those older than that surging to 2.45 million or 43.3 percent.

In 2003, Wu said, the percentages of the working population -- those aged between 15 and 64 -- to the non-working population was 71.3 percent versus 28.7 percent. Wu said the financial burden of Taiwan's working population will reach a serious level in 2051 when the ratio will be 55.6 percent versus 44.4 percent.

With women generally living longer than men by five to six years, Wu said women will dominate elderly age groups. In 2000, the female-male ratio among those older than 65 was 898 to 997 and the ratio for those aged over 80 was 134 to 149.

According to Wu's estimate, the female-male ratio among those aged over 65 will be 1,231 to 1,125 by 2010, and the ratio will be 253 to 240 among those aged over 80. By 2030, the ratio will be 2,711 to 2,328 among those aged over 65 and 543 to 371 among those aged over 80.
In her view, Wu said, care for elderly single women, including those widowed or divorced, will be a serious problem along with the aging of the population in general.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Yanukovych Seeks Opposition Status.
Ukrainian Prime Minister Viktor Yanukovych will put up a symbolic legal fight against Viktor Yushchenko's victory and then turn his attention to becoming an opposition leader, Yanukovych's campaign director, Taras Chernovil, said in an interview Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF INTERNET USERS IN TAIWAN INCREASES

TEXT.P: The number of Internet subscribers in Taiwan topped 8.01 million at the end of November, up 1.07 percent from last year, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Among the Internet users, the tallies show, 3.65 million used broadband, an increase of 24.8 percent year-on-year.
Meanwhile, dial-up connection users amounted to 13.53 million, up 1.4 percent over that from a year ago, the statistics indicate.
At the same time, the country's mobile phone users dropped by 13.1 percent to 21.81 million.
DGBAS officials ascribed the decrease to a stricter scrutiny of subscribers' personal information used in applying for the service, a part of the government's efforts to combat crime.
However, mobile phone users made calls for a total of 23.12 billion minutes in the first 11 months of this year, up 8.8 percent from the previous year's level.
Mobile phone service providers had a combined revenue of NT$181.4 billion (US$5.66 billion) during the period between January and November, an annual growth of 4.6 percent, the statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DONATE US$5 MILLION TO HELP TSUNAMI-HIT NATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan will donate US$5 million to help Asian countries hit by a powerful earthquake and ensuing tidal waves over the weekend, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Wednesday.

Speaking at a weekly Cabinet meeting, Yu said that as a member of the international community, Taiwan must offer timely humanitarian aid to South and Southeast Asian nations affected by killer tsunamis wrought by a 9.0-magnitude earthquake under the Indian Ocean on Sunday.

Yu directed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to raise US$5 million in relief aid for all affected countries. If the ministry doesn't have enough in its budget, Yu said the government's second reserve funds can be used to meet the demand.
Yu also ordered the formation of a 100-member medical group, to be composed of trained rescuers and medical professionals, to travel to disaster zones to assist in relief work.
Meanwhile, Yu directed all Cabinet members to donate one-day-worth of their salaries as relief funds.

The premier further asked the foreign ministry to keep close contact with Taiwan's representative offices in tsunami-affected countries and coordinate with other government agencies in offering timely assistance to those countries.
Two Taiwan relief teams have already left for Indonesia and Thailand Tuesday, bringing with them more than three tons of medical and relief supplies.
On Wednesday, two medical groups, organized by the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation and the Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps headed for Sri Lanka to lend medical assistance.

According to foreign wire service report, the area around the Indonesian town of Meulaboh -- a fishing village of 40,000 residents -- bore the brunt of the earthquake, which sent massive tidal waves thundering across the Indian Ocean that killed more than 67,000 people in about a dozen countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-PARAGUAY FTA SECOND-ROUND TALKS TO BE HELD IN FEB.

TEXT.P: The second round of talks on a free trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and Paraguay will be held Feb. 20-25 in Taiwan, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Wednesday.

The Taiwan-Paraguay FTA first-round talks were held in Asuncion last August, in which the two sides agreed to dub the future bilateral free trade accord as a "close strategic economic partnership (CSEP)" and signed a CSEP framework agreement, Ho noted.

With regard to FTA talks with Nicaragua and Guatemala, the minister said that the third round of Taiwan-Nicaragua FTA negotiations will be held Jan. 31 in Miami, Florida, while the Taiwan-Guatemala consultations will begin on March 1.
Taiwan expects to sign accords with Nicaragua and Guatemala in the first half of next year, she continued.
Taiwan is also seeking to sign free trade agreements with other countries, particularly the United States, Japan, Singapore and New Zealand.

The government has prioritized settling differences with the U.S. on the issues of opening Taiwan's telecommunications market, rice imports, pharmaceutical prices and the protection of intellectual property rights, the minister added.
Taiwan-Japan talks will be held through private channels and will focus on removing trade barriers for individual items in the initial stage, Ho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO FACE THREE BIG CHANGES WITHIN THREE YEARS: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan will face three important changes in the next three years and ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers will have to deal with these situations by crafting the best legislation possible, Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday.
Meeting with a group of newly elected DPP lawmakers in her office, Lu said the first change will be global changes prompted by the globalization and the emergence of mainland China as a major power.

The second will be changes in Taiwan caused by an aging population, the increasing number of foreign women who enter the country through marriages to local people and the "information gap" between those with access to information on the Internet and those without such access.
The third change will be in people's thinking. This will come from political differences among the people of Taiwan and the destruction of traditional morals, she said.
She urged the DPP lawmakers to keep these issues in mind when they are creating laws for the citizens of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR DEC. 30 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, Dec. 30:
09:00, The Legislative Yuan committees will start their sessions for the day.
09: 00, Premier Yu Shyi-kun will attend the inauguration of a wind-powered electricity generating station in Shihmen, Taipei County.
09: 30, A seminar on the prospects of Taipei-Washington-Beijing triangular ties in 2005 will be held at the National Policy Research Institute.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTRICITY AND WATER RATES TO BE RAISED: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Electricity and water rates will be raised, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh confirmed Wednesday.
At a year-end news conference, Ho said electricity rates will be raised no more than NT$0.5 per unit, or one kilowatt/hour.
Since the average household consumes 300 units a month, the rate hike will increase the electricity bill of each household by about NT$150 (US$4.71), Ho said.

In order to justify the raise in electricity rates, Ho said Taiwan's electricity costs NT$2.07 per unit on average, which is far less than the NT$4.8 per unit in Japan, NT$3.74 per unit in Hong Kong, NT$3.56 per unit in the Philippines, and NT$2.13 per unit in South Korea.

Furthermore, Ho argued, the increase in international oil prices has driven up the cost of producing electricity, and the Taiwan Power Company is expected to lose NT$9 billion (U$281.95 million) next year if it does not adjust rates.

For the same reason, the price of water will also be raised, the minister said, arguing that Taiwan's water rates, now NT$10.77 per ton, are unreasonable cheap compared to NT$62.7 per ton in Germany, NT$56.7 per ton in Denmark, NT$17.5 per ton in the United States, NT$14.4 per ton in Canada, and between NT$17 to NT$44 per ton in Hong Kong.

Although the cost of water is not particularly affected by the price of oil, the minister said Taiwan's water rates have remained unchanged for 10 years. A rate hike will also encourage users not to waste water and will give the water company the resources to fund replacing aging pipelines.

Meanwhile, as to the question of whether to allow local manufacturers of small LCD panels and integrated circuits to invest in mainland China, Ho said her ministry understands local businessmen's desire to get the green light from the government, but the economics ministry can't make that decision by itself.
Noting that Beijing is crafting an "anti-secession law" with Taiwan as its target, Ho said some policy-makers believe this question should be shelved for the time being.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MEDICAL TEAM HEADS FOR SRI LANKA

TEXT.P: A Taiwan medial team headed for Sri Lanka Wednesday to help people injured in tsunamis caused by a magnitude-9.0 earthquake in Indonesia Sunday.
Meanwhile, the Department of Health decided to sent an 11-member medial team to Medan, Indonesia Thursday.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has set up a special account with the Central Bank of China in Taipei for collecting donations for the relief of the earthquake victims.
The account number is: 270240.
The Council of Agriculture has decided to sent rice to the countries ravaged by the tsunamis and earthquake.
