DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Tsunami Death Toll Hits 60,000. Survivors Scramble for Food. Exhausted survivors of southern Asia's giant earthquake and tsunami combed the rubble for food and belongings as officials stepped up efforts to identify and bury the dead, whose numbers topped 60,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Hunger, disease stalk survivors
Thousands of corpses rotted in Indonesia's tropical sun on Wednesday as many who escaped death in the worst tsunamis in recorded history faced a fight for survival against hunger and disease.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: 25 Filipinos feared dead
IVY CATHERINE Tomenio, along with her Japanese husband and their three young children, left their hotel in Phuket, Thailand, that Sunday morning to see the island's famed beaches when the killer waves came.
The Philippine Star: 16 Filipinos feared dead but no confirmation yet
More Filipinos are feared to have died in the killer tsunamis that struck southern Thailand, with the likely death toll climbing to 16 after eight more "Filipino-sounding" names were submitted by Thai authorities, the Department of Foreign Affairs (DFA) said yesterday.
The Manila Times: Epidemics threaten to raise death toll
Confirmed deaths and warnings that disease could multiply the horror of Asia's tsunami catastrophe took estimates of the final toll to more than 100,000 as the world's biggest ever relief operation stuttered into life against enormous odds Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORTS OF BANANAS TO BE FULLY LIBERALIZED

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) will continue its pilot program next year to allow unrestricted exports of bananas, particularly to Japan.
Since 1974, the Taiwan Provincial Fruit Marketing Cooperative (TPFMC) has been the sole exporter of bananas to Japan -- Taiwan's largest fruit export market.
Since the number of Taiwan bananas exported to Japan in recent years has declined, the COA decided to allow other organizations to export bananas to areas outside of Japan on a trial basis in 2004.
The TPFMC will still handle the majority of the Japanese market but others will come on board to try to expand Taiwan's banana export footprint in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SENDS NATIONAL-LEVEL MEDICAL TEAM TO INDONESIA

TEXT.P: An 11-member medical team organized by the Cabinet-level Department of Health headed for Medan, Indonesia Thursday to offer post-disaster medical aid to areas devastated by killer tsunamis.

Minister of Health Chen Chien-jen came to the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to support those preparing to face the grim realities of dealing with the aftermath of the death of thousands. Chen thanked the volunteers for their selflessness.
It was the first national-level medical aid team from Taiwan to lend a hand since a magnitude-9.0 earthquake and subsequent tsunamis tore through in a dozen countries around the Indian Ocean Sunday.

Under the health department's coordination, Chen said, more than 100 other medical professionals are also waiting to join aid missions in tsunami-hit countries, including Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Thailand and India. Out of humanitarian concerns, Chen said the Cabinet has directed the health department to organize medical aid teams to help with post-disaster relief work.
The team, headed by Tsai Ming-tse, director of National Cheng Kung University Hospital's emergency room, will travel to Aceh, the northern Indonesian province closest to the quake's epicenter.
According to foreign wire service reports, Indonesia has suffered the largest number of victims, with 45,268 known dead, although the toll could rise to 80,000 in Aceh alone.
The team carried with it medical supplies and equipment as well as power generators, tents and daily necessities to ensure self-sufficiency.
Prior to his departure, Tsai said the team will first work at the provisional relief center set up by the Indonesian government in Medan, which lies close to Aceh province.
"Our initial focus will be on surveying the damage wrought by the killer quake and tsunamis on public health systems in the region and drafting follow-up medical aid plans," Tsai said.
As rebels have been active in Aceh province, Tsai said his team will coordinate with Indonesian authorities to ensure the safety of the team.
The team should complete its survey in five to seven days, Tsai added.
Two Taiwan relief teams already left for Indonesia and Thailand Tuesday, bringing with them more than three tons of medical and relief supplies.
On Wednesday, two medical groups, organized by the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation and the Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps headed for Sri Lanka to lend medical assistance.
On Wednesday, Premier Yu Shyi-kun also announced that the government will donate US$5 million to help tsunami-hit Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO WORD YET ON PREMIER NOMINATION, CONTRARY TO REPORT: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office dismissed a newspaper report Thursday that had claimed that Premier Yu Shyi-kun would step down and be replaced by Lin Hsin-i, the convener of an economic advisory team to the president.

The Department of Public Affairs of the Presidential Office sent text messages to all news media saying that President Chen Shui-bian has yet to finalize his lineup for the new Cabinet. The action was in response to a front-page report in the China Times that detailed the reshuffle.
The messages also asked that the media not report on wild speculation to avoid misunderstandings.

A ranking official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , speaking on condition of anonymity, also said that the candidate for premier will only become clearer after an overall consideration of several key posts.

He said that President Chen is focusing now on creating good relations between the ruling and opposition parties, and that this is currently more important than considerations on the makeup of the new Cabinet.

If the premiership is decided now, how can the DPP talk about cooperation with the People First Party (PFP), an ally of the largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), adding that the posts of DPP chairman, premier, and the speaker and the vice speaker of the Legislative Yuan will have to be taken into overall consideration.
There is still some time before the new Cabinet takes office on Feb. 1, he said. The more immediate task is to select a new chairman of the DPP, he added.

As Friday is the last day for registration for party chairman hopefuls, the president is bound to nominate a candidate, widely believed to be Premier Yu, he said. The legislature will then discuss major issues, such as the general budgets of the central government for next year. Only after taking care of all these things will the issue of who should head the Cabinet be addressed in earnest, he said.
Meanwhile, the KMT caucus whip in the legislature said that if the president nominates Lin as the new premier, the KMT will strenuously oppose the move.

Huang Teh-fu claimed that although in the past Lin served as a Minister of Economic Affairs, a chairman for the Council for Economic Planning and Development, and a vice premier, it was while on his watch as economics minister that Taiwan's economy began declining, in particular because of the suspension of the ongoing construction of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant in 2000, which caused a great deal of drag on the country's economy.

Responding to Huang, Ker Chien-ming, acting DPP chairman, said the ruling and opposition parties should put a halt to their bickering, adding that if the rivalry continues, regardless of who ends up being the next premier, no one will be able to work with him because of the fragmented nature of the political landscape.
Both the KMT and the PFP also criticized the reported nomination of Lin as an indication of the dearth of talented people in the DPP camp.

KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said that the premier Taiwan needs now must be capable of upgrading Taiwan's economy, bettering cross-strait relations and promoting harmony between the ruling and the opposition parties. It is "obvious that neither the core members nor the succession team of the DPP have this caliber of individual, " Chang said.

The KMT had foreseen this scenario and had recommended before the Dec. 11 legislative elections that Chiang Ping-kun, legislative vice speaker and a seasoned economic expert, head the Cabinet. Every poll has shown that Chiang meets all the conditions to be the next premier, Chang claimed.

Liu Wen-hsiung, PFP caucus whip, questioned the contributions of Lin during his stint as economics minister, asking if he had come up with any policies to address the hollowing out of Taiwan's industry and the shortage of talented people.
Liu said that if Lin really becomes the next premier, it will only show that the DPP had no one left to turn to.
Chiang Ping-kun, however, said that he was confident of Lin's financial background and his performance in various government posts, saying that he would be a "good premier."
KMT Chairman Lien Chan had suggested to President Chen that Chiang head the Cabinet, but Chiang said that if the position is not his, he will not " feel sorry."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOPES FOR EARLY RESTORATION OF TSUNAMI-HIT NATIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that it is his hope that tsunami-hit nations will get back on their feet as soon as possible with help from the international community.
Pointing out that a lot of civic groups from Taiwan have joined the rescue and relief effort, Chen said the disaster highlights both the fragility of human lives and the borderlessness of human love.
The president voiced his view on the matter in the latest issue of his online newsletter.

Chen recalled that Taiwanese rescue workers had been back in Taiwan less than a month after going to Turkey to help victims of an earthquake there when the deadly earthquake hit Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999 turning Taiwan from a rescuer to a victim.
A total of 38 rescue teams from 21 countries arrived in Taiwan to offer their help immediately after the catastrophe, Chen noted.
Chen said this experience shows that the world is like a big family and there is no way to tell when a disaster is going to occur.

While the boundary between countries is getting vaguer and vaguer today, civic organizations are more flexible and efficient than the government sector in terms of offering foreign aid and conducting international economic and cultural exchanges, Chen said.
For example, he said, Taiwan has for a long time helped its diplomatic allies in Africa turn deserts into paddy fields through various international cooperation projects.

He stressed there may be different realistic considerations as far as international politics is concerned, but the international community speaks a common language -- the pursuit of human well-being and peace.
As a member of the global village, Taiwan must positively contribute to the international community, he added.

Also on Thursday, a number of private and public organizations in Taiwan such as the Kaohsiung County Government, International Investment Trust Co. and the Splendor Hotel launched fund-raising drives to encourage their staff to donate one-day's pay to help the tsunami victims.

More than 80,000 people have been reported killed in tsunamis triggered by a 9.0-magnitude earthquake off Indonesia's Sumatra island on Sunday. In addition to Asian countries including Indonesia, Sri Lanka, India, Thailand, Myanmar, Malaysia, the Maldives and Bangladesh, the tsunamis also hit African nations such as Somalia and Kenya.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAN-BLUE LEADERS LOSE CASE TO ANNUL PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court threw out Thursday a case instituted by defeated presidential candidate Lien Chan and his running mate James Soong to invalidate the March 20 presidential election.
A panel of three High Court judges handed down the judgment, which is subject to appeal.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIA TO COMPLETE POST-DISASTER RECONSTRUCTION QUICKLY

TEXT.P: India should be able to complete post-disaster reconstruction soon, Vijay Gokhale, director general of the India-Taipei Association, said Thursday.

Gokhale said that Tamil Nadu, a state in coastal southeastern India, and the outlying Andaman Islands, were badly hit by tsunami triggered by a 9.0-magnitude earthquake under the Indian Ocean Sunday, resulting in heavy casualties, but otherwise, the impact of the catastrophe on India's overall economy is not great.

He expressed appreciation for the concern and assistance offered by the Taiwan government and civic groups, but stressed that except for assistance from the United Nations and other international relief organizations, India has no need for Taiwan's help.
India has embarked on disaster-relief and reconstruction work and should be able to deal with the aftermath with its own resources and manpower, he said.

Apart from Tamil Nadu and the Andaman Islands, scenic spots and other infrastructure in the country's other states remain intact, he said, urging Taiwan tourists and businessmen to have no fear of visiting.

All international and domestic airports, stations, and other public facilities in India are unaffected by the recent disaster and there are also no worries about health hazards, he assured Taiwan people.

He said the countries worst-hit by the lethal tidal waves are Indonesia, Sri Lanka and the Maldives. The Indian government has donated US$15 million to Sri Lanka and US$5 million to the Maldives for relief and post-disaster reconstruction.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen met with representatives in Taiwan of tsunami-hit nations, including India, Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand, Wednesday to find out what Taiwan can do to assist their countries.
Chen learned that Indonesia and Thailand are in urgent need of aid, especially coroners and medical supplies, while Malaysia and India do not require any foreign assistance for the time being.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Aid Flows Slowly Into Stricken Regions.
Disorganization hampers distribution of needed supplies as Asian tsunami's toll rises past 77,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING INTENDS TO CHANGE TAIWAN STRAIT STATUS QUO WITH LAW: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that mainland China's so-called anti-secession legislation is aimed at altering the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo and further thwarting the Republic of China's survival in the international community.
Chen made the remarks while addressing a ceremony to mark the promotion of 41 new generals in his capacity as commander-in-chief of the ROC armed forces.

Over the years, Chen said, the mainland has declined to renounce the option of using force against Taiwan and has never ceased its military maneuvers targeting Taiwan. Besides continuing to enhance its military spending and overall combat capabilities, Chen said, the mainland is now even working on a so-called anti-secession law aimed at changing the cross-strait status quo and blocking Taiwan's presence in the world arena.

Noting that mainland submarines can now reach waters within the "second island chain" of the Pacific Ocean covering the Kuriles, Hokkaido, the Marianas and Palau, Chen said Taiwan's security faces a grave threat and Asia-Pacific regional security is also at stake.

In the face of this new challenge, Chen said the ROC armed forces must speed up combat training and arsenal renovation to effectively deter any possible mainland invasion and ensure permanent peace in the Taiwan Strait.
Chen also took advantage of the occasion to appeal for public support for the government's NT$610.8 billion arms procurement project.

"Kuwait was once taken over by Iraqi forces in a very short period of time. We should learn from that lesson. Without advanced defensive weapons, we can't deter aggression, nor can we safeguard peace," Chen said.

The special budget bill for the massive arms procurement project is still pending legislative approval. Under the project, Taiwan intends to buy eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C Orion submarine-hunting aircraft and six PAC-III Patriot anti-missile batteries from the United States.

A total of 41 military officers will be promoted to the rank of general from Jan. 1. Among them, 11 will be promoted to either lieutenant-general or vice admiral and 30 will be promoted to either major general or rear admiral.

Meanwhile, Ministry of National Defense officials said 36 general-rank officers will retire or transfer to civilian positions in January. In addition, the officials said, 88 generals will change position in line with the ongoing military streamlining project.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S GDP GROWTH TO SLOW TO 4.05% IN 2005: ACADEMIA SINICA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) growth is expected to slow to 4.05 percent in 2005 owing to high raw material and oil prices, international interest rate hikes and appreciation of major currencies, according to an annual economic outlook report released Thursday by the Academia Sinica.
Citing a forecast by the International Monetary Fund, Academia Sinica economist Wu Chung-shu said the world GDP growth will rise to 5 percent in 2004 from the 3.9 percent of 2003.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's GDP growth will expand to 5.99 percent in 2004 from the 3.34 percent of 2003, Wu said.

Although the momentum of private investment will remain strong in Taiwan in 2005, international demand for exports from Taiwan is likely to dwindle because of high international raw material and oil prices, international interest rate hikes and appreciation of major currencies due to a weak U.S. dollar, Wu said.
These negative factors are thus likely to slow GDP growth to 4.05 percent in 2005, Wu said.

He predicted that the growth of private consumption will fall to 2.51 percent in 2005 from the 2.96 percent of 2004, while the growth of private investment will decline to 7.86 percent in 2005 from a high of 25.82 percent in 2004.

International oil prices are expected to stabilize and stand at US$37.25 per barrel in 2005, which will help Taiwan's consumer price index growth to drop slightly to 1.53 percent from the 1.58 percent of 2004, Wu said.

In terms of foreign trade, the growth in the export of Taiwan products and services will slide to 8.8 percent in 2005 from the 17.49 percent of 2004, while the growth in imports will shrink to 8.36 percent from the 19.65 percent of 2004, Wu said.
Meanwhile, he said, the tension across the Taiwan Strait and mainland China's measures to cool its overheating economy are also likely to affect Taiwan's economic performance in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.02 to close at NT$31.978.
A total of US$738 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.126 and dipped to a low of NT$31.950 during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND TEAM ARRIVES ON KINMEN TO INVESTIGATE DEPOT EXPLOSION

TEXT.P: A team of experts headed by Vice Chief of the General Staff Gen. Feng Shih-kuang arrived on the frontline island of Kinmen Thursday to inspect the cause of an explosion at two ammunition depots in an idle military barracks a day earlier.
The Neiyang military barracks has 11 ammunition depots, two of which exploded in the incident, military sources said. Fortunately, nobody was injured or killed in the blast.
The two depots had contained a total of 1,881 rounds of 81 mm mortars, 175 rounds of 60 mm mortars and an unspecified amount of machine gun bullets.
Initial investigations show that the blast might have been caused by the burning of weeds by civilians in the vicinity of the barracks, military sources said.
The first blast occurred at 4: 10 p.m. and sporadic explosions were still being heard at 9: 15 p.m. The military cordoned off the region and imposed traffic controls in the surrounding area.
According to the military's standard operation procedures, nobody can enter an explosion site within 24 hours of the last blast.
Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan Defense Committee meeting, Vice Defense Minister Hou Shou-yeh confessed to human negligence as being the cause of the incident.
Hou said the ministry will carefully investigate the cause of the explosion and adopt necessary measures to improve ammunition depot management.

DOC.HEADLINE: WATER, ELECTRICITY RATE HIKES REST WITH NEW CABINET: MOEA

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Thursday that electricity and water rates face pressure to be increased, but added that it will be up to the new Cabinet to decide if and when such hikes are made.
Ho made the remarks after she reported to the caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party about government policy on adjusting electricity and water rates.

She had said a day earlier that electricity and water rates will be raised, drawing immediate criticism from the opposition, but noted that Premier Yu Shyi-kun has said he will not address the issue during his term "out of consideration" for the burden of the people and the manufacturers, as well as to avoid stimulating price hikes of other consumer goods."
Yu is scheduled to lead his Cabinet in an en masse resignation Feb. 1, according to protocol, when the new Legislative Yuan is scheduled to be sworn in.

She said that sufficient funds are needed to maintain water and electricity supplies, that the rate hikes will be sent to the Legislative Yuan for review and that the Executive Yuan will respect the result of the review.
The various political parties responded to the rate hike proposals along party lines.

Tsai Huang-liang, caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said that the adjustment of water and electricity rates needs to be further considered and that a final decision has yet to be made.
But he also said that the rates must reasonably reflect costs, otherwise the national coffers will have to make up for any shortfalls and the taxpayers will eventually have to cover such losses.
However, the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said that it will pool the strength of the people to oppose to the rate hike proposal.
Huang Teh-fu, KMT caucus whip in the legislature, claimed that the number of poor people is increasing along with the economic slump, and that the KMT could therefore not accept a hike.

KMT legislator Chen Chieh also said that state-run businesses such as Taiwan Power Company and Chinese Petroleum Corp. have reported handsome profits, yet the government clamors for rate hikes, which he claimed has "caused panic" among the general public.

Liu Wen-hsiung, caucus whip of the People First Party, an ally of the KMT, said that when the legislature is reviewing the general budget of the central government, it will demand all related agencies not to hike the rates before a rigorous assessment has been made.

Liu said that his party will ask the government to immediately freeze all planned hikes in water, electricity, air and other transportation fares, as well as national health insurance premiums, or it will not rule out the possibility of mobilizing a rally to protest the hikes.

According to the Consumers' Foundation, the government's plan to raise water, electricity and transportation rates will impose an average additional spending of between NT$2,000 and NT$3,000 per month per person.

Foundation officials said that the Civil Aeronautics Administration has convened several meetings with air carriers to discuss air fare hikes, but the information concerning the cost of the air carriers has never been published and that such an air fare hike plan will seriously undermine the rights of consumers.
Ho said in a year-end press conference Wednesday that electricity rates will be raised by no more than NT$0.5 per unit, or one kilowatt/hour.

She said that Taiwan's electricity costs NT$2.07 per unit on average, which is far less than the NT$4.8 per unit in Japan, NT$3.74 per unit in Hong Kong, NT$3.56 per unit in the Philippines, and NT$2.13 per unit in South Korea.

She also argued that the increase in international oil prices has deriven up the cost of producing electricity and that the Taiwan Power Company is expected to lose NT$9 billion (US$281.95 million) next year if it does not adjust rates.

For the same reason, the price of water will also be raised, Ho said, arguing that Taiwan's water rates, now NT$10.77 per ton, are unreasonably cheap compared to NT$62.7 per ton in Germany, NT$56.7 per ton in Denmark, NT$17.5 per ton in the United States, and NT$14.4 per ton in Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT INVITES PUBLIC TO ATTEND FLAG-RAISING CEREMONY ON NEW YEAR'S DAY

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Thursday that it welcomes any members of the public who wish to attend a flag-raising ceremony in downtown Taipei Saturday to usher in the New Year.

KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said Thursday that the opposition-organized flag-raising ceremony will be held at the square of historic Zhongshan Hall, in view of the building's historical significance.
The ceremony will also feature a "young and dynamic" atmosphere, with youth bands and flag bands performing prior to the ceremony, Chang said.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan will then lead the crowd to sing the Republic of China national anthem, joined by a youth chorus, he continued.

A prayer activity will also be arranged for the representatives from all ethnic groups -- Hoklo, Hakka, aborigines and those who consider themselves to be of mainland Chinese descent -- to express their good wishes for the New Year, Chang added.
Meanwhile, the nation's official flag-raising ceremony will take place as usual in front of the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS TAIWANESE GROUP URGES BEIJING TO DROP ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 29 (CNA) (By Lilian Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: An overseas Taiwanese organization urged mainland China Wednesday to stop its efforts to enact an "anti-secession law" targeting Taiwan, branding it an attempt to unilaterally alter the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo.
The call was made in a joint statement released by several New York State branches of the Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace (GADP).
The law will be highly provocative because it will authorize a unilateral change in the status quo across the Taiwan Strait and intensify cross-strait tensions, according to the statement.

It pointed out that President Chen Shui-bian has repeatedly offered olive branches to the mainland to try to improve cross-strait relations after his re-election in March this year, but Beijing has ignored the goodwill and has continued to attack Taiwan.
The GADP noted that the Republic of China and the People's Republic of China have been two independent entities since 1949 and that this remains the status quo across the strait today.
Taiwan and the mainland should seek peaceful co-existence and avoid using force to destroy the status quo, it said.
By enacting the law, Beijing is trying to define the current status between Taiwan and the mainland as "unified " and to claim jurisdiction over Taiwan, according to the GADP.
The law will accept unification as the only outcome of cross-strait negotiations, with all other scenarios subject to punishment, it said.
Also, it added, Beijing's bid to introduce the law exhibits its intention to invade Taiwan because the law will authorize the launch of military action against the country.
The National People's Congress of China is expected to vote on a draft of the law during its full session scheduled for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 12.37 points to close at 6,100.86.
The bourse opened at 6,109.98 and fluctuated between 6,117.66 and 6,087.32 during trading. A total of 3.51 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$66.89 billion (US$2.09 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 2.1 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.4 percent, cement stocks and textile stocks both at 0.3 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.2 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.1 percent.
Only one of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 362 to 331, with 185 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January lost three points to close at 6,115, with 12,968 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February moved up four points to finish at 6,120, with 87 contracts traded, while March futures gained 16 points to finish at 6,120, with two contracts traded.
June futures gained 13 points to finish at 6,100, with nine contracts traded, while September futures moved down nine points to close at 6,002, with 12 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,118 for January, 6,116 for February, 6,104 for March, 6,087 for June and 6,011 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.
January TE futures moved down 0.35 points to close at 227.9, with 1,512 contracts traded, while February TE futures lost 0.3 points to finish at 228, with 14 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.
January TF futures lost 1.8 points to finish at 1,028.2, with 2,678 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved down 1.2 points to end at 1,028, with 45 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST COMMERCIAL WIND POWER PLANT BEGINS OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun presided Thursday over the opening of a commercial wind power plant in Shihmen village, Taipei County, calling its operations a display of the government's resolve to make Taiwan nuclear power-free.

Claiming that the start of the plant's operations means a stride closer by the government toward its goal of building Taiwan into a nuclear-free country, Yu said that the plant will also stand tall as a new landmark in the scenic northeast coastal area.

The Shihmen wind power plant, the first of its kind in Taiwan for purely commercial purposes, has six power-generating units with a combined capacity of nearly 100 million kilowatt-hours per year that will help reduce the emission of more than 8,600 tons of carbon dioxide each year and replace some 3,820 tons of fuel coal.

According to the premier, the government earmarks around NT$3 billion (US$93.75 million) each year for the research and development of alternative energies in line with a global drive to reduce the emission of carbon dioxide as obliged by the Kyoto Protocol that will take effect next year in most of the world's developed countries.
Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh and Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) Chairman Lin Ching-chi were also present at the opening.

Echoing Yu's remarks, Lin said that the state-run Taipower has been devoted to the development of alternative energy sources and he pointed out that the company is determined to increase the portion of its power generated by recyclable energy sources from the current level of 5.4 percent to 10 percent in 2010.
Taipower has been advocating wind force power and is planning to establish 400 sets of equipment capable of generating 600,000 kilowatts per year, Lin said.
The Shihmen wind power plant is the first completed by Taipower out of its planned first-stage installation of 60 sets of power-generating facilities by the end of 2006.
Construction of the plant kicked off in December 2003 at a cost of about NT$200 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW `CRUCIAL VARIABLE' IN TRIANGULAR TIES: ROC ENVOY

TEXT.P: If mainland China insists on enacting a so-called anti-secession law targeting Taiwan, it would be a "crucial variable" in the delicate triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations, the top ROC envoy in the United States said Wednesday.

Speaking at a year-end gathering with Chinese-language reporters stationed in the U.S. capital, David Ta-wei Lee said both Taiwan and the United States think the timing is not right for mainland China to legislate such a law at the moment.
Noting that the anti-secession legislation marks a unilateral move to alter the Taiwan Strait status quo, Lee said Beijing should stop before it commits a serious blunder.
According to Lee, the U.S. authorities informed the Republic of China representative office right after they found out about Beijing's plan.
Both sides have since kept close contact and have fully discussed the issue, Lee said, adding that both Taiwan and the United States see no need for Beijing to enact such a bill.
"Now is also not the right time for Beijing to work on such a piece of legislation," Lee said.

Beijing announced its plan to legislate an anti-secession law Dec. 17 and Lee said that if Beijing goes ahead with its plan, that day will mark a "turning point" in the development of the delicate triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations. He did not elaborate.

Pointing out that a resumption of cross-strait dialogue is the most important factor in the triangular ties, Lee said the chances for cross-strait dialogue would be even slimmer if Beijing were to push ahead with its plan.

Touching on Taiwan-U.S. relations, Lee dismissed as "incorrect" speculation that some recent statements by U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell and Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage might signal a backtracking of U.S. commitment to Taiwan or a change in U.S. policy toward Taiwan.

Lee said both Powell and Armitage have been and are still Taiwan's good friends. Some controversial words uttered during media interviews were just "slips of the tongue," Lee said, adding that the U.S. authorities have consistently assured him that their policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged and that their security commitment remains valid.
Asked who will represent Taiwan at President George W. Bush's upcoming inauguration ceremony for a second term, Lee said he was not in a position to make an announcement.
"It should be announced by our government in Taipei, " Lee said, adding that the representative will certainly be a high-level politician.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng headed the Taiwan delegation to Bush's 2000 inauguration ceremony but Lee would not reveal whether Wang will be the chief delegate this time around, although he stressed that the representative's level will definitely not fall below that of Wang.

As to Vice President Annette Lu's application to make a weeklong transit stay in the United States on her way to visit the ROC's diplomatic allies in Central and South America, Lee said the representative office is still negotiating the visa issue with the U.S. authorities and that no conclusion had been reached.

DOC.HEADLINE: 40.04% SATISFIED WITH PRESIDENT'S PERFORMANCE: POLL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's approval rating stood at 40.04 percent as of Thursday, according to the results of a public opinion poll released that day.
The telephone poll of 1,068 randomly chosen residents around Taiwan was conducted by Shih Hsin University from Dec. 22-27, with a margin of error of 3 percent.
According to the survey, 40.04 percent of the respondents said they were satisfied with Chen's performance, compared to 53 percent who gave a thumbs-down to his performance.
Vice President Annette Lu's approval rating was 36.6 percent, compared to a disapproval rating of 49.1 percent.
Nearly 53 percent of those interviewed said they were content with Premier Yu Shyi-kun's performance, while 37.5 percent said otherwise.
The respondents were divided over the performance of the Cabinet as a whole, with 46.7 percent giving a thumbs-up and 44.5 percent giving a negative evaluation.

By individual Cabinet members' performance, Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan received the top rating, followed by Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan, Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lang, Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan, Department of Health Minister Chen Chien-jen, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, Minister of Finance Lin Chuan, Council of Hakka Affairs Chairman Lo Wen-jia and Government Information Office Director-General Lin Chia-lung, in that order.
The poll also found 52.2 percent to be satisfied with their present livelihoods, compared to 42.4 percent who said they were dissatisfied with their present life.
Nevertheless, only 39.4 percent said they were optimistic about their future, while 50.0 percent said they were pessimistic.
Meanwhile, 59.5 percent said they support a proposal that incumbent Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng continue to head the next legislature, to be inaugurated Feb. 1, 2005.
About 50 percent said they were satisfied with the performance of the outgoing legislature, compared to 32.1 percent who gave a negative assessment; nearly 18 percent did not express an opinion.

According to the poll, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party received a support rating of 25.6 percent, the main opposition Kuomintang's support rating was 25 percent, the People First Party had a support rating of 6.52 percent and the Taiwan Solidarity Union's support rating was 3.12 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL BANK RAISES KEY INTEREST RATES

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) raised key interest rates Thursday by an eighth of a percentage point (0.125 percentage point) in an effort to combat increased inflationary pressure in the domestic market.
The CBC made the interest rate hike announcement following a meeting of its board of directors, putting a damper on rampant speculation that the central bank might not do so.
The increase will lift the CBC's re-discount rate to 1.75 percent. One-year short term rate and rate on accommodation with collateral will stand at 4 percent and 2.125 percent, respectively.

Speaking at a news conference in the wake of the meeting, CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan stressed that the move was made in order to maintain domestic product prices as inflationary pressure is mounting in the face of imminent raises in public utilities early next year, such as bus and air fares, as well as water and electricity rates.

Citing a forecast by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Perng said that the domestic economy and consumer product prices will expand by 4.56 percent and by about 2 percent, respectively, in 2005.

In an effort to ease speculation over soaring product prices, the central bank decided to make the move to help stem looming inflation, he said, adding that "the country's interest rates should be adjusted upward to normal levels."
The impact of the hike on domestic companies should be limited, as Taiwan's interest rates are still relatively low, he pointed out.
It is the second time the CBC has raised its key interest rates this year. It first lifted its rates by a quarter percentage point in late December.

Meanwhile, Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) -- the country's top economic policy planner -- said at a year-end news conference that his council will do its best to keep the growth rate of the consumer price index below 2 percent for the whole of next year.

As long as international oil prices can be controlled at a price below US$35 per barrel next year, it will be easier to bring down product prices in the domestic market and also possible for the CEPD to meet its target, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP LEADERS LOSE CASE TO ANNUL PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and his running mate in the March 20 presidential race, People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong suffered another setback Thursday after a court threw out a case they brought to invalidate the March 20 presidential election.

A panel of three judges from the Taiwan High Court said in the judgment that the grounds on which the two plaintiffs claimed the presidential election should be invalidated could not stand up in court.

In the reasoning behind its judgment, the judges said that although the plaintiffs claimed there were more than 900,000 ballots issued to voters inappropriately by election workers, a review of the electoral rolls found that only 3,700 ballots were given out in questionable situations.
Even all these ballots were considered invalid it would not reverse the results of the outcome of the election in which President Chen Shui-bian won by a margin of 29,518 votes, the judgment said.

As to the plaintiffs' claims that the first national referendum, held concurrently with the presidential election, gave Chen an unfair advantage, the court said that whether the referendum and presidential election could be held simultaneously should be determined by the Council of Grand Justices through an interpretation of the Constitution.
The court said it would be difficult anyway to determine that Chen's campaign was unfairly boosted by the referendum.

Citing opinion polls conducted before the elections that showed Lien and Soong were ahead of Chen and Chen's running mate Annette Lu, the court said these surveys further contradicted the plaintiffs' claims.

The Central Election Commission (CEC) , which organized the election and referendum and thereby became the defendant in the case, was ordered to hold the referendum and the presidential election at the same time, and there is no evidence that it failed to do its job fairly, according to the judgment.

The court also did not agree with the plaintiffs argument that by conducting the referendum and election simultaneously, the secrecy of the vote, which is enshrined in law, was compromised, as most supporters of Lien and Soong did not even vote in the referendum -- upon Lien's instructions.

In regard to the mysterious shooting of Chen on the eve of election day, the court said there is no evidence to substantiate the plaintiffs' claim that the government kept an unreasonably large number of police and military personnel on duty as a result of the shooting, thereby stripping them of their right to vote.

The court acknowledged the plaintiffs' claims that 35 polling stations around the island mistakenly issued ballots in the presidential elections based on the rolls meant for the referendum, but pointed out that the rolls were found to be the same as the electoral rolls and therefore would not have affected the results of the election anyway.
Lee Tsung-teh, the leading attorney for Lien and Soong, decried the judgment as "not being grounded on law" but refused to say whether his client will appeal against it.
Chang Shih-hsing, the attorney for the CEC, said he was pleased with the judgment, which vindicates the country's 180,000 election workers.
Chen Chi-mai, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan, urged the KMT and PFP to accept the court's judgment and stop trying to overthrow the results of the presidential election.
Chen said the two opposition parties should devote their energy to promoting the wellbeing of the public rather than keeping struggling against the people's choice.
Hsieh Gung-bing, a spokesman for the PFP, condemned the judgment as a travesty of justice and of having "disappointed the public."

PFP official Chang Hsieh-yao said the court had breached the six-month time required by the law for the court to pass down a judgment in such a case, as the lawsuit was instituted by the plaintiffs April 5.

He also accused the judges for failing in their duties, arguing that they asked the plaintiffs to substantiate their claims with evidence rather than investigating the suspicious points by themselves.
Tseng Yung-chuan, director of the KMT Central Policy Coordination Committee, blamed the court for being cowardly and afraid of standing up against the people in power.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 31, or the 20th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1799: The Dutch Administration in Batavia (now Jakarta) takes over the Dutch East India Company's territories in Indonesia.
1879: Thomas A. Edison, American inventor, demonstrates for the first time his electric incandescent light at Menlo Park, New Jersey.
1880: George Marshall, U.S. Army general and statesman, is born. As secretary of state, he devised the Marshall Plan for post-war economic recovery in Europe.
1909: The Manhattan Bridge, a two-section suspension bridge, is opened to traffic in New York.
1915: Yuan Shih-kai, who promised to establish a republican government when he assumed the provisional presidency of the Republic of China, orders the restoration of the imperial system, with himself on the throne, beginning from 1916.
1919: The United States, Britain, and Japan sign an agreement on East Siberia.
1924: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who had fallen ill earlier, arrives in Peking from Tientsin to hold talks with Tuan Chi-jui, provisional chief executive of the Peking-based government. While in Peking, Dr. Sun succumbed to liver cancer and died on March 25, 1925.
1946: U.S. President Harry S. Truman officially proclaims the end of World War II.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek reiterates the government's policy of continuing attempts to settle disputes with the communists by political means.
1946: Chang Hsueh-liang, the commander of the Northeastern Army who played a key role in the kidnapping of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in Xian, is escorted to Taiwan and put under house arrest at the Chingshang hot spring in Hsinchu. The Xian Incident was a severe setback to Chiang's efforts to subjugate the communists.
1956: President Sukarno proclaims a state of siege in Sumatra, Indonesia.
1964: President Sukarno threatens to quit the United Nations if Malaysia is given a seat on the Security Council.
1971: Kurt Waldheim of Austria takes over as the United Nations secretary-general after U Thant retired.
1975: More than 1,600 foreign students present an autographed album to Premier Chiang Ching-kuo at a year-end meeting.
1976: Education Minister Y. S. Tsiang hosts a dinner to honor foreign students and visiting professors at the Chientan Youth Activity Center with more than 1,000 students and teachers from 30 countries attending.
1977: Cambodia breaks off diplomatic relations with Vietnam and suspends all air services between the two countries.
1979: The Sino-U.S. Mutual Defense Treaty against the Chinese communists in the area is ended.
1983: The United States deploys Cruise missiles and Pershing II missiles in Britain and West Germany.
1985: The Taipei World Trade Center is inaugurated.
1988: Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto sign the first agreement between India and Pakistan in 16 years, agreeing not to attack each others' nuclear facilities.
1991: All senior delegates to the ROC's First National Assembly, Control Yuan, and Legislative Yuan retire from office.
1996: Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong submits his resignation to Premier Lien Chan.
1997: Mohammed Rafiq Tarar becomes the ninth president of Pakistan.
1998: Finance ministers of the European Union announce definite rates for converting the currencies of the 11 nations due to launch the single euro currency on Jan. 1, 1999.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui calls for increased constructive dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Straits on an equal footing so as to contribute to peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian calls on Beijing leaders to try to break through the existing cross-strait stalemate with open-mindedness and forward-looking vision so as to jointly establish a mechanism for permanent peace and political integration of Taiwan and the mainland.
2001: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) issues operational certificates to seven financial holding companies, the first batch of its kind in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only men of moral character who know how to love men or to hate men. If you fix your mind upon a moral life, you will be free from evil."

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP PRESIDENTIAL AIDE SU TSENG-CHANG COULD BE NEW DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: If President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff is elected as the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) new chairman, he could hold both positions concurrently, party sources said Friday.

President Chen stepped down as DPP chairman to take responsibility for the party's poorer than expected showing in the Dec. 11 legislative elections. If Su Tseng-chang is elected the new chairman, he would take over the position on Feb. 1, 2005, the sources said.
Since the DPP chairmanship is not a full-time job, Su could retain his post as secretary-general at the Presidential Office, the sources added.

Su, formerly a magistrate of Taiwan's largest county, Taipei County, and a charismatic figure who has a broad support base, is on the DPP shortlist as a possible contender in the next presidential election in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEMPERATURE COULD FALL TO 5 DEGREES IN NORTHERN TAIWAN TONIGHT

TEXT.P: The mercury in the Taiwan area has dropped sharply since Friday morning as a cold front from northern China approaches, with temperatures expecting to plummet to 5 degrees Celsius at the coldest between Friday night and Sunday morning, the Central Weather Bureau reported.

Friday through Sunday is expected to have the coldest weather yet this year due to the cold snap, weather bureau forecasters said, adding that temperatures in northern Taiwan and the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu are forecast to fall to around 5 degrees Celsius.
The weather bureau called for the farming and fishery sectors to guard against frost damage, particularly operations located at higher elevations.

Ice pellets formed on Mt. Tatun in Taipei's northern suburb Friday morning, serving as an indication that snow was likely, the weather bureau meteorologists said, adding that snow is likely in the Yangmingshan area, which includes Mt. Tatun, if the humidity in the following hours is high enough.
As of 1: 00 p.m. Friday, traffic controls were put into place on Yangteh Blvd. -- the main road to Yangmingshan -- to stem the expected rush of people eager to catch a glimpse of snow.

Friday morning, the lowest temperature in low-lying areas around Taiwan was recorded in Tamshui, Taipei County, at 7.2 degrees Celsius. It has been snowing for two days in the mountainous areas, including Mt. Jade and Mt. Hehuanshan, meteorologists reported.

Meanwhile, the weather bureau also called for fishing boats operating on the seas to the north and northeastern of Taiwan, as well as in the Taiwan Strait, to be watchful against strong winds and high tides as a strong northeast monsoon is sweeping in.

DOC.HEADLINE: YU CABINET TO RESIGN EN MASSE JAN. 21
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Dec. 31 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Cabinet is scheduled to resign en masse Jan. 21, the day that the Legislative Yuan wraps up its current session, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday.
Yu said that when the Legislative Yuan concludes its session Jan. 21, the Executive Yuan will submit its resignation en masse on the same day, following a constitutional tradition.
The fifth legislature is scheduled to go into history Jan. 31 although its legislative operations will end Jan. 21. The new, or the sixth legislature, is scheduled to begin working Feb. 1, 2005.
Noting that the Executive Yuan under his leadership will spare no efforts to continue to serve the country until Jan. 21, Yu said that operations of this governmental "apparatus" will never cease.
Yu made the remarks during a "light-opening and enshrinement" ceremony marking the opening of a Buddhist museum in downtown Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP PRESIDENTIAL AIDE RESIGNS AHEAD OF DPP CHAIRMANSHIP VOTE

TEXT.P: Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang submitted his resignation to President Chen Shui-bian Friday immediately after Su signed up to run for chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Su, who is likely to be elected the next DPP chairman in the upcoming DPP by-election for a new party leader, said that he is determined to completely focus his energy and time on party affairs rather than going back and forth between two jobs.
DPP party sources said earlier in the day that Su could hold both positions concurrently as the president's chief of staff and as DPP chairman since the chairmanship is not a full-time job.

President Chen stepped down as DPP chairman recently to take responsibility for the party's poorer than expected showing in the Dec. 11 legislative elections. If Su is elected the new chairman, he would take over the position on Feb. 1, 2005.

A charismatic figure who has a broad support base after serving for years as magistrate of Taiwan's largest county, Taipei County, Su went to the DPP headquarters Friday morning to register for the chairmanship by-election with his wife and their three adult daughters, as well as with DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung.

Echoing President Chen's remarks that democratic politics are tantamount to party politics, Su said that he made a promise to himself that if he is elected DPP chairman, he will see to it that the DPP becomes a better party, one which is more capable of meeting the people's needs and delivering on its promises.
Meanwhile, Su said that as far as he knows, President Chen has not yet decided who will be the next premier or who will succeed him as the top presidential aide.
The Cabinet, led by Premier Yu Shyi-kun, is scheduled to resign en masse Jan. 21, several days prior to the last day of the fifth legislature's term.
