DOC.HEADLINE: TSU WILL NOT JOIN A DPP-PFP ALLIANCE: TSU WHIP

TEXT.P: An influential Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) lawmaker said Friday that if the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (PFP) forms an alliance with the People First Party (PFP), his party will not join.
Chen Chien-ming, deputy convener of the TSU legislative caucus, said that as the DPP's ally, the TSU can understand why the DPP has to cooperate with the PFP on major policy issues.

Over the past four years, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the PFP, which controls a slim majority in the current Legislative Yuan, has blocked the DPP administration's reform agenda nearly at every turn.

Following the Dec. 11 legislative elections, relations between the two "pan-blue alliance" parties soured over a combination of factors. Against this backdrop, there has been speculation that the DPP may turn to the PFP for cooperation in the new legislature. Should that be the case, the DPP administration will have a working majority in the 225-seat legislature, with the DPP holding 89 seats and the PFP controlling 34 seats.

Noting that party realignments are not uncommon in democratic countries, Chen said the TSU, which will have 12 seats in the new legislature to be inaugurated Feb. 1, can understand the rationale of the proposed DPP-PFP cooperation on some policy issues.
Nevertheless, he said, the TSU will not join such a new alliance. The TSU will insist on playing the role of an opposition party, Chen added.
He also reminded the DPP not to forget its promise to its supporters to promote Taiwan's separate identity from China.
In Taiwan's political spectrum, the DPP and the TSU are generally branded as pro-independence while the KMT and the PFP adopt a more reconciliatory stance toward mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS CAN BE BASED ON 2003 MODEL: MAC

TEXT.P: Cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday for Taiwan businessmen working in mainland China could be modeled after similar services that were put into place in 2003, an official in charge of mainland China policy said Friday.

Liu Teh-shun, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , made the remarks after the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said that it would work to see if it could secure the flights. Chinese Lunar New Year's Day falls on Feb. 9, 2005.
Liu said that the MAC has repeatedly tried to get the mainland side to come to the table and talk about the charter flights but to no avail.
With only a little more than a month before Chinese New Year Day, he suggested using the 2003 model in which the government coordinated with air carriers to organize the flights.

With Beijing's consent, Taiwan carriers operated one-way, special charter flights between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau during the 2003 Chinese New Year holiday. The services were not offered the following year because Beijing insisted that mainland carriers also be allowed to provide the same flight services but refused to negotiate the necessary technical details with Taiwan.
Liu said that if Taiwan businessmen believe that more cities should be included in the services, the MAC is willing to consult with air carriers to expand the services to Guangzhou and Beijing.
If mainland air carriers want to apply to Taiwan for charter flights, then the operations will be more complex in that both sides would need to consult each other to come to an agreement.

The KMT legislative caucus said in a news conference earlier Friday that the government has not actively promoted the charter flights and that the KMT will step in and take control in paving the way for the services to be opened.
KMT Legislator Tseng Yung-chuan noted that many Taiwan businessmen in the mainland have expressed their interest in the flights to the KMT caucus.

"Since the government is incapable of accomplishing this task, the KMT legislative caucus will take over, " Tseng said, adding that the KMT caucus and six Taiwan air carriers will go to the mainland next week to communicate with air carriers there.

KMT Legislator John Chang said that if the cross-strait charter flights can be implemented during the Chinese New Year holiday, it will not only ease cross-strait tensions but will also establish a model for direct cross-strait flights.
He said he hoped that Taiwan businessmen, their dependents, students and tourists who hold Republic of China passports and valid travel documents can use the service.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILLS TO PROBE KMT ASSETS PUT ON FAST TRACK

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan put three bills aimed at investigating the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) alleged ill-gotten assets on the fast track Friday.

Legislators agreed that the bills, proposed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) and People First Party (PFP), will skip a committee review procedure and enter the second reading directly.
Inter-party consultations will be held to seek to integrate the three versions before the second reading, according to the legislature's decision.

However, it remains highly uncertain as to whether any of the bills will be passed by the end of the current legislature, which ends Jan. 21, with the KMT insisting on opposing the enactment of any law that it believes is designed to "liquidate" the party.
Huang Teh-fu, whip of the KMT legislative caucus, said the fact that the KMT did not obstruct Friday's proceeding does not mean it supports the law.
Huang dismissed the DPP-proposed and TSU-proposed bills as violating the principles of democracy and the rule of law for being retroactive and based on a "presumption of guilt."
Huang said his party will have the bills killed by dragging out the inter-party consultations.
According to law, any bills that are not passed at the end of a legislative term will be scrapped. The final session of the current legislature is set to run through Jan. 21.
Tseng Yung-chuan, head of the KMT's Policy Committee, said the KMT believes that assets of political parties should be regulated by a political parties law.
Tseng said his party supports the PFP-proposed bill and hopes the bill could be considered together with the political parties bill put forth by the KMT.

In view of the KMT's plan to delay the party assets law, TSU legislative caucus chief Chen Chien-ming demanded that inter-party consultations on the three bills be started next Monday to ensure that some form of legislation is passed within the current legislative session.
Lu Hsueh-chang, deputy convener of the PFP legislative caucus, said whether or not a law will be passed this session depends on the KMT's attitude on reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved down against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, giving up NT$0.061 to close at NT$31.917.
A total of US$1.189 billion changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.978 and slid to a low of NT$31.500 during the trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 38.83 points to close at 6,139.69.
The bourse opened at 6,118.63 and fluctuated between 6,160.96 and 6,077.51 during trading. A total of 4.25 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$613.96 billion (US$19.24 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 1.4 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 0.9 percent, foodstuff issues and textile stocks both at 0.8 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.7 percent and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.
The two other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down at 1 percent and plastics and chemicals shares losing 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 451 to 258, with 177 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREE AIDS TESTS DURING PREGNANCY TO KICK OFF NATIONWIDE JAN. 1

TEXT.P: Beginning Jan. 1, 2005, the government will provide AIDS tests at no cost to pregnant women nationwide in an effort to prevent mother-to-child HIV transmission, the Department of Health (DOH) reported Friday.

All pregnant women living in the Republic of China, regardless of whether they are covered by the national health insurance program, are welcome to go to a hospital for a free AIDS test, officials from the DOH's Center for Disease Control (CDC) said.
According to CDC tallies, there have been 11 "AIDS babies" in Taiwan as of Nov. 30. All mothers of these HIV-positive infants had not received any AIDS tests.

Of these babies, CDC officials said, one case was discovered only after the mother and child were required to receive an AIDS test at the time when the child's father was dying of AIDS. The man did not tell his wife about his illness so the mother was totally in the dark and had no idea that she and her baby were HIV-positive, too.

CDC Director-General Kuo Hsu-sung noted that roughly 220,000 new babies are born in Taiwan annually. If all pregnant women receive the free AIDS test during their pregnancy, about 30 women should be identified as being HIV-positive.

If the HIV-positive women are in turn treated with antiretroviral drugs during their pregnancy, particularly during the most critical first three months of pregnancy, the chances of their babies contracting the virus from their mothers will be significantly lowered, Kuo added.

In addition, Kuo said, the costs for examining all of the country's pregnant women will be relatively much cheaper than treating AIDS patients. It will cost about NT$40 million a year for the nationwide free AIDS tests, while each AIDS patient needs about NT$14 million throughout his or her life.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January gained 73 points to close at 6,188, with 29,454 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February moved up 65 points to finish at 6,185, with 165 contracts traded, while March futures gained 46 points to finish at 6,161, with 20 contracts traded.
June futures gained 50 points to finish at 6,150, with seven contracts traded, while September futures moved up 78 points to close at 6,080, with 23 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,115 for January, 6,120 for February, 6,115 for March, 6,100 for June and 6,002 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

January TE futures moved up three points to close at 230.9, with 3,109 contracts traded, while February TE futures gained 2.4 points to finish at 230.4, with 30 contract transactions. March TE futures gained 2.15 points to close at 229.3, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

January TF futures gained 17.8 points to finish at 1,046, with 6,264 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved up 14.6 points to end at 1,042.6, with 173 contracts traded. March TF futures gained 17.2 points to finish at 1,043, with seven contracts changing hands, while June TF futures moved up 8.4 points to close at 1,033, with one contract transaction. September TF futures gained 10.2 points to finish at 1,033, with two contracts changing hands.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG SHOULD DEVELOP OWN FEATURES: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday that the potential of Kaohsiung is immense and that it should develop its own distinctive features rather than trying to copy those of Taipei.
The premier made the remarks as he inspected a military barracks, part of which will be converted to a park in the southern port city.

Noting that there are legislators who have suggested that some central government agencies be moved to Kaohsiung, or even that the Presidential Office be relocated there to help its development, the premier said that government agencies such as the Council of Labor Affairs and the Council of Agriculture could indeed be relocated to Kaohsiung, but there are still a dozen other government agencies in Taipei and Kaohsiung would still not be comparable to Taipei in that respect.
After the proposed park and other major construction projects are completed, Kaohsiung will definitely be "ahead of Taipei, " he claimed.

"Kaohsiung has immense potential and can develop its own distinctive features, " Yu said, adding that it will not have to rely on the relocation of the Presidential Office, a task he said could take more than a decade if it were ever to be implemented.

Yu was accompanied to the Weiwu barracks by Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan, Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) Chairman Chen Chi-nan, Vice National Defense Minister Huo Shou-yeh, and Vice Transportation and Communications Minister Tsai Tuei.

The proposed park will be home to a southern Taiwan artistic and cultural center with a national concert hall and a national theater, which the premier said will be even better than those in Taipei and will be on a par with international standards.

The premier said that the budget for the center is about NT$8 billion (US$250 million) , which has been included into the nation's five-year, NT$500 billion (US$15.625 billion), "10 Major Construction Projects" program, although it has yet to be screened by the Legislative Yuan.
Pre-construction work of an investigation of historic sites and old trees will cost NT$200 million that will come from other government agencies.
The premier expressed hope that construction can start in 2006 and be completed in 2008 or 2009.

He pointed out that President Chen Shui-bian attaches great importance to the balanced development of northern and southern Taiwan and said he hopes the CCA will work closely with Kaohsiung county and city governments so that the center will be even better than those in Taipei.
The CCA is scheduled to finalize the sites of the concert and theater halls next May.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI 101 OFFICIALLY OPENS

TEXT.P: The world's tallest skyscraper, Taipei 101, officially opened Friday.

President Chen Shui-bian, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou were invited to the opening ceremony and offered a ride on the building's high-speed elevator to an observatory on the 89th floor.

Diana Chen, chairwoman of the Taipei Financial Center Corp., which owns the building, said it was a moment of pride and thankfulness to see "the world's tallest and best building" finally completed after six years of construction.
Chen said her company hopes to share the joy with all the people in Taiwan and the world.
The Taipei 101 project, comprising a main office tower and a shopping mall, broke ground in January 1998. The shopping mall opened in November 2003.
The 508-meter building was certified by the Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat as the tallest in the world in October.

It has the world's two fastest elevators, which move at 1,010 meters per minute, and the world's biggest and heaviest tuned mass damper that stabilizes the building against earthquakes, typhoons and high wind.

A series of events have been held over the past week to heat up its official inauguration, which included French "Spiderman" Alain Robert being hauled up the side of the building on the end of a rope Dec. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOLLOWS POPE'S CALL TO HELP TSUNAMI VICTIMS IN ASIA
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Dec. 31 (CNA) (By Tony Fang & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Following Pope John Paul's call to help tsunami victims in South and Southeast Asia, Taiwan donated US$10,000 Tuesday to the Pontifical Council "Cor Unum" for relief operations, officials of the Republic of China Embassy at the Vatican said Friday.
On behalf of the ROC government, the embassy delivered the donation to the Vatican's branch of humanitarian action, the officials said.
Taiwan is willing to participate in international relief and charity operations, the officials noted, adding that benevolence should have no boundaries.
What Taiwan is trying to achieve is "wherever there are needy people, there is love from Taiwan," they continued.

A great number of casualties and property losses have been reported in several South and Southeast Asian nations, including India, Sri Lanka, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand and the Maldives, after they were hit by tsunami triggered by a 9.0-magnitude earthquake off the Indonesian island of Sumatra Dec. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MEDICAL TEAM ARRIVES IN NIAS

TEXT.P: Members of a national-level medical team dispatched by Taiwan arrived Friday on the Indonesian island of Nias to inspect the aftermath of the tsunami that hit various countries around the Indian Ocean Sunday.
The team members were expected to decide later in the day whether to work in the worst-hit Aceh Province on Sumatra or on Nias, which lies about 125 km off western Sumatra.
The 11-member team arrived in Medan, the capital of North Sumatra Province, a day earlier.
According to local officials, more than 2,000 residents on Nias have been affected by the disaster, with more than 100 killed and 31 others reported missing.
As diseases such as cholera and malaria have broken out among the residents, the island is in dire need of doctors and medical supplies, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIFTING OF DAILY CEILING FOR SHARE PRICES ON TAIEX INEVITABLE: FSC

TEXT.P: A lifting of the daily ceiling of 7 percent for the rise and fall of share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange is inevitable, the chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission under the Executive Yuan said Friday.

Kung Chao-sheng said at a year-end press conference that there will be a number of new measures put into practice March 1, including no limitation on the daily ceiling of the rise and fall of share prices in the first five days for first-time-listed or over-the-counter stocks on the Taiwan Stock Exchange.
Kung said that new measures are being made in view of international trends.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DECLARES WAR ON DRUGS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday his administration will step up a crackdown on drug abuse and trafficking in the coming three years for the sake of protecting citizens' health.
Chen made the announcement while attending a ceremony marking the conclusion of a pre-job training program for new Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) staff.

Noting that contraband drug seizures reached a 10-year high of 8,400 kg in 2004, Chen said the figure indicates the law enforcement officers' achievements on the one hand but the seriousness of Taiwan's drug problem on the other.
In the face of the situation, Chen said, the government is determined to designate 2005-2008 as a period for an intensified campaign against drug abuse and trafficking.

Chen said relevant government agencies have also drafted a joint operation plan to fight against illegal narcotics and he expressed hope that MJIB investigators can cooperate closely with other law enforcement officers in all anti-drug operations.

Meanwhile, Chen outlined three other most important tasks for the Investigation Bureau -- fighting against corruption to establish clean politics; upgrading forensic investigation technology; and abiding by due procedure in criminal investigations.
Chen said Taiwan ranks 35th in the 2004 global clean politics rating compiled by Transparency International -- a leading non-governmental organization dedicated to combating corruption.

"The rating indicates that there is still ample room for Taiwan to improve its political transparency and accountability, " Chen said, adding that he hopes the MJIB can further intensify investigations into official corruption and vote-buying.
With fast developments in forensic science, Chen said, Taiwan must speed up the establishment of a world-class laboratory for scientific tests to facilitate criminal investigations.

He also stressed the importance of abiding by legal procedure in criminal investigations in order to protect the human rights of those subject to questioning and investigation. "Justice cannot be served if we fail to follow due procedure," he added.

The president also took advantage of the occasion to express his doubts about the higher-than-average voter turnout in three counties -- Changhua, Yunlin and Pingtung -- in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

"Many people told me that vote-buying was very rampant in those three counties, which also registered the nation's three highest voter turnout rates in the just-concluded legislative elections. I wonder whether there is a direct relationship between vote-buying and the high voter turnout, " Chen said, adding that he hopes law enforcement authorities can make further investigations into all suspicious vote-buying cases and review their work strategies in order to enhance operational efficiency.

The average voter turnout in the Dec. 11 legislative elections was a record low of about 59 percent, while Changhua's voter turnout reached 68 percent, Yunlin's was 64 percent and Pingtung's was 62 percent.

Chen originally expected the two "pan-green camp" parties -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- to jointly win a majority in the elections. However, the two parties failed to reach the target, leading Chen to step down as DPP chairman to assume responsibility for the election flop.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER WORKER AT MILITARY-FUNDED LABORATORY FOUND GUILTY OF SPYING

TEXT.P: A former technician of the military-funded Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology (CIST) was sentenced to 10 years in prison by the Taiwan High Court Friday for leaking classified defense information.

Huang's former wife Chen Chu-cheng, who confessed during the trial to carrying secret information for Huang to Huang's mainland Chinese contact, was given a 15-month sentence, suspended for three years.
Huang, who had worked at CIST for 28 years until his arrest in 2003, was accused of trying to sell secrets relating to the country's "smart bombs" to Beijing in return for US$2 million in 2001.
He was reportedly trying to seek mainland investment in producing these bombs on the mainland for export to Egypt.

In order to convince his potential mainland partners that he had the technology to manufacture the bombs, Huang passed information about some weapons developed by the CIST for the armed forces through his former wife.
Another woman, Lin Wei, who was accused of seeking mainland investors for Huang, was sentenced to seven months, suspended for three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM OFFERS FREE 5-MINUTE CALLS TO 5 TSUNAMI-HIT NATIONS

TEXT.P: Chunghwa Telecom will provide one free five-minute call per person per day to five tsunami-hit Asian countries from Jan. 1-7, company officials said Friday.

From Jan 1-7, clients making international calls with the 019 prefix to Thailand, Indonesia, India, Sri Lanka and the Maldives will not be charged for the first five minutes of their first call for that day, they said.

In addition, from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Jan. 1-2, Chunghwa Telecom will provide five-minute free call services at its service centers in Taipei, Taoyuan, Yunlin and Kaohsiung, where many of the foreign workers live, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 HOPEFULS BIDDING FOR TSU CHAIRMANSHIP

TEXT.P: Three candidates have put themselves forward to bid for the chairmanship of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , as registration for a by-election for the party chairmanship entered the last day of its four-day registration period Friday.

The by-election became necessary after Huang Chu-wen stepped down to take responsibility for the party's worse-than-expected performance in the Dec. 11 legislative elections. The TSU garnered only 12 legislative seats, one less than in the previous elections.

Acting TSU Chairman Huang Tzung-yuan, who has advocated that there should be only one candidate for the by-election, said he has done his best to communicate with the other hopefuls and expressed regret that three people have insisted on running.
The three hopefuls are Su Chin-chiang, secretary-general of the National Cultural Association, TSU Legislator Lo Chih-ming and at-large Legislator Kuo Lin-yung.
Huang, who accompanied Su to solicit the support of the party's central executive members, noted that Su is the favorite of former President Lee Teng-hui, the party's so-called "spiritual leader."
Huang said that after Lee returns from his sightseeing trip in Japan, he will take care of the matter. "It doesn't matter if it ends up with a popular vote," he said.
For his part, Su said it is only normal in a democratic political party to have competitors and that he will "play by the rules."
Lo said in a press release that after the disappointing Dec. 11 legislative elections, the party is in low spirits and in dire need to find its way.

"Serving the party is the responsibility of every member, " Lo said, adding that he has already written four articles on the direction and development of the party after the legislative elections and that his participation in the by-election will be best way for him to realize his goals.

Lo noted that Lee has never suggested who should be the next chairman and that if clearly shows support to a particular candidate after he returns from Japan, then he will withdraw from the by-election.
On the other hand, Kuo said that a new legislative electoral system will be established in the next Legislative Yuan and that the next three years will be crucial to the development of the TSU.

If the party wants to follow through its goals of "rectifying" the name of the nation and writing a new constitution, it will have to establish a democratic mechanism, which is why he wants to take part in the race, Kuo said.
According to the TSU party charter, if more than one person is participating in an election, there must be a popular election, which has been set for Jan. 22.
The TSU estimates that it has around 8,000 members.

DOC.HEADLINE: 58% WANT REFERENDUM AS HEDGE AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW: POLL

TEXT.P: More than half of local people responding to a recent opinion survey support a proposal to hold a defensive referendum to protect Taiwan's sovereignty in the face of Beijing's so-called anti-secession legislation, a private think tank said Friday.

The Taiwan Thinktank conducted a telephone poll of 1,070 randomly chosen adult residents around the island from Dec. 28-29 to explore their views about the mainland's plan to enact an anti-secession law targeting Taiwan next year.
The survey results show that 52 percent of the respondents were aware of Beijing's so-called anti-secession legislation plan, compared to 47 percent who said they had not heard of such a plan.
Nearly 80 percent said they think the anti-secession law will give Beijing an excuse to invade Taiwan in the future and will facilitate its attempt to drive a wedge into the Taiwan people.
To cope with Beijing's plan, 58 percent said Taiwan should hold a defensive referendum to protect Taiwan's sovereign status, but 27 percent said they were opposed to such a proposal.
Under Taiwan's referendum law, the president can call a national referendum when the nation's sovereignty is threatened.
While 53 percent said the United States should dissuade Beijing from going ahead with its plan, 22 percent said they do not think the United States should do so.

According to the survey results, 53 percent said they believe Beijing's anti-secession legislation will hinder a resumption of cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue, 48 percent said the legislation will affect Taiwan's democratic development, 70 percent said the legislation could further suppress Taiwan's diplomatic space and 64 percent said the legislation will heighten cross-strait tension.
Up to 88 percent said the major domestic political parties should stop their bickering or war of attrition and work together to address the mainland's ever-intensifying threat to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Many Still in Need as Aid Is Trickling to Stricken Area.
The injured and the stranded awaited food drops and other aid as the death toll surged past 120, 000.
The Wall Stree Journal: Death Toll Rises to 120,000.
The tsunami death toll rose to nearly 120,000, and Indonesia said its toll alone could reach 100,000. Annan said governments have pledged $500 million in aid.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER KEEPS LID ON FUTURE PLANS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun, who is expected to lead his Cabinet to resign Feb. 1 when the new legislature is sworn in, declined to reveal his future plans Friday while visiting the southern city of Kaohsiung.

Instead of talking about his own future, the premier expressed hope that the Executive Yuan's request for NT$500 billion (about US$15.6 billion) over five years for the "10 Major Construction Projects" program will be approved by the Legislative Yuan.
Yu said the program will help keep next year's economic growth rate at the same 6 percent as this year, while driving down unemployment from 4.14 percent this year to under 4 percent next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT MEETS WITH JAPANESE MENTOR
DOC.DATELINE: Kyoto, Japan, Dec. 31 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui met with his Japanese mentor Sukekata Kashiwa Friday, one of the main purposes of his current seven-day sightseeing trip to Japan.
Kashiwas, 98, was Lee's professor when Lee studied at the agroeconomics department of Kyoto University in the early 1940s, when Taiwan was still a Japanese colony.
It was their first reunion in nearly 60 years as they had lost contact for decades and did not get in touch against until three years ago with the assistance of Lee's Japanese friends.

Over the past three years, Lee has sent seasonal gifts to his mentor and although he desired to meet his mentor in person, the Japanese government previously would not grant him a visa for fear of offending Beijing.

Both Lee, 81, and Kashiwas said they were extremely happy to be able to meet again. They drank tea and chatted at Kashiwa's home. Kashiwa said he had also prepared 29 books to be presented to Lee as gifts.
Earlier in the day, Lee was denied entry to Kyoto University. He was turned away at the door on the grounds that his police escorts were barred from entering the campus under a university law.

Japanese medical community sources who helped arrange Lee's current trip said the Beijing government has pressured the Japanese authorities and Kyoto University not to allow Lee to visit his alma mater.
As a result, 10 Kyoto University professors and doctors had to meet with Lee at a restaurant in downtown Kyoto, Japan's ancient capital.

Lee told Taiwan reporters that he did not feel regret over his inability to enter the campus of his alma mater. "I only feel that my alma mater became very strange to me, " he said calmly while visiting Ginkakuji Temple that afternoon.
Lee said his trip has helped him come to a better understanding of the Japanese way of thinking. He said Japan is an advanced and orderly country from which Taiwan can learn much.
Lee, accompanied by his wife and other family members, arrived in Nagoya Monday to start his trip.
Even though his visit is private in nature, it still drew loud protests from mainland China.

Lee riled Beijing during his 12 years in office from 1988-2000 when he campaigned to raise Taiwan's international profile. He redefined the island's ties with the mainland in 1999 as a "special state-to-state" relationship, causing Beijing to break off fence-mending talks which remain suspended to this day.
Japanese officials said Lee is visiting as a private citizen and as such, had no basis for turning down his visa application.
Lee last traveled to Japan in April 2001, when he had treatment for a heart condition. He will conclude his current visit and return to Taiwan Jan. 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S CHIEF AIDE ALMOST SURE TO BE ELECTED DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Su Tseng-chang, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, is almost certain to be elected chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) after becoming the only candidate to register for the position by the time registration closed Friday.
Although Su will run unopposed, the DPP headquarters is nevertheless mulling whether to line up a forum in which Su will air his vision for the party and field questions from a group of scholars.

While entering his name as a candidate, Su has already outlined his goals of making DPP a platform where different political views may be exchanged and a forum where public policies may be formed through discussion, a cradle where future leaders of the country will be groomed, and the ultimate leader of all social groups.

A vote by all DPP members has been scheduled for Jan. 30. A DPP official has estimated that it will cost the party about NT$7.5 million to send vote notices to DPP members, print ballots and open at least 80 election stations around the island.

The winner of the election, to be announced Feb. 1, will fill in the vacancy left by Chen Shui-bian who resigned as DPP chairman to take responsibility for the party's lackluster performance in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN TOUTS TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's movement from fifth place to fourth in the 2004 Global Growth Competitiveness Ranking compiled by the Geneva-based World Economic Forum has proved the country's marvelous economic performance over the past year, the Executive Yuan said in a press release Friday.

In an apparent rebuttal of a local newspaper's report that the Executive Yuan's performance dipped to a 10-year nadir in 2004, the press release said the sharpening of Taiwan's competitiveness is a loud and clear confirmation of the improvement of the country's overall economic environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JAN. 1 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, Jan. 1:
06: 25, The 2005 new year day's national flag-raising ceremony will be held at the plaza in front of the Presidential Office.
06:50, A new year's day run organized by the Chinese Taipei Road Running Association will start at the cross between Ketagalan Avenue and Park Road in Taipei.
09:00, President Chen Shui-bian will attend the ceremony marking the founding anniversary of the Republic of China at the Presidential Office.
09:30, Vice President Annette Lu will attend a ceremony to launch a campaign for healthy life at the Taipei Railway Station.
09: 30, The Executive Yuan will hold a rally at its headquarters to mark New Year's Day.
11: 00, Chunghwa Telecom will hold a news conference to announce its offer of free phone calls to tsunami-hit countries at No. 27, Changchun Rd., Taipei.
14:10, Vice President Annette Lu will attend a ceremony to launch a campaign for healthy life at the National Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts in Taichung City.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN DELEGATION TO VISIT U.S.

TEXT.P: A Legislative Yuan delegation will visit the United States in early January, a co-convener of the legislative branch's Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee said Friday.

Sun Kuo-hwa of the opposition Kuomintang said that the delegation will leave Jan. 5 for New York and Washington, D.C., where the lawmakers will meet their U.S. counterparts, government officials and think tank scholars to exchange opinions on Taiwan's situation in the wake of the Dec. 11 legislative elections, Beijing's plan to establish an anti-secession law and other matters of mutual concern.
The delegation will also inspect Taiwan's overseas missions in the two cities and visit overseas Chinese communities there, he went on.
However, he said, the final itinerary of the visit is pending full arrangements by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
